headline: U.S. Appeals Court Rejects Fifth Attempt to Move Boston Marathon Bombing Trial
text: BOSTON — A divided federal appeals court has rejected a motion by Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, accused in the Boston Marathon bombing, to move his trial out of the city, paving the way for opening statements in the case to begin Wednesday.

headline: Golf’s Spring Training Comes With Balls, Gloves and Cleats, but No Batting Cage
text: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — A few minutes from the spring training home of the Miami Marlins and the St. Louis Cardinals, several of the best players in the world have spent this week honing their swings. They have worked on moving the ball in different directions and set different goals for each day.

headline: Mexico Moves to Save Endangered Porpoise
text: MEXICO CITY — The Mexican government is making a final effort to save the vaquita, a tiny porpoise that has been driven to the edge of extinction as a result of illegal fishing for another endangered species that is served as a delicacy in China.

headline: At St. John’s, a Heralded Class Still Seeks a Capstone
text: They arrived four years ago, a small army of prize recruits that was supposedly Coach Steve Lavin’s message to the college basketball establishment that St. John’s was back, and perhaps soon to be better than ever.

headline: Germans at the Crux of Crises, but Reluctantly
text: BERLIN — Germany has become Europe’s indispensable nation, at the center of crises over Ukraine and Greece. But a country uncomfortable with leadership, often labeled a reluctant hegemon, has had a rocky month.

headline: G.O.P. Race Starts in Lavish Haunts of Rich Donors
text: PALM BEACH, Fla. — Instead of the corn dogs and pork chops on a stick ritually served up on the hustings of Iowa, the latest stop on the donor trail featured meals of diver scallops and chocolate mousse. The setting was the Breakers, a sprawling Italian Renaissance-inspired hotel here, where the cheapest available rooms fetched $800 a night. And for the half-dozen Republican presidential candidates invited to the annual winter meeting this weekend of the Club for Growth, an influential bloc of deep-pocketed conservatives, the prize was not votes. It was money.

headline: Tupperware’s Sweet Spot Shifts to Indonesia
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The party had the feel of 1960s America, almost. A group of women, thrilled to get a break from the daily routine of hanging laundry and shuttling their children to and from school, sat in a circle, listening to a friend hawk plastic storage bowls in a dizzying array of pastels.

headline: In Tributes, Knicks Remember Anthony Mason
text: There was a somber undercurrent before the Knicks’ game against the Toronto Raptors on Saturday night as the organization paid tribute to Anthony Mason, a former player who died early Saturday after suffering congestive heart failure just over three weeks ago.

headline: What to Expect on the Fifth Day of Milan Fashion Week
text: Marni celebrated its 20th anniversary last year, with its September show as a marker of the occasion — though not, Consuelo Castiglioni said at the time, a retrospective. That would be backward-looking, and Marni is still moving forward.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
text: 10 P.M. (CBS) BATTLE CREEK Two mismatched law-enforcement officers — Russ Agnew (Dean Winters), an old-school detective who dislikes anything new, and Milt Chamberlain (Josh Duhamel, above right with Mr. Winters), a debonair F.B.I. agent assigned to set up a high-tech satellite office — are forced to work together as partners in a dilapidated Michigan city best known for Kellogg’s cereal. This new series “lies somewhere between a lighthearted procedural and a black-lined comedy,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. A collaboration between Vince Gilligan, who created AMC’s “Breaking Bad,” and David Shore, who came up with Fox’s “House” — and with reminders of both shows — it’s “a mixing of rare breeds that works,” she added.

headline: South Korean President Urges Japan to Admit Past Wrongs
text: SEOUL, South Korea — President Park Geun-hye of South Korea urged Japan on Sunday to have the “courage and honesty” to admit to its historical wrongdoings against Koreans and other Asians, including its enslavement of Korean women in military brothels during World War II.

headline: Bouncing to the Beat of Kaboom
text: Rich and Dee Gibson have found a familiar comfort in an unlikely place: under a mushroom cloud amid flames and explosions. For the past 30 years, the couple has made a living going around the world blowing up things — creating mesmerizing spectacles at air shows.

headline: 1915: Americans Are Glad French, Not British, Warship Captures Dacia
text: NEW YORK — The seizure of the Dacia by a French warship causes satisfaction here. Commenting on the capture of this vessel, the NEW YORK HERALD says: ‘‘Because of the rigidity of French law it was always expected that the seizure would be made by the French navy. It is regarded as fortunate to have a French test case, since there are no issues between France and the United States, while there are issues between Great Britain and the United States. Germany misses an opportunity of twisting the Lion’s tail over this incident.’’ The feeling among the public is that this is the only satisfactory outcome possible of the Dacia case, in view of the extremely friendly feelings which exist between this country and France. On every side I hear admiration expressed of the extreme wisdom shown by the French nation in resisting the temptation to imitate Germany and some of the neutrals in sending propagandists here to meddle in American international affairs, since the public sentiment here is still fighting capably for the Allies. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 2, 1915

headline: Documentary on Air Pollution Grips China
text: Millions of Chinese, riveted and outraged, watched a 104-minute documentary video over the weekend that begins with a slight woman in jeans and a white blouse walking on to a stage dimly lit in blue. As an audience looks on somberly, the woman, Chai Jing, displays a graph of brown-red peaks with occasional troughs.

headline: 1965: Montreal Explosion Kills 28
text: MONTREAL — At least 28 people were killed today [Mar. 1] and more than 50 injured in a breakfast-hour explosion and fire in a suburban block of apartment buildings. Schoolchildren, whose books and satchels were found among debris, were preparing to leave for school when the explosion rocked the apartment building in the Montreal suburb of La Salle at 8:15 a.m. Wind quickly spread the fire from the blast to three adjacent apartment buildings, police said. Two hours later, the fire department declared the fires were under control and the search for victims began. About 100 people were missing, a police official said, as he announced the death toll in the building where the explosion occurred. It housed about 10 families. There were none dead in the adjacent buildings. The middle section of the three-story, U-shaped complex, containing at least 12 apartments was flattened. Two wings of it were heavily damaged by fire from the explosion. Rescue workers — guided by screams and moans — dug into the debris trying to reach an undetermined number who were trapped when the building collapsed with a ‘‘big boom,’’ according to witnesses. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 2, 1965

His true age was never entirely clear, but by an account in his autobiography, he would have been 89 when he died.

headline: Icy Stillness and Muted Fishing in a New England Port
text: NEW BEDFORD, Mass. — Mark Abraham, who has fished the New England coast for decades, kept a sharp eye on his catch as the slimy haddock spilled onto a dockside conveyor belt. He had just returned from 10 frigid days at sea, among the most brutal he has spent.

headline: ‘Focus’ Takes Top Box-Office Spot
text: Will Smith will have to wait for another movie to vanquish concerns about his popularity among moviegoers. Terrible weather across the United States contributed to weak multiplex turnout over the weekend, with ticket sales down 14 percent compared with the same period last year, according to Rentrak, which compiles box-office data. In his first major role since the 2013 bomb “After Earth,” Mr. Smith helped “Focus” collect roughly $19.1 million in North American ticket sales, easily enough for first place but a bit less than most analysts had expected.

headline: Milan Remembers John Fairchild
text: MILAN — For an industry in the unbreakable slipstream of fashion shows, news of John Fairchild’s death broke slowly. Mr. Fairchild died during fashion week, a fact he might have liked, or at least deemed appropriate. So while the fact was spreading on social media Friday morning New York time, it was late afternoon in Milan, and most of the editors — including Mr. Fairchild’s successors at Women’s Wear Daily — were watching Alessandra Facchinetti’s collection for Tod’s.

headline: Samsung Galaxy S6 and Galaxy S6 Edge, Unveiled at Mobile World Congress, Offer Best of iPhone and More

In the case of its new flagship Galaxy S phones, announced Sunday at the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, Spain, Samsung has created phones that unquestionably borrow on the most appealing elements of the iPhone. But they also stand out with their own impressive design twists.

Her difficulty in walking she ascribed to two lower-back fractures that may be treatable.

headline: Review: ‘John & Jen,’ a Revival Starring Kate Baldwin and Conor Ryan
text: Growing up isn’t easy. Just take a look at Richard Linklater’s “Boyhood” if you need reminding. But imagine how difficult it must be to do so — and I mean the hard part, from early childhood to the end of adolescence — in less than two hours, and in song, and in front of a live audience.

headline: Review: ‘Comfort Dogs’ Explores the Solace of Communing With Canines
text: The performers in the playwright and director William Burke’s “Comfort Dogs: Live From the Pink House” are unusually brazen. They will sniff your hand, nuzzle your thigh, leap into your lap. Some of these actors are dogs. Some are people playing dogs. All are pretty cute.

headline: Review: ‘Tap Lab,’ From the Bang Group, Conveys Musical Scores Through Footwork
text: If tap dancing is music as well as dance, then why not use tap to play musical scores? Such was the plausible idea behind “Tap Lab,” the Bang Group’s contribution to the Harkness Dance Festival. At the 92nd Street Y on Saturday, the company, led by David Parker, attempted to realize scores by Mozart, Morton Feldman and Steve Reich with foot and body percussion. “Tab Lab” was an accurate title for a collection of dogged exercises and weak experiments. Rather than metal on wood or skin on skin, the dominant sound was a kind of silence: the absence of inspiration.

headline: Review: In Olen Steinhauer’s ‘All the Old Knives,’ Exes Recall Love and Blood
text: The inspiration for “All the Old Knives,” Olen Steinhauer’s unusually short and wily spy novel, was a television adaptation of a poem. As he watched Alan Rickman and Emma Thompson in the 2010 British dramatization of the Christopher Reid poem “The Song of Lunch,” Mr. Steinhauer was excited by its structure. The poem describes two lovers meeting for a meal long after the end of their affair, and it is essentially confined to a restaurant. Could a good spy novel be written if an author played by those same rules?

headline: Juilliard and the Manhattan School of Music Play Strauss’s ‘Ein Heldenleben’
text: “Ein Heldenleben” (“A Hero’s Life”), Richard Strauss’s grandiose paean to himself, which makes huge demands on a symphony orchestra, does not leap to mind as grist for a student performance. Yet there it was last week, twice, performed by students of the Juilliard School and the Manhattan School of Music. The Juilliard Orchestra played it on Tuesday at Carnegie Hall, led by the veteran maestro David Zinman, and the M.S.M. Symphony performed it on Thursday at the Manhattan School, conducted by George Manahan, the school’s director of orchestral activities.

headline: ‘Fault in Our Stars’ Team to Adapt Another Novel
text: John Green’s debut novel, “Looking for Alaska,” is coming to the big screen, and the screenwriters Scott Neustadter and Michael H. Weber have signed on to write the adaptation. The screenwriting pair previously worked with Mr. Green on the box office hit “The Fault in Our Stars,” as well as Mr. Green’s 2008 novel, “Paper Towns,” to be released in theaters this summer. “Looking for Alaska” won the Michael L. Printz Award, and depicts a teenage boarding school romance gone awry. The novel currently sits at No. 4 on The New York Times Young Adult Best Sellers list. (“The Fault in Our Stars” still holds the top spot.) Mr. Neustadter and Mr. Weber previously teamed up to write “The Spectacular Now” and “(500) Days of Summer.” They are also involved in adapting another best-selling novel, “Where’d You Go, Bernadette,” which Richard Linklater has been tapped to direct.

headline: Nick Offerman Joins ‘Confederacy of Dunces’
text: It’s not quite The Cones of Dunshire, but it’s close. This November, the “Parks and Recreation” alumnus Nick Offerman will star in the world premiere production of “A Confederacy of Dunces” with the Huntington Theater Company in Boston. The play is being adapted by Jeffrey Hatcher (“Stage Beauty”) from the beloved 1980 novel of the same name by John Kennedy Toole. Alan Friedman called the novel a “masterwork of comedy” in his review for The New York Times Book Review. Mr. Toole was awarded the 1981 Pulitzer Prize for the novel posthumously; he committed suicide in 1969. Many efforts have been made to adapt the novel. John Belushi, Will Ferrell and Jack Black were among those attached to various film projects that never fully developed. Mr. Offerman will be the first lead in the role, and will move from one outlandish egotist (on “Parks”) to another. “I am simply tumescent at the prospect of assaying the beloved character of Ignatius J. Reilly with our team of magnificent and weird artistic champions,” Mr. Offerman said in a statement. “It seems only fitting that I should follow seven seasons of Ron Swanson’s beef with the pudding of Toole’s corpulent fop.” David Esbjornson will direct. Performances are scheduled to run Nov. 11 through Dec. 13.

headline: Cumming and Hall to Play Café Carlyle
text: Alan Cumming isn’t done with New York just yet. After wrapping up his return to his Tony-winning role as the M.C. in “Cabaret” in March, Mr. Cumming will make his debut at the Café Carlyle for a two-week stint from June 2 to 13. The program is “Alan Cumming Sings Sappy Songs,” and will also feature the Emmy-winning musical director Lance Horne and the cellist Eleanor Norton. The Carlyle will welcome another Broadway star for its spring season: Lena Hall, fresh after starring as Yitzhak in “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” which won the 2014 Tony Award for best musical revival. Ms. Hall will be performing April 7 to 18. Other performers announced include John Pizzarelli (April 21 to May 2) and Judy Collins (May 5 to 16).

headline: The National Museum of Iraq Reopens
text: In response to the destruction of ancient artifacts by militants in northern Iraq, Iraq’s National Museum, in Baghdad, has officially reopened for the first time in 12 years. The museum suffered great losses after the American invasion in 2003 — it was one of the many sites that fell prey to rampant looting during the war. Some 15,000 pieces, including ancient statues, sculptures and cuneiform tablets, were pillaged. But museum officials announced the recovery of hundreds of items in 2010, and now report that one-third of the missing items are back in the collection. Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi was on hand for the ceremonies and condemned the Islamic State, which posted videos of militants taking sledgehammers to statues and reliefs in the Mosul Museum in northern Iraq. “Those barbaric, criminal terrorists are trying to destroy the heritage of mankind and Iraq’s civilization,” Mr. al-Abadi said, according to the BBC.

headline: Speech by Netanyahu Opens Political Divisions in Israel, Too
text: JERUSALEM — At Jerusalem’s bustling Mahane Yehuda market, a traditional bastion of support for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s conservative Likud Party, Israeli divisions played out among the fruit and vegetable stalls on Sunday as Mr. Netanyahu departed for Washington with plans to deliver a contentious speech on the Iranian nuclear threat before a joint meeting of Congress.

headline: Xi Jinping’s ‘Four Comprehensives’ Give Shape to a Crowded Agenda
text: Slogans studded with numerals and abstract exhortations are central to the dramaturgy of the Chinese Communist Party, intoned like spells to exalt leaders, cajole citizens and malign enemies. Yet as President Xi Jinping’s latest contribution shows, the magic of a party slogan often works through its supple vagueness.

headline: Radio Station Identification
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — The nice thing about Monday puzzles is that you can depend upon them to make you feel smart, especially if you have already tumbled to the “crossword solver’s way of thinking.” A good Monday puzzle should feel like a break in the proceedings, a smooth solve that restores your faith in your abilities after the weekend battles with the constructors and Will Shortz. If you’re very lucky, the puzzle will be entertaining as well, enough so as to bring out a smile on your face.

headline: Towns Made for Burning
text: “I never saw so much destruction before,” Charles Wright Wills of the 103rd Illinois Infantry wrote in his diary on Feb. 7, 1865. This was no idle hyperbole. Wills had been at war for nearly four years, moving through the ranks from private to major. He’d seen hard fighting throughout the Atlanta Campaign, and plenty of devastation along the March to the Sea. But now he was in South Carolina, and the entire tenor of the March had changed.

headline: To Questions, Alex Rodriguez Has but One Real Reply

headline: 10 Questions for Senator Orrin Hatch
text: When Republicans recaptured the Senate last fall, Orrin G. Hatch of Utah became chairman of the Finance Committee overseeing the federal tax code. As the chamber’s longest-serving Republican, Mr. Hatch, 80, is also Senate president pro tempore — third in the line of presidential succession after the vice president and the speaker of the House.

headline: Netanyahu’s Visit Bringing Uninvited Problems for Jewish Democrats
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner’s unilateral invitation to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to address Congress on Tuesday has turned a foreign policy issue that has had near unanimous support in both parties — Israel — into a bruising political showdown.

headline: Anthony R. Cucci, Combative Jersey City Mayor, Dies at 92
text: Anthony R. Cucci, whose term as mayor of Jersey City was rife with the bitterness of local politics and colored with sidelights both tragic and comic, died on Thursday in Jersey City. He was 92.

headline: Syria: 19 Christians Have Been Released by the Islamic State, Local Leaders Say
text: Nineteen of the Assyrian Christians seized by Islamic State militants last week in northeastern Syria have been freed, and they met with church officials in a cathedral in the city of Hasaka, local leaders said Sunday. Three of those freed were women, and according to videos and photographs, some appeared to be elderly men. Dawoud Dawoud, an official with the Assyrian Democratic Organization, said that Islamic State fighters were reported to be looting some of the villages they seized along the Khabur River, where many of the hostages were captured. Scores of the captives remain unaccounted for, though Sunni Arab local leaders have been mediating between Assyrian Christian leaders and Islamic State militants to free the rest, officials said. Meanwhile, the United States-led coalition against the Islamic State bombed targets near Hasaka for the third day in a row, according to Central Command. The strikes suggested a stepped-up operation in response to the advance by Islamic State militants that drove more than 1,000 of the Assyrian Christians, a minority in Syria, from their homes.

headline: Algeria: Violence Erupts at Protest Over Shale Gas Drilling Project
text: Protests against hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, for shale gas in southern Algeria turned violent over the weekend when the police clashed with demonstrators outside a base run by the American company Halliburton near the town of Ain Salah. Tensions were still running high on Sunday, but no further violence was reported. Antifracking protests against the government oil and gas company Sonatrach and its international partners have occurred almost daily for two months, but had been peaceful until now. Clashes broke out when protesters approached Halliburton’s walled compound and burned tires in the roads. The police fired tear gas and detained at least a dozen. About 20 protesters were injured, three of them seriously, according to a local hospital. Algeria, which gets much of its revenue from the export of oil and gas, has been conducting a pilot project to test for shale gas near Ain Salah and announced in December that it was ready to start extracting gas by hydraulic fracturing. Groups that oppose the government have joined the local protesters in Ain Salah to demand a moratorium on fracking, citing environmental concerns.

headline: In Los Angeles, Stadiums Battle Heats Up
text: For years, the N.F.L. played cat and mouse with the city of Los Angeles. Every so often a team in, say, Minnesota, would threaten to move to L.A. in an effort to crowbar concessions out of its government leaders back home. Once the team got public financing, it stayed put.

headline: Colorado Yogis Balk at State Regulation of Teacher Training
text: DENVER — It was evening at one of this city’s most popular yoga centers, and teacher training was about to begin. Students wore flowing genie pants. Votive candles lit a classroom. Annie Prasad Freedom, the studio’s founder, greeted arriving yogis.

headline: Marina Abramovic to Publish a Memoir in 2016

She’s stretched out naked on the floor under a model skeleton in one piece of performance art, shivered nude on a block of ice in another, and lived on a platform for 12 days in a Chelsea gallery, where visitors watched her bathe, sleep and go to the bathroom.

headline: 2=Jeter, 3=Ruth, 4=Gehrig. ... In the Bronx, Numbers Are Finite.
text: TAMPA, Fla. — When Garrett Jones was traded to the Yankees in December, he was hoping to bring with him his good-luck charm of a number, 46. When the Yankees acquired shortstop Brendan Ryan, he knew he would be denied his favorite childhood number, 7. And when Jacoby Ellsbury signed a free-agent contract with the Yankees, he realized that even though the team was giving him $153 million, the Yankees would not give him a jersey with 2 on the back.

headline: The Strange Urge to Raise Rates

headline: What’s On TV Monday
text: 8 P.M. (El Rey) EL REY NETWORK PRESENTS: THE DIRECTOR’S CHAIR The El Rey network founder Robert Rodriguez interviews Francis Ford Coppola about his inspiration, his reluctance to direct both “The Godfather” (starring Marlon Brando, above) and “The Godfather: Part II,” and his struggles with “Apocalypse Now.” The talk is followed at 9 by “The Conversation” (1974), starring Gene Hackman as Harry Caul, a surveillance expert who has been hired to eavesdrop on a married woman (Cindy Williams) and her lover (Frederic Forrest) by her husband, known as the Director (Robert Duvall). But three people have died because of Harry’s work, and now he’s worried that two more may soon die. The film received three Oscar nominations but lost for best picture to “The Godfather: Part II.” Writing in The New York Times, Vincent Canby called “The Conversation” haunting and bothersome: “Haunting because its suggestion that technology has gotten out of hand, though not exactly new, is so convincingly and fastidiously detailed. It’s bothersome because Mr. Coppola, the writer as well as the director, has nearly succeeded in making a great film but has, instead, made one that is merely very good.”

headline: Walmart’s Visible Hand
text: A few days ago Walmart, America’s largest employer, announced that it will raise wages for half a million workers. For many of those workers the gains will be small, but the announcement is nonetheless a very big deal, for two reasons. First, there will be spillovers: Walmart is so big that its action will probably lead to raises for millions of workers employed by other companies. Second, and arguably far more important, is what Walmart’s move tells us — namely, that low wages are a political choice, and we can and should choose differently.

headline: ‘Please Stop Helping Us’ and ‘Shame’
text: One of the few things conservatives and liberals agree on about the ’60s is that it was a decade of radical change in the nation’s politics, ethnoracial and gender relations, popular culture and international policies. For liberals, the decade marked the nation’s greatest transition toward a new era of personal, socioeconomic and political liberation and inclusion, especially for blacks, initiated by the courts, the civil and voting rights acts and the Great Society programs. To most conservatives, the period, with few exceptions, was a terrible turn for the worse. And for African-­American conservatives like ­Jason L. ­Riley and Shelby Steele, beyond the ending of formal discrimination in voting, education and civil rights, the era was for black Americans an unmitigated disaster, the consequences of which persist to this day.

headline: The Slippery Slope of Disinflation
text: Arguments for tight money often rest on claims that inflation, even at low rates, is a slippery slope: say that 2 percent is OK, then people will make the case for 4, then 10, and before you know it we’re Weimar. It’s not clear whether that has ever really happened: actually existing Weimar, like all hyperinflations, was a byproduct of political chaos, and the 1970s had as much to do with oil shocks as with policy misjudgments. In any case, it’s certainly nothing we’ve seen in advanced countries for a long time.

headline: 1940: Roosevelts in Divorce Court
text: LOS ANGELES — After meeting Romelle Schneider, a nurse at the Mayo Clinic where he was treated last summer, James Roosevelt twice asked his wife for a divorce, Mrs. Roosevelt testified in divorce court here today [March 2]. Both times, Mrs. Roosevelt, born Betty Cushing, refused to give her husband, the President’s oldest son, a divorce, she said. On February 15 he filed a suit for separation, charging his wife with desertion. Mrs. Roosevelt filed a cross-suit in which she asked for a settlement of $50,000, which would be paid immediately, and an additional $25,000 annually until she dies or re-marries or her husband dies. She is also asking the custody of their two daughters. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 3, 1940

headline: Senator Barbara Mikulski, Maryland Democrat and Role Model, to Retire in 2017
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, the animated and occasionally irascible Democrat from Maryland who rose from being a community organizer to become the longest-serving woman in Congress, announced Monday that she would retire when her term ends in 2017.

headline: Rev. Malcolm Boyd, an Author, Activist and Counterculture Rebel, Dies at 91
text: The Rev. Malcolm Boyd, an Episcopal priest and author who challenged racism, war and religious complacency in the 1960s and ’70s, and was one of the first prominent clergymen in America to acknowledge his homosexuality publicly, died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 91.

headline: Los Angeles Philharmonic Chief Heads to Harvard
text: Deborah Borda is going from Walt Disney Concert Hall and the Hollywood Bowl to Harvard.

headline: Philadelphia Fed Picks Patrick Harker, University of Delaware President, to Lead It
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said Monday that it had named as its new president Patrick Harker, president of the University of Delaware.

headline: The Unknown Notebooks of Jean-Michel Basquiat
text: Graffitist, painter, actor poet: The late artist’s rarely seen personal writings and sketches are expressions of 1980s downtown New York, and, perhaps, of his truest vision.

headline: Removing an Artist’s Lifework
text: After 40 years in the diamond district of Manhattan, the Ney family is being evicted on March 19. Joel Ney is rushing to move about 4,000 pieces of his father’s artwork from the premises.

headline: 15 Pieces of Art Snatched From Fontainebleau
text: PARIS — French investigators are searching for 15 gold and bronze artworks stolen from the Château de Fontainebleau in an early morning break-in on Sunday. The target was a crown that once belonged to the king of Siam.

headline: In Eviction From Diamond District, Losing Much More Than Home
text: The small room is cluttered with paintings and sculptures — some colorful, some stark, some fresh and pliant, some old and burned. Whatever their state, all appear to incandesce.

headline: Nature’s Fighter Jets With Flapping Wings
text: The goshawk, a powerful predatory bird that can take down prey like pheasants, rabbits and crows, is having a literary moment with “H Is for Hawk,” an award-winning memoir by Helen Macdonald that mixes a tale of personal loss with the struggle to train a goshawk to hunt.

headline: ScienceTake | Hawk Cam Captures the Hunt
text: Thanks to a helmet camera, researchers discovered that a goshawk mixes its methods of chasing its prey.

headline: Video Shows Los Angeles Police Shooting
text: Graphic video shows several police officers in Los Angeles struggling with a man suspected of robbery before one fatally shoots him.

headline: As Milan Week Ends, a Buzz Gap
text: MILAN — It has been an odd, unsatisfying season in Milan. Parties and celebrities were thin on the ground; the biggest trends to emerge have been Lurex and fur for the feet (really: sheared-mink shoes will be big come September). The ’80s are of interest to some. Rumors have swirled with no closure.

headline: Kerry’s Remarks to U.N. on Nuclear Talks
text: Secretary of State John Kerry discussed the Iranian nuclear talks, saying that Israel’s security is important, but “so is the security of all the other countries in the region.”

headline: Family Tradition in the Saddle
text: The Wright family of Utah has a long history of ranching and rodeoing and hopes a combination of the two can provide for future generations.

headline: Hedge Fund Suit Accusing U.S. of Misconduct Faces High Bar
text: When investigators arrive at the door of a hedge fund with a search warrant, the consequences can be devastating. Clients fear being linked to misconduct, and even a history of strong investment returns often cannot stem the tide of withdrawals if there is even a whiff of scandal.

headline: Jonas Kaufmann Cancels Wednesday’s ‘Carmen’ at the Met
text: It was one of the hottest opera tickets of the year. With Jonas Kaufmann, the star tenor, scheduled to sing only two performances this season at the Metropolitan Opera — and in one of the most popular operas in the repertoire, Bizet’s “Carmen” — both sold out fast.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Giorgio Armani Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: Netanyahu’s Remarks to Aipac
text: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel addressed the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, saying that in his speech to Congress he would speak up against Iran and its “tentacles of terror.”

headline: Gordon Dyal, Veteran Deal Maker at Goldman Sachs, to Retire
text: Gordon E. Dyal, a former head of Goldman Sachs’ mergers business and a veteran deal maker, is retiring, the firm announced in an internal memorandum on Monday.

headline: In France, Pesticides Get in Way of Natural Wines
text: TOURS, France — The task ahead of me was a two-day tasting marathon of wines with a welter of confusing labels: natural, organic, organic practice and biodynamic. But for Jean Bardet, a semiretired chef with two Michelin stars to his name, there was little confusion about the worthiness of such bottles.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Giorgio Armani Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: Nail Clipping
Gum Snapping
Gyora Benedek’s Hidato
text: Our puzzles this week are several Hidato and a numeric puzzle suggested by Gyora Benedek, the Israeli computer scientist and adventurer. We first met Dr. Benedek, who invented the Hidato puzzle, about a year ago (see post here), and it’s a pleasure to have him back.

headline: Nose Sniffling
The Brilliant Boris Nemtsov: A Reformer Who Never Backed Down
text: Eventually they’ll arrest someone for murdering Boris Nemtsov, especially after President Vladimir Putin was said to be giving the case his personal attention. The authorities have already begun to spin conspiracy theories, including the outrageous suggestion that he may have been killed by political allies to create a martyr. What will remain is not a murder case, but the image of the opposition politician who had once personified so many of Russia’s hopes, lying dead within sight of the Kremlin fortress and the whimsical cupolas of St. Basil’s Cathedral.

headline: Maggie Smith Says She Will Leave ‘Downton Abbey’ After Next Season
text: The Dowager Countess is done and there’s no use in trying to convince her otherwise. Maggie Smith, who plays the quip-ready matriarch on the hit British series that just finished its fifth season in the United States, said in an interview with The Sunday Times that she was done with the character following the upcoming season.

headline: Knuckle Cracking
Lawyer Put Health Act in Peril by Pointing Out 4 Little Words
text: WASHINGTON — The first lawsuits challenging the Affordable Care Act were still in the early stages, but conservative lawyers were already working on a backup plan in December 2010 if the first line of attack failed.

headline: For Richard Prince’s ‘Fashion’ Series, an Unlikely Exhibitor
text: All nine of the artist’s rephotographed advertisements will be shown together for the first time at Nahmad Contemporary.

headline: Clive Owen to Make Broadway Debut in Pinter’s ‘Old Times’
text: Clive Owen, an Oscar nominee for “Closer” who is now starring on the Cinemax series “The Knick,” will make his Broadway debut in the fall in a revival of Harold Pinter’s “Old Times,” Roundabout Theater Company announced on Monday.

headline: Games on a Reservation Go By in a Blur
text: FORT DEFIANCE, Ariz. — The Navajo teenagers scamper out of the locker room as if their feet are on fire.

headline: Stock Trading Platform IEX Hires Ex-N.Y.S.E. Regulatory Chief
text: IEX, the upstart stock-trading platform that rocketed to prominence last year after being featured in the Michael Lewis book “Flash Boys,” has hired a former New York Stock Exchange official as it seeks to become a full-fledged stock exchange.

headline: 1965: Jets Blast North Vietnam
text: DA NANG, South Vietnam — More than 160 U.S. and Vietnamese Air Force planes hammered two targets in North Vietnam today [March 2] in the biggest air strike to date against the Communists in the North. The massive raid — described as a resounding success — was the first that has been launched as a purely offensive action. All previous U.S. air strikes on the North have been in retaliation for specific Communist attacks in the South. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 3, 1965

headline: New Subway Etiquette Campaign: ‘Please Don’t Urinate in This Area’
text: On a mezzanine level at the West Fourth Street subway station, near a billboard for the New York Lottery and a door that says “Supervision Only,” transit workers have posted several paper signs.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 3 Episode 6 Recap: Shame On You, Mr. President
text: Season 3 Episode 6 Recap: Chapter 32

headline: After Net Neutrality Vote, Wheeler Turns to Salesmanship
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Tom Wheeler has gone from policeman to salesman.

headline: A Thin Line of Defense Against ‘Honor Killings’
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Faheema stood trembling in the courtyard of the large house, steeling herself for the meeting with her family.

headline: Lowering Diabetes Risk After Pregnancy
text: About nine percent of pregnant women have gestational diabetes, which usually goes away after they give birth. But about half these women will develop Type 2 diabetes later in life. A new study suggests two ways to significantly reduce the risk.

headline: It’s Tough to Be the King Every Night
text: It has been an incredible season for James Harden. The Houston Rockets guard is leading the N.B.A. in scoring, dominated the All-Star Game and has found himself in the conversation for the Most Valuable Player Award. But the Rockets made quite a statement Sunday after an overtime win over the Cleveland Cavaliers when their Twitter account declared Harden the new King James.

headline: The Tax Con Cometh
text: The Internal Revenue Service is not emailing you to request personal information. Not now. Not ever.

headline: Spring’s Lightweight Suits
text: Whether slim-cut or slightly slouchy, the new relaxed suiting features a construction that lets you cut loose, anywhere, anytime.

headline: Every Woman Who Has Served in the U.S. Senate
text: Of the 1,963 people who have served in the Senate, just 46 have been women, or about 2 percent. Senator Barbara Mikulski, a Democrat from Maryland who announced on Monday that she would not run for re-election, has served longer than any other female senator.

headline: Gulf of Mexico Turns Deadly for Dolphins
text: A scientific explanation has proved elusive, but evidence is building that the BP Deepwater Horizon oil spill has played a role in harming the mammals.

headline: Google Confirms Plans for Wireless Service
text: It’s official: Google wants to offer a wireless service, but not like just any other phone carrier.

headline: Bonnie Slotnick Finds a New Home
text: To Browse: Discovering a New Space to Find Old Recipes

headline: Goodie Bags Filled With Memories
text: A welcome in-room amenity like a bottle of Champagne or fruit plate is standard at many high-end hotels, but some properties are going beyond the expected greeting by also giving their guests a gift at checkout.

headline: Britain Had Wheat Before Farming, Study Says
text: DNA from an underwater site suggests that there was wheat in Britain 8,000 years ago — 2,000 years before farming arrived in the region.

headline: Good Thing Bumblebees Don’t Have Car Keys
text: Bumblebees can remember the patterns, colors and scents of different flowers, researchers have discovered. But memory can fail in the bumblebee, just as it does in humans.

headline: Why Schools Should Undermine Moral Teachings
text: The philosophy professor Justin P. McBrayer has lobbed up a fascinating question on the Opinionator blog:Are our schools not just failing to teach morals (something many parents would argue are best taught at home in any case), but actively undermining those teachings?

headline: Britain’s Elite Still Enjoying a Tax Break 100 Years Old
text: LONDON — They are among the British moneyed elite: the head of the nation’s largest bank, a billionaire hedge fund manager and the owner of some of London’s most luxurious nightclubs.

headline: Near or Far, Head South to Escape the Winter
text: We seem to be trapped in a winter of extremes — cold snaps, snowfall that feels fit for a Disney movie, droughts that have farmers almost looking at storms in the Northeast with envy. If you just want to run away from it all, you’re not alone. The Travel section has you covered, just in time for spring break.

headline: Disclosure Can Produce Meaningful Change
text: In a recent The Trade column, Jesse Eisinger of ProPublica criticizes Justice Louis Brandeis’s advice that “Sunlight is...the best of disinfectants” for social problems. He describes the reliance on transparency and disclosure as an ineffective “regulatory crutch,” saying that “if lawmakers want to end a bad practice, ban it. Having them admit it is not enough.”

headline: 3 Attica Guards Resign in Deal to Avoid Jail
text: Three guards accused of beating an inmate at the Attica Correctional Facility so severely that doctors had to insert a plate and six pins into his leg each pleaded guilty on Monday to a single misdemeanor charge of misconduct. The last-minute plea deal spared them any jail time in exchange for quitting their jobs.

headline: Bangladeshi Police Arrest Suspect in Blogger’s Killing
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Security officials arrested a suspect in the killing of a Bangladeshi-American blogger known for his antipathy toward religion, who was hacked to death in Dhaka, the capital, on Thursday.

headline: Hillary Clinton Aides Issue Talking Points on Rebutting Attacks
text: Aides to Hillary Rodham Clinton circulated a series of talking points to allies on Monday to help them respond to a spate of negative news accounts in recent weeks about the Bill, Hillary and Chelsea Clinton Foundation.

headline: 3 Israelis Are Charged on Suspicion of Supplying Materials to Hamas Militants
text: JERUSALEM — During Israel’s 50-day war against Hamas in Gaza last summer, residents of Israel’s border communities lived in fear of rocket or mortar attacks, or the possibility that Hamas militants could attack Israelis through tunnels.

headline: The Nuclear Talks With Iran, Explained
text: What the United States and Iran want out of discussions over Iran’s nuclear development.

headline: In Richard Prince's 'Fashion' Series, A Beautiful — and Prescient — Radicalism
text: The contemporary art market is “almost a fraud,” the billionaire art dealer David Nahmad famously said to the Independent on Sunday several years ago, following another interview in Forbes in which he called the work of artists like Jeff Koons and Richard Prince “luxury products.” Asked about his comments, another member of the prominent clan weighed in: “I don’t think Richard Prince decided to waste his life making trash, so to someone they’re worth something,” Helly Nahmad, of the eponymous London-based gallery, told the Financial Times in 2011. “What they’re worth is a different argument.”

headline: Soup Slurping
Ticket Resellers Asking High Prices for Final Grateful Dead Shows
text: The last time Chicago’s Soldier Field hosted a Grateful Dead show, there was no such thing as StubHub.

headline: 2 Killed in Latest Bombing to Strike Cairo
text: CAIRO — An explosion outside a central courthouse killed two people and injured at least nine others on Monday, extending a series of small bombings around Cairo. Security officials said most of those injured were policemen.

headline: Why Warren Buffett Is Worth $72 Billion and You’re Not
text: Consider these two truthful sentences:

headline: ‘My Friend Has a Son Who Is Autistic’
text: When I attend a school function to watch my 11-year-old, who has a language-based learning disability, I am content to stand solo. I love keeping an eye on him from a distance as he sings in a concert or runs around with his classmates.

headline: Tech Deals That Are Poor Fixes for Limp Sales
text: A $15 billion technology M.&A. spree is a poor fix for limp sales.

headline: Snip, Snap, Slurp: Misophonia Makes Them Unbearable
text: Popcorn munching? Gum chewing? Knuckle cracking? What sound most grates on your nerves?

headline: Questions to Ask a Prospective Financial Adviser
text: There’s a fight brewing in Washington. While fighting in Washington isn’t new, the cause of this particular fight might shock you. People are arguing about financial advice. Last week, the debate gained national attention as President Obama waded into the discussion.

headline: Five More Years for ‘Judge Judy’
text: LOS ANGELES – Judge Judith Sheindlin has signed on for five more televised years of sorting out rancorous rent disputes, adjudicating stranger-than-fiction dognapping cases and, as ever, zinging litigants as coming from a long line of idiots.

headline: India Begins Campaign to Eliminate Elephantiasis
text: India recently began one of the biggest drug-distribution campaigns in its history in an effort to eliminate “elephant’s foot disease,” also known as elephantiasis or lymphatic filariasis.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg Goes on Charm Offensive for Internet.org
text: BARCELONA, Spain — In front of a packed audience here, Mark Zuckerberg turned on the charm.

headline: A 125-Year-Old Textiles House Teams Up With a ’60s-Inspired Fashion Label
text: When Natasha Garnett profiled the 125-year-old textile company Schumacher for T’s Fall 2014 Women’s Fashion issue, she illustrated the brand’s historic and steadfast dedication to designer collaborations, helmed by its creative director Dara Caponigro. And its latest, a 13-piece capsule collection created with Lisa Perry, is available in New York beginning today at the designer’s Madison Avenue boutique. The tunics, dresses, pants, coats and skirt are a mashup of the two houses’ greatest hits: the designer recreated a handful of her signature styles using a selection of Schumacher’s most popular fabrics. Despite their throwback roots, the resulting looks — ’60s-inspired silhouettes printed with bright colors and fauna-inspired motifs (zebra stripes, prancing deer, leopard spots) — are youthful and refreshingly modern.

headline: Readers Respond: On ‘How We Learned to Kill’
text: Timothy Kudo’s Sunday Review piece, “How We Learned to Kill,” a reflection on killing from a veteran of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, drew an extraordinary number of comments from veterans of wars past and present.

headline: Police Are Criticized for Use of Force in Shooting in Los Angeles’s Skid Row
text: LOS ANGELES — A line of tents and people huddled in blankets filled the sidewalks of San Pedro Street on Monday in the heart of this city’s Skid Row. The occasional police car drove by. In the middle of the block, flowers were piled next to a note bidding goodbye to a man who had called this piece of sidewalk his home until Sunday afternoon.

headline: Vitamin-Packed With Promises
text: In the late 1800s a disfiguring and often fatal disease became epidemic in the South. Called pellagra (Italian for “rough skin”), it caused diarrhea, mental confusion, and severe scaling and flaking of the skin. By 1911, pellagra had become the leading cause of death in asylums. Eventually, the Public Health Service dispatched the physician Joseph Goldberger to determine its cause.

headline: Two Strains of H.I.V. Cut Vastly Different Paths
text: Thirty-four years ago, doctors in Los Angeles discovered that some of their patients were succumbing to a normally harmless fungus. It soon became clear that they belonged to a growing number of people whose immune systems were hobbled by a virus, eventually known as human immunodeficiency virus, or H.I.V.

headline: Saving Big on Energy Bills, People Take It to the Bank
text: Sometimes, even the supposed experts can lose track of a billion dollars or two. Or, in this case, $100 billion.

headline: In Performance | Pinkins and Wiest
text: Tonya Pinkins and Dianne Wiest play co-workers at odds in Joel Drake Johnson’s play “Rasheeda Speaking.” The New Group production was at the Pershing Square Signature Center in 2015.

headline: Researchers Link Syrian Conflict to a Drought Made Worse by Climate Change
text: Drawing one of the strongest links yet between global warming and human conflict, researchers said Monday that an extreme drought in Syria between 2006 and 2009 was most likely due to climate change, and that the drought was a factor in the violent uprising that began there in 2011.

headline: Termites: Guardians of the Soil
text: The giant termite mounds that rise up from the sands of the African savanna are so distinctive it’s tempting to give them names, like “Art Deco Skyline” or “Trumpeting Elephant” or “Flagrantly Obvious Fertility Totem.”

headline: ‘Infinite Monkey Cage’ Brings Playful Science Series to U.S.
text: “Do not be scared of science.” That is the message of “The Infinite Monkey Cage,” according to one of its hosts, the comedian Robin Ince. The science-meets-comedy radio show, which has been broadcast on BBC’s Radio 4 since 2009, has also become one of Britain’s most popular podcasts, and is gaining a following in the United States. This month, Mr. Ince and his scientist co-host, Brian Cox, are taking the show on a brief American tour, kicking off on Thursday night at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts in New York, where the guests will be the astrophysicists Neil deGrasse Tyson and Janna Levin, the comedian Lisa Lampanelli and the actor Tim Daly.

headline: Shooting Style
text: Marie Rime photographs the uniforms of Swiss gun culture.

headline: Review: ‘Lucky Alan,’ Jonathan Lethem’s Dreamlike Tales of Seclusion
text: In two of the stories in his superfluous new collection, Jonathan Lethem uses the snow globe as a symbol for isolation and removal from the hustle and bustle and Sturm und Drang of ordinary life. It’s a favorite image, which has popped up in earlier books like “Motherless Brooklyn” and “Chronic City,” and an apt metaphor for the separation that so many of his characters feel, whether it’s Dylan Ebdus in “The Fortress of Solitude,” who was bullied as a child, or Lionel Essrog, the detective with Tourette’s syndrome in “Motherless Brooklyn.”

headline: Nemtsov’s Partner Says Russia Held Her Against Her Will
text: MOSCOW — They met three years ago, by some accounts on a vacation to Turkey, and soon enough became a couple.

headline: Saving a River Giant, and a Livelihood
text: In the Brazilian Amazon, conservation efforts have led to a resurgence of the pirarucu, one of the largest freshwater fish in the world.

headline: Study Says Pregnant Women in India Are Gravely Underweight
text: NEW DELHI — Her first child survived eight months before succumbing to pneumonia; her second was stillborn; her third, delivered in a rickshaw, gasped for an hour before dying.

headline: Extra Sleep Linked With Stroke Risk
text: Sleeping more than eight hours a day is associated with a higher risk for stroke, a new study has found.

headline: A Quest to Solve Ceres’ Mysteries
text: What are the bright spots on Ceres, the largest known asteroid? No one knows, including scientists working on NASA’s Dawn mission, which begins orbiting Ceres on Friday. The two reflective spots, in a 57-mile-wide crater, could be ice or salt, the scientists speculate. “The team is really, really excited about this feature, because it is unique in the solar system,” Carol Raymond, the mission’s deputy principal investigator, said in a news conference Monday. “The mystery will be solved, but it is one that’s really got us on the edge of our seats.”

headline: A Surgery Standard Under Fire
text: What she wanted, the patient told the geriatricians evaluating her, was to be able to return to her condominium in Boston. She had long lived there on her own, lifting weights to keep fit and doing her own grocery shopping, until a heart condition worsened and she could barely manage the stairs.

headline: Netanyahu in Washington: High Stakes
text: To the Editor:

headline: Attention, All Scientists: Do Improv, With Alan Alda’s Help
text: STONY BROOK, N.Y. — Martha Furie stormed into the room and huffily sat down in a chair.

headline: Rick Perry Steps Up PAC Staffing
text: Rick Perry, the former Texas governor who ran unsuccessfully for the Republican presidential nomination in 2012, is continuing to put the pieces in place for a 2016 campaign.

headline: Should Pregnant Women Eat More Tuna?
text: For years pregnant women have been warned about eating tuna because of concerns about mercury exposure. But a federal panel has reignited the debate about the benefits and risks of eating tuna and other seafood during pregnancy.

headline: Gaining Altitude
text: Etihad and the other Persian Gulf airlines operate the latest-generation airplanes, hire younger flight attendants and offer onboard perks that stretch the definition of first class.

headline: Arming the Immune System Against Cancer
text: James P. Allison is the chairman of the immunology department at the University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. His seminal research opened up a new field in cancer treatment: immunotherapy. Instead of poisoning a tumor or destroying it with radiation, Dr. Allison has pioneered ways to unleash the immune system to destroy a cancer.

headline: An East Hampton Bookstore Pops Up in Manhattan
text: To coincide with the Armory Show, the annual contemporary and modern art fair that opens this week in New York, the East Hampton-based bookshop and gallery Harper’s Books (Reed Krakoff is a fan) will bring some of its rare inventory to Manhattan for a three-day pop-up at the Carlyle Hotel.

headline: Hospital Rating Systems Differ on Best and Worst
text: Four popular national rating systems used by consumers to judge hospitals frequently come to very different conclusions about which hospitals are the best — or worst — potentially adding to the confusion over health care quality, rather than alleviating it, a new study shows.

headline: Harrington, 43, Beats the Yips and, in a Playoff, a Rival Half His Age
text: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — Rory McIlroy was not going head-to-head against Rickie Fowler for the Honda Classic crown in a duel of young, photogenic players that no doubt would have piqued the casual sports fan’s interest in golf. The top-ranked McIlroy missed the cut in the weather-plagued event, and Fowler finished outside the top 40.

headline: Venezuela Tells U.S. to Reduce Embassy Staff
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — With diplomatic relations fraying rapidly between the United States and Venezuela, the government of President Nicolás Maduro has given the American Embassy here 15 days to come up with a plan to drastically shrink its staff, Venezuela’s foreign minister announced Monday.

headline: Reactions: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Editor:

headline: Safety Advocates Want Harsher Penalties for New York’s Drivers
text: After Allison Liao, 3, was killed by a car in Queens, the man who was behind the wheel, Ahmad Abu-Zayedeh, was not charged. But last month, his driver’s license was revoked by the state, after a long campaign by the girl’s parents, Amy Tam-Liao and Hsi-Pei Liao.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
text: There’s soccer everywhere you look this week. Unless you’re not looking, in which case there’s mostly basketball and, here in the Northeast, snow.

headline: Shooting of Boris Nemtsov Draws Comparisons to Death of Another Putin Foe
text: LONDON — The fatal shooting in Moscow last week of a Russian opposition leader, Boris Y. Nemtsov, has prompted comparisons with the 2006 poisoning of Alexander V. Litvinenko, another foe of President Vladimir V. Putin, who fled to Britain in 2000 and secured British citizenship weeks before he died of what was almost the perfect poisoning.

headline: A Few Reasons to Love Bleeding
text: Q. Does donating blood improve health?

headline: Slow Start for ‘The Heidi Chronicles’ on Broadway
text: Ticket sales were off to a slow start last week for the new Broadway revival of Wendy Wasserstein’s “The Heidi Chronicles,” starring Elisabeth Moss of “Mad Men” fame, according to box office data released on Monday. “The Heidi Chronicles,” which won both the Tony Award for best play and the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1989, grossed $305,345 for eight performances, or 34 percent of the maximum possible amount – on the low side for a well-known play with a star performer. Ms. Moss is an Emmy Award nominee for her years as the copywriter Peggy Olson on “Mad Men.”

headline: Review: ‘The Man in the Woman’s Shoes,’ a Mikel Murfi Solo Play
text: If Mikel Murfi ever fails as an actor (and this seems highly unlikely), he could make a killing at children’s birthday parties. The man has a rare talent for animal sounds. In the brief span of “The Man in the Woman’s Shoes,” at the Irish Arts Center, he voices chickens, bees, sea gulls, songbirds, sheep, a pig, a dog and a dying turkey, that last with enough realism to put you off drumsticks for life.

headline: Pierre Hardy Shares His Favorite Hometown Haunts in the City of Light
text: Pierre Hardy shoes are as Parisian as escargot. And as Fashion Week kicks off in the City of Light, the revered accessories designer — who has also logged stints at Dior, Hermès and Balenciaga and collaborated with Gap, Frédéric Malle and Nars — is as excited to be there as any visitor. “I love to just hang out in town; I rarely go away for the weekend,” he says. “Paris is always, in any season, a great relief, and a source of pleasure to look at.” Here, the native and Marais resident opens up his Paris black book for T.

headline: State to Seek Death Penalty in Killing of Students in North Carolina
text: DURHAM, N.C. — Prosecutors will seek the death penalty for the man charged with the killings of three Arab-American students in a Chapel Hill, N.C., apartment complex, the district attorney’s office handling the case said Monday.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 3 Episode 7 Recap: Nothing Is Forever
text: Season 3 Episode 7 Recap: Chapter 33

headline: A Refugee Embraces a Visual Language
text: As a young refugee unfamiliar with a new language, Sylvia Plachy learned to watch her surroundings. A new retrospective tracks 50 years of her journey.

headline: Court Skeptical of Arizona Plan for Less-Partisan Congressional Redistricting
text: WASHINGTON — An independent redistricting commission created by Arizona voters in 2000 seemed to be in trouble on Monday at the Supreme Court. Several justices suggested that the commission, meant to make the process of drawing congressional district lines less partisan, crossed a constitutional line.

headline: Review: Vienna Philharmonic’s Familiar and Fierce Show of Brahms
text: After City of Dreams, the adventurous and arduous three-week festival that the Vienna Philharmonic presented at Carnegie Hall and elsewhere around the country last year, the orchestra may be forgiven for having reverted to a tidy package of core repertory for its annual weekend in New York. Namely, music of Brahms: It performed his First and Third Symphonies at Carnegie on Friday evening, the Second and Fourth on Saturday evening and the “German Requiem” on Sunday afternoon, all conducted by Daniele Gatti.

headline: Review: In ‘Billy & Billie,’ a Step-Sibling Romance Tests Taboos
text: Take the time restrictions off of a playwright — “Don’t worry about saying what you have to say in two-and-a-half hours or less” — and what do you get? Something that looks like “Billy & Billie,” a new half-hour, 10-episode series about stepsibling romance from Neil LaBute that begins Tuesday on DirecTV’s Audience Network.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Ukraine and More – Pictures of the Day

headline: Review: ‘Alice in Wonderland,’ by Unsuk Chin, Told With Restraint
text: LOS ANGELES — Beginning with a subterranean, almost inaudible rumble, Unsuk Chin’s “Alice in Wonderland” isn’t quite the madcap spectacle you might expect from an opera based on Lewis Carroll’s novel. While there is ample zaniness in the two hours of music that follow, it is the score’s sober core that keeps the opera’s mood pleasurably disconcerting.

headline: Paul Beatty, Author of ‘The Sellout,’ on Finding Humor in Issues of Race
text: Even in elementary school, the novelist Paul Beatty knew how to make waves with words. At a cafe in the West Village recently, he recalled attending a summer camp in Santa Monica, Calif., where he and other children decorated the outside of a bus in a “hippie” style. Mr. Beatty painted a poem about the police near the top of the bus, and once on the road his verse attracted the attention of the actual police. “I wish I could remember the poem,” he said. “Something ‘pigs,’ ‘fuzz.’ The thing must have been four lines. They made me get out and erase one or two of the words.”

headline: Billionaire Grocer Is Said to Be a Suitor for The Daily News
text: A few weeks ago, John A. Catsimatidis, the billionaire owner of the grocery chain Gristedes, met Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the owner of The Daily News in New York, for lunch at Casa Lever, an Italian restaurant in Manhattan.

headline: Los Angeles Police Chief on Shooting
text: Charlie Beck, the Los Angeles police chief, said that in video of a fatal police shooting of a homeless man, a rookie officer can be heard saying, “He has my gun.”

headline: Tatiana Trouvé Unwinds History in Public Art Project
text: As a pastoral sculpture socked into the heart of a metropolis, Central Park has fascinated and provoked artists for decades. Claes Oldenburg hired gravediggers to excavate and refill a hole in it, to form an “invisible monument.” Christo and Jeanne-Claude gated and orange-ified it. Diane Arbus used her camera to draw deeply from its well of the weird. Robert Smithson, creator of the monumental “Spiral Jetty” in the Great Salt Lake, suggested that the idea belonged to the park’s beginnings: He called Frederick Law Olmsted, its chief designer, the “first ‘earthwork artist.’ ”

headline: Review: ‘Romantic Piano Quartets,’ From Chamber Music Society
text: Not every work of music written during the so-called Romantic period fits the most common definition of that word: describing something expressing, or conducive to, amorous feelings. Perhaps the Highly Strung period would be a more accurate way to characterize the 19th century, when raw sensitivity and indulgence in heightened emotions — be they anger, foreboding or desire — prevailed in music.

headline: Review: New Releases by Kelly Clarkson, Sannhet and Asleep at the Wheel
text: KELLY CLARKSON

headline: The Fashion-Forward Gun Clubs of Switzerland
text: The Swiss photographer Marie Rime grew up with a rifle in her hands. The daughter of a sport shooter, she took up the pastime at 14, and soon won a state championship in riflery. “On Saturdays,” she says, “I would just put my rifle on my back, get on my bike and go to the shooting range.”

headline: At JPMorgan Chase, Business Tilts Toward the Consumer Side and Away From Wall St.
text: A reversal of fortunes within the financial industry is illustrated in few places more vividly than JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Björk Is on Display, Up Close and in 3-D at MoMA
text: At the Museum of Modern Art on Sunday afternoon, Björk was seemingly everywhere. An artist known as Shoplifter sewed strands of hair onto Björk’s face. Around the corner, a textile conservator restrung pearls onto a topless wedding gown by Alexander McQueen, which was also worn by Björk. Nearby, Björk’s crystal-encrusted face floated in midair. A miniature Björk was on her way.

headline: Tena Stivicic Wins Blackburn Drama Prize
text: The playwright Tena Stivicic was to be awarded the 37th annual Susan Smith Blackburn Prize on Monday night for her play “3 Winters,” a dark, era-hopping drama about a Croatian family in post-World War II Zagreb. At a ceremony at Playwrights Horizons, Ms. Stivicic was to receive $25,000 and a numbered print by the artist Willem de Kooning.

headline: Merrill Lynch Hires Tax Expert From Credit Suisse
text: Bank of America Merrill Lynch has hired Lewis Steinberg, a senior banker from Credit Suisse, to serve as its in-house tax expert, the firm announced in an internal memorandum on Monday.

headline: The Cry Being Heard Around Washington: ‘I Need a Netanyahu Ticket’
text: WASHINGTON — For Senator Lindsey Graham, the only ticket more in demand than a seat inside the House chamber for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s address to Congress on Tuesday morning would be “if it was Garth Brooks — maybe.”

headline: Nurse Who Contracted Ebola in the U.S. Sues Her Hospital Employer
text: The nurse who was the first person to contract Ebola in the United States filed suit on Monday against the Dallas hospital where she worked, saying it knowingly left workers without the training or equipment needed to handle the disease.

text: Etihad and the other Persian Gulf airlines operate the latest-generation airplanes, hire younger flight attendants and offer onboard perks that stretch the definition of first class.

headline: Prison Terms Are Reduced for Amish in Beard-Cutting Attacks
text: A federal judge on Monday reduced the prison sentences for the leader of a breakaway Amish sect and seven followers who were convicted in a series of beard-cutting attacks on rival Amish in 2011.

headline: New York Sponsor of Port Authority Reform Bill Rejects a New Jersey Compromise
text: ALBANY — A legislative sponsor of an effort to overhaul the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said on Monday that a possible compromise bill suggested by a leading New Jersey Republican would not be acceptable in New York, all but dooming its chances as currently imagined.

headline: Custer’s First Stand
text: In July 1864 Lt. Gen. Jubal A. Early led 14,000 battle-hardened and enthusiastic Confederate veterans to within six miles of the new Capitol dome in Washington. Six months and several crushing defeats later, Early found himself wintering in Staunton, Va., with fewer than 2,000 dispirited troops.

headline: Removing an Artist’s Lifework
text: After 40 years in the diamond district of Manhattan, the Ney family is being evicted on March 19. Joel Ney is rushing to move about 4,000 pieces of his father’s artwork from the premises.

headline: Under Law, Christie Can Use Exxon Settlement to Help Balance Budget
text: A debate over New Jersey’s proposed $250 million settlement of what had been an $8.9 billion pollution lawsuit against Exxon Mobil Corporation has highlighted an obscure provision of a state law that would appear to allow Gov. Chris Christie to apply most if not all of the settlement toward balancing the state budget.

headline: Central Figure in the Atlanta Schools Cheating Scandal Dies
text: ATLANTA — Beverly L. Hall, the former superintendent of the Atlanta public schools who was awaiting a criminal trial for her alleged participation in a conspiracy to alter students’ standardized test results, died Monday after an extended battle with breast cancer, her legal team said.

headline: For the U.S. and China, a Test of Diplomacy on South Sudan
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United States may have midwifed the birth of South Sudan, the world’s youngest nation. But China has quickly become among its most important patrons, building its roads and pumping its oil.

headline: A Viral Defense of Russian Imperialism, Addressed to Obama
text: A Russian video blogger’s strident defense of his nation’s invasion and occupation of its neighbors, in the form of an open letter to President Obama uploaded to the web on Saturday, has become an instant hit among Russian nationalists, but raised alarm bells in other former Soviet republics.

headline: Senior Myles Mack Doesn’t Regret Choosing Rutgers
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — Favorite day? The senior guard Myles Mack did not hesitate on that one. It was Dec. 29, 2011, when Rutgers upset No. 10 Florida in a double-overtime thriller during his first season. A heralded class of talented freshmen led the way. Fans stormed the court and celebrated well after workers began to clean up.

headline: China Names 14 Generals Suspected of Corruption
text: BEIJING — China’s military authority on Monday released a list of 14 generals who are under investigation or have been convicted of graft, among them the son of one of China’s once highest-ranking generals.

headline: Cleveland Mayor Apologizes for Language Used to Blame Tamir Rice for His Death
text: Moving to stem fresh anger over how Cleveland has handled the killing of 12-year-old Tamir Rice, Mayor Frank G. Jackson apologized on Monday for language that the city’s lawyers used in court filings to assert that the boy’s death was his own fault.

headline: Terrorism Case Against Pakistani Man Is Going to Jury
text: As arguments in Abid Naseer’s trial on terrorism charges came to a close on Monday, jurors had heard from British intelligence officers in disguise, an F.B.I. attaché who observed Osama bin Laden’s dead body and Mr. Naseer himself arguing that he was an innocent man.

headline: Hillary Clinton Used Personal Email Account at State Dept., Possibly Breaking Rules
text: WASHINGTON — Hillary Rodham Clinton exclusively used a personal email account to conduct government business as secretary of state, State Department officials said, and may have violated federal requirements that officials’ correspondence be retained as part of the agency’s record.

headline: A Yankee Hurler Shows Great Mechanics
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees, who this season will be counting on a starting rotation that appears to be held together by duct tape and baling wire, on Monday employed a pitcher who could throw all day (and all night, too) without wearing out knee cartilage, elbow ligaments or shoulder sockets.

headline: A Warning From Buffett About Banks
text: “Money-shufflers don’t come cheap.”

headline: New York Fire Dept., Diversifying Ranks, Is Set to Swear In First Lesbian Chaplain
text: Maybe it is her short, spiky hair, or the cigarettes, which she gives to the men repairing the wiring in her Brooklyn apartment. Maybe it is because she swears. For whatever reason, the Rev. Ann Kansfield does not fit the stereotype of a minister.

headline: Climate Change Researcher Offers a Defense of His Practices
text: The scientist at the center of a controversy over fossil-fuel funding for climate research denounced his critics on Monday and said that he would be “happy to comply” with possible additional disclosure requirements from scientific journals publishing his papers.

headline: Senate Democrats Block Joint Negotiations on Homeland Security Funding
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats on Monday blocked a House attempt to force joint negotiations over legislation to fund the Department of Homeland Security through the fiscal year.

headline: Europe Unlikely to Meet Climate Goal, Study Finds
text: BERLIN — The European Union will fail to meet an ambitious goal of significantly reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 2050 unless it takes more aggressive measures to limit the use of fossil fuels and adopts new environmental policies, according to a report scheduled for release on Tuesday.

headline: Libyan General’s Promotion Could Hinder United Nations Peace Talks
text: MISURATA, Libya — The speaker of Libya’s internationally recognized Parliament named Gen. Khalifa Hifter on Monday to the recently created position of commander in chief of the army, potentially hindering United Nations-sponsored talks to end the country’s internal strife.

headline: Massachusetts: Boat Is Subject of Sparring in Bombing Case
text: Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the defendant in the 2013 bombing of the Boston Marathon, said Monday that they wanted the jury in his trial to view the entire boat in which he hid while the authorities searched for him several days after the bombing, not just cut-out panels on which he is said to have written a message. During a hearing at Boston’s federal courthouse, William Fick, a defense lawyer, called the boat a powerful piece of evidence and compared Mr. Tsarnaev’s lying in it to the way a body might lie in a crypt, adding that he did not see why the boat could not be brought to the courthouse. Prosecutors said that the suggestion was impractical, in part because the boat is still covered in blood and broken glass, and that many photographs of it exist. Judge George A. O’Toole Jr. said he may wish to view the boat himself before making a decision. Also Monday, defense lawyers filed their fourth change-of-venue motion with the court. The jury is to be seated on Tuesday, and opening arguments are expected to begin Wednesday.

headline: Sentencing for Former Principal at Bronx High School Is Delayed
text: A former principal at Cardinal Hayes High School who was charged with stealing thousands of dollars from the Bronx institution was given an extra two weeks on Monday to pay about $8,200 in restitution to avoid going to jail for one year.

headline: Review: ‘The Mystery of Love and Sex’ Looks at Identity and Secrets Too
text: The detective work in “The Mystery of Love & Sex,” a perfectly wonderful new play by Bathsheba Doran that opened on Monday at the Mitzi Newhouse Theater, extends well beyond the matters of high importance referred to in the title. In this tender and funny exploration of the lives of two couples from two generations, Ms. Doran also probes such fertile mysteries as the fluidity of identity, our ability to keep secrets from both our family and even ourselves, and the difficulty — and the rewards — of forgiveness.

headline: Gambler’s Last Words
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Each generation likes to think they invented stuff. Nothing angers a young person who thinks they have come up with a spiffy and original idea more than to find out that someone in the past had thought of it first. I believe that’s because we, as a species, are still hunter-gatherers at our core and the biggest piece of meat always went to he who felled the animal.

headline: Some Owners of Private Colleges Turn a Tidy Profit by Going Nonprofit
text: After a recent government crackdown on the multibillion-dollar career-training industry, stricter limits on student aid and devastating publicity about students hobbled by debt and useless credentials, some for-profit schools simply shut down.

headline: 2 Veterans and 2 Rookies Seek Mets’ Last Bullpen Slot
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Around 11 a.m. Monday, on one of the main fields at the Mets’ spring training complex, Matt Harvey toed the rubber for his latest bullpen session. A horde of fans watched his every move. General Manager Sandy Alderson, Manager Terry Collins and several other members of the team’s hierarchy made sure to be there, too.

headline: Monroe Freedman, Influential Voice on Legal Ethics, Dies at 86
text: Monroe H. Freedman, a dominant figure in legal ethics whose work helped chart the course of lawyers’ behavior in the late 20th century and beyond, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Toronto Police Say Tunnel Mystery Is Solved
text: OTTAWA — Toronto’s mystery tunnel has turned out to be a place for a couple of guys to get away from it all, more a “man cave” than a terrorist threat.

headline: Giants’ Pierre-Paul Gets Franchise Tag; Lions’ Suh Does Not
text: In a move that was expected, the Giants on Monday designated defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul as their franchise player, a maneuver that virtually ensures that he will remain with the team at least one more season.

headline: Australia to Send More Troops to Iraq as Trainers in ISIS Fight

headline: Obama Calls for Changes in Policing After Task Force Report
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday called for prompt action to change police practices across the country after the deaths of unarmed black men in Ferguson, Mo., and Staten Island at the hands of white officers exposed frustrations about law enforcement in minority communities.

headline: Ernie Hemmings, Founder of a Bible of Classic Cars, Dies at 88

headline: Larger-Than-Life Advertising Imagery, Brought Down to Size
text: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: David Letterman: A Look Back
text: After 33 years as the cigar-chomping, larger-than-life face of late-night television, David Letterman, 67, will count down his last top-ten list when the final episode of "Late Show with David Letterman" airs in May. The Indianapolis native grew up worshiping Johnny Carson, and after getting his start as a wisecracking TV weatherman, went on to host both "Late Night" on NBC and "Late Show" on CBS. Renowned for his biting wit and hard-nosed interview style, Letterman has made his name poking fun at his employers and quarreling with guests like Madonna and Cher. Now, as he prepares to say goodbye to the Ed Sullivan Theater, a look back at the career of TV's most lovable misanthrope.

headline: In Buenos Aires, a Hub of Local Culture Under One Exquisite Roof
text: Over the weekend, a hybrid concept space called Casa Cavia opened its doors in the upscale Palermo Chico neighborhood in Buenos Aires. The building, which dates back to 1927 and was originally built as a two-story residential home, retains much of its original design but was recently upgraded by its new owner, the restaurateur and film producer Lupe Garcia. Inspired by local cafes from the 1920s and 1930s, she recruited KallosTurin architects to integrate marble, brass, leather and terrazzo floors into the space, which now houses a restaurant and bar, patisserie, flower shop, perfumery, bookstore and publisher all under one exquisite roof.

headline: A New Chapter
text: In the reassembly of a book’s torn-out pages, the artist Mark Hagen finds a symbol of rebirth to echo the poet Michael Dickman’s sonnet about welcoming a child into the world.

headline: Figures From U.S.-Led Coalition Show Heavy 2014 Losses for Afghan Army
text: WASHINGTON — The Afghan Army lost more than 20,000 fighters and others last year largely because of desertions, discharges and deaths in combat, according to figures to be released Tuesday, casting further doubt on Afghanistan’s ability to maintain security without help from United States-led coalition forces.

headline: A Polarized Court, Weighing a Reversal of the Safety Net

text: So much of life is about leave-taking: moving from home to college, from love to love, from city to city and from life stage to life stage.

headline: Finding Refuge in a Visual Language
text: Sylvia Plachy’s approach to photography has remained constant, even if her gear or technique has changed at times. She tries to make everything disappear, to forget who she is. For one, she does not like to talk when she takes pictures. “Of course, you have to with people,” she said. “Sometimes. But I usually prefer just to smell it and be there and understand it through instinct.”

headline: Will the Supreme Court Say No to Gerrymandering?
text: The citizens of Arizona — like so many others nationwide — were long fed up with their elected officials drawing skewed electoral districts to keep themselves, and the majority party, in power.

headline: How Warren Buffett Does It
text: Fifty years ago, a young investor named Warren Buffett took control of a failing textile company, Berkshire Hathaway. “I found myself ... invested in a terrible business about which I knew very little,” Buffett relates in his annual letter to shareholders, which was released over the weekend. “I became the dog who caught the car.”
