headline: Are You Really Allergic to Antibiotics?
text: NOVI, Mich. — ALLERGIC reactions to antibiotics can be severe, including symptoms ranging from hives and wheezing to anaphylactic shock. People with such allergic reactions are right to steer clear. The problem is that many, and probably most, people who say they’re allergic to antibiotics actually aren’t. For penicillin, the most commonly reported allergy, many studies have estimated that up to 90 percent of claims of allergies are not legitimate.

headline: To Hurt ISIS, Squeeze the Cash Flow
text: The fight against the Islamic State must be a multipronged effort, designed to counter the terrorists, their ideology and their murderous strategy on every level.

headline: The Education of ‘Jihadi John’
text: LONDON — LAST week, the man called “Jihadi John” by the world’s media was unmasked as Mohammed Emwazi, a Kuwaiti-born Muslim and naturalized British citizen from London. Not only that, but the Islamic State’s most notorious Western recruit was identified as a graduate in computer science from the University of Westminster.

headline: Test Yourself | The Winter That Won’t End
text: Here are several paragraphs from a Feb. 27 article, “With White-Knuckle Grip, February’s Cold Clings to New York.”

headline: Confessions of a Pebble Thief
text: During my first year of therapy with Dr. Conger, I began what started as a random gesture and soon became a ritual. After each session, on the short, pebbly path from his home office to the street, I’d secretly pick up a small rock and pocket it.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
text: 8 P.M. (TCM) THE ARTIST (2011) George Valentin (Jean Dujardin, in an Oscar-winning performance), a silent-screen star, finds his luster fading when he refuses to speak on film with the arrival of sound, while Peppy Miller (Bérénice Bejo), a young extra he helped get a break, becomes the next big thing. Then Peppy insists that Valentin star in her next movie. This film, written and directed by Michel Hazanavicius, also won for best director and best picture. “Though its protagonist mourns the arrival of sound, ‘The Artist’ itself is more interested in celebrating the range and power of a medium that can sparkle, swoon and suffer so beautifully that it doesn’t really need to have anything to say,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, choosing the film as a critics’ pick. And because of the expressiveness and dexterity of Mr. Dujardin and Ms. Bejo — “they dance beautifully and also portray emotion with just the right blend of naturalism and melodramatic exaggeration — ‘The Artist’ is more than a clever pastiche of antique amusements,” he wrote. “It may be something less than a great movie, but it is an irresistible reminder of nearly everything that makes the movies great.”

headline: What Makes a Good Teacher
text: As American students lag behind their peers in other countries, how can the U.S. ensure and improve the quality of school instruction?

headline: Barclays Logs $268 Million 2014 Loss, After Charges for Potential Legal Costs
text: LONDON — The British bank Barclays said on Tuesday that it fell to a loss in 2014, its annual results dragged down by charges related to potential fines and litigation costs for conduct by its employees. It also posted lower income in its investment bank as it continues to shrink that business.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Nature’s Fighter Jets With Flapping Wings
text: In “Nature’s Fighter Jets With Flapping Wings,” James Gorman writes about new research on how hawks capture their prey.

headline: What Sounds Annoy You?
text: Gum snapping? Soup slurping? Dog barking? Popcorn munching?

headline: Simon Rattle to Return to His Roots, Taking Over the London Symphony
text: Their long flirtation is over, and now they are engaged: Simon Rattle, the Liverpool-born maestro who rose to become chief conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic, said on Tuesday that he would return to Britain in 2017 as music director of the London Symphony Orchestra.

headline: Driven | 2015 Volkswagen Golf TSI
text: The classic silhouette of the Volkswagen Golf hasn’t changed much in 40 years, but its high-end touches and fuel-efficient power make it a good value.

headline: Video Review: 2015 Volkswagen Golf, a Crowd-Pleaser in Many Forms
text: THE Volkswagen Golf was introduced in 1974, effectively replacing the original people’s car, the Beetle. Now, 40 years later, Golf is not as beloved (there’s no reboot of “The Love Bug” with a Golf as Herbie, is there?), but this seventh-generation hatchback deserves immense respect. It has won nearly every award, including North American Car of the Year and World Car of the Year.

headline: BlackBerry Announces Leap Phone, Moving Back Toward Touch Screens
text: BARCELONA, Spain — After returning in force to its keyboard roots last year, BlackBerry jumped back into touch-screen phones this week at the Mobile World Congress here, announcing the five-inch BlackBerry Leap.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: David Vann’s ‘Aquarium’
text: David Vann’s new novel, “Aquarium,” about a lonely young girl who meets an old man at the Seattle Aquarium, begins on a deceptively light note. Its cinematic quality is due largely to a series of lovely, well-curated fish photographs that accompany 12-year-old Caitlin’s observation of the exotic fauna. But the momentary lightness of these early pages soon unspools into psychological darkness — and the intricate, colorful pictures diminish — as Caitlin moves away from the tranquillity and beauty of the aquarium and into the more dangerous spaces of a world populated by humans.

headline: Neil Gaiman’s ‘Trigger Warning’
text: If there is any contemporary cognate to the kind of literary celebrity once enjoyed, in a vastly different cultural setting, by Charles Dickens or Leo Tolstoy, it is surely found in Neil Gaiman. A wildly popular tale-spinner as well as a writer of considerable gifts and transcendent ambition, Gaiman has been embraced by critics even as he has amassed a Kardashian-­scale Twitter following. He has written novels for children and comic books for adults (advancing both forms in the process), and vice versa.

headline: Ascap Topped $1 Billion in Revenue Last Year, Lifted by Streaming
text: Ascap, the music licensing agency, is in one sense fighting for its survival, seeking to change decades-old rules to fit the economics of online music. In another, it is finding ways to distribute more money than ever to its thousands of songwriters.

headline: New York Today: Boys of Spring
text: Good morning on this chilly Tuesday.

headline: 20 Killed as Bus Falls Off Cliff in Central China
text: BEIJING — The weeks around the start of the Lunar New Year are busy ones for entertainers in China, like acrobats and traveling opera troupes. But the journeys of one such group during the nascent Year of the Sheep ended in disaster when a bus carrying 33 members plunged off a cliff in central China on Monday night, killing 20 people on board and injuring the other 13.

headline: European Banking Regulator Postpones Next Stress Tests to 2016
text: LONDON — European banks will have another year to prepare for the next round of stress tests that will examine the ability of the region’s lenders to survive a potential financial crisis or severe economic downturn.

headline: In Congress, Netanyahu Faults ‘Bad Deal’ on Iran Nuclear Program
text: WASHINGTON — With dark warnings and a call to action, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel used one of the world’s most prominent venues on Tuesday to denounce what he called a “bad deal” being negotiated with Iran and to mount an audacious challenge to President Obama.

headline: Cross Section of Democrats to Snub Netanyahu’s Speech to Congress
text: WASHINGTON — Some are standing with President Obama. Some are protesting the actions of the House speaker, John A. Boehner. Still others say they do not want to be props in Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s re-election campaign.

headline: For Netanyahu and Obama, Difference Over Iran Became a Chasm
text: WASHINGTON — Over six years of bitter disagreements about how to deal with the Iranian nuclear threat, President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel kept running into one central problem: The two leaders never described their ultimate goal in quite the same way.

headline: In Chapel Hill, Suspect’s Rage Went Beyond a Parking Dispute
text: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — On the last day of Razan Mohammad Abu-Salha’s life, it was too cold to run.

headline: Man Convicted of Rape in Delhi Blames Victim
text: NEW DELHI — In the months after the death of a young woman who was brutalized and gang-raped on a moving bus in New Delhi in 2012, thousands of politicians, activists and ordinary citizens crowded India’s airwaves and its public spaces to say their piece about the crime.

headline: The ‘Loser Edit’ That Awaits Us All
text: If you have ever watched a reality TV show and said, “He’s going home tonight,” you know what the “loser edit” is. I imagine it started as a matter of practicality. If you have 20 contestants, they can’t all receive equal airtime. When an obscure character gets the heave-ho, the producers have to cobble together a coherent story line. Intersperse the snippets across the hour, and we can identify sins and recognizable human frailty that need to be punished. Anyone tuning in for the first time catches up quickly. The loser edit is not just the narrative arc of a contestant about to be chopped, or voted off the island, whatever the catchphrase. It is the plausible argument of failure.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: LaCroix Sparkling Water
text: I was introduced to them at work, the same place where most of us worry about contracting respiratory viruses. I’d just landed a job in sunny Los Angeles, where I ate breakfast, lunch and dinner at a standing desk in a windowless office. I was paid more money than I’d ever made before, which was just enough that I could never stop counting it, over and over until it lost meaning, like that thing that happens when you do acid and stare at your hand.

headline: Larry Wilmore Has No Beef With Bill O’Reilly

headline: The Doom of the American System?
text: Vox’s Matt Yglesias has an essay this week making an extended, detailed version of a case that he (and others) have made before: That our era of partisan and ideological polarization is exposing weaknesses inherent in America’s presidential system of government, and that those weaknesses may threaten the stability, if not the survival, of the American constitutional order. It’s an essay that I suspect will be dismissed unread by a number of conservatives as just the latest iteration of the “America the ungovernable”/”the system has failed the president” genre popular among liberal writers in the waning days of struggling Democratic administrations. (Well, Jimmy Carter’s, in particular.) But Yglesias’s argument, to his credit, isn’t a lament for brilliant liberal reforms thwarted by filibustering bad guys and Madisonian mistakes; instead, he argues that President Obama has found ways to govern in the face of gridlock, mostly by the creative/Caesarist application of executive power to domestic policy, and that the next president, Republican or Democratic, will probably find ways to do the same. His point is that governance is increasing happening outside constitutional norms, not that it isn’t happening at all, and that it’s happening that way for reasons that are independent of particular chief executives and whose influence neither political party is likely to soon roll back.

headline: 1965: Congo Jails Unesco Teacher

It was a part of continuing Congolese police harassment of United Nations employees here, UN sources said, in spite of Premier Moise Tshombe’s order that such harassment stop. A senior UN official said the situation ‘‘would be comical if it weren’t so tragic.’’ The incident came 11 days after 13 United Nations teachers and their 22 dependents were expelled, only to be invited back to the Congo hours after their plane left for Athens. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 4, 1965

Kaltenbach told White about his early career in New York, living in SoHo back when it was in its artistic prime. Kaltenbach even explained how, after a number of LSD trips, he began to hear what he interprets to be the voice of God. “I was hearing God, he was telling me things that were going to happen, and they would happen. It was just not possible.”

headline: Review: Sarah Manguso Offers Crumbs Relating to Her Diary

It’s about her long battle with a crippling neurological disease, one that forced her during her 20s to have her plasma replaced more than 50 times. It’s a harrowing book. It’s also a funny one. A boyfriend visits her in the hospital and declares her condition “greasy but stable.”

headline: New York City Plans to Study the Diversity of Its Cultural Groups
text: In a major study to be undertaken this summer, the de Blasio administration will review the diversity of the boards, staffs and audiences of New York City cultural organizations, such as museums, orchestras and dance troupes.

headline: Mr. Netanyahu’s Unconvincing Speech to Congress
text: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel could not have hoped for a more rapturous welcome in Congress. With Republicans and most Democrats as his props, he entered the House of Representatives to thunderous applause on Tuesday, waving his hand like a conquering hero and being mobbed by fawning lawmakers as he made his way to the lectern.

headline: Review: Roman Rabinovich Plays Bach and More at SubCulture

headline: Review: Ekmeles Performs John Cage at the Avant Music Festival
text: In 2006, Trogen, a Swiss town, began hosting a series of performances of the complete choral works by Bach, with their sequence determined by the liturgical calendar for which they were written. According to the Swiss J. S. Bach Foundation, which is behind the project, the series will have covered all of his cantatas, masses, oratorios and motets by 2030.

headline: Karl Lagerfeld on Fur (Yea), Selfies (Nay) and Keeping Busy
text: MILAN — Karl Lagerfeld, arguably the most recognizable fashion designer in the world, is in a back office at Fendi’s headquarters on the Via Solari, receiving from an assistant a gift someone has sent for his Birman, Choupette.

headline: U.N. Moves Closer to Sanctions in South Sudan Conflict
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations Security Council on Tuesday unanimously adopted a resolution to impose sanctions on those who disrupt efforts to restore peace in South Sudan, but it stopped short of barring the warring factions from buying more arms.

headline: Seeing Stars at Anthony Vaccarello
text: The constellation prize for today’s shows in Paris went to the hairstylist Anthony Turner and the makeup artist Tom Pecheux for the beauties they sent down the runway at Anthony Vaccarello. For Turner, the off-duty look they collaborated on was dictated by casting. “All the girls are beautiful,” he says, “so it wasn’t about creating characters or turning them into something they are not.” For tousled rock-‘n’-roll strands, Turner worked L’Oreal Professional PLI from roots to ends, letting each model’s hair part naturally. Pecheux, for his part, was feeling more Chrissie Hynde and less David Bowie with the tattoo-looking designs he created under one of each of the models’ eyes. Inspired by the clothes, he drew the shape of a star out of the corner of the eye — “but we have seen that before,” he says. So he began erasing the star’s lines until he arrived at a more subtle geometric touch. And despite the heavily-lined eyelids, Pecheux didn’t use a drop of mascara; he didn’t want the models to look “too bourgeoisie.”

headline: What Do Unions Know About Running Schools?
text: The charter school movement got its foothold two decades ago by promising that independently operated schools would outperform their traditional counterparts if they were allowed to receive public money while being exempted from some state regulations — including the requirement that they be unionized. Charter advocates made the deal more compelling by vowing that charter schools would be closely overseen and shut down when they failed , in contrast to traditional schools, which were allowed to fail in perpetuity without consequence.

headline: Clock Ticks for Paul Rudolph’s Orange County Government Center

headline: Review: ‘The Lesson’ Is a Test of Conscience and Patience
text: We first encounter Nade (Margita Gosheva) in the classroom, preceded by the sound of chalk on the blackboard. An English teacher in a provincial Bulgarian town, she is stern but not without a hint of warmth. At the moment, though, she is preoccupied with finding out which of her students has been stealing money from unattended backpacks. This turns out to be a sign of worse trouble to come.

headline: The 17th Armory Show, New as Ever
text: What’s that old adage about New York real estate? Location, location, location. So how is it that the Armory Show, which opens its 17th iteration this week, absolutely thrives on Piers 92 and 94 — which sit on the West Side Highway at 55th Street, otherwise known as Manhattan’s Siberia? The secret: its director, Noah Horowitz, who swooped in four years ago to save the fair from what was widely regarded as its hemorrhaging status. At the age of 35, Horowitz, who penned the art-market manual “Art of the Deal” and is a faculty member at Sotheby’s Institute of Art, commands expert status in the ways of the contemporary scene, and has made the fair his own. “Overall, I think the feeling is of renewed strength to the fair. We’ve made a huge emphasis on quality, in the stature of the galleries themselves — and I don’t mean just blue-chip galleries, but also young and mid-career ones, too,” he explains of his strategy. Since finding its foothold in 1999, the Armory Show, which draws its namesake from the Park Avenue Armory and its inspiration from the 1913 exposition accredited with bringing “shock of the new” modernism to America, has always emphasized, well, evolution. “One of the challenges in the market we operate in these days is things have become very flat, and a lot of things start looking the same,” says Horowitz, who stresses his investment in new artists and galleries.

text: Television already has more real estate shows than necessary, but if you can’t get enough of peering inside strangers’ houses, FYI offers a new series on Wednesday night that at least varies the formula. The only trouble is, you have to watch it as if you were touring a fixer-upper. Envision a real estate agent whispering in your ear, “Pay no attention to those holes.”

text: “CSI: Crime Scene Investigation,” now chugging along in its 15th season, keeps leaving its spinoffs in the dust. “CSI: Miami” gave up after 10 seasons, “CSI: NY” fell away after nine. But the hope for advertising dollars springs eternal, so here we have “CSI: Cyber,” making its debut on CBS on Wednesday night.

headline: Members of Newtown Shootings Panel Recall Toll Their Work Took

headline: Scooter LaForge’s Paintings Suit Walter Van Beirendonck (and Beyonce, Too)
text: Like so many modern relationships, the collaboration between the designer Walter Van Beirendonck, one of the famous “Antwerp 6,” and the New York artist Scooter LaForge started on Facebook. Beirendonck began following LaForge’s public profile several years ago, and the rest will sound familiar: “One day, we started to chat,” Beirendonck says. After asking the artist to paint an invitation and poster for an earlier collection, the designer more recently commissioned several paintings from LaForge with imagery relating to “topics I wanted to refer to in the Whambam! collection,” Beirendonck’s spring/summer 2015 line. LaForge’s paintings depicting a shark, birds of paradise, a bloody beach, a machine gun, a warplane and a kitten were then scanned digitally and translated into woven fabrics.

text: Gout, a form of arthritis, is extremely painful and associated with an increased risk for cardiovascular problems. But there is a bright side: It may be linked to a reduced risk for Alzheimer’s disease.

text: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin said Tuesday that he would sign a ban on abortions after 20 weeks, coming out strongly on an issue important to social conservatives that he played down in his re-election campaign last year.

headline: Britain: Man Linked to Militants in Yemen Is Extradited to the U.S.
text: A Vietnamese man accused of helping develop online propaganda for Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Yemen has been extradited from Britain to face trial in Manhattan, United States prosecutors said Tuesday. The defendant, Minh Quang Pham, 32, had been living in Britain. He went to Yemen in 2010; swore an oath of allegiance to the group, Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula; and provided it with “expert advice and assistance in photography and graphic design of media,” an indictment charges. In Yemen, he worked with an American citizen who helped produce Inspire, an English-language online magazine published by the group, the authorities said. The indictment does not name the American, but he appears to have been Samir Khan, who was later killed in a drone strike. Mr. Pham’s lawyer did not respond immediately to messages seeking comment.

headline: For White House Spokesman, Clinton Emails Trump Netanyahu Speech
text: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, found himself spending nearly his entire news conference Tuesday discussing  Hillary Rodham Clinton’s use of a personal email account when she was secretary of state, rather than the speech delivered earlier in the day by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

headline: Namibia: President Is Awarded $5 Million Prize for Good Governance
text: Namibia’s departing president, Hifikepunye Pohamba, has been awarded the 2014 Ibrahim Prize for Achievement in African Leadership. In making the announcement on Monday in Kenya, the prize committee’s chairman, Salim Ahmed Salim, said, “President Pohamba’s focus on forging national cohesion and reconciliation at a new stage of Namibia’s consolidation of democracy and social and economic development impressed the prize committee.” The Ibrahim Prize, the largest annually awarded prize in the world, is worth $5 million over the first 10 years, followed by a stipend of at least $200,000 a year. The Mo Ibrahim Foundation, established in 2006 by a Sudanese-British telecom mogul, makes the annual awards. Mr. Pohamba, 79, has served two terms as president and is due to hand over power at the end of the month. He was a founding member of the governing party, Swapo, which fought for Namibian independence from South Africa in 1990. Since the prize’s inception, four former presidents have received it. In the past two years, no prize was awarded.

headline: Confessions From New York’s Era of Fury Show Their Cracks
text: On Monday, Pascal Carpenter, age 42, left prison after serving 25 years, his sentence for being the lookout in a mugging that became a murder. Under New York law, if someone is killed during the commission of a felony — say, a robbery — everyone who took part in the lesser crime can be held liable for the homicide. It’s not just New York; some states execute the lookouts.

headline: Virginia: Women’s College Will Close Over Finances
text: Sweet Briar College, a century-old women’s liberal-arts college near Lynchburg, announced Tuesday that it will close in August. The college, which has 700 students and 329 employees, cited “insurmountable financial problems” and the shrinking number of students interested in a rural women-only college. Sweet Briar will be the third liberal-arts institution in the state to fold in the last two years, after Saint Paul’s College and Virginia Intermont College. There is no decision yet on what will become of the 3,250-acre campus.

headline: What Bibi Didn’t Say

And how should we balance the critiques of our policy from the serious Bibi versus the cynical Bibi?

Wright has made that play hundreds of times. But this time, it was a small reminder that Wright’s left shoulder was healthy again after a season of discomfort and that he was at full strength for a 2015 campaign that he has said he hopes will end the Mets’ long run of futility.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
text: 8:05 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE DREAMERS (2004) Louis Garrel (top), Eva Green (center) and Michael Pitt (above) portray the points of a photogenic triangle in this drama from Bernardo Bertolucci (“Last Tango in Paris”) about an American who befriends French twins in Paris during the 1968 student riots. This adaptation of Gilbert Adair’s novel “The Holy Innocents” is “disarmingly sweet and completely enchanting,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “The sex in this movie is, as measured by the display of body parts and the amount of time the actors spend out of their clothes, more explicit than even the most notorious scenes in ‘Last Tango,’ ” he said. “But it is hard to imagine a voyeur more benevolent than Mr. Bertolucci, whose eager scrutiny of the eros of the young is, like Jeremy Irons’s in ‘Stealing Beauty,’ less a matter of prurience than of an honest, nostalgic appreciation of natural human vitality.”

headline: Delivering Unwelcome Species to the Mediterranean
text: The Mediterranean Sea is among the world’s great environmental jewels. The sea is highly saline, almost entirely enclosed by land and contains immense biodiversity. Scientists have long worried that its health is imperiled. Swelling coastal populations and ship traffic have brought overfishing and pollution. Climate change threatens to roil the waters still further.

headline: Photos Hopscotch Through Cortázar’s Paris
text: Hugo Passarello was young and starry-eyed when he first encountered “Hopscotch” by the Argentine novelist Julio Cortázar. Like most readers, he was enthralled by the stream-of-consciousness narrative that shattered notions of structure. Set in Paris and written episodically, the novel boasts 155 snapshots which Cortázar gives readers three options to move through: progressively; hopscotching with instructions; or blazing a unique path.

headline: China’s Military Budget Increasing 10% for 2015, Official Says

headline: Abuse at Attica Calls for Federal Scrutiny

He had been given a diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease 25 years before I first entered their small apartment in the Baruch housing projects, which stand where the Williamsburg Bridge meets Manhattan.

headline: The Hardest (and Most Important) Job in Afghanistan
text: Early one cold January morning on the high plains of eastern Afghanistan, Maj. Mohammad Qasim and a few of his officers gathered in the rundown barracks that serve as a district headquarters for the Afghan National Police in Baraki Barak. Qasim and his officers were the only government security available to the 100,000 people living in a district roughly twice the size of Manhattan, and about half of the district was now controlled by the Taliban. Kabul is just 40 miles away, but the Afghan National Army had not been to Baraki Barak in two years. The ceiling in Qasim’s office leaked when it rained, and the electricity was out indefinitely, so the men had taken to sitting on floor cushions around the wood stove in Qasim’s bedroom, drinking green tea from smudged glass mugs and dealing with the problems of the day. This morning, the first problem was the death of Hajji Khalil.

headline: ‘New York Spring Spectacular’ Brings High Kicks to Radio City Music Hall
text: Two monumental puppets representing Patience and Fortitude, the lions guarding the entrance to the main branch of New York Public Library, tapped their paws and swished their tails onstage at Radio City Music Hall the other day. It was break time during rehearsals for Radio City’s “New York Spring Spectacular,” and in an orchestra seat, Randy Weiner, one of the show’s creative directors, leaned back and began formulating, aloud, a few interesting notions.

headline: ‘The Strategist: Brent Scowcroft and the Call of National Security’
text: In foreign policy, every success is just the start of the next crisis. Brent Scowcroft has pointed this out often in his four ­decades at the top of the American national security establishment. When the Soviet Union was conceding defeat in the nuclear arms race, he wondered if Gorbachev would instead “kill us with kindness.” When the Evil Empire was crumbling, he fretted about loose ­nuclear weapons and ethnic slaughter. When American troops were routing Saddam Hussein in the Persian Gulf war of 1991, he worried that “Iraq could fall apart,” leaving us to pick up the pieces. Again and again, this taciturn Mormon has been the Woody ­Allen of American foreign policy.

text: Do you play an instrument? Draw? Take photos? Write poetry? Dance?

headline: Deadly Blast Rocks Coal Mine in East Ukraine
text: KRASNOARMIRSK, Ukraine — An explosion ripped through a coal mine in the separatist-held eastern city of Donetsk, Ukraine, early Wednesday morning, killing several miners and leaving dozens more trapped underground and feared dead.

headline: A Lawyer Taking Aim at the Health Care Act Gets a Supreme Court Rematch

A few days later, he slipped out of New York City to attend the wedding of a Hasidic leader’s grandson. headline: Standard Chartered Profit Fell 37% in 2014
text: LONDON — The British bank Standard Chartered, which generates most of its earnings in Asia, said on Wednesday that profit fell 37 percent in 2014. It cited higher charges for bad loans and other credit risks, an accounting charge on its Korean business, and a previously announced settlement with the United States authorities.

headline: One Twin Exercises, the Other Doesn’t
text: Identical twins in Finland who shared the same sports and other physical activities as youngsters but different exercise habits as adults soon developed quite different bodies and brains, according to a fascinating new study that highlights the extent to which exercise shapes our health, even in people who have identical genes and nurturing.

headline: ‘Our Kids,’ by Robert D. Putnam

In successive versions of “Bowling Alone” (as a 1995 article and an instant-classic book), Putnam argued, to bipartisan acclaim, that civic life is declining with ominous consequences. Bill Clinton brought him to Camp David. The campaigns of Al Gore and George W. Bush sought his advice. Barack Obama gave him a medal.

headline: The Supreme Court Has the Power to Deepen a National Health Divide

headline: Solicitor General Will Try, Again, to Keep Health Care Law Alive
text: WASHINGTON — Three years ago this month, Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli Jr. stood before the Supreme Court to defend President Obama’s health care law against a constitutional challenge that threatened to destroy its central provision. His oral argument drew harsh reviews, but in the end he managed to persuade five justices to accept his backup argument, saving the law.

headline: Bristol-Myers Squibb Enters Drug Licensing Deal With Danish Biotechnology Firm
text: LONDON — The Danish biotechnology company Bavarian Nordic said on Wednesday that it could receive up to $975 million under a licensing agreement with Bristol-Myers Squibb for Prostvac, a treatment for advanced prostate cancer that is in clinical trials.

headline: Can I Hide My Beliefs During Jury Selection?
text: I live in a Midwestern state that has the death penalty. I am scheduled to be a juror for the first time in March, and I’m afraid I will face a difficult ethical choice if I am selected for a capital case. Though I consider myself an atheist, I was brought up Quaker and still hold dear many of those values — nonviolence, a belief in the goodness of each person, peace and simplicity, to name a few. I believe that the death penalty is inherently wrong, unethical and unjust. Should I be put on a capital case, I am considering hiding my beliefs to improve my odds of selection so I can subvert an unfair system. I know it is unethical and possibly illegal to lie to the judge and lawyers, but do the means justify the ends in order to save a life? NICO

headline: Morning Agenda: Equity Firms Push Into Landlord Loans
text: EQUITY FIRMS PUSH INTO LANDLORD LOANS | In the aftermath of the financial crisis, large private equity firms spent tens of billions of dollars buying foreclosed homes across the United States to operate them as rental properties. Now, three big firms ‒ the Blackstone Group, Colony Capital and Cerberus Capital Management ‒ are providing loans to smaller investors who are looking to do something similar, Matthew Goldstein reports in DealBook. These firms are betting that so-called landlord loans to small and midsize investors will become the next big opportunity to profit from the rebound in the United States housing market.

headline: Hirshhorn Museum’s New Curator Brings a Different Perspective
text: WASHINGTON — Two days into his job as chief curator at the Smithsonian’s Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, Stéphane Aquin is, as he would say, dépaysé — away from home and off kilter. Heading out to our breakfast meeting, he makes the mistake of hailing a cab which, in classic Washington fashion, takes him all over town before depositing him at his destination — a few minutes’ walk from where he started out. At a grill, hungry for an egg sandwich, Mr. Aquin is offered such a dizzying array of options that he switches his order to sausage, which arrives as pancake-shaped patties of meat. Not quite the saucisse he’d have been served at any bistro in his native Montreal.

headline: Voters Unlikely to Care Much About the Hillary Clinton Email Furor

According to unofficial returns, the measure was defeated 3,799 to 1,016.

headline: 1890: Forth Bridge Is Completed
text: EDINBURGH — The great railway bridge that now spans the Firth of Forth, to-day [March 4] received from the Prince of Wales its formal dedication. Here, amid wind and a drizzling rain the last rivet was driven home, the Prince using a silver key to turn the valve of the hydraulic riveting machine. The Prince, with some difficulty, made his way to the end of the platform and declared the bridge open.  The Forth Bridge, without doubt, is the highest effort of engineering skill in metal construction that the world has seen. An international significance attaches to the event from the presence of a large number of distinguished foreign guests. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 5, 1890

headline: What the Fed’s 2009 Transcripts Reveal About Its Handling of the Recession

headline: 1994: Eurostar Tunnel Links Britain to the Continent

Queen Elizabeth II traveled through the Channel Tunnel in a gleaming Eurostar express to meet President François Mitterrand and inaugurate the first land link between England and the Continent.

headline: Ludo Lefebvre’s Roasted-Carrot Salad

headline: David Hallberg Out for American Ballet Theater’s Spring Season
text: David Hallberg, the American Ballet Theater principal dancer, is injured and will not perform during the company’s Metropolitan Opera House season, the company announced on Wednesday. Mr. Hallberg, who is also a principal dancer with the Bolshoi Ballet, had foot surgery last fall.

headline: Jean-Michel Othoniel Shares His Process in a Small but Poignant Exhibition
text: For his second American museum exhibition, the French artist Jean-Michel Othoniel says he shares “the hidden part of my work.” “Secret Flower Sculptures,” on view beginning March 12 at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, explores the artistic process he began developing four years ago, when he was an artist in residence at the Gardner. (It was then that he also discovered an 18th-century book, “The Art of Describing Dance” by Raoul-Auger Feuillet, which informed the new Water Theater grove design he created in collaboration with the landscape architect Louis Benech, which opens to the public at the garden of Versailles this spring.)

headline: 1940: French Develop Pursuit Planes
text: The French aviation industry has developed a pursuit plane whose speed exceeds that of the renowned Messerschmitt 110, it was learned yesterday [March 4]. According to an official source the plane will be in mass production by the end of June. A spokesman of the Air Ministry said the development of this craft would not mean the curtailment of purchases of Curtiss pursuit planes in the United States. He said the Curtiss ships are equal in speed to the Messerschmitts and far more maneuverable and would supplement the French production. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 5, 1940

headline: Actavis’s Bond Sale Demonstrates Investor Hunger for High-Yield Debt
text: Actavis is showcasing the value of being barely investment grade. They yield less than a bigger and higher-rated debt issue that Verizon did in 2013. Buyers of top-tier debt can’t help but keep looking further downward.

headline: 36 Hours in Rome
text: Paolo Sorrentino’s mesmerizing film “La Grande Bellezza” (“The Great Beauty”), which won an Oscar for best foreign-language film in 2014, sparked controversy and endless conversation about the current state of the Italian capital. But one fact was indisputable: Rome, as the film’s seductive backdrop, was gorgeous. This is true in every season, but especially in colder months when the summer flood of tourists ebbs. From outlying neighborhoods that beckon with new restaurants and bars, to the historic center, where Mr. Sorrentino’s protagonist, Jep, wandered through so many scenes, Rome remains poised to prove that its beauty runs deep.

headline: High Rent, Low Wages
text: Recently, gasoline prices have been falling, and pulling down inflation with them. But prices have also dropped for a range of other consumer goods, including new and used cars and trucks, appliances and furniture, groceries and alcoholic beverages. It is possible to chalk up oil prices to volatile movements that are as likely to go up as down. But falling inflation more broadly is a sign of economic weakness, because in a healthy economy, prices rise along with improving conditions.

headline: Classical Playlist: Schumann, Bach, Prokofiev and More
text: SCHUMANN: String Quartets No. 1, 2 and 3Ying Quartet(Sono Luminus DSL-92184)Though the 200th anniversary of Schumann’s birth was celebrated in 2010, this year, for whatever reasons, has seen a burst of new Schumann recordings, especially of the four symphonies. Now the impressive Ying Quartet offers this rewarding recording of Schumann’s three string quartets (No. 1 in A minor, No. 2 in F, No. 3 in A). The ensemble, originally comprised of four siblings, came to attention in 1992 upon the members’ graduation from the Eastman School of Music. (Three of the siblings remain; Ayano Ninomiya has been first violinist since 2010.) These insightful performances balance Romantic impetuosity with refinement and intelligence. (The album comes with a standard CD and an additional Pure Audio Blu-ray version.) (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Doug Wright’s ‘Posterity,’ With John Noble and Hamish Linklater
text: Characters with thorns, plucked from history in all their contrariness, have been an abiding source of inspiration for Doug Wright. A Marquis de Sade in extremis was the central figure in “Quills,” which won Mr. Wright an Obie Award in 1996.

headline: Indian Official on Rapist’s Interview

headline: Iraqis Want Lead Role in Driving ISIS From Mosul

headline: JPMorgan Promotes Two to Run Mergers in North America

headline: Bouchra Jarrar’s Paris Short List
text: Like Paris itself, Bouchra Jarrar’s clothes fuse traditional elegance with contemporary cool. The designer founded her namesake line, which includes both haute couture and ready-to-wear collections, in 2010 after a decade and a half spent in some of the city’s top ateliers, including stints as Nicolas Ghesquiere’s studio manager at Balenciaga and as head of couture design at Christian Lacroix. Her fastidiously tailored daywear has since achieved cult-favorite status thanks to such signatures as couture-grade motorcycle jackets and expertly cut pants.

headline: European Court Upholds British View on Euro Clearinghouses
text: LONDON — In a judgment with political and financial ramifications, a European court on Wednesday ruled that the European Central Bank cannot require financial houses that clear trades of euro-denominated securities to be in eurozone countries.

headline: Is There Life After Hermès?
text: PARIS — Christophe Lemaire, the whispery, whiskery designer of Lemaire, is an odd avatar of steel-spined grit. He’s a philosophe of fashion, given to long pauses for thought as he chews over how and why he makes the clothes he makes. He dresses plainly, in Japanese-denim work shirts tucked into Japanese-denim jeans. He doesn’t broadcast bravery.

headline: Chrissie Hynde to Publish Memoir
text: The golden women of rock ‘n’ roll have more stories to tell.

headline: Ben Bernanke Has an Impressive Passive-Aggressive Streak, and Other Things We Learned in the New Fed Transcripts
text: The annual release of transcripts of Federal Reserve meetings is a time to take stock of how some of the nation’s top economic policy makers made their decisions, with the comfortable advantage of five years of hindsight.

headline: Children Return to School in Liberia as Ebola Outbreak Ebbs
text: Ebola cases have receded into the single digits in Liberia, but fear of the virus and a depressed economy have dampened a back-to-school campaign.

headline: Back to School, Though Not Back to Normal, in a Liberia Still Fearful of Ebola
text: MONROVIA, Liberia — A couple of dozen students sat quietly inside the C.D.B. King Elementary School’s dim and dusty auditorium on their first morning back. Despite the stuffy heat, many of the children wore long sleeves and trousers that covered as much skin as possible.

headline: Children Return to School in Liberia as Ebola Outbreak Ebbs
text: Ebola cases have receded into the single digits in Liberia, but fear of the virus and a depressed economy have dampened a back-to-school campaign.

headline: With Negative Rates, Europe Is Entering a No-Default World
text: In a world of negative interest rates, it certainly pays to be a borrower, Shakespeare’s concerns notwithstanding.

headline: Ferguson Police Department Report
text: Investigation of the Ferguson Police Department by the Department of Justice.

headline: Justice Department Report on Shooting of Michael Brown
text: Department of Justice report into the shooting death of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., in August.

headline: Researchers Report Milestone in Developing Quantum Computer
text: Scientists at the University of California, Santa Barbara, and at Google reported on Wednesday in the journal Nature that they had made a significant advance that brings them a step closer to developing a quantum computer.

headline: Interview Renews Horror of New Delhi Gang Rape
text: A new documentary that includes an interview with one of the men who raped and brutalized a woman aboard a private bus in New Delhi in 2012 has reignited passions about the case.

headline: Verbatim: A Tortured Phrase
text: – Josh Earnest, White House spokesman, questioning the basis for the case against the Affordable Care Act heard Wednesday at the Supreme Court.

headline: U.S. Jury Convicts Man Charged in a Britain Bomb Plot
text: A 28-year-old Pakistani man who represented himself at trial was convicted on Wednesday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn of supporting terrorism and conspiring with Al Qaeda to bomb a shopping center in Manchester, England.

headline: Charlie Hebdo Documentary to Be Shown in New York
text: Two months after the deadly terrorist attack on the Paris office of Charlie Hebdo, a 2008 documentary about that satirical newspaper will be screened at New York’s IFC Center on Monday. Bob Mankoff, cartoon editor of The New Yorker, will introduce the film.

headline: A Review of Digital Tools for Artists, Photographers and Writers
text: For a budding artist, a simple pen and paper may seem a bit old-fashioned in the age of iPad animation tools. Today, there are smart notebooks that can turn drawings into digital concepts, new types of camera gear that can work a smartphone and keyboards made for the multitasker.

headline: British Property Secrecy Could Hide Crimes, Report Says
text: LONDON — Foreign companies registered in offshore tax havens like the British Virgin Islands own 36,342 buildings in London that could be used for illegal purposes, a report by Transparency International said on Wednesday.

headline: Atomic Dilemma: Debating How to Prevent Iran From Developing Nuclear Weapons
text: Overview |  The United States, Israel, Saudi Arabia and other allies agree that Iran must not be allowed to develop a nuclear weapon. But beyond that consensus, there is a fundamental split in what is the best way to achieve that goal. Is it diplomacy? Is it punishment, in the form of economic sanctions, and threats, in the form of imminent military action? And even if negotiations yield an agreement, will a country like Iran, with which the United States has had no formal relations since 1979, abide by an agreement, or will it simply use the accord as a cover for producing a breakout weapon? These are tough questions. And the best answer is up for debate — the kind of complex real-world debate students can participate in, write about and learn from in this lesson.

headline: In Lincoln Exhibit, Witnesses to History
text: Notes from Abraham Lincoln’s autopsy will be on display at the Fenimore Art Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y., starting April 1.

headline: Senate Fails to Override Obama’s Keystone Pipeline Veto
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Wednesday failed to override President Obama’s veto of a bill that would have approved construction of the controversial Keystone XL oil pipeline.

headline: The Sleek, Somber Side of Yang Li’s Beauty Look
text: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways.

headline: France Is Rebuked Over Corporal Punishment by Parents
text: France has gotten a diplomatic slap on the wrist over spanking.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Ben Carson on Prisons and Gay ‘Choice’
text: In an interview with CNN’s Chris Cuomo, Ben Carson, the neurosurgeon who may run for president as a Republican in 2016, explained why he thinks being gay is a choice.

headline: What to Know About Bank Stress Tests
text: Wall Street is on edge as it awaits the release of the results of the Federal Reserve’s stress tests.

headline: Dinosaurs Forever
text: New picture books include "Dinosaur vs. Mommy" and "If I Had a Triceratops."

headline: Jittery Alex Rodriguez Gets a Hit and Fist Bumps in His Spring Debut
text: TAMPA, Fla. — A fly ball had barely settled into the glove of Yankees left fielder Ramon Flores — the final out of the top of the first inning — when Alex Rodriguez popped out of the dugout and into the on-deck circle. He was taking practice swings with a weighted bat before all of his teammates had made it off the field.

headline: Review: ‘American Crime,’ a Series Where Justice Is Far From Black or White
text: The crime doesn’t seem to be about race. But everything around it — the rage of the accused, the grief of the victims’ families, the investigation, the defense and the prosecution — is tinged with prejudice of one kind or another.

headline: Syrian Opposition to Post Dead Detainees’ Photos
text: WASHINGTON — The Syrian opposition on Wednesday began posting about 4,000 photographs of detainees who have died in President Bashar al-Assad’s prisons so that family members can try to identify the victims and potentially serve as plaintiffs in war crimes cases that could be filed in courts in Europe and possibly the United States.

headline: Outdated Encryption Keys Leave Phones Vulnerable to Hackers
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A government policy that forbade the export of products with strong encryption in the 1990s has years later left users of devices like Android and Apple phones vulnerable to hackers when they visit one-third of all websites, including whitehouse.gov and nsa.gov.

headline: The Supreme Court and the Fate of American Health Care
text: In 2012, the chief justice of the United States, John Roberts Jr., saved the Affordable Care Act by a single, surprising vote. On Wednesday morning, the chief justice was again expected to hold the decisive vote as the Supreme Court heard extended oral argument in the latest assault on President Obama’s signature health care law.

headline: Clash of Views on Netanyahu’s Speech
Herringbone Hits the Runways for Fall 2015
text: Herringbone, traditionally a men’s wear suiting pattern, is no stranger to the women’s wear runways. And for fall 2015, designers are pushing long, dramatic lengths of it, nearly from head to toe. Back in New York, DKNY and Marc Jacobs introduced it on a large coat and ladylike cape, respectively. And in Milan, Prada went for a more masculine shape befitting the fabric’s roots: a retro suit accented with bright gem tones in keeping with the house’s colorful show.

headline: First Draft Focus: Making It Official
text: President Obama thanked Congress before signing the bill approving appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security this fiscal year.

headline: More Children Eat Fruit in School, Study Shows
text: WASHINGTON — Changes made to government-subsidized meals by the Obama administration to get schoolchildren to eat more fruits are having their intended effect, according to a study released on Wednesday.

headline: Ferguson Police Tainted by Bias, Justice Department Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Wednesday called on Ferguson, Mo., to overhaul its criminal justice system, declaring that the city had engaged in so many constitutional violations that they could be corrected only by abandoning its entire approach to policing, retraining its employees and establishing new oversight.

headline: Big Sean Opens at No. 1
text: The 26-year-old rapper Big Sean is a protégé of Kanye West, and gets plenty of paparazzi attention as the boyfriend of the pop starlet Ariana Grande. Now he has another claim to fame: a No. 1 album.

headline: F.D.U.-Florham, Division III Champion, Sets Its Sights on Repeating
text: Marc Mitchell was born and raised in Newark. Now 46, he has coached New Jersey basketball teams — recreation league, middle school, high school and college — for more than 20 years.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 3, Episode 10 Recap: Petrov and the Jordan Valley
text: Season 3, Episode 10: Chapter 36

headline: Taxi Flings Take a Back Seat to Uber
text: It started innocently enough: Rachel Rabbit White, a journalist in her 20s who writes about sex, was hailing a taxi with her boyfriend at the time and a female friend after a Lower East Side party.

headline: Split Over Obama’s Affordable Care Act
text: Outside the Supreme Court on Wednesday, supporters and opponents of the Affordable Care Act gathered ahead of the arguments over the fate of President Obama’s health care law.

headline: Washington Fights for Its Right to Sled
text: News from the nation’s capital: Let there be snow! And sledding!

headline: Yale Report Clears Police Officer in Encounter With Student
text: An internal investigation by the Yale University police found that one of its officers did nothing wrong when, with his gun drawn, he approached a student matching the description of a burglary suspect and ordered him to the ground.

headline: Review: Keith Jarrett at Carnegie Hall, Precise and Aglow
text: In his improvised solo piano concerts, Keith Jarrett has made it a custom to save a familiar song or two for the encores — a gleaming prize at the finish line. But of his three encores at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night, just one fit that bill: “I’m a Fool to Want You,” an abject cry of romantic despondence introduced by Frank Sinatra in 1951.

headline: Frozen Yoga? It’s Snowga
text: It seemed as if yoga should have exhausted its opportunities for expansion by now, considering it has already made such unlikely alliances as marijuana, dogs, karaoke and stand-up paddleboards. But the yoga creep carries on with what may be the practice’s strangest bedfellow yet: snow.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Iraq, South Africa and Nepal.

headline: Youth Symphony Cancels Program That Quotes ‘Horst Wessel’ Song
text: Jonas Tarm had won the kind of opportunity most young composers can only dream of: the New York Youth Symphony had commissioned a piece from him and planned to play it this Sunday at Carnegie Hall. But the youth symphony pulled his piece this week after learning that it includes a musical quotation from the “Horst Wessel” song, the Nazi anthem.

headline: The Ferguson Police Department: The Justice Department Report, Annotated
text: The Justice Department’s investigation into law enforcement in Ferguson, Mo., found that the police and courts meted out illegal and unduly harsh treatment, particularly to black people.

headline: Ice Cream as Health Food? This Bar Comes Close
text: When Alexander Soros, a son of the billionaire hedge fund manager George Soros, hosted a charity dinner in the Hamptons on a hot summer evening in July 2012, Michael Shoretz parked an ice cream cart just outside the dining area to offer samples of his new Enlightened ice cream bars.

headline: Review: Yonatan Gat Shreds Protocol in a Rampant Concert
text: For six years, until 2011, the guitarist Yonatan Gat was in Monotonix, a kind of garage-punk incursion unit from Tel Aviv. Generally, Monotonix set up on the floor of clubs, or in the middle of crowds in outdoor places, and ran rampant. The singer Ami Shalev set fire to things, swung from pipes, charged out of the room with the microphone, climbed on the audience and the other band members; the drummer Haggai Fershtman pummeled and crashed. Mr. Gat had to be the steady center of it. He had to keep the riffs going.

headline: An Eye for an Eye at Rochas
text: If spring/summer 2015 was the moment of no-makeup makeup, then fall/winter may be the season of “Can you see me now?” In a move that echoed other runways prominently featuring shapes and symbols painted onto the face (Anthony Vaccarello, Jacquemus, Gareth Pugh, Vivienne Westwood), Lucia Pieroni added paisley motifs to the model’s browbones for today’s Rochas show at the Palais de Tokyo. Using matte black Clé de Peau Beauté Intensifying Cream Eyeliner, she added accents above the eye and on the lower lid to create a bold look that made last season’s doe-eyed girl seem downright grown-up. To offset the groovy statement shape, Pieroni skipped mascara and brought a natural glow to the skin, ever so slightly groomed the girls’ brows and finished off the look with a barely-there pink pout. “We didn’t want strange,” she says. “We wanted just a little something slightly off.”

headline: Natalia Revuelta Clews, Fidel Castro Ally And Mother of His Daughter, Dies at 89
text: She was the emerald-eyed knockout of Havana society, and everyone knew her as Naty. She belonged to the Havana Country Club and lunched aboard yachts. She was married to a distinguished surgeon, and they lived in one of the best neighborhoods in the city.

headline: A Fashion Magazine’s Successful Business Model (Hint: It’s Free!)
text: Every Thursday evening, attractive young men and women gather outside select Métro stations in Paris to hand out free copies of the fashion and beauty magazine Stylist to specific commuters.

headline: Shelf, iPad, Bed Table: Reading, February 2015
text: How can you rely on someone’s opinion of a book if you don’t know what else that person likes?

headline: Vionnet: Fall 2015 RTW
text: Paris

headline: March 4, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Ukraine, South Africa, Nepal and the United States.

headline: Shopping with Antonino Buzzetta
text: With smartphones as alarm clocks, the timepiece near your pillow can simply be attractive.

headline: Children’s Lung Health Improves as Air Pollution Is Reduced, Study Says
text: For the first time, researchers have shown that reducing air pollution leads to improved respiratory function in children ages 11 to 15, a critical period of lung development.

headline: Are Manhattanites Becoming Brooklyn’s Bridge-and-Tunnel Crowd?
text: I’m a two-time bridge-and-tunnel person. Having regularly fled my native Brooklyn because it wasn’t fun enough, I’m now insinuating my way back in there because my adopted borough isn’t fun enough.

headline: Jerry Saltz, New York Magazine Art Critic, Suspended From Facebook
text: For the last eight years the veteran New York magazine art critic Jerry Saltz has built a lively and enviable following on Facebook, which he has described as his 21st-century version of art haunts like the Cedar Tavern or Max’s Kansas City. But on Wednesday, Mr. Saltz was seized by the elbows and shown the door, digitally speaking.

headline: The Supreme Court: A Full Hearing
text: Covering a big Supreme Court argument presents special challenges. There are no cameras in the courtroom, and the court does not release audio recordings until the end of the week. No electronic devices are allowed. Reporters bring only pen and paper, as in the old days.

headline: Spray Deodorants Are Rehabilitated, With Help From Europeans
text: The underarm area is about the size of a Post-it note, but our individual notions about what keeps it dry and decent smelling are as impassioned as if it were a more substantial patch of skin.

headline: Brocade Ankle Boots to Complement a Girl-Power Message at Dries Van Noten
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Review: Malpaso Dance Company Presents Two New York Premieres at the Joyce
text: Last spring, New York received a gift from Cuba: a premiere by Ronald K. Brown courtesy of Malpaso Dance Company. For its return visit to the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, the troupe, formed in 2012 by Osnel Delgado, Daile Carrazana and Fernando Sáez, hosts another impressive guest choreographer, Trey McIntyre. This prolific and much-admired dancemaker expresses playfulness without settling into a frivolous place.

headline: Raising an Artists’ Colony
text: An artists’ community has sprouted upstate among disused industrial buildings. If it continues to thrive, there will be pizza and beer for everyone.

headline: Howard Hughes Slept Here
text: The 9,000-square-foot house in Los Angeles with a pool and a past was an impulse buy.

headline: How to Wear Nude Lips Without Looking Washed Out
text: Celebrities like Jennifer Lopez and Kim Kardashian have finessed the beigey lip so expertly that it feels timeless and seductive — a signature. And nude lips are everywhere at the fall runway shows: Vera Wang, Altuzarra, Rodarte, Burberry, Prada.

headline: New Tracy Letts Play Coming to Steppenwolf Theater Next Year
text: Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago announced on Wednesday that two notable world premieres would be part of its 2015-16 season: a new play by Tracy Letts, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of “August: Osage County,” and a new adaptation of John Steinbeck’s “East of Eden” by members of the Steppenwolf team who won acclaim for an earlier staging of Steinbeck’s “Grapes of Wrath.”

headline: Justice Department’s Report on the Ferguson Police Department
text: In a scathing report released Wednesday, the Justice Department concluded that the Ferguson Police Department had been routinely violating the constitutional rights of its black residents.

headline: Van Hollen to Run For Mikulski’s Senate Seat in Maryland
text: The race to replace retiring Senator Barbara A. Mikulski in Maryland is officially on.

headline: At Evening Bar in TriBeCa, a Homey Feeling
text: A new TriBeCa spot tries something different from the usual high-end hotel bars: a feeling of home. Evening Bar, tucked off the lobby of the Smyth, is a tiny but inviting place that looks like a stylish friend’s studio apartment. A handful of leathery love seats and midcentury modern chairs is scattered around a fireplace that competes with the backlit glow of the mahogany bar.

headline: Review: On USA’s ‘Dig,’ a Murder Investigation Takes an Apocalyptic Turn
text: A red calf is born in Norway, an eerie 12-year-old boy is raised in captivity in New Mexico and a young American archaeologist is murdered in Jerusalem. The connection? Too early to tell, but all signs point to the world being saved 10 weeks from now.

headline: The Forgotten Emancipation
text: March 4, 1865, is remembered as the day of Abraham Lincoln’s Second Inaugural address, but it was also a moment that has been forgotten in the long history of slave emancipation in America.

headline: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
text: On Thursday, Dressbarn will unveil DRESSBAR, a curated collection of spring frocks available in stores and online. For the occasion, the high-street retailer will also open a New York City pop-up where you’ll find pretty numbers like a Luxe by Carmen Marc Valvo floral print fit and flare ($58). At 102 Fifth Avenue.

headline: The 20-20 Hindsight of an Instructive Deal
text: Steve Conrad of Manhasset, N.Y., teaches bridge on cruise ships. Teachers usually have a good eye for an instructive deal. Conrad sent one to me, modestly acknowledging that he had misplayed, immediately saw what he had done wrong and wished he could have taken a mulligan.

headline: Bank of England in Money Market Inquiry
text: LONDON — The Serious Fraud Office, the British agency that investigates and prosecutes fraud and corruption, is investigating whether the Bank of England played any role in rigging money market auctions during the financial crisis in 2007 and 2008.

headline: A Pop-Up Dinner Series With an Artsy Edge
text: “There’s absolutely nothing about exclusivity in what we do,” explains Waël Mechri-Yver, the founder of Babël, a New York events program he created in 2013 that has collaborated with Queen of the Night, Sleep No More and the Bowery Hotel and has just launched a monthly pop-up dinner series titled Escena Magica. “What we try to cultivate is word of mouth, and there’s no barriers. We sell our tickets online. Everything is open.”

headline: Lung Cancer Treatment Using Immune System Wins F.D.A. Approval
text: The first immune-based treatment for lung cancer won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday, and it could displace more conventional chemotherapy for certain patients, at least.

headline: World Press Photo Revokes Prize
text: PARIS — Following days of intense controversy, the jury of one of photojournalism’s top awards, the World Press Photo contest, stripped an Italian photographer of a first prize after it found that he had misrepresented the location of one of the atmospheric images.

headline: Trailer: Rendez-Vous With French Cinema
text: A preview of the series.

headline: Review: Erik Larson’s ‘Dead Wake,’ on the Sinking of the Lusitania
text: The Lusitania is about to sink — and sink, and sink — all over again. This May is the 100th anniversary of the attack on the grand British ocean liner by a German submarine, and the expected crop of books will commemorate the occasion. But the most attention-getting of the bunch is guaranteed to be Erik Larson’s “Dead Wake,” because Mr. Larson is an old hand at treating nonfiction like high drama. As he demonstrated with “In the Garden of Beasts” and “The Devil in the White City,” he knows how to pick details that have maximum soapy potential and then churn them until they foam.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: César Winners Fill Roster at Rendez-Vous With French Cinema
text: For most of its 20-year existence, the annual film series Rendez-Vous With French Cinema has promoted a vision of France as the most civilized and sophisticated country on earth, one ruled by a benign, eternal beauty, Catherine Deneuve. The very expression “rendez-vous” evokes a dream world of delicious secret liaisons in Parisian haunts.

headline: Where Howard Hughes Was Underfoot
text: As a house tour enticement, “Do you want to see Howard Hughes’s vault?” is pretty irresistible. Of course you want to see Howard Hughes’s vault. Who doesn’t?

headline: AbbVie to Pay $21 Billion for Pharmacyclics, Maker of a Promising Cancer Drug
text: AbbVie announced late Wednesday that it had agreed to buy Pharmacyclics, maker of a cancer drug that some analysts predict will eventually become one of the best-selling treatments for the disease, for about $21 billion.

headline: The Wassaic Project: A Festival, a ‘Beautiful’ Flood and Now Art
text: WASSAIC, N.Y. — When Bowie Zunino is interviewing candidates for residencies at the Wassaic Project, she spends a lot of time trying to talk them out of coming.

headline: Bruce Willis to Make Broadway Debut in ‘Misery’
text: Bruce Willis will make his Broadway debut this fall as the bedridden novelist in a stage adaption of “Misery,” best known from the 1990 film thriller that starred James Caan and, in an Oscar-winning performance, Kathy Bates as the psychotic fan who holds the writer hostage.

headline: Committee Investigating Benghazi Subpoenas Hillary Clinton’s Emails
text: The House committee examining the 2012 attacks on American outposts in Benghazi sent a subpoena to Hillary Rodham Clinton’s lawyer on Wednesday, requesting all emails she had in her personal account as secretary of state that relate to Libya.

headline: The Value of a Chair
text: Scott McGlasson uses organic materials to build heirloom furniture pieces. But is his method sustainable?

headline: Associated Press Threatens Legal Action Over Request for Hillary Clinton Information
text: The Associated Press said Wednesday that it was considering legal action over unfulfilled Freedom of Information Act requests for government documents covering Hillary Rodham Clinton’s tenure as secretary of state.

headline: The Feds vs. Ferguson
text: On Wednesday, the Department of Justice released the utterly devastating results of its investigation of the Ferguson Police Department.

headline: When Profits Can Become Sawdust
text: ST. PAUL — What is the value of a dining-room chair? You can’t eat it. And you can sit on the floor free, as millions (billions?) of people do.

headline: Reading The Times With David Axelrod
text: Now director of the Institute of Politics at the University of Chicago, David Axelrod was senior adviser to President Obama and is the author of “Believer: My Forty Years in Politics.”

headline: Should I Remove Sports Memorabilia Before Showing My Home?
text: It may seem disloyal to your team, but most buyers would prefer seeing a clean, uncluttered, neutral space.

headline: As Hope Solo Returns to Field, U.S. Rallies Past Norway in World Cup Tuneup
text: VILA REAL DE SANTO ANTÓNIO, Portugal — About four minutes into Wednesday’s Algarve Cup game between the United States and Norway, a Norwegian player lofted a cross toward the area in front of the Americans’ goal.

headline: The Story That Came From a Dog
text: Over the last two decades, the ceramist Rae Dunn has attracted many admirers with her intentionally imperfect handmade pieces: pared-down tableware with subtle details, whimsical teapots, earthy vases with wobbly forms. So when she published her first book, “Wilma’s World” (Chronicle Books, $15.95), it was natural to expect that it would be about ceramics.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Vionnet Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Vionnet Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Seeking Drugs and Weapons, Rikers Locks Down Inmates for 34 Hours
text: New York City correction officials this week took the unusual step of locking down more than half of the inmates at Rikers Island in their cells for 34 hours straight, as part of an effort to curb escalating gang violence.

headline: Stylish Bedside Clocks
text: Daylight saving time begins at 2 a.m. on Sunday, and in the spirit of springing forward, the interior designer Antonino Buzzetta, 30, went looking for stylish bedside clocks.

headline: Holder’s Report Describes Racial Tension
text: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. described the Justice Department’s “searing” report on Ferguson, Mo., which found deep distrust between police officers and residents.

headline: Family Wedding Forces Rubio to Skip Iowa Candidate Forum
text: And then there were 10.

headline: Not a Banister Was Changed
text: Fifty years ago, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Law was enacted to ensure that important buildings survived the whims, greed or cultural indifference of developers and city officials. Among the 31,000 properties designated as landmarks, only 117 are interiors, like City Hall, left, and the New Amsterdam Theater, right. This small fraction gets special treatment in “Rescued, Restored, Reimagined: New York’s Landmark Interiors,” a show opening on Friday at the New York School of Interior Design.

headline: Sales at Love Adorned, Waggo, Ladies & Gentlemen Studio and Design Within Reach
text: Love Adorned is discounting some bedding and home furnishings by 20 percent through March 12 (wool Pendleton Navajo Water blankets and Hidatsa Earth blankets, regularly $375 each, are $300); 269 Elizabeth Street (Houston Street), 212-431-5683, loveadorned.com.

headline: A Timeless Portrait of Nepal
text: Kevin Bubriski arrived in Nepal as a Peace Corps worker. He has returned over the decades to capture its stark landscapes and resilient people, reminders of a vanishing world.

headline: Mark Lippert, U.S. Ambassador to South Korea, Is Hospitalized After Attack
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The United States ambassador to South Korea, Mark W. Lippert, was attacked Thursday morning by a knife-wielding man who said he opposed joint American-South Korean military exercises, according to the South Korean police and journalists who were at the scene.

headline: Taubman’s New Firm, PJT Partners, Starts to Take Shape
text: A fledgling investment bank run by Paul J. Taubman, the former Morgan Stanley deal maker, is getting ready to make its Wall Street debut.

headline: A Return to Nepal
text: Kevin Bubriski’s 2015 Smartphone Photos from Nepal

headline: Etsy, Online Bazaar for Handmade Goods, Files for Initial Offering
text: Etsy was born in 2005 in a Brooklyn loft as a way for one of its co-founders to sell his handmade wooden goods.

headline: A Harmonic Convergence of Apples and Oranges
text: In a rare instance of graphic-design geekery intersecting with furniture, the Italian company Cassina is adding a new frame color to Franco Albini and Franca Helg’s 1959 Tre Pezzi (or Three Pieces) armchair to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Milan subway system that they also designed together.

headline: Putting a Mattress Through the Rinse Cycle
text: For anyone worried about dust mites or bedbugs, or about cleanup after bed-wetting, conventional mattresses have a notable weakness: They’re not washable. That’s one reason Michael Rothbard, the president of Sleep Studio, created Newton Rest, a mattress company that does away with springs and foam. Its mattresses are made with a zip-off casing containing Wovenaire, a spongy, porous block of food-grade polymer developed in Japan. Once unzipped, the casing can be washed, and the Wovenaire can be hosed in the shower. The mattresses are recyclable (the company plans to accept used-mattress returns) and highly breathable. “Air passes easily through it,” Mr. Rothbard said. “Any body heat or perspiration you have during the night dissipates.” A crib mattress ($295) is to be introduced in mid-April; adult mattresses ($1,350 to $2,450), a month later; 212-679-6679, newton.rest or newtonbaby.rest.

headline: One Sofa With the Works, Please
text: Rob Royer believes there is a yawning abyss in the furniture market between the inexpensive cookie-cutter couch and the luxury lounge. So last year he founded Interior Define to bridge the divide. The company works with factories to manufacture its own sofas, each made to order. Customers are pampered with a degree of customization (sizes, fabrics and a few other features can be selected), but the prices reflect the savings the company makes by dispensing with warehouses and middlemen. Mr. Royer estimated that his sofas cost 30 to 40 percent less than comparable ones sold by conventional retailers. (The Sloan sofa, shown here, starts at $900.) Customers can see the collections in a Chicago showroom, where Interior Define thriftily has its offices, or peruse them online. Not all of the customization options are posted on the website, he said, so be sure to ask. Information: 872-802-4119 or interiordefine.com.

headline: Clinton Hires Campaign Lawyer Ahead of Likely Run
text: While attention around Hillary Rodham Clinton has been focused on her email use as secretary of state, her team quietly brought on a new lawyer for her campaign-in-waiting two months ago.

headline: Let’s Give Color a Big (Early) Hug
text: Colorful prints for spring can’t come soon enough; footwear from Band of Outsiders; a new label showcases the work of artists and more.

headline: With Gucci’s New Creative Director, Accessories Designers Come Into the Spotlight
text: Bags and shoes have become the fulcrum of fashion house sales. So those who design them are being promoted to bring their sense to creative direction.

headline: Andrew Lack Leaves Broadcasting Board of Governors After 6 Weeks
text: WASHINGTON — Andrew Lack is leaving his position as chief executive of the Broadcasting Board of Governors, the agency announced on Wednesday, one day after it was reported that he was in advanced discussions to return to NBC to lead its news operations.

headline: In Turkey, Testing the President’s Food Not for Taste, but for Poison
text: ISTANBUL — In a modern twist on a self-preservation tactic used by cautious kings and pharaohs, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey is having his food tested before he eats — not by a human taster, though, but in the lab.
