headline: Elephants to Retire From Ringling Brothers Stage
text: In the 133 years since P. T. Barnum bought his first one, no animal has been so closely identified with the circus as the elephant, starring under the big top, adorning posters and ritually announcing the circus’s arrival with a gawk-worthy parade into town — in the case of New York, through the Midtown Tunnel.

headline: The Dilemmas of King v. Burwell
text: I haven’t commented much on the issues at play in the latest Obamacare case to reach the Supreme Court, mostly because there are so many lawyer-bloggers and health care pundits on the internet offering more informed takes than mine. But now duty calls, so here is my pundit’s view of things:

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Roland Mouret Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Roland Mouret Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Review: ‘Merchants of Doubt,’ Separating Science From Spin
text: Late last month Senator James M. Inhofe, Republican of Oklahoma, brandished a snowball on the Senate floor, suggesting that the ugly winter weather afflicting the Eastern Seaboard was evidence that global warming is a hoax. This moment of political theater was widely ridiculed (by Jon Stewart and others), but “Merchants of Doubt,” Robert Kenner’s informative and infuriating new documentary, ought to remind us that the denial of climate change is hardly a joke.

headline: U.N. Rights Chief Criticizes World Powers
text: GENEVA — The United Nations’ rights chief on Thursday delivered a blunt critique of global powers, including the United States, in a report warning that many measures adopted by governments in the name of protecting national security violated human rights.

headline: Ann Demeulemeester: Fall 2015 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Jeb Bush May Be One Bush Too Many for Rank-and-File Iowa G.O.P.
text: JEFFERSON, Iowa — Sheryl McDonald, a retiree, voted for both Presidents Bush. “But I’m finding out they did some things we got stuck with,” she said. “I do not want to see Jeb Bush run,” she added. “He turns me off.”

headline: Impertinent Collection
text: Great art speaks to us, but it’s rare that we are able to talk back. Armed with a sketchbook and a camera, our Abstract Sunday columnist stalked the halls of the Museum of Modern Art for a week this winter, using a lo-fi technique that allowed him to transform the museum’s masterpieces. By holding up his drawings between his camera and the painting, he could extend them outside their frame or highlight visual confluences among the artworks and their surroundings, creating a whole new gallery in the process.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Wild Peaches’
text: This Poetry Pairing features Elinor Wylie’s poem “Wild Peaches” and the article “Their Own Museum” by Penelope Green.

headline: Here’s What Will Truly Change Higher Education: Online Degrees That Are Seen as Official
text: Three years ago, technology was going to transform higher education. What happened?

headline: Paco Rabanne: Fall 2015 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Throwback Thursday | Feminists and Feminism, Yesterday and Today
text: Do you consider yourself a feminist? How would you define the word?

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Paco Rabanne Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: John Kerry, in Saudi Arabia, Reassures Gulf States on Iran Nuclear Talks
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Secretary of State John Kerry on Thursday sought to reassure Saudi Arabia and other Gulf states that the negotiation of a nuclear accord with Iran would not lead the Obama administration to let down its guard against any Iranian interference in the region.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Paco Rabanne Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: A Mishap Sheds Light on an Ebola Vaccine
text: The moment he felt a needle jab into his thumb in September on an Ebola ward in Sierra Leone, Dr. Lewis Rubinson knew he was at risk of contracting the deadly disease. What could he do but wait to see if he got sick, and hope that treatment would pull him through?

headline: North Korea May Have a Missionary in Custody
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The chief pastor from a Korean church in suburban Toronto who failed to return home from a humanitarian mission to North Korea is reportedly being held by the government there.

headline: Watch Your Mouth, Coach Boeheim (a Lip-Reading Fan Does)
text: Sometimes it takes a deaf man to fully appreciate what someone is saying. And so it is with Geoff Herbert and Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim.

headline: U.S. Presses U.N. on Syria Chlorine Attacks
text: The United States is pushing the United Nations Security Council to condemn the use of chlorine as a chemical weapon in Syria, and impose unspecified measures against those who use it in the future.

headline: Plane Avoids Disaster as It Skids Off a Runway at La Guardia Airport
text: For passengers flying into La Guardia Airport, the majestic New York City skyline cannot help but command attention.

headline: 1890: A Diabolical Plot
text: NEW YORK — The arrest of Mr. J. Burchell, at Niagara Falls, for the murder of Mr. F. C. Benwell, has, it is claimed, disclosed one of the darkest and most diabolical plots ever chronicled in this country. Mr. Douglas Raymond Pelley, a young Englishman who was in company with Mr. Burchell, made a statement in Court yesterday [March 5], that indicates that there had been a deep laid plot, concocted in England, to lure the unsuspecting young men into an agreement to come to this country in order to engage in a large and lucrative business.

headline: Accounts of Heartbreak in Tsarnaev Trial as Victims of Boston Marathon Bombings Testify
text: BOSTON — It was, said Jeffrey Bauman, “pure carnage.”

headline: Digital Learning Companies Falling Short of Student Privacy Pledge
text: Last month, as part of an article about data security lapses by digital learning companies, I wrote about security vulnerabilities with Raz-Kids.com, a popular reading program for elementary school students. Since then, the service has upgraded its data security by, among other things, encrypting its student accounts.

headline: M.L.S. Set to Begin 20th Season With New Lineup
text: There is much that is new about Major League Soccer as it begins its 20th season this weekend, with one team shuttered and two new ones joining, but the best news for the league and its players could be that there will be soccer at all. The new collective bargaining agreement hammered out Wednesday night clears the way for Friday night’s opening game (the defending champion, Los Angeles, will host Chicago) and a full weekend schedule highlighted by a meeting Sunday between the league’s two expansion teams, New York City F.C. and Orlando City. Surely no one was happier than they were to welcome labor peace and a chance to get started.

headline: Balmain: Fall 2015 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Paying Homage to Burgundy and Michel Lafarge
text: It was a seemingly incongruous scene: 55 worldly gastronomes who had traveled to New York from all parts of the country rising to applaud an 86-year-old farmer at one of Manhattan’s best restaurants. Only in wine do the worlds of agriculture and conspicuous consumption collide with such joyous reverence, especially when the wine is Burgundy and the farmer is Michel Lafarge.

headline: Scott Walker’s Electoral Record Is Less Impressive Than It Looks
text: Gov. Scott Walker is the rare conservative favorite who emphasizes electability. He won three contests in four years in Wisconsin, which hasn’t voted for the Republican candidate in a presidential election since 1984. He did so without compromising on the Republican Party’s core principles; instead, he prevailed in a high-profile fight with organized labor.

headline: Bravo, Ringling Brothers, for Taking Elephants Out of Circuses
text: Circuses can be entertaining and wonder-filled without relying on confined, prodded and abused elephants. That’s long been the argument of animal welfare campaigners and elephant-free circuses.

headline: New Publisher for German-Language Edition of Martin Amis’s ‘The Zone of Interest’
text: PARIS — The Swiss publisher Kein & Aber has picked up Martin Amis’s concentration-camp satire, “The Zone of Interest,” months after the author’s longtime German and French publishers rejected it.

headline: Balmain’s Diamond in the Coif
text: At Balmain’s fall 2015 fashion show, the designer Olivier Rousteing sent the house’s signature brand of no-nonsense foxiness down the runway. For the hair, the stylist Sam McKnight took cues from Lauren Hutton in “American Gigolo” and Michelle Pfeiffer in “Scarface,” but wanted to “modernize the gloss,” he says. McKnight started by ironing out any wave in the hair, squared off the edges for a blunt, clean line and then went for a deep side part. The real key, however, was to have one side slicked back and tucked behind the ear so that the single, enormous agate earring that accessorized many of the looks was properly shown off.

headline: House of Inasal
text: Filipino comfort food in Woodside, Queens.

headline: Straight From Filipino Streets
text: “Unlimited rice”: It is a siren call. At House of Inasal, a Filipino restaurant that opened last year in Woodside, Queens, it’s the happy surprise waiting on the first page of the menu, announced by a speech bubble cut out of kraft paper and taped in the margin.

headline: Barcelona’s Mobile World
text: Many of the world’s top smartphone makers — with the notable exception of Apple — converged at the Fira Gran Via complex in Barcelona this week with the aim of enticing buyers around the globe.

headline: Peter Madoff’s Former Home Sells for $3.5 Million
text: The Long Island estate of Peter B. Madoff, the younger brother of Bernard L. Madoff, has been sold for several million dollars less than its original asking price, after years of efforts to find a buyer.

headline: Andrew Solomon Named President of PEN American Center
text: The author Andrew Solomon has been elected to be president of the literary and human rights organization PEN American Center.

headline: Larger-Than-Life Advertising Imagery, Brought Down to Size
text: Natan Dvir’s “Coming Soon” photography series captures the collision between aspirational commercial displays and the mundanity of everyday life.

headline: South Korea Says Attacker of U.S. Ambassador, Mark Lippert, Acted Alone
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The South Korean police said Friday that they were seeking to bring attempted murder and other criminal charges against an anti-American activist who slashed the United States ambassador to South Korea, Mark W. Lippert, with a kitchen knife.

headline: 1977 | Home Opens Its Doors
text: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

headline: Bertrice Small, 77, Writer of Risqué Romance Novels, Dies
text: Bertrice Small, a convent-educated writer whose dozens of bodice-ripping romance novels titillated readers for decades, died on Feb. 24 at her home in Southold, N.Y., leaving her 57th novel unfinished. She was 77.

headline: Chef Lineup Announced for Dan Barber’s Food Waste Pop-Up, WastED
text: A high-profile experiment in wasting nothing will start on March 13 at Dan Barber’s Blue Hill restaurant in Greenwich Village. That’s when the restaurant will turn into a pop-up called wastED, to run through the end of the month, with a menu of dishes devised from leftovers like stems, peelings, rinds and bones, by a roster of guest chefs who will change each evening.

headline: Last Known Ebola Patient in Liberia Is Discharged
text: Liberia’s last Ebola patient was discharged on Thursday after a ceremony in the capital, Monrovia, bringing to zero the number of known cases in the country and marking a milestone in West Africa’s battle against the disease.

headline: Boehner Sticks to Foreign Policy, Pressing to Arm Ukraine
text: Days after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel spoke before Congress at his invitation, Speaker John A. Boehner deepened his focus on foreign policy on Thursday by urging President Obama to arm the Ukrainian military.

headline: Explicit Artwork on Display in London, but Not for Everyone
text: LONDON — Jake and Dinos Chapman’s sexually explicit artwork “Bring Me the Head Of …” — a video, played on loop, of a 10-minute lesbian sex scene — was banned by the police when it was first displayed at the Ridinghouse Editions gallery here in 1995.

headline: The Red Carpet, Fashion's 5th City
text: Fashion month marches into its homestretch. And yet, despite the recreating of Diana Vreeland’s apartment at Marc Jacobs in New York, a waterfall at Hunter in London and a giant boom box at Moschino in Milan, it’s hard not to think the most headline-grabbing show of the season may have already happened in a town not generally known for its ready-to-wear cred.

headline: After Menopause, Female Killer Whales Take Lead in Finding Food
text: Despite no longer reproducing, postmenopausal female whales play a crucial role in the survival of killer whales, researchers have found. With extensive knowledge of their environment, female whales in their 70s and 80s lead younger whales to food in times of scarcity.

headline: LVMH Celebrates Its Designer Search
text: PARIS — “Is this the god of London?” Kanye West exclaimed to the English designer Craig Green before hopping into Mr. Green’s booth and gamely strapping into one of his armor-like, tunic-cum-breastplate designs.

headline: In Paris, Affairs à La Mode
text: PARIS — The thousands of cadenas d’amour, or love locks, attached to the Pont des Arts are hidden by graffiti-covered hoarding these days, there to discourage anyone from adding to the wishes that are endangering the bridge, but along the sides the locks poke out, impossible to contain. It’s not that dissimilar from the situation on the runways.

headline: Julien Dossena on His 10 Most Prized Possessions
text: In just a few seasons, Julien Dossena has made Paco Rabanne new again. The young Frenchman, who spent several years toiling under Nicolas Ghesquière at Balenciaga before his appointment, has created a high-tech, athletic-inflected style that’s true to the house’s space-age spirit yet free of mod clichés. (Even the brand’s signature material, chain mail, looks new — and feels light — under his direction.)

headline: Out There | Einstein’s Telescope
text: From 2015: A century after Albert Einstein proposed that gravity could bend light, astronomers now rely on galaxies or even clusters of galaxies to magnify distant stars.

headline: Astronomers Watch a Supernova and See Reruns
text: It’s “Groundhog Day” in the cosmos.

headline: Patricia Arquette and Mary J. Blige Starring in Films Added to Tribeca Festival Lineup
text: New films featuring Patricia Arquette, Oscar Isaac, Jessica Biel and Matthew Broderick will screen in the Spotlight section of the Tribeca Film Festival, organizers announced Thursday.

headline: Ancient Mars Had an Ocean, Scientists Say
text: After six years of planetary observations, scientists at NASA say they have found convincing new evidence that ancient Mars had an ocean.

headline: Iowa Radio Host’s Call to Abandon G.O.P. Falls on Deaf Ears
text: In Iowa, the power of deeply conservative talk radio hosts on the powerhouse station WHO-AM is fabled. A drive-time host in 2008 who relentlessly criticized Mitt Romney was partly credited with his poor caucus showing.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: blood letting, attention deficit and sleep risks. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: In Germany, an Ugly Past Rears Its Head
text: BERLIN — The past lurks here like a tripwire.

headline: El Niño Forms, but Forecasters See Little Weather Impact
text: Federal government scientists say that a long-anticipated El Niño weather pattern formed in the Pacific Ocean last month, but that it will most likely have little significant impact worldwide.

headline: Gerhard Richter, Damon Albarn and Björk Among Highlights of Manchester International Festival
text: Gerhard Richter, Arvo Pärt, Björk, Douglas Gordon, Charlotte Rampling and Damon Albarn are among the artists participating in this year’s Manchester International Festival, which announced its schedule on Thursday.

headline: Indians Find Ways to See Rape Documentary Despite Ban
text: NEW DELHI — A British-made documentary about a grisly gang rape in India spread throughout social media on Thursday, thwarting official efforts to block it and gaining a wide audience despite a government ban.

headline: Rick Owens: Fall 2015 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Google Introduces Long-Anticipated Insurance Shopping Site
text: The United States insurance industry has been anticipating — or dreading — Google’s entry into insurance shopping for the better part of a year. The wait is over.

headline: Björk, a One-of-a-Kind Artist, Proves Elusive at MoMA
text: The prodigious Icelandic musical phenomenon Björk is the most avant-garde popular artist of her time, the creative force behind extraordinary music videos and also one of the most instinctive of talents. So she probably should have trusted her first response — No thanks — when the Museum of Modern Art came calling.

headline: Sacred Space
text: The photographer Massimo Vitali lives with his wife and son in Lucca, Italy, in a 14th-century church that lay empty for 17 years.

headline: Egypt Replaces Minister Who Helped Quell Dissent
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s interior minister, who played a central role in the military-backed government’s far-reaching and ruthless crackdown on political dissent, was removed from his post on Thursday in a cabinet shake-up announced by the president’s office.

headline: Attacks Cripple 11 Oil Fields, Libya Says
text: CAIRO — The Libyan national oil company declared 11 oil fields nonoperational because of “theft, looting, sabotage and destruction” by “unidentified armed groups,” the company said in a statement late Wednesday.

headline: Christie Administration Officials Praise Deal With Exxon
text: The administration of Gov. Chris Christie offered details for the first time on Thursday about its settlement of a legal battle with Exxon Mobil Corporation over contamination in which the company agreed to pay a fraction of the damages that the State of New Jersey had sought.

headline: Fastest Star in the Galaxy Got an Unusual Start
text: Hurtling through the galaxy at about 1,200 kilometers per second is a compact helium star with an unusual origin. Unlike most high-velocity stars, scientists say this one — thought to be the fastest unbound star in the galaxy — was set in motion not by the black hole at the center of our galaxy, but by a former companion.

headline: Heavy Politics
text: A few days ago Bloomberg had a great story about the politicization of pizza — which is part of the broader pattern in which nutrition and obesity have become deeply partisan. Big Pizza is now an industry as dedicated to the GOP as coal or tobacco.

headline: The Ferguson Nightmare
text: The Justice Department report on the bigoted law enforcement practices used in Ferguson, Mo. illustrates two things very clearly. First, that racism tainted virtually every decision local government made. Second, the city’s decision to raise significant revenue through fines transformed both the police department and the courts into instruments of white supremacy and economic repression. These excerpts give a sense of the nightmarish conditions under which black citizens of Ferguson and nearby St. Louis County municipalities have lived as a result.

headline: Eaton Vance Charts Exchange-Traded Future
text: Thomas E. Faust Jr. does not come across as an industry disrupter. He is the chief executive of Eaton Vance, a midsize fund company in Boston that has carved out a solid yet unspectacular niche as a provider of investment funds and advice.

headline: De Blasio and Developer Are Close, but Not on Lower-Cost Housing
text: Unlike many of his more wary real estate brethren, Rob Speyer moved quickly to build a strong relationship with New York’s liberal mayor, Bill de Blasio, after his election in 2013.

headline: Glacier to Yellowstone on a Bike
text: Cycling from Glacier National Park to Yellowstone might seem like an intense endeavor, but to guides at the Cycling House in Missoula, Mont., “it’s just a chance to take off work, see some beautiful scenery and get to know people,” Shaun Radley, the company’s director of operations, said of its new summer excursion.

headline: Big Donors Are Asked to Encourage a ‘Civil’ G.O.P. Primary
text: Foster Friess, the businessman who helped finance Rick Santorum’s 2012 presidential campaign through large donations to the outside group supporting his candidacy, is asking his fellow multimillionaire donors to press the Republican field to be “civil” during the party’s primary in 2016.

headline: Live Chat About Finding That ‘Sweet Spot’ in Life and Work
text: Join me and “The Sweet Spot” author Christine Carter for a live chat about finding your groove at home and work. Christine coached three readers with three very specific problems: finding more time to exercise, ending an email obsession, and focusing on work in a home office where distractions are just a kitchen away.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 3, Episode 11 Recap: Every Seven Years
text: Season 3, Episode 11: Chapter 37

headline: Cardinal Edward M. Egan, 82, Dies; Led New York Archdiocese in Trying Time
text: Cardinal Edward M. Egan, a stern defender of Roman Catholic orthodoxy who presided over the Archdiocese of New York for nine years in an era of troubled finances, changing demographics and an aging, dwindling priesthood shaken by sexual-abuse scandals, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 82.

headline: Broncos’ Peyton Manning to Play in 2015
text: Quarterback Peyton Manning, a perennial Pro Bowl selection and a sure shot for the Pro Football Hall of Fame, will return for the 2015 season after he reworked his contract with the Denver Broncos.

headline: Success Runs Deeper Than All the 3-Pointers
text: FORT MYERS, Fla. — About an hour before the start of an afternoon practice last week, Kaneisha Atwater shot dozens of 3-pointers as a wall-mounted computer called the Noah Instant calculated the trajectory of each attempt.

headline: Why AbbVie May Have Overpaid for Cancer Drug Maker
text: AbbVie’s chief executive may have overpaid once again.

headline: Letters: ‘Chasing the Scream’
text: ‘Chasing the Scream’

headline: California Senate Race Gets a Republican Contender
text: California now has a Republican contender for its soon-to-be open Senate seat.

headline: J. Crew’s New, Very French Stripes — and Address
text: Come tomorrow, J. Crew will be the new American in Paris when it opens its first shop in the Marais, the brand’s second location in Europe apart from its four London posts. The 1,800-square-foot space, housed inside a restored storefront made of lacquered brass, antique oak and marble, will be dedicated to the women’s collection (a men’s boutique is set to debut in the City of Light later this year). In celebration, the design team has partnered with Saint James, famous for its Parisian chic sailor stripes, on a 33-piece collection of one-of-a-kind tees exclusive to the new address (€85 – €250). “We thought about Brigitte Bardot, baguettes and berets,” the creative director Jenna Lyons explains about the tops. She sums them up as being “unique and a bit bonkers.”

headline: Guest Post | Analyzing the Elements of Art: Six Ways to Think About Shape
text: March is National Youth Arts Month, and we’re collaborating with KQED Art School to explore one of the seven elements of visual art — shape — and suggest ways to apply the ideas to images and articles found in The New York Times.

headline: A Wink at the Quirks of a Famed Collector
text: Now that the Barnes Foundation has weathered its move from Albert Barnes’s home in suburban Merion, Pa., to downtown Philadelphia in 2012, it seems newly game to look at itself with a bit of irreverence.

headline: Nasdaq Changed in Its Climb to 5,000
text: That the Nasdaq composite index closed over 5,000 this week for the first time in 15 years is not just a reminder of the virtues of patience. It’s even more a testament to the transformative power of capitalism.

headline: States Weigh Legislation to Let Businesses Refuse to Serve Gay Couples
text: ATLANTA — As it looks increasingly likely that the Supreme Court will establish a nationwide right to same-sex marriage later this year, state legislatures across the country are taking up bills that would make it easier for businesses and individuals to opt out of serving gay couples on religious grounds.

headline: Review: ‘The Last Flight of Poxl West’ by Daniel Torday
text: In summary, the plot of Daniel Torday’s evocative first novel, “The Last Flight of Poxl West,” may sound a little schematic. A 15-year-old boy named Eli worships his uncle Poxl, who writes a well-received memoir about his heroic exploits as a bomber pilot during World War II. But in the wake of the book’s success, Eli discovers that Poxl is not exactly who he has pretended to be.

headline: McDonald’s Asks a Band to Play for Free Food, but No Money at SXSW
text: With each passing year, raging against the invasion of brands at the South by Southwest music festival feels more futile. Once known as a pre-Internet launching pad for emerging independent musicians, the industry bacchanal in Austin, Tex., taking place this year from March 17 to 22, has grown into a sometimes uncomfortable hodgepodge of acts still striving to make it big and more established stars performing amid an onslaught of hashtags, according to some veteran observers.

headline: ISIS Is Adept on Twitter, Study Finds
text: The Islamic State, the violent extremist group that espouses a return to a seventh-century caliphate, has been astonishingly successful at spreading its message using 21st-century social media, according to a study released Thursday.

headline: A Different Kind of Protest in Washington
text: Many used Thursday’s snowstorm to hold a “Sled-In,” openly defying a ban on sledding on Capitol Hill grounds.

headline: In Ellen Pao’s Suit vs. Kleiner Perkins, World of Venture Capital Is Under Microscope
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Speak up — but don’t talk too much. Light up the room — but don’t overshadow others. Be confident and critical — but not cocky or negative.

headline: Review: ‘Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt’ Features a Midwestern Fish Out of Water
text: There was a time when just being from the Midwest was funny. That was the joke of “Wonderful Town,” the 1953 musical about two sisters from Columbus, Ohio, who move into a basement apartment in Greenwich Village with eccentric neighbors and a kooky landlord. (“Why, oh why, oh why, oh — why did I ever leave Ohio?”)

headline: First Draft Focus: Civil Disobedience, by Sledding
text: Many used Thursday’s snowstorm to hold a “Sled-In,” openly defying a ban on sledding on Capitol Hill grounds.

headline: Events at the Brooklyn Museum and the United Palace Theater
text: In a city like New York, having countless entertainment options to choose from on a Saturday night can lead to paralyzing indecision and the strange feeling that there’s nothing to do.

headline: Young Designers Revive Sweater Dresses on the Runway
text: Ah, the sweater dress: an easy piece to dress up or down, and a year-round, lazy-day staple. But thanks to this season’s new ribbed knit dresses, updated by a trio of cool, new, young designers, the garment will become less of a throw-on-and-go piece and more of an I-have-arrived look by fall. In London, Thomas Tait and the design duo at Marques’Almeida both introduced dresses in bright, poppy colors and asymmetrical silhouettes. And today in Paris, Sébastien Meunier presented a darker version on the Ann Demeulemeester runway. Each drapes the body for a cozy yet sophisticated feel — even when matched with a pair of chunky white sneakers.

headline: Florida Gulf Coast Women Aim High
text: Images from a day with the women’s basketball team at Florida Gulf Coast University, which is 27-2 and ranked No. 20 entering the quarterfinals on Friday of the Atlantic Sun Conference tournament.

headline: Art of Internment Camps Will Head to Auction
text: ART OF INTERNMENT CAMPS

headline: A Giant Picture of Snow Across the United States
text: These composite satellite images compare snow cover in February from 2013 to 2015.

headline: McConnell Changes Course on Iran Vote
text: Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican majority leader, changed course Thursday in the face of opposition from Democrats and opted against pushing ahead with a bipartisan bill that would give Congress the authority to review any nuclear deal with Iran.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Rick Owens Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Erin Baiano.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Rick Owens Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Erin Baiano.

headline: A Year After Flight 370’s Disappearance, Grief and Anger Endure
text: Nearly a year ago, on March 8, Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 left Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, for Beijing. The Boeing 777 was due to arrive with 239 crew members and passengers, among them more than 150 Chinese citizens. About 40 minutes after takeoff, contact between the aircraft and air traffic controllers ceased. Hundreds of relatives of the Chinese passengers traveled to Beijing and waited for weeks in a hotel for news of their loved ones.

headline: How Not to Be ‘That’ Sports Parent
text: There really is a right way and a wrong way to watch a child’s sporting events. Whether it’s soccer, hockey, baseball or dressage, the best parent-spectator is the one whose biggest concern is his child. Not whether his child’s team wins. Not his child’s performance on the ice or the field. Not his child’s playing time, his child’s penalties, his child’s coaches or his child’s teammates. Just the child. The one out there playing a game and (one hopes) having fun.

headline: Court Upholds Right of Reporter to Publish Excerpts From Diary of James Brown’s Wife
text: In a freedom of speech case, South Carolina’s Supreme Court ruled Wednesday that Sue Summer, a reporter for The Newberry Observer, could publish the diary of a woman recently recognized as the wife of the singer James Brown. Ms. Summer had published excerpts from the diary as part of her coverage of the continuing dispute over the distribution of Mr. Brown’s estate.

headline: Mail Trucks of the Past
text: A look back at postal vehicles of the last 120 years.

headline: Review: ‘Ennion,’ at the Met, Profiles an Ancient Glassmaker
text: If the name Ennion is familiar to you, you probably are a scholar or collector of ancient glassware, and you’ll appreciate the significance of “Ennion: Master of Roman Glass,” a small exhibition of ancient glassware at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. But you don’t have to be a specialist to profit from this lovely and informative show.

headline: To Explain Missing Malaysia Airlines Flight, ‘Rogue Pilot’ Seems Likeliest Theory
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The retired chief pilot of Malaysia Airlines is torn between logic and loyalty to an old friend. Nik Huzlan, 56, was one of the first captains to fly the 12-year-old Boeing 777 that disappeared over the Indian Ocean a year ago this Sunday. He has known the pilot who flew the plane that day, Zaharie Ahmad Shah, for decades.

headline: Organic Ice Cream for Tongue-in-Cheek Types
text: If the two new flavors being introduced by Three Twins Ice Cream this week, in honor of its 10th anniversary, sound a little familiar, it’s with good reason: “We’ve heard these flavors remind some people of those two guys up in Vermont,” the brand’s founder, Neal Gottlieb, says slyly. Banana Nut Confetti and Cherry Chocolate Chunk were designed as winking homages to Ben & Jerry’s beloved Chunky Monkey and Cherry Garcia, respectively — but with the distinction of being fully organic, which Ben & Jerry’s is not. Even the packaging is in on the joke: “We’re not monkeying around with this combination of banana, walnuts and chocolate,” declares the Banana Nut Confetti pint, while Cherry Chocolate Chunk insists, “You’ll be grateful that this sumptuous combination is available in organic.” Both ice creams are smooth, rich and fruit-driven, a fitting tribute to — dare we say improvement upon? — their inspiration.

headline: Fed's Stress Test of Big Banks: Part One
text: The nation’s largest banks have adequate capital to withstand a severe economic downturn and market turmoil, the Fed has found in its latest annual stress test.

headline: Search at Sea for Flight 370 Yields Optimism Amid Disappointment
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Despite months of disappointment, toughing out seas lashed by cyclonic winds and thousands of hours of searching for debris thought to be on a seabed almost three miles deep, Paul Kennedy is determined.

headline: Big Banks Pass Muster in Latest Stress Tests
text: The nation’s largest banks appear to have the financial strength to survive a nightmarish world where unemployment soars, house prices plummet and Wall Street crashes, the Federal Reserve said on Thursday.

headline: Jonas Kaufmann Withdraws From Second Met Performance
text: The star tenor Jonas Kaufmann has withdrawn from Saturday’s sold-out matinee performance of “Carmen” at the Metropolitan Opera, citing illness — meaning that Mr. Kaufmann, who was scheduled to sing only two performances there this season, will miss both.

headline: ISIS Attacks Nimrud, a Major Archaeological Site in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — The Islamic State militant group attacked the ancient archaeological site of Nimrud in northern Iraq and damaged it with heavy vehicles, Iraq’s Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities said Thursday.

headline: Yulia P Transforms at Rick Owens
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Yulia P before (left) and after (right) makeup by Lucia Pieroni and hair by Luigi Murenu.

headline: Jeff Koons: ‘Jim Beam — J. B. Turner Engine and Six Individual Cars’
text: In 1986, Jeff Koons produced “Luxury and Degradation,” an exhibition at International With Monument Gallery in the East Village. It featured reproductions of ads for alcoholic beverages and cast stainless-steel copies of novelty liquor decanters made by Jim Beam. Among these was a set of seven model railroad cars on a single track. Within each car was a fifth of Jim Beam whiskey with a tax-stamped top.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
text: Photos from New York, Ukraine, Russia and India.

headline: Review: Musica Sacra Highlights Living Composers
text: Musica Sacra, the notable professional chorus and mainstay of the New York choral scene, has a strong reputation both for its interpretations of the classics, such as the annual performances of Handel’s “Messiah,” and for its commissioning of new works.

headline: March 5, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from New York, Ukraine, Russia and India.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Balmain Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Balmain Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Lanvin Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: Will New York Have a Clinton-Like Email Problem?
text: The furor over former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton’s use of a personal email should be a warning to New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo.

headline: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
text: 80 YEARS AGO

headline: Passenger and Official on Plane Skidding
text: A passenger on the Delta Air Lines flight that skidded off the runway at La Guardia Airport described the scene and an official from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey gave a statement.

headline: Frank Talk on Race
text: I am an experienced public relations consultant in business for myself. Usually I am hired sight unseen after clients review my portfolio, speak with me on the telephone and check my references. But occasionally, after positive conversations, would-be clients ask to meet me in person. When they discover I am black, I almost never get the work. How can I avoid wasting my time with these meetings and alert people in advance about my race? I send my LinkedIn profile, but they rarely look at it. (And for the record, people find me affable and attractive.)

headline: Reveling in a Role
text: As the number of remaining regular-season games dwindles, ushers reflect on their experiences at Nassau Coliseum, where their jobs often felt more like a family reunion than work.

headline: A Long Island Goodbye
text: The ushers at Nassau Coliseum are institutions at the arena, which is the home rink of the Islanders until next season.

headline: Review: Handel’s ‘Semele’ Comes With Sumo Wrestlers at BAM
text: Knowing nothing about opera should disqualify a director from being invited to stage one. At least you would think so. Yet many companies boast of recruiting neophyte directors as a way to shake up the art form. Alas, a lot of trendy, clueless productions have resulted.

headline: Joan Waltemath: ‘One does not negate the other’
text: Painting and architecture used to be much closer, such that at least during the Renaissance artists sometimes practiced both. Joan Waltemath is a painter, although she taught at the architecture school at Cooper Union for many years, but her works are planned and constructed almost like buildings.

headline: ‘Once Upon a Time and Now’
text: In 1989, when AIDS and the culture wars were slamming the art world, the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Community Center in New York mounted a big morale-boosting group exhibition on the 20th anniversary of the Stonewall riots. Of the 50 pieces — half by men, half by women, gay and not — in that show, a few were site-specific murals and remain visible, even as the interior has changed. A current show, “Once Upon a Time and Now,” highlights and adds to them.

headline: Claudia Comte: ‘No Melon No Lemon’
text: Since opening in 2008, the Gladstone Gallery’s space on West 21st Street has emphasized large sculptures or environmental installations. In December, for example, the painter R. H. Quaytman put abstract painting and architecture on a collision course with challenging, if decidedly confused, awkward results. Now the Swiss-born, Berlin-based artist Claudia Comte makes her American debut with roughly the opposite: a sculptural-architectural ensemble resembling a designer boutique, home furnishings store or art fair stand. This totality makes a delightful first impression, but its sources and references are startlingly obvious.

headline: U.S. Auction Suggests Lingering Interest in Bitcoin
text: The falling price of Bitcoin has not entirely quashed investor enthusiasm for the virtual currency.

headline: Pablo Helguera: ‘Strange Oasis’
text: Social practice, a recent term developed to describe art projects often staged in distinct communities and concerned with social justice issues, is hard to translate into a gallery in Chelsea. You might not even know this was a social practice-type show, except that Pablo Helguera, who also works in the education department at the Museum of Modern Art (museum education departments are hotbeds of social practice activity), is well known in the field.

headline: Lanvinrtw: Fall 2015 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Review: Sara Baras in a Flamenco Whirlwind
text: In “Voces, Suite Flamenca,” the Spanish flamenco star Sara Baras pays tribute to six luminaries of her art who have influenced her. Their likenesses appear on mobile flats that suggest monumental headstones. Their voices can be heard in recordings, expounding in Spanish on the meaning of flamenco. Live singers and guitarists add resonant voices of their own. That most of the show rings hollow is the fault of Ms. Baras.

headline: 11 Little-Known Facts About John Galliano and Alexander McQueen
text: Shocking and endearing anecdotes culled from Dana Thomas’s new book, “Gods and Kings,” about the rise and fall of the fashion designers.

headline: Thomas Struth’s Entanglement
text: The German photographer Thomas Struth, who was recently the subject of an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, seems to work at the descriptive limits of photography. His eye is meticulous, and each of his images contains a tremendous amount of information. He is perhaps best known for his large-format photographs of people in art museums. Those photographs thrill the eye with double vision: We are looking at people who are looking at something. In fact, it gets more reflexive than that: We are generally looking at these pictures in a museum, and the images are usually of people who are themselves looking at something in a museum.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Fair City
text: Scenes from the Independent and other art fairs in New York.

headline: At Rick Owens, a Sculptural Hairstyle Among the Many
text: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways.

headline: Madonna on ‘Rebel Heart,’ Her Fall and More
text: Madonna was perfectly turned out and running nearly an hour late for an interview at her Upper East Side home on Wednesday evening. She looked tense as she apologized. “I’m late for everything now,” she said.

headline: Review: ‘The Art Show’ at the Park Avenue Armory Covers the Creative Map
text: What you see on entering “The Art Show,” the annual fair of the Art Dealers Association of America, is yourself and other visitors reflected in a giant mirror. Displayed in Luhring Augustine’s booth, “Cords,” by the veteran Italian conceptualist Michelangelo Pistoletto, consists of four mirrored panels with a cutout, photographic rendering of stanchions connected by fat ropes. The ropes evoke the atmosphere of exclusivity fostered by high-end galleries like the 72 convened here. On the other hand, the mirror inclusively reflects viewers themselves and, by extension, the broader public they belong to. In art, the public might find reflections of itself and its own, ever-evolving cultural identity.

headline: Review: The 2015 Armory Show Overlaps History and Cultures
text: Now in its second decade, the Armory Show — which in 1999 itself appropriated the name from the historic 1913 Armory Show — is far past its mythic origins of 1994, when the fair opened in the Gramercy Hotel and art was displayed on hotel room beds.

headline: Review: Independent Art Fair Combines Less Is More and Growth
text: Six years ago, when it started out, the art fair called Independent really was sort of that. It had a cool guerrilla buzz. In the former Dia headquarters on West 22nd Street in Chelsea, it was tiny compared with the cattle-call Armory Show. More rebelliously, admission was free. And the look was new. Instead of booths the size of stockyard stalls, there were wide-open prairies of exhibition space on all three floors. Within these democratic vistas, you could hardly tell where one gallery ended and another began.

headline: Furor Over Clinton Emails Tests Relationship With White House
text: The uproar over Hillary Rodham Clinton’s personal email account when she was secretary of state is the most public test of her relationship with the Obama White House since her book tour last summer.

headline: An Ankle Boot with a Futuristic Heel at Paco Rabanne
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: ‘Audubon’s Aviary: The Final Flight’ Alights at the New-York Historical Society
text: JOHN JAMES AUDUBON painted many birds, but for sheer stage presence, his great gray owl is hard to beat. Perched on a rotten branch, it turns halfway, as though disturbed, and fixes the viewer with an imperious stare. The yellow eyes glow, their intensity magnified by concentric ringlike markings that spread outward, like a feathery vortex. The plumage is regal — thick drapery, in a gray and brown pattern, falling in soft folds. The owl exudes the heavy solemnity of one of Velázquez’s popes or Holbein’s portrait of Thomas More.

headline: Review: In ‘Buzzard,’ an Angry, Unkempt Antihero
text: Marty Jackitansky (Joshua Burge), the repellent protagonist of the bleakly amusing indie film “Buzzard,” is a slovenly office temp at a mortgage company in Michigan who supplements his meager income from a $9.50-an-hour job with small-time con artistry. The bank for which he works and the neighborhood where he lives are so drab that his daily routine of clerical drudgery, fast-food snacks and toxic junk-culture distractions is a living hell.

headline: Theater Listings for March 6-12
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Reaction to Regulation: 1934 vs. Today
text: Last week, the Federal Communications Commission voted to regulate Internet service as a public utility, reclassifying broadband providers under Title II of the Communications Act of 1934 and subjecting them to stricter rules. Republicans and many broadband providers have criticized the decision, arguing that it was driven by the president and gives the federal government too much control, draws on dated laws and will result in subjective interpretations of broad mandates.

headline: Comedy Listings for March 6-12
text: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Movie Listings for March 6-12
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for March 6-12
text: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: With Nemtsov’s Killing, a Leadership Void Widens for Russia’s Opposition
text: MOSCOW — Among the motley collection of former ministers, retired spies, billionaire oligarchs, intellectuals and others who constitute Russia’s anemic liberal opposition, Boris Y. Nemtsov, the Kremlin critic fatally shot last week, always stood out.

headline: Jazz Listings for March 6-12
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Dance Listings for March 6-12
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Walker Says Clinton ‘Should Answer Questions’ About Email Use
text: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a likely Republican presidential candidate in 2016, criticized Hillary Rodham Clinton for using a personal email account when she was secretary of state.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘It Follows’
text: David Robert Mitchell narrates a sequence from “It Follows,” opening March 13.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for March 6-12
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: David Robert Mitchell Narrates a Scene From ‘It Follows’
text: In this video, the writer and director David Robert Mitchell discusses the opening sequence of his teenage horror drama “It Follows,” opening March 13, about an evil force that steadily tracks its victims.

headline: Spare Times Listings for Children for March 6-12
text: ‘Letters From Anne and Martin’

headline: Spare Times Listings for March 6-12
text: Around Town

headline: Opera & Classical Music Listings for March 6-12
text: Reviews of classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Making Egypt’s Streets Safe for Women
text: Eman Helal hopes to not only document the widespread harassment of women on Cairo’s streets, but also aims to spur changes in public attitudes and behavior.

headline: Review: In ‘Chappie,’ a Smart Robot Runs With the Wrong Crowd
text: Frankenstein’s monster gets a titanium makeover in “Chappie,” a science-fiction blood-spurter and would-be heart-warmer that wavers uncertainly between laughter and tears. Set in South Africa in the usual bummer future — yet again, it’s man against man, as well as machine — the movie imagines a scenario in which tin-can police march in lock step with their human analogues to roust the usual tattooed and dreadlocked gun-toting degenerates. All the aerial shots of the dangerously swarming and swelling multitudes suggest that such draconian tactics are necessary.

headline: Lincoln and Douglass’s Last Encounter
text: As the presidential coach plowed through thick mud on Pennsylvania Avenue, Frederick Douglass sensed danger. The editor and abolitionist activist began walking as closely behind as he could, studying every onlooker for a hint of conspiracy. When they reached the Capitol for Lincoln’s Second Inaugural without incident, a relieved Douglass joined the vast crowd, finding a place in front of the East Portico.

headline: Review: ‘October Gale’ Stars Patricia Clarkson
text: A woman alone in the movies is rarely alone for long. In “October Gale,” a low-key character study gives way to increasingly clamorous melodrama when a widowed doctor, Helen (Patricia Clarkson), finds a bleeding man making a mess on the floor of her lakeside vacation home. Having gone out to inspect a noise (and left her front door open), she’s returned to find William (Scott Speedman), a handsome stranger — good looks being a prerequisite for gigs like this — with a bullet in his shoulder. While some women might run for a kitchen knife, this good doctor starts dressing his wound.

headline: This Week’s Movies | March 6, 2015
text: The New York Times film critics review “The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel,” “Merchants of Doubt” and “Chappie.”

headline: Review: ‘Kidnapping Mr. Heineken’ Revisits a 1983 Dutch Crime
text: The sole object lesson in the true-crime drama “Kidnapping Mr. Heineken” is that not every crime deserves its own movie. That much becomes clear in the director Daniel Alfredson’s dreary, uninvolving fictionalized take on the real 1983 snatching of Alfred Heineken, chairman of the company bearing his family’s name. A few years ago, the same story was turned into “The Heineken Kidnapping,” a Dutch movie with Rutger Hauer in the title role, which racked up some business in the Netherlands and is available on Amazon on demand.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Urges New York Businesses to Raise Hourly Wages to Over $13
text: Facing resistance in Albany over his calls for a minimum wage exceeding $13 an hour in New York City, Mayor Bill de Blasio took his case directly to business leaders on Thursday, urging them to raise workers’ pay to that level voluntarily.

headline: ‘The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel”
text: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel.”

headline: Reinventing the Mail Truck
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — On a recent snowy morning, Michael Ellis prepared his mail truck for the daily route he has run here for the last decade, through a neighborhood in the Washington suburbs.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Merchants of Doubt’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Merchants of Doubt.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Chappie’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Chappie.”

headline: Immigration Fight Shouldn’t Stall Vote to Confirm Lynch, Democrats Say
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats on Thursday intensified their push for a vote on the confirmation of Loretta E. Lynch as attorney general, arguing that her nomination should not be held up because Republicans are angry with President Obama over executive action on immigration.

headline: Alberto Nisman, Argentine Prosecutor, Was Killed, His Ex-Wife Says
text: BUENOS AIRES — The former wife of a federal prosecutor who died of a gunshot wound to the head after making explosive accusations against Argentina’s president charged Thursday that he had been murdered — reviving a bitter debate here over the mysterious circumstances shrouding his death.

headline: Lack of Diversity Persists in Admissions to New York City’s Elite High Schools
text: Amid calls for new admissions procedures to increase diversity in New York City’s elite public high schools, the number of black and Hispanic students winning seats remained virtually unchanged this year, according to statistics the Education Department released on Thursday.

headline: Review: In ‘Two Men in Town,’ a Parolee Is Hounded by a Cop
text: Paroled after serving 18 years in prison for the killing of a sheriff’s deputy, William Garnett tries to build a normal life in a small border town in the New Mexico desert. William, who converted to Islam in the penitentiary, buys a used motorcycle, finds a job at a ranch and begins a romance. His peace is threatened by a grudge-holding sheriff and by an old friend who wants to drag William back into his criminal ways. His parole officer does what she can to head off what seems like an inevitably tragic turn of events.

headline: Palestinian Council Questions Security Arrangement With Israel
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — A Palestinian leadership body called Thursday night for curtailing longstanding security coordination with Israel, but left decisions on when or whether to take such a step to President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority and the Palestine Liberation Organization’s executive committee.

headline: Vice Media C.E.O. Begins Move Into Washington by Meeting Senators
text: WASHINGTON — Shane Smith, the burly, bearded chief executive and self-described “pit bull” of the fast-growing Vice Media, rumbled into Washington on Wednesday for a tour, including his first private meetings with several senators.

headline: Review: In ‘Faults,’ Mind Games Don’t End Beyond the Cult
text: Cult mind games — the cultivation of blind obedience from communal devotees — are entering their own as a dramatic staple. “Sound of My Voice,” from 2012, cast Brit Marling as the charismatic leader of a mysterious sect; “Martha Marcy May Marlene,” from 2011, offered Elizabeth Olsen as a shattered escapee from a guru’s domination; and Paul Thomas Anderson’s “The Master,” from 2012, starred Philip Seymour Hoffman as a fraud sapping the free will of Joaquin Phoenix.

headline: Review: ‘An Honest Liar,’ a Documentary About the Debunker James Randi
text: “Magicians are the most honest people in the world,” the illusionist James Randi says at the beginning of “An Honest Liar.” “They tell you they’re gonna fool you, and then they do it.” Documenting a lifetime spent gulling audiences and pursuing con men, the directors Justin Weinstein and Tyler Measom have produced a jaunty, jovial portrait with a surprising sting in its tail.

headline: Review: ‘The Mind of Mark DeFriest’ Is a Documentary About a Prison Houdini
text: The indomitable personality and talents of the serial prison escapee Mark DeFriest outshine the weaknesses of this documentary that bears his name. Gabriel London’s “The Mind of Mark DeFriest” recounts how this Florida man landed in prison and kept breaking out through illegal (and often outlandish) means.

headline: Review: ‘Earth’s Golden Playground,’ a Documentary on Prospecting in the Yukon
text: Early in Andreas Horvath’s “Earth’s Golden Playground,” a look at modern-day prospectors in the Yukon territory of Canada, an underground shot at a gold dig suggests an ultra-lo-fi variation on the opening of “There Will Be Blood.” But Mr. Horvath’s procedural, increasingly dry documentary takes the “rush” out of “gold rush.”

headline: Ed Modzelewski, Fullback for Maryland and the Browns, Dies at 86
text: Ed Modzelewski, the fullback known as Big Mo, who starred with his brother Dick, the defensive tackle called Little Mo, on an undefeated University of Maryland team, then collided with him in the N.F.L. of the 1950s when his Cleveland Browns faced Dick’s Giants, died on Saturday in West Sedona, Ariz. He was 86.

headline: Review: In ‘Unfinished Business,’ Vince Vaughn and Sienna Miller Are Rivals
text: A “EuroTrip” with balance sheets, the slick, innocuous comedy “Unfinished Business” fails to seal the deal. Dan Trunkman (Vince Vaughn) is a St. Louis executive and father whose company is being restructured by Chuck Portnoy (Sienna Miller), a shark already demanding too many hours from employees. Enraged, Dan starts a rival outfit, hiring Tim McWinters (Tom Wilkinson), an older colleague forced into retirement, and Mike Pancake (Dave Franco), a young, pretty dullard.

headline: Robert G. Dean, Whose Theories on Sand Saved Beaches, Dies at 84
text: Though they have probably never heard of him, beachgoers regularly see the work of Robert G. Dean, especially if they visit towns on the barrier islands that line the East and Gulf Coasts.

headline: Schwab’s Service for Investors Seeking Thrifty Advice Raises Eyebrows
text: Charles Schwab is poised to introduce an investment service for consumers who crave low-cost personalized advice but do not have a lot of money to invest. And it is dangling an attractive lure in front of investors, in a way that its competitors have not: It says its service is free.

headline: Cardinal Edward M. Egan Dies at 82
text: Cardinal Egan was one of America’s most visible Catholic leaders.

headline: Review: ‘Deli Man’ Is a Documentary on Jewish Delis, Schmaltz and All
text: “Deli Man” examines the state of the Jewish deli through David Gruber, known as Ziggy, a founder of Kenny & Ziggy’s New York Delicatessen Restaurant in Houston. Trained in culinary school, he represents the third generation in his family to run such a restaurant, the film says; Ziggy’s grandfather was a source for many of his recipes and Yiddishisms. “Since he was a little kid, he’s been an 80-year-old Jew,” says J. Mackye Gruber, Ziggy’s brother (and the co-director of the 2004 film “The Butterfly Effect”).

headline: Harrison Ford Crashes Plane on Golf Course
text: The actor Harrison Ford was injured on Thursday when a single-engine, World War II-era training plane he was piloting crashed onto a golf course in Venice, Calif., shortly after takeoff from Santa Monica Airport.

headline: Companies Turn Tables on Human Rights Lawyers
text: Over the past decade, companies doing business in Colombia, like Chiquita Brands and Dole Food, have incurred the wrath of Terrence Collingsworth, a lawyer who has accused them of mistreating workers or conspiring to kill labor activists.

headline: AbbVie Wins Bidding War for Maker of Cancer Drug, Then Goes on Defensive
text: Robert Duggan, according to his many websites, has played basketball with Pat Riley of the N.B.A., taught his children to surf by the time they were 3 and made fortunes starting and selling companies in fields as varied as cookies and robot surgery. He is the largest donor to the Church of Scientology.

headline: A League Full of Professionals, in Actions if Not in Pay
text: BOSTON — In the Canadian Women’s Hockey League, job titles are often ambiguous.

headline: Review: ‘The Mafia Kills Only in Summer’ Is a Comical Look at the Mob
text: The best that can be said for the Italian television host Pierfrancesco Diliberto — as far as his comic, feature-film debut is concerned — is that he’s not nearly as annoying as Roberto Benigni. Granted, that’s a very low bar to clear.

headline: Gov. Christie Goes Easy on a Big Polluter
text: The state of New Jersey invested more than 10 years in a lawsuit to recover $8.9 billion in damages from Exxon Mobil Corporation for environmental contamination of more than 1,500 acres of wetlands, marshes and meadows in northern New Jersey. Exxon’s liability was not in dispute. But just as a state judge was nearing a decision on damages, Gov. Chris Christie’s administration intervened and quietly agreed to settle the claim for a stunningly low $250 million.

headline: With Eyes on His Vote in Health Subsidies Case, Roberts Lets on Little
text: WASHINGTON — Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. usually displays his supple intellect and competitive nature at Supreme Court arguments, where he makes points and punctures the positions of the lawyers who appear before him.

headline: Pushing Limits of a Sport, and a Budget
text: GOODYEAR, Ariz. — You hear it from just about every major league hitter: Strikeouts are rising because pitchers throw really, really fast. Relievers trot in from the bullpen, one after another, and overpower the hitters.

headline: Review: In ‘These Final Hours’ an Imminent Apocalypse Incites Depravity
text: Every time the world ends, somebody has to learn a lesson, generally about Love and What’s Really Important. In “These Final Hours,” an Australian drama, it’s James’s turn. The lesson may not be particularly original, but the film has some striking moments as it follows him to his destiny.

headline: Iran Gains Influence in Iraq as Shiite Forces Fight ISIS
text: AWJA, Iraq — All along the green irrigated plains in the heart of what American occupying troops used to call the Sunni triangle, lampposts and watchtowers are flying the flags of the Badr Organization, a Shiite militia long hated and feared by many Iraqi Sunnis.

headline: Review: Adam Carolla’s ‘Road Hard,’ a Comedy About a Comic
text: Adam Carolla really wants people to know that he hates show business. And Los Angeles. And the road. And his audience. And any younger performer who gained popularity with the help of the Internet or social media.

headline: In U.C.L.A. Debate Over Jewish Student, Echoes on Campus of Old Biases
text: LOS ANGELES — It seemed like routine business for the student council at the University of California, Los Angeles: confirming the nomination of Rachel Beyda, a second-year economics major who wants to be a lawyer someday, to the council’s Judicial Board.

headline: Back to a Short Putter, Adam Scott Is Happy With the Results
text: DORAL, Fla. — Adam Scott looked as if he were paying tribute to the recently departed Leonard Nimoy on Thursday on the greens of Doral’s Blue Monster. Holding his putter in his left hand, Scott rested his right hand, palm down, lightly on the grip and gave his golf ball a modified Vulcan salute.

headline: Mexico: Gunmen Kill a Navy Officer
text: A navy officer put in charge of Mexico’s second-largest port in an effort to wrest control of it from a drug gang was shot and killed in what the authorities said Thursday was a robbery attempt. The officer, Rear Adm. José Luis Corro Chávez, was shot Wednesday after he refused to leave his vehicle when gunmen demanded it outside his house in the port city of Lázaro Cárdenas, in Michoacán State. Two suspects have been arrested. Admiral Corro had served at the port since November 2013, when the navy began trying to root out the Knights Templar gang, which had been smuggling iron ore to China and extorting mining interests in the area. The authorities said the shooting was not related to organized crime, but it came nearly a week after the arrest of the former top leader of the Knights Templar, Servando Gómez.

headline: 529 College Savings Plans in a State of Evolution
text: EARLY this year, 529 college savings plans stirred a lot of attention — outrage, really — when President Obama proposed eliminating the tax-free status of withdrawals from the accounts, which millions of Americans use to save for higher education costs.

headline: Senate Will Postpone Debate on Iran
text: Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky and the majority leader, will postpone consideration of a bill giving Congress the authority to review any deal President Obama reaches with Iran on its nuclear program, bowing to opposition from Democrats who charged that he was rushing the measure. Mr. McConnell, who this week set the stage for a procedural vote on the legislation on Tuesday, decided on Thursday that he would wait to bring up the bipartisan measure. Don Stewart, a spokesman for Mr. McConnell, said that would give Democrats time to “decide whether or not they believe they and Congress as a whole should be able to review and vote on any deal the president cuts with the leaders of Iran.” The decision merely delays what promises to be an intense debate in Congress over whether Mr. Obama should be able to seal a deal with Iran aimed at blocking it from acquiring nuclear weapons and under what terms. A growing bipartisan coalition of lawmakers believes Congress must have a say over any such accord, and they are moving to lay out tough requirements for Mr. Obama that could shape any deal.

headline: Success is a Great Deodorant
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — David Phillips goes into quite a bit of detail about his puzzle, so I’m going to be brief and then get out of his way. The one point I would like to make is that I am starving right now.

headline: Review: ‘Fish in the Dark,’ Larry David’s Antic Broadway Debut
text: The fish itself — the one that figures in ads for the new play “Fish in the Dark” and can be seen on the drop curtain at the Cort Theater — is pretty great, a charming and maddening creature destined to capture your heart. O.K., if you insist: It is pret-ty, pret-ty, pret-ty great.

headline: Is Boxing Dead? Some Are Betting Heavily That It Isn’t
text: Al Haymon makes a habit of not speaking to reporters, but that’s fine. What Haymon is attempting speaks louder than anything he might say anyway. Haymon, a Harvard-educated boxing manager and adviser, is challenging the pay-per-view model that has enriched a few people at the expense of an entire sport.

headline: Brown Family Lawyer Announces Civil Case

text: incandescent • \ˌin-kən-ˈde-sənt\ • adjective

headline: Maika Monroe Runs for Her Life in ‘It Follows’
text: Maika Monroe has spent a lot of time running for her life. Last year, in the thriller “The Guest,” she played a girl who must flee from the strange and dangerous man (Dan Stevens) staying with her family. In the horror movie “It Follows,” opening March 13, she’s stalked by an evil force in human form that will kill her if it catches her. The only way to break the curse is to have sex with someone and pass it on.

headline: New York City Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Are Suspended on Friday
text: Because of snow removal, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Hemlines and Heartbreak in Fassbinder’s ‘The Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant’
text: Rainer Werner Fassbinder (1945-82) was a comet whose brief, productive career belied even as it blazed forth the decline of imported film culture. At the time of his death from a drug overdose, at 37, Fassbinder left some 40 features, a pair of TV mini-series and two dozen stage plays. But none were more Fassbinderian than this German writer-director’s 1972 film, “The Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant,” part confession, part travesty.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
text: 8 P.M. (Starz) MALEFICENT (2014) In this live-action back story to the 1959 Disney animated musical “Sleeping Beauty,” a happy young fairy (in a role shared by Isobelle Molloy and Ella Purnell) living in the moors becomes friends — and then something a bit more, involving a kiss — with a human farmhand (played by Michael Higgins and Jackson Bews). But eventually the boy grows into a man (Sharlto Copley) and helps wage war against the mossy wonderland of the fairy (now Angelina Jolie), whose wings are literally clipped. Now in an eternally foul mood, she retreats into a dark place, where years later she plots against his child, Aurora (Elle Fanning), who is destined to fall into a deep sleep after pricking her finger on a spindle. Ms. Jolie “makes a fabulous monster” as “she breezes through the movie, part superstar, part superfreak,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Consciously or not, coherently or not, ‘Maleficent’ tells a new kind of story about how we live now, not once upon another time. And it does so by suggesting, among other things, that budding girls and older women are not natural foes, even if that’s what fairy tales, Hollywood and the world like to tell us. And while that may sound drippy, it’s exactly the kind of hokey that, movie by movie, may finally make a real difference.”

headline: Revenge Movies Offer Mythic Middle-Aged Protectors
text: Time was, a prestigious actor midway through the journey of life would guest star on a cable show to get through the dark wood of his career. But premium television is no longer second-tier entertainment, and middle-aged actors, in contrast to their female counterparts, have no shortage of material from which to choose. That’s especially true with the booming subgenre of revenge movies made for, by and essentially about them.

headline: A Team Whose Fans Are Few but Devoted
text: The Boston Blades are the only team in the Canadian Women’s Hockey League based in the United States, and many of their players work part-time jobs to supplement their income.

headline: In the Documentary ‘GTFO,’ Female Video Gamers Fight Back
text: In the documentary “GTFO,” Jenny Haniver is relaxing in her living room in Wisconsin, thumbs on her Xbox controller, settling in for another session of Call of Duty. But when her fellow online combatants discover that the shooter in their midst is, to their chagrin, female, the comments commence. One player takes potshots at women — they are poor game players, they can’t drive — before commanding Ms. Haniver to leave the game. “You’re useless when your hymen is broken,” he tells her.

text: “2 seconds more we would have been in the water!”

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Making Egypt’s Streets Safe for Women
text: Like her male Egyptian colleagues, Eman Helal often dons a gas mask and helmet when she photographs protests in Cairo. But the protective gear provides her an extra level of security — from men in public. Her helmet and mask hide her hijab — the only hint she is a woman, as she otherwise dresses like a man while working — making it far less likely that she will encounter the verbal abuse or physical and sexual assaults that women have come to expect on Cairo’s streets.

headline: Long-Term Care Crisis
A Trade Deal and the Threat to American Jobs
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Temptation of Hillary
text: Hillary Clinton’s record is more moderate than the Democratic primary voter today. So it was always likely that she would move left as the primary season approached. It’s now becoming clearer how she might do it. She might make a shift from what you might call human capital progressivism to redistributionist progressivism.

headline: A New Twist in the Ferguson Case
Hillary’s Step
text: On Mount Everest, just shy of the summit, the final rock-and-ice obstacle that stands between a climber and the highest point on the planet is known as the Hillary Step. It was named for Sir Edmund Hillary, who made the first ascent of the mountain along with Tenzing Norgay in 1953.

headline: Alabama’s Dangerous Defiance
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — ON Tuesday the Supreme Court of Alabama prohibited the state’s probate judges from issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples. This decision effectively throws down the gauntlet, challenging the federal courts to make earlier federal rulings stick — including last month’s refusal by the United States Supreme Court to stay a federal judge’s decision requiring the state to recognize same-sex marriages. It draws on a disturbing line of thinking in the history of American federalism, one that, were it to gain currency as a model, could compromise our entire system of law.

headline: Pepperoni Turns Partisan
text: If you want to know what a political party really stands for, follow the money. Pundits and the public are often deceived; remember when George W. Bush was a moderate, and Chris Christie a reasonable guy who could reach out to Democrats? Major donors, however, generally have a very good idea of what they are buying, so tracking their spending tells you a lot.

headline: The President’s Weak Privacy Proposal
text: President Obama has said that the country needs a strong privacy law so consumers can protect personal information from advertisers, Internet firms, employers and other businesses. But the country is not going to get it from Mr. Obama. The bill his administration recently offered will do little to help individuals while giving companies great leeway in determining how they collect, use and share personal data.

headline: Deferring Those Huge College Tuition Bills
India’s Careful Plan for Growth
text: Narendra Modi chose incremental pragmatism in proposing his first full budget since becoming India’s prime minister last year. The $288 billion budget did not fulfill the expectations for economic reform that he has fostered since his election. But he offered enough initiatives on spending, taxes and other areas of economic policy to satisfy many investors for now, and to keep alive hopes that he can guide India to greater growth and development.

headline: Don’t Kill Keystone XL. Regulate It.
text: BOULDER, Colo. — TWO years ago, I spent a month watching engineers inspect the Trans-Alaska Pipeline, one of the world’s biggest, most remote and most complicated pipelines. The endeavor entailed sending a five-ton “smart pig” — a rust-detecting robot — 800 miles across the length of Alaska, like a spitball in a giant straw, as it hunted for signs of metal loss.

headline: A Call From Selma
text: This short documentary explores how the murder of a white minister in Selma, Ala., helped catalyze the civil rights movement.

headline: ‘A Call From Selma’
text: When many of us think about the civil rights movement, we remember the courage of the black protesters who risked their lives and livelihoods to push for equal rights. But obscured in this history is the fact that it took the murder of a white clergyman to trigger the national outrage about rights abuses in the South that led to real change.

headline: The Excitement of Learning From Profit and Loss
text: It’s often been said that the key to success is being able to handle failure. For example, from Winston Churchill: “Success is stumbling from failure to failure with no loss of enthusiasm.” Or C. S. Lewis: “One fails forward toward success.”
