headline: Netanyahu’s Iran Thing
text: Let’s begin with Benjamin Netanyahu’s Iran logic. He portrays a rampaging Islamic Republic that “now dominates four Arab capitals, Baghdad, Damascus, Beirut and Sana,” a nation “gobbling” other countries on a “march of conquest, subjugation and terror.” Then, in the same speech, he describes Iran as “a very vulnerable regime” on the brink of folding.

headline: How to Drive a Getaway Car
text: Never mind trying to outrace another vehicle when you need to escape, says Walter Farrer, a security consultant who teaches evasive-­driving courses to business executives and wealthy Mexican families who want to avoid kidnappings. Disappear instead: drive a mini­van, which is like an automotive duck blind, mobile camouflage for the road. “They make you hard to follow,” Farrer says. A newish mini­van or midsize S.U.V. in gray with no bumper stickers is ideal. “Make sure both taillights work,” Farrer says. “You don’t want anything on your car that is easily identifiable.” In particularly high-risk cities — kidnappings for ransom are a persistent problem in Mexico — he presses his clients to drive cars covered in dust bearing local plates.

headline: Massimo Vitali Moves Into a 14th-Century Church
text: The photographer Massimo Vitali lives with his wife and son in Lucca, Italy, in a 14th-century church that lay empty for 17 years. “The church was used mainly for storage,” Vitali said. “There were mice and birds in it, there was water. In Italy, when you purchase an ancient church, you have to keep it open; you cannot divide the space into smaller rooms.” For additional living space, Vitali’s architect, Paola Sausa, attached a former sacristy to the church.

headline: Cover to Cover
text: The illustrator Tom Gauld on book guilt.

headline: ‘Outside the Abandoned Packard Plant’
text: There is a driving rhythm in this poem — the industry of crickets, the forward motion of the lines — even as there is no man-made machinery at work in the defunct auto plant. The contrast between the two heightens the tension between what is lost and the image, in the last line, of a possible future. Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

headline: Birdman
text: The Pigeon King delivered his closing statement to the jury dressed in his only suit. His name was Arlan Galbraith, and he was representing himself. He had abruptly fired his lawyer nearly two years earlier, during the long lead up to the trial, and then ignored the judges who advised him to hire another. He seemed adrift but also supremely confident. One of his former employees, who testified for the prosecution, speculated that he must have watched too much “Law & Order”: “I think he sat down one day and said, ‘Yeah, I can do this.’ ”

headline: Re: The Unimpeachable Manly Truth
text: It was “a weird but productive sociological experiment,” in the words of one journalist: Put Gary Shteyngart in a 600-square-foot luxury cage at the Four Seasons in Manhattan and force him to watch nothing but Russian television for seven days on three giant screens arranged around his plush, king-size bed. It was “an (oddly) rare look at what [President Vladimir] Putin is actually telling the Russian people,” tweeted Whitney Kassel, a columnist for ForeignPolicy.com.

headline: Redefining Gender in Mexico City
text: When you see a person, how many seconds do you have to make a mental model? Immediately, the first thing you notice — man or woman? But I always had issues with my gender. And when people can’t understand, they get uncomfortable.

headline: Restaurant Report: Selfie in Moscow
text: Scoff if you want, but the name is perfect: Selfie, from the team behind the fashionable Moscow restaurant White Rabbit, is a pouty-lipped snapshot of the current insular moment among the city’s cosmopolitan elite.

headline: Hidden Gems on Ecuador’s Emerald Coast
text: Reggaeton blaring, we zoomed along the coast of Esmeraldas, past a series of resort towns, white sand beaches spoiled only by concrete hotel towers. Our Ranchera, an Ecuadorean open-air bus, paused just long enough for schoolchildren to climb atop the roof before we veered slightly inland away from the jagged, rocky coast and into the remnants of a jungle canopy.

headline: Discovering the Ruins of Italy’s Ionian Coast
text: It was my first day back in Metaponto in a decade, and I was anxious. As my train from Rome pulled into the station, after a six-hour descent past Vesuvius, the craggy Lucanian Dolomites, olive groves and pebbly streams, and finally the small hill towns and low, pale mountains (calanchi) of the Basilicata region, I wondered what had changed in this place since my last visit. My family was from this area originally, four generations back, and I had come here twice before to do genealogical research. But it had been a while.

headline: Parliamentary Panel Urges Britain to Stand Up for Hong Kong
text: A British parliamentary committee has warned that Hong Kong’s high degree of autonomy is at risk and called on London to take a stronger stand on behalf of democratic change in its former colony.

headline: Morning Agenda: Big Banks Pass Stress Tests

But some banks fared better than others, DealBook’s Peter Eavis writes.

headline: A Prince Who Would Be King Challenges Sepp Blatter for FIFA’s Presidency
text: LONDON — Sepp Blatter has been elected to four consecutive terms as president of FIFA, a run that dates to 1998. In his first election — the process gives every FIFA-affiliated country a vote — Blatter defeated a former head of the European soccer confederation. In the second, he defeated the leader of the African soccer confederation. In the third and fourth, he ran unopposed.

headline: Retirement in a Community. but Which One?
text: SUE CANFIELD knew what she wanted: to have regular lunches with her young grandson, to be close — not too close — to at least one of her grown children, but to be in a place where she could also have an active, engaged life of her own.

headline: What to Expect on the Third Day of Paris Fashion Week
text: Fashion Week is a fashionably late affair. Twenty minutes after the stated time is the norm. And yet Loewe, the first show on the docket Friday has let it be known that it will start at 9:30 on the dot, come what may. Loewe’s Jonathan Anderson is, after all, a busy guy. This week alone, he’s been at the LVMH prize open house (as the artistic director of an LVMH brand, he sits on its 12-person jury) and celebrated a collaboration with Larry Clark for his own brand, J.W. Anderson, at Colette. Time’s a wasting!

headline: Accused Rapist Is Dragged From His Jail Cell in India and Killed
text: NEW DELHI — A mob of thousands stormed a jail in the northeastern Indian city of Dimapur, seized a prisoner accused of rape, paraded him through the streets and beat him to death before they could be stopped by police gunfire, a police official said on Friday.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments

Another building was prone to flooding, because the storm drainage system was never connected to the sewage system. With buildings rising at a pace not seen in years, some fear that shoddy construction could be making a comeback, too.

headline: When Rural Meets Resort
text: The tiny town of Amenia, N.Y., population 4,436, is perhaps best known for its hamlet of Wassaic, the last stop on the Metro-North Railroad’s Harlem line and home to an artists’ community that hosts an annual festival there. Bordering Connecticut in rural Dutchess County, Amenia has had a tough time since its largest employer, an institution for the developmentally disabled, closed two years ago.

headline: Job Growth Was Fantastic Last Month. So Why Aren’t Wages Rising More?
text: First the good news. The American job market has truly, really, finally, unquestionably shifted into a higher gear.

headline: Kate Tempest, a British Triple Threat, Crosses the Pond
text: LONDON — Kate Tempest — poet, playwright, rapper, cross-genre talent — took to the stage at Electric Brixton, a club in the historically working class neighborhood one recent Sunday night, and looked into the crowd of more than a thousand people. “I don’t want to see you hidden behind your phone screens!” she called out in her unmistakable South London accent. “This is real! This is happening!” Being together in one room, living the same moment, she said, is “as close to connecting” as many of us ever achieve.

headline: How to Find More Time
text: Want to add some hours to your day? O.K., you (probably) can’t alter the fabric of time. But a new study suggests that the way you feel about your goals can alter your concept of time — and that some simple strategies could make you feel less rushed.

headline: Briton Arrested Over Cyberattack on U.S. Defense Department

headline: 11 Little-Known Facts About John Galliano and Alexander McQueen
text: Fashion-philes are on high alert: This evening in Paris, at the Grand Palais, John Galliano will stage his first ready-to-wear collection — and make his first on-schedule appearance at Paris Fashion Week — as creative director of the recently rechristened Maison Margiela. (Galliano was famously fired from his post at Dior in 2011 after a pair of anti-Semitic outbursts in Paris.) The designer’s extraordinary rise and sudden downfall, precipitated by the pressures of delivering multiple product lines for an international conglomerate — together with the similar trajectory of his contemporary and sometime rival, the late Alexander McQueen — is the subject of the T contributing editor Dana Thomas’s new book, “Gods and Kings” (Penguin Press, $29.95), an occasionally titillating and ultimately poignant read released just in time for the start of one of fashion’s most scrutinized third (or, more accurately, fifth or sixth) acts.

headline: Letter From the Editor: Inequality at the Supreme Court
text: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Stuff We Liked

headline: NBC Brings Back Andrew Lack to Lead Its News Division
text: NBC Universal reached into its past to chart a new path forward on Friday, hiring Andrew Lack to lead its news division after a series of missteps that culminated with the suspension of Brian Williams last month.

headline: Introducing Motherlode’s New Artist-In-Residence: Abigail Gray Swartz
text: We’re thrilled to welcome Abigail Gray Swartz to the Artist-in-Residence role. She’ll be accompanying essays and posts here with art that’s like an essay in a different format. The longer I look at her work, the more it says. She first appeared in this space illustrating Margaret Gilmour’s essay, “My Friend Has a Son Who Is Autistic.” If you read a little further, you’ll get a sense of how that came about.

headline: Before Starting as a Coach, It Helps to Go Into Training

headline: French Court Rules It Has Jurisdiction Over Facebook in Nude Painting Case

headline: Wisconsin Votes to Limit Collection of Fees by Unions
text: MADISON, Wis. — The State Assembly on Friday approved legislation barring unions from requiring workers to pay the equivalent of dues, leaving Wisconsin poised to become the 25th state with what advocates describe as a right-to-work law.

headline: In Boon to Its Stock, Apple Will Replace AT&T in Dow Index
text: Apple, the highest-valued company in the world, will be added to the Dow Jones industrial average next month in yet another sign of how popular the computer giant has become for investors.

headline: Standing Till the End
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Standing at ice level and facing the Islanders’ runway, Mike Artusa smiled broadly and had a handshake or a hug ready for all the familiar faces. And there was a seemingly endless supply of those.

headline: 1915: General Receives Medal
text: LONDON — A communication from the British General headquarters, dated Thursday [March 4], says: — Sir John French was this afternoon presented by General de Lacroix, late Commander-in-Chief of the French army, with the Military Medal, the highest French military honor obtainable. Sir John French is the only Englishman on whom it has ever been bestowed, and King Albert of Belgium and Grand Duke Nicholas are the only other foreigners.

headline: Ferguson Police Bias Not an Isolated Case, Obama Says
text: President Obama on Friday said that he thought the pattern of racial discrimination described in a report by the Justice Department about the Ferguson Police Department was not an isolated example.

headline: The NAIRU Straitjacket and Cromwell’s Rule
text: Today’s employment report continued the pattern we’ve been seeing for a while. Unemployment is falling, and is now very close to previous estimates of the NAIRU, the unemployment rate at which inflation begins accelerating. But inflation isn’t accelerating; in particular, there is still no hint of wage pressure in the data. So what should the Fed do?

headline: Christian Dior: Fall 2015 RTW
text: Paris

headline: BP Signs $12 Billion Deal to Develop Natural Gas in Egypt
text: LONDON — In a sign that Egypt’s strained relations with the international oil industry may be improving, BP said on Friday that it had reached an agreement to invest with a partner about $12 billion to develop natural gas resources in the country.

headline: The Below-Zero Lower Bound
text: Further to my earlier post on negative interest rates: here’s what may be a simpler way to think about it. When central banks push interest rates on government debt below zero, the effective lower bound is the return on cash held by people who would otherwise be holding that government debt — not people looking to expand their checking accounts. So the liquidity advantages of bank deposits over cash in a vault are pretty much irrelevant. It’s all about the cost of storage.

headline: At Museo del Prado, Blind Visitors Can Touch Masterpieces
text: MADRID — Guards make sure visitors to the Museo del Prado stay at arm’s length from its masterpieces. But here on a recent morning was José Pedro González running his fingers over one of El Greco’s most famous paintings, “The Nobleman With His Hand on His Chest.” He went back and forth over the nobleman’s eyes, rubbed his beard and eventually reached his hand, tracing the edges of each digit.

headline: Game Over for the Astrodome, ‘Stadium of the Future’
text: The stadium was a gargantuan advertisement for the possibilities suggested by American technology, and yet was rendered a relic within decades.

headline: Color-Coded Makeup at Christian Dior
text: Backstage at Christian Dior, Peter Philips created a beauty profile that mirrored the swoops and swirls of color printed on the house’s fall 2015 collection. The creative and image director of Christian Dior Makeup carefully complemented each look with a single shade of eye shadow (deep green, navy, aubergine or brick), which he applied wet, to intensify the pigment, over the socket and up to the orbital bone. The unifying application on each face: four to five coats of mascara and heavy black kohl liner. “We wanted graphic makeup with a little twist,” Philips says. It is indeed a dark departure from the thin adhesive strips of pastel eyeliner he created for the house’s spring 2015 runway.

headline: Saints’ Owner Marches Out of Step With His Heirs’ Expectations
text: NEW ORLEANS — Tom Benson sat at the head of a wooden conference table unruffled in a dark business suit, with a crisp aqua necktie and a handkerchief tucked neatly in his breast pocket. One after another, the top executives who run his two teams — the N.F.L.’s Saints and the N.B.A.’s Pelicans — offered details about how their ad campaigns, ticket sales and digital signboards were doing.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Zarxio, Its First Biosimilar Drug
text: The Food and Drug Administration has approved the first so-called biosimilar drug for use in the United States, paving the way for less expensive alternatives to an entire class of complex and costly drugs.

headline: Daniel Von Bargen, Actor in ‘Seinfeld’ and ‘Malcolm in the Middle,’ Dies at 64
text: Daniel Von Bargen, a character actor who played both bumbling and menacing authority figures and was probably best known as George Costanza’s thickheaded boss on “Seinfeld,” died on Sunday in Cincinnati. He was 64.

headline: Finding Equilibrium in Seesawing Libidos (Updated With Podcast)
text: A medication leads to a hypersexualized wife, and a husband puffing to keep up. In time, the mismatch subsides, leaving them partners in a bigger way.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel,’ ‘Merchants of Doubt’ and ‘Chappie’
text: In this video, Times critics share their thoughts on “The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel,” “Merchants of Doubt” and “Chappie.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
text: This week’s featured property is a 1920 Victorian two-family in Greenwich, Conn.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured property in the New York Region:

headline: First Draft Focus: A Snowy Departure
text: Marine One took off on Friday with President Obama onboard, heading to Andrews Air Force Base for a scheduled flight to South Carolina.

headline: A Proper Stew for St. Patrick’s Day
text: With St. Patrick’s Day just around the corner, you may be thinking about corned beef and cabbage. There’s nothing wrong with it, but that’s Irish-American. For something that may actually be served on Irish soil, have a go at a proper Irish stew.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: This week’s properties include co-ops in the Sutton area, Greenwich Village, Ditmas Park, and a house in Riverdale.

headline: Through It All, Pelosi Keeps House Democrats Moving in One Direction
text: WASHINGTON — The quarterback Brett Favre has long retired. Cher shut down her most recent tour. Representative Nancy Pelosi — repeatedly written off and derided since her party lost the House in 2010 — powers on.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: 1940: New Ship Secretly Sails
text: The Queen Elizabeth en route to New York in 1940. (britishpathe.com)

headline: After a Fire, Learning to Cook Again, One Grilled Cheese at a Time
text: Four months pregnant, with my 19-month-old son at the kitchen table eating chicken fingers, it happened. I’d been in full-on nesting mode, and no recipe on the Food Network was too big or too small. That night, I was experimenting with Sandra Lee’s corn dogs — a secret guilty pleasure for both my husband and me. Just like Sandra Lee instructed, I filled my pot with oil, and while it was heating up, I put the batter together for the hot dogs.

headline: Selma Hosts Its Own Civil Rights Concert
text: It has been a big year for Selma, Ala., with the country renewing focus on the city, thanks to an Oscar-nominated film carrying its name, and the celebrations of the 50th anniversary of the civil rights march from Selma to Montgomery, Ala.

headline: Exclusive | 285 Lafayette Street
text: A four-bedroom loft in a sought-after prewar condominium conversion is poised to enter the market at $11.5 million.

headline: Roos Abels Transforms at Dior
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Roos Abels before (left) and after (right) makeup by Peter Philips and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE BURIED GIANT,  by Kazuo Ishiguro. (Knopf, $26.95.) Ishiguro’s exceptional seventh novel, a mixture of fantasy, historical fiction and myth set in a semi-historical medieval England, remains in the mind long after it has been read.

headline: ‘Girl in the Dark: A Memoir,’ by Anna Lyndsey
text: A reader trolling the bookstore’s memoir section, sampling passages from random volumes, finally encountering Anna Lyndsey’s melodic, penetrating prose among the drama-heavy movie-of-the-week wannabes, might be excused for any unbecoming public outburst: a fist in the air, say, and a bellow of “Score!” For although “Girl in the Dark” is based on the author’s experience of a startling medical condition — full-body light sensitivity so severe that Lyndsey becomes largely restricted to a stifling blackout room — a spot-check of its paragraphs reveals the quiet, ingenious consciousness of a poet.

headline: Found Fiction
text: I grew up in a Massachusetts town in which the recycling and disposal facility was a paragon of Yankee thrift and was restricted to members, like a country club.

headline: ‘The Last Good Paradise,’ by Tatjana Soli
text: Ann and Richard, a married Los Angeles couple, have their own vision of the American dream — he wants to be a big-time restaurateur, she a big-time lawyer — but it’s crumbling before their eyes. Their goal, and that of their peers, was once to be so busy they could say, without irony, “My people will call your people.” Instead, they’re on a treadmill of anxiety. Their professions — and the people around them — have turned fickle. Ann realizes that she hates the law and her regimented life: Unable to become pregnant, she’s being shot up with hormones in between meetings. Richard is struggling even to start a restaurant, let alone keep one running.

headline: Inside the List
text: Death By Chocolate: The crime novelist Joanne Fluke has come up with a winning formula for her best sellers — think of a luscious dessert, then add death. Thus far in Fluke’s series of Hannah Swensen mysteries-with-recipes, in which a small-town Minnesota baker keeps stumbling across corpses, 10 titles have hit the list, including “Cream Puff Murder,” “Cinnamon Roll Murder,” “Blackberry Pie Murder” and the latest, “Double Fudge Brownie Murder,” new at No. 13 in hardcover fiction. (The series has also spawned a best-selling cookbook, “Joanne Fluke’s Lake Eden Cookbook,” that might as well have been called “Saturated Fat Murder.”) Before starting the Hannah Swensen series, Fluke wrote more than 30 thrillers in a darker vein, but she dreamed of striking out in a new direction. “I always wanted to write a cookbook,” she explained in a 2013 interview with a Seattle television station, “and I couldn’t sell the darn thing. So, actually, what happened is, my editor said, ‘Would you like to write cozy mysteries?’ And I said, ‘Can I put recipes in them?’ . . . I decided I would write something kinder, gentler, and use my baking.”

headline: MC Hamilton
text: Ron Chernow always knew his acclaimed 2004 biography of Alexander Hamilton would someday be turned into a hip-hop musical. Well, not always, but since 2009, when he first met the composer and actor Lin-Manuel Miranda, whose “Hamilton” has been a smash hit Off Broadway at the Public Theater. (The show will move to Broadway in July.)

headline: Paying Tribute to Thomas Stanley and His ‘Millionaire Next Door’
text: The rich are different from you and me, though maybe not quite like we think they are.

headline: ‘Gods and Kings,’ by Dana Thomas
text: Karl Lagerfeld has a wonderful reply to those who think fashion could use more innovators. No doubt, he says, but in any period only a few individuals are crucial. The 1920s had Chanel and Patou, the ’30s Vionnet and Schiaparelli. The ’40s belonged to Dior. By the ’50s, Chanel was back and her twin engine was the saintly Balenciaga. Genius is rare. It sustains the rest of the industry with ideas, energy and, of course, drama.

headline: Paperback Row
text: SHOTGUN LOVESONGS,  by Nickolas Butler. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin’s Griffin, $15.99.) Lifelong bonds are tested in Butler’s big-hearted first novel when four boyhood friends — and the woman who has meant something special in each of their lives — are reunited in middle age in their small Wisconsin hometown. “Butler has written an unmistakably American novel — and a good one,” Jonathan Evison said in the Book Review.

headline: ‘The Tusk That Did the Damage,’ by Tania James
text: Tania James’s impressive new novel, “The Tusk That Did the Damage,” brings a sharp and unnerving sensibility to bear on dismal and necessary events. A wild elephant’s post-mortem exam, for instance, finds that a poacher’s bullet has left a “burn hole like a black star” in its body; as officials search for the bullet itself, “they took a saw to the animal’s side, the sound like a zipper going up and down.” Such matter-of-fact yet startling associations make for the kind of unexpected fusions that can be found across these pages.

headline: French Translation
text: GUYS LIKE ME

headline: A Racy Silicon Valley Lawsuit, and More Subtle Questions About Sex Discrimination
text: A gender discrimination trial is gripping Silicon Valley this week with lurid details about an office affair, a nude photo book and a bathrobe-clad man showing up at a female colleague’s hotel room.

headline: Classic and Eclectic
text: A four-bedroom loft on the second floor of 285 Lafayette Street, a sought-after prewar condominium conversion, is poised to enter the market for $11.5 million.

headline: Ben Jealous Considers Run for Maryland Senate Seat
text: Benjamin T. Jealous, a former president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and a veteran activist, is considering a run for the Senate seat in Maryland that Barbara A. Mikulski will be leaving in 2017.

headline: Cutting Out the Meat With Mushrooms
text: A couple of years ago I gave you a recipe for a roasted mushroom base, a sort of vegetable Hamburger Helper that I had learned to make from Scott Samuels, a Culinary Institute of America chef. Chef Samuels combined it with ground beef to make delicious burgers. It has caught on among food service professionals who want to improve the nutritional profile of their offerings. Now they refer to it as, simply, “The Mix,” and they are keeping mushroom growers very busy.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Julien David Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: Isabel Marant: Fall 2015 RTW
text: Paris

headline: During Bakery Break-In, Only Recipes Are Taken
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It takes three days to make a cruffin, a muffin-croissant hybrid that is the signature of Ry Stephen, a 28-year-old pastry chef. His shop, Mr Holmes Bakehouse, has been open three months and inspired a wild following, with customers lining up early to buy the ice-cream-cone-shaped cruffins, which reliably sell out before the line is gone.

headline: Albert Maysles, Pioneering Documentarian, Dies at 88
text: Albert Maysles, the award-winning documentarian who, with his brother, David, made intensely talked-about films, including “Grey Gardens” and “Gimme Shelter,” with their American version of cinéma vérité, died Thursday night at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Julien David Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: Haitian Griot Is a Postcard From the Caribbean
text: “Have you ever had griot?”

headline: Facts & Figures: Vaccines Under Fire
text: Americans are less likely to say vaccination is “extremely important” than they were in 2001, according to a poll released Friday. They are also much more likely to have heard about disadvantages of vaccines — 30 percent said they’d heard “a great deal” about such disadvantages, up from 15 percent in 2001.

headline: Down in North Carolina, One Family Makes Maple Syrup in Its Own Backyard
text: At the mountainside Waterfall Farm in the northwest region of the state, indigenous trees are tapped, and the sap is stewed in a handmade sugarhouse.

headline: Troubleshooting Android in Safe Mode
text: Q. My Android phone just started freezing and crashing a few days ago. What would cause it to do so?

headline: Putin Takes a Pay Cut, as Does Most of the Kremlin
text: MOSCOW — With ordinary Russians grumbling about the sharp rise in food prices, President Vladimir V. Putin made a populist move on Friday, announcing that he and almost everyone who works for him will take a 10 percent cut in pay.

headline: Whiting Awards Celebrate 30 Years With 10 Winning Writers
text: The winners of the 2015 Whiting Awards were announced on Thursday night at the New-York Historical Society. Each of the 10 chosen writers receives a cash award of $50,000. The awards are “based on early accomplishment and the promise of great work to come,” according to the Whiting Foundation.

headline: In One Case, State Dept. Criticized Use of Personal Email
text: The case of an ousted ambassador to Kenya who served while Hillary Rodham Clinton led the State Department has gained fresh attention in light of the controversy surrounding reports that she exclusively used a personal email account for government business.

headline: Syracuse Basketball and Coach Jim Boeheim Hit Hard by N.C.A.A.
text: Members of the athletic staff forged classwork. Players were handed cash for appearances as volunteers. Others were allowed to skirt the university’s drug policy without consequence.

headline: What I Love | Gilbert Gottfried
text: The gravel-voiced comedian and actor shares a recently decorated Chelsea loft with his wife, Dara, and their two children.

headline: Alec Baldwin Selected to Be Mayor of New York on HBO
text: Several years ago, the actor Alec Baldwin told The New York Times that he was interested in being mayor of New York City. “I am someone who is fully prepared for the fact that I could go into this and do it and completely have my ass kicked,” he said at the time of the prospect of running for office. “I could throw a party and no one could come. And it would be this staggering lesson for me.”

headline: Margherita Missoni Amos’s New Children’s Wear: Meant for Mixing and Matching and Playing Dress-Up
text: For a little kid, playing dress-up can be one of the most thrilling forms of discovery. And for Margherita Missoni Amos, of one of fashion’s most storied families (she’s the granddaughter of Ottavio and Rosita), playing dress-up has always been a way of life. It’s no surprise, then, that the 32-year-old mom is launching her own children’s collection inspired by the possibilities of fun that exist in wearing clothes. Simply called Margherita, her first venture outside of the Missoni label was conceived for baby boys and girls ages 0-2, and for girls up to age 7. And all the pieces — washed-linen dresses with bright Balinese-batik inspired prints, color-blocked sweaters, seersucker striped tees ($30-$80) — are meant to be mixed and matched. “I want children to express their creativity through choosing their own clothes,” Missoni Amos explains. “That’s why I didn’t create any perfect matching outfits.”

headline: Madonna is Still Madonna On ‘Rebel Heart’
text: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss “Rebel Heart,” the new album by Madonna.

headline: A Prediction Market for Inflation, or Deflation
text: Something unusual is happening to prices right now: They are falling.

headline: At Dior, Lanvin and Rick Owens: The Power Woman in Winter
text: PARIS — For a while there it looked as if the hair was going to overshadow the clothes.

headline: Views at One57 for $29,329,100
text: A three-bedroom three-and-a-half-bath apartment on the 65th floor of One57, the glassy-blue skyscraper where the priciest transaction for a single residence in New York City recently took place, sold for $29,329,100 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: MoMA to Host Wikipedia Editing Marathon, to Improve Coverage of Women in the Arts
text: This weekend, in conjunction with International Women’s Day, the group Art + Feminism will be hosting its second international edit-a-thon, with the goal of improving Wikipedia’s coverage of women and the arts and encouraging more women to contribute to the online encyclopedia.

headline: Los Angeles Police Leader Makes Outreach to Muslims His Mission
text: LOS ANGELES — On a damp and dreary Saturday two months ago, several hundred mourners gathered outside City Hall here for a memorial service honoring Dr. Maher Hathout. Born in Egypt and trained as a cardiologist, Dr. Hathout, 79, had devoted decades to espousing a moderate version of Islam and reaching across denominational lines to other faiths.

headline: A Casualty of a Frigid New York Winter: Outdoor School Recess
text: Midmorning on Tuesday, several hours before snow would return in a ritual that now seems as consistent as receiving the mail, temperatures in New York were cold but not abusive. It was the kind of day, unlike so many others recently, in which forgetting your gloves did not necessarily mean you would feel as if you needed treatment at an urgent-care clinic before you got to work. And yet with the temperature in the 20s, under skies vaguely the color of moleskin, it was neither objectively comfortable nor pleasant.

headline: Verbatim: Jeb Bush Says He’s Baffled by Clinton Emails
text: — Jeb Bush, speaking to an Iowa radio station about Hillary Rodham Clinton’s use of a private email account.

headline: Rare Mark Rothko Painting Leads Christie’s New York Auction
text: Mark Rothko once said that his formula for a good painting included a dollop of hope – “10 percent to make the tragic concept more endurable.” When bidders gather on May 13 at Christie’s to do battle for the next big Rothko to come to auction – a blazing red and black work, “No. 36 (Black Stripe),” painted in 1958, a banner year for the artist – they will have to bring a lot more than hope.

headline: In Two Worlds
text: For young Muslims in New York, it is sometimes a struggle to balance religion and middle school.

headline: Balancing Islam and Middle School in Queens
text: Somewhere between stepping off the school bus and climbing into the go-kart, Sandra Ibrahim, 14, took off her pink hijab. She was on a trip to an indoor amusement park in New Rochelle, N.Y., with her Islamic weekend school, surrounded by other Muslim children, parents and teachers. She knew the adults would like her to keep the head scarf on. But there she was, zooming along the track, her dark brown ponytail swinging freely behind her.

headline: N.C.A.A. Infractions Committee's Report on Syracuse
text: The N.C.A.A. issued a 94-page report Friday on violations committed by the Syracuse athletic department.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Erik Larson’s ‘Dead Wake’
text: This week, Erik Larson talks about “Dead Wake: The Last Crossing of the Lusitania”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Orlando Patterson discusses two new books by black conservatives, “Please Stop Helping Us” and “Shame”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Robert Christgau’s ‘Going Into the City’
text: Since nobody asked, what’s my favorite piece of writing by Robert Christgau? His elegant 17-word assessment of the Beatles’ “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band” approaches pure poetry, and his takedowns of sitting ducks like Emerson, Lake and Palmer’s “Trilogy” and Cybill Shepherd’s “Cybill Does It . . . to Cole Porter” are delectable morsels of schadenfreude. But nothing delighted me quite like the criteria he provided for the letter grades that accompanied his nugget-size record reviews in his long-running Consumer Guide feature.

headline: ‘To Explain the World,’ by Steven Weinberg
text: Steven Weinberg doesn’t think much of Plato or Pythagoras. Nor does he hold René Descartes or Francis Bacon in ­especially high regard. But in his new book on the origins of science, “To Explain the World,” Weinberg casts particular aspersions on science historians themselves.

headline: Nina Stibbe’s ‘Man at the Helm’
text: Nina Stibbe: “I’m trying to write a novel. . . . Was just about to show AB a little synopsis and a few pages. . . . ”

headline: ‘There’s Something I Want You to Do,’ by Charles Baxter
text: Some of our sturdiest atheists now allow that those inexplicable, ineffable, somehow enlarging experiences traditionally classed as religious also happen to people who adhere to no particular doctrine, lack acquaintance with the theologians and ­reject all deities.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Erik Larson’s ‘Dead Wake’
text: This week, Erik Larson and Orlando Patterson.

headline: Madonna Is Still Madonna on ‘Rebel Heart’
text: Madonna’s new record, “Rebel Heart,” is the full version of the album that was partly leaked in work-tape form last December. It’s a résumé of power and influence: a flex-rospective. In songs like “Veni Vidi Vici” she’s essentially reminding you who she is. (Literally so, in the case of “Bitch I’m Madonna.”)

headline: ISIS Bulldozing of Ancient Nimrud Site in Iraq Stirs Outrage
text: News that Islamic State fighters had bulldozed and vandalized the ancient city of Nimrud in northern Iraq provoked outrage on Friday, as archaeologists despaired that the militant group was systematically destroying priceless antiquities in a wellspring of civilization.

headline: At the Independent Fair, Art Not Quite on the Margin
text: The Armory Week satellite offers a trim, well-curated selection of up-and-coming and under-the-radar artists and galleries.

headline: Off Court, Red Storm’s Fiercest Rebounder Is Anything But
text: When Amber Thompson arrived at St. John’s four years ago as the recipient of a basketball scholarship, her body language was not promising. She would hold her hand in front of her face when she spoke. She would look away from others to avoid eye contact. She was so painfully reserved it raised questions about her ability to assert herself on the court.

headline: Revisiting Selma
text: Recollections from those who took part in the march for freedom.

headline: NASA’s Dawn Probe Begins Orbiting Dwarf Planet Ceres
text: NASA’s Dawn spacecraft entered orbit around the asteroid Ceres on Friday morning at an altitude of just under 38,000 miles. Currently, the spacecraft is above the night side of Ceres, limiting the amount of information that can be gathered.

headline: Apple’s Entry Will Help an Antiquated Dow Catch Up
text: Apple’s entry into the Dow Jones industrial average is a bit like polishing an antique. The average share price of 30 stocks selected by committee will finally include the world’s biggest company in place of AT&T. It’s an overdue move for an outdated yardstick — one that, like landlines and checkbooks, lives on.

headline: C.I.A. to Be Overhauled to Fight Modern Threats
text: LANGLEY, Va. — John O. Brennan, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, is planning to reassign thousands of undercover spies and intelligence analysts into new departments as part of a restructuring of the 67-year-old agency, a move he said would make it more successful against modern threats and crises.

headline: Earning the Trust of Afghan Women: Reporter’s Notebook
text: In a March 1 article, Alissa J. Rubin, the Paris bureau chief, wrote about Afghan policewomen and their struggle against culture. The article was the first in a series that examined the legacy of efforts to help Afghan women and girls.

headline: Short Circuits Reported in Mars Rover’s Drilling Arm
text: The Mars rover Curiosity appears to be suffering intermittent short circuits in its robotic arm, which could limit its drilling of rocks, NASA said on Friday.

headline: Why Not Retire the Circus Elephants Now?
text: If the welfare of elephants were truly its only concern, the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus would stop using them in performances now, and put them on a train to sunny Florida, where they could enjoy a comfortable retirement. Instead, as The Associated Press reported Thursday, its 13 wrinkly troupers will be touring the country, doing lumbering tricks in costume for paying customers, until 2018. Then they will be sent to the company’s park near Polk City, Fla., and perform no more.

headline: Menendez Is to Face Corruption Charges, U.S. Official Says
text: The Justice Department is preparing to file corruption charges against Senator Robert Menendez, a scrappy 61-year-old veteran of New Jersey politics, after a two-year investigation into allegations that he accepted gifts and lavish vacations in exchange for political favors for a longtime friend and political benefactor.

headline: Matt Harvey Has Can’t-Miss Outing in Must-See Return to Mound
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Mets fans started applauding Matt Harvey as he left the bullpen Friday afternoon, before he threw a single pitch. The whole way, as Harvey made his way toward the dugout, fans stood and cheered him as he passed.

headline: Millennials on the Homeownership Path
text: Besieged by the recession and buried in student loan debt, the so-called millennials, born from the early ’80s through the late ’90s, have largely lacked the financial wherewithal to buy their own homes. Even 30-year-olds were as likely to be stuck in their childhood bedrooms as they were to own their own place as of 2013, according to a recent report from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

headline: Ontario’s Beer Bottleneck Is Under Siege by Brewers and Buyers
text: OTTAWA — Brewers Retail has sold beer pretty much the same way since it opened 88 years ago.

headline: The New Jobs Report Shows Janet Yellen’s Quandary in a Nutshell
text: The biggest decision that Janet Yellen has faced in her year-old Federal Reserve chairmanship was laid bare in a single report on the domestic job market released Friday.

headline: China Blocks Web Access to ‘Under the Dome’ Documentary on Pollution
text: BEIJING — “Under the Dome,” a searing documentary about China’s catastrophic air pollution, had hundreds of millions of views on Chinese websites within days of its release one week ago.

headline: The Osprey’s Springtime Return to New York
text: Science may have branded the exact hour and minute of Earth’s entry into spring’s cosmic alignment (March 20 at 6:45 p.m. this year), but many prefer more personal markers of the coming season. Whether you find yourself staring at the pallid face of the full moon; listening to the first cold, unmusical trills of frogs; or considering March’s swelling tree buds, it is comforting to discover the earthly evidence of what is clearly ancient magic. We are still connected to the timeless.

headline: CaixaBank of Spain Pushes Ahead With Offer for Portuguese Bank BPI
text: MADRID — CaixaBank of Spain said on Friday that it would push ahead with a takeover bid for the Portuguese bank BPI, even after BPI’s board rejected its offer of about 1.08 billion euros and one of BPI’s largest investors urged it to consider another merger plan.

headline: “Mommy, Will You Marry Us?”
text: Lori Cimino, left, and Julie Durden, right, were married Feb. 21 in a group same-sex ceremony at the James Royal Palm Hotel in Miami Beach.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Thinner Solved!
text: On Thursday we challenged Well readers to solve the case of a middle-aged woman with arthritis who developed a wasting illness after what looked like a simple cold. Her rheumatologist was worried that the immune suppressing medications the patient took to treat her joint disease had caused the new illness. More than 300 of you took on the challenge, and 17 of you correctly identified this rarity. The correct diagnosis is …

headline: A Modern Marriage With Multiple Parts
text: Growing up in Miami, Lori Cimino described herself as, “stubborn and bratty” and someone who “dug my heels into whatever it was I thought I wanted.”

headline: Meet the Margiela and Louis Vuitton Alum Who Staged Paris Fashion Week’s Buzziest Show So Far
text: A mob scene gathered outside of the seedy Paris gay club Le Dépot last night, awaiting entry to Vetements’ fall/winter 2015 show. Inside, major critics and major stars — Kanye West and Jared Leto among them — were on hand to witness the Vetements creative director Demna Gvasalia’s third collection. Gvasalia, a Georgian-born, Paris-based designer, learned his skills at the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Antwerp and honed his craft at Maison Martin Margiela and Louis Vuitton. After becoming frustrated with the business model of designers keeping established fashion houses afloat, Gvasalia stepped out on his own, making his own rules on the way.

headline: Jets Will Acquire Brandon Marshall and Re-Sign David Harris
text: It will take far more than one bold move, one major trade and one critical re-signing for the Jets to contend again. But after an off-season of sweeping change throughout the organization, the Jets’ march toward respectability continued Friday with the biggest personnel decisions made so far by the team’s new general manager, Mike Maccagnan.

headline: Black Comedians in South Africa Put Power in the Punch Lines
text: JOHANNESBURG — It was a warm Friday morning in Braamfontein, a hip neighborhood here. Inside an airy loft with views of the Nelson Mandela Bridge, a young television crew was assembled around a conference table, in heated debate about the coming week’s broadcast.

headline: Paul Taylor, at 84, Has a New Mission With American Modern Dance
text: So, how often does Paul Taylor attend dance performances?

headline: Murry Sidlin’s ‘Defiant Requiem’ Returns to Avery Fisher Hall
text: Can there be more than one way to think and feel about “Defiant Requiem,” the concert-drama based on musical activity in the Nazi concentration camp at Terezin during the Holocaust, conceived by the conductor Murry Sidlin? On the surface, at least, the production seems to represent only good — noble intentions, spiritual uplift and redemption — and it unquestionably holds profound meaning for many who are connected with it or have witnessed it.

headline: 50 Years On, Association for Advancement of Creative Musicians Influences Jazz
text: Muhal Richard Abrams, the restlessly inventive pianist and composer, is a next-step thinker, not the type to rhapsodize about the past. But he has lately found cause to reflect on a time, 50 years ago on the South Side of Chicago, when he began to mobilize his peers in pursuit of originality and self-determination, ending up with a collective called the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians.

headline: Germany Sets Gender Quota in Boardrooms
text: BERLIN — Germany on Friday became the latest and most significant country so far to commit to improving the representation of women on corporate boards, passing a law that requires some of Europe’s biggest companies to give 30 percent of supervisory seats to women beginning next year.

headline: Heems Talks About ‘Eat Pray Thug’
text: Himanshu Suri, the musician and artist known as Heems, is an operator across worlds that may seem, at first, incompatible.

headline: Maison Margiela: Fall 2015 RTW

headline: A Makeover, With Monsters
text: Gilbert Gottfried doesn’t remember his parents ever owning furniture that matched. Thus, as a child growing up in Brooklyn, he found it strange to visit people whose sofa had even a nodding acquaintance with their easy chair or lounger. When the gravel-voiced comedian and actor was old enough to move to his own place, a two-bedroom rental in Chelsea, he outfitted it with a motley assortment of curbside castoffs.

headline: Out of a Struggle With Infertility, Success
text: Fourteen years ago, when Robert Johnson, now 31, donned his navy blue trumpet jacket, he never thought that getting outfitted like a “screaming” nerd would attract anything other than an acceptance to the college of his choice, let alone a wife. The circle of young instrumentalists was small and exclusive, so meeting someone new was rare: Everyone just knew one another.

text: New York City is suffering from dive-bar-collapse disorder, with old gin mills either disappearing (Jackie’s Fifth Amendment, Blarney Cove), forced to move (Subway Inn) or sanitized beyond recognition (Mars Bar).

headline: Menendez and Melgen, Florida Eye Doctor, Have a Long History
text: Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, is expected to face federal corruption charges related to his relationship with Dr. Salomon E. Melgen, a Florida eye doctor who has been his longtime political benefactor.

headline: The Little Hotel That Couldn’t
text: Pinched between behemoth buildings on East 61st Street and within earshot of the Queensboro Bridge’s stampeding roar, and most easily spied by looking down from the Roosevelt Island tram, is the Mount Vernon Hotel Museum & Garden, a fashionable resort in the era of Andrew Jackson.

headline: Deaths Reported in Syria of Top Figures in Group Affiliated With Al Qaeda
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A loyalist of Osama bin Laden who trained fighters to battle American troops in Iraq and became a commander of Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Syria was killed there in the last week along with three fellow leaders, according to Syrian insurgents and a monitoring organization.

headline: Hampton Creek, Maker of Plant-Based Protein Foods, Signs Distribution Deal With Foodbuy
text: Hampton Creek, the upstart maker of foods that incorporate plant proteins instead of eggs, has signed a deal that will significantly increase distribution of its products.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Erik Larson’s ‘Dead Wake’

headline: At the Independent Fair, Art Not Quite on the Margin
text: New York is literally a flurry. As yet another fresh blast of snow blankets the city, the art set has descended upon Manhattan for the whirlwind series of art fairs collectively known as Armory Week. As part of the lineup, the Independent fair, entering its sixth year, has once again set up camp in the former Dia exhibition space in West Chelsea. Compared to the vast pier complex housing the Armory Show itself, organizers of the Independent have opted to remain in the decidedly smaller location, featuring a trim and well-curated selection of 50 galleries — a welcome amuse-bouche to what can otherwise seem like a glut of exhibitors.

headline: Investigator Admits Guilt in Hiring of a Hacker
text: A private investigator who has done work for small New York City law firms that specialize in personal injury and medical malpractice litigation pleaded guilty on Friday in federal court in Manhattan to one charge of conspiracy in hiring a hacker to help with his investigation.

headline: Urging Persistence on Racial Gains, Obama Recalls Sacrifice in Selma
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — For the nation’s first African-American president, it was a week of two documents that told the story of a country still grappling with its own history.

headline: What a College Stunt Says About Higher Education Today
text: In an age rife with “disruptions” to the higher education system, one man claims to have employed an appealingly simple one: Just show up on campus, and never actually enroll.

headline: Families of Flight 370 Victims Fear Silence as World Moves On
text: PARIS — Most of the time, Ghyslain Wattrelos believes that his wife and two of his three children are dead.

headline: U.S. Constricts Snake Trade, But Boa Wriggles Free
text: The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service today extended trade and import bans to four species of constricting snakes that can devastate native wildlife, but the agency dropped the boa constrictor from consideration because it is already so widely reared and kept as a pet.

headline: Remembering Albert Maysles
text: Albert Maysles, the pioneering documentary filmmaker who frequently collaborated with his brother, David, died Thursday at 88. His influential career spanned nearly 60 years.

headline: Klimt Work Should Remain in Austria, Panel Says
text: BERLIN — Gustav Klimt’s gold leaf and mother-of-pearl masterpiece, the “Beethoven Frieze,” should remain in Austria, a government panel said in rejecting a claim that its Jewish former owner had been forced to sell it. Austria’s Art Restitution Advisory Board “recommended unanimously” that the 112-foot-long work remain in possession of the government, which bought it from Erich Lederer in 1972.

headline: Coffee With Neighborhood Joes
text: D’Amico Coffee Roasters in Carroll Gardens offers a rare equilibrium of old and new Brooklyn, attracting old-timers who are happy to chat with the younger customers bearing computers or strollers.

headline: At D’Amico Coffee Roasters, Old and New Brooklyn Meet
text: Late on a Saturday morning, a small flock of retired longshoremen settled around the low tables of D’Amico’s. A young woman with earbuds sat focused on her laptop as the old-timers took their seats around her, boxing her into a corner next to an enormous, gleaming coffee roaster. The old-timers bickered and dissected the day’s tabloids, cheerfully criticizing one another in vanishing Brooklyn vernacular. Occasionally, Frank or Tony would nudge the young woman for an opinion: “Is this guy nuts or what?” She would momentarily remove an earbud and nod, then go back online. Augie, a neighborhood electrician, punctuated the din with the stamping of coffee bags.

headline: ‘Bates Motel’ Grows in Character and Creepiness in Season 3
text: When it began in 2013, the A&E series “Bates Motel” was an intriguing idea with uncertain staying power. As it starts Season 3 on Monday night, it has evolved into a deftly acted story of small-town dysfunction, creepy when it needs to be yet far more wide ranging than the movie that inspired it.

headline: As Clinton Stumbles, Conservatives Stir Democrats’ Pot
text: The furor over Hillary Rodham Clinton’s private email account as secretary of state has delighted Republicans this week, but conservatives are not done trying to make the most of her misfortunes.

headline: Adding Good Deeds to the Investment Equation
text: EVERY two years, the residents of Richmond, Calif., a city long known for some of the highest rates of violence in the United States, gather to discuss its priorities. For years, the No. 1 concern was crime.

headline: Obama Announces Optimistic Jobs Figures
text: The president announced an increase in job creation but also said that the unemployment rate nationwide, especially among African-Americans, remained too high and that there was more work to do.

headline: Sex Expert’s Secret Is Out, and China’s Open to It
text: BEIJING — Li Yinhe, China’s leading advocate of freewheeling sexuality, has been shocking this outwardly prudish nation for three decades.

headline: Where Terrorism Research Goes Wrong
text: TERRORISM is increasing. According to the Global Terrorism Database at the University of Maryland, groups connected with Al Qaeda and the Islamic State committed close to 200 attacks per year between 2007 and 2010, a number that grew by more than 200 percent, to about 600 attacks, in 2013.

headline: Winners of the Night of the Stars Charity Bridge Event
text: One of the most successful bridge charity events is the Night of the Stars. This year’s edition, the eighth, was played on Feb. 26 at the Royal Hospital for Neuro-disability in Putney, southwest London. This pro-am raised more than 50,500 pounds (about $76,760) for four charities.

headline: For Zhang Huang, Love’s Battlefield Is a Ming Dynasty Temple
text: Retold throughout Greek and Roman antiquity, the myth of Semele, consort to Jove and mother of Bacchus, has come to symbolize the amorous heights of love as well as the precipitous fall that so often follows; it’s a classic tale of love betrothed and betrayed, divine dalliance and mortal downfall. Indeed, for the contemporary Chinese artist Zhang Huan, whose restaging of Handel’s 18th-century operatic version of the myth opens for its first U.S. run this week at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the constant of any opera “is found in the attention it pays to the human desire.” Speaking via an interpreter from his Shanghai studio a few days before the curtain was set to raise, Zhang freely admitted that he initially lacked interest in opera as an art form. Known for large-scale bronze statues of disembodied Buddhas and performance pieces entailing body suits made of raw meat, Zhang’s appointment to direct Handel’s opera in 2009, for the Brussels-based opera house La Monnaie, raised the eyes of both opera and art-world aficionados. “I had hoped people not only saw an opera, but also performance art,” Zhang says. “‘Semele,'” he quickly adds, “was my very first opera, and it will be my very last.”

headline: If Warren Beatty Is Directing, Shooting Can Wait. For Years.
text: LOS ANGELES — An incurable tinkerer, Warren Beatty was at work again last weekend, shooting a scene for a 40-year passion project whose status is almost as mysterious as its subject: the industrialist Howard Hughes.

headline: Review: In ‘Platform 2015,’ the Beauty of Ragged Edges at Danspace Project
text: If you mate a stellar ballet dancer with an adventurous postmodern choreographer-dancer, what do you get? A mix-and-match duet? When Claudia La Rocco, a freelance critic for The New York Times, organized six such pairings as part of “Platform 2015: Dancers, Buildings and People in the Streets,” she wisely imposed no format on her recruits.

headline: Review: Augusta Read Thomas’s Spiritual ‘Resounding Earth’
text: Budding composers are well advised to write for standard instrumentation: The simpler and more common the forces required, the higher the chances of a piece getting performances beyond the premiere.

headline: Holder Weighs Dismantling the Ferguson Police Dept.
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. vowed a firm response on Friday to what he called “appalling” racial misconduct by law enforcement officials in Ferguson, Mo., suggesting he was prepared to seek the dismantling of the police force there if necessary.

headline: State of Change
text: As we were organizing this issue, we were struck — and rather hard — by the myriad confounding ideas and influences percolating right now in the world of men’s fashion and style. It’s as if a tectonic shift is happening beneath us — a bit destabilizing but full of possibility. Culture and behavior change slowly, so it’s not as though anyone is going to topple over from the force of the new ideas here, but the currents are strong nonetheless.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Bagels, Basketball, Banchan and Burrata
text: As co-owner of three restaurants in Brooklyn (Talde, Pork Slope and Thistle Hill Tavern) and two recently opened in Jersey City (Talde Jersey City and Carrino Provisions), the chef and entrepreneur Dale Talde spends much of his time putting out fires: a no-show cook, an inadequate bread delivery, the perpetual turnover of employees. Now Mr. Talde, a 36-year-old former “Top Chef” contestant, has a new project. He is catering his own wedding. In October, he will marry Agnes Chung, 28, a reporter for NY1, in the Hudson Valley. The couple lives in Downtown Brooklyn.

headline: ‘The Events’ Uses Local Choirs for Vocals, Minus a Script
text: Two hours before going onstage at New York Theater Workshop in “The Events,” by the Scottish playwright David Greig, Susan Glass had only a vague, fumbling-in-the-dark sense of what she and her Greenwich Village community chorus, the Glass Menagerie, were getting into.

headline: An Argument for Hearing a Work With a Nazi Reference
text: The Germans who invaded the Soviet Union in 1941 are represented in Shostakovich’s “Leningrad” Symphony by an unexpectedly bright tune that hardens into a bitter march. Recent Metropolitan Opera audiences may recognize it from Lehar’s operetta “The Merry Widow” as an echo of the melody to which Count Danilo sings “I’m off to Chez Maxim.”

headline: In a Dance Remix of Netanyahu’s Speech, Two Words Echo: ‘Iran — Haman’
text: As the debate continues over this week’s address to Congress by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, an Israeli video blogger’s dance remix of the speech seems to suggest that it can be boiled down to two words: “Iran — Haman.”

headline: Metropolitan Opera Board to Have a New President
text: The Metropolitan Opera, which has been grappling with serious financial challenges, will soon have a new president of its board of directors.

headline: Inside T’s Spring Men’s Style Issue
text: T’s latest issue examines the many conflicting ideas at play in men’s fashion and style today. No one embraced those contradictions more than our cover subject, the legendary Jean-Michel Basquiat: We peek inside his closely guarded notebooks and shine a light on the painter as you’ve never seen him before. Shayne Oliver, the Hood by Air designer who likely would have rolled in Basquiat’s circle had he been born 20 years earlier, shares with us the many diverse influences behind his gender-fluid street wear. In an essay focusing on clothes like Oliver’s, Jon Caramanica traces how rap icons such as Raekwon and Kanye West have influenced not only street fashion, but the runway as well. We’ve also dressed some of France’s most talented men in some of the season’s best clothes — proving that some things, like brooding-French-artist chic, never lose their appeal. Elsewhere, Andrew O’Hagan combs through the male overgrooming epidemic, looking for chaos amid the order; Jody Rosen travels to Ordos, China, one of the world’s most famous ghost towns that wants to be so much more; the artist Pablo Bronstein takes us inside his home in Deal, England, where antique glamour and campy kitsch live in curious harmony; and Marilyn Manson and John Waters test out an urban scooter and one-legged pants, with predictably weird results. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Memo to Therapists: It’s Not Me, It’s You
text: How should I tell my therapist, on Day 2 of our relationship, that we aren’t a good fit? Of all of therapy’s potential etiquette minefields — the client who unleashes his searing revelations three minutes before the end of sessions; the therapist who nods off, or whose picture keeps popping up on clients’ People You May Know feature on Facebook — termination seems like one of the more challenging ones. How do you skitter without scratching the parquet?

headline: Review: Vladan Nikolic’s ‘Allure’ Shows New York Through Immigrants’ Eyes
text: The complicated lives of four immigrant women casually intersect in “Allure,” a title that accurately reflects the seductive quality of its black-and-white images. The Serbian-born director, Vladan Nikolic, seems to have a knack for choosing dexterous cinematographers. (He has twice used his wildly gifted countryman Vladimir Subotic.) Here he passes the reins to Aleksandar Kostic, who turns New York City into a dreamy melting pot of conflict and yearning.

headline: For Some in Transgender Community, It’s Never Too Late to Make a Change
text: One Friday night last fall, 50 well-dressed guests piled into an apartment in Hell’s Kitchen for a party celebrating Sheela-Marie Padgett, a 57-year-old former dancer with the New York City Ballet.

headline: After a Homecoming, a Son Finds His Muse
text: A book editor is downsized out of a job, but finds salvation and inspiration for a memoir when he returns home to care for his mom.

headline: Bill Cunningham | A Breath of Fresh Air
text: Young members of the experimental art world and the unorthodox fashion world staged shows filled with new expressions and an audience to match.

headline: Bill Cunningham | A Breath of Fresh Air
text: Young members of the experimental art world and the unorthodox fashion world are vividly shown here. The Spring/Break Art Show, in the dilapidated main post office on 31st Street, was filled with experimental ideas and conceptual displays. The show ($10) is open through Sunday; enter on the corner of 31st Street and Eighth Avenue. During fashion week, young designers staged off-site shows filled with new expressions and an audience to match. They often outshone the main runway shows.

headline: Friday Night Music: The Lone Bellow, Button
text: Zach Williams usually sings lead for this “Brooklyn country music” trio, but all three are star-quality performers. They have a new album out, which is great — but I ran across this performance of a song from their first, and had to share.

headline: Deriving From Photographs
text: “Richard Estes: Painting New York City,” an exhibition, opens March 10 at the Museum of Arts and Design.

headline: From Snapshots Come Paintings: Work by Richard Estes
text: “For every one painting I make, I probably take about 100 photos,” said Richard Estes, who is neither a hyperrealist nor a photorealist, but a “photo-derived” painter, according to Patterson Sims, the curator of an exhibition titled “Richard Estes: Painting New York City,” which opens March 10 at the Museum of Arts and Design.
