text: The Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra announced on Friday that it had extended the contract of its music director, Louis Langrée, through its 125th anniversary season in 2019­-20.

headline: Police Release Ottawa Gunman’s Video
text: OTTAWA — A cellphone video made by a gunman moments before he opened fire in Canada’s Parliament and at a war memorial, killing a soldier, was released by the police on Friday, more than four months after the violent events.

headline: From the Archives: Where’s the Spirit of Selma Now?
text: This story by Gay Talese ran in The New York Times Magazine on May 30, 1965, almost three months after the attacks on demonstrators at the Edmund Pettus Bridge. In advance of the 50th anniversary of the 1965 march, he returned to Selma to report on Selma today and what has changed and what has not over the past half century.

headline: Unlikely Allies in a Gay Rights Battle in Georgia
text: ATLANTA — Former Attorney General Michael J. Bowers of Georgia has already earned an enduring — his critics would say notorious — place in gay rights history.

headline: Women See Themselves as Left Out Amid Talk of Change in Catholic Church
text: VATICAN CITY — In the first two years of his papacy, Pope Francis has stirred great expectations for change among Roman Catholics who believe that the church has not kept pace with the social transformations of secular society.

headline: Resolution Censures Chemical Weapons
text: In an unusual display of unity over the divisive four-year-old conflict in Syria, the Security Council passed a resolution on Friday that condemned the use of chlorine as a chemical weapon in that country, and threatened sanctions that could include a military response to any further violations. The resolution, drafted by the United States, was approved 14-0, with one abstention, from Venezuela. The resolution followed a report this year by the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons that chlorine bombs had been used in the conflict, even after the Syrian government had signed the global treaty banning such munitions and had agreed to the destruction of its arsenal, which was basically completed by June. Like that report, the Security Council resolution did not specify which side in the conflict had used the chlorine bombs. But critics of the Syrian government, including the United States, have pointed out that the bombs had been seen dropped from helicopters, which are only possessed by the Syrian military.

headline: The Labor Picture in February
text: The Labor Department said Friday the unemployment Rate in the United States decreased to 5.50 percent in February of 2015 from 5.70 percent in January of 2015. That’s the lowest unemployment rate since May 2008. This month 295,000 jobs were created, exceeding economists’ expectations.

headline: A Thick Trail of Breadcrumbs Leads to Aspiring New York Police Officers
text: The union boss remembers meeting him two or three years ago, before the kid had turned 21. Must have been — the young man was, after all, heading out that night to try to buy beer at bodegas in Manhattan in a sting operation meant to curb sales of alcohol to the under aged.

headline: Books on New York’s Role in the Civil War, and Coney Island
text: The sesquicentennial celebration of the Civil War culminates next month with 150-year-old images of City Hall draped in black. “The Nation Mourns,” a banner proclaims from the portico, and thousands of curious and inconsolable New Yorkers queue up to view the body of Abraham Lincoln for the last time.

headline: Iraqi Forces Said to Near ISIS-Held Tikrit
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s largest offensive against Islamic State militants came a step closer to the city of Tikrit on Friday, with Shiite militiamen and Iraqi troops advancing into the town of Dour, according to Iraqi state television.

headline: In Mexico, an Extreme Race in the Shadow of Extreme Danger
text: Josue Stephens, one of the organizers of the Caballo Blanco ultramarathon last week in Urique, Mexico, realized something was amiss when he was warned not to drive along the coastal route because so many people had been killed there recently. When he finally got to Urique, he saw armed men in bulletproof vests swarm into the local police station, take everyone’s guns and throw two officers into the back of a truck before barreling away.

headline: A Third Blast on Oil Trains Stirs Scrutiny
text: For the third time in less than a month, a train carrying flammable crude oil has derailed and burst into flames, prompting questions over whether stricter measures being considered to ensure their safety will be enough.

headline: Pakistan Honors Victims of School Massacre
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Education officials in northwestern Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province have renamed more than a hundred schools in honor of the children killed last year in a Taliban attack on an army-run public school in Peshawar, the provincial capital.

headline: The Boring Life of a Private Investigator
text: WHEN I first became a private investigator, I was enthralled by the idea of the brash gumshoe who was modeled on the American cowboy and incubated in the pulps — a lawless lone wolf.

headline: After Rory McIlroy’s Shot Drops Into Water, His 3-Iron Suffers the Same Fate
text: DORAL, Fla. — Rory McIlroy fleetingly considered giving the 3-iron in his right hand a reprieve. Then frustration got the better of him, and he flung it into the same water hazard on the Blue Monster course that seconds earlier had swallowed his golf ball.

headline: U.S. Attorney Keeps Talking, but Leaves Out Sheldon Silver
text: One day after the arrest of Sheldon Silver, the former State Assembly speaker, in January, Manhattan’s top federal prosecutor spoke at a local law school about public corruption, alluding repeatedly to Mr. Silver when castigating the way deals were made in Albany, by “three men in a room.”

headline: U.S. Relied on Unarmed South Korean Officer to Protect Envoy
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The United States was relying on a lone, unarmed South Korean police bodyguard to protect Mark W. Lippert, the American ambassador to South Korea, when he was attacked Thursday, a senior United States official said Friday, adding to questions in South Korea about whether security had been too lax.

headline: Asking Megadonors for Just a Million
text: The coffers of Jeb Bush’s not-quite-declared campaign for president are filling at such a rate that fund-raisers have reportedly been instructed not to ask megadonors to give more than $1 million each this quarter. The concern is seemliness — that acceptance of multimillion-dollar checks from deep-pocketed supporters could bolster the impression that Mr. Bush, the former Florida governor, is in their debt, according to a Washington Post report.

headline: Brian Carman, Surf Rocker, Dies at 69
text: Brian Carman, who as a high school student in the early 1960s helped write the instrumental surf-rock hit “Pipeline” for his band, the Chantays, died on Sunday at his home in Santa Ana, Calif. He was 69.

headline: Jobs and the Federal Reserve
text: The latest jobs report showed that unemployment fell to 5.5 percent in February and that 295,000 jobs were added to the economy. But the labor market is not as healthy as those figures might suggest.

headline: Better Bonding Through Telenovelas
text: Two people are unable to console each other during their mutual bereavement in “Guadalupe in the Guest Room,” the first of three world premieres being staged in the coming months by Two River Theater in Red Bank. There is a language barrier between the 30-something Steve (Charles Socarides) and Guadalupe (Socorro Santiago), his mother-in-law, as they mourn the untimely death of his wife, Claudia. A native of Mexico, the widowed Guadalupe possesses only a rudimentary knowledge of English. Steve’s command of Spanish is equally poor.

headline: Harve Bennett, Quiz Kid and ‘Star Trek’ Producer, Dies at 84
text: Harve Bennett, who navigated a rocky path from childhood stardom to youthful disaffection to adult success as a producer of four “Star Trek” films and an Emmy-winning TV movie, died on Feb. 25 in Medford, Ore. He was 84.

headline: When the Elephants Exit the Big Top
text: Was Ringling Brothers right to ban the elephants from their shows?

headline: Holidays That Reflect New York’s Students
text: New York City’s decision to add two Muslim holidays to the public school calendar is welcome news — not just for Muslim pupils, an estimated 10 percent of the city’s 1.1 million public school children, who will no longer have to skip school to celebrate with their families, but for all New Yorkers who believe that the school system is made stronger when it adapts to reflect the diverse and growing communities it serves. The holidays are Eid al-Fitr, which marks the end of the holy month of Ramadan, and Eid al-Adha, a commemoration of the willingness of Ibrahim, or Abraham, to sacrifice his son at God’s command.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 6, 2015
text: March 6, 2015

headline: Republicans Set Up Shop in Iowa, Where Few Will Prosper
text: DES MOINES — There are so many reasons for Republicans to ignore Iowa.

headline: Bullets Over Washington
text: In 1986, Congress passed, and Ronald Reagan signed into law, the Law Enforcement Officers Protection Act. It directed the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives to ban certain types of ammunition that could pierce the body armor worn by police officers. The National Rifle Association had originally opposed the legislation — which, in fact, was one of a series of events that caused a split between the N.R.A. and most police associations — but the logic behind it was irrefutable.

headline: Around the World in a Song
text: In the age of the global village, a musician need not have vast experience living in a particular country to evoke its culture. Commitment and a connection to that country’s wider community — actual or virtual — can suffice.

headline: Journeys in Gender
text: Gender transitions are difficult but rewarding for many, including Sheela-Marie Padgett, a former dancer.

headline: Review: In ‘Reverberation,’ Singles Adrift in the Big City
text: HARTFORD — Grief begets isolation, and isolation begets loneliness in “Reverberation,” a keenly felt, haunting drama by Matthew Lopez about two New Yorkers adrift in their lives who strike up a sustaining friendship. The play, making its premiere here at Hartford Stage, has the cool but precise observational feel of current television shows about singles in the city like HBO’s “Girls” and “Looking,” at least until an ill-judged spasm of violence at the end shatters the elliptical mood.

headline: Science as a Vocation
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Most people don’t notice when a puzzle is a PANGRAM (the grid uses every letter FROM A TO Z, once), but you might have a vague sense of it while solving. Every time you fill in a “rare” letter, like J, K, Q, V or Z, you might wonder if you’ll eventually run into all 26 letters of the alphabet in your crossword puzzle.

headline: Federal Court in Alabama Is Asked to Clear Way for Same-Sex Marriages
text: ATLANTA — Lawyers for gay and civil rights groups on Friday asked a federal court in Mobile, Ala., to force the state’s probate judges to once again issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, three days after the Alabama Supreme Court ordered them to stop.

headline: In New Haven, an Exhibition on a Yale Professor Who Helped Rescue Art During World War II
text: As the Allied forces advanced north in Italy  during the last year of World War II, Capt. Deane Keller arrived in Pisa and found that the fighting had left much of the ancient city reduced to rubble.

headline: Harlem Man Is Convicted of Murdering His Girlfriend
text: A Harlem man was convicted of second-degree murder on Friday in the death of his girlfriend, whom he stabbed 38 times before hiding her body in a plastic barrel in his bedroom.

headline: Cardinal Egan Is Recalled Fondly at a Chapel He Called Home
text: As the leader of the sprawling Archdiocese of New York, Cardinal Edward M. Egan could be seen as a fierce defender of church doctrines and a no-nonsense administrator who closed or merged parishes and schools to help restore the archdiocese to financial stability.

headline: Jeb Bush Kicks Off Courtship of Iowa
text: URBANDALE, Iowa – Jeb Bush, making his first visit to this presidential kickoff state as a likely candidate, began his bid to win the caucuses here by paying tribute to two Iowa touchstones and calibrating his message about why he supports education standards loathed by many conservatives.

headline: Bridgehampton Chamber Music Festival Adds a Spring Series
text: The Bridgehampton Chamber Music Festival, a highly regarded summer event, will expand its offerings this month with a new spring series.

headline: Yale Beats Harvard to Take Control of Ivy League
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — The basketball rivalry between Harvard and Yale dates to the 1900-1 season, when John Kirkland Clark, a former Bulldog, introduced the sport to the Crimson athletic department while attending law school at Harvard.

headline: Carlos Beltran Has No Hits, but No Pain, in His Return for Yankees
text: TAMPA, Fla. — What Carlos Beltran did Friday night against the Pittsburgh Pirates did not show up in the box score. Making his spring training debut, Beltran struck out twice, walked on four pitches and made one meaningful throw, corralling Neil Walker’s double and getting the ball back in cleanly.

headline: Readers Drawn Into Debate Over U.C.L.A. Student’s Jewish Background
text: In Kerckhoff Hall, the bustling student union building at the University of California, Los Angeles, a student council meeting was underway. Not exactly newsworthy, one would argue, if not for what came after.

headline: Room to Breathe In the Mediterranean
text: Here’s the question: In Armonk, a town chockablock with a range of dining spots, some highly lauded, how does newcomer Fattoria Dinner House distinguish itself, apart from its unwieldy name?

headline: A Japanese Pub on the Saugatuck
text: The chef Bill Taibe began his gustatory takeover of Westport modestly, with the minuscule Le Farm. Then he opened the Welk. His newest venture is Kawa Ni, which is Japanese for “on the river” — it is at the bridge overlooking the Saugatuck River.

headline: Where Mediterranean Leans Lebanese
text: When I walk into a “Mediterranean” restaurant, it’s hard to know what kind of food to expect. It could be Israeli or Syrian or Turkish or Egyptian. I could be looking forward to kofta and end up with a menu full of risottos or spinach pies, given the diverse countries that surround that sea.

headline: Portuguese Flavors, and Plenty to Take Home
text: Here are two helpful hints on visiting Lisbon Cafe in Carle Place: Come hungry and don’t be shy about asking for doggy bags. Generosity should be the middle name of this Portuguese restaurant, which opened in January.

headline: Corrections: March 7, 2015
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “I have always conducted myself in accordance with the law.”

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
text: 9 P.M. (Showtime) INSIDE LLEWYN DAVIS (2013) Oscar Isaac portrays Llewyn, an aspiring folk singer mourning the death of his musical partner (the voice of Marcus Mumford) and leaving mayhem — a crying hostess, a pregnant woman, an escaped cat — in his wake as he bounces from couch to couch in Greenwich Village during a single week in 1961. Carey Mulligan, Justin Timberlake, Stark Sands and Adam Driver round out the cast as Llewyn’s fellow folk singers; John Goodman is a drug-addicted jazzman; and Garrett Hedlund is a Beat poet. And while Llewyn’s background and antics were inspired by the life of Dave Van Ronk, “this is not a biopic, it’s a Coen brothers movie, which is to say a brilliant magpie’s nest of surrealism, period detail and pop-culture scholarship,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Mr. Isaac, a versatile character actor here ascending to the highest levels of his craft, refuses the easy road of charm.” One of the film’s lessons, as Mr. Scott sees it, is: “We are, as a species, ridiculous: vain, ugly, selfish and self-deluding. But somehow, some of our attempts to take stock of this condition — our songs and stories and moving pictures, old and new — manage to be beautiful, even sublime.”

headline: What to Expect on the Fourth Day of Paris Fashion Week
text: Junya Watanabe is a strong, silent type. The man makes the Sphinx look chatty. So you’re as unlikely to get a preview of his collection as you are to get an explanation after.

headline: Grim Prospects Drive an Exodus From Kosovo
text: For months now, buses have been bringing Kosovo Albanians through Serbia to the porous land border with Hungary, which is in the European Union.

headline: Kosovars Who Fought for Land Are Now Eager to Leave
text: STANOVC, Kosovo — The extended Cakaj family has built a few dozen homes here, along Tony Blair Street, between the Dubai supermarket and the French peacekeepers base, in a clannish faith that closeness would bring security. But recently the family of Kosovo Albanians has begun to splinter, as a disastrous economy, static politics and a newly created opening in the border with Serbia have enticed tens of thousands of Kosovars to leave their troubled land in search of opportunity and work.

text: Ben Casselman reads an op-ed in the Wall Street Journal and declares,

headline: Haider Ackermann: Fall 2015 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Brazil Bribery Inquiry Targets Top Politicians
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s highest court on Friday authorized an investigation of dozens of prominent political figures, including the leaders of both houses of Congress, intensifying a sweeping bribery scandal that is bedeviling President Dilma Rousseff’s government at a time when she is grappling with a sluggish economy.

headline: 2 Suspects Are Detained in Killing of Kremlin Critic
text: MOSCOW — Two suspects have been detained in the killing of the opposition leader Boris Y. Nemtsov, the head of Russia’s internal law enforcement agency announced on Saturday.

headline: Gunman Kills Five in Restaurant in Mali
text: DAKAR, Senegal — A masked gunman opened fire on a restaurant in Mali’s capital, Bamako, early Saturday morning, killing at least two Europeans — a Frenchman and a Belgian — and three Malians.

headline: At Hotels, One-Day-Only Vacations
text: If the “staycation” was the travel industry’s response to the Great Recession, the “daycation” is perhaps another sign of recovery from it.

headline: Elie Saab’s Fall 2015 Collection at Paris Fashion Week
text: The live stream from Elie Saab at Paris Fashion Week has ended. Watch the live stream here.

headline: 1951: Department Store Celebrates 2,000 Years of Paris
text: PARIS is celebrating her 2,000th anniversary this year. It completely slipped our mind until the other day when we were invited to a luncheon at the Plaza-Athénée to celebrate the occasion. The luncheon was given by Filene’s, a Boston department store, well known for remembering birthdays and anniversaries. The store’s executives had loaded down two of their representatives with 2,001 candles and instructions to bake a cake and throw a big blowout for the French capital.

headline: Mugler: Fall 2015 RTW
text: Paris

headline: How Much Is That Doggie Affecting Prices?
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Remembrance of NAIRUs Past
text: More on the Cromwellian aspect of monetary policy: the Philadelphia Fed has a helpful summary of Fed estimates of the NAIRU reaching back to 1989. Here’s what their numbers looked like on the eve of the great Clinton/Greenspan boom:

headline: Obama, at Selma Memorial, Says, ‘We Know the March Is Not Yet Over’
text: SELMA, Ala. — As a new generation struggles over race and power in America, President Obama and a host of political figures from both parties came here on Saturday, to the site of one of the most searing days of the civil rights era, to reflect on how far the country has come and how far it still has to go.

text: McDonald’s is having an identity crisis.

text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Haider Ackermann Fall/Winter 2015
text: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Secret Service Briefly Locks Down White House After Bomb-Sniffing Dog’s Alert and Nearby Fire
text: WASHINGTON — The White House was put under a security lockdown Saturday morning by the Secret Service after a bomb-sniffing dog alerted its handlers to examine a car not far from the presidential residence and offices, a spokesman for the agency said.

headline: Vivek Gupta of Zensar Technologies: Beware of Hiring People Just Like You
text: This interview with Vivek Gupta, C.E.O. of Zensar Technologies, a global software services company based in Pune, India, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Variety: A Fatigued Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Do you have trouble finding time to get to your daily crossword puzzle? I do, although I never miss a New York Times crossword, of course. It’s part of the job. What I have trouble with is finding the time to do some of the other indie puzzles out there, like the ones listed in the Blogroll. They’re fun and maybe, one day when the emus don’t need as much care, I will have a chance to actually solve some of them.

headline: Stagflation Predictions
text: Matt O’Brien catches a piece by Dick Morris a few years ago predicting that Obama’s legacy would be stagflation. But I say, oh yeah? I’ll see your Dick Morris (who cares, really?) and raise you a … Paul Ryan: Thirty Years Later, a Return to Stagflation.

headline: Jihadists May Have Wrecked an Ancient Iraqi Site
text: BAGHDAD — Iraqi officials said Saturday that they were investigating reports that Islamic State militants had destroyed Hatra, an archaeological site that dates to the first century B.C., two days after officials confirmed that the group had bulldozed another nearby site, the ancient Assyrian city of Nimrud.

headline: Yu Darvish May Need Season-Ending Surgery on Elbow
text: SURPRISE, Ariz. — Yu Darvish, a star right-hander for the Texas Rangers, may soon become the latest ace pitcher to have Tommy John surgery. The Rangers said Saturday that Darvish had a sprained ulnar collateral ligament in his right elbow and that their doctor had recommended the operation, which would cost Darvish the entire 2015 season.

headline: In Iowa, Christie Highlights His Agricultural Credentials
text: DES MOINES — Gov. Chris Christie on Saturday sought to appeal to hundreds of Iowans at a farming forum at the State Fairgrounds here by reminding them that that he, too, is from an agricultural state: “New Jersey is the Garden State, remember,’’ he said.

headline: Move Over Mao: Beloved ‘Papa Xi’ Awes China
text: BEIJING — The must-see tourist sights of the Chinese capital form a grandiose circuit: the Great Wall, the Forbidden City, Tiananmen Square and, for early birds willing to brave long lines, the mausoleum of Mao Zedong.

headline: To Break In Their Gloves, Yankees Dunk, Tenderize and Lather Up
text: TAMPA, Fla. — When Alex Rodriguez played in Texas, he noticed that as the hot, humid summers dragged on, they would take a toll on the glove he used to play shortstop. It would become heavy and malleable, losing the firm shape that he liked.

headline: At the Fed in 2009, Rolling the Dice in a Crisis
text: Ben Bernanke and his colleagues at the Federal Reserve Board have earned accolades from all corners for the extraordinary actions they took to rescue the financial system in 2009. While 2008 was the Fed’s annus horribilis, exposing how unaware the central bank had been of the risks building in the financial system, 2009 was its year of redemption.

headline: Mike Huckabee Strikes a Populist Tone at Iowa Agriculture Summit
text: DES MOINES — The agriculture industry generally supports free trade and an immigration overhaul, but former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas made clear Saturday at an industry summit here that he is more of a populist than many of the other Republican presidential hopefuls.

headline: Warren Buffett’s Awesome Feat at Berkshire Hathaway, Revisited
text: Warren Buffett is taking a victory lap, and on the 50th anniversary of his reign at Berkshire Hathaway he is entitled to it. From a failing New England textile company, Berkshire became the vehicle for one of capitalism’s greatest investing feats.

headline: After Talks, Nuclear Deal on Iran Is Seen as Close
text: PARIS — Secretary of State John Kerry wrapped up a week of diplomacy in Europe and the Middle East within what many experts say is striking distance of an initial accord with Iran over its nuclear program.

headline: Comme des Garçons: Fall 2015 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Unarmed Man Is Shot Dead by Police After Scuffle in Wisconsin
text: A 19-year-old Wisconsin man was shot and killed Friday by a police officer during a scuffle inside an apartment in Madison, police officials said. The shooting prompted protests that continued on Saturday and led officials to call for restraint while the shooting is investigated.

headline: Bosses Who Love Themselves
text: Try to avoid working for a company with a narcissist at the top. That’s because narcissistic C.E.O.s tend to overspend on investments and deliver substandard results. On top of that, they are often paid more than their humbler yet better-performing peers, according to a recent study.

headline: Zing and Talent Add Up to Hope for the Mets
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Pop. Pop! POP!

headline: Lawyers Seek Reprieve for Killer Who Lost Part of His Brain Decades Earlier
text: In January 1972, Cecil Clayton was cutting wood at his family’s sawmill in southeastern Missouri when a piece of lumber flew off the circular saw blade and struck him in the forehead. The impact caved in part of Mr. Clayton’s skull, driving bone fragments into his brain.

headline: Hiring a Coach to Spark the Job Hunt
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Martin O’Malley Steers Clear of Hillary Clinton Email Issue
text: Martin O’Malley, the former Maryland governor who is considering a bid for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2016, took a pass on Friday when asked about the controversy over Hillary Rodham Clinton’s email use at the State Department, but called transparency “required in the modern age.”

headline: Charter School in Miami Fails, but Proves Useful on Jeb Bush’s Résumé
text: MIAMI — “That’s where the classrooms were,” said Katrina Wilson-Davis, pointing at the deserted building that housed the school where she was once principal. She climbed the chipped stairs that children used to race down at recess in their cherry-red school uniforms and walked past a street sign that still warns drivers of a 15-mile-an-hour speed limit on school days.

headline: The Brands in Art Basel’s Orbit
text: When visitors arrive at Art Basel Hong Kong this month, they will be able to explore artwork by Richard Serra, Keith Haring and Ai Weiwei — along with a plethora of luxury brands decked out to show their artistic side.

headline: Tangled Case of a Baylor Football Player Poses a Test for the Rules of Eligibility
text: An apparently homeless Baylor football player was recently declared ineligible because of N.C.A.A. violations, resulting in a spasm of outrage followed by bewilderment. One week later, there remain more questions than answers about this case and, more important, about the procedure by which college students are barred from playing sports, an increasingly significant topic as the N.C.A.A.’s power to regulate its member institutions, from academics to amateurism, erodes.

headline: Heartbreak in Gaza
text: In Gaza, Nicholas Kristof finds the place still in ruins after last year’s war with Israel.

headline: Jeb Bush Stakes Out Contrary Position on Energy Subsidies in Iowa
text: DES MOINES — Jeb Bush said Saturday that he wanted to phase out federal benefits for renewable fuels and wind energy, using an agricultural summit here to side with his party’s free-market advocates over the industry groups who staged the forum.

headline: At Roger Vivier, Ankle Boots for Punk Sophisticates
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: The Week in Political Pictures
text: Netanyahu in Congress, health insurance subsidies, a “sled-in” and more.

headline: Acne: Fall 2015 RTW
text: Paris

headline: In Greece, Desperate Times and Offbeat Measures
text: PARIS — Despite the European accord last month to extend a financial lifeline to Greece, Athens is rapidly running out of cash.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
text: Netanyahu in Congress, health insurance subsidies, a “sled-in” and more.

headline: A Sexual Desire Drug
text: Responses to an Op-Ed essay that criticized a drug aimed at women who lack sex drive.

headline: Anne Curzan
text: Anne Curzan is a professor of English at the University of Michigan who specializes in the dynamism of modern language and gender differences in language use.

headline: Christians Loving Jews
text: HE was almost lost in the whirl of lawmakers, pundits, plutocrats and other boldface names who showed up for Benjamin Netanyahu’s speech to Congress last week. But the presence of Pat Boone was a key to understanding why John Boehner was playing a smart game of party politics to stand so solidly with the Israeli prime minister.

headline: The Case for Old Ideas
text: ONE of the anxieties haunting the 21st century is a fear that technological change will soon make many human lives seem essentially superfluous.

headline: What Ending Health Subsidies Means
text: If the Supreme Court rules that no federal tax credit subsidies can be provided to Americans buying insurance on federal health exchanges in 34 states, the economic effects could be devastating.

headline: Protect the Police From Armor-Piercing Bullets
text: The nation’s police forces should be the first to rally behind a federal proposal to ban the sale and manufacture of the 5.56-millimeter steel-core bullet. The bullet can be used in newly adapted handguns to provide lethal force to pierce the vests and body armor used by law enforcement officers.

headline: Making Clinton Coverage Bulletproof
text: IN an “open letter” to The Times last week, the author David Brock claimed that a high-profile story about Hillary Rodham Clinton’s email practices “had unraveled under scrutiny,” and was riddled with ”innuendo.” He demanded an immediate correction.

headline: With the Clintons, Only the Shadow Knows
text: WASHINGTON — SOMEWHERE in Smithsonian storage sits a portrait of Bill Clinton with two odd features: He is standing next to a shadow meant to conjure Monica Lewinsky’s blue dress, and he is not wearing his gold wedding ring.

headline: Winds of War in Gaza
text: GAZA — IT is winter in Gaza, in every wretched sense of the word. Six months after the latest war, the world has moved on, but tens of thousands remain homeless — sometimes crammed into the rubble of bombed-out buildings. Children are dying of the cold, according to the United Nations.

headline: Warhead Checklist: 12 Issues, 11 Unaddressed
text: Iran has declined to give technical replies to all but one of twelve specific allegations about its atom-bomb development.

headline: What Iran Won’t Say About the Bomb
text: OVER the course of a dozen years, ever since atomic sleuths from the United Nations began scrutinizing Iran’s nuclear program, hundreds of inspections have uncovered a hidden world of labs and sprawling factories, some ringed by barbed wire and antiaircraft guns, others camouflaged or buried deep underground. Yet despite that progress, Iran has so far managed to evade a central question — whether it knows how to build an atom bomb.

headline: America Needs Its Own Emojis
text: ALL I wanted to do was wish my fiancée happy birthday using emojis. But I couldn’t replicate the rebus of the classic Sandra Boynton greeting card: Hippo, Birdie, Two Ewes. My vocabulary was too limited.

headline: Sabotaging a Deal With Iran
text: Congressional critics of an emerging international agreement to limit Iran’s nuclear program moved with uncommon speed last week to force a vote that could have blown up the negotiations, which are now at a delicate stage. Cooler heads prevailed, and action was delayed. But Congress could still sabotage the deal.

headline: A Cable (and Girder) Guy
text: David Flores, 31, is a bridge inspection assistant team leader for HNTB, an architecture, engineering and construction firm. He is based in New York.

headline: Turned Away From Iowa Ag Summit
text: The Iowa Ag Summit, which has drawn Jeb Bush, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin and other leading 2016 Republican presidential hopefuls, is billed as a bipartisan event, but organizers turned away some ticket-holders who were registered Democrats without explanation.

headline: The Right Caddie? It Depends on the Golfer
text: DORAL, Fla. — After Adam Scott’s high-profile split with his caddie, dozens of suitors reached out to him, including a man who enclosed a photo of himself and claimed to have ties to Japan’s Imperial House. A match made in Snapchat, it was not.

headline: On the Case at Mount Sinai, It’s Dr. Data
text: Jeffrey Hammerbacher is a number cruncher — a Harvard math major who went from a job as a Wall Street quant to a key role at Facebook to a founder of a successful data start-up.

headline: The Cost of Paying Attention
text: A FEW years ago, in a supermarket, I swiped my bank card to pay for groceries. I watched the little screen, waiting for its prompts. During the intervals between swiping my card, confirming the amount and entering my PIN, I was shown advertisements. Clearly some genius had realized that a person in this situation is a captive audience.

headline: Egypt Executes an Islamist Supporter of Ousted President
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s government carried out the death penalty for the first time against an Islamist supporter of the ousted President Mohamed Morsi on Saturday, executing a man convicted of murder during the political violence that followed the military takeover of the government in 2013, the Interior Ministry said.

headline: Listeners Will Get the Birthday Gift
text: Longevity can assume a different order of magnitude in the jazz realm, where wisdom and experience are revered, and no one ever seems to retire. Still, there’s something singular about the staying power of the redoubtable drummer Roy Haynes, who will turn 90 on Friday, celebrating the occasion on the bandstand at the Blue Note.

headline: Amid Challenges, Humanity Arises
text: The annual ReelAbilities: NY Disabilities Film Festival is a workout for the emotions, full of both triumphant movies about overcoming adversity and sobering ones about struggle and loss. This year’s festival, the seventh, which runs from Thursday through March 18, is no exception.

headline: Ravishing Works Too Rarely Seen
text: “The Plains Indians: Artists of the Earth and Sky,” one of the greatest exhibitions of American Indian art you may ever see, opens Monday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The show was originated by the Musée du Quai Branly in Paris and the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art (where I saw it) in Kansas City, Mo., and organized by the inestimable Gaylord Torrence, the Nelson-Atkins’s curator in the field and also the orchestrator of its acclaimed permanent collection galleries.

headline: A Company Debut Is Also a Salute
text: When Merce Cunningham died in 2009 (it seemed sudden, though he was 90), his company embarked on a legacy tour, as he had instructed, performing around the world for two years before dissolving in New York on the eve of 2012. During this time, the privilege and burden of maintaining the celebrated Cunningham repertory fell to Robert Swinston, a veteran of the company for three decades. He joined as a dancer in 1980, became Cunningham’s assistant in 1992 and was named director of choreography after Cunningham’s death.

headline: Youth Isn’t Always Wasted
text: The music director of the New York Youth Symphony is often a rising star, and the talented, energetic Joshua Gersen, who currently holds the post, is no exception. He was recently named assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic, a prime steppingstone to a major career. On Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, he leads his superlative youth orchestra in Beethoven’s Violin Concerto (with Elena Urioste as soloist) and Rimsky-Korsakov’s colorful “Scheherazade.” The concert was also supposed to feature the premiere of Jonas Tarm’s “Marsh U Nebuttya,” but it was removed from the program when the orechestra discovered that it quoted a Nazi anthem. (2 p.m., 212-247-7800, nyyouthsymphony.org.)

headline: Tourist Traps Stand No Chance
text: What if you detoured around the tourist attractions when visiting a place for the first time and ventured off the beaten path? In “American Canvas,” which makes its premiere on Wednesday on Ovation, Dave Holmes focuses on the culture and history, not always mentioned in guidebooks, that make three cities distinctive. His journey begins in San Francisco, where he watches the Spidey-esque members of Bandaloop dance on the faces of skyscrapers with the help of rock-climbing equipment; traces the footsteps of Jack Kerouac and Allen Ginsberg; tosses a coin into an antique arcade machine; and samples the fare at the country’s oldest Chinatown. He also tours “@Large” an exhibition at Alcatraz, the former penitentiary, centered on freedom and confinement. Its creator, the Chinese artist and activist Ai Weiwei, considers himself to be in “soft detention,” he told The New York Times, his own passport withheld by his government.

headline: For Once, Expectation Returns the Cubs’ Embrace
text: MESA, Ariz. — David Ross has felt it once before, the euphoria of romping out to the mound as a World Series champion, bathed in the lights of an ancient ballpark in a flagship baseball town. He wants to do it again, which is why he picked the Chicago Cubs as a free agent this winter.

headline: A Bittersweet Bow for the Elephant
text: ON Thursday, Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus announced that its 13 traveling elephant performers would retire by 2018, ending a storied tradition for the Greatest Show on Earth.

headline: A Former Star Is Prepared for One Final Shot
text: These days, tennis comebacks arrive in all shapes and sizes, driven by injury, illness, burnout or suspension, sometimes after years away from the professional tours.

headline: African Training Exercise Turns Urgent as Threats Grow

These worries have prompted American and allied commandos to rush to train African counterterrorism troops to fight extremists on the continent.

headline: Kentucky Primary Change Would Allow Rand Paul to Run While Keeping Senate Seat

headline: In Iowa, Jeb Bush Risks Support With Unpopular Stances

headline: Dean Hess, Preacher and Fighter Pilot, Dies at 97
text: Dean Hess, a flying preacher who unwittingly bombed a German orphanage during World War II and six years later helped rescue hundreds of Korean foundlings endangered by Communist troops converging on Seoul, died on Monday at his home in Huber Heights, Ohio, near Dayton. He was 97.

headline: Ferguson Became Symbol, but Bias Knows No Border

The court system there, which is overseen by a white judge but has almost exclusively black defendants, routinely sends people to jail for failure to pay minor traffic fines, a new lawsuit alleges.

headline: Dirk Shafer, Playgirl Centerfold Who Revealed He Was Gay, Dies at 52

headline: Bill Clinton Defends Foreign Donations to Family Foundation

headline: J. B. Holmes Leads Cadillac Championship by Five After a Round of Maintenance
text: DORAL, Fla. — J. B. Holmes is like the miler who runs a blistering first lap and tries to hold off the pack. In his first loop around Trump National Doral’s Blue Monster, Holmes tied a course record with a 10-under-par 62. He has played the next 36 holes in one under, including a two-under 70 on Saturday to maintain his lead at the Cadillac Championship, a World Golf Championships event.

headline: Review: Björk at Carnegie Hall, Heartbreak and Pathos
text: The one indelible moment in “Björk” — a worshipful retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, which has met with something other than critical approval — happens in “Black Lake,” a sound and video installation commissioned for the show. Björk is depicted alone, in a stark Icelandic landscape, furiously pounding a fist against her chest. She seems riven with despair, possibly trying to jolt her heart back into its rhythm, as unseen strings sustain a restive chord for an eternal half-minute or so.

headline: 1940: Police Guard Judy Garland After Kidnap Warning
text: LOS ANGELES — Acting on a mysterious telephone warning that Judy Garland, the seventeen-year-old film star, was to be kidnapped, the police raced to her home and sent out radio cars patrolling the district. The telephone switchboard operator at the police station received an anonymous message asking if he knew who Judy Garland was and saying: ‘‘Get to her house quick. She is going to be kidnapped.’’ While the police kept guard outside her home, Judy went on with a party she was holding. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 9, 1940

headline: What’s On TV Sunday

(Comedy Central) NIGHT OF TOO MANY STARS: AMERICA COMES TOGETHER FOR AUTISM PROGRAMS Jon Stewart hosts; Larry David, Martin Short, Larry Wilmore, Fred Armisen, Andy Cohen, Ilana Glazer, Abbi Jacobson and Susan Sarandon oversee the phone banks; and Bill Burr, Louis C. K., John Oliver, Paul Rudd, Amy Schumer, Steve Buscemi, Steve Carell, Gilbert Gottfried, Maya Rudolph and Sarah Silverman, above, perform in sketches taped at the Beacon Theater in this telethon on behalf of autism awareness and education.

headline: Kenzo’s Battle-Ready White Shadow
text: At the Kenzo fall 2015 show, the label’s co-creative directors (and co-founders of Opening Ceremony) Carol Lim and Humberto Leon celebrated the collective conscious. “We wanted a look that would be symbolic of the women’s strength and give an element of protection,” Lim says. The hairstylist Anthony Turner interpreted this as “almost Amazonian,” he said backstage, by giving the models deep side parts lined up with the outer edge of the brow and slicking hair into long, thick, low ponytails with a blunt edge. By contrast, the makeup artist Aaron de May brought the free-spirited warrior women to life with dewy, pearlescent complexions, glassy lips and a thick swath of opaque white shadow applied with a chopped-up paintbrush to create an erratic edge. “The makeup feels like they took something from nature and put it on with their fingers,” Leon says. “It looks like the girls did it themselves,” de May adds.

headline: 1965: Marines Land in Vietnam by Sea, Air
text: DA NANG, South Vietnam — Two battalions of U.S. marines today [March 8] landed by sea and air in South Vietnam to guard the strategic Da Nang air base, about 80 miles from the North Vietnamese border. Viet Cong guerrillas fired at the U.S. transport planes carrying many of the troops, but apparently the only result was a bullet hole in the wing of a C130 aircraft. No Marines were hurt. South Vietnamese government troops had spent the weekend flushing out Viet Cong guerrillas in the area to make the region around Da Nang as safe as possible for the 3,500-man Marine force to land. But the Marine deployment around the air base could soon lead to the first ground fighting between U.S. combat units and Communist guerrillas in Vietnam. U.S military men have been serving as advisers to South Vietnamese Army and Marine outfits in the field. But until now, there have been no American ground combat formations in South Vietnam. Spokesmen for the U.S military mission in Saigon said the Marines would remain under U.S. control, but their duties would be assigned after consultation with South Vietnamese military officers. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 9, 1965

headline: Review: The New York Philharmonic Highlights Nordic Works
text: The Contact! new-music concerts were among Alan Gilbert’s first ideas at the helm of the New York Philharmonic, and they remain some of his best. At times, the series has seemed a missed opportunity, stuck in sleepy Manhattan halls and too focused on prominent composers. But high hopes have often been musically fulfilled.

headline: Review: Michael Meyer’s ‘In Manchuria’ Documents a Changing Rural China
text: In Chinese, the region that was once the cradle of the mighty Qing dynasty is today rather prosaically known as Dongbei, the Northeast. Home to 110 million people, it has smoggy cities and bitingly cold weather. It can seem drab or worse to a visitor. But Michael Meyer has a more refined sense of history and poetry, and with his new book, “In Manchuria: A Village Called Wasteland and the Transformation of Rural China,” he seizes the opportunity to dig beneath the region’s gritty surfaces.

headline: Job Growth for Hispanics Is Outpacing Other Groups
text: WASHINGTON — With the economy adding nearly 300,000 jobs in February, it’s clear that the labor market is on a roll. And, perhaps surprisingly, there is no group for whom that is truer than Hispanics.

headline: Visiting Nurses, Helping Mothers on the Margins
text: MEMPHIS — When it came time to have the baby, Shirita Corley was alone. Her mother was at the casino, her sister was not answering her cellphone, her boyfriend had disappeared months earlier, and her father she had not seen in years.

headline: Review: Hozier at Beacon Theater With Somber Songs of Love and Other Futilities
text: Hozier, the Irish songwriter who performed at the Beacon Theater on Friday night, is a somber phenomenon. His songs ponder passion, mortality, compulsion and sin. His voice is a richly melancholy moan, with echoes of Van Morrison and Jeff Buckley; his music is grounded in blues, soul and Celtic ballads, and it’s full of minor chords, starkly syncopated guitar picking, blunt tom-tom beats and moody drama. Yet Hozier, whose debut album was released last fall, is also a hitmaker who was greeted, between his doleful songs, with the squeals and whistles of pop adoration and female voices calling out, “I love you!”

headline: Review: ‘The Legend of Mulan’ Choreographs a Chinese Folk Tale
text: Mulan, the girl who disguises herself as a man to join the army in place of her frail father, is beloved by Disney fans. But does it work as a dance? The Hong Kong Dance Company, in residence at the David H. Koch Theater, presented its version of that Chinese folk tale on Thursday with a four-act production of “The Legend of Mulan.”

headline: Apple Watch Demonstration, Questions for HSBC and Greece’s Bailout
text: Here are some of the top business stories to pay attention to in the coming week.

headline: Review: St. Paul Chamber Orchestra Opens Its New Concert Hall
text: ST. PAUL — While the world has many splendid opera houses and orchestra halls, performance spaces ideally suited to chamber orchestras of, say, 30 to 35 players, are rarer. These ensembles are like hybrids between chamber groups and full orchestras. What’s needed is a hall that allows clarity and detail in the playing to come through while providing orchestral resonance and bloom.

headline: On the Fall 2015 Runways in Paris, Black Patent Leather Coats Are Slicker Than Ever
text: Patent leather, in all its glossy glory, has made a return to the runway in a big way for the fall/winter 2015 season — from a prim and proper skirt suit at Emilia Wickstead and J.W. Anderson’s ode to the ’80s in London to thigh-high boots at Versace. In Paris, especially, we’ve seen lots of black patent leather outerwear. First, Jonathan Anderson’s flirtation with the decade of excess at Loewe included a loose coat. At Maison Margiela, John Galliano’s debut prêt-à-porter collection for the brand featured a sleek, floor-grazing belted coat. Finally, at Dior, Raf Simons’s interest in the material (as evidenced by his couture presentation in January) was again demonstrated by a netted black patent coat.

headline: Review: Kronos Quartet, in an Emotionally Packed Performance
text: The Kronos Quartet offered a program of new and recent works full of ideas in the Late Nights at Zankel Hall series on Saturday, and the composers’ program notes were sometimes more compelling than the music.

headline: Review: The Peggy Spina Tap Company at the Spina Loft in SoHo
text: It has been many years since lofts in SoHo were the province of musicians, dancers and artists. There are holdouts, though, and on Friday one of them invited the public in. Passing the high-end stores on Prince Street, audience members climbed a rickety staircase to sit on folding chairs in Peggy Spina’s loft. Ushers took care to keep slush-wet shoes off the wooden floor. That was reserved for footwear with metal on the soles. Ms. Spina is a tap dancer.

text: Plays that mix realism and absurdity can be difficult to stage effectively. The director and actors have to figure out how to do that Durang-ian swing between “could happen” and “deliriously improbable.”

headline: Jack White to Release Elvis’s First Recording
text: The musician Jack White portrayed Elvis Presley in “Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story” in 2007. Now, he’s bringing Elvis back to life in another way: by releasing Elvis’s first-ever recording on Third Man Records, Mr. White’s label, after paying $300,000 for the acetate disc. Billboard reported that Mr. White was the anonymous bidder who bought the 1953 recording at a Graceland auction this January. The record features two covers of ballads, “My Happiness” and “That’s Where Your Heartaches Begin,” and was recorded by an 18-year-old Presley in Memphis three years before his breakout single, “Heartbreak Hotel.” Third Man Records will release the recording on April 18, Record Store Day, as a 10-inch, 78-r.p.m. facsimile. Mr. White has broken a few vinyl-related records recently. On Record Store Day last year, he set the world’s fastest time (3 hours, 55 minutes and 21 seconds) for recording, pressing and releasing a vinyl disc, and his 2014 album, “Lazaretto,” is the biggest-selling vinyl album since 1994.

headline: 6 Stabbed at Migos Show
text: Six people were stabbed at a concert by the rap group Migos on Friday night in Albany, said Steven Smith, the public information officer for the Albany police. The concert, at the Washington Avenue Armory, took a violent turn between 12:50 and 1:35 a.m. None of the injuries were life threatening. In addition, a 19-year-old woman reported that she was robbed and assaulted in a venue bathroom by six women. She sustained minor injuries to her head and face. The police are investigating, but no arrests have been made. In October, three people were shot, one fatally, outside Club Hive in Queens, following a Migos after-party at the site.

headline: DC and Marvel, Beware: Valiant Is to Make Films
text: DC’s Justice League and Marvel’s Avengers are going to have to make room for even more heroes coming to the big screen. The independent comic book publisher Valiant Entertainment and the Beijing-based DMG Entertainment announced on Sunday a nine-figure investment and partnership for feature-film financing as well as publishing, television and licensing opportunities. Valiant’s library of characters and concepts include X-O Manowar, an alien abductee from the past thrown into the present with high-tech armor, and the series Harbinger, about teenagers with special abilities at odds with a corporation out to shape the destiny of the world. Comic superheroes are profitable and highly sought intellectual properties for film franchises, said Dan Mintz, the chief executive officer of DMG, in a statement, “so taking a stake in the last independent massive comic universe is a strategic investment for DMG that will produce movies and TV that are both appealing and relevant to a global audience.” In addition to developing films for release in the United States and China, the two companies will develop Valiant’s characters for new audiences in China and the Asia-Pacific region. There are plans for Chinese-language publishing, animation and theme parks, as well as toys and apparel.

headline: The Song That Drove Sherman Crazy
text: By the time Maj. Gen. William T. Sherman arrived in Boston for the 1890 national encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic, he was already sick of hearing “Marching Through Georgia,” a song commemorating his historic 1864 campaign from Atlanta to the Atlantic coast. The opera singer Clara Louise Kellogg, a friend of his, later asserted that Sherman had always hated it “above all songs,” but something snapped in the old general’s mind that day in Boston. We can only imagine his growing discomfort as he stood on the grandstand and heard no less than 250 different bands parade by playing the tune. Although Sherman kept his composure at the time, rumors quickly spread that he vowed then and there to never attend another reunion without a guarantee that no one would play it.

headline: Two Portrayals of Patz Suspect: Manipulative, or Mentally Ill

headline: What’s On TV Monday
text: 9:10 A.M. (HBO Signature) ATONEMENT (2007) Saoirse Ronan (above with James McAvoy) received an Oscar nomination for her portrayal of Briony, a 13-year-old aspiring playwright who accuses the son (Mr. McAvoy) of a family servant — and the lover of her older sister (Keira Knightley) — of a crime in this drama directed by Joe Wright and based on the Ian McEwan novel. Romola Garai and Vanessa Redgrave play Briony at different times in her life. “The main casualty of the film’s long, murky middle and end sections is the big moral theme — and also the ingenious formal gimmick — that provides the book with some of its intensity and much of its cachet,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “As the title suggests, ‘Atonement’ is fundamentally about guilt and the attempt to overcome it, and about the tricky, tragically imperfect power of art to compensate for real-life crimes and misdemeanors.” The film received six more Oscar nominations, including one for best picture, and won for Dario Marianelli’s score, featuring the pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet and a clacking typewriter.

headline: When Food Is Wasted, Many Ills Come to the Fore
The World’s Problem With Sex Ed
text: ONTARIO was thrown into an uproar recently when officials presented the first changes to the province’s sex-education curriculum since 1998. Starting in the fall, second graders will learn about “saying no” and “improper touching”; third graders will be introduced to gender identity and sexual orientation; and seventh graders will learn of the dangers of “sexting” and of sexually transmitted diseases.

headline: Our Navy Is Big Enough
text: AT General Dynamics Bath Iron Works in Maine, workers are completing a warship unlike any the world has seen. The $3.3 billion Zumwalt destroyer uses all-electric propulsion, employs stealth features, carries a huge arsenal of guided missiles, and mounts advanced cannons that can hit targets 63 miles away. Most likely it will never be tested in battle, because no other nation is even attempting to build a warship like the Zumwalt, which symbolizes the gigantic advantage the United States Navy enjoys.

headline: Partying Like It’s 1995

headline: No Cause to Delay the Afghan Pullout
text: Last year, the Afghan Army lost more than 17,000 troops and civilian employees as a result of desertions, combat deaths and discharges, leaving a force that is authorized to employ 195,000 people significantly understaffed. In the fight against the Taliban, Afghan forces have been getting killed and injured at a significantly higher rate than in 2014, exacerbating attrition levels that appear to be unsustainable.

headline: A Complicated Future for a Banlieue on the Outskirts of Paris
text: PANTIN, France — Life in my neighborhood, a banlieue on the northeastern edge of Paris, has been changing for a while. In October, the local green market moved to a new public square that has a new bistro with cafe tables and a lavish new bakery, even a new vendor selling organic kale. Pantin, dubbed the “Brooklyn of Paris” because of its booming cultural scene, seemed to be turning into a French version of Williamsburg.

headline: ClassPass and the Joy and Guilt of the Digital Middleman Economy
text: Each month, I pay $99 to a company called ClassPass for the luxury of taking an unlimited number of fitness classes in and around Brooklyn, where I live. headline: Morning Agenda: Stress Tests Threaten Goldman Profit
text: STRESS TEST RESULTS THREATEN GOLDMAN PROFIT | After Goldman Sachs’s poor performance on Federal Reserve stress tests, analysts and investors are worried that the bank could be barred from buying back its own stock or increasing dividends, an important profit source for the bank, DealBook’s Nathaniel Popper writes. The bank has used dividends and share buybacks to appeal to investors, which generally increase the amount of profits attributed to every share, at a time when other elements of the bank’s business have faced challenges. The Fed will publicly give its final verdict on Goldman’s buyback plans on Wednesday.

headline: When a Presidential Nominating Contest Isn’t a Contest

headline: Changing Tastes Blamed for Slide at McDonald’s

headline: Leon Wieseltier Takes New Humanities Post at Brookings
text: The Brookings Institution was founded in 1916 with the mission of becoming “the first private organization devoted to analyzing public policy issues at the national level.” Now, the think tank known for its work on economics, governance and foreign policy (and a steady drip of news releases with titles like “Innovation and manufacturing labor: a value-chain perspective”) will be adding the humanities to its portfolio.

headline: Quiet Start to Central Bank Bond-Buying Program for the Eurozone
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank began its long-awaited bond-buying program on Monday, an unprecedented 1.1 trillion euro bid to help revive the eurozone economy.

headline: Japanese Women Play Without Their Superstar
text: VILAMOURA, Portugal — The players of the Japanese women’s national soccer team went through a training drill here last week, scooting short passes in from the wings before sprinting toward the penalty area and blasting shots on goal. One after another after another they went, mostly working in silence except when they broke into loud cheers after a player hit a particularly pretty shot that found the side netting. The mood was upbeat — the sunny weather on Portugal’s south coast surely helped — but also serious and focused.

headline: Mall Owner Simon Property Bids for Rival Macerich to Aim at High-End Shoppers
text: Across America, many shopping malls are dying. Stagnant middle-class incomes, overbuilt retail space and competitors like Amazon.com and Costco are turning these former fixtures of the retail landscape into abandoned boxes, devoid of clients or customers.

headline: Unions Suffer Latest Defeat in Midwest With Signing of Wisconsin Measure
text: MADISON, Wis. — For decades, states across the South, Great Plains and Rocky Mountains enacted policies that prevented organized labor from forcing all workers to pay union dues or fees. But the industrial Midwest resisted.

headline: In Forecasting Health Costs, Let Technology Be Your Guide
text: The expansion of health care insurance can drive the development of new technologies that can drive up health care spending. But it doesn’t have to.

headline: New Research on Antidepressants and Pregnancy Finds No Link to Asthma
text: Many women with a history of depression who take antidepressants assume that once they get pregnant, they should try to wean themselves off their meds to avoid negative side effects for the baby. A new large study published in the journal Pediatrics challenges one reason behind that assumption. The research found that taking selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (the antidepressants also known as S.S.R.I.s) while pregnant does not increase the risk of asthma in the resulting babies. What is associated with an increased risk of asthma? According to this study and other research, untreated prenatal depression.

headline: How to Get More Women to Join the Debate, Part II
text: Many people asked good questions in response to my article about how only 25 percent of comments in the New York Times are made by women. Here are responses to several of them.

headline: Wet and Ever-So-Slightly Wild Ponytails at Stella McCartney
text: “It’s really quite directional in an effortless way,” says the hairstylist Eugene Souleiman of the look he created for the Stella McCartney fall 2015 fashion show. “The collection is really very beautiful, so I didn’t want to do romantic, I didn’t want to do pretty, I didn’t want to do glamorous. I wanted to do something that wasn’t so refined.” Backstage at the Paris Opera House, Souleiman spritzed models’ dry hair until damp and used his fingers to work through piles of mousse to achieve a wet-look effect with texture and hold. After pulling hair into a ponytail at the crown of the head, he matted wisps around the face. “We wanted to make it look as if the girls pulled their hair back into a ponytail after they had been swimming,” he says. “We haven’t dipped our feet into the water, we dove right in.”

headline: Secede? Separatists Claim Texas Never Joined United States

headline: In Chávez, Maduro Trusts, Maybe to His Detriment and Venezuela’s

headline: Ebola-Stricken Countries Lagged in Health Systems

headline: 1915: U.K. Wants Power Over All Factories During the War
text: LONDON — Great Britain is the main arsenal of the Grand Alliance. This aspect of the war received new emphasis from Mr. Lloyd George in his speech in introducing the Amending Defence of the Realm Bill in the House of Commons this afternoon. The Chancellor said it is of vital importance to the country that the Government should be given every facility for the output of munitions of war. Under the act of 1914 the Government obtained the power to take over any works where war material is being produced. It now asks for power in respect to works where war material is not being produced at present, but which are capable of being used for the purpose. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 10, 1915

headline: Herblock’s Sharp Pen, and Others’, to Go on Display at Library of Congress
text: The Library of Congress  will showcase the power and punch of the political cartoon in the exhibition “Pointing Their Pens: Herblock and Fellow Cartoonists Confront the Issues,” which opens March 21. Herbert L. Block, who died in 2001, was the chief editorial cartoonist for The Washington Post for more than half a century. His work forms the core of the exhibition, which focuses on six subjects that inspired some of his most memorable cartoons: World War II, the McCarthy era, the Cold War, the Vietnam War, Richard M. Nixon and the Middle East. Each will have two cartoons by Herblock and three by his contemporaries.

headline: 1965: Alabama Brutality Condemned
text: WASHINGTON — President Johnson today sharply condemned brutality against Negro demonstrators in Alabama but urged both sides in the voting-rights dispute to observe law and order. A Cadillac hearse pulled up, and traffic was halted by the police. The great double doors of the cathedral swung open, and a small procession of priests, along with Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the sitting archbishop of New York, emerged into the sunlight.

headline: A Time to Avoid Anxiety Drugs
text: People sometimes take Valium or Ativan to relieve anxiety before surgery, but a new study suggests that these benzodiazepine drugs have little beneficial effect and may even delay recovery.

headline: Brooklyn Style, Transported to the Suburbs of Connecticut
text: Brooklyn might be the cradle of the maker movement, with its deep appreciation for all that’s handcrafted and artisan-made, but predictably that cultural aesthetic has increasingly found a home in the borough’s surrounding suburbs. Case in point: Gather, a recently opened fashion and home décor shop tucked away in the front-porch-loving town of Old Greenwich, Connecticut. Co-owned by Rebecca Karson, a former prop stylist who grew up in Brooklyn Heights, the 80-square-foot space is tiny (even by New Yorkers’ standards) and filled with a well-edited selection of small batch goods, including porcelain clay pottery hand-carved by the artist Elizabeth Benotti; Jess Brown’s rag dolls, which are filled with sustainable corn fiber and dyed using Persian black tea; slim, delicate gold jewelry sculpted by Rebecca Peacock (who works out of her farmhouse studio in the Catskill Mountains); and delicate clothing from Nuthatch, which hails from Maine and employs local mills. In other words, it’s a mix you can imagine browsing, matcha tea in hand, at the Brooklyn fleas. Still, Karson didn’t set out to curate her shop that way. She simply scouts for pieces that catch her eye. “I’ve always gravitated towards things that are handmade or vintage,” she explains. “They tell a more interesting story.”

headline: Obama Opens U.S. Effort to Fill High-Paying Tech Jobs
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama kicked off an initiative on Monday intended to train more people for higher-paying jobs in high-technology services as he seeks to counter wage stagnation in an economy that has otherwise been improving.

headline: Lisa Bonchek Adams: She Did as Much as She Could for as Long as She Could
text: Lisa Bonchek Adams lived her life on her own terms, regardless of her diagnosis. She fought long and hard against death, and she refused to be silenced, even when others questioned her decision to live her cancer out loud — and to die out loud. Her death on March 6, 2015, was not unexpected by any who followed her, nor was it expected. Lisa always told her readers when things were bad. But she never gave up, or at least, not publicly. In every update, no matter how grave, Lisa looked forward to spring.

headline: A New Tool to Investigate Inside Tippers
text: The British philosopher Francis Bacon is attributed with saying that “knowledge is power,” and Wall Street pours enormous resources into obtaining information in the hope that greater knowledge will provide an edge on the market. But recent charges against a corporate officer show that passing along confidential information can be perilous, even if the intent is something other than insider trading.

headline: Blocking the Paths to Suicide
text: Every year, nearly 40,000 Americans kill themselves. The majority are men, and most of them use guns. In fact, more than half of all gun deaths in the United States are suicides.

headline: Discerning Plant Picks Its Pollinators
text: When it comes to pollinators, plants are not usually picky. But one tropical plant seems able to choose its suitors, a new study found. When Heliconia tortuosa resisted researchers’ attempts to pollinate it by hand, they tried introducing the plant to six species of hummingbirds and a butterfly. Only two types of the hummingbirds — those with the longest bills and that travel most extensively — were consistently successful in getting pollen from the plant. Writing in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, researchers at Oregon State University and the Smithsonian suggest this coyness may be a way for the plants to ensure genetic diversity.

headline: Art in Residence
text: On Saturday evening in the City of Light, the worlds of art and fashion collided, as they’re wont to do, for cocktails at the residence of the American ambassador to France, which was transformed into a one-night-only art exhibition. Works on loan from Galerie Perrotin and Galerie Thaddaeus Ropac — by artists Erwin Wurm, Daniel Arsham, Alex Katz, Tom Sachs, Not Vital and Xavier Veilhan — set the scene for the party, which the U.S. ambassador Jane D. Hartley hosted in honor of T magazine.

headline: Supreme Court Sides With Amtrak, With Some Distaste

The ruling was a setback for a trade group that had challenged a 2008 federal law giving Amtrak, which carries passengers, a role in setting standards for freight railroad companies.

headline: Stricter Oversight Ordered for Animal Research at Nebraska Center

headline: Obama Did Email Clinton, but Was Unaware of Details of Her Address

headline: Woman as Warrior, From Kenzo
text: PARIS — A motley, emo kind of bunch was gathered in the parking lot outside the Paris Event Center in the 19th Arrondissement before the Kenzo show at 10 a.m. on Sunday, bolting coffee in paper cups distributed from a truck and snatching chocolate-chip cookies from trays. Among the many slouchy knit caps boldly bobbed one red turban.

headline: A Splash of Flash

headline: The Most Memorable Costumes of ‘Mad Men’ Get the Museum Treatment
text: As compelling as the storylines and characters on “Mad Men” — which airs the second half of its final season beginning April 5 on AMC — are the show’s meticulously researched 1960s-era costumes. (In many instances, the outfits — Ginsberg’s stained shirt, Megan’s “Zou Bisou Bisou” dress — almost feel like characters themselves.) Now, a new exhibition opening March 14 at the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, “Matthew Weiner’s Mad Men,” brings the show’s wardrobe, and the rest of its creative process, to life. More than 25 of the ensembles developed by the show’s costume designer, Janie Bryant, will appear alongside props, advertisements and other ephemera from the show’s production department, giving fans the chance to see such garments as Joan’s blood-stained dress from the lawn-mower episode and Sally’s first minidress up close. Bryant worked closely with the museum’s curators to assemble the collection, even going so far as to track down clothing that had since disappeared into Hollywood costume houses. “To see a costume in full action on screen and then see it standing still,” she says, “is a whole different kind of visual experience.”

headline: Keeping Your Hair in Chemo
text: Hair loss is one of the most obvious side effects of cancer treatment. Now, a growing number of breast cancer patients are freezing their scalps as a way to preserve their hair during chemotherapy.

headline: Rubio-Lee: Promise and Problems
text: Last week, Senators Marco Rubio and Mike Lee released the outline of a comprehensive tax reform, which adds changes to corporate and investment taxes to their earlier proposal for a more pro-family revision of the individual code. The plan earned generally favorable comments from Yuval Levin, Ramesh Ponnuru and James Pethokoukis, all writers associated with the tendency we’re calling reform conservatism, but the addition of tax cuts on the business side drew praise from a wider range of conservative and libertarian policy writers and economists as well. The reformist interest in reorienting Republican tax policy toward middle-class families has created tensions with the party’s supply-side wing, but because it reforms the corporate/business code the Rubio-Lee plan clearly has the potential to be a politically-unifying vision, marrying pro-family and pro-growth policy while putting the era of “9-9-9″ and Fair Tax-style unicorns in the rearview mirror.

headline: New Umberto Eco Novel, ‘Numero Zero,’ Coming This Fall

headline: Sam Simon, 59, Dies; Guided ‘The Simpsons,’ Then Shared His Profits
text: Sam Simon, who was one of the major creative forces behind “The Simpsons” and who left the show after its fourth season in a lucrative arrangement that allowed him to spend much of the rest of his life giving his money away, died on Sunday at his home in the Pacific Palisades area of Los Angeles. headline: Fighting Back Against Malware

headline: Review: ‘The Liquid Plain,’ a Naomi Wallace Drama at the Signature Theater
text: In “The Liquid Plain,” the soggy play by Naomi Wallace at the Signature Theater, a pair of runaway slaves eke out a living on a dock in Rhode Island, desperately hoping to escape across the sea to Africa. Adjua (Kristolyn Lloyd) and Dembi (Ito Aghayere) are lovers determined to forge new lives for themselves, and they sustain each other with ardent affection and dreams of a future that will ease memories of the brutalities they endured in the past.

headline: Life and Warmth in Fed Transcripts: Reporter’s Notebook
text: Every so often I get an admiring note from a reader who is impressed that I have published an article about some new report almost as soon as the report was released. Sometimes I just say thank you. Sometimes I tell them the secret: I got the report in advance, on condition that I would not publish an article until it was released publicly. It was not magic; it was just careful choreography.

headline: Randall Miller, Film Director, Pleads Guilty in ‘Midnight Rider’ Manslaughter Trial
text: LOS ANGELES — In a rare assignment of criminal liability for safety violations on a film set, the producer and director Randall Miller on Monday pleaded guilty to involuntary manslaughter in the death of Sarah Jones. Ms. Jones was killed by a freight train on the Georgia set of “Midnight Rider” last year.

headline: Sinkhole in Russia Threatens Home
text: A striking video shot earlier this year by a resident captured images of a huge sinkhole in Solikamsk, Russia.

headline: Two Fall Into Sinkhole in Seoul
text: Security footage captured the moment a man and a woman stepped off a bus and fell into a sinkhole in the capital of South Korea.

headline: A Sinkhole at the Corvette Museum
text: A huge sinkhole opened up in February 2014 at the National Corvette Museum in Bowling Green, Ky., swallowing eight rare and notable versions of the Chevrolet sports car.

headline: Clinton Considering News Conference to Address Email Questions
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton will soon add to the solitary Twitter message she has sent dealing with the controversy over her private email use as secretary of state.

headline: PreCheck Expansion Plan Raises Privacy Concerns
text: THE idea raised alarms among privacy advocates: Social media postings would be fair game for private companies doing background checks on people applying for the PreCheck security program, under a government request made in December.

headline: Republicans’ Latest Threat to an Iran Deal
text: By now it should be obvious that a vocal segment of Congress is determined to do whatever it can to undermine President Obama’s attempts to negotiate an agreement that would restrict Iran’s nuclear program. House Republicans invited Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to denounce the pact in a speech to Congress, and a bipartisan group of senators is pushing legislation that could set new conditions on a deal and force a congressional vote.

headline: The Himalayas From 20,000 Feet
text: The famous mountains of the Himalayas, including Mount Everest, captured in a way never seen before.

headline: Apple Unveils the Apple Watch
text: Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, introduced the Apple Watch, an edition of which is made of 18-karat gold and retails starting at $10,000.

headline: Videos at Tsarnaev Trial Show Carnage and Suspects in Boston Marathon Bombings
text: BOSTON — One video showed “Black Hat” and “White Hat,” as they were known in the early days to F.B.I. agents investigating the Boston Marathon bombing, wearing backpacks and weaving their way purposefully past onlookers down the sidewalk of Boylston Street, alongside weary runners nearing the finish line.

headline: Smart Luggage for the Connected Age
text: It wasn’t long ago that the main selling point of a piece of luggage was its durability — think American Tourister and its rather excitable gorilla.

headline: Review: ‘Fashions for Men,’ a Revival at the Mint Theater
text: Tall and stately, the elderly woman leaned on a cane, heading down in the elevator after a matinee of Ferenc Molnar’s “Fashions for Men” at the Mint Theater. “When I was in high school, Molnar was the hottest thing going,” she told her companion.

headline: March 9, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Egypt, Ukraine, Chad and Japan.

headline: Review: ‘Woyzeck, FJF’ Is a Quixotic Adaptation at the New Ohio Theater
text: Georg Büchner, who died in 1837, was a playwright so ahead of his time that the theater is still playing catch-up. Before his young demise, he wrote the historical epic “Danton’s Death,” the odd comedy “Leonce and Lena” and perhaps his trickiest play of all, the unfinished “Woyzeck,” which exists only in jumbled fragments. A definitive text, production or even an ordering of scenes proves elusive.

headline: Walkabout: Snow in New York, Not So Much in Alaska
text: Mush A lack of snowfall in Alaska has moved the starting point of the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race from Willow to Fairbanks, more than 200 miles north. The weather pattern that slammed parts of the Northeast with snow this winter has left Alaska fairly warm. (The New York Times)

headline: Review: In ‘Powers,’ Bad Guys With Superhero Status
text: For a show that exists as an offshoot of a video-game console, “Powers” plays less like a video game than you might expect, or fear. The new 10-episode series — available beginning Tuesday through Sony’s online PlayStation Network, console not required — is action-oriented, with doses of violence and crude language, but it’s a television show, not a first-person shooter. And it’s a reasonably entertaining one in its CW-style, low-rent, formulaic way.

headline: Erik Larson, Author of ‘Dead Wake,’ Seizes Historical Mysteries
text: On a clear afternoon about 100 years ago, a large British passenger ship started sinking off the coast of Ireland, listing violently as it was sucked down into the ocean.

headline: Robert Swinston, a Merce Cunningham Disciple, Brings His Troupe to New York for a Debut
text: “We begin again.”
