text: Math Celebrations

headline: Spare Times Listings for March 13-19
text: Around Town

headline: Giants Lose Safety Antrel Rolle to Bears
text: The Giants’ search for help at safety began in earnest on Thursday after Antrel Rolle, a defensive mainstay for the last five seasons, left to sign a three-year contract worth $11.25 million with the Chicago Bears. He received $5 million in guaranteed money.

headline: The Problem Is Bigger Than Ferguson
text: The Justice Department’s exposé of the bigoted law enforcement practices at play in Ferguson, Mo., has rightly led to an exodus of officials from the town government. In the week since the report was made public, the police chief, the city manager and the municipal court judge have all stepped down, and the city’s court has been placed under state supervision.

headline: Language of Greek Crisis Shifts From Financial Jargon to Humiliation
text: BERLIN — Greece’s financial crisis has often been framed in the dry, impersonal language of finance. At issue were credit ratings, bond yields and repayment schedules. The pulse of a collapsing nation was often measured in technical jargon about borrowing costs and primary surpluses.

headline: Key Chicago Figure, Despite a Plea by Obama, Gives a Lift to Emanuel’s Rival
text: CHICAGO — Several weeks ago, President Obama was at an event in Chicago when he approached Willie Wilson, a businessman who had challenged Rahm Emanuel in the mayor’s race, with a gentle plea, Mr. Wilson said.

headline: Senators Remain at Impasse Over Bill’s Abortion Provision
text: WASHINGTON — Senators on Thursday continued to struggle to come to terms with an unexpected impasse over a bipartisan human trafficking bill, with the sides refusing to yield their positions on a provision that would ban money from a victims’ fund from being used for abortions.

headline: Ebola, Thief of Rituals, Leaves No Graves to Decorate
text: MONROVIA, Liberia — Finda Fallah sat in her tiny one-bedroom apartment, boiling up rice and leftovers with one of the few children in her family still alive.

headline: This Week’s Movies | March 13, 2015
text: The New York Times film critics review “Cinderella,” “Going Clear” and “Seymour: An Introduction.”

headline: Univision Fires Host Rodner Figueroa for Insult to Michelle Obama
text: Univision fired the talk show host Rodner Figueroa after he said that Michelle Obama looked like someone from the cast of the film “Planet of the Apes.”

headline: From the Gates Foundation, Direct Investment, Not Just Grants
text: The Ebola crisis underscored a problem that vexes experts in global health: Vaccines are one of the most cost-effective ways to save lives, especially in developing countries, yet traditional vaccines can take years to develop.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Cinderella’
text: Kenneth Branagh narrates a sequence from the film.

headline: Kenneth Branagh Narrates a Scene From ‘Cinderella’
text: In this video, the director Kenneth Branagh discusses a sequence from the new version of “Cinderella,” featuring Lily James and Richard Madden.

headline: Iran: New Appeal for Detained Reporter
text: The Iranian lawyer for Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post reporter incarcerated in Iran for nearly eight months, has requested a five-day release for him starting March 21, the beginning of Iran’s New Year, so he can be with his family, Mr. Rezaian’s brother, Ali, said Thursday at a news conference in Washington. Ali Rezaian also said the lawyer, Leila Ahsan, had not yet been allowed to meet with Mr. Rezaian, a native Californian of Iranian descent, but had been given access to the case files. Iranian officials have not disclosed the nature of the charges but have hinted that they are related to espionage.

headline: Clip: ‘Seymour: An Introduction’
text: A scene from the documentary.

headline: Review: ‘Seymour: An Introduction’ Is a Lesson in Perseverance
text: As its title suggests, “Seymour: An Introduction” doesn’t try to offer the final word on its subject, Seymour Bernstein, the pianist, composer, teacher, philosopher and ultimate New Yorker. Instead, in 81 transporting minutes, this intimate, big-hearted documentary draws you so completely into his world that you feel as if you know all there is to know, even as questions linger. So effectively does it close the distance between you and Mr. Bernstein that afterward you may find yourself scanning the streets, hoping to catch sight of him, as if for an old friend.

headline: His Skill Finally Unmasked, Goaltender Devan Dubnyk Finds a Home
text: ST. PAUL — The idea sprang as a brainstorm from a first-time father. After Nathaniel Dubnyk was born in August 2013, his father, Devan Dubnyk, then a goaltender for the Edmonton Oilers, asked the noted Swedish mask designer David Gunnarsson to incorporate an image of the baby on the mask he planned to wear that season.

headline: Senator Corker Pushes Obama for Congressional Vote on Iran Deal
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee urged President Obama on Thursday not to seek a United Nations endorsement of the emerging nuclear agreement with Iran without first giving Congress a chance to vote on it.

headline: California’s Ailing Sea Lions
text: Record numbers of sea lions are being discovered up and down the state’s coast.

headline: Starving Sea Lions Washing Ashore by the Hundreds in California
text: CAPISTRANO BEACH, Calif. — By the time Wendy Leeds reached him, the sea lion pup had little hope of surviving.

headline: ‘Lila’ Honored as Top Fiction by National Book Critics Circle
text: Marilynne Robinson won the National Book Critics Circle Award on Thursday for her novel “Lila,” the final book in her trilogy set in the fictional Gilead, Iowa.

headline: Stopping Online Harassment Before It Starts
text: Yik Yak, created in 2013, is a relatively young social network. But it already has a problem with harassment.

headline: Review: In ‘Cymbeline,’ a Drug Kingpin
text: Was the director Michael Almereyda watching an episode of “Sons of Anarchy” when he decided to tackle “Cymbeline”? For an overextended seven seasons (2008-14), that FX show retold “Hamlet” through the trials and tribulations of a violent motorcycle gang and its circle. Back in 2000, Mr. Almereyda, an independent American filmmaker, wittily conceptualized his own “Hamlet” to suit the indie-movie times, casting Ethan Hawke as a film student who wonders whether to be or not while strolling in a Blockbuster video store near a sign labeled “action.”

headline: Serena Williams Strikes the Right Note in a Time of Turmoil
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Serena Williams officially ended her 13-year boycott of the annual tennis tournament held here when she addressed members of the news media Thursday to explain why she returned.

headline: Just as Ferguson Was Making Progress, Shooting Deals a Setback
text: FERGUSON, Mo. — In her three years as a city councilwoman, Kim Tihen has not been afraid to speak against the powers in her own city.

headline: Review: In ‘Cinderella,’ Disney Polishes Its Glass Slippers
text: Poor Cinderella — she still can’t catch a break. In the 1950 Disney animated musical, her friendly neighborhood mice know the score and give it song: “Night and day, it’s Cinderelly! ‘Make the fire, fix-a breakfast, wash the dishes, do the mopping, and the sweeping and the dusting.’ They always keep her hopping!” In Disney’s latest version, directed by Kenneth Branagh, the mice stick to squeaking and look about as real as most computer-generated rodents. And, fascinatingly, much remains the same, including a fairy tale that opens with clear skies but soon plays the poor-little-girl blues before you-know-who comes along. “Maleficent” and its revisionism are so last year.

headline: Holder Calls Ferguson Gunman a ‘Punk’
text: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. condemned the attacks on two police officers in Ferguson, Mo., calling the attacker “a damn punk.”

headline: De Blasio Names 3 to Rent Board as Annual Fight on Increases Nears
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio has appointed three new members of the board that sets rents for about one million rent-stabilized apartments in the city, completing the process of filling all nine seats with his selections just in time for the annual fight over rent increases.

headline: Events in Connecticut for March 15-21, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island for March 15-21, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in New Jersey for March 15-21, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Westchester for March 15-21, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Jurors Hear Harrowing Account of Boston Bombers’ Hostage
text: BOSTON — The murderous rampage of the Tsarnaev brothers that engulfed this city two years ago began to come apart when they encountered someone they could not possibly have seen as a threat: a mild-mannered apps designer who had pulled his car over to text a friend.

headline: Suddenly, It Seems, Water Is Everywhere in Solar System
text: Oceans trapped under ice appear to be pretty common in the solar system and one of them, on a small moon of Saturn’s, appears to be quite hot.

headline: Move Over, Clinton. Albany Email Farce Takes Center Stage.
text: This may be the first time in history that a column about digital storage must be rendered as a kind of drawing room comedy.

headline: Powerful Lasers Easy to Buy, Experts Say
text: Stargazers use them to pick out constellations, teachers to direct students’ eyes, and pet lovers to make their cats dance.

headline: Review: ‘3 Hearts,’ With Three Stars, by Benoît Jacquot
text: The French filmmaker Benoît Jacquot’s “3 Hearts” has the incalculable advantage of teaming three of Europe’s most revered actresses, Charlotte Gainsbourg, Chiara Mastroianni and Catherine Deneuve, in a proudly old-fashioned romantic melodrama. Those names alone make it sound delectable, and in its outlines, this quintessential Gallic bodice-ripper might be described as a hybrid of “An Affair to Remember” and the German filmmaker Dominik Graf’s recent “Beloved Sisters.”

headline: In New Hampshire, Clinton Backers Buckle Up
text: PORTSMOUTH, N.H. — If Hillary Rodham Clinton is dying to roll her eyes at all the questions about her private email server, she has a soul mate in Laura Donohoe, who did just that, in utter disgust, as she defended Mrs. Clinton on Thursday between spoonfuls of clam chowder.

headline: Dawn’s Direction
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Let’s talk about the voices I hear. Don’t call my doctor, I’m not hearing random ones. Today, I’d like to talk about the very distinctive voices of the puzzle constructors we love. Because, if you listen very carefully when you solve a puzzle, you can hear them. Will Shortz edits the clues, but he is very good at letting the original voices of the constructors comes through.

headline: Patz Judge Denies Mistrial Request Over Suspect’s Drug Use
text: A prosecutor cross-examining an expert witness on Thursday suggested the hallucinations of the man on trial for the murder of Etan Patz could have been caused by cocaine abuse, not mental illness. That line of questioning prompted the defense to move for a mistrial because the judge had only recently allowed it.

headline: Review: In ‘Run All Night,’ Liam Neeson Sticks to What Works
text: Yes, “Run All Night” is another action film starring Liam Neeson, with a title as generic as you might expect. But the movie, directed by Jaume Collet-Serra, who directed Mr. Neeson in the efficient airborne thriller “Non-Stop,” has two saving graces: a tight script and terrific acting.

headline: New Rules Are Issued for Testing of Medical Devices
text: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration said Thursday that it was toughening testing procedures for manufacturers of reusable medical devices. It issued the new requirements in the wake of news that two people in a Los Angeles hospital had died from a deadly bacteria traced to medical scopes.

headline: Review: ‘Champs’ Tyson, Holyfield and Hopkins Recount Careers
text: “Champs” spends about a third of its time perpetuating the myth of boxing as a path out of poverty, a third of it taking a cursory look at what’s wrong with the sport and a third being a greatest-hits compilation.

headline: At Baruch, a New York Rental to the Stars, the Wood Floors Tend to Squeak
text: As the N.C.A.A. tournament approaches, the best basketball scene in the country is not Rupp Arena, home of the undefeated Kentucky Wildcats, or even Cameron Indoor Stadium, the Duke Blue Devils’ noisy home. Rather, it is a nondescript gym in Manhattan, home of the commuter school Baruch College.

headline: Review: ‘The Cobbler,’ With Adam Sandler, a World in Others’ Shoes
text: The good news is that “The Cobbler” isn’t another “Grown-Ups” sequel. Adam Sandler, as he did with Jason Reitman’s little-seen “Men, Women & Children,” works outside his sophomoric-humor comfort zone in this urban fairy tale directed by Tom McCarthy (“The Station Agent”). The bad news is that he is not very well served. “The Cobbler,” which Mr. McCarthy wrote with Paul Sado, speaks to the fabulist side of Mr. Sandler, the one that appeared in “Click” and “Bedtime Stories.” But it’s an uneasy fit, in a trite story.

headline: At Chinese Political Meetings, the Fashion Is Restraint
text: Simple meals, plain boiled water instead of the bottled mineral kind, a paucity of designer logos.

headline: After Bilking Victims of $10 Million, Serial Swindler Is Sentenced to Nearly 22 Years
text: Like many white-collar criminals, William Lange spent freely with the money he made from his fraud: $115,000 on Harley-Davidson motorcycles; a $2,350 stay at the Mirage in Las Vegas; landscaping work and $5,000 worth of fancy railings for his Gig Harbor, Wash., waterfront mansion; a testosterone-laden moose hunt.

headline: Review: In ‘Eva,’ Robot Designer Loves Cute Kid
text: Robots haven’t become an integral part of the everyday world as quickly as some people had predicted, but in the not-too-distant future of “Eva,” an appealing film from Spain, they’re very much a factor. We learn this early on, when the central character, Alex (Daniel Brühl), steps off a plane trailed by his robotic cat.

headline: Where Beijing’s Trash Is Reborn
text: When The New York Times asked Sim Chi Yin, a photographer based in Beijing, to photograph a story about “beginnings,” she started thinking about the outskirts of her city, which she has been exploring for the past year as part of her continuing work on urbanization in China. This week, we are marking the launch of our primary Instagram account, @nytimes, with images of beginnings by seven photographers around the world. The photos by @chiyin_sim were published on the account over the course of the day on Thursday. — Kerri MacDonald

headline: Review: In ‘Home Sweet Hell,’ Married Life Isn’t Heaven
text: Mona (Katherine Heigl), the chief villain of the shrill comedy “Home Sweet Hell,” is the sort of terrifying suburban status seeker who might inspire fond memories of the 1994 John Waters film “Serial Mom.” She insists that her children “argue constructively” and requires nothing less than perfect hedges. She indulges in casual bigotry and refuses to mingle with the employees of the furniture company she runs with her husband, Don (Patrick Wilson). She lists 15 precise minutes of sex with him on her calendar. She keeps an album of goals for her perfect family.

headline: Not to Worry: Masahiro Tanaka Looks Like His Old Self
text: TAMPA, Fla. — With 19 precise pitches, Masahiro Tanaka did more to calm the nerves of anxious Yankees fans than any of his declarations of good health possibly could. People needed to see it live, and Tanaka, the right-handed pitcher who sneered at the surgical knife last summer, put his ability on display Thursday with striking resolve.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Thursday, March 12, 2015
text: March 12, 2015

headline: Obama Discusses Ferguson With Jimmy Kimmel
text: LOS ANGELES — President Obama on Thursday said that whoever shot at police officers in Ferguson, Mo., this week were “criminals” and should be arrested, but added that their actions should not detract from the civil rights issues that have been raised.

headline: Review: ‘Like Sunday, Like Rain,’ a Sentimental Intersection of Two Lives
text: Leighton Meester of “Gossip Girl” acquits herself quite well in “Like Sunday, Like Rain,” and so does a young newcomer named Julian Shatkin. It’s a bittersweet story that thins out toward the end as it turns too obviously sentimental, but it’s still a nicely etched tale of the intersection of two unrelated lives.

headline: Funeral for Shannan Gilbert Is Outlet for Family’s Grief, and Suspicion
text: AMITYVILLE, N.Y. — The scene at the cemetery here on Thursday was rather quotidian: a silver-colored coffin topped with pink-and-white carnations in union beneath the kind of light-pink ribbon bow normally found atop a wrapped gift.

headline: Rangers’ Klein, Injured by Puck, Will Miss at Least Three Weeks
text: The Rangers said Thursday that Kevin Klein, a stalwart defenseman who has a knack for scoring key goals, would miss three to four weeks with an upper-body injury.

headline: Review: ‘The Lovers’ Portrays Romances Intertwined Across Time
text: The title of “The Lovers” refers not just to characters but also to two rings that join together. In this inert, exasperatingly proportioned phantasmagoria from Roland Joffé, who wrote the screenplay and directed, the jewels’ fortunes in 1778 India have a ripple effect on a futuristic diving mission hundreds of years later. Or perhaps it’s the other way around.

headline: Review: ‘Walter’ Is Obsessed With Fate
text: In “Walter,” the title character is a ticket taker at a multiplex, a good gig for someone who enjoys fantasy. Walter, an obsessive-compulsive in his early 20s, believes himself to be a son of God, required to decide the final destination — heaven or hell — of every individual he sees. Folks lining up to get into the theater just make his true calling easier.

headline: Review: ‘The Wrecking Crew’ Hails the Music Behind the Faces
text: THE WRECKING CREW

headline: NASA Mission to Study Magnetic Explosions Lifts Off
text: A NASA mission to study magnetic explosions high above Earth successfully launched to orbit on Thursday night.

headline: As Protesters Disparage Bratton, an Unlikely Defender Emerges: City Council
text: With relations between New York City lawmakers and police officials warming, it was left to a handful of protesters at a budget hearing at City Hall on Tuesday to voice outrage over current policing policies.

headline: Staten Island Judge Allows Suit on Teacher Tenure to Proceed
text: Opponents of New York State’s teacher tenure laws won a small but important victory on Thursday, when a Staten Island judge allowed a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of those rules to move forward.

headline: Big East Tournament: Xavier Advances With Overtime Victory Over Butler
text: Even the most ardent of Big East rivals can usually wrap up a game in regulation. That was true of Butler and Xavier in their two regular-season meetings this year.

headline: Alexander McQueen-Inspired Tea Treats: Almost too Pretty to Eat
text: As Fashion Month comes to a close and London ramps up for a longer-running fashion presentation of sorts — the March 14th opening of “Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty” at the Victoria and Albert Museum — the Berkeley hotel is feting the exhibition’s European launch with its own very McQueen-inspired spin on the afternoon teatime ritual.

headline: A Notebook With Pop-Art Bona Fides
text: Those who still prefer to carry around a physical notebook, rather than relying on Evernote (or just tweeting every passing thought), are a peculiar bunch possessed of inflexible loyalties: whether you’re a Moleskine or a Rhodia person tells journal snobs everything they need to know. (There’s some ego involved, to be sure: “Our notebooks give us away,” as Joan Didion famously wrote, “for however dutifully we record what we see around us, the common denominator of all we see is always, transparently, shamelessly, the implacable ‘I.’”)

headline: Life or Movie? ‘Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter’ and ‘The Wolfpack’ Blur Lines
text: In a dark apartment in Tokyo, a lonely woman is transported to the snowy vistas of Minnesota. She gets lost in the fuzzy images on her TV, fast-forwarding, rewinding and pausing, searching for clues and meaning. When the worn-out tape is snarled in her VCR, she pulls the unspooled mess into her face and inhales reverently.

headline: Boy, 15, Dies Trying to Jump Between Rooftops in Brooklyn
text: A 15-year-old boy fell to his death in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, on Thursday when he tried to jump from the top of one four-story apartment building to the top of another, the police said.

headline: Word of the Day | prolixity
text: prolixity • \pro-ˈlik-sə-te\ • noun

headline: Mardy Fish Ends Hiatus but Falls at Indian Wells
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — In his first singles match in more than 18 months, Mardy Fish held two match points in the third set Thursday at the BNP Paribas Open before falling to Ryan Harrison, 6-4, 4-6, 7-6 (3).

headline: In ‘La Sapienza,’ Eugene Green’s New Film, a Man Works on His Artistic Soul
text: In the early 1970s, when the director Eugene Green first visited the church Sant’Ivo alla Sapienza, a Baroque masterpiece in Rome, he encountered Roman intransigence. “The guardian kept saying he didn’t have the key; one of his colleagues had the key.” Then along came a tourist.

headline: Agitating With Animation: ‘When the Wind Blows’ and ‘Coonskin’
text: No one, post-Charlie Hebdo, can doubt a cartoon’s capacity to change the world — R. Crumb’s breezy remonstrance “It’s only lines on paper, folks!” notwithstanding. Animated cartoons are generally more circumspect than static drawings, but some have been agitators as well.

headline: The Letter From John Lennon Behind ‘Danny Collins’
text: In 1971, a British folk singer named Steve Tilston gave an interview to ZigZag — a small, underground-rock rag named for a Captain Beefheart jam and a popular brand of rolling papers — in support of his debut LP, a collection of earnest, fingerpicked guitar songs that recall Nick Drake and Jackson C. Frank. When asked if he thought fame and fortune might prove toxic to his songwriting, Mr. Tilston did not equivocate. “Yes, yes, of course it will,” he recalls saying. “My heart will suffer.”

headline: SEC Chooses Greg Sankey as Its Next Commissioner
text: Greg Sankey will be the next commissioner of the Southeastern Conference, replacing Mike Slive, the conference announced Thursday. Sankey, currently the SEC’s executive associate commissioner and chief operating officer, will be introduced Friday morning in Nashville, where the conference is holding its men’s basketball tournament.

headline: Jenna McMahon Dies at 89; Created Popular Sitcoms
text: Jenna McMahon, who teamed up with Dick Clair, her partner in a comedy act, to create the long-running sitcom “The Facts of Life,” died on March 2 in Monterey, Calif. She was 89.

headline: Childbirth in Bolivia’s High Plains
text: Correction appended below.

headline: Yoshihiro Tatsumi, Formative Manga Artist, Dies at 79
text: Yoshihiro Tatsumi, a Japanese cartoonist whose dark, psychologically astute tales helped establish the genre of adult comics and graphic novels, died on March 7 in Tokyo. He was 79.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Feb. 13
text: Photographs from the past week from New York City and the region include images from Cardinal Egan’s funeral Mass and the end of winter.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
text: 10:30 A.M. (Encore) HOOSIERS (1987) Norman Dale (Gene Hackman) is the new basketball coach in a small Indiana town in this tale of competition and redemption set in the early 1950s. His unorthodox coaching style initially rankles the townspeople and alienates the players but ultimately proves successful. Dennis Hopper, in an Oscar-nominated role, plays Shooter Flatch, an alcoholic who helps coach the team. “Who could resist a tiny Middle Western town where the barber shop is called Rooster’s and the game of basketball is foremost on every mind?” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times about this sports classic, directed by David Anspaugh. “Probably no one, and the quaintly innocent ‘Hoosiers’ is irresistible in much the same way.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “This was not someone trying to bring healing to Ferguson. This was a damn punk, a punk who was trying to sow discord.”

headline: Corrections: March 13, 2015
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Book on Sandy Alderson Set for Release as Mets Try to Turn Page
text: In his first four seasons as the general manager of the Mets, Sandy Alderson put together a body of work that included a lot more losses than victories, a surprising number of quips and a steadfast ability to never point a finger at the team’s owners for repeatedly saddling him with payrolls that were meager by major-market standards.

headline: St. Joseph’s Coach Phil Martelli Finds Grandson Mellows Him
text: This week, for his preschool class’s show and tell, Philip Stephen Martelli brought in a printout of the Atlantic 10 tournament bracket and demonstrated how teams advance to the championship.

headline: Q. and A.: Michael Meyer on Living and Writing ‘In Manchuria’
text: The American writer Michael Meyer first arrived in China in 1995 as a Peace Corps volunteer and has since documented changes in disparate corners of the country.

headline: Why We Need to Keep Forces in Afghanistan
Is the Yik Yak Social App a Force for Good, or Ill?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Anti-Vaccine Parents
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cab Rides to Nowhere
text: To the Editor:

headline: Shocks of Climate Change
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Focus on Violence Against Women
We Have a President for a Reason
text: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — THE letter that 47 Senate Republicans addressed to Iranian leaders this week, warning them about making a nuclear deal with President Obama, came as a surprise to many Americans. But it would not have surprised our earliest forefathers. After all, it was not uncommon, in the years immediately following the American Revolution, for individual Americans to negotiate directly with representatives of foreign governments.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Big Test
text: The political world is stuck in the middle of an accelerating protocol crisis. All sorts of customary acts of self-restraint are being washed away. It used to be that senators didn’t go out campaigning against one another. It used to be they didn’t filibuster except in rare circumstances. It used to be they didn’t block presidential nominations routinely.

headline: The Southwestern Water Wars
text: WIMBERLEY, Tex. — “WE don’t want you here,” warned the county commissioner, pointing an accusatory finger at the drilling company executives as 600 local residents rose to their feet. “We want you to leave Hays County.”

headline: Congress’s Duty on Authorizing Force
text: The Republicans in the Senate seem to have had no trouble inserting themselves into the Iran nuclear negotiations, when they had no business interfering. Yet they have shown little interest in carrying out a job that is squarely within their constitutional mandate — drafting an authorization for war against ISIS that Democrats can support and President Obama will sign.

headline: Strength Is Weakness
text: We’ve been warned over and over that the Federal Reserve, in its effort to improve the economy, is “debasing” the dollar. The archaic word itself tells you a lot about where the people issuing such warnings are coming from. It’s an allusion to the ancient practice of replacing pure gold or silver coins with “debased” coins in which the precious-metal content was adulterated with cheaper stuff. Message to the gold bugs and Ayn Rand disciples who dominate the Republican Party: That’s not how modern money works. Still, the Fed’s critics keep insisting that easy-money policies will lead to a plunging dollar.

headline: Digital Dog Collar
text: I hate the new Apple Watch. Hate what it will do to conversation, to the pace of the day, to my friends, to myself. I hate that it will enable the things that already make life so incremental, now-based and hyper-connected. That, and make things far worse.

headline: Reaching Math Students One by One
text: Like middle school math teachers everywhere, the seventh-grade math teachers at Middle School 88 in the southern part of Brooklyn’s Park Slope have an impossible job. At this high-poverty school, which not long ago was considered failing, students enter with levels of math skills ranging from kindergarten to eighth grade. How can anyone teach to them all?

headline: North Korea Is Said to Fire 7 Missiles Off Its East Coast
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea has fired seven surface-to-air missiles into waters off its east coast, South Korean officials said on Friday, in the country’s latest missile test coinciding with joint United States-South Korean military exercises.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | ‘Ambush’ Seen in Shooting of 2 Police Officers in Ferguson
text: In “2 Police Officers Shot in Ferguson ‘Ambush’ Are Released From Hospital,” John Eligon and Richard Pérez-Peña report on more violence in Ferguson, Mo.

headline: Test Yourself | One Last Dance at Johnson’s Barn
text: Here are several paragraphs from a Feb. 25 article, “Johnson’s Barn, a North Dakota Institution, Plans Its Last Dance.”

headline: Valerie Jarrett: ‘I Intend to Stay Until the Lights Go Off’
text: The president’s senior adviser and confidante on immigration, working with Republicans and whether she’s the Democratic Dick Cheney.

headline: How Much Should Fans Be Allowed to Distract Opposing Teams?
text: Isn’t basketball, baseball or any other sport supposed to be about great athleticism and sportsmanship? May the best team win? Or are fans part of the game too?

headline: Carly Fiorina Shapes Herself as the Republican Foil to Hillary Clinton
text: WASHINGTON — She has been the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, a senior adviser to a Republican presidential nominee and a candidate for the United States Senate. But Carly Fiorina recently took on her boldest role yet: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s loudest critic.

headline: Key to Hawks’ Team Play: Nourish the Individual
text: ATLANTA — The Hawks’ practice gym has bare walls, some cardio equipment crammed behind a baseline and patchwork flooring, a result of a recent leak. Most N.B.A. teams have gleaming, multimillion-dollar facilities. The Hawks spend their time in something that looks straight out of the Cold War.

headline: Vague Email Rules Let Federal Agencies Decide When to Hit Save or Delete
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. used an email alias named for the Temptations, the Motown group. Lisa P. Jackson, a former Environmental Protection Agency administrator, used “Richard Windsor” — a combination of her dog’s name and a New Jersey town — for her electronic alter ego.

headline: Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side Is Forgotten but Not Gone
text: If you were prone to quick and superficial judgments, you might take one look at Anne Saxelby, a young and winsome purveyor of costly artisanal cheeses on the Lower East Side, and cast her in the role of bad witch in your own little gentrification play. For nearly a decade, Saxelby Cheesemongers has occupied a stall in the Essex Street Market, a municipal food hall built by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia. And yet few have done more than Ms. Saxelby to work to preserve the market’s character and unite its disparate group of vendors, among them old-school Hispanic grocers dealing in unusual root vegetables and other inexpensive produce and retailers of the meticulously cured, the refined and the handcrafted.

headline: Wet Wipes Box Says Flush. New York’s Sewer System Says Don’t.
text: With its sewer system under siege, tallying millions of dollars in equipment damage across its underground maze, New York City is confronting a menace that has gummed the gears of plumbing networks around the world: the common wet wipe.

headline: For Brooklyn’s District Attorney, Year One Is a Trial by Fire
text: One Sunday morning in February, Kenneth P. Thompson, the Brooklyn district attorney, showed up with some fellow politicians to celebrate the 249th anniversary of the African Wesleyan Methodist Episcopal Church. The event, in Bedford-Stuyvesant, was supposed to be one of those occasions elected officials love: a straightforward, stress-free gathering of voters that focused on history, not headlines.

headline: Battered but Unbowed, ISIS Is Still on Offensive
text: WASHINGTON — The Islamic State is facing growing dissension among its rank-and-file fighters and struggling to govern towns and villages it has seized, but the militant Sunni group is still managing to launch attacks and expand its ideological reach outside of Iraq and Syria, senior American officials said.

headline: ‘The Last Flight of Poxl West,’ by Daniel Torday
text: Early on in “The Last Flight of Poxl West,” Daniel Torday’s expertly crafted first novel, an irksome grad student with dandruff asks the title character if we have “reached a point of saturation with all the first-person accounts” of World War II.

headline: Ask Well: Arsenic in Rice Crackers?
text: Question:

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: China’s Middle Class Chafes Against Maze of Red Tape
text: BEIJING — A rambunctious girl with a fondness for drawing and robots, Jessica Cherry looks like a typical 5-year-old. But in the eyes of the Chinese government she is invisible.

headline: New York Today: Global Trekker Rolls Into Town
text: Friday and the weekend: Stopping in the city on a human-powered journey, deteriorating weather, and don’t flush those wet wipes.

headline: Putin Has Vanished, but Rumors Are Popping Up Everywhere
text: MOSCOW — Where’s Putin?

headline: Official Report Describes Blunders in Deadly Police Raid in Philippines
text: MANILA — A botched police raid that killed 44 elite officers and jeopardized a landmark peace deal in the Philippines involved blunders by officials from the field commander all the way up to President Benigno S. Aquino III, according to a report released on Friday.

headline: Daily Report: New Rules for Net Neutrality May Set Stage for Legal Battles
text: The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday released extensive details of how it would regulate broadband Internet providers as a public utility, producing official wording that almost certainly sets the stage for extended legal fights, Rebecca R. Ruiz reports.

headline: UBS Chief Executive’s Pay Rose Nearly 5% in 2014
text: LONDON — Sergio P. Ermotti, the UBS chief executive, saw his compensation increase nearly 5 percent in 2014, despite the Swiss bank’s financial performance for the year being “tempered” by legal and regulatory charges, the lender said on Friday.

headline: With Plan to Join China-Led Bank, Britain Opens Door for Others
text: BEIJING — A surprise decision this week by Britain to join China’s new development bank for Asia, despite opposition from the Obama administration, will almost certainly encourage other American allies to become members, particularly Australia and South Korea, analysts said Friday.

headline: Leatherback Turtles Don’t Need Google Maps
text: Leatherback turtles can travel thousands of miles through the ocean each year. Yet when females are ready to nest, they somehow manage to return to the same beach again and again.

headline: Tracing Jewish Heritage Along the Danube
text: In Hungary, Slovakia, Austria and Germany, the river was a guide and a witness to vanished Jewish life.

headline: 3 Day-Cruises Worth the Trip
text: Itineraries in Chicago, San Francisco and New York offer the chance to admire the cities’ architecture, nature and history — in just a few hours.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: healthy ‘cheese,’ happy conservatives and simple concussion tests. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Skiing
text: If I hadn’t become a writer, I’d be living in a rusty car with a ski rack, roaming the Rockies in perpetual pursuit of fresh powder. I dream of skiing constantly; as soon as the first snowflake of the season starts its descent from the gray skies of Chicago to its flatlands, I begin following snowfall reports from various ski resorts, occasionally and arbitrarily informing my wife, Teri, that Jackson Hole or Alta got a foot overnight. The thought that some skiable place somewhere has received fresh powder makes life worth living between November and April — and beyond, and forever.

headline: The Last Volunteer
text: It was 1937, and the Fascists had already revolted in Spain. I was walking down a street in Hollywood when I saw a sign — “Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade” — written on the side of a building. I turned the corner, opened the door and went in. The people inside said, “What can we do for you?” I said, “I want to go to Spain.” They couldn’t legally send people to Spain, they told me, but did I want to help? I did. My life started with poverty and then came the Depression. I felt a certain responsibility to help the Spanish workers and farmers.

headline: How to Teach a Bird to Talk
text: A single parrot cannot forage for fruit and watch for predators at the same time; it depends on its chittering flock for protection. Therefore, to teach a bird that can talk — parrots, parakeets or mynas, for example — to talk, find one that for lack of better options thinks of you as its flock. “Don’t get an old, disappointed bird,” says Sri Ganapathy Sachchidananda Swamiji, a 72-year-old guru who, when not traveling the world playing synthesizer concerts for his followers, can be found at his bird sanctuary in Mysore, India, home to more than a thousand birds, including some 40 trained talkers. “Buy a baby bird.” Specifically, opt for one bred in captivity (or rescued) rather than one snatched from the wild.

headline: ‘Starting to Show’
text: In this poem, the visual delight of the imagery — the sun’s brightness “in the belly of the sky” — is undergirded by a pattern of rhyme and almost-rhyme. With the rhyme occurring in the middle of a line instead of at the end, combined with the rhythm of the short lines, the poem calls to mind the activity of the unborn child, a counterpoint to what is seen: that which is felt in the body. Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

headline: Jane Goodall Is Still Wild at Heart
text: Jane Goodall was already on a London dock in March 1957 when she realized that her passport was missing. In just a few hours, she was due to depart on her first trip to Africa. A school friend had moved to a farm outside Nairobi and, knowing Goodall’s childhood dream was to live among the African wildlife, invited her to stay with the family for a while. Goodall, then 22, saved for two years to pay for her passage to Kenya: waitressing, doing secretarial work, temping at the post office in her hometown, Bournemouth, on England’s southern coast, during the holiday rush. She had spent her last few days in London saying goodbyes and picking up a few things for the trip at Peter Jones, the department store in Chelsea. Now all this was for naught, it seemed. The passport must have fallen out of her purse somewhere.

headline: 19th-Century Tourists Took Silly Vacation Photos, Too
text: On the cover of this week’s magazine, Alex Honnold peers over the edge of Overhanging Rock, a famed outcropping at Glacier Point in Yosemite National Park. Honnold, one of the world’s greatest rock climbers and a master of climbing alone and without ropes, is known for doing things few others do — but this isn’t one of them. The adventurous, or at least vertigo-unafflicted, have been inching out onto Overhanging Rock for photo ops for more than a century.

headline: Mets Hitters and New Coach Start to Mesh, With Help From a Net
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — When batting practice ended on Tuesday morning, Ruben Tejada stuck around the field for extra work. Kevin Long, the Mets’ new hitting coach, wanted him to try a new drill that Long had developed.

headline: Hillary Clinton, and Names Fit to Print
text: It has been nearly 46 years since Hillary Clinton’s name first appeared in The New York Times. Were she to win the Democratic nomination for president in 2016, her time in the news in this publication before becoming a presidential nominee would be longer than that of any other Democrat.

headline: Link to Protests Unknown in Ferguson Police Inquiry
text: FERGUSON, Mo. — Investigators pursued several leads on Friday as they tried to determine who shot two officers standing outside the police station at a protest here, but they said it was unknown how many suspects were involved or whether there was any link between demonstrators and those who fired the shots.

headline: Assange’s Lawyer Welcomes Swedish Prosecutors’ Officer to Question Him in London
text: LONDON — A lawyer for Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder who has taken refuge in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London since June 2012, welcomed an offer by Swedish prosecutors on Friday to travel to Britain to question him on allegations of sexual assault, and suggested that the offer would be accepted.

headline: Today in Politics: Republicans Set Sights on First Primary State
text: Good Friday morning from Washington. After a week filled with discussion of email servers and smartphones, President Obama revealed to Jimmy Kimmel that he delegates his tweeting and never sends a text. Former President George W. Bush, motivated by the situation in Myanmar, made a rare foray into foreign affairs; and don’t try pestering Supreme Court justices about coming decisions – they don’t budge. But in the meantime, for those seeking a campaign fix, the Granite State is the place to look this weekend.

headline: For Michaela DePrince, a Dream Comes True at the Dutch National Ballet
text: AMSTERDAM — Michaela DePrince was appearing here in the third act of Balanchine’s “Jewels” with the Dutch National Ballet on a recent evening. There were about a dozen ballerinas in bejeweled white tutus arrayed across the stage, and there she was all the way stage right in the front line.

headline: An Update on Our Second Annual Student Editorial Contest
text: First of all, thank you for your enthusiasm.

headline: Defense in Marathon Bombing Has Echo of Clarence Darrow
text: BOSTON — When Judy Clarke, the lead defense lawyer for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, announced at the outset of his trial last week that her client was responsible for the Boston Marathon bombings, she was following a strategy laid out by Clarence Darrow almost a century ago.

headline: Morning Agenda: Commerzbank in U.S. Settlement
text: COMMERZBANK IN U.S. SETTLEMENT | Commerzbank, one of Germany’s biggest lenders, agreed on Thursday to pay nearly $1.5 billion and dismiss some of its employees to resolve an array of charges in the United States, DealBook’s Ben Protess reports. “The case, the latest black eye for a giant global bank accused of sending tainted money through the American financial system, closes the book on several investigations into Commerzbank,” he adds.

headline: Can an Evil Man Change?
text: CAPE TOWN — South Africa’s most notorious apartheid-era assassin, Eugene de Kock, has received parole after spending 20 years in prison. The government’s decision to let him walk free has unleashed a sort of identity crisis among South Africans. Could a man once known as “Prime Evil” really have changed? Why are we showing such charity to the deadliest cog in apartheid’s racist machine? And more important, why are so many South Africans — mostly white — so angry that this specific prisoner has been freed?

headline: If It’s Thursday, It Must Be ‘Home’ — No More
text: For many longtime readers of The Times, Thursday was tinged with sadness. One of their favorite weekly sections, Home, was no longer in the paper. The section was discontinued after the March 5 edition, almost exactly 38 years after its debut.

headline: How to Survive the College Admissions Madness
text: HERE we go again. At Harvard, Emory, Bucknell and other schools around the country, there have been record numbers of applicants yearning for an elite degree. They’ll get word in the next few weeks. Most will be turned down.

headline: What’s On This Week Around The World
text: London

headline: Police Failed to Address Sexual Abuse in Northern British City, Report Says

headline: Andy Samberg Will Host the Emmys

In recent years “Saturday Night Live’ alumni like Amy Poehler, Tina Fey, and Seth Meyers have all hosted a major award show. (Ms. Poehler and Ms. Fey did the Golden Globes for three years in a row and Mr. Meyers was the host of the 2014 Emmys.)

headline: Got College Admissions Frenzy? Read ‘Where You Go Is Not Who You’ll Be’
text: It really is the season. Facebook updates, most at least self-depreciating, have begun announcing the college choices of my friends’ children. Many include some big names in the campus world — but for a lot of reasons, many don’t. Many, if not most, of my old friends’ kids are off to places like Kansas University, Wichita State, Washburn University in Topeka, or maybe to Southern Methodist University or even the University of Texas at Austin. I’m delighted for them. I’m thrilled.

headline: A Bespoke Perfume Doesn’t Come Cheap

headline: Layers of Spring
text: Lasagna, that many-layered marvel, is a dish that shifts with the seasons. Like fashion, it comes in different hues and textures that match the weather.

headline: From The Upshot’s Editor: Political Mysteries
text: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

text: James Baldwin, Richard Wright

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: DEAD WAKE: The Last Crossing Of The Lusitania, by Erik Larson. (Crown, $28.) The 100th anniversary of the great ship’s sinking is the occasion of this entertaining book by the masterly author of “The Devil in the White City.”

headline: Mario Vargas Llosa’s ‘Discreet Hero’
text: When I think of the writers I adored in my 20s, during the 1970s and ’80s, it almost makes me think that winning the Nobel Prize in Literature must not be so hard, because nearly every one of them has won it: García Márquez, Bellow, Morrison, Coetzee, Naipaul, Grass and, in 2010, the youngest and only surviving member of the Latin American “boom,” Mario Vargas Llosa. I mention this not to pitch myself as a reliable Nobel handicapper but to point out the futility of ascribing any politically correct left-wing bias to the Swedish Academy, since at least three of those favorites — Bellow, Naipaul and Vargas Llosa — are about as politically correct as Margaret Thatcher. All three have been identified with the cultural and political right, none more so than Vargas Llosa, who ran seriously for the presidency of Peru and who to this day is probably, partly through the opinion columns he publishes in Spain’s El País, the Spanish language’s most prominent conservative intellectual.

headline: ‘The Illuminations,’ by Andrew O’Hagan
text: The literature of war is by its very nature political. If a writer’s sentences are ­personal — what else, really, can they be? — and a writer has trained his lens on a bloody battleground, in reading him we will come to know where he stands, where his passions lie. When it comes to fiction, this passion can often result in ­rhetoric-spouting characters whose sole purpose is to service the author’s ideas. But in “The Illuminations,” the Scottish novelist and critic Andrew O’Hagan has created a story that is both a howl against the war in Afghanistan and the societies that have blindly abetted it, and a multilayered, deeply felt tale of family, loss, memory, art, loyalty, secrecy and forgiveness.

headline: ‘The Unraveling of Mercy Louis,’ by Keija Parssinen
text: American television would have it that high schools are the site of endless intrigue: In cult favorites like “Twin Peaks” and “Veronica Mars,” teen­agers enact adult dramas in miniature, sleuthing in trench coats before joining their peers in ill-fitted dresses and wrinkled suits at prom. Such is the lot of the American teenager, a creature at once juvenile and jaded.

headline: Rock ’n’ Write
text: Kim Gordon’s memoir, “Girl in a Band,” is reviewed this week by the musician, writer and producer Questlove. Gordon, a founder of the seminal art-rock band Sonic Youth, is the latest in a cavalcade of rock stars (of a certain age) to write a memoir. Odds are that if you were on MTV at anytime in the 1980s, you’ve published your life story in the past decade.

headline: Religious History
text: THE NUNS OF SANT’AMBROGIO

headline: ‘The Tell-Tale Heart,’ by Jill Dawson
text: Patrick Robson, the main character in Jill Dawson’s novel “The Tell-Tale Heart,” is a 50-ish divorced British academic whose least complicated relationship is with his BMW. A well-practiced philanderer, Patrick juggles Helen, his ex-wife, and Lucy, a former mistress, as well as a scorned girlfriend, a younger (of course) colleague who avenges herself by bringing Patrick up on sexual harassment charges before a university committee. Patrick knows he’s a rogue; he also admits to being the “world’s worst father” to his two children: Alice, his daughter with Helen, and Ben, his son with Lucy.

headline: Reif Larsen’s ‘I Am Radar’
text: Set aside for the moment the black baby born to white parents, the avant-­garde puppeteers and the quantum physics that swirl around the whole kit and caboodle. The most interesting facet of Reif Lar­sen’s 600-plus-page novel, “I Am Radar,” is that it reads like something far more compact than its bulk might suggest. There are maps, diagrams and pictures (e.g., an elephant plummeting from a bridge, a Cambodian prisoner of the Khmer Rouge) that remind one of the ­visual arrangements in W. G. Sebald’s novels. Then there is a deeply patterned narrative that darts easily from small-bore domestic dramas to sweeping historical catastrophes with just the right fillip of silliness and levity to keep the whole text eminently ­approachable.

headline: Inside the List
text: The Insider: Joseph Kanon’s seventh historical thriller, “Leaving Berlin,” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 11. Kanon first cracked the list with his debut novel, “Los Alamos,” in 1997 — but he was already well known in the book business before then, having spent some 30 years as an editor and publishing executive, including a stint as president of Dutton. During that long first act, Kanon worked with fiction writers including Muriel Spark, Louis Auchincloss, Frank Conroy and Jayne Anne Phillips. But he never dreamed of writing a novel himself, he told an Australian newspaper in 2009. “I didn’t have manuscripts secretly in the bottom drawer,” he said. “Honestly, I didn’t. I was happy in publishing. I was in the service of other people’s books. The last thing you want is to be in competition with your writers.” That all changed after Kanon left the industry in the mid-1990s, when he vacationed in New Mexico and was struck by the idea for a crime novel set during the Manhattan Project. “I never told anyone I was doing it,” he said. “I didn’t even tell my wife. I didn’t know if I could do it. What could be more embarrassing than a publisher who couldn’t write?”

headline: Mary Helen Specht’s ‘Migratory Animals’
text: Tales of naïve Americans abroad may have defined our national fiction around the turn of the last century, but the literature of the early 21st abounds with an entirely more sophisticated sort of traveler, perfectly exemplified by Flannery, the hard-as-nails heroine of Mary Helen Specht’s delightfully ambitious first novel, “Migratory Animals.” A far cry from Henry James’s Isabel Archer, Flannery — like many of her generation and station — is “on the lam” from both her middle-class, middlebrow roots and the lifestyle-driven superficiality carefully honed by her onetime college friends. She has settled in Nigeria less because her work as a climate-change scientist has repercussions for local farmers and more because it’s a few continents away from her sister, Molly, “an emotional tar pit” for whom Flannery served as a surrogate mother during the years when the girls’ actual mother was slowly, grotesquely deteriorating from Huntington’s disease.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE SPLENDID THINGS WE PLANNED: A Family Portrait, by Blake Bailey. (Norton, $15.95.) Bailey, the biographer of Richard Yates, John Cheever and Charles Jackson, takes up his own family’s turbulent history in this achingly honest memoir. He tells of his failings and his parents’ — his father was a prosperous Oklahoma lawyer, his mother a German immigrant with a bohemian streak — but the dark heart of the story is Bailey’s older brother, Scott, and his alcohol- and drug-fueled fall from grace.

headline: ‘In Every Way,’ by Nic Brown
text: It sounds impossible: Give up your baby for adoption and still spend every day with her. But Maria, the 19-year-old protagonist of Nic Brown’s novel “In Every Way,” does just that, becoming the full-time nanny of the daughter she gave away. This is an ingenious feat, considering Maria opted for a mostly closed adoption. That the reunion is nonetheless entirely believable is a credit to Brown’s gift for realism, and evidence that there is no anonymity in the digital age.

headline: ‘The Death of Caesar,’ by Barry Strauss
text: Among the most poignant objects that survive from the era of the Ides of March — March 15, 44 B.C., the day Julius Caesar fell to the knives of Brutus, Cassius and perhaps 21 other senators — is a dime-size silver denarius, minted by Brutus a year or two after the murder. One side of this rare coin shows ­military-style daggers flanking a felt pileus cap, a symbol of freedom from slavery, and the abbreviation EID MAR. On the other side, remarkably, Brutus had his own portrait stamped. Before this, Caesar was the only Roman who had dared put himself on a coin, for to do so was to assume the stature of a monarch — or a god.

headline: ‘The Rebellion of Miss Lucy Ann Lobdell,’ by William Klaber
text: There are only two basic plots in fiction, writers occasionally say: “Somebody goes on a journey” and, the other side of the coin, “A stranger comes to town.” Brilliantly, William Klaber has managed to combine them. In this deeply satisfying historical novel, he recreates the voice of Lucy Ann Lobdell, a real mid-19th-­century New York woman who abandoned her young daughter and set out — dressed and passing as a man — to find the independence (and money) denied her as a woman. After many years of wandering as Joseph Lobdell, she married another woman and eventually found herself locked away as a lunatic.

headline: Abandonment Issues
text: The older I get, the more preoccupied I become with the number of things I’ve given up on over the years. I’m fond of the line, often attributed to Paul Valéry, about how “a work of art is never finished, merely abandoned,” but as I look back with mounting unease at a path strewn with half-started and half-finished projects, I wonder if I might have taken this counsel too much, and too literally, to heart.

headline: EQT and Goldman Sachs Funds Sell Remaining Stake in ISS
text: LONDON — The Swedish private equity firm EQT Partners and funds advised by Goldman Sachs have sold their remaining stake in the Danish outsourcing company ISS for about $1 billion a decade after acquiring the company.

headline: Facing Steep Climb, Lakers Are Rungs Ahead of the Knicks
text: LOS ANGELES — For a voice of experience on how a very bad N.B.A. team can quickly be transformed into a formidable one, Byron Scott should be your man.

headline: Hillarynomics: Big Policy Questions for Clinton
text: Barring an unexpected economic boom over the next year and a half, the 2016 Democratic nominee for president will probably not base her campaign around being President Obama’s heir.

headline: Newark Valentine’s Day Homesteaders Face Financing Challenge
text: The city of Newark generated plenty of publicity on Valentine’s Day, when more than 500 hopeful buyers lined up for a shot at purchasing one of 100 vacant lots being offered for $1,000 apiece.

text: Jazz in New Orleans is getting a new home with the April 2 opening of the Peoples Health New Orleans Jazz Market in the Central City neighborhood.

headline: Bringing Bolshoi Ballet to Movie Theaters
text: The Bolshoi Ballet is coming to a movie theater near you. Well, in all likelihood: the 2015-16 season of “Bolshoi Ballet in Cinema,” presented by Pathé Live and BY Experience, will show seven full-length ballets — three prerecorded (so the casts are known) and four shown live or on the day of performance — in some 450 spots across the United States and Canada.

headline: Upper East Side Maisonette for $18 Million
text: A grandly proportioned 17-room maisonette in a white-glove co-op at 120 East End Avenue opposite Carl Schurz Park is poised to enter the market with an asking price of $18 million. The monthly maintenance charge for the residence, which has a private entrance on the avenue and a formal entry via the building’s discreet lobby on East 85th Street, is $9,467.

headline: 1940: Ex-Governor of Punjab Slain
text: LONDON — A mysterious assassin today [March 13] shot and killed Sir Michael O’Dwyer, former Lieutenant Governor of the Punjab, and wounded Lord Zetland, Secretary of State for India, Sir  Louis W. Dane and Lord Lamington at the conclusion of a meeting in Caxton Hall while 150 of Britain’s highest ranking civil servants looked on in horror. The outrage is believed to be an act of vengeance arising out of the Amritsar shooting of 1919.

headline: In China, a Building Frenzy’s Fault Lines
text: As the real estate market in the United States was collapsing in the mid-2000s, Wall Street went in search of new terrain, and found it in China. All across the country, from Beijing to Shenzhen, sprawling housing developments and business districts were popping up, seemingly overnight. Real estate prices were soaring. Western banks, hedge funds, private equity firms and other investors wanted a piece of the action.

headline: Netanyahu Shifts Tactics as His Likud Party Appears to Slip in Final Surveys
text: JERUSALEM — When Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu made an unannounced visit this week to the Mahane Yehuda market here, he did not invite the local news media. Instead, selected scenes from his tour were filmed and the video released by his campaign.

headline: Paris Fashion Week Street Style
text: After a monthlong marathon of shows, Paris Fashion Week is the last chance for insiders to peacock their carefully planned outfits. The Tuileries Garden, the hub for all things style (and Paris itself in itsfinery), is the perfect backdrop for showgoers to parade their looks. Here, some noteworthy moments from outside the shows.

headline: Love or Hate Christian Laettner, but It Is Time to Honor Him
text: Christian Laettner is not a member of the Basketball Hall of Fame as an individual. But an objective look at a player whom fans loved to hate says he should be.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: 5 Women’s Rights Activists Are Formally Detained in Beijing
text: BEIJING — The police in Beijing have put five young female activists under formal detention on suspicion of “picking quarrels and provoking trouble,” lawyers for four of the women said on Friday. The charge is one that the Chinese authorities have increasingly used in recent years to quell activism and discussion of social and political issues.

headline: Israel Chooses
text: Scenes from the campaign trail earlier this year, as Israelis grappled with a rapidly evolving political landscape.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘The Last Flight of Poxl West’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Teddy Wayne reviews Daniel Torday’s first novel, “The Last Flight of Poxl West.” Mr. Wayne writes:

headline: Greenwich Village Townhouse Brings $9,500,000
text: A 20-foot-wide townhouse in Greenwich Village, with a dual-personality exterior that includes an unassuming brick front and a whimsical rear facade boldly accented with a rainbow of colors, sold for $9,500,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Letting a Broken Arm Heal Without Surgery
text: Broken arms are routinely treated with surgery, but a randomized trial has found that many breaks can be allowed to heal on their own.

headline: Notes on an ‘Idiot’s’ Guide to Retirement
text: My article in this week’s special section on retirement was an attempt to get off my behind and actually think about my finances. As the article points out, I’ve been avoiding any real confrontation with issues like retirement for many years, though I always made sure to set up a regular contribution to a 401(k) account. Was it enough? Finding out was the point of the article. And since, like many reporters, I do almost nothing without a deadline, having an assignment to write on the subject made me finally take my own financial life seriously.

headline: 1890: Revelers Pack Paris Streets
text: Paris offered yesterday a perfect picture of metropolitan bliss. Years have passed since the city had enjoyed itself so thoroughly on the occasion of the Mid-Lent festival. It was not that the masks were more numerous or the perambulating blanchisseuses more gaily attired than in former fêtes of the Mi-Carême, but simply that the sun shone down with spring-like warmth and brightness, giving an extra glitter to every spangle, and making each peal of laughter sound with double merriment.

headline: Vaccines Face Same Mistrust That Fed Ebola
text: MONROVIA, Liberia — West Africa’s Ebola epidemic may be waning, but another outbreak in the future is a near certainty, health officials say.

headline: Childless by Choice
text: ALTADENA, Calif. — I WENT to a fortuneteller when I was 25. Her house was on a busy street, its shingled siding a strange, marigold orange, the trim a clashing bright red and blue. A banner advertised: “Special: $5.”

headline: Readers Respond: On ‘Republican Idiocy on Iran’
text: For many readers of Thursday’s editorial on the subject, Republican senators’ open letter to Iran represents a dangerous new low in U.S. politics and international relations.

headline: Fortum Agrees to Sell Swedish Power Distribution Grid for $6.9 Billion
text: LONDON — Fortum, the state-controlled Finnish utility, said on Friday that it had agreed to sell its Swedish electricity distribution network to a consortium of Swedish funds and Borealis Infrastructure Management of Canada for 6.6 billion euros, or about $6.9 billion, including debt.

headline: Fear of Frying
text: Nutritionists will tell you that “butter is back” is not quite the right message to be sending to the public about the significance of fat in a healthy diet. We can, however, let go of our fear of frying, especially if we use monounsaturated fats like olive oil and polyunsaturated fats like grapeseed oil. Study after study has indicated that refined carbohydrates play a much more insidious role in our national health problems than fats do, and that a moderate-fat (but low-saturated fat) diet like the Mediterranean diet (about 40 percent calories from fat) is a healthy way to eat, and even more important, an enjoyable, very easy way of eating to adhere to.

headline: What I Love | James Klein and David Reid
text: Two ceramists live with their own and others’ works, vintage furniture and a few beloved unidentified objects.

headline: In Queens, Ceramics, History, and a Bit of Mystery
text: The ceramists James Klein and David Reid came to live in the borough of Queens as many do, after a stint in Brooklyn.

headline: The Trouble With Advance Directives
text: The man had written an advance directive four years ago, before his advancing dementia had made communication difficult. He had been very specific.

headline: All You Need to Know About Income Inequality, in One Comparison
text: The Wall Street bonus pool for last year is roughly double the total earnings of all Americans who work full time at the federal minimum wage.

headline: Valeant Said to Be Planning to Raise Its Bid for Salix Pharmaceuticals
text: Valeant Pharmaceuticals is planning to team up with Pershing Square Capital Management and other top shareholders, including ValueAct Capital, to raise its bid for Salix Pharmaceuticals this weekend, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Watching ‘Fresh Off the Boat’ at Asia Roma in Chinatown
