headline: Director of Durst Film Says He Is ‘Relieved’ About Arrest
text: The director Andrew Jarecki and his co-writer and cinematographer Marc Smerling didn’t know what they were getting themselves into when they agreed to interview Robert Durst. The real estate heir contacted them following the release of their 2010 film “All Good Things,” a thinly veiled dramatization of the 1982 disappearance of Mr. Durst’s first wife, Kathleen McCormack. Mr. Durst said he wanted to tell his side of the story. The results of Mr. Jarecki’s and Mr. Smerling’s investigation became “The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst,” a six-part documentary whose final episode aired Sunday night, one day after Mr. Durst was arrested in New Orleans on charges stemming from an investigation into the murder of his friend Susan Berman in Los Angeles in 2000. In the final episode, Mr. Durst is heard, on a live microphone he’s wearing in the bathroom following a formal interview in April 2012 with Mr. Jarecki, seeming to confess to three murders. Mr. Jarecki and Mr. Smerling spoke by phone this morning about the case, “The Jinx” and its aftermath. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Robert Durst, Saying He Was Worried, Fled to Familiar Refuge Before His Arrest
text: NEW ORLEANS — Not for the first time in his life, Robert A. Durst had left his home and sought to disappear. And not for the first time, he went to New Orleans.

headline: U.N. Monitor Says Iran Is Worsening on Rights, Despite Pledges
text: GENEVA — Iran’s use of the death penalty is rising and its repression of political critics is worsening despite promises by President Hassan Rouhani of a less restrictive society, a United Nations human rights monitor said on Monday.

headline: Looking at the Promise and Perils of the Emerging Big Data Sector
text: There is a certain predictability to media and technology finance. Any company looking for money is inevitably characterized as similar to whatever has recently garnered the highest valuations.

headline: For Ruben Gallego, a Ride on Air Force One and a Presidential Aside
text: WASHINGTON — For Representative Ruben Gallego, a freshman Democrat from Arizona, joining the 114th Congress started with a heady ride.

headline: Stephen Colbert and George Lucas in Conversation at the Tribeca Film Festival
text: Stephen Colbert once battled Jon Stewart over who could lay claim to the title of biggest “Star Wars” fan on the planet. Mr. Stewart may have won that round, but Mr. Colbert’s expertise will be put to the test again when he sits down for a public conversation with George Lucas on April 17, one of several events, including talks with Courtney Love and Harvey Weinstein, announced Monday by organizers of the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: π Dollars
text: Our π Day celebration continues this week with a recent pi-related question posed on Quora that has received an astounding 700,000-plus views. There’s no single right answer — just fun to think about what you’d actually do. And the question is —

headline: At Oregon Festival, Films About (and on) Bicycles
text: In Portland, Ore., motion pictures are the heart of the Filmed by Bike Festival, screening short films about cycling, often shot from rolling bicycles.

headline: Economic Ignorance Blogging
text: We need a name for a syndrome related to, but not quite the same as, the Dunning-Kruger effect. That effect, you may or may not know, shows that truly incompetent people are so incompetent that they believe themselves competent.

headline: Taking Care With Calcium Supplements
text: Q. I have been told that women should stop taking calcium supplements after menopause, as there is a danger of heart attack and stroke. Is this true?

headline: The Kaisa Bandwagon
text: Excited by China’s property boom, wealthy investors poured money into the distressed property developer, Kaisa. Those who jumped in later have suffered.

headline: New York’s Sewer, Up Close
text: New York City politics can be unseemly. Sometimes a walking tour of used wet wipes is part of the deal.

headline: Beauty Tips for Girls, From Lego
text: My 7-year-old wants to know if she has an oval face. Why? Because “oval faces can often have almost any style haircut because almost everything looks great on this face shape!” Her sudden concern with her hairstyle “looking great” comes courtesy of her new Lego Club Magazine, which included “Emma’s Beauty Tips” in the March-April 2015 Lego Club Magazine.

headline: The New Optimism of Al Gore
text: NASHVILLE — Al Gore wants to make a point about cellphones, and he has a helpful set of slides on his laptop. “Do you want to see that?” he asks, and starts to turn the MacBook around.

headline: Jessica Lange Says She’s Done With ‘American Horror Story’
text: Really, what is there left for one to do after playing a nun in charge of an insane asylum, a powerful New Orleans witch, and the proprietor of a Florida freak show? For Jessica Lange, apparently, not much more.

headline: 1940: Limits on Bread and Chocolate
text: Further restrictions regarding the baking and selling of bread, effective April 1, and control of the manufacture of chocolate candy anticipating its removal from the market on September 1 were announced yesterday [March 16] in decrees of the Department of Agriculture published in the ‘‘Journal Officiel.’’ The law regarding chocolate forbids the manufacture after June 1 of fancy chocolates, chocolate ‘‘fondant’’ or milk chocolate, or confectionery made with fancy chocolate, permitting only common, unsweetened chocolate used for cooking. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 17, 1940

headline: Closing Arguments Begin in Test Cheating Trial of 12 Atlanta Educators
text: ATLANTA — After more than five years of controversy and five months of testimony, a prosecutor used seven words on Monday to recap the accusations against the dozen Atlanta educators seated in a courtroom here.

headline: Netanyahu Warns of New ‘Hamastan’
text: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel spoke at a Jewish settlement the day before the Israeli election, warning that his opponents Tzipi Livni and Isaac Herzog would fail to protect residents.

headline: Fringe Gone Wild
text: Not the wispy embellishment of days past, but a full-on takeover of a garment by its trim. At last, the ornamental becomes essential.

headline: 2 Years On, Cypriots Still Seething Over Banking Crisis
text: A slow recovery is underway and European officials have moved on, but in Cyprus many people are still bitter over the “bail-in” that was put in place.

headline: U.N. Orders Review of 1961 Crash That Killed Dag Hammarskjold
text: LONDON — The plane had flown deep into the African night on a mission for peace. Finally, it drew near its destination in the copper mining region of what is now northern Zambia. The crew radioed for permission to descend. Then there was nothing.

headline: As Cyprus Recovers From Banking Crisis, Deep Scars Remain
text: NICOSIA, Cyprus — The financial world has pretty much moved on since Cyprus was briefly the epicenter of market anxiety.

headline: Russell Page, a Natural Artist
text: This spring, London’s Garden Museum is exhibiting the work of the landscape designer Russell Page, perhaps the leading horticultural talent of the 20th century, who was, by his own account, “the most famous garden designer no one has ever heard of.” A master of structuring nature with an architect’s eye, Page, whose clients included Marella Agnelli, Oscar de  la Renta and Lady Bird Johnson, created mesmerizing green spaces with clipped shrubs, gleaming ponds and sweeping vistas. For the first time, his personal photographs, notes and unrealized designs have been brought together, shedding light on the passion and process of the late luminary.

headline: ‘Color Purple’ Revival Names Its Celie and Shug
text: A stripped-down production of “The Color Purple,” the musical adaptation of the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, will feature an up-and-coming British theater star and an Academy Award-winning American actress when it opens on Broadway this fall.

headline: Court Strikes on Insider Trading, and Congress Lobs Back
text: Sir Isaac Newton’s third law of motion was that “for every action there is an equal and opposite reaction.” The response from Congress to an appeals court decision in United States v. Newman, which overturned the insider trading convictions of two hedge fund managers, is perhaps more an overreaction.

headline: The Moment
text: Pieces for the home that bring elegance of form to the most basic functions.

headline: Memories Weaken Without Reinforcement, Study Finds
text: What happens to forgotten memories — old computer passwords, friends’ previous phone numbers?

headline: What We’re Reading Now
text: The Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics is rolling out a new nutrition seal, “Kids Eat Right,” for select foods. However, it’s unclear what exactly the label implies, since the first food to display the seal is Kraft Singles, a product whose connection to real cheese is so dubious that the FDA ordered the company to stop calling it “cheese food” in 2002. Bizarrely, the academy insists the seal is not an endorsement but just an advertisement for its Kids Eat Right educational website. No wonder parents think sugary drinks are healthy.

headline: Obama Grass-Roots Group Trying to Find a Role for 2016
text: The remnants of President Obama’s grass-roots campaign apparatus, Organizing for Action, have been in a period of flux in the last month as the organization tries to find a place among Democratic groups heading into 2016.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Sen. Tom Cotton’s Geography Lesson
text: Republican Sen. Tom Cotton of Arkansas, who last week wrote an open letter to Iran asserting that its leaders “may not fully understand our constitutional system,” helpfully noted on Sunday that Iran already controls Tehran, which is its capital.

headline: Angels Maintain Realm Amid a Star’s Relapse
text: TEMPE, Ariz. — Matt Joyce joined the Los Angeles Angels in an off-season trade, and his new teammates sometimes amaze him. Joyce made an All-Star team once, for the Tampa Bay Rays, but players like Mike Trout and Albert Pujols seem otherworldly to him in batting practice.

headline: Kendrick Lamar on His New Album and the Weight of Clarity
text: LOS ANGELES — Following the success of his major label debut, “good kid, m.A.A.d. city,” in 2012, the rapper Kendrick Lamar did not indulge in earthly luxuries. Instead, he got baptized.

headline: Expansion by Mideast Airlines Sets Off a Skirmish in the U.S.
text: Like many airports around the country, Orlando International in Florida has made efforts to attract foreign carriers in recent years. They have paid off; Orlando now gets more than 40 foreign flights a day from places like Germany, Brazil and Colombia.

headline: 1965: Deputies Beat Rights Marchers
text: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — Mounted sheriff’s deputies swinging clubs, canes and ropes charged civil-rights demonstrators today [March 16], injuring at least eight. One of those injured was a white college professor, Donald Hope, 38, of Juniata College, Huntingdon, Pa. He suffered scalp lacerations. The 600 demonstrators, mostly students, were taking part in a march on the Capitol building. Though the mounted police charge broke up the march, the demonstrators later regrouped and reached the Capitol building armed with a parade permit and escorted by city police. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 17, 1965

headline: Paying for Hurricane Sandy
text: Victims of the storm rely on complicated government programs to receive money for their damaged homes.

headline: Rand Paul Is Capturing an Audience; the Challenge Is Winning Votes
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — While his rivals were slogging their way across New Hampshire this weekend, Senator Rand Paul was here, some 1,700 miles away at the South by Southwest festival, where he was competing for oxygen not with other Republicans but with a Judd Apatow premiere and with Grumpy Cat — the Internet meme, in the fur.

headline: Wall Street Prosecutor Will Join WilmerHale
text: A white-shoe law firm has poached another Wall Street prosecutor.

headline: Seamus Mullen’s El Colmado Butchery Fits in the Neighborhood
text: To Shop: A Butcher in the Neighborhood

headline: Hillary Clinton Gets Irish Honor, and a Warm Embrace
text: On the eve of St. Patrick’s Day, Hillary Rodham Clinton was lucky enough to bask in the approval of a crowd of Irish and Irish-American power brokers who gathered in Manhattan for her induction into the Irish America Hall of Fame.

headline: In Performance: T. Oliver Reid
text: Mr. Reid, with Lawrence Yurman on piano, sings “Take the A Train,” a number Mr. Reid performs in his show “Drop Me Off in Harlem,” on Sunday at the Metropolitan Room.

headline: Sale of an Astérix Page Helps Families of Charlie Hebdo Victims
text: PARIS – An original Astérix comic book page fetched 150,000 euros, or about $160,000, at a sale at Christie’s here, with all the proceeds going to the families of those killed in the attack on the offices of the Charlie Hebdo satirical newspaper in January, according to the auction house.

headline: In Performance | T. Oliver Reid
text: Mr. Reid, with Lawrence Yurman on piano, sings the jazz standard “Sophisticated Lady,” a number Mr. Reid performs in his show “Drop Me Off in Harlem,” playing on March 22 at the Metropolitan Room.

headline: It May Be Time to Lighten Up When You’re Scaring the Kids
text: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has made a name for himself by firing up the Republican base with blazing speeches that shred his opponents.

headline: Lawyer Doubts Suspect’s Role in Ferguson Shootings
text: FERGUSON, Mo. — A lawyer for Jeffrey L. Williams, the 20-year-old suspect charged with shooting two officers during a demonstration outside the police station here, said Monday that he did not believe that his client had fired the shots.

headline: Retro Striped Knits for Spring
text: With a pair of well-worn, washed-out Levi’s, these throwback shirts and sweaters are charming, youthful and the best of the season.

headline: Care Differs for American and African With Ebola
text: The latest American aid worker to contract Ebola overseas, last week in Sierra Leone, was swiftly evacuated to a specialized treatment center for infected health workers run by the British Defense Ministry in the country’s capital, Freetown, then on to the National Institutes of Health clinical center in Bethesda, Md. Doctors at the center said Monday that his condition had worsened from serious to critical since his arrival on Friday.

headline: Haitian Leader’s Power Grows as Scandals Swirl
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — With a brisk clap of his hands, Michel Martelly summed up the first steps he would take if he ever left the music business and became the president of Haiti.

headline: Behind Closed Doors
text: Bombarded by imagery all day at work, the renowned advertising provocateur Sam Shahid comes home to, well, very little.

headline: Imaging the Israeli Settlements
text: Jodi Rudoren’s recent article on expanding Israeli settlements was accompanied by striking visuals that helped to tell the story of how rapidly the settlements have grown.

headline: Houthi Rebels Release Detained Yemeni Ministers
text: CAIRO — Houthi rebels released Yemen’s former prime minister and members of his cabinet after nearly two months of house detention on Monday, in a sign of some progress toward easing the country’s chaotic political crisis.

headline: A New Showcase in Paris Celebrates the Art of Pen and Paper
text: The pen may be mightier than the sword, but it has admittedly lost some of its potency in the Internet age. “Écriture (Writing),” a new product showcase at the Paris concept store Merci, aims to celebrate the analog with a display of historic and iconic paper goods and desktop accouterments. Notable wares include those by the century-old Swiss manufacturer Caran d’Ache, from high-quality Technograph graphite pencils and water-soluble Prismalo colored pencils, both of which the company has been making for 80-plus years, to ballpoint pens in the brand’s 849 model, which are being sold for the first time outside of Switzerland. Other featured products include notepads and folio cases by the French brand Exacompta and gold ballpoint pens and molded glass pencils by the Danish company Hay.

headline: Why Female Athletes Shouldn’t Have to Beat Men
text: The mixed martial artist Ronda Rousey has defeated 11 opponents, the most recent one in only 14 seconds. Perhaps predictably, this has led to questions about whether she will fight men.

headline: Netanyahu Rules Out Palestinian State
text: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, in an interview with NRG the day before the general election, said that a Palestinian state would not be created if he remained prime minister.

headline: Uniting Arabs in a Race for the Knesset
text: In Ayman Odeh’s campaign for a seat in the Knesset, he hopes to unite Arab Israeli political factions and boost voter turnout.

headline: Decoding the Rules of Conversation
text: PARIS — MY kids have recently picked up a worrying French slang word: bim (pronounced “beam”). It’s what children say in the schoolyard here after they’ve proved someone wrong, or skewered him with a biting remark. English equivalents like “gotcha” or “booyah” don’t carry the same sense of gleeful vanquish, and I doubt British or American kids use them quite as often.

headline: Questioning the Value of Health Apps
text: A bodybuilder presses the iPhone’s camera with a fingertip, and his heart rate and blood oxygen levels appear on the screen. A fellow in pajamas steps onto a scale, peers at his smartphone, and sighs dejectedly. A runner races along the waterfront, a cellphone strapped to her pumping arms.

headline: Tool of N.C.A.A. Bracket Ignorance: Your Basketball Smarts
text: There are more than 9.2 quintillion ways to fill out the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament bracket, and as March Madness gets underway, more than 100 million Americans are determined to get it exactly right.

headline: Johann Johannsson’s ‘Drone Mass’ Bridges Ancient and Modern at Temple of Dendur
text: Audience members won’t have to duck their heads at Tuesday’s world premiere of Johann Johannsson’s “Drone Mass,” and security guards at the Temple of Dendur need not worry about unauthorized surveillance photography. No pilotless aircraft accompanies this oratorio, which the Metropolitan Museum of Art presents in a performance by the vocal group Roomful of Teeth and members of the American Contemporary Music Ensemble, with Mr. Johannsson on electronics.

headline: U.S. Oil Prices Fall to Six-Year Low
text: Oil prices fell to six-year lows on Monday in the face of concerns that a glut in the United States was outpacing already-brimming storage facilities.

headline: Clever Coastline Coasters
text: Customized coasters — linen squares embroidered with friends’ names, thick felt cutouts emblazoned with their initials — are so much more than an opportunity to protect the furniture while posing as a thoughtful host. For me and my fellow hypochondriacs, they’re really just a vehicle for containing each guest’s … germs, especially now that the seasons are changing and warmer days will give way to spring colds and mucous-y allergies. “No, no, Emily. That’s not your glass. See? It’s sitting on Katherine’s coaster. Speaking of glasses, how’s your pinkeye coming along?”

headline: Older Really Can Mean Wiser
text: Behind all those canned compliments for older adults — spry! wily! wise! — is an appreciation for something that scientists have had a hard time characterizing: mental faculties that improve with age.

headline: Review: Christopher Wheeldon’s ‘Swan Lake’ Focuses on the Men
text: PHILADELPHIA — When, oh, when will America acquire an even half-decent staging of Tchaikovsky’s full-length “Swan Lake”? Having long had most of the world’s best “Nutcracker” productions, it now has the world’s two best stagings of Tchaikovsky’s “The Sleeping Beauty”: at American Ballet Theater (Alexei Ratmansky’s, new this month) and Boston Ballet (Ninette de Valois’s, with supplementary choreography by Frederick Ashton). But what about “Swan Lake”?

headline: Review: In ‘One Big Happy,’ It’s Mom and Dad and Mom
text: It’s no longer unusual to find nontraditional families on television and for people in those families to be having babies. Apparently the makers of “One Big Happy,” an intelligence-insulting sitcom that begins Tuesday night on NBC, haven’t noticed, because every minute of their show screams: “Hey! We’ve got a pregnant lesbian! Bet you’ve never seen that before!”

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
text: This is one of those weeks that build to a terrific finish Sunday. But there will be plenty to watch before then. The Times soccer editor, Andrew Das, a shameless Ajax supporter, suggests what to watch.

headline: Seeking Hospitality Outside Its Traditional Realm
text: I’M a control freak, and I guess I’m proud of that because that means that my clients don’t have to worry — I’ll do that. Since I’m a designer, and principal and founder of Tonychi & Associates, it’s very important for me to go where the jobs are, and my travels can take me anywhere throughout the United States, Europe or Asia.

headline: Smaller Airports Struggle Against Big Airports’ Lures
text: TUCSON — THERE were so many people booked on the 8 a.m. bus trip to the Phoenix airport the other morning that the Arizona Shuttle company had to call in a bigger vehicle.

headline: Preparing for Ebola, but Stopping Lassa Fever
text: Last fall, with the Ebola epidemic raging, the small nation of Benin, a few countries away from the outbreak zone, experienced a cluster of unexplained deaths.

headline: At 73, a First TV Job at the Final Four
text: Bill Raftery’s summons to call his first Final Four for CBS and TBS next month came at age 73 — and was only 32 years in the making.

headline: Why Is the Timeline of ‘The Jinx’ So Confusing?
text: Following Sunday’s finale of “The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst” on HBO, questions have arisen about the timeline of events presented in the documentary. (Gawker has a particularly detailed account here.) Whether it’s because of those unanswered questions or for other reasons, the director Andrew Jarecki has canceled previously scheduled appearances on “The Tonight Show” and MSNBC’s “All In With Chris Hayes,” as well as with other media outlets.

headline: The Writer’s Room
text: Surrounded by photographs, family mementos and the clamor of everyday life, five authors offer a glimpse into the spaces where they create.

headline: A Sixth Season for ‘Community,’ Rescued by Yahoo Screen
text: It’s an insufficiently appreciated fact that for five seasons, television’s most highly conceptual, self-referential, pulverize-the-fourth-wall show was carried by a television dinosaur — NBC, the oldest of the big broadcasters. That show was “Community,” and while NBC may not have been entirely happy with it — the seasons got shorter and farther apart, and the show’s creator, Dan Harmon, was banished for Season 4 — the network stuck it out for 97 episodes of sometimes forced but often sweetly hilarious meta-comedy.

headline: Neanderthal Jewelry: The Eagle Talon Line
text: Neanderthals may have used the talons of white-tailed eagles to make jewelry 130,000 years ago, long before the appearance of modern humans in Europe, according to a new study published in PLOS One. At an archaeological site in Croatia, researchers discovered the talons, above, with notches and abrasions suggesting they had been made into necklaces or bracelets. Eagle talons may have had symbolic value to Neanderthals, the researchers said.

headline: Banco de Madrid Files for Bankruptcy Protection
text: MADRID — Banco de Madrid, a small Spanish bank, filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday after a United States government report last week accused its parent company in Andorra of laundering money on behalf of organized crime groups in China and Russia, as well as for government officials in Venezuela.

headline: Cablevision to Offer HBO Now Streaming Service for Internet Customers
text: Cablevision said on Monday that it would offer HBO’s new Internet streaming service, HBO Now, becoming the first cable provider to announce plans to distribute the service, which does not require a traditional TV subscription.

headline: Why Icicles Look the Way They Do
text: The reason Stephen Morris studies icicles is simple. They are common and beautiful, and they make you wonder. And they are now documented online in all their chilly, wet glory in the Icicle Atlas.

headline: Dark Knight
text: Fleeing the sunny Southern gentility of his childhood, a budding film director turns a New York house into a louche fantasy.

headline: White House Treading Carefully in Israeli Elections
text: President Barack Obama, whose bitter differences with Prime Minster Benjamin Netanyahu have intensified in recent weeks, will be closely watching the outcome of Israeli elections on Tuesday, in which Mr. Netanyahu’s power is on the line.

headline: Out of Kony’s Shadow
text: Since 2011, when President Obama sent U.S. Special Forces to central Africa to support the mission to capture warlord Joseph Kony, things on the ground in northeastern Congo have improved: The world has recently celebrated the capture of the top Lord’s Resistance Army commander, Dominic Ongwen. Violent attacks have declined dramatically. Some folks are farming again, and markets are now packed with rice, vegetables and peanuts.

headline: Robert Durst Says He ‘Killed Them All’
text: “What the hell did I do? Killed them all, of course,” Robert Durst whispered to himself in the final episode of the HBO documentary “The Jinx.”

headline: Lost in Transition After Cancer
text: “You are being deported,” a surgeon announced to me last fall. That’s a scary thing for a child of two immigrants to hear. But he was referring to the removal of my port, a medical device implanted just beneath my right collarbone — a gateway for the dozens of rounds of chemotherapy, antibiotics and blood transfusions that have entered my body since I received a leukemia diagnosis at age 22.

headline: Review: ‘The Top of His Game,’ a W. C. Heinz Sportswriting Collection
text: W. C. Heinz performed so splendidly as a correspondent during World War II that upon reporting home, The New York Sun rewarded him with a long vacation, a handsome bonus and a new assignment. Heinz, 32, had proven overseas that he had an uncommon eye for human interest stories, so he was offered a promotion to the Washington bureau. It was a coveted position at which many of his colleagues would have jumped.

headline: The Toll of a Solitary Life
text: Do you like being alone? New research from Brigham Young University shows just how bad loneliness and social isolation, even for people who prefer their own company, can be for health.

headline: Don’t Flush That Wipe!
text: This is not a particularly savory topic, but the brave people who run modern sewer systems around the world face a growing menace: the “flushable” wet wipe.

headline: U.S. Announces Plan to Combat Illegal Fishing
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has announced a plan to crack down on the multibillion-dollar global black market in seafood, an effort that would try to trace a fish’s story from where it was caught to how it was shipped.

headline: National Guard Praises Record of 4 Who Died in Helicopter Crash
text: The four Louisiana National Guard members who died last week in a helicopter crash near the Gulf Coast had multiple deployments to war zones and a long record of responding to hurricanes, floods and oil spills, Guard commanders said Monday.

headline: Too Much Cardiac Testing
text: The electrocardiogram you got at your most recent physical may have been a waste of time and money.

headline: Review: Meghan Trainor Performs at Irving Plaza
text: There were about a dozen items of clothing for sale at Meghan Trainor’s concert Sunday night at Irving Plaza. T-shirts in loud colors and sweatshirts that trumpeted “All About That Bass,” after Ms. Trainor’s breakout hit, took up a large swath of the wall behind the merchandise table, as if they’d been eagerly wheatpasted. Nearby, the tour sponsor, HP, set up a photo booth encouraging fans to “Capture Your Meghan Moment.”

headline: Review: Charles Lloyd Returns to the Village Vanguard
text: Charles Lloyd seemed perfectly at home onstage at the Village Vanguard on Sunday night, working with standard equipment: his tenor saxophone, his quartet, his tunes. Awash in the dimensions of his sound in the room, it was almost possible to imagine that this was a regular visit, a piece of the usual bounty for jazz lovers in New York.

headline: The Gardner Masterpieces, Still Missing, But Visible Again Online
text: BOSTON – To mark a somber date, the 25th anniversary of the largest art theft in American history, the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum here, has created a “virtual tour” of the 13 items, including paintings by Rembrandt and Vermeer, that were stolen from the museum on March 18th, 1990.

headline: Hillary Clinton Criticizes Republicans for a ‘Trifecta Against Women’
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton scolded congressional Republicans on Monday for mounting a “trifecta against women” by delaying the nomination of Loretta E. Lynch for attorney general by tying it to stalled legislation on human trafficking.

headline: MoMA Lands Jasper Johns’s ‘Painted Bronze’
text: It’s a small work of art — precisely the size of an old Savarin coffee can jammed with artist’s paintbrushes — but in the history of postwar art and in the career of Jasper Johns, one of the most important artists of the last half century, it looms large.

headline: Dreams on Wheels, and Their Unsung Stylists
text: A look at the sketches of artists who worked at Ford, Chrysler and General Motors between 1946 and 1973.

headline: Schneiderman Issuing Ethics Plan Aimed at New York Legislators
text: ALBANY — Staking out a broad vision of ethics reform amid a swirl of other proposals in the capital, New York’s attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, called for an elimination of all outside jobs for state legislators and the end of a widely criticized system of per diem payments.

headline: New Albums From Sirens, Zaleski and Miller
text: SLEEPING WITH SIRENS

headline: What Patients Prefer to Know
text: If you had a serious illness, how much would you want to know about it?

headline: Music in Review: Performances by Sasha Cooke, Escher String Quartet and Ensemble Signal
text: ESCHER STRING QUARTET

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Readers respond to articles about science and health.

headline: Valeant’s Sweetened Bid for Salix May Have Delivered 2 Knockouts
text: The sweetened $11 billion bid by Valeant Pharmaceuticals for Salix Pharmaceuticals may have scored two knockouts. By coming up with an extra 9 percent over its previous offer, the acquisitive drug maker, now backed by the hedge fund executive William A. Ackman, quickly put an end to a rival bid from Endo International. But the extra cash required, and the debt already on its balance sheet, leave Valeant’s business model looking wobbly.

headline: Layoffs at Food Start-Up Hampton Creek
text: Hampton Creek, a high-profile food start-up that has attracted investors and talent from the technology industry, laid off nearly a fifth of its work force last month, just months after announcing it had raised $90 million in funding.

headline: Walkabout: St. Patrick’s Day Parades in Unexpected Places
text: Seeing Green Some say everyone is Irish on St. Patrick’s Day. Here, several places to watch a parade — including a couple you probably would never expect. (petergreenberg.com)

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Tuning Out Digital Buzz, for an Intimate Communion With Art
text: Once upon a time, our big museums were the “quiet cars” of a fast-track American culture industry. Like libraries, they were places where the volume was low, the energy slow, the technology unobtrusive. You came to them to look, to think and, in the days before museums became the prime social spaces they are now, to be alone in a small, like-minded crowd. You could take a little art home by hitting the postcard rack in the gift shop. But the only way you would retain most of what you saw was by spending time in the galleries and imprinting things on your brain.

headline: The Forgotten Man of Bauhaus, Almost
text: The Xanti Schawinsky show is the latest in a series of expositions to reassess the reputations of lesser-known members of the Bauhaus.

headline: In Miami Beach, the Faena Forum Is to Open in December
text: MIAMI — In the last few years, the Miami arts landscape has both rapidly expanded and been roiled with upheavals as the region tries to shore up a permanent cultural beachhead in a place better known until recently for an annual art fair and an actual beach. The next entry onto the scene, the Faena Forum, will be unusual in its format, design and leadership, and it won’t resemble anything else nearby when it is completed in December in a formerly sleepy section of Miami Beach.

headline: Paul Ha Raises the Cultural Profile at M.I.T.
text: CAMBRIDGE, MASS. — Shortly after Paul Ha became director of the List Visual Arts Center at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in late 2011, he was surprised to learn that Joan Jonas, the pioneering performance art and video artist, was a longtime faculty member at the university. He invited her to lunch to introduce himself and reveal his plan: to propose her as the artist representative for the United States at the 2015 Venice Biennale.

headline: Archive of Xanti Schawinsky, Bauhaus Artist, Is Exhibited in Zurich
text: How could an artist and designer as prolific, gifted and charismatic as Xanti Schawinsky — a central figure in mid-20th-century avant-garde circles in Europe and the United States — have come close to being forgotten?

headline: In ‘Magna Carta: Law, Liberty, Legacy,’ a Document Resonates
text: LONDON — When King John of England and a group of rebellious barons gathered in a marshy field just outside London in 1215, creating a foundation of modern democracy was not on their minds.

headline: Museums Seek to Lure, Then Lock In, Teenage Connoisseurs
text: Walking past Ghirlandaio’s “Old Man With a Young Boy” at the Louvre over Christmas break, I listened as my 18-year-old son, Ethan, explained how the artist was among the first to portray eye contact within a portrait; how Leonardo used the color blue to convey distance; how Raphael was a favorite of the Medicis. At the Musée d’Orsay, I watched as my 16-year-old daughter, Maya, dragged Ethan over to Manet’s “Le Déjeuner sur l’Herbe” — a painting they had both studied — and then debated its merits.

headline: Four Museums Plan Their Centennials
text: Four American museums, established after the first generation of major museums got their start in the 1870s, are observing their centennials this year and next: the Baltimore Museum of Art, incorporated in 1914 and celebrating its anniversary through early summer; the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, opened in 1915; the Memphis Brooks Museum of Art, which opened in 1916; and the Cleveland Museum of Art, which opened in 1916. And, not surprisingly, the centennial celebrations of the four museums look back at their history and the civic leaders who founded them, in many cases using 21st-century ways to engage local communities.

headline: A Document That Resonates Far and Wide
text: From original documents to curios, items from the British Library’s exhibition on Magna Carta.

headline: At Museum of Arts and Design, a Swan Song for Lowery Stokes Sims
text: Robin Cembalest, an arts consultant and former executive editor of ARTnews, used the Yiddish word “haimish” to describe Lowery Stokes Sims, the chief curator of the Museum of Arts and Design. Roughly translated, “haimish” means all the good qualities associated with home: informal, warm, approachable and comforting.

headline: A Sly Fusion of Creativity and History
text: Exhibits at the International Museum of the Reformation in Geneva include everything from talking table settings to 16th- and 17th-century sheet music for hymns.

headline: A Sampling of Art Exhibitions, From Coast to Coast
text: Leonardo da Vinci, meet Frida Kahlo. Spring 2015 shows at American museums showcase artists from around the world and through the centuries.

headline: Museums Showcase Attitudes and Beliefs as Well as Objects
text: Most museums are defined by the objects they display. A fine-arts museum exhibits paintings and sculptures. A history museum shows artifacts and documents. A science museum presents experiments.

headline: Reformation Museum in Geneva Blends Humor and Wonder
text: GENEVA — Finding the International Museum of the Reformation is almost as complicated as explaining the historical movement it chronicles.

headline: Spring Museum Exhibitions, From Masks to Renoirs
text: Here’s a sampling of promising exhibitions around the country this spring.

headline: Cedar Grove, Peabody Essex and Other Niche Museums Foray Into Contemporary Art
text: Cedar Grove, the Thomas Cole National Historic Site in Catskill, N.Y., is devoted to the life and art of that Hudson River School painter, who is known all over the world for his richly detailed landscapes.

headline: Met Founds Research Institute Centered on Lauder’s Cubist Gift
text: When the cosmetics magnate Leonard A. Lauder was trying to decide which museum should inherit his $1 billion collection of Cubist art, he asked those he was considering how they would keep the collection alive as a focus of intellectual inquiry and public interest. “We wanted to avoid the usual ‘donation, installation, catalog and then what?’ ” said Emily Braun, Mr. Lauder’s longtime curator.

headline: Children’s Museum of Pittsburgh Leads Movement to Acquire Tenants
text: Across the country, museums are playing landlord.

headline: A Fervid Experiment Recalled
text: Images of Robert Rauschenberg, Merce Cunningham, Josef Albers and others in their Black Mountain heyday.

headline: For Lower East Side, Chinese-Americans and Brontës, Museums of Their Own
text: Pushcart peddlers once filled Orchard Street. Early-20th-century Socialists gathered in Straus Square. The streets of the Lower East Side of Manhattan are indelibly stamped with the lives of the immigrants who made them their entry points to the United States. Walking these same streets today “can be the best classroom to the city’s history,” said Annie Polland, senior vice president for programs and education at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum.

headline: In the Spirit of Black Mountain College, an Avant-Garde Incubator
text: In the annals of 20th-century American art, few legends loom quite as large as that of Black Mountain College. Founded in 1933 by the classics scholar John Andrew Rice and the engineer Theodore Dreier, it was a progressive institution based in Black Mountain, a small North Carolina town that aimed to place art making at the heart of a liberal arts education. That same year, the Nazis forced the closing of another grand experiment, Germany’s Bauhaus school, prompting many of its teachers and students to decamp for the United States. Several landed at Black Mountain, most prominently Josef Albers, who was chosen to lead the art program, and his wife, Anni, who taught textile design and weaving.

headline: ‘American Dreaming’ Celebrates a Heady Era of Car Design
text: Rodell Smith started drawing cars in grade school in the early 1930s. More than 80 years later, at 92, he’s still drawing them on the days he feels up to it. Mr. Smith worked nearly 40 years as a professional automotive stylist at Ford and Chrysler, and along with thousands of other mostly unheralded artists and craftsmen, he helped define the look of American progress in an era fueled by 300-horsepower optimism.

headline: The Met and RISD Are Among Museums Redisplaying Antiquities
text: For years, the windows of the antiquities galleries at the RISD Museum, at the Rhode Island School of Design, were blocked out with color transparencies of ancient sites. The idea was to immerse visitors in the ambience of antiquity by shutting out external distractions.

headline: Museums Flex Their Multilingual, Multicultural Muscles
text: As the Americans who are at least 5 years old and speak a language other than English at home now exceed 20 percent of the population, museums across the country are responding with bilingual and non-English educational programs for all ages.

headline: How a Rising Dollar Is Creating Trouble for Emerging Economies
text: In India, it is a leading electric utility, Jaiprakash Power Ventures, selling off facilities and negotiating with lenders to avoid a default, having increasing its debts thirtyfold in six years.

headline: Rangers’ Martin St. Louis Is Expected to Miss 10 to 14 Days
text: The Rangers, who were already without goalie Henrik Lundqvist and defenseman Kevin Klein, said Monday that forward Martin St. Louis was expected to miss 10 to 14 days with a lower-body injury.

headline: Photos of the Day: India and Elsewhere
text: India and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: March 16, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Israel, Pakistan, Israel and Japan.

headline: How to Be Both
text: Vulgar and restrained, loud and retiring, straight-up and mysterious. On the undiminished charisma of Sarah Lucas, the former rude girl of British art.

headline: Crowning Preteen Beauty Queens
text: Ilana Panich-Linsman was forced to question her ideas about youth and beauty as she followed one contestant in the world of children’s beauty pageants.

headline: Uber’s Chief Financial Officer to Leave Company
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Brent Callinicos, the chief financial officer of Uber, plans to leave the ride-sharing company, in what will be one of the highest-level departures yet for the six-year-old start-up.

headline: Quirky $200 Million Art Venture Proves Just the Ticket for Tasmania
text: HOBART, Australia — For most of its existence, Tasmania was known as a faraway island at the bottom of Australia, a grim 19th-century redoubt where British colonial officers imprisoned convicts in the harshest of the empire’s jails and killed much of the aboriginal population.

headline: Review: In ‘Buyer & Cellar,’ a Visit to the Babs Cave
text: “Buyer & Cellar,” at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, starts off with a warning. Its lone performer announces that the “premise is preposterous.” The story is fictional, he tells us. “You know that, right?”

headline: Marine Veteran Requests Deportation From Iran
text: Increasingly desperate to return to the United States, a Marine veteran of Iranian descent who has been incarcerated in Iran for three and a half years has renounced his Iranian citizenship, requested deportation and accused Iran of using American prisoners as “bargaining chips,” his family said Monday.

headline: As Cosmos Head to Cuba, Fans May Be Unable to Follow
text: The New York Cosmos will play in Cuba in June, but it may prove difficult for their fans to join them on the trip.

headline: Brazil Official Charged in Petrobras Bribery Case
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Prosecutors on Monday filed new corruption charges arising out of the huge bribery scheme at Petrobras, the national oil company, against the treasurer of the ruling Workers Party — putting additional pressure on President Dilma Rousseff at a time when she is fighting calls for her ouster over the burgeoning scandal.

headline: Failed by Law and Courts, Troops Come Home to Repossessions
text: Charles Beard, a sergeant in the Army National Guard, says he was on duty in the Iraqi city of Tikrit when men came to his California home to repossess the family car. Unless his wife handed over the keys, she would go to jail, they said.

headline: Vanuatu: Cyclone Toll Rises
text: The cyclone that lashed the Pacific island nation of Vanuatu over the weekend killed at least 24 people, a United Nations office said, while on Tuesday relief workers said initial glimpses of the devastation on remoter islands indicated the death toll could rise, perhaps sharply. The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs said in a report issued Monday about Cyclone Pam that it had confirmed the 24 deaths across three parts of the islands: Tafea, Efate and Tanna. But that count did not include more isolated islands where fierce winds of 160 miles an hour and more leveled many homes.

headline: N.Y.U. Professor Is Barred by United Arab Emirates
text: The United Arab Emirates, where New York University opened a new campus last year, has barred an N.Y.U. professor from traveling to the monarchy after his criticism of the exploitation of migrant construction workers there.

headline: Egypt: Militants Claim Ambush
text: Militants identifying themselves as the Sinai Province of the Islamic State said  Monday that they had captured the engine of an American-made M60 tank from the Egyptian military in an ambush. A spokesman for the Egyptian armed forces said no engine had been taken. The militants, who went by the name Ansar Beit al-Maqdis before they pledged their loyalty last fall to the Islamic State, have killed hundreds of soldiers and policemen in a campaign against the military-backed government. President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi has declared an all-out war on the militants around their base in the North Sinai, but has nonetheless struggled to end their attacks. The militants posted six pictures on Twitter of what appeared to be the engine, describing it as “spoils” of an ambush on “the apostate army.”

headline: Malcolm Brogdon, Virginia Star, Is Pursuing Master’s Ahead of N.B.A.
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Amid the academic scandals at Syracuse, North Carolina and elsewhere around the N.C.A.A., maybe it just seems unusual these days to find athletes who also happen to be high-achieving students. But consider Malcolm Brogdon, the redshirt junior guard who helped lead Virginia to the Atlantic Coast Conference regular-season title and a top-five ranking for much of this season — all while he was working on a master’s degree in public policy.

headline: New Jersey Senate Upholds Christie’s Veto of Port Authority Curbs
text: The New Jersey Senate failed in its effort on Monday to override Gov. Chris Christie’s veto of legislation aimed at curbing patronage and political interference at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in the wake of the George Washington Bridge lane closing scandal.

headline: G.M. Will Face Further Discovery in Broader Class-Action Case
text: DETROIT — While General Motors has settled one potentially explosive lawsuit related to defective ignition switches, the company still faces the possibility of depositions of its employees in a broader class-action case.

headline: German Media Want Greek Finance Minister’s Head Over ‘Fingergate’
text: Speaking to a small group of Croatian radicals in 2013, an obscure Greek economist suggested that Greece should have simply defaulted on its debts in 2010 and told the German government to deal with the consequences. For emphasis, he used a crude expression and extended his middle finger, in an ancient gesture considered obscene even in the days of Diogenes.

headline: Blackstone Group Purchases Landmark Willis Tower in Chicago
text: Jonathan D. Gray grew up in the Chicago suburb of Highland Park, just a 40-minute drive from the Sears Tower, one of the most recognizable office buildings in the world.

headline: SXSW 2015: A Look at ‘Raiders!’
text: Some fedoras were spotted, but no snakes were present at the premiere of “Raiders!” at SXSW on Saturday at an Alamo Drafthouse theater in Austin. The documentary tracks the enduring artistic commitment of Chris Strompolos and Eric Zala, two friends who spent their adolescent summer vacations creating a shot-for-shot remake of Steven Spielberg’s 1981 thriller, “Raiders of the Lost Ark.” Now in their 40s, the men reunited in June to shoot the one scene they never completed: the airplane fight sequence that pits Indiana Jones against a brutish mechanic near the blades of a moving airplane. (A camel and a few complicated explosions are also involved.)

headline: Curtis Gans, 77, Is Dead; Worked to Defeat President Johnson
text: Curtis Gans, who helped organize a quixotic crusade to depose President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1968 and transformed the movement’s improbable electoral success into what became a lifelong object lesson in the virtues of voting, died on Sunday in Frederick, Md. He was 77.

headline: Data on Health Law Shows Largest Drop in Uninsured in 4 Decades, the U.S. Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said on Monday that 16.4 million uninsured people had gained health coverage since major provisions of the Affordable Care Act began to take effect in 2010, driving the largest reduction in the number of uninsured in about 40 years.

headline: Adidas to Exit the N.B.A., Opening the Door to Rivals
text: Adidas said Monday that it will not bid for a new contract with the N.B.A. when its deal expires in 2017, letting slip a high-profile partnership that has allowed it to outfit some of the country’s top athletes.

headline: Tour Bus Companies Agree to Settle Antitrust Lawsuit
text: Two of New York City’s biggest tour bus operators have agreed to pay $7.5 million and give up nearly 50 of their stops in Manhattan to settle an antitrust lawsuit brought by state and federal officials.

headline: Pointing Fingers in Apple Pay Fraud
text: When Apple was planning its Apple Pay electronic payment system last summer for its iPhones, the nation’s banks raced to be included among the first credit card issuers associated with the new technology.

headline: Iranian Officials Ask Kerry About Republicans’ Letter
text: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — Iranian officials questioned Secretary of State John Kerry about a letter that Tom Cotton of Arkansas and 46 other Republican senators issued last week arguing that a potential nuclear accord would not be binding unless it was approved by Congress.

headline: Daevid Allen, Guitarist and Singer in Progressive Rock, Dies at 77
text: Daevid Allen, an eccentric Australian-born guitarist, singer and poet who was an original member of the psychedelic rock group the Soft Machine and went on to found Gong, an aggressively avant-garde band whose influence far exceeded its relatively modest success, died on Friday in Australia. He was 77.

headline: Mexican Journalist Is Fired After Report About First Lady
text: MEXICO CITY — One of Mexico’s best-known journalists, who exposed a possible conflict of interest involving the first lady’s purchase of a house from a government contractor, was fired on Sunday in a dispute that defenders see as an act of retaliation and an attack on press freedom.

headline: Sharing Files via Dropbox With People Who Don’t Have an Account
text: Q. I am having trouble trying to figure out how to send tax files to my parents on Dropbox, but since they are not Dropbox users, I don’t know how to share my files with them. How can I do this?

headline: Radio Broadcasters Seek Changes in Disclosure Rules for Paid Programming
text: A group of radio broadcasters has asked for changes to federal rules about how stations disclose paid programming, raising fresh concerns about one of the music industry’s most enduring scandals — payola.

headline: Capturing 46th Title, Hannah Kearney Ends Her Moguls Career on Top
text: Five years after Hannah Kearney won an Olympic gold medal in moguls skiing, her dream came true: She closed out her international career with a victory in Sunday’s dual moguls event at the F.I.S. Freestyle World Cup finals in Megève, France.

headline: Michelle Obama Going to Asia to Push Education
text: WASHINGTON — Michelle Obama will travel to Japan and Cambodia this week to kick off the administration’s new effort to promote the education of millions of girls worldwide.

headline: New York Police Begin Using ShotSpotter System to Detect Gunshots
text: The New York Police Department has started using a detection system that pinpoints the location of gunfire and sends the information to law enforcement, the latest move to modernize the nation’s largest police force, the department announced on Monday.

headline: Intersection | Harajuku Style in Tokyo
text: Mademoiselle Yulia, a fashion designer and style icon with dyed blue hair, is very inspired by the stylish and colorful Harajuku neighborhood of Tokyo.

headline: Remarks on Family by Dolce and Gabbana Bring Swell of Criticism
text: What began as a brush fire over the weekend for the fashion designers behind the Dolce & Gabbana label spread quickly across the Internet.

headline: House Republican Budget Overhauls Medicare and Repeals the Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans on Tuesday will unveil a proposed budget for 2016 that partly privatizes Medicare, turns Medicaid into block grants to the states, repeals the Affordable Care Act and reaches balance in 10 years, challenging Republicans in Congress to make good on their promises to deeply cut federal spending.

headline: Irresistible TV, but Durst Film Tests Ethics, Too
text: It was the sort of publicity you cannot buy. The day before HBO broadcast the final episode of the six-part documentary series “The Jinx,” the subject of the film, Robert A. Durst, was arrested on a murder charge.

headline: Utah’s Season Is So Sweet, Even the Lockers Smell Nice
text: LAS VEGAS — The locker room was empty except for the Utah men’s basketball coach, Larry Krystkowiak, who reached into his bag and pulled out what appeared to be a short section of braided rope. It was black on one end.

headline: Police Recall Dodging as Marathon Bombing Suspect Ran Over Brother
text: BOSTON — One of the most shocking details to emerge from the night of mayhem two years ago when the Boston Marathon bombers engaged in a shootout with the police in suburban Watertown was that Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was fleeing the scene, drove over his brother, Tamerlan.

headline: Pinterest Valuation at $11 Billion After New Round of Fund-Raising
text: Less than a year after being valued at $5 billion, Pinterest has joined the 11-digit valuation start-up club.

headline: State Senate Works to Block Christie From Settling Pollution Lawsuit Against Exxon
text: The New Jersey Senate approved two measures on Monday contesting Gov. Chris Christie’s attempt to settle a pollution lawsuit against Exxon Mobil Corporation for a fraction of the damages that the state had originally sought.

headline: Obama on Republican Education Budget
text: While meeting with the Council of the Great City Schools leadership, the president said that there would be a “major debate” if the Republican budget lowered federal spending on education.

headline: Obama Plans to Use Week to Press Economic Case
text: WASHINGTON — With Congress pushing to complete a budget plan this week that reflects the cost-cutting priorities of the new Republican majority, President Obama plans to devote much of his week to laying out an alternative approach that would increase spending on domestic programs such as education and health care.

headline: United Nations Workers Accused of Sexual Abuse
text: UNITED NATIONS — United Nations personnel were accused in nearly 80 cases of rape, sexual assault and sex trafficking in 2014 alone, with the bulk of the cases involving peacekeepers deployed to some of the most troubled parts of the world.

headline: Trial Opens in Deaths of 2 French Teenagers Fleeing the Police in 2005
text: PARIS — A decade ago, two teenagers were electrocuted when they hid in a transformer at an electrical substation while running from the police. Their deaths set off a wave of unrest that plunged the French suburbs into chaos.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 16, 2015
text: March 16, 2015

headline: Women’s N.C.A.A. Bracket
text: Women’s N.C.A.A. bracket.

headline: Iran Sent Arms to Iraq to Fight ISIS, U.S. Says
text: WASHINGTON — Iran has deployed advanced rockets and missiles to Iraq to help fight the Islamic State in Tikrit, a significant escalation of firepower and another sign of Iran’s growing influence in Iraq.

headline: Connecticut Occupies Usual Perch
text: It has been 20 years since Rebecca Lobo led Connecticut to the undefeated season that started it all for Coach Geno Auriemma and the Huskies. On Saturday, UConn will begin its quest for a 10th title over that span.

headline: Review: ‘Placebo,’ With Carrie Coon, Opens at Playwrights Horizons
text: Pliny the Elder — naturalist, philosopher, warrior and all-around sage of the early Roman Empire — plays an unlikely role in “Placebo,” the new play by Melissa James Gibson that opened on Monday at Playwrights Horizons.

headline: Some Tests
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — It’s always interesting to hear what inspires people to create. When it comes to crossword puzzles, almost anything can trigger the “Oooo! That would make a spiffy puzzle theme!” brain response.

headline: Hillary Clinton at Irish American Event
text: Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke at her induction into the Irish America Hall of Fame, recalling an early decision of her husband’s in the Northern Ireland peace process.

headline: In Accepting Irish-American Honor, Hillary Clinton Recasts Her Role in a Peace Pact
text: The subjects of Ireland and tea made for an unpleasant brew in Hillary Rodham Clinton’s 2008 campaign for president. Her primary opponent, Barack Obama, once belittled her as having merely “had tea with” world leaders as first lady. Her husband defended her as “a peacemaker, not a tea maker.” Then she was accused of overstating her own contribution to the Northern Ireland peace process.

headline: For Pawn in Disputed Transfer, a Winning Move
text: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J. — On her way to helping Seton Hall earn its first berth in the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament in two decades, Daisha Simmons had to make a few stops. Literally.

headline: Moved by Mountains and the Sea in Indonesia
text: A short visit with a friend led Rony Zakaria to spend years exploring how faith shapes the relationship between people and nature in Indonesia.

headline: Bad Luck or Bad Practices? It’s Tough for Mets to Tell
text: So extensive is the growing list of Mets pitchers who have needed Tommy John surgery in recent years that even their general manager had difficulty recalling all of them on Monday.

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Recap: Every Single Penny
text: Season 1, Episode 7: “Bingo”

headline: Candidates for Mayor Face Off in Chicago
text: CHICAGO — Sparring over pensions, red-light cameras, public education and gang violence, the mayoral candidates Rahm Emanuel and Jesus G. Garcia confronted each other in their first one-on-one debate on Monday, three weeks before the runoff election.

headline: The Case for Kentucky as College Basketball’s Greatest Defensive Team
text: Kentucky’s dominant defense could be the best in N.C.A.A. history.

headline: With Hustle and Grit, Manhattan’s RaShawn Stores Inspires by Defying the Odds
text: RaShawn Stores often prayed alone. At other times, he prayed with family members. They all sought guidance, unsure how to respond when a dream collided with harsh financial reality.

headline: A Laid-Back Alternative to Miami Hot Spots
text: A quietly quirky restaurant opens off of the beach’s most boisterous strip.

headline: Ad-Rock and Num Pang Share a Recipe for Their New, Charitable Banh Mi
text: Food, hip-hop and ’90s street style converge at the well-traversed, brightly colored graffiti-tagged sandwich empire Num Pang (established in 2009, the name is Cambodian for bread). This spring, the restaurant’s co-chefs and owners, Ben Daitz and Ratha Chaupoly, teamed up with the New York native Adam Horovitz (“Ad-Rock”) of the Beastie Boys to re-engineer pastrami on rye, a sandwich as iconic in New York as the boys behind it. Their creation, a limited-edition banh mi, is on menus at Num Pang’s six locations today.

headline: Behind Sam Shahid’s Closed Doors
text: Bombarded by imagery all day at work, the renowned advertising provocateur comes home to, well, very little.

headline: Design With a Bit of Drama
text: The British furniture and lighting designer Lee Broom is known both for his clever, often nostalgic creations and the elaborate ways he displays them: In 2012, during the Milan Furniture Fair, he showed inside an old pub that he bought in London, disassembled and rebuilt in Milan. This year, he’ll return to the prestigious event with a unique take on the department store — Memphis-style chairs and fragmented mirrors in the “gents’ fitting room,” fluted tables that furnish the “bookstore” and tubular fluorescent lamps with cut crystal that illuminate the “perfumery.” “I always try to do something theatrical,” he says. “And once I learned that the department store was an English invention, I knew I had the right idea.”

headline: Obama Wades Into Marijuana Debate in Vice Interview
text: President Obama has a number of speaking styles in his repertoire, from soaring oratory to serious policy wonkishness, withering sarcasm and cocky defensiveness. For an interview with Vice News released Monday, he went with optimistic paternalism.

headline: Word of the Day | regicide
text: regicide • \ˈre-jə-ˌsid\ • noun

headline: EBay Set to Open New Section on Its Site for Sotheby’s Auctions
text: EBay, the giant online auction site, sells millions of items to customers all over the world every single day. It wants to sell a whole lot more.

headline: Louise Erdrich Wins Library of Congress Award
text: Louise Erdrich, author of the novels “Love Medicine” and “The Round House,” will receive the Library of Congress Prize for American Fiction this year.

headline: Soccer Sites Set for Rio
text: Matches for the soccer tournament at the 2016 Rio Olympics will be held in six Brazilian cities. The most surprising inclusion was that of Arena Amazônia in Manaus, more than 1,800 miles from the main Olympic park.

headline: Tax Cuts Still Don’t Pay for Themselves
text: Last week, I wrote about the new tax plan from Senator Marco Rubio and Senator Mike Lee as the “Puppies and Rainbows Tax Plan,” because it’s a plan that includes something for everyone. It calls for big tax credits for middle-income families with children, corporate tax cuts and complete elimination of the capital gains tax — and as a result would cost trillions of dollars in revenue over a decade.

headline: Playing Where the Money Is
text: Diana Taurasi, one of the top players in women’s basketball, is not returning to the W.N.B.A. this season, honoring the wishes of her better-paying Russian team.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
text: 9 P.M. (CW) IZOMBIE Olivia Moore (Rose McIver), a formerly driven medical student, becomes depressed and slovenly when she is turned into a zombie. She must now subsist on human brains, culled from the bodies in the morgue where she works, which give her flashes of the memories they contain. She uses them to aid a homicide detective (Malcolm Goodwin) in solving murders in this new series, which counts Rob Thomas and Diane Ruggiero-Wright of “Veronica Mars” fame among its executive producers. Writing in The New York Times, Neil Genzlinger called the show “ridiculously likable.”

headline: Vanuatu Death Toll Is Likely to Rise as Glimpses of Cyclone’s Fury Emerge
text: HONG KONG — Initial glimpses of remote parts of the Pacific island nation of Vanuatu, which was lashed by a cyclone over the weekend, indicated widespread devastation, relief workers said Tuesday.

headline: Corrections: March 17, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “Have you all seen the broken, paralyzed president, who has been kidnapped by generals? He’s only just flown in from Switzerland, where he attended a birth, as you know.”

text: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. headline: Crowning Preteen Beauty Queens
text: From Palestinian refugee camps to Brooklyn pizzerias, Ilana Panich-Linsman has documented the lives of teenage girls, finding a common ground from her own youth in western Massachusetts, where she often felt alone and confused.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Commissioner Bratton, on Police Trends
The Loretta Lynch Confirmation Mess
text: What does the abortion issue have to do with the prevention of human trafficking? Nothing.

headline: Gen. Petraeus’s Light Punishment
text: Granted, Americans love a comeback story.

headline: The Hidden Talent of Steve Jobs
text: The relationship between journalists and Steve Jobs could often be fraught, but there were always a handful of reporters he liked and trusted. They included John Markoff of The New York Times; Steven Levy, formerly of Wired magazine (he’s now at Medium); Walt Mossberg, the longtime technology columnist for The Wall Street Journal (he’s now at Re/code); and Brent Schlender of Fortune. They had all been on the technology beat seemingly forever, and they had known Jobs for decades.

headline: Could Obama Bypass the Supreme Court?
text: CHICAGO — IT is time to talk about President Obama’s contingency plan for health care. The Supreme Court heard oral arguments earlier this month in King v. Burwell, a case challenging the provision of tax credits on federal insurance exchanges. While the legal issues are dry lawyers’ fare — how to interpret several interconnected phrases of the Affordable Care Act — the practical stakes are high. The government estimates that millions of Americans will be left without affordable health insurance if it loses.

headline: Skills in Flux
text: Several years ago, Doug Lemov began studying videos of excellent teachers. He focused not on their big strategies but on their microgestures: How long they waited before calling on students to answer a question (to give the less confident students time to get their hands up); when they paced about the classroom and when they stood still (while issuing instructions, to emphasize the importance of what’s being said); how they moved around the room toward a student whose mind might be wandering.

headline: Venture Capital’s Boys’ Club on Trial
text: Venture capitalists are widely considered to be men — and they are almost all men — who can see the future. But there is at least one thing they have not been able to see clearly or willing to do anything about for a long time: A terrible record of hiring and promoting women.

headline: ‘A Conversation With My Black Son’
text: For generations, parents of black boys across the United States have rehearsed, dreaded and postponed “The Conversation.” But when their boys become teenagers, parents must choose whether or not to expose their sons to what it means to be a black man here. To keep him safe, they may have to tell the child they love that he risks being targeted by the police, simply because of the color of his skin. How should parents impart this information, while maintaining their child’s pride and sense of self? How does one teach a child to face dangerous racism and ask him to emerge unscathed?

headline: A Conversation With My Black Son
text: In this short documentary, parents reveal their struggles with telling their black sons that they may be targets of racial profiling by the police.

headline: Test Yourself | A Basketball Team Helped by Math
text: Here are several paragraphs from a March 14 article, “Davidson Math Students Lend a Hand to Basketball Team.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Kendrick Lamar on His New Album and the Weight of Clarity
text: In “Kendrick Lamar on His New Album and the Weight of Clarity,” Joe Coscarelli writes about Mr. Lamar’s new album.

headline: How Do You Solve a Problem Like Ben Carson?
text: Late in February, Dr. Ben Carson, the celebrated pediatric neurosurgeon turned political insurrectionist, was trying to check off another box on his presidential-campaign to-do list: hiring a press secretary. The lead prospect, a public-relations specialist named Deana Bass, had come to meet him at the dimly lit Capitol Hill office of Carson’s confidant and business manager, Armstrong Williams. Carson sat back and scrutinized her from behind a small granite table, as life-size cardboard cutouts of more conventional politicians — President Obama, with a tight smile, and Senator John McCain, glowering — loomed behind each of his shoulders. (The mock $3 bill someone had left on a table in Williams’s waiting room undercut any notion that this was a bipartisan zone; it featured Obama wearing a turban.)

headline: Are Manners Important?
text: Put your napkin on your lap. Keep your elbows off the table. Chew with your mouth closed. Society imparts all sorts of manners for us to follow at the dinner table, and elsewhere.

headline: Labels, Digital Included, Assume New Importance at Museums
text: Like a primatologist observing gorillas in the wild, Judy Rand sometimes prowls around museums to spy on visitors. Ms. Rand, a museum consultant in Seattle and an acclaimed writer of exhibit labels, loves spotting guests reading her work aloud.

headline: Diana Taurasi Focusing on Playing in Russia, Where the Money Is
text: YEKATERINBURG, Russia — The noise inside the arena is deafening. Thousands of Russians in off-brand tracksuits and snow pants are shouting and beating inflatable foil batons together as Diana Taurasi, perhaps the greatest women’s basketball player in the world, dribbles across the court.

headline: For the Walker Art Center, a Shop That Peddles Evanescence
text: Visitors to the gift shop at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis will soon be able to buy something a little more esoteric, alongside their Chuck Close posters and Pantone mugs. “On Mother’s Day,” the promotion might go, “how about a new ringtone calibrated by the composer Nico Muhly, just for stressful family calls?”

headline: Museums Turn to Technology to Boost Attendance by Millennials
text: If museums face an uncertain future, you wouldn’t know it from “Henri Matisse: The Cutouts,” which recently drew 664,000 to the Museum of Modern Art. The show was so thronged that MoMA kept its doors open round-the-clock on the closing weekend last month.

headline: A More Public Option for Investigating Shootings by Police Officers
text: MISSOULA, Mont. — In most places, the actions of the police officer who fatally shot Kaileb Williams, 20, would have been judged in secret, by an anonymous grand jury weighing criminal charges behind closed doors.

headline: Streetcar Revival Is Wavering in Some Cities
text: WASHINGTON — First, suburban Arlington, Va., abandoned long-laid plans last fall to build a streetcar line its leaders hoped would help revitalize a neglected corridor.

headline: Afghan Militia Leaders, Empowered by U.S. to Fight Taliban, Inspire Fear in Villages
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Rahimullah used to be a farmer — just a “normal person living an ordinary life,” as he put it. Then he formed his own militia last year and found himself swept up in America’s exit strategy from Afghanistan.

headline: Sex-Trafficking Bill, Ensnared by Politics, Is Left in Limbo by a Senate Vote
text: WASHINGTON — Congress headed into another major legislative standoff Tuesday when a measure to create a fund for victims of sexual trafficking failed to clear a procedural hurdle, leaving in peril a bill that once had the support of a majority of lawmakers.

headline: ‘Culture Crash,’ by Scott Timberg
text: In 2010, the Louisville Orchestra filed for Chapter 11 protection. Reader comments generated by a newspaper article on this development, Scott Timberg writes in “Culture Crash,” “gave a sense of the way many people think about culture and the market.” Timberg reproduces some of the comments “in all their typo-filled glory.” “Pack up your fiddles and go home boys and girls,” one reader advised. “Maybe find real jobs. Go to Nashville and vie for some sessions work.” Another commenter opined: “Sale all of assets to pay these people off, fire them all and get rid of the Orchestra. It isn’t popular with the residents or they would have packed crowds and not have to worry about $$$.”

headline: I.P.O. Could Value Refresco Gerber at Up to $1.36 Billion
text: LONDON — Refresco Gerber, one of Europe’s largest bottlers of soft drinks and fruit juices, said on Tuesday that the expected price range for its initial public offering could value the company at up to 1.29 billion euros, or about $1.36 billion.

headline: Myanmar Sentences 3 to Prison for Depicting Buddha Wearing Headphones
text: YANGON, Myanmar — A bar manager from New Zealand and two Burmese men were sentenced to two years in prison in Myanmar on Tuesday for posting an image online of the Buddha wearing headphones, an effort to promote an event.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: (Want to get the Morning Briefing in your inbox first thing? Sign up.)

headline: Exploring Indianapolis, for the Final Four and Beyond
text: The brackets are filled in, and the betting pools are rich. It must be mid-March.

headline: The Virtues of Microadventures
text: Alastair Humphreys adventure-hopped for a decade, starting with a four-year round-the-world bicycle trip after college. From there, the British author, blogger and motivational speaker traversed southern India, rowed across the Atlantic Ocean and trekked 1,000 miles across the Arabian Peninsula’s Empty Quarter.

headline: Hotels for the Next Generation
text: Longing for alternatives to the conventional, cookie-cutter hotel? Along with crocuses and daffodils, new specialty chains from major hospitality companies including Marriott, Hilton, Hyatt and Carlson Rezidor will be springing up across the globe in the coming weeks and months.

headline: In Geneva, Art Thrives Where Watches Were Made
text: When the strikingly redesigned Musée d’Ethnographie de Genève (Geneva Museum of Ethnography) reopened in October 2014, the Quartier des Bains, the neighborhood that’s become Geneva’s own little SoHo, got a defining new landmark. Bound by the Rhone and Arve rivers in the southern part of the city, this unexpectedly hip gallery- and museum-studded neighborhood in a town best known for banks, international institutions like the Red Cross and luxury watches has emerged as one of the liveliest and most innovative contemporary art districts in Europe.

headline: IBM Introduces Twitter-Fueled Data Services for Business
text: When IBM announced its partnership with Twitter last October, the move seemed both promising and logical.

headline: Israel Elections: Results and Analysis
text: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and his chief challenger, Isaac Herzog of the center-left Zionist Union, appeared to win about the same number of parliamentary seats in the Israeli election on Tuesday.

headline: Jeb Bush Emails Reveal Foresight on Disclosures

headline: New York Today: St. Patrick’s Day Parade (and Protests)
text: Top of the morning to you on this St. Patrick’s Day.

headline: Daily Report: Apple Pay and Banks Tussle Over Fraud
text: When Apple was planning its Apple Pay electronic payment system last summer for its iPhones, the nation’s banks raced to be included among the first credit card issuers associated with the new technology, writes Andrew Ross Sorkin.

headline: Private Equity Firm Permira Sells Last of Its Hugo Boss Stake
text: LONDON — The private equity firm Permira has sold its remaining stake in Hugo Boss after steadily reducing its holdings in the German fashion brand in recent years in anticipation of an eventual exit.

headline: Japan’s Central Bank Warns of Temporary Return to Deflation
text: TOKYO — Over the last two years, the Japanese central bank governor, Haruhiko Kuroda, has accomplished what a string of more cautious predecessors failed to do: reverse a prolonged and damaging slide in the price of goods and services in Japan.

headline: Detention of Rights Activists in China Soared in 2014, Report Says
text: The Chinese authorities last year detained more people advocating greater civic rights than at any time since at least the mid-1990s, a United States-based organization said in a new report.

headline: A Sucker Is Optimized Every Minute
text: Not long ago, our blockbuster business books spoke in unison: Trust your gut. The secret to decision-making lay outside our intellects, across the aisle in our loopy right brains, with their emo melodramas and surges of intuition. Linear thinking was suddenly the royal road to ruin. Dan Ariely’s “Predictably Irrational” tracked the extravagant illogic of our best judgment calls. The “Freakonomics” authors urged us to think like nut jobs. In “Blink,” Malcolm Gladwell counseled abandoning scientific method in favor of snap judgments. Tedious hours of research, conducted by artless cubicle drones, became the province of companies courting Chapter 11. To the artsy dropouts who could barely grasp a polynomial would go the spoils of the serial bull markets.

headline: The Lost Glove Waves Farewell to Winter
text: Perched on the cusp of spring, we watch the soot-gray snowbanks melt and feel the deep-winter blues flow down the storm drain. In the gutter we see a soggy record of the season left behind: fossil layers of litter, unfrozen unscooped poop and, quite touching, long-lost gloves waving their final goodbyes.

headline: Object Lesson
text: In November 2013, thousands of people gathered in Maidan Nezalezhnosti, the central square in Kiev, to protest their government’s refusal to ratify an agreement with the European Union. The demonstrations went on for months; when brutal attempts were made to stop them, they only became more popular. The crowds were enormous, containing, at times, more than 100,000 people. Many of the photographs from the protests had the organized disorder of medieval battle scenes: spiky barricades, rows of tents, patches of soil and ash, flashes of color where flags were held aloft, sudden brightness from reflections and fires, a great swirl of angry humanity and dark-helmeted riot police massed behind shields, all of it set against backdrops of smoke, fog or falling snow. So epic and cinematic were the photographs from the Maidan that it took some effort to remember that they were first and foremost news images, unstaged depictions of real, ongoing human suffering.

headline: A Blurred Line in Copyright Law
text: Does the law need to be updated to reflect changes in modern music?

headline: Today in Politics: As Hillary Clinton Tests the Waters, Who Pays?
