headline: Morning Agenda: Blame Game in Apple Pay Fraud
text: BLAME GAME IN APPLE PAY FRAUD | When Apple was planning its Apple Pay electronic payment system last summer for its iPhones, the nation’s banks rushed to be included. Now, some of the banks “are privately complaining that Apple Pay may not be so great after all,” Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. “But the banks may largely have themselves to blame,” he adds. “A raft of headlines over the last week about unusually high fraud rates from thieves using stolen credit numbers on Apple Pay has exposed what many of the banks privately acknowledge they have been trying to fix for months.”

headline: Chinese Developer Evergrande Gets $16 Billion Lifeline Amid Slump
text: HONG KONG — Chinese banks have extended $16 billion in credit lines to shore up one of the country’s largest and most heavily indebted home builders, as pressure mounts on developers short of cash in a slumping property market.

text: SEOUL, South Korea — Tension between Seoul and Beijing over Washington’s desire to deploy a ballistic missile defense system in South Korea intensified on Tuesday as South Korea made an unusual public retort to China, asking it not to meddle in its defense policy.

Oliver Reid, with Lawrence Yurman on piano, singing the jazz standard “Sophisticated Lady,” a number Mr. Reid performs in his cabaret show “Drop Me Off in Harlem.” The song was composed as an instrumental piece by Duke Ellington, who introduced it on record in 1933; the lyricist Mitchell Parish later added the words.

headline: Patrik Ervell’s Campaign With No Clothes
text: The men’s wear designer Patrik Ervell’s latest ads will feature only the work of the late photographer Peter Hujar. The earliest of the never-before-seen photos — a mix of black-and-white portraits and still lifes — were shot in 1981, the year after Ervell was born. “His images are timeless,” says Ervell of Hujar, who, like his controversy-courting peer Robert Mapplethorpe, captured iconic pictures of downtown fixtures such as Susan Sontag and Candy Darling. “They could have been taken for me last week.”

But that did not diminish the enthusiasm of one group that proudly marched up Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, spangled with green sashes, to make history in the emerald tide: It was the first, and only, gay organization allowed in the parade.

headline: Left and Right, Family and Economics
text: My Sunday column weighed in on the latest (and presently very intra-Timesian) version of the neverending “does culture or economics explain family breakdown?” debate. Responding, in part, to the critics of my colleague David Brooks’s earlier column on morals and the social fabric, I made the case that there just hasn’t been the kind of significant increase in privation (or the kind of cuts to welfare programs; quite the reverse) that some writers on the left invoke as an explanation for why today’s poor and working class Americans are so much less likely than in prior eras to have children within wedlock and stay married when they do. Instead, notwithstanding all the burdens they bear and challenges they face, downscale Americans have somewhat more income and a much stronger safety net than their grandparents and great-grandparents did. So as much as economic burdens clearly play a role in family instability, and would be plausible explanations for the existence of a persistent rich-poor family-structure gap, they seem like weaker explanations for why out-of-wedlock birth rates have gone up so rapidly over the last half-century, not only among the underclass but increasingly in Middle America as well.

headline: As California Drought Enters 4th Year, Conservation Efforts and Worries Increase
text: LOS ANGELES — The rainy season drove into California in December with wet and windy promise: soaking rain, snow, dark gray skies and a flash of hope that the drought that has scorched this region had run its course. And then came January — with record high temperatures and record low rainfall.

headline: Joel McHale on the Latest Revival of ‘Community’ and Being O.K.  With ‘Reference Humor’
text: Apologies to Tina Fey and Robert Carlock, but evidence suggests that “Community” is actually the most unbreakable comedy on television, even though it’s technically not on “television” anymore. The show’s new season debuted on Tuesday at Yahoo’s video site, Yahoo Screen.

headline: Israel’s Election: The Rare Actual Tossup
text: Pundits love to refer to elections as tossups, but most are not. By the time Election Day arrives, one candidate tends to be a strong favorite, even when the polls are fairly close. But today’s election in Israel is the rare exception: It’s close to a true tossup.

headline: Jeb Bush, 20 Years After Conversion, Is Guided by His Catholic Faith
text: CORAL GABLES, Fla. — He arrived a few minutes early — no entourage, just his wife and daughter — and, sweating through a polo shirt in the hot morning sun, settled quietly into the 14th row at the Church of the Little Flower.

headline: 1890: Strike Takes Riotous Turn
text: LIVERPOOL — The most critical stage in the history of the great dock strike was reached to-day [March 17], when the refusal of a large proportion of the carters to cease work in order to strengthen the hands of the dock laborers culminated in an alarming riot. The disturbance began by those teams-men who had ceased work in defiance of the grace remonstrance by the treasurer of the Union, falling upon those in charge of the horses, knocking them about, and tearing bales of cotton off their carts. A large body of police was hurriedly marched to the scene, and after much trouble the rioters were dispersed. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 18, 1890

headline: Grimm Associate Is Sentenced to 3 Months in Prison
text: An associate of former Representative Michael G. Grimm received a surprisingly harsh sentence on Tuesday for violating campaign finance law, a signal that Mr. Grimm may face tough consequences when he is sentenced later this year for tax fraud.

headline: If Only G.E. Had an Activist Investor Who Cared
text: Almost nothing General Electric does registers with its stockholders. A big asset sale? Shares hardly budge. A multibillion-dollar acquisition? Yawn. Aggressive shrinkage of its irritating financial business? Crickets. It seems investors no longer care about the company, a $254 billion conglomerate run by Jeffrey R. Immelt. If only G.E. had an activist who cared.

headline: Intriguing Sketches Reveal the Depths of Geoff McFetridge’s Quirky, Beautiful Mind
text: The artist, who illustrated visuals for Spike Jonze’s “Her” and has created everything from Nike sneakers to a stop-motion music video filled with toast, shares 30 drawings in a new zine.

text: Hillary Rodham Clinton might be hoping to turn the page on her email controversy, but Republicans are doing their best to keep the story in the spotlight.

headline: Deep Wounds and Lingering Questions After Israel’s Bitter Race

headline: Review: In ‘Remote New York,’ an Unseen Tour Guide Calls the Shots
text: I am but a member of the horde, a cipher among countless ciphers. We swarm through the city’s streets and subways, moving together like parts in a machine. We are replaceable, we are erasable, we are disposable. Soon no one will know we existed.

headline: Last-Ranked Bhutan Stuns Sri Lanka a Second Time
text: THIMPHU, Bhutan — Inside a monastery high up in the hills that surround Bhutan’s capital city, the players on the country’s national soccer team were consulting the dice.

headline: This Time, Robert Durst Faces a Murder Charge in the Capital of Celebrity Trials
text: The dead man lay on the floor, the defendant testified, killed accidentally as the two struggled over a loaded gun. What to do next came to him in a haze of drugs and Jack Daniel’s: He carved up the body until he was “swimming in blood,” he testified, wrapped the parts in garbage bags and dumped them in Galveston Bay.

text: For years, Nintendo had insisted that it would not take its beloved cast of video game characters, including Mario and Zelda, to the smartphones and tablets that tens of millions of people now use to play games.

headline: Video Review: Volvo V60 Cross Country, Good for the Long Haul
text: ARE luxury automotive brands banned from using comprehensible names? It would explain the baffling alphanumeric monikers that Acura, Audi, BMW, Infiniti, Lexus and Mercedes use. Volvo forks off this trail with the newest V60 variant by adding two actual words: Cross Country.

headline: For St. Patrick’s Day Parade, Shamrocks and Green Eyeshadow

headline: Works Sighted: Female Amputees Deserve Better
text: Most prosthetics are designed for men, meaning female amputees can struggle with moving comfortably, finding shoes that fit, or holding a child. Things are changing, but slowly.

headline: Iran and U.S. Differ on Optimism About Nuclear Talks
text: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — Iran and the United States issued contrasting assessments Tuesday on their progress toward an agreement to limit Iran’s nuclear program as Energy Secretary Ernest J. Moniz met here with his Iranian counterpart.

headline: Retro Striped Knits for Spring
text: Nautical tends to be the go-to stripe for the spring and summer months; but this season, the best men’s striped knits, from polos to pullovers, are instead retro in nature. In burnt oranges, acid greens and electric blues, they feel as charmingly youthful as one of the boys captured in a Daniel Meadows photograph circa 1973 — especially when paired with well-worn, washed-out Levi’s.

headline: Lawyer: Durst Did Not Kill Susan Berman
text: Dick DeGuerin, the lawyer for Robert A. Durst, said that Mr. Durst did not kill his friend Susan Berman and that the murder charge was based on a television show and not on fact.

headline: Sources of Slow Recovery
text: The other R&R — Christina and David Romer — have an interesting new paper questioning the other Reinhart-Rogoff result, the claim that financial crises consistently lead to deep, sustained slumps. I’m not ready to referee this one, at least not yet. Romer and Romer clearly have done an impressively systematic job of identifying financial distress in an objective way; but I wonder, very tentatively, if they’re looking at the wrong variable. My sense is that the aftermath of credit and housing bubbles is consistently remarkably bad – Alan Taylor and colleagues have been documenting this proposition — and that may not be well captured by reports of credit-market distress.

headline: Springtime in California
text: Mark Bittman embraces the vegetables of the season.

headline: Spring’s Opening Act
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — Back in the ’80s, I resented the existence of Meyer lemons and anyone who championed them. Those groovy Bay Area people would write recipes calling for Meyer lemons, as if anyone could find them, and insist that a regular lemon just wouldn’t do.

headline: Lone Star State of Mind
text: Will Butler of Arcade Fire [and it’s a different Will Butler! You see, I’m on a panel with the AF Butler brothers Thursday, so I just assumed …] has a somewhat downbeat piece about the corporatization of SXSW. And I have just arrived in Austin to do some investigative reporting on the scene, remaining clearly focused on the socioeconomic issues – that is, aside from the concerts and the parties, which I will of course attend purely for research purposes. headline: 1940: Nazi Planes Bomb Naval Base
text: LONDON — Fourteen Nazi warplanes last night [March 16] bombed units of the British fleet at Scapa Flow in the second raid on the naval base since war started, damaged at least one warship and killed eight men, including one civilian, the first killed on British soil. One German plane was shot down and others were damaged, the official British report said. The air raiders previously made a brief reconnaissance flight over the Orkney Islands. The German communiqué said three British battleships and one cruiser were ‘‘badly damaged’’ during the raid. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 18, 1940

headline: Congress Scrutinizes F.C.C. Following Release of New Internet Rules
text: Nearly three weeks after the Federal Communications Commission voted to regulate broadband Internet like a public utility, Congress is putting the agency and its new rules under the microscope.

headline: Aaron Schock, Facing Questions on Spending, Is Resigning
text: Representative Aaron Schock, Republican of Illinois, is resigning his House seat at the end of the month.

headline: Results at Jefferies Expose the Bank’s Weaknesses
text: Jefferies is rubbing salt into its own wounds. The Wall Street firm managed to avoid a second straight quarterly loss, but only barely.  Net income for its first quarter was a dismal $12.5 million as the three months to February exposed some of the investment bank’s weaknesses.

headline: Northern Tiger Set to Open Downtown
text: Headliner

headline: Intriguing Sketches Reveal the Depths of Geoff McFetridge’s Quirky, Beautiful Mind
text: Like most artists, Geoff McFetridge relies on early drawings to inform his final works. An illustrator based in Los Angeles, the 43-year-old creates graphic images in fine lines and bold colors, and his output is as prolific as it is varied: He has produced skateboard decks and album covers, cleaning product packaging and beer bottle labels, often collaborating with high-profile names like Spike Jonze and Nike. In one memorable stop-motion film, for the fun-loving alt-rock band OK Go, McFetridge burned illustrations into 2,430 pieces of toast. “I am always interested in creating work that lies between image and language,” he says.

headline: Facebook Announces a Payments Feature for Its Messenger App
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook‘s instant messaging service isn’t just for sending smiley faces and photos anymore. Now you can use it to send money instantly to your friends.

headline: Neville Wakefield’s Many Muses
text: From the toy sailboats he made as a boy to the large-scale installations he’s overseen in his career, the art world curator credits his rural childhood and his own children for sharpening his keen aesthetic.

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘Into the Woods’
text: For its new production of the musical “Into the Woods,” Theater Latté Da in Minneapolis didn’t look to fairy tales for inspiration. It went for something with more oom-pah: a German beer hall.

headline: Beyond Pop
text: A revival of interest in the iconic 1960s and ’70s work of the French designer has revealed an artist whose career was more varied and extensive than most realize.

headline: SXSW Music 2015: Early Show-Hopping, Taking In Known and Unknown Bands
text: AUSTIN, Tex.­­ — The sprawl of the South by Southwest Music and Media Conference gradually shifts today toward the festival’s original core: music.

headline: Where the Republican Budget Plan Meets Reality on Health Care
text: The budget proposal released by House Republicans on Tuesday promises it can repeal Obamacare and save the government a lot of money in the process. But the document relies on some vague accounting to justify this claim.

headline: The Columbus Theatre’s Folk Revival
text: The happy saga of a vaudeville-turned-movie-turned-porn venue.

headline: To Butler’s Delight, Roosevelt Jones Finds Way to Score
text: When Matthew Graves was an assistant at Butler, he was known as a shooter’s coach. Graves believed that all players, from the point guard to the big men, needed a perimeter game. So when he called the former Butler coach Brad Stevens in the fall of 2009 and said that he had just scouted a unique talent, Stevens thought Graves had stumbled upon a phenomenally gifted shooter.

headline: U.S.-Cuba Talks on Restoring Diplomatic Ties End Abruptly
text: MEXICO CITY — The United States and Cuba have ended their third round of talks on re-establishing diplomatic relations as abruptly as the meeting was announced, with no breakthrough on sticking points and in an atmosphere of rising tension over Venezuela.

headline: Self-Justifying Swedes
text: One fundamental principle in the years since the financial crisis, with all the bad judgments and policy missteps we’ve seen, is that nobody ever admits having been wrong about anything. And it turns out that people can not admit error in Swedish, too. Lars Svensson has the details on the Riksbank’s deputy governor Jansson.

headline: SXSW 2015: Will Ferrell Discusses Fraternities, ‘Get Hard’ and More
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — The actor and comedian Will Ferrell arrived here on Monday with Kevin Hart to present the comedy “Get Hard.” Last week, we asked readers to submit questions for Mr. Ferrell. He sat down with us at the Four Seasons to answer some of them. Here are his responses:

headline: Review: In ‘Running Away From the One With the Knife,’ a Suicide Pondered
text: Percolating coffee drips into a pot at the front of the Chocolate Factory stage. Boiling grounds are a familiar scent, burbling water a familiar sound, the sort of routine you reach for when the world seems inexplicable, unmoored.

headline: Hungary Without Two Thirds
text: A guest post from my Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele, head of the Law and Public Affairs program:

headline: After I.V.F.: Pregnant, but Still Stuck in the Past
text: Every time I tell someone I’m pregnant, the first thought that grips my heart in terror is, “What if I have to tell them that it didn’t work?”

headline: Drugs on Campus: A Reporter’s Challenge
text: What’s a young reporter to do when she’s assigned to investigate a college drug scene after a series of overdoses? Try to blend in. Tatiana Schlossberg realized recently that it’s harder than one might think.

headline: Netanyahu Soundly Defeats Chief Rival in Israeli Elections
text: TEL AVIV — After a bruising campaign focused on his failings, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel won a clear victory in Tuesday’s elections and seemed all but certain to form a new government and serve a fourth term, though he offended many voters and alienated allies in the process.

headline: S.E.C. Chief Voices Support for Higher Advice Standard for Brokers
text: PHOENIX — The chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission announced on Tuesday that she planned to explore setting a higher standard for brokers in dispensing investment advice, putting the agency in the middle of a potential fight between the Obama administration and the financial industry.

headline: Cultivating Genius
text: Cy Twombly painted some of the 20th century’s great works in the hilly Italian coastal town of Gaeta. All the while, Nicola Del Roscio, who watched over him, quietly created his own Eden.

headline: Voting for Israel’s Next Prime Minister
text: As the results of Israel’s tight election roll in, Israelis reflect on the issues they hope the next prime minister will make priorities.

headline: Air Force Veteran From New Jersey Tried to Aid ISIS, U.S. Charges
text: An Air Force veteran from New Jersey, recently fired from his job as an airplane mechanic, has been charged with trying to support the Islamic State by seeking to join the group.

headline: Review: Pierre-Laurent Aimard and Tamara Stefanovich in All-Boulez Program
text: Pierre Boulez emerged in the late 1940s in Paris as a combative modernist, the brash new leader of the avant-garde. By 1952 he declared that any musician who had not felt the “necessity of the dodecaphonic language” was “of no use.” Despite subsequent decades of winning over mainstream classical music audiences through his work as a conductor with lucid, colorful performances of everything from Wagner operas to Mahler symphonies, Mr. Boulez, who turns 90 on March 26, has never shaken his early reputation for writing pieces of off-putting complexity.

headline: So Glad You Could Make It, Mr. Mayor
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio was late again this morning. The Daily News reported that he arrived 15 minutes behind schedule to a St. Patrick’s Day Mass at St. Patrick’s Cathedral. This was after he somehow managed to be equally late to a St. Patrick’s Day breakfast and reception in his own house, Gracie Mansion.

headline: Obama Takes St. Patrick’s Day-Themed Swipe at Republicans
text: The White House fountain was running green and a green tie-wearing President Obama was full of St. Patrick’s Day puns when he blasted Republicans’ newly unveiled budget on Tuesday.

headline: Taxes Take Away, but Also Give Back, Mostly to the Very Rich
text: “Get your billions back, America,” the tax preparer H&R Block urges in television advertisements.

headline: Eleven Madison Park
text: Daniel Humm and Will Guidara pull out all the stops with food and service.

headline: Men, Money and the Marriage Crisis
text: As promised in my last entry, this will be the first of two posts on the theme of whether economic trends largely explain post-1960s family breakdown (my answer: no), addressing counterarguments that I didn’t have room to discuss in Sunday’s column. The first counterargument is about men: It concedes that there is a modest upward post-’60s trend in household income, rather than a steep decline, but it argues that focusing on the general trend ignores a collapse in earnings for low-skilled men, which — since it takes two to tango, and marry — suffices to explain why it’s become harder for working class males to successfully fill the roles of husband and father … especially since, with women entering the workforce, they aren’t as economically dependent on men as they once were and don’t need to settle for a guy whose wages keep on falling.

headline: Review: Paul Taylor Troupe’s Dizzying New Palette Takes Shape
text: A year ago, on the cusp of its 60th anniversary, the Paul Taylor Dance Company announced its new identity as Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance. On Saturday night at the David H. Koch Theater, one aspect of the troupe’s expanded mission — to preserve modern dance masterworks by artists other than Mr. Taylor — began to take shape, with the presentation of Doris Humphrey’s 1938 “Passacaglia and Fugue in C Minor.”

headline: Patching Up the Social Safety Net
text: Few people played as critical a role in the construction of the American social safety net as Wilbur Cohen.

headline: A Villa With Caribbean Views
text: The house, set on two and a half acres above Plum Bay, is on the market for $3.9 million.

headline: Injuries Leave Rangers Reduced but Not Diminished
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The list of Rangers who have played in every game this season is short, and it will shrink by one on Wednesday, as Martin St. Louis will not suit up against the Chicago Blackhawks because of a lower-body injury.

headline: Cleveland Clinic Grapples With Changes in Health Care
text: CLEVELAND — In downtrodden East Cleveland, a three-story family health center has replaced the city’s full-service hospital. Seven thousand miles away in Abu Dhabi, a gleaming 24-story hospital is preparing to admit patients this year.

headline: Iowa G.O.P. to Walker: Drop Adviser Who Trashed State
text: Iowa’s Republican leadership blasted Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin on Tuesday for hiring a senior adviser who has mocked the state’s caucus and its voters, and called on Mr. Walker to fire her.

headline: Coming of Age as a Guide at Ground Zero
text: Annalee Tai, a 16-year-old junior at Bard High School on Manhattan’s Lower East Side, has only the sketchiest recollection of planes smashing into the World Trade Center in 2001.

headline: So, Print Is Dying? Don’t Tell the Megazine
text: Like chocolate bars and Arctic ice caps, printed periodicals have shrunk over the last decade. The Wall Street Journal, Rolling Stone, The New York Times and dozens more have reduced their physical dimensions to maintain fiscal fitness.

headline: Trips for Cyclists Who Want to Sample the Tour de France
text: For cyclists who want to crank more than coast, two American tour operators are offering cycling trips highlighting the Alpine L’Étape du Tour (French for “stage of the Tour”).

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Pakistan and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: What You Get for … $1,200,000
text: This week’s properties include a condo in Missouri, a contemporary in Los Angeles and a townhouse in Philadelphia.

headline: March 17, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Pakistan, Israel, London and the United States.

headline: General Motors’ Stock Buyback Follows a Worrying Trend
text: General Motors’ announcement that it will buy back $5 billion worth of stock raises the question of whether the stock buyback has turned into a shareholder activist shakedown.

headline: Review: In ‘Lucia di Lammermoor’ at the Met, Singing Through Sickness
text: Whatever glamour and passion there is in the Metropolitan Opera’s blandly efficient revival of Donizetti’s “Lucia di Lammermoor” hovers around Joseph Calleja. Though he was announced at Monday’s performance as recovering from the flu, and had the wear in his tone and coughs to prove it, this invaluable tenor nevertheless sang Edgardo with plangent vigor. The characteristic sob in his throat, dimmed only slightly by his illness, was both affecting and exciting.

headline: Criminal Complaint Against Mr. Pugh
text: An 11-page complaint that sets forth the United States’ charge that Tairod Nathan Webster Pugh attempted “to provide material support and resources” to ISIS.

headline: ‘Empire,’ the Meteor That Never Fell to Earth
text: The plotlines of “Empire,” Fox’s hip-hop prime-time soap opera, tell a complicated tale of family rivalry and skulduggery. The text messages exchanged by Fox executives as the show’s success improbably grew week by week told a more succinct story.

headline: New Directors/New Films Festival Gives Spotlight to Youth
text: Like the first buds on the trees and the hint of springtime softness in the air, New Directors/New Films is an annual sign of renewal. The program, a joint presentation of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, dispels the lingering post-Oscar malaise and imports some energy and novelty from Sundance. Its geographically and stylistically wide-ranging selection of first and second features and short films emphasizes youth — (mostly) young protagonists and (mostly) young filmmakers navigating obstacles and seizing opportunities.

headline: Review: In Richard Maxwell’s ‘The Evening,’ Going Gentle Into the Night, or Not
text: Everybody knows that life ends in death. And for much of our waking hours, we do our best to push this awareness to the very back of our minds. There are times, though, when such kindly amnesia isn’t possible. And then everything we look at is suddenly and abruptly heightened by the sense that existence is defined by extinction.

headline: Review: ‘Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter,’ Inspired by an Urban Legend
text: The real-life story that inspired “Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter” was too good to be completely true, but that doesn’t diminish the film, a delicate, haunting study of a woman who has in several senses lost her way.

headline: A Conversation With James Wacht of Lee & Associates
text: Mr. Wacht, 59, is the president and an owner of Lee & Associates NYC, a commercial real estate brokerage firm affiliated with Lee & Associates Commercial Real Estate Services, which has its headquarters in Newport Beach, Calif. He is also an owner of Sierra Real Estate, a property management company, and the Cogswell Lee Development Group, which specializes in property acquisitions.

headline: Review: ‘Amour Fou,’ About the Woman in a Poet’s Suicide Pact
text: Romantic longing takes a beating in “Amour Fou,” an eccentric, coolly deadpan story of love, including that of the self. Set in Germany in the early 19th century, it tells of a middle-class woman, Henriette (Birte Schnoeink), who, to her great surprise, catches the eye of an insistently gloomy young poet, Heinrich (Christian Friedel).

headline: Kendrick Lamar, Emboldened, but Burdened, by Success
text: Calling mainstream hip-hop a series of compromises is unfair, but the genre is far from where it was even a decade ago. It’s still a privileged space for black expression, but has also become extremely conscious of everyone else listening in. Broadly speaking, it has reframed its concerns as universal, not specific. It is, by and large, polite — a warm and welcoming host.

headline: Review: A Darker ‘Pinocchio’ Strays From Disney’s Wholesome Take
text: The truths in the retelling of “Pinocchio” now at the New Victory Theater are more contemporary than we’re used to hearing. Bearing shadows truer to Carlo Collodi’s 19th-century tale than Walt Disney’s version, this family-friendly show, from the Windmill Theater and the State Theater Company of South Australia, manifests robust energy, visual flair and an aversion to modern-day phoniness.

headline: Recent Commercial Transactions
text: RECENT SALE

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Kendrick Lamar’s New Album, ‘To Pimp a Butterfly,’ Is a Streaming Hit
text: Since its surprise release on Sunday night, the rapper Kendrick Lamar’s highly anticipated album “To Pimp a Butterfly” (TDE/Aftermath/Interscope) has been insta-analyzed and tweeted about constantly, generating high praise from Kanye West, among many others.

headline: Living In Sunnyside, Queens
text: In western Queens, an old-fashioned neighborhood of squat prewar apartment buildings, rowhouses and bustling shopping streets.

headline: Orange Seeks Foreign Partner for Video Site Dailymotion
text: The chief executive of Orange, the big French telecommunications company, said on Tuesday that he was seeking a foreign partner for Dailymotion, the Web-based video-sharing service that is France’s answer to Google’s YouTube.

headline: The Future of TV Streaming
text: Consumers should be very happy with the news that Apple could soon sell a streaming-TV service that will offer a number of networks including CBS, ABC, Fox and ESPN.

headline: Breast-Feeding May Have Benefits Decades Later
text: Breast-feeding has well established short-term benefits, but now researchers have found that its advantages may persist into adulthood.

headline: Ryanair Dangles Possibility of Ultracheap Trans-Atlantic Travel
text: PARIS — Nearly a decade after it first floated the idea of $10 flights between London and New York, Ryanair, Europe’s largest discount airline, is once again dangling the possibility of ultracheap travel across the Atlantic.

headline: White House Response to Israeli Election
text: The White House press secretary, Josh Earnest, said President Obama was confident “the strong ties between the United States and Israel will endure,” regardless of the victor in Israel’s election.

headline: Alan Moore’s Novel  ‘Jerusalem’ Coming in 2016
text: Alan Moore, best known for his graphic novels, including “Watchmen” and “V for Vendetta,” is set to publish his second non-graphic novel, “Jerusalem,” next year. If past interviews with Mr. Moore are any indication, the book could clock in at more than one million words.

headline: Bangladesh’s Third Gender
text: A Bangladeshi photographer has been documenting the lives of hijras, men who sexually identify as women and live under the watch of a guru.

headline: Environmental Report Details Heat’s Costly Escape Through Elevator Shafts
text: It is a common winter phenomenon in New York City: As you try to pull open a lobby door, it seems soldered shut. Wrestle it open, and you are greeted by a shrill whistle and a blast of air.

headline: In Paris, Glittering Debuts
text: Haute joaillerie houses unveiled their spring 2015 collections during fashion’s Couture Week.

headline: In Paris, Jewelry for Springtime
text: Luxury houses, including Boucheron, Chanel and Chopard, unveiled their spring 2015 collections in January during Couture Week. The semiannual event was added to the couture calendar in 2010 by its organizer, the Fédération Française de la Couture, in an effort to link the jewelers’ collections to the fashion events staged by couture houses such as Christian Dior, Chanel and Givenchy.

headline: Puzzlement Over Killing of 3 Girls in Delhi
text: NEW DELHI — In the afternoon confusion of South Delhi, it seems, nobody took notice of the wraithlike woman struggling uphill to the place local people call “the forest,” one young daughter held in the crook of each arm and a third, a little girl in pigtails, scrambling behind.

headline: An Uneasy Coalition for Israel
text: If the Israeli election was above all a referendum on the leadership of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, he prevailed. After accumulating nine years in office over three terms, that is a measure of his political guts, however limited his political achievements.

headline: Taliban Faction Kills Lawyer
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A lawyer who had represented the Pakistani doctor who helped the C.I.A. hunt Osama bin Laden was shot dead Tuesday in northwestern Pakistan, the local police said.

headline: Huayi Brothers, Chinese Film Company, Courts Hollywood Again
text: LOS ANGELES — Huayi Brothers Media, a Chinese movie company with international aspirations, has publicly linked arms twice in the last three years with a Hollywood company only to have the deals fall apart at the last minute.

headline: United Nations Panel to Share Details on War Criminals
text: GENEVA — United Nations investigators monitoring the conflict in Syria said Tuesday that they would share details on suspected war criminals with judicial authorities in countries preparing to prosecute them, calling it “a first step” to ensuring accountability.

headline: Gulf Carriers Strike Back at U.S. Campaign to Re-examine Open-Skies Agreements
text: WASHINGTON — With their airlines’ prospects in the United States being threatened, top officials from Emirates and Etihad Airways, the mega-carriers based in the Middle East, defended their businesses on Tuesday and shot back at American rivals who had accused them of unfair competition.

headline: 2 Charged With Murder in Stabbing of Man as He Left Stamford McDonald’s
text: STAMFORD, Conn. — It was unusual when Antonio Muralles, 52, did not show up for work on Thursday morning.

headline: Pearson Under Fire for Monitoring Students’ Twitter Posts
text: Is it corporate due diligence or spying on children?

headline: Largest Presbyterian Denomination Gives Final Approval for Same-Sex Marriage
text: After three decades of debate over its stance on homosexuality, members of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) voted on Tuesday to change the definition of marriage in the church’s constitution to include same-sex marriage.

headline: No Record That Hillary Clinton Signed That She Had No Documents
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department said Tuesday that it had no record of Hillary Rodham Clinton, or the two secretaries of state before her, signing a form stating that they had no government records in their possession when they left office.

headline: A Durst Sibling Recounts the Violent Ripples Below a Charming Surface
text: At age 7, Robert Durst deliberately shoved his younger brother, Douglas, onto the ice at a skating rink, according to Douglas. He broke his wrist. That was their life, as boys and men: a low-grade menace that swelled as they grew up.

headline: Gunmen Kill Health Workers From Pakistan Polio Drive
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Gunmen killed two female health workers and one police guard in northwestern Pakistan in the latest attack on people involved in a polio immunization campaign.

headline: New Bribery Evidence Adds a Year to Biomet’s Probation
text: Life was supposed to return to normal for Biomet, the giant medical devices manufacturer accused of foreign bribery, when its federal probation expired next week. But on Tuesday, Biomet disclosed that prosecutors would extend its probation another year as they investigate new evidence of wrongdoing at the company, the Justice Department’s latest attempt to stem a widening pattern of corporate recidivism.

headline: William B. Ewald Jr., Eisenhower Aide and Revisionist Author, Dies at 89
text: William B. Ewald Jr., who was a White House speechwriter for Dwight D. Eisenhower and wrote several revisionist histories to help redeem the former president’s reputation, died on Monday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 89.

headline: Penn State Fraternity’s Secret Facebook Photos May Lead to Criminal Charges
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — Within the Kappa Delta Rho fraternity at Pennsylvania State University, the Facebook page and its photographs — of drugs, hazing and nude, unconscious women — were supposed to be among its brotherhood’s secrets.

headline: Lance Armstrong Is Said to Meet With Usada Chief in Bid to Cut Ban
text: Lance Armstrong recently met with a longtime nemesis, the head of the United States Anti-Doping Agency, in an effort to have his lifetime ban from sports overturned, according to a person familiar with the meeting.

headline: Breakaway Party Leader Stays Mum on Where He’ll Throw Support After Israeli Elections
text: The Israeli political leader who could prove key to determining who becomes the next prime minister is a popular right-leaning former member of Parliament, and was a longtime member of Benjamin Netanyahu’s party.

headline: Part of New Jersey’s Bias-Intimidation Law Is Ruled Unconstitutional
text: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that the state’s unusual bias-intimidation law was unconstitutional, dealing a potential reversal to one of the most well-known hate crime prosecutions in recent history.

headline: An Israeli Election Turns Ugly
text: Israel’s election has done a lot to reveal the challenges facing the country and the intentions of the men who seek to lead it. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s outright rejection of a Palestinian state and his racist rant against Israeli Arab voters on Tuesday showed that he has forfeited any claim to representing all Israelis.

headline: Personal Triumph for Thad Matta, but a Trying Year for Ohio State
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Thad Matta, who had just secured the most victories in Ohio State men’s basketball history, was celebrated at halfcourt inside Chicago’s United Center after a flawed but gutsy victory against Minnesota in the Big Ten tournament Thursday.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 17, 2015
text: March 17, 2015

headline: Lawyers for Suspect in Boston Marathon Bombing Steer Blame to Brother
text: BOSTON — The lawyers trying to spare the Boston Marathon bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev from the death penalty have so far been stymied from telling jurors much about their main defense: that his 26-year-old brother, Tamerlan, cajoled him into participating.

headline: Serena Williams Defeats Sloane Stephens to Advance at Indian Wells
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Renewing a rivalry that fizzled when the bright hope began to fade, Serena Williams again asserted her brilliance Tuesday afternoon with a 6-7 (3), 6-2, 6-2 victory over Sloane Stephens in the fourth round of the BNP Paribas Open.

headline: Voters in Nazareth Cheer Gains by Arab Alliance
text: NAZARETH, Israel — Choruses of beeping horns echoed through this Arab city in northern Israel as word spread that an alliance of Arab parties had received 14 seats in the next Parliament, making it the third-largest bloc.

headline: Letter Bound for White House Tests Positive for Cyanide
text: WASHINGTON — A letter intended for the White House tested positive for cyanide at an off-site mail screening facility on Tuesday, according to a statement from the Secret Service.

headline: Where to Find the Ends
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — It’s very rare that I am able to decide exactly which video I am going to end a post with before I even finish solving a puzzle. Usually, I solve it and stare at the completed grid, waiting for inspiration. Not today.

headline: Cuomo Gains Support for Ethics Policies
text: ALBANY — With a budget deadline two weeks away, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Tuesday that he had come to an agreement on new ethics policies with the State Assembly, which his fellow Democrats control, though a deal with the Republicans who lead the State Senate was not secure.

headline: Sandy Alderson Defends Mets’ Handling of Zack Wheeler
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Sandy Alderson, the Mets’ general manager, generally appears calm and measured when he addresses the news media, even when the questioning gets a little intense. He is, after all, both an Ivy League graduate and a former Marine who served in Vietnam.

headline: How the Obama and Republican Budgets Compare
text: Charts showing how G.O.P budget proposals for 2016 contrast with President Obama’s.

headline: Outcry Over Pink Sculpture Intersects With Broader Questions in Long Island City
text: When New York City’s cultural czars revealed the choice of a new piece of public art for Long Island City late last year, the response was swift and withering.

headline: Demise of Gigaom Doesn’t Faze Its Rivals
text: In the week and a half since the technology news site Gigaom stopped publishing, it has been held up as a cautionary tale for media in a go-go era. Here was a news organization that once looked promising, but collapsed so unexpectedly that its reporters were working on articles right up to the moment they were told they were out of jobs.

headline: Brigade Takes On ISIS Allies in Libya
text: CAIRO — Fighters aligned with the Islamic State who control the Libyan city of Surt have begun clashing with a brigade from the neighboring city of Misurata that is trying to drive them out, according to news reports on Tuesday, and a leading Tunisian militant was killed in the battle.

headline: Missouri Executes Killer Who Had Brain Injury
text: A Missouri man who was missing 20 percent of the frontal lobe of his brain was executed on Tuesday, after the United States Supreme Court declined to delay his death and order a test of his mental competency.

headline: Egypt to Charge Officer in Killing of Shaimaa el-Sabbagh
text: CAIRO — Egyptian prosecutors said Tuesday that they were charging a police officer with a type of manslaughter in the shooting of a poet and activist whose killing at a peaceful demonstration made her the latest symbol of police abuse.

headline: After 4 Years, Florida Police Are Cleared in Shooting
text: MIAMI — After a four-year investigation, Miami-Dade prosecutors said on Tuesday that they would not charge 12 police officers who unleashed more than 100 bullets at a reckless driver who crashed into several cars in Miami Beach, drove on a sidewalk and nearly ran over several officers on bicycles.

headline: ‘Justified’ Recap: Raylan and Boyd, Hanging at a Pizza Party
text: Season 6, Episode 9: “Burned”

headline: Good Basketball Elsewhere Holds Lessons for Knicks
text: In an exercise that continued to defy rational human behavior, paying customers again filled Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night for the Knicks’ game against the San Antonio Spurs. It had been about nine weeks since my last visit to the Garden, and the Knicks were still entrenched in last place and still hoping to unearth some confidence and still trying to solve the riddles of the triangle offense.

headline: Picking Israel’s Next Premier
text: The votes are in, but Israelis may not know who will be their next prime minister for days.

headline: C. C. Sabathia, Pitching for Yankees, Has Nerves but ‘No Complaints’
text: TAMPA, Fla. — C. C. Sabathia had not stood atop a mound in a major league game since last May, so there were manifold questions and concerns on Tuesday night: about his surgically repaired right knee, his arm strength, his control, his velocity, his stamina.

headline: Syria: Reports Claim Downing of a U.S. Surveillance Drone
text: The Syrian state news media reported Tuesday that the country’s air defense systems had shot down an American surveillance plane near the northwestern city of Latakia. American defense officials confirmed that United States military controllers had lost contact with an unarmed, remotely piloted craft — an MQ-1 Predator — over northwestern Syria but said they had no information to corroborate that it had been shot down. They said they were investigating. Syrian state television showed footage of what it said were the remnants of the plane being loaded into a truck by soldiers. If confirmed, the downing would be the first of an American aircraft in Syria since a United States-led coalition began bombing Islamic State extremists there last year.

headline: Ladders That Stand Apart
text: The latest incarnations of one of the oldest designs in the world continue to marry usefulness with beauty of form.

headline: A Cricket Match, With Politics in the Spotlight
text: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — No social function on this island is as important as the recent annual Royal-Thomian cricket match, but this year’s event was particularly special because of what has become known here as the Royalist coup.

headline: Go Ahead, Ruin My Day
text: As the saying goes, “to err is human, to forgive is divine,” to which I’d add: “to ignore” is even more human, and the results rarely divine. None of us would be human if we didn’t occasionally get so wedded to our wishes that we failed to notice — or outright ignored — the facts on the ground that make a laughingstock of our hopes. Only when the gap gets too wide to ignore does policy change. This is where a lot of U.S. policy is heading these days in the Middle East. Mind the gaps — on Iran, Israel and Iraq. We’re talking about our choices in these countries with words that strike me as about 10 years out of date. Alas, we are not dealing anymore with your grandfather’s Israel, your father’s Iran or the Iraq your son or daughter went off to liberate.

headline: American Express to Start Multi-Business Loyalty Program
text: American Express, looking to broaden its influence after recent setbacks with its core charge card business, is set to introduce a new, broad-based customer loyalty program that works regardless of how shoppers pay.

text: The country’s largest marketers are slashing their advertising budgets as they shift a larger portion of their spending to digital, according to new figures released on Wednesday.

headline: Bangladesh’s Third Gender
text: Shahria Sharmin had gone to her husband’s factory in Dhaka, Bangladesh, looking to tell a positive story about the garment industry, one that would offset negative public perceptions. What she found, instead, was an even more challenging topic: the lives of five hijras, the local term for the culture of men who identify as women. By day, they presented themselves as men, but at night they dressed as women and kept a home for their boyfriends.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
text: 10 P.M. (ABC) THE UNTOLD STORY OF ‘THE SOUND OF MUSIC’ Diane Sawyer travels to Austria with Julie Andrews in this “20/20” special celebrating the 50th anniversary of the film “The Sound of Music,” and explores its cultural impact during a time of unrest in the United States. In Salzburg they trace the steps of the von Trapp family, who inspired the movie; tour the former home of Maria von Trapp, the character Ms. Andrews portrayed; visit the train station where the family escaped the Nazis; and speak with the Mother Abbess of the Nonnberg Abbey, where Maria was a postulant after World War I. Christopher Plummer, who played Captain von Trapp, also shares his recollections of the film and his relationship with Ms. Andrews, who chimes in about a few of her favorite things.

headline: Time for Sanity in College Admissions
A Way Out on Immigration Reform
text: THE goal of fixing our broken immigration system is further away than ever. President Obama’s executive orders — which would allow up to five million of about 11 million illegal immigrants to stay in this country — have been challenged in the courts, and Republicans, a majority in the new Congress, have held up appropriations and confirmations in retaliation.

headline: How Best to Strengthen Chemical Regulations
text: Two bills were introduced in the Senate last week to reform the Toxic Substances Control Act, which by most accounts has been a miserable failure at ensuring the safety of chemicals used in consumer products. The bills take vastly different approaches and raise the troubling question of whether to settle for a reasonable compromise or strive instead for a stronger reform.

text: If the budget resolution released on Tuesday by House Republicans is a road map to a “Stronger America,” as its title proclaims, it’s hard to imagine what the path to a diminished America would look like.

headline: As Chinese Tourism Increases, American Museums Adapt
text: It’s now easier for mainland Chinese to visit the United States, thanks to relaxed visa rules instituted late last year, allowing 10 years before visa renewal rather than one year. The change is expected to increase Chinese tourism and real estate investment, but it will also have a less obvious beneficiary: American museums.

headline: Gyorgy Kepes, Wizard of Light and Motion, Comes Back Into Focus
text: LONDON — Whenever he had free time, the Hungarian designer Gyorgy Kepes would disappear into a makeshift darkroom at the Institute of Design, an experimental school he had founded with a group of friends in Chicago in 1939, to create abstract, often surreal images of familiar objects like stones, leaves and slices of bread.

headline: For ‘Alice in Wonderland’ Milestone, a Stampede Down the Rabbit Hole
text: While the Alice of Lewis Carroll’s “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” was a fictional British character, she has touched the hearts of young and old worldwide, particularly in the United States.

headline: How Often Do You Engage in ‘Fat Talk’?
text: How often do you complain about your body — or overhear others doing so? Have you been known to say, “I’m so fat” to your friends?

headline: Afghan First Vice President, an Ex-Warlord, Fumes on the Sidelines
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The security meeting was almost at a close when the first vice president of Afghanistan, the former warlord Abdul Rashid Dostum, began crying.

headline: Japan’s Businesses Respond to Abe’s Push for Higher Wages
text: TOKYO — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan has been putting unusually strong pressure on his country’s businesses to raise workers’ pay, a crucial but still missing piece of his economic growth plans.

headline: ‘The Age of Cryptocurrency,’ by Paul Vigna and Michael J. Casey
text: Money, “The Age of Cryptocurrency” ­explains, is “a medium of exchange, a unit of account and a store of value.” But for Schopenhauer it was “human happiness in the abstract,” and for Dostoyevsky “coined liberty.” These passion metaphors reflect the febrile excitement about Bitcoin that Paul Vigna and Michael J. Casey, both of The Wall Street Journal, share in their wide-ranging, interesting account of the origin, past and possible future of this virtual-money wannabe.

headline: Bill Browder’s ‘Red Notice’
text: The grandson of the head of the American Communist Party commits the ultimate act of rebellion: He gets a business degree from Stanford. From there, he goes on to build the biggest hedge fund in Russia. After exposing widespread government corruption, he gets expelled from the country. While he’s gone, the Kremlin raids his fund and perpetrates an elaborate financial fraud. The lawyer investigating the crime is tortured and dies in prison. He avenges his lawyer’s death, exposing a cover-up at the highest levels of the Putin regime.

headline: How to Get Your Spouse to Exercise
text: Spouses influence each other’s exercise habits, for better and worse, more than is often recognized, according to an interesting new study of the workout habits of middle-aged couples. The study found that changes in one spouse’s routine tend to be echoed in the other’s, highlighting the extent to which our exercise behavior is shaped not just by our personal intentions but by the people around us as well.

headline: Beck, Dave Grohl and John Legend to Perform at Rock Hall of Fame Ceremony
text: Beck, Dave Grohl and John Legend will perform at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony on April 18 in Cleveland, it was announced on Wednesday. Several current Hall of Fame members will be on hand to induct the newest crop: Stevie Wonder will induct Bill Withers and Patti Smith will induct Lou Reed, who died in 2013.

headline: Outlook for Solar Gets a Bit Brighter
text: LONDON — Here is a trick question: Which country led the European Union last year in putting new solar panels on rooftops and in countryside energy parks? If you chose sunny Spain or balmy Italy, you were wrong. Britain, the green and pleasant land often shrouded in cloud, was the leader, according to the market research firm I.H.S.

headline: Win in Israel Sets Netanyahu on Path to Rebuild and Redefine Government
text: JERUSALEM — Israelis emboldened Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu with a clear mandate in balloting on Tuesday, paving the way for him to lead a right-leaning and religious coalition that could be far easier to control, since his own party holds many more seats now.

text: FRANKFURT — Protesters set cars on fire and clashed with police officers on Wednesday as they marched toward the European Central Bank’s new headquarters in a demonstration against austerity and capitalism that took on a markedly more heated tone than past protests.

headline: Edinburgh International Festival, Under New Director, Sets Lineup
text: LONDON — A focus on big international stars and more diverse musical programming characterizes Fergus Linehan’s first Edinburgh International Festival, which will run Aug. 7-31. Mr. Linehan, who was the director of the Sydney festival, then head of the contemporary music program at the Sydney Opera before coming to Edinburgh, succeeded Jonathan Mills as director.

text: Good morning on this cold and windy Wednesday.

headline: Aid Trickles to Vanuatu as Relief Workers Report Vast Cyclone Damage

headline: Daily Report: You Can Now Send Your Friends Money on Facebook
text: Facebook‘s instant messaging service isn’t just for sending smiley faces and photos anymore. Now you can use it to send money instantly to your friends.

headline: The Invisible Primary Means No TV Ads. For Now.
text: There’s a reason the early part of the presidential nomination contest is called the invisible primary: There are no television ads yet. Voters in key states should enjoy the lull while it lasts, which could be until summer or maybe even longer.

headline: Charles C. W. Cooke Can Fend for Himself
text: You were born in England and moved here in 2011 to work for National Review. What made you decide to resettle in the colonies? I’d spent a lot of time in America. We have family friends in California and Arizona. I always had great love for America. I even had an Apollo 11 lunchbox.

headline: Alabama Shakes’s Soul-Stirring, Shape-Shifting New Sound
text: In the upstairs dressing room at the Georgia Theater in Athens, Ga., in January, Alabama Shakes was getting restless. The band was about to perform songs from its second album, “Sound & Color,” for the first time, and the room was full of distractions. Friends and relatives had driven over from Alabama: cousins and uncles, wives and girlfriends, crying babies and unrestrained toddlers. Sippy cups and spilled Cheerios were scattered everywhere.

headline: Do You Tell a Friend His Daughter Is Sexually Active?
text: A man told me he was approached by his best friend’s daughter, a minor, who confided that she and her boyfriend had become sexually active. She wanted his opinion on birth control. The man says he would want to know if it were his daughter, but to tell the parents would violate the girl’s trust. What do I tell him? NAME WITHHELD, CONNECTICUT

headline: Today in Politics: Washington Responds to Netanyahu’s Victory in Israel
text: Good Wednesday morning from Washington, where March Madness is already starting to get political, and even St. Patrick’s Day could not bring President Obama a lucky budget from Republicans. The resignation of Representative Aaron Schock of Illinois is still the talk of the town, but Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin may have found himself a headache in Iowa. Yet for now, the biggest electoral drama is the result in Israel’s vote.

headline: How to Be Misled by Polls, Hillary Clinton Email Edition

headline: Restaurant Report: Low Country Kitchen in Steamboat Springs, Colo.
text: For Brian and Katy Vaughn, owners of two restaurants in Steamboat Springs, Colo., it’s all about family. Before settling for good in Steamboat Springs, where the couple met, the Southern-born Vaughns took a major detour back through the South, she to attend architecture school and he to work for the chef Norman Van Aken in Miami. When they wanted to settle down and raise a family, home turned out to be the mountains of Colorado.

headline: A Pioneer for Death With Dignity
text: More than two decades before Brittany Maynard’s public advocacy for death with dignity inspired lawmakers in Washington, D.C., and at least 16 states to introduce legislation authorizing the medical practice of aid in dying for the terminally ill, Senator Frank Roberts of Oregon sponsored one of the nation’s first death-with-dignity bills.

headline: Noam Chomsky on the Roots of American Racism
text: This is the eighth in a series of interviews with philosophers on race that I am conducting for The Stone. This week’s conversation is with Noam Chomsky, a linguist, political philosopher and one of the world’s most prominent public intellectuals. He is the author of many books, including, most recently, “On Western Terrorism: From Hiroshima to Drone Warfare,” with Andre Vltchek.

headline: Iraqi Forces and Militias Said to Loot Sunni Towns
text: BAGHDAD — Iraqi militias and security forces destroyed and looted the property of displaced Sunni civilians after reclaiming the town of Amerli from Islamic State militants last year, according to a Human Rights Watch report issued Wednesday.

headline: Serbia Arrests Eight Suspected in 1995 Srebrenica Massacre
text: LONDON — Prosecutors in Serbia said on Wednesday that eight men suspected of having participated in the 1995 Srebrenica massacre, Europe’s bloodiest slaughter since World War II, had been arrested. The arrests were described by prosecutors as the first by the Serbian police of anyone accused of doing the killing at Srebrenica, where 8,000 Muslims died.

headline: Morning Agenda: More Scrutiny for Biomet
text: MORE SCRUTINY FOR BIOMET | The giant medical devices manufacturer Biomet, which was accused of foreign bribery, disclosed on Tuesday that prosecutors would extend its probation another year as they investigate new evidence of wrongdoing at the company, Ben Protess reports in DealBook. The Justice Department is investigating whether Biomet helped bribe government officials in Mexico and Brazil, a reminder of an earlier bribery case that Biomet settled in 2012. To resolve the first case, Biomet paid $17 million and struck a so-called deferred prosecution agreement that withheld criminal charges as long as the company behaved during three years of probation.

headline: French Court Blocks Airbus Insider Trading Trial
text: PARIS — A French court on Wednesday blocked an insider trading trial of seven current and former executives of the Airbus Group, as well as two of its former shareholders, arguing that the defendants had already been cleared by stock market regulators, making any further prosecution of the case a violation of European double jeopardy rules.

headline: N.C.A.A. Bracket Conundrum: To Pick Kentucky or Not to Pick Kentucky?
text: Participants in our interactive N.C.A.A. bracket, which rewards correct picks based on their overall popularity among readers, have reached a consensus: Not surprisingly, Kentucky is the team to beat. More than half of Times readers pick the Wildcats to reach the national championship, and 41 percent have chosen them to win the title.

headline: Fortescue, Big Iron Ore Miner, Pulls $2.5 Billion Debt Sale
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Fortescue Metals Group of Australia, the world’s fourth-largest iron ore exporter, has pulled a $2.5 billion debt sale amid a 48 percent plunge in the price of iron ore that prompted investors to demand better terms than Fortescue was willing to offer.

headline: Obama May Find It Impossible to Mend Frayed Ties to Netanyahu

headline: Sunnyside, Queens, ‘Mayberry’ Near Midtown
text: Sunnyside, in western Queens, is a stark contrast to the gleaming glass residential towers rising in nearby Long Island City. Here is an old-fashioned New York neighborhood of squat prewar apartment buildings, rowhouses and shopping streets that still have mom-and-pop businesses.

headline: Law School Proximity Matters for Partner Prospects, Study Finds
text: Elite law schools are not always a glide path to becoming a partner at a big law firm. A new study of partners’ academic pedigrees shows that a large number of graduates who reach the top rung at a law firm do not necessarily come from the top-ranked law schools.

headline: Tunisia Museum Attack Is Blow to Nation’s Democratic Shift
text: CAIRO — Gunmen in military uniforms killed 19 people on Wednesday in a midday attack on a museum in downtown Tunis, dealing a new blow to the tourist industry that is vital to Tunisia as it struggles to consolidate the only transition to democracy after the Arab Spring revolts.

text: Amanda Hesser and Merrill Stubbs of Food52 show you how to make three variations of rice pudding, all without a recipe.

headline: ‘The Tallest Tree in the Forest,’ a Play About Paul Robeson

headline: Lisa Howard on Her Latest Broadway Show, ‘It Shoulda Been You’
text: Being told you’re too tall or short for a role is hard enough. Being told you’re too heavy would seem downright excruciating. But Lisa Howard has heard that plenty of times and nevertheless managed to persevere in a career that includes one “Twilight” movie and four Broadway shows.

headline: Ben Miles Takes On ‘Wolf Hall’ Onstage
text: If you stroll over to the Frick Collection, as the cast of “Wolf Hall, Parts One & Two” recently did, you can see Hans Holbein’s 1530s portrait of Thomas Cromwell, the court consigliere at the center of the Royal Shakespeare Company’s stage adaptation of Hilary Mantel’s prizewinning novels.

headline: An Uber Service Is Banned in Germany Again
text: BERLIN — A judge in Frankfurt dealt a setback to Uber on Wednesday, ruling that drivers for its ride-sharing service UberPop must hold the official permits required of taxi drivers to operate in Germany. The ruling reinstates one of the most severe legal restrictions faced by the company anywhere in the world.

headline: City Ballet Announces 2015-16 Season
text: World premieres: Seven. Balanchine ballets: 28. Dancers: 94. Composers danced to: 47, including Ellis Ludwig-Leone of the band San Fermin and Bryce Dessner of the National, who were commissioned to write scores.

headline: Sweden Cuts Key Interest Rate to Minus 0.25%
text: The Swedish central bank on Wednesday again cut its main interest rate, bringing it deeper into negative territory to head off deflationary pressures.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Emerges as an Unexpected Champion of Religion
text: Growing up, Mayor Bill de Blasio was the only child on his block who did not attend Mass on Sundays. “Everyone else was at church, and I wasn’t,” he recalled in an interview last week. “Some of the kids envied me.”

text: Amy Schumer discusses writing and starring in “Trainwreck,” a comedy directed by Judd Apatow.

headline: SXSW 2015 Video: Amy Schumer on ‘Trainwreck’
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — The comedy “Trainwreck,” written by and starring Amy Schumer and directed by Judd Apatow, received an enthusiastic response at its screening here on Sunday. In this video interview recorded at the festival, Ms. Schumer discusses her role in the movie, how her screenplay drew from personal experiences, and how she finds the comedy in tragic situations.

headline: Insider City Tours From InterContinental Hotels
text: Guests at InterContinental hotels in Tel Aviv, Paris and London can now take part in the company’s “Secrets of the City,” a program that offers specialized tours of each city.

headline: Clippers’ Doc and Austin Rivers Try to Balance Their Many Roles
text: LOS ANGELES — Spend a few moments with Austin Rivers, and it becomes clear soon enough that he is a chip off the old Doc.

headline: Deal Makers Less Upbeat About M.&.A. Growth
text: NEW ORLEANS — Last year was by all accounts a banner year for mergers. But as one of the takeover industry’s main conferences prepares to begin here, a new survey has found that significantly fewer deal makers believe that 2015 will prove any better.

headline: Obama’s Bracket Is Just a Bit More Daring This Year
text: President Obama has made his annual N.C.A.A. bracket projections, and he is going with the consensus favorite, Kentucky, to win it all.

headline: The Brooklyn-Born-Raised-and-Based Artist Who Dripped Her Way to Chanel Sneakers and Car Service
text: Joyce Pensato, a 70-something-old breath of fresh air whose current and fourth solo show is currently on view at Petzel Gallery, explains her slow rise to painterly fame.

headline: 36 Hours in Dubai
text: Explore street view, find things to do in Dubai and sign in to your Google account to save your map.

headline: 36 Hours in Dubai
text: Dubai has emerged as an ethnically diverse metropolis where the world’s populations mingle in markets, galleries and international restaurants, both humble and high-end.

headline: 36 Hours in Dubai
text: Dubai is impossible to ignore. As its leaders and property developers proudly trumpet, the city-state along the Persian Gulf has the world’s highest building (the Burj Khalifa), the world’s tallest hotel (JW Marriott Marquis Dubai), the world’s largest artificial island (the Palm Jumeirah) and the world’s biggest mall (Dubai Mall).

headline: Better Sleep for a Better Sex Life
text: A good night’s sleep may be important for a woman’s sex life, a small study suggests.

headline: Jeb Bush Picks Up a New Supporter for a Run: His Mother
text: Barbara Bush, often the most outspoken member of the family, put an early damper on the thought of Jeb Bush’s running for president with a verbal eye roll, suggesting that maybe some other American clans could produce presidential candidates.

headline: Japan Investigates Death Threats Against Caroline Kennedy, U.S. Ambassador
text: TOKYO — The police in Japan are investigating telephoned death threats to the United States ambassador, Caroline Kennedy, the daughter of President John F. Kennedy, and to an American diplomat in Okinawa, Japanese and international news agencies reported on Wednesday.

headline: For Perfect Pasta, Add Water and a Vigorous Stir
text: On a clear fall day in Rome, I was sitting outside at Flavio al Velavevodetto, a restaurant in Testaccio, in a neighborhood that was once the city’s slaughterhouse district and is now inhabited by both older working-class people and gentrifying youngsters. Flavio de Maio, an elegant, middle-aged businessman turned chef, sat across the table from me; a translator sat between us. I had come at the recommendation of a friend, the Rome-based journalist and historian Katie Parla, who told me that if I was looking for the epitome of Roman pasta, this was the place.

headline: The Art of the Tantrum
text: No one does cranky with quite as much panache as the French. Two picture books about bad moods, both written by Francophone authors and offered in English translations for the first time, demonstrate what may be the secret. Both take an approach that many parents struggle to master: The less you fight it, the more likely it is that irritability will give way on its own to something else — sometimes, even something charming.

headline: ‘Goodfellas’ Will Help Close Tribeca Film Festival
text: You and a date probably won’t be able to attend closing night of the Tribeca Film Festival by entering through the basement, wending your way through labyrinthine hallways and perhaps a kitchen, greasing several palms and having seats set up in the front row. But if you’re willing to settle for buying tickets and walking through the front doors, you can watch that famous tracking shot and other memorable scenes in a newly remastered version of the Martin Scorsese gangster film “Goodfellas,” organizers announced Wednesday.

headline: ‘Wolf Hall,’ a Six-Part TV Series, Tackles Hilary Mantel’s Books
text: OXFORDSHIRE, ENGLAND — Thomas Cromwell was rolling a cigarette. Henry VIII was sitting on a chair amid a stretch of green lawn, eyes closed, face turned to the summer sunlight. A gaggle of ladies-in-waiting swept across the gardens. A courtier popped his head apologetically around the door of Broughton Castle. “Five minutes,” he said.

headline: Sony’s PlayStation Vue Is Introduced in 3 Cities
text: Television fans who want to break free from a traditional TV subscription now have more options than ever to pay for what they want to watch, and how they want to watch it.

text: The main draw of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament begins Thursday, and the New York Times bracket is a fun way to test your predictions in a system that, like financial markets and most forms of sports betting, rewards you for taking an against-the-grain pick that proves accurate.
