text: Duct tape. Cardboard boxes. Enthusiasm.

headline: Wind-Blown Plywood Kills Woman in Greenwich Village
text: Tram Thuy Nguyen came to New York about eight months ago to be with her fiancé, her former boss said, and her favorite topic in recent months had been her coming marriage.

headline: New Global Fund to Help Countries Defend Smoking Laws
text: Bloomberg Philanthropies and the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation announced on Wednesday that they had started a global fund to help low- and middle-income countries fight legal challenges to their smoking laws by the tobacco industry.

headline: After ISIS Retreats in Iraq, Evidence of Shiite Retaliation
text: Dozens of Iraqi villages that were under the control of the Islamic State suffered from looting and extensive property destruction after being retaken by pro-government forces, a study says.

headline: Named Next President of N.Y.U., Oxford’s Leader Inherits Challenges From John Sexton
text: New York University, which has become known for its global aspirations as much as its enviable home in Greenwich Village, named the head of one of the world’s most prestigious universities as its 16th president on Wednesday.

headline: For Wearables, Design Leads Tech
text: Wearables are leading a revolution to combine design with ingenuity to make new products. During development of Nike’s Fuelband, for example, many details, from material to font, came from designers.

headline: National Gallery in London Appoints New Director
text: LONDON — Ever since last summer, when Nicholas Penny, the director of the National Gallery here, announced his plans to retire, speculation and rumors about who might succeed him abounded. On Wednesday, the National Gallery announced that Gabriele Finaldi, the deputy director for collections and research at the Prado museum in Madrid, would take up the post. The appointment was confirmed by the British prime minister, David Cameron.

headline: Netanyahu at Risk of Isolating Israel, Palestinian Envoy to U.N. Warns
text: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is putting Israel on a collision course with its allies, the Palestinian ambassador to the United Nations said Wednesday, warning that if Mr. Netanyahu succeeded in forming a new government, he would further isolate his country.

headline: Neither Simon Nor Macerich Can Claim High Road in Mall Bid
text: American operators of fancy retail complexes are showing similarities to far-flung bazaar traders. The mall owner Macerich rejected an unwanted $22 billion takeover bid from a larger rival, the Simon Property Group. The premium offered may be less valuable than claimed. Even so, the target company’s response is the more disingenuous.

headline: First Draft Focus: All Aboard
text: President Obama took off for Cleveland on Wednesday.

headline: Syracuse’s Athletic Director Resigns; Jim Boeheim to Retire in 3 Years
text: A major figure in the N.C.A.A. report on infractions and academic misconduct at Syracuse gave up his job Wednesday, but it was not Jim Boeheim, the men’s basketball coach, who will remain on the team’s bench for three more seasons.

headline: Air Force Veteran Pleads Not Guilty in ISIS Case
text: An Air Force veteran from New Jersey accused of trying to support the Islamic State pleaded not guilty on Wednesday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

headline: Flowers in Vases, Illustrated
text: From a series for T in which the artist Leanne Shapton makes new artworks from pictures in old books.

headline: 1915: Women Called to War Service
text: LONDON — An important step has been taken by the Government in calling upon women to register themselves for paid employment in the nation’s service, to fill up ranks which are at present without sufficient labor, and also to release men for the fighting line.

headline: A 3-D View of a Chart That Predicts The Economic Future: The Yield Curve
text: The current flatness of the curve shows investors expect mediocre growth.

headline: Judge Sends Rowland, Ex-Connecticut Governor, Back to Prison
text: NEW HAVEN — Former Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut is going back to prison.

headline: 1965: Russian ‘Walks’ in Space
text: A French television report on the first spacewalk, by the Soviet cosmonaut Alexei A. Leonov. ina.fr

headline: Inquiry Into Rape of Indian Nun Is Sent to Federal Agency
text: NEW DELHI — With no arrests yet in the rape of a nun  and the robbery of a convent school last week in the Indian state of West Bengal, the state’s leader on Wednesday delegated the case to the federal investigating agency.

headline: Why Can’t We Stop Watching ‘Empire’?
text: What is it about “Empire,” the Fox series about a family of music moguls that wraps up its first season this week, that makes the show so addictive? It might be the juicy plotlines; Taraji P. Henson’s ferocious and charming portrayal of Cookie Lyon, the estranged matriarch of the family; the so-bad-it’s-almost-good soundtrack, produced by Timbaland; or some combination of all three. The soapy drama, which debuted in January, was the highest-rated new series on television this season. Its ratings and audience numbers have risen each week the show has aired — a phenomenon that is practically unheard-of. Fox has already renewed the series for a second season.

headline: Wayne Odesnik Barred From Tennis After Second Doping Violation
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — The International Tennis Federation and the United States Anti-Doping Agency announced Wednesday that the American Wayne Odesnik had been barred for 15 years after urine samples he submitted in December and January tested positive for multiple banned substances. It was Odesnik’s second doping offense in five years.

headline: Praying With Jeb Bush
text: Michael Paulson will soon begin reporting on theater for The Times, but for his penultimate article as a national religion reporter, he wrote about the role that Catholicism plays in Jeb Bush’s life.

headline: Survivors on Aftermath of Vanuatu Storm
text: Survivors tried to rebuild on Wednesday after a cyclone lashed out over the Pacific island nation of Vanuatu last weekend.

headline: Kansas, a No. 2 Seed, Limps Into the N.C.A.A. Tournament
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — At the end of a brief practice the day before the Big 12 tournament quarterfinals at Sprint Center here, Kansas forward Cliff Alexander, a freshman, left the court with his gray T-shirt drenched in sweat. Alexander, embroiled in an eligibility issue with the N.C.A.A., had no reason to hold back because he would not be playing in the tournament.

headline: A Perfectly Simple Hermès Watch That’s Simply Perfect
text: The new Slim d’Hermès is an expression of luxurious minimalism. Unlike timepieces designed to measure your steps while tracking your pace, the French house has created a line of watches for both men and women — its first series in over 20 years — that marks the passing of time in the most spare and elegant way. Enclosed in a slender rose gold case, the luminescent dial of the watch shown here features numerals custom-created by Philippe Apeloig, a well-regarded French graphic designer. (Apeloig is also behind the signage for Jean Nouvel’s upcoming Louvre Abu Dhabi.) A sapphire crystal case back reveals the ultrathin automatic movement, manufactured at the prestigious Swiss watchmaker Vaucher, now owned in part by Hermès. As befits a company that started out making leather harnesses for European noblemen in 1837, the hand-stitched Havana alligator strap receives the same attention to detail as does a Kelly bag. Valuing creativity and craftsmanship above all, Hermès shows how perfect simple can be.

headline: Car Bomb Targeting Afghan Officials Kills 7 Civilians
text: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan — A huge car bomb rocked the capital of Helmand Province late Wednesday morning, killing seven people and wounding more than 45 in an attack aimed at a gathering of officials in a secure Afghan government compound.

headline: Do Conversations About Race Occur Where You Work?
text: This week, Starbucks encouraged its baristas to engage customers in discussion about race relations while serving up lattes. The campaign has touched off a lot of discussion on social media, and it makes me wonder:

headline: SXSW Music 2015: Lines Everywhere, but Space on the Dance Floor
text: SXSW is recognizably more safety­-conscious this year after a deadly incident in 2014, when a drunken driver crashed through a barrier and killed four people waiting in line on the street outside a club, and injured others. There are more barricades, more police officers and more streets closed to traffic.

headline: Africa Center Post Gives Michelle D. Gavin a Chance to Show Diplomatic Skills
text: After a rocky start, the luxury condominiums at One Museum Mile, the 19-story, Robert A. M. Stern-designed tower anchoring the northeast corner of Central Park, are all occupied now.

headline: Scenes From SXSW
text: Timbaland and Tink, Meg Mac, Future, Kate Tempest and others performed at the music festival in Austin, Tex.

headline: Myanmar Shows Signs of Democratic Reversal, U.N. Official Says
text: GENEVA — Myanmar is reversing democratic reforms at an accelerating rate in an election year that will define its future, a United Nations investigator monitoring developments in the country said on Wednesday.

headline: Dieudonné M’bala M’bala, French Comedian, Convicted of Condoning Terrorism
text: PARIS — The provocative French comedian Dieudonné M’bala M’bala was found guilty on Wednesday of condoning terrorism after a Facebook message he posted in January suggested sympathy with one of the gunmen in the attacks that killed 17 people in Paris.

headline: Starbucks Initiative on Race Relations Draws Attacks Online
text: Scrawled on Starbucks cups, the words “Race Together” were intended to stimulate conversations about race relations in America, beginning just days before the company’s annual shareholders meeting on Wednesday. But the coffee company’s campaign has instead unleashed widespread vitriol and derision.

headline: For the Love of Watches
text: Andrew Luff’s collection is focused on timepieces made by small watchmakers, and the color orange.

headline: Lindsey Vonn Wins World Cup Title in Downhill
text: Roughly a year ago, at home in Colorado, Lindsey Vonn’s mornings were devoted to grueling gym sessions rehabilitating her twice rebuilt right knee. Vonn’s afternoons were spent with the leg enveloped in ice, a routine that had kept her out of consecutive racing seasons.

headline: T-Mobile Aims to Make Phone Plans Easier for Businesses
text: Since T-Mobile USA introduced its simplified phone plans for consumers in 2013, the carrier has significantly grown its customer base. Now it has another target: business subscribers.

headline: A Nation on the Move: Exploring the Promise of the First Transcontinental Railroad
text: In this lesson, students use primary sources to answer the question: Why was the first transcontinental railroad more than just another railroad in the eyes of the nation?

headline: Fed Creeps Closer to Higher Rate That May Not Arrive for Months
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve on Wednesday moved to the verge of raising interest rates for the first time since the economy fell into recession more than seven years ago, even as officials suggested that the Fed might not pull the trigger until well into the second half of the year.

headline: Good News for Medical Marijuana
text: A bipartisan Senate bill that would permit the medicinal use of marijuana in states that allow it is slowly gaining support among lawmakers. The latest to sign on is Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, who became a co-sponsor of the bill on Tuesday.

headline: Suspect Is Captured After Rampage in Mesa, Ariz., Leaves One Man Dead
text: MESA, Ariz. — After an argument in a motel, a gunman went on a deadly rampage through a quiet neighborhood here early Wednesday, leaving one man dead and at least five others wounded before being captured, the authorities said.

headline: Study Reveals Genetic Path of Modern Britons
text: In A.D. 410, Roman authority in Britain collapsed and Romano-British society disappeared from history under the invading tides of Angles and Saxons from northern Europe. Historians have been debating ever since whether the Romano-British were wiped out or survived by adopting their conquerors’ language and culture.

headline: Netanyahu’s Day, and Israel’s Future
Video Feature: Design Gains Importance as Devices Get More Personal
text: THERE’S how a product looks and how you interact with it, and both of those things come down to design. In tech, it is the design that separates a successful product from a dud.

headline: Dana Farouki on Where to Eat, Shop and Gallery-Hop in Dubai
text: The art collector, adviser and booster Dana Farouki moved from New York to Dubai almost five years ago, cementing a relationship with the city that began with family when she was a child and has continued through her nearly 10 years as a curator and champion of arts organizations and initiatives in the UAE, including the Guggenheim Abu Dhabi. She has served on the Board of Patrons for Art Dubai, the ninth edition of which begins today and runs through Saturday, since the fair began in 2007. She’s also on the jury for the Abraaj Group Art Prize, whose winners (all artists from the Middle East, North Africa or South Asia) will be showcased at the fair this week.

headline: Senate Republicans Rebuff House Colleagues With Their Budget Plan
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Wednesday released an austere budget that maintains strict caps on military spending and cuts trillions of dollars from health care and welfare, sending a rebuff to their House colleagues.

headline: The FaceTime Babysitter
text: One recent Saturday afternoon, when Rafi Fletcher was home alone with her nearly 1-year-old son, the Minneapolis mom wanted to get some work done on her women’s clothing start-up, Tibby & Finn.

headline: Valentin Rasputin, Russian Writer Who Led ‘Village Prose’ Movement, Dies at 77
text: MOSCOW — Valentin Rasputin, a patriarch of the so-called village prose writers who emerged in the Soviet Union in the 1960s to address moral and environmental issues and depict the remains of a rural Russia about to be consumed by industrialization, died here on Saturday. He was 77.

headline: Grant Hill, Former Duke Star, Now an Analyst for Turner Sports
text: Duke is the top seed in the South Region in the 2015 N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament and may have a chance to derail Kentucky. While Christian Laettner made the Shot to defeat Kentucky in the 1992 East Regional final, he never would have had the chance without the Pass, an 80-foot inbounds toss from Grant Hill.

headline: App Smart | Tech Your Way To Fitness
text: There are numerous calorie counters and exercise tracking apps available. Let your phone be your guide to better fitness and nutrition.

headline: Video Feature: Apps for Tracking Fitness and Losing Weight
text: LIKE many of you, I’m trying to shake off the winter doldrums, so I’ve discovered a few apps that help turn fitness into a quantifiable part of daily life.

headline: No Business Like Show Business (Personal)
text: I’m at SXSW; saw my first couple of sets last night. And right away I had a demonstration of why you want to see live performances.

headline: After Aide Quits, Walker Faces Some Conservative Criticism
text: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin is being criticized by some conservatives after his digital aide Liz Mair resigned over intemperate Twitter posts about the sacred status of the Iowa caucuses in the presidential nominating process.

headline: Crowdfunded Entrepreneurs, Tripped Up by the Taxman
text: Jenny Wecker, a fledgling Salt Lake City entrepreneur, had a hit on her hands at the end of December: She collected $42,000 in pledges from the crowdfunding site Kickstarter for more than 300 orders of a stylish diaper bag she had designed.

headline: Modern and Postmodern Recessions
text: As I mentioned yesterday, Romer and Romer have a new paper questioning the claim that recoveries are always slow after financial crises — and certainly slow recovery isn’t inevitable.

headline: Why Does Dick Cheney Keep Talking?
text: As I read the incredibly long interview with Dick Cheney published by Playboy Magazine yesterday, filled with his usual rewriting of history and sneering attacks on President Obama, the big question that came to mind was: Why do an interview with Mr. Cheney at this point at all? And, relatedly: Why does Mr. Cheney feel this endless need to maintain a public profile?

headline: SXSW Music 2015: The First Day’s Worthy Showcases
text: Some worthy showcases from the first day of the SXSW Music festival:

headline: Pope Francis to Speak at U.N. During Annual Gathering of World Leaders
text: Pope Francis, an outspoken advocate for the rights of the poor, will visit the United Nations during its annual conclave of world leaders in September, Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon announced Wednesday. Francis will be the fourth pope to visit the United Nations in its 70-year history.

headline: PlayBuzz Rides Quizzes and Lists to $16 Million in Financing
text: PlayBuzz, a website and online platform for creating quizzes, lists and surveys, which has been ranked as one of the most shared sites on Facebook, said on Wednesday that it had raised $16 million in a fresh round of financing.

headline: Dissident Journalist in Yemen Is Shot and Killed
text: CAIRO — One of Yemen’s best-known dissident journalists, who survived beatings and imprisonment under the former authoritarian government, was shot and killed on Wednesday by unidentified gunmen outside his home in the capital, Sana, according to witnesses and officials.

headline: Both Sides in ‘Blurred Lines’ Copyright Suit Signal a Continuing Battle
text: The “Blurred Lines” case has resulted in one of the biggest jury verdicts in the history of music copyright, and it’s not closed yet.

headline: Review: ‘Hunchback of Notre Dame’ at Paper Mill Playhouse
text: MILLBURN, N.J. — Granted, I didn’t actually tally them up, but the words “Kyrie eleison” — that’s Greek for “Lord have mercy” — seem to be sung more frequently in the musical version of “The Hunchback of Notre Dame” at the Paper Mill Playhouse here than they are in many a Mass. Which is saying something, if you’ve heard a few Masses in your day.

headline: Nicole Najafi’s Marfa Myths Encounters, From Dev Hynes to a New Tequila Drink
text: The founder of the year-old brand with a cult following, Industry Standard, shares pictures from her weekend adventure in West Texas’s picturesque high desert city.

headline: Janet Yellen Isn’t Going to Raise Interest Rates Until She’s Good and Ready
text: The key words in Janet L. Yellen’s news conference Wednesday were rather pithy, at least by central bank standards. “Just because we removed the word ‘patient’ from the statement doesn’t mean we are going to be impatient,” Ms. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said.

headline: Corners of American Life
text: The playwright Lisa D’Amour is busy all over the country.

headline: Facts & Figures: New Yorkers’ Punishing Commutes
text: New York City has earned a dubious honor: Its residents spend more time commuting, on average, than residents of any other major city in the country, according to a report issued by the city comptroller’s office. This news comes just a few weeks after New Yorkers learned that subway delays had increased more than 45 percent between 2013 and 2014.

headline: Review: Kate Tempest, a Young Poet Conjuring Ancient Gods
text: A wunderkind rapper and spoken word performer equally influenced by Wu-Tang Clan and Joyce, Bukowski and Blake; an English poet whose musical sense of language bridges the worlds of rap and traditional lyric verse; a fan favorite at the Glastonbury music festival who became the youngest winner of the Ted Hughes poetry prize. Such dichotomies not only attest to the 29-year-old Kate Tempest’s gift for shattering — and transcending — convention and conventional genres, but they also underscore the tensions and contradictions that fuel her dynamic art.

headline: Mets Are Looking Like Lumberjacks (With Smoother Swings)
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Over the off-season, like any man on hiatus from work, Noah Syndergaard did not shave every day. He had some stubble when he came here in January to train with a group of Mets. Then he saw Bobby Parnell and Josh Edgin and their substantial beards, and Vic Black’s beard on social media, and he decided to commit to growing his own.

headline: Fed Removes Promise to Be ‘Patient’
text: Janet L. Yellen, chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, said that while it was unlikely that the Fed would raise a key interest rate at its next meeting in April, there might be increases later.

headline: Federal Employee Will Not Face Criminal Charges in Drone Crash at White House
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department said Wednesday that it would not criminally charge a federal employee who was operating a hobbyist’s drone that crashed on the South Lawn of the White House in January.

headline: Artek Celebrates the German Harpsichord
text: Bach’s music, played on a harpsichord representing his time and place: as natural as this may seem, it is an infrequent event, at least in New York. The Artek ensemble made that point strongly over the weekend with Harpsichords of Germany, a little festival of concerts, workshops and discussions at Immanuel Lutheran Church on the Upper East Side.

headline: Who Should Lead the New York Philharmonic? Readers Respond.
text: The classical music critics of The New York Times recently pondered who should take over as music director of the New York Philharmonic after Alan Gilbert steps down in 2017.

headline: At the Prague Marathon, History Is a Spectator
text: The Prague International Marathon starts in Staromestske Namesti, or Old Town Square, in the heart of the city, directly between Old Town Hall, with its famous astronomical clock, built in the early 15th century, and the weathered bronze monument of Jan Hus and his followers. Hus, the Charles University philosophy professor and preacher who was burned at the stake as a heretic in 1415, stands stately and tall in the center of the square. You half expect to see a starter’s pistol in his hand.

headline: In Israel, Opera Echoes From Rocks and Ruins
text: When Eitan Campbell, the director of Israel’s Masada National Park, first came to work at the promontory in 1972, he was taken by a small etching of a sailboat on one of the fortress’s ancient stone walls. Perhaps it was a bored Herodian soldier, sitting atop the mountain in the hot sun of 30 B.C., who spied the vessel afloat in the nearby Dead Sea and painted its likeness to pass the time.

headline: European Union Moves to Limit Special Tax Deals
text: BERLIN — European Union officials on Wednesday proposed new rules to try to discourage tax-avoidance deals with multinational corporations, which critics say give some countries unfair business advantages.

headline: The Brooklyn-Born-Raised-and-Based Artist Who Dripped Her Way to Chanel Sneakers and Car Service
text: The biggest change in Joyce Pensato’s life since her recent ascent to painterly panacea? “Oh, I only take car services now,” she giddily boasts. That’s also discounting the Chanel high-tops she splurged for recently at Barneys, but hey, she only bought them because they were comfortable. “Well, I got two pairs,” she confesses. In fact, that Uber is Pensato’s greatest quotidian extravagance at the age of 70 — or somewhere in that ballpark, a lady never tells — is revealing of a painter who not only remained in the New York art scene’s periphery until recently, but, like many women, took years to find the confidence to really be herself. “I was really isolated, I wasn’t connected to any scene, I felt so alone,” she says. It could be easy to lump Pensato into the art world’s growing trend of “discovering” artists in their golden years. But her big, brash, bold canvases of Batman, Bart Simpson and other pop-cultural totems, which have become instantly recognizable, actually are not simply the byproduct of some advanced-style fad. In fact, her current and fourth solo at New York’s Petzel Gallery, open until March 28, features the caricature motifs she’s been working in since as long as she can remember (as well a surrealist Pop-culture series of photographs she’s just beginning to explore). Though Pensato has been drawing her whole lifetime, her tale is one of a personal journey of self-expression and finding her own unbeaten path — even if “I never got off the L train,” she jokes.

headline: Scott Walker’s Bracket: More Conservative Than Jeb Bush’s
text: Scott Walker’s bracket is even more conservative than Jeb Bush’s.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
text: Israel and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Review: Ailey II Displays Acrobatic Tussles Between the Sexes
text: Across a foggy stage, illuminated from the sides, dancers run past like extras in a disaster movie, anxiously looking in every direction. This is the start of a work called “Breakthrough,” but if the dancers or their audiences are searching for an artistic one, they will search in vain.

headline: Winners in Norman Kay Platinum Pairs in New Orleans
text: NEW ORLEANS — The Norman Kay Platinum Pairs is one of the toughest events to win at the Spring North American Championships. Every entrant has to have amassed a number of platinum master points, which are awarded only in the top national championships. After two days of play, just 28 pairs qualify for the final two sessions.

headline: March 18, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Israel, Tunisia, South Sudan and the United States.

headline: SXSW Music 2015: Playing Unpaid, and Driving for Lyft (for a Paycheck)
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Like so many other musicians, Kervens Joseph, an aspiring rapper known as Acafool, came to the South by Southwest Music and Media Conference here to make contacts in the industry by playing a handful of unpaid concerts. “Just for the exposure,” he said on Wednesday, as the music portion of the festival kicked into gear following the film and interactive events.

headline: Surprise in Israel Election as Exit Polls Falter
text: JERUSALEM — Israelis woke up to a surprise on Wednesday morning, having gone to bed the night before with the results of their national elections in a near tie.

headline: Philippine Airlines Resumes Flights to New York
text: After a nearly 18-year hiatus, Philippine Airlines, also known as PAL, has restored service between Manila and New York City.

headline: ‘Empire’ vs. Madonna in Battle for No. 1
text: What counts as a No. 1 album? These days the answer — or at least the way the music industry tries to spin the question — is sometimes open to interpretation.

headline: Microsoft Backs Further Away From Selling Software
text: Microsoft dismantled another piece of its old way of doing business on Wednesday.

headline: Nicole Najafi’s Marfa Myths Encounters, From Dev Hynes to a New Tequila Drink
text: “I don’t know what it is, but the sky there is just legendary,” says Nicole Najafi about Marfa, Texas. “It’s so blue and so clear.” Of course the founder of the year-old denim brand Industry Standard noticed the cobalt-colored heavens above West Texas’s artist-populated high desert city: Blue is, predictably, her favorite color. Najafi is just back from her first trip there, for the three-day Marfa Myths Festival, curated by Ballroom Marfa and the record label Mexican Summer, that took place Friday through Sunday. “I think what makes Marfa so special, besides being a tiny town bursting with fine art and culture in the middle of nowhere, is that it is so hard to get to — the nearest airport, El Paso, is three hours away. Festivals tend to evolve into these huge, multi-faceted events that get inundated with people and morph into something totally different from what they started as. I had just assumed that would eventually be the case with Marfa; but the more I spoke to people who have been coming for many years, I learned that Marfa hasn’t changed very much. I love that.”

headline: Pakistan Steps Up Executions of Convicts, but One Gets Reprieve
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan hanged nine prisoners on Wednesday as part of a broader acceleration of executions that has drawn loud protests from human rights groups.

headline: William Pope.L Makes Statements From the Fringes
text: LOS ANGELES — It was a plaintive sight: a monumental American flag drooping so low on its pole that it would touch the ground were it not for a wood platform. The artist William Pope.L was tending to the flag carefully. He lifted the tail end, where the stripes were separated at the seams, and spread them apart, the way you might separate a girl’s long hair before braiding it.

headline: Pentagon Confirms Strike Killed Shabab Militant Leader in Somalia
text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon said Wednesday that airstrikes last week against the Shabab extremist group were successful, and that Adan Garar, a senior member of the group, had been killed in a drone strike on his vehicle.

headline: For Tug Captain, Job That Runs in Family Turns Deadly Off Long Island
text: There was rain, thick fog and an ocean swell — in other words, just another day on the water for Donald Maloney, 60, as the Sea Bear, the tugboat he was captaining, traveled along the South Shore of Long Island on Saturday.

headline: Review: Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance at David H. Koch Theater
text: Among the endlessly interesting aspects of the performing arts is the matter of physical projection. Why is it that this dancer (or singer or actor) stands and moves in a way that doesn’t read beyond a few rows of the auditorium, whereas another seems to effortlessly exude presence and legibility fit for a stadium? In dance, the difference is often more striking among companies.

headline: Brain Swelling Tied to Deaths From Malaria
text: When children die from a severe form of malaria, swelling of the brain is often what kills them, a new study finds.

headline: Natalia Osipova in the Royal Ballet’s ‘Swan Lake’
text: New York has seen the sensational Russian ballerina Natalia Osipova in a wide range of ballets — but, curiously, never in the illustrious double role of Odette-Odile in “Swan Lake.” This now changes, but on screen, not onstage. Now in her second season as a principal of the Royal Ballet in London, she recently danced the role three times at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden; the last of these, performed on Tuesday, is to be streamed to American cinemas in HD, starting tonight in East Coast theaters. (West Coast streamings occur later this month.) I saw the first, on Feb. 21, during a trip to London.

headline: Dolce & Gabbana Comments Trigger Public Outrage ... and Uncomfortable Silence
text: Over the last 30 years, Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana have dressed Madonna, designed costumes for Baz Luhrmann movies and fended off one of the most convoluted tax evasion cases in recent business history.

headline: Goldwyn Heirs to Sell Art and Hollywood Hills Mansion
text: LOS ANGELES — The art collection and Hollywood Hills mansion that for decades were a physical representation of the Goldwyn dynasty’s staying power in film are being sold following the death of Samuel Goldwyn Jr.

headline: Mercedes-Benz to Sponsor U.S. Version of Rock in Rio
text: For Mercedes-Benz, the decision to sponsor a pop festival came down to toilets, dirt and mud.

headline: Fashion’s Love Affair With the ’70s
text: Some stylish options to evoke the ’70s.

headline: In Time for Spring, Sailor Pants and More
text: Sailor pants from Kenzo, Ace & Jig and more; Donald Duck and Mickey Mouse motif printed scarves; NikeLab’s collaboration with Sacai; and Maison Margiela’s sweet daisy jewelry.

headline: The ’70s Are Back in Fashion. Again.
text: What did the ’70s feel like? As recalled by Bebe Buell, a singer and onetime habitué of that fabled hipster magnet Max’s Kansas City: “Everybody’s eyelids were very heavy. I used to chuckle to myself, thinking, ‘That’s the cannabis eye, the quaalude eye’ — the look people get when they’re feeling no pain.”

headline: Before ‘Empire,’ a Foundation Laid by ‘Platinum’
text: A family-run hip-hop label is under siege: First there are the competitors, who are stealing the label’s artists; then there are the artists themselves, who are unreliable and prideful; and finally, there’s the internal strife between brothers.

headline: Math Professor’s N.C.A.A. Bracket Tests the Value of Predicting Upsets
text: The upsets are always the tricky part of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament. The methods we have developed at Davidson College often uncover several upsets in the first round, giving us leverage in the online bracket competitions we have participated in.

headline: Cheap Thrills at Neiman Marcus’s Cut-Price Outlet Store
text: An outlet store is an awkward stepchild. It has to be close enough to the parent brand to leech some of the elder’s prestige, but not close enough to devalue it. It must attract the right customers without offending the wrong ones. Its appearance should deftly suggest, with things like paint color and lighting, a haven of cheap thrills with the possibility of hidden treasures.

headline: SXSW 2015: George Miller on the Evolution of ‘Mad Max’
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — When the director George Miller was announced and came onstage to introduce a 35mm screening of “Mad Max: The Road Warrior” here on Monday, the crowd rose instantly to their (happy) feet. Mr. Miller’s 1981 film built a grungy, postapocalyptic world that has often been imitated (and at this festival with the movie “Turbo Kid,” humorously saluted), but not quite duplicated. It is arguably the most discussed in the franchise by critics and audiences, with its blistering airy landscapes, sparse dialogue, inventive camerawork and amplified action. At the screening, the first audience member to ask a question was the director Robert Rodriguez. He kept his inquiry simple: “How the hell did you do it?”

headline: Facials for Those Who Can’t Hide All Day After
text: With the success of blowout specialists like Drybar and DreamDry, it’s scarcely surprising that similarly minded salons are proliferating, each focusing on just one service. The newest additions focus on fuss-free facials, often with unisex appeal. As with the hair services, convenience and expertise are emphasized, with prices set to encourage regular patronage, not an occasional splurge.

headline: Why a Spielberg and a Goldwyn Passed Over Their Dads’ Hollywood for Snapchat
text: When your last name is Spielberg (as in Steven) or Goldwyn (as in John, Samuel Jr. and Samuel Sr.), finding a gig that lets you work on feature-length projects headed for the silver screen needn’t be difficult.

headline: Capturing the Night in Digital Photos, Spectacularly

There will be several store exclusives, like a silver high-shine “Have a Nice Day” featherweight Ebury bag ($1,550), as well as a range of leather stick-on letters ($55) and symbols ($75) for those who prefer to personalize their message.

headline: Mascaras That Are Better for Batting
text: My eyelashes are truly pitiful. They’re so wimpy even extensions look ludicrous, yet a fake eyelash strip feels gauche. A liquid liner and coats of mascara are as good as it gets. And when it comes to mascara, I like mine gloppy — that is, a formula and brush that generously load product onto my lashes with minimal effort. If you’re the sort who prefers a natural lash look, read no further. But if you weren’t a winner in the genetic eyelash lottery, one of these mascaras may be for you.

headline: Warnings Raised of a Greek Exit From the Euro
text: PARIS — Just a few weeks ago, fears that Greece might exit the euro union subsided when Europe extended its financial bailout. But as a new war of words escalates between Athens and its creditors, talk of a “Grexit” is heating up.

headline: Netanyahu’s Win Is Good for Palestine
text: WASHINGTON — IF anyone doubted where Benjamin Netanyahu stood on the question of peace, the Israeli prime minister made himself clear just before Tuesday’s election, proclaiming that there would never be a Palestinian state on his watch. Then he decided to engage in a bit of fear-mongering against Palestinian citizens of Israel in hopes of driving his supporters to the polls. “The right-wing government is in danger,” Mr. Netanyahu announced on Election Day. “Arab voters are heading to the polling stations in droves.”

headline: G.M. Exiting Russia, for the Most Part

headline: Investment Firm Buys Stake in Activist Hedge Fund Jana Partners
text: The private equity unit of Neuberger Berman Group has bought a stake in the activist hedge fund Jana Partners, underscoring the growing popularity of investors who rattle the boards of corporate America.

headline: Sales of Streaming Music Top CDs in Flat Year for Industry
text: The American market for recorded music was flat in 2014, but income from streaming services like Spotify and Pandora has quickly grown to become a major part of the business, eclipsing CD sales for the first time, according to a report released Wednesday by the Recording Industry Association of America.

headline: Islamic Scholars Promote Sharia as an Alternative to Extremism

headline: State Department Is Asked to Explain Handling of Hillary Clinton’s Emails

headline: Rory McIlroy Commits to Practice and to Father-Son Rounds

He turned down invitations from Palmer, the tournament host, for three years, including twice when he was ranked No. 1, to spend time with his globe-trotting girlfriend, the tennis player Caroline Wozniacki, who was competing in back-to-back events in California and Florida.

headline: Palestinian Leaders See Validation of Their Statehood Effort
text: JERUSALEM — Under most circumstances, an Israeli leader’s frank admission that he would never agree to a Palestinian state would be a disaster for the Palestinian leadership. But when Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said precisely that in the heat of the recent election campaign, it seemed to have the opposite effect, validating the unilateral approach the Palestinians have decided to follow.

text: CHICAGO — A team of Cook County sheriff’s deputies starts each morning in a small office in the juvenile court building here, poring over a list of children missing from state-run foster care and group homes and searching for clues to their whereabouts.

Putin led Russia in celebrating the first anniversary of its annexation of Crimea on Wednesday with a rally and concert, Russian-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine warned that a cease-fire there was at risk of collapsing because of a dispute over political autonomy for regions in the war zone.

headline: Ebola Cases Increase in Guinea
text: The World Health Organization said Wednesday that 95 new cases of Ebola had been confirmed in Guinea in the week that ended last Sunday, the highest weekly total for that country so far this year. The other two West African countries that have been ravaged by Ebola — Sierra Leone and Liberia — showed continued improvements for the week. Sierra Leone reported 55 confirmed new cases but that was the country’s lowest weekly total since last June. Liberia reported no new confirmed cases for the third consecutive week. Wednesday was the 12th day since the last known Ebola patient in Liberia had a negative test. Forty-two days must elapse after that test before transmission of the highly contagious Ebola virus is considered to have ended in Liberia. The weekly update by the W.H.O. also said a total of 10,154 people had died from the Ebola epidemic so far, almost all of them in the three worst-affected countries.

headline: Samuel Charters, Foundational Scholar of the Blues, Dies at 85

headline: Netanyahu Will Make History
text: Well, it’s pretty clear now: Benjamin Netanyahu is going to be a major figure in Israeli history — not because he’s heading to become the longest-serving Israeli prime minister, but because he’s heading to be the most impactful. Having won the Israeli elections — in part by declaring that he will never permit a two state-solution between Israelis and Palestinians — it means Netanyahu will be the father of the one-state solution. And the one-state solution means that Israel will become, in time, either a non-Jewish democracy or Jewish non-democracy.

headline: Bergdorf Goodman Shares Recipes for Fashionable Fetes at Home
text: Bergdorf Goodman, the globally renowned retailer with one fashionable Fifth Avenue address, belongs to a rare set of iconic New York City institutions that appeal not only to tourists, but also to the most elite of locals. And there’s one floor where the department store’s casual window shoppers and seasoned regulars converge seamlessly: the seventh, in the Kelly-Wearstler designed BG Restaurant. If its powder-blue walls could talk, the fashion set’s secrets — divulged there over uptown fare, classic cocktails and afternoon tea — could probably fill a book. Instead, BG is releasing a chic little tome filled with recipes ($35, out March 24 from Harper Design). Some are from its own kitchen, and others come courtesy of the fashion designers, editors and stylists who eat there.

headline: Allen Jerkens, ‘Giant Killer’ of Horse Racing, Dies at 85

headline: Buddy Elias, Cousin of Anne Frank and Guardian of Her Legacy, Dies at 89
text: Buddy Elias, the closest living relative of Anne Frank and an ardent guardian of her legacy, died on March 16 at his home in Basel, Switzerland — a house whose attic yielded a cache of long-forgotten letters from Anne and her family that formed the basis of a recent book. He was 89.

headline: Sweden: At Least Two Are Killed as Gunfire Erupts in Restaurant
text: Several people were shot and at least two died inside a restaurant in a suburb of Sweden’s second-largest city, Gothenburg, on Wednesday night in what the police said might have been an act of gang-related violence. Ulla Brehm, a spokeswoman for the Gothenburg Police Department, said the shootings took place on the island community of Hesingen, an area with a history of “difficulties with youth gangs, drugs and violent criminals.” She said two people died in the shooting and several more were wounded and taken to hospitals. Ms. Brehm added that there was “nothing indicating that this was terrorism at all. Not at all.” The police said the shooting occurred around 10 p.m. in a popular local restaurant called Var Krog och Bar, which means “our tavern and bar” in Swedish, that is on a bustling square.

headline: ‘Empire’ Finale Review: A Sizzling End to Season One
text: It seems like a violation of Chekhov’s gun rule to put Naomi Campbell in the first act and not have her throw a phone at someone in the third. (She tore up a check instead.) But other than that, the first season of “Empire,” which ended on Fox on Wednesday, was pretty perfect.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
text: 7 P.M. (HBO) ADMISSION (2013) Tina Fey portrays Portia Nathan, an admissions officer at Princeton who seems to take a special kind of glee in controlling the fate of students applying to the university. She also has a goal of her own: to succeed the retiring dean of admissions (Wallace Shawn) and beat out her office rival (Gloria Reuben) while reclaiming Princeton’s place at the top of the U.S. News & World Report rankings. But just as her smug English-professor boyfriend (Michael Sheen) dumps her for an aggressive Virginia Woolf scholar (Sonya Walger), a fellow Dartmouth alum (Paul Rudd) comes along with an unusual student (Nat Wolff) he wants Portia to consider. “How could anyone make light of the brutal, capricious system by which our young people are judged and sorted?” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this comedy from Paul Weitz, adapted from the novel by Jean Hanff Korelitz. “I must confess that I don’t know whether to be relieved or disappointed that ‘Admission,’ which had the potential to be a sharp, satirical jab at the soft belly of middle-class anxiety, chose instead to be a warm and wacky fable of wish fulfillment.”

headline: In Japan, a Farmhouse Becomes a Journalist’s Elegy

headline: Today in Politics: Hillary Clinton Looks to Secure Labor Support
text: Good Thursday morning from Washington, where royalty will be paying a rare visit to the White House. Congress remains logjammed in many respects, but a warm moment between Senator Harry Reid of Nevada and Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky showed the Senate’s softer side. Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin is facing a backlash from conservatives over the handling of one of his aides, while two other would-be presidential front-runners are moving ahead with their pre-campaign machinations.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Nardwuar the Human Serviette
text: My favorite journalist is a shrieking British Columbian who dresses like an exploded 1970s Soviet golf catalog. He was born John Ruskin, but changed his name to Nardwuar the Human Serviette. (“Serviette” is Canadian for napkin.) He hosts a weekly radio show on CiTR Vancouver, 101.9 FM, but his best work is done on camera, in chaotic interviews with musicians that he posts on YouTube.

headline: The Brain’s Empathy Gap
text: Nyiregyhaza (pronounced NEAR-re-cha-za) is a medium-size city tucked into the northeastern corner of Hungary, about 60 miles from the Ukrainian border. It has a world-class zoo, several museums and universities and a new Lego Factory. It also has two Roma settlements, or “Gypsy ghettos.” The larger of these settlements is Gusev, a crumbling 19th-century military barracks separated from the city proper by a railway station and a partly defunct industrial zone. Gusev is home to more than 1,000 Roma. Its chief amenities include a small grocery store and a playground equipped with a lone seesaw and a swingless swing set. There’s also a freshly painted elementary school, where approximately 60 students are currently enrolled. Almost all those students are Roma and almost all of them live in Gusev.

headline: Raising Teenagers: The Mother of All Problems
text: My daughter complains that she can’t sleep. Sometimes I pass her room at 11 o’clock, at midnight, and see the light still on under the door. Inevitably, if I go in, I find her propped up in bed with her laptop, the blue haze from the screen on her face.

headline: Ferguson’s Other Shooter
text: Last Wednesday night when two police officers were shot in front of the Police Headquarters in Ferguson, Mo., Heather De Mian was on the sidewalk across the street. The headquarters has been the site of regular demonstrations since Michael Brown, 18, was killed by a Ferguson police officer, Darren Wilson, last August. Protesters had gathered to celebrate the resignation of Ferguson’s police chief after a Department of Justice report detailed systematic bias against black residents by his officers, and De Mian was broadcasting live video of the rally to the Internet from her cellphone.

headline: The Scrutiny Phase: Hillary Clinton’s Negativity Challenge
text: Sometimes, no news really is good news — or at least it’s the best news you can expect. This is especially true when you are being publicly scrutinized by a keen group of observers. Such is the dilemma of Hillary Clinton, who — before her email woes began — was being criticized for not saying enough about what she’s been up to and then for saying too much. The criticism has only intensified.

headline: Identity Crisis
text: A Wisconsin case offers the Supreme Court an opportunity to block a systemic assault on the right to vote.

headline: In Berkeley’s Warehouses, Foodies Find a New Home
text: West Berkeley’s warehouse district has long been known for high-end lumberyards, tile shops and other stores serving creative homeowners, a kind of D.I.Y. answer to the upscale showrooms of San Francisco’s Design District. Recently, the area’s large, relatively affordable spaces have begun attracting a different creative crowd: innovative culinary entrepreneurs looking to spread their wings. Even some big boys are jumping in. Last June, the Bay Area-based specialty chocolatier TCHO moved its headquarters to a 49,000-square-foot facility here. This new wave of good food purveyors is making the neighborhood a draw for foodies as well as design lovers.

headline: How I Buy Weed
text: His place is in one of those New York City neighborhoods that’s run-down but not dangerous. There’s no intercom in the building, so to open the downstairs door, you have to have your own key. He doesn’t take phone calls on either landline or cell. He doesn’t use the Internet. He stays off the grid.

headline: Stop Playing the ‘Race Card’ Card
text: So, Starbucks’ chief executive, Howard Schultz, wants us to serve the country coffee and a race dialogue.

headline: Testing a Few Good Women for Combat
text: This month, the Marine Corps began a historic experiment at its base in Twentynine Palms, Calif., to test women’s performance in combat arms. This Ground Combat Element Integrated Task Force uses high-tech tools to measure the physical performance of both men and women after a federal mandate to integrate women into all military occupational specialties — or request an exception — by January 2016. This differs from the past two decades, in which combat performance has only been measured in large-scale desert exercises. As a former Marine who was encouraged by the camaraderie of gender-integrated training, I look forward to this study’s promise to increase force readiness in a corps that is not quite 7 percent female.

headline: Morning Agenda: Jana Partners Sells Stake
text: JANA PARTNERS SELLS STAKE | Dyal Capital Partners, the private equity unit of Neuberger Berman Group, agreed on Wednesday to buy a 20 percent stake in the activist hedge fund Jana Partners, Alexandra Stevenson writes in DealBook. The stake will be passive, meaning Dyal will not have a say in Jana Partners’ day-to-day operations.

headline: N.C.A.A. Tournament 2015 Live Blog
text: Live coverage of the first round of the 2015 N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament.

headline: Paying for Workers' Training
text: If the 'skills gap' needs to be bridged, whose responsibility is it?

headline: China Issues New Guidelines to Reduce Logging
text: China will reduce logging on planted forests and eventually end logging on natural forests, under a plan published this week by the State Council, China’s cabinet.

headline: Karole Armitage’s New Dance Work Traces Steps for a Greener Path
text: It takes a committed bunhead to spend eight hours hiking over a mountain with a 13,000-foot peak just to get to ballet class. It also requires one devoted to nature. Karole Armitage is both. As a child, she spent summers at Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory in Gothic, Colo., a former ghost town from the silver mining period where her father, a biologist, did research.

headline: GoDaddy Sets Price Range for I.P.O.
text: GoDaddy, the Internet services provider known for its provocative television commercials, said on Thursday that it planned to sell shares in its initial public offering priced between $17 and $19 a share.

headline: Introducing the N.C.A.A. Bracket Comparison Table
text: If you’re playing our risk-adjusted N.C.A.A. bracket game, you still have a precious few hours before the games begin to find the best bargains on upsets you think others have overlooked.

headline: Daily Report: Suddenly, Lots of Streaming Options for Cord Cutters
text: Television fans who want to break free from a traditional TV subscription now have more options than ever to pay for what they want to watch, and how they want to watch it, Emily Steel reports.

headline: Neighbors Help Chase an Ex-Boyfriend
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Wanted: Manhattan Roommates and Space to Entertain
text: Gillian Morris disliked her living situation. She paid almost $1,000 a month “for a storage locker and a crash pad” in Brooklyn with two roommates, many roaches and a tedious commute to Manhattan. Almost as bad, the place was so small it was difficult to entertain guests there.

headline: 2 Associates of Ex-Security Chief to Face Trial Over Bribery in China
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese Communist Party’s push to extinguish the political network of a man who was once one of its most powerful officials entered a new phase on Thursday when the government announced that two of his associates would soon face trial on charges of bribery.

headline: What Not to Worry About in Teaching Young Children to Read
text: The importance of reading to children from birth. Kindergarten readiness. The various approaches to teaching reading. All of those issues have been much in the news of late (and they’re never far from the minds of parents of young children), so my “Parent-Teacher Conference” email folder is full of questions about early literacy. Fortunately, Daniel T. Willingham’s new book, “Raising Kids Who Read,” was published this month, and it addresses every single one of them.

headline: Block by Block | Union Square
text: Union Square is centrally located, conveniently reached by public transportation and its park is bustling seven days a week.

headline: Block by Block: Union Square (Video Series)
text: Union Square is the focus of the next video in our new monthly series, “Block by Block.” Watch for future installments from neighborhoods around the city.

headline: Iran Nuclear Talks Lag, With Status of New Centrifuges Another Hurdle
text: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — A dispute over what limits should be placed on the development of new types of centrifuges has emerged as a major obstacle as negotiators try to work out an initial accord on Iran’s nuclear program, Western officials said on Thursday.

headline: United Nations Investigators Accuse ISIS of Genocide Over Attacks on Yazidis
text: GENEVA — United Nations human rights investigators on Thursday leveled accusations of genocide and war crimes at the Islamic State, citing evidence that the extremist group’s fighters had sought to wipe out the Yazidi minority in Iraq.

headline: Raising Teenagers: Inevitably a Problem?
text: Rachel Cusk is a chronicler of rich, if sometimes bleak, inner lives — sometimes her own, but more often those of her fictional characters. Now, in “Raising Teenagers: The Mother of All Problems” for The New York Times Magazine, she describes her experience of watching her children evolve into people with rich inner lives of their own. These are not the inner lives of children, into which adults are sometimes welcomed, but the inner lives of teenagers, eternal protagonists in a continuing war against the old — a group that she has, in their eyes, joined.

headline: The Next Frontier: The Great Indoors
text: In 1962, the ecologist Robert Whitaker set out to categorize the different realms of life on Earth. Some were deserts, others tundra, still others tropical forests. He coined a word for these inhabited environments, one that scientists have used ever since: biomes.

headline: David Brandon Geeting Finds Irreverence in the Everyday
text: The photographer’s new monograph, “Infinite Power,” collects his joyful, surreal contemporary depictions of the mundane.

headline: In Netanyahu’s Next Knesset, a More Compatible Coalition
text: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his Likud party achieved a surprisingly strong victory in Tuesday’s election. Now, he is likely to build a right-wing coalition of 67 of the 120 members of the Knesset, Israel’s Parliament.

headline: ‘Lincoln and the Jews’ Explores Bonds With a Nation’s Growing Minority
text: ON Sept. 20, 1862, Abraham Lincoln had a lot on his mind. The Civil War was raging, and just days later he would issue the preliminary draft of the Emancipation Proclamation.

headline: Rubio Ally to Lead ‘Super PAC’ Backing His Candidacy
text: As Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, and his advisers prepare for an all-but-certain presidential run, they will have a close ally managing the “super PAC” supporting his candidacy.

headline: Well Book Club: ‘Better Than Before’
text: Every day of your life is shaped by your habits. Are you a morning or evening person? Messy or tidy? Do you eat breakfast or skip it? Drive or commute? Pack a lunch or dine out? Exercise or watch television?

headline: Day 2 of Live March Madness Coverage Begins
text: We’re back for another full day of N.C.A.A. men’s tournament games. The New York Times has reporters fanned out across the country for comprehensive coverage.

headline: 1940: Chamberlain Says No Peace
text: LONDON — Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain dropped a large lump of salt today [March 19] on all palaver about a ‘‘peace offensive,’’ which is emanating from the Continent in the wake of yesterday’s Alpine rendezvous of Benito Mussolini and Adolf Hitler.

headline: Haldi
text: The cooking of Kolkata in Curry Hill

headline: In Curry Hill, a New Kid on the Block
text: On the menu it is called an egg roll, but what arrives looks more like an elongated turnover, with squared-off ends as sharp as hospital corners. The crepelike wrap is crisp but doesn’t crackle, so that all the attention goes to the interior: lamb minced fine but still juicy and shot through with just enough chile to warm, not scar you.

headline: New Chairman for El Museo del Barrio
text: El Museo del Barrio, the oldest museum in the United States devoted to Latino art, is appointing a new board chairman. It said Michael J. Garcia, a former United States attorney who has served on the board since 2010, will succeed Tony Bechara, who is stepping down after leading the museum’s board for 15 years.

headline: Japan and China Inch Toward Mending Ties
text: TOKYO — In a small step toward a possible thaw in relations, officials from Japan and China on Thursday held their first meeting on security issues in four years, discussing the creation of a hotline to ease tensions in the East China Sea.

headline: Kasich Looks to Republican Primaries, ‘Ohio Story’ in Hand
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Gov. John R. Kasich was sipping coffee in the sun-drenched garden room of his official residence, boasting about his “Ohio story” of economic recovery, when he was told that some Republicans thought a fellow Midwestern governor, Scott Walker of Wisconsin, was more conservative. He bolted upright.

headline: The Politics of Tweets, Candor and Corn in Iowa
text: Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker’s intense focus on the Iowa caucus as his launching pad for the White House has been severely jolted by mocking comments about the state’s ballyhooed political process and iconic corn crop — observations rather proudly made by Liz Mair, a respected campaign advisor who was hired this week but then driven to resign a day later.

headline: Jeb Bush Meets Ludacris
text: Jeb Bush was in Georgia on Thursday, speaking to state lawmakers about education. But before delivering his remarks, Mr. Bush met the rapper Ludacris, who was being honored by the Legislature for his work with the Ludacris Foundation.

headline: A British Proposal to Help Control Bankruptcy Costs
text: Beginning next October, corporate reorganization professionals in Britain are going to have do something quite amazing: At the start of a case, they are going to have to estimate what their total fees will be. And if they exceed that amount, they will have to go back to the creditors and obtain further approval.

headline: A Kentucky Team and Its Star Seek Their Own Fame
text: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — The top-ranked, undefeated team from Kentucky arrived at the Final Four, wearing familiar blue and white, but the charter was a bus, not a plane. The trip took nine hours with a stop at Arby’s and a gym for practice. The team hotel is not five-star plush but Holiday Inn utility.

headline: True West
text: The purist Mark Haddawy would no sooner tweak a Haston gown than alter a great ’70s house. Even one he lives in.

headline: Boehner Says Aaron Schock’s Resignation ‘Stunned’ Him
text: Speaker John A. Boehner tends to have a good feel for his caucus, but he acknowledged on Thursday that he was surprised by the abrupt resignation this week of Representative Aaron Schock of Illinois, who had faced questions over his adherence to spending rules.

headline: $10 Million Settlement in Target Data Breach Gets Preliminary Approval
text: A federal judge on Thursday gave preliminary approval to a $10 million settlement of a lawsuit brought by customers of Target, which experienced an online attack involving confidential customer data during the holiday season in 2013.

headline: Small Dreams and Long Odds on N.C.A.A. Tournament’s First Day
text: Shortly after Hampton University defeated Manhattan on Tuesday night in the first game of the N.C.A.A. tournament, Hampton’s president, Bill Harvey, was on the phone, more proud than excited.

headline: Survivor Recounts Tunisian Museum Attack
text: An Italian survivor of a deadly attack on Wednesday recounted the ordeal from her hospital bed in Tunis.

headline: Advice on Being Left Out of Family Photos
text: When I met my boyfriend, his aunt instituted a rule that girlfriends and boyfriends not be included in family portraits until the couples are engaged. Eighteen years later, we are still together, but have decided not to marry. His aunt apologized to me ages ago. But my boyfriend’s brother still insists that I not be included in family photos. My boyfriend stood up to him, and this brother is no longer welcome in our home. But when we attend family functions, he acts friendly to me. How should I handle this?

headline: Israel’s Netanyahu Reopens Door to Palestinian State, but White House Is Unimpressed
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Thursday tried to backtrack from his pre-election declaration that no Palestinian state would be established on his watch, but his new assertions appeared to do nothing to assuage an infuriated Obama administration.

headline: Classical Playlist: Tchaikovsky, Handel, John Adams and More
text: TCHAIKOVSKY: ‘Iolanta’Anna Netrebko, Sergey Skorokhodov, Alexey Markov and other singers; Slovenian Philharmonic Orchestra, Emmanuel Villaume, conductor(Deutsche Grammophon 479 3969; two CDs)Just in time for the Metropolitan Opera’s new production of Tchaikovsky’s final opera, “Iolanta,” Deutsche Grammophon has released a winning live 2012 recording from the Philharmonie Essen in Germany featuring Anna Netrebko, the star of the Met’s production, in the title role. This tender, rich one-act fairy-tale opera tells of a young princess who has been raised by her overprotective father so that she does not realize she is blind, though something about her constricted world seems off to her. Ms. Netrebko brings an engrossing combination of aching vulnerability and vocal charisma to Iolanta. The whole cast is excellent. Best of all may be the glowing, warm playing that the conductor Emmanuel Villaume draws from the Slovenian Philharmonic Orchestra. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: On Location | London
text: A newly renovated London apartment is reminiscent of the Spring Street loft the owner had lived in during the 1980s.

headline: Powerful Afghan Police Chief Killed in Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Matiullah Khan, whose rise from local militia commander to powerful regional police chief left him one of the wealthiest and most powerful men in southern Afghanistan, was killed on Wednesday in a targeted suicide bombing in Kabul, officials said on Thursday.

headline: Hands-On Law School
text: The University of New Hampshire School of Law offers second- and third-year students the opportunity to serve a legal residency, a kind of apprenticeship that lets them participate in legal activities under supervision. Those who pass a review of their work can skip the bar exam.

headline: Bar Exam, the Standard to Become a Lawyer, Comes Under Fire
text: For decades, law school graduates have endured a stressful rite of passage, spending the first 10 weeks after classes end taking cram courses in the arcane details of the law before sitting down for the grueling, days-long bar exam. Those who do not pass cannot practice law, at least in nearly all the states and the District of Columbia that consider the exam the professional standard.

headline: SXSW 2015: Films That Were the Talk of the Festival
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — From intimate indies to blockbuster debuts, this year’s South by Southwest film festival was again a place for discoveries.

headline: At Corison Winery, the Focus on Napa Cabernet Never Blurs
text: Napa Valley is not known for its reserve, subtlety and understatement. Flamboyance, yes, as well as grandiosity, weight, excess and the wines that epitomize these traits. Yet before Napa wineries began to take architectural cues from Las Vegas, the Valley was largely a quiet agricultural center that let its wines speak for themselves.

headline: ‘Empire’ Finale Draws Season-High Viewership
text: After last week’s episode of “Empire,” a Fox teaser warned viewers: Don’t miss the two-hour finale, or you’ll almost certainly risk being spoiled.

headline: Japanese Police Arrest Man Accused of Threatening to Bomb U.S. Embassy and Base
text: TOKYO — The Japanese police said on Thursday that they had arrested a 52-year-old man on suspicion of threatening to bomb the United States Embassy in Tokyo and an American military base on Okinawa.

headline: Review: In ‘Hierba Mala Nunca Muere,’ Castro Rails Against Change
text: The old bird is understandably confused. When he was a boy, Havana was sometimes called the Paris of the Caribbean. He thought he had put an end to that capitalist decadence, but now that he’s in his late 80s, some guy is suddenly trying to open Cuba back up again. And the guy is black.

headline: Frank Kaminsky Leads the Wisconsin Badgers
text: The team’s top scorer, rebounder and playmaker is a 7-footer who developed himself from a gawky teenager to a national player of the year candidate.

headline: Senior Banker Predicts Robust Deal-Making Will Continue
text: NEW ORLEANS — If the opening comments from one of the senior deal makers at the Tulane Corporate Law Institute here are to be believed, the good times for mergers and acquisitions will continue to roll.

headline: Curtain Call | Women’s Fall 2015
text: To mark the conclusion of the Women’s Fall 2015 shows, T catalogs the bows of some fashion visionaries.

headline: My Choice, My Voice: Lauren
text: tk

headline: Karly Koch’s “Voicing My Choices”
text: tk

headline: ‘Fatal Attraction’
text: Images from two exhibitions of works by the artist Piotr Uklanski.

headline: Review: In ‘Fatal Attraction,’ Piotr Uklanski’s Unblinking Gaze
text: As bad-boy artists go, Piotr Uklanski has always been fairly elusive. During his 20-year career he has tended to do something startling — if not shocking — and then lie low, reappearing after a decent interval. And when he does, he is often somewhere else entirely, doing something unlike anything he’s done before.

headline: Scientists Solve a Puzzle: Cosmic Dust Comes From Supernovae
text: Cosmic dust containing elements like iron, carbon or oxygen plays an important role in the formation of planets and stars. But early galaxies consisted only of gas, and the dust appeared later. Where the dust came from has long been a mystery.

headline: The First Signs of Spring
text: Plants in bloom and Mister Softee trucks straining at the leash mean spring is around the corner.

headline: Loosening a Founder’s Iron Grip
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: A Jewelry Journey Through Rome
text: Adventures in Art, a New York City company specializing in art and jewelry excursions, has a new getaway to Rome highlighting the city’s jewelry traditions: “Rome: From Etruscan Gold to Bulgari Gems,” a three-night trip from June 4 to  7.

headline: Russell Simmons Plans Musical on Early Days of Hip-Hop
text: The pioneering rap impresario Russell Simmons is aiming to bring a hip-hop revue to Broadway late next year. The musical, currently titled “The Scenario,” will feature renditions of classics from the 1980s and ’90s.

headline: S.E.C. Chief Sees Virtue in Activist Investors
text: NEW ORLEANS — For several years, much of the debate at the big deal maker conference here has been whether shareholder activism is a blight on the corporate landscape.

headline: FIFA Confirms Winter World Cup for 2022
text: FIFA confirmed that the 2022 World Cup in Qatar would be played in the winter, announcing Thursday that its governing executive committee had set the date of that year’s final for Dec. 18.

headline: Wisconsin’s Frank Kaminsky Takes Pride in Growing Up
text: LISLE, Ill. — A faded school crest overlooks the A-frame Catholic school gymnasium where exposed metallic heating ducts and off-white bricks run the length of the basketball floor below.

headline: Syracuse’s Jim Boeheim Says Penalties Are ‘Unduly Harsh’
text: In his first news conference since the N.C.A.A. penalized his program on March 6, Jim Boeheim, the men’s basketball coach at Syracuse, took responsibility for some of the transgressions revealed in a 94-page N.C.A.A. report, but he also lashed out at the penalties, which he called “unduly harsh.”

headline: Will Republicans Still Support a Two-State Solution Even if Netanyahu Doesn’t?
text: For the last decade and a half, Democratic and Republican politicians have, at least officially, agreed on the broad contours of what an end to the decades-long, on-again-off-again peace process in Israel and the Palestinian territories should look like. The two-state solution, as it’s called, was formally endorsed by George W. Bush early in his presidency and was formally agreed to by Israeli, Palestinian and American officials in 2007. Even the Republican Party platform declares, “We envision two democratic states — Israel with Jerusalem as its capital and Palestine — living in peace and security.”

headline: Restoration Politics
text: The Continental chic of Camelot in the ’60s, the gilded splendor of the Reagan-era ’80s — but what about a new take on the unique charms of Gerald and Betty Ford’s ’70s Southern California dreaming?

headline: Dante de Blasio, Mayor’s Fast-Talking Son, Is a State Debate Champion
text: In a classroom in Lower Manhattan, two pairs of debaters fired off a rapid rat-tat-tat-tat-tat of ideas, battling it out before a panel of judges for the mantle of state champion in varsity policy debate.

headline: Ex-Trader Sentenced to 19 Months for Insider Trading in London
text: LONDON — Julian Rifat, a former trader arrested nearly five years ago in what was then described as the largest crackdown on insider trading here, was sentenced to more than a year in prison on Thursday after he pleaded guilty in November to insider trading.

headline: A Look at Revolution
text: The Singapore-based watch magazine, which has the largest print circulation in the world, says it has to keep advancing on the digital front, too.

headline: Recipe Lab: Roast Lamb
text: Julia Moskin roasts lamb slathered in a mixture of butter, anchovies, rosemary and garlic.

headline: The Designers of Fall/Winter 2015 Fashion Week Take Their Bows
text: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of New York, Milan and Paris Fashion Weeks, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 31 fashion visionaries.

headline: Verbatim: Just Wanna Have Fun
text: — Hillary Rodham Clinton, speaking in Atlantic City at an event for camp professionals.

headline: A Tech Column on Wearable Gadgets Draws Fire as ‘Pseudoscience’
text: Nick Bilton writes a tech-related column called Disruptions, but the name might have been changed to Eruptions this week, given the way readers and others reacted.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Prince Meets the President
text: President Obama offered Prince Charles a warm greeting at the White House, telling his guest how beloved he and his family are in the United States.

headline: Notre Dame Breaks Through, Holding Off Northeastern
text: PITTSBURGH — There is a perception about the Notre Dame men’s basketball program, and it is steeped in fact. It is that, come March, come the N.C.A.A. tournament, the Fighting Irish cannot figure out how to win.

headline: French Proposal on Models’ Weights Clashes With Labor Laws, Opponents Say
text: PARIS — Lawmakers on the French Parliament’s health committee said Thursday that they had rejected two provisions of an anorexia prevention measure but left open the possibility that an amended version could win approval when the provisions are debated anew by the full National Assembly in early April.

headline: Scientists Seek Ban on Method of Editing the Human Genome
text: A group of leading biologists on Thursday called for a worldwide moratorium on use of a new genome-editing technique that would alter human DNA in a way that can be inherited.

headline: Lindsey Vonn Wins World Cup Super-G Title to Tie Career Record
text: Lindsey Vonn bought a house last year in her longtime home, Vail, Colo. After moving in, she asked a contractor to build a trophy case above the fireplace for her collection of World Cup crystal globes, the hefty decorative awards given to the winners of season-long ski racing championships.

headline: Body of David Bird, Missing Wall Street Journal Reporter, Is Found
text: A body pulled from the Passaic River in New Jersey this week was identified on Thursday as that of a reporter for The Wall Street Journal who disappeared in January 2014 while out walking near his home, officials said.

headline: No. 14-Seeded U.A.B. Surges to Stun Iowa State
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Jerod Haase’s last game as a college player was in Birmingham, Ala., in 1997 in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s round of 16. His Kansas team was 34-1, with its only loss having come in double overtime against Missouri, but the Jayhawks were stunned by a nine-loss Arizona team in the tournament, 85-82. Haase knows all about the sting of defeat and the sudden, unexpected packing of bags in March.

headline: Letters: The Content of Character
text: The Content of Character

headline: Putting a Breakup of Bank of America to a Shareholder Vote
text: The idea of big American banks breaking up will finally get input from the public.

headline: Touch Time, for the Blind and Everyone Else
text: LONDON — Serving in Afghanistan, Lt. Bradley Snyder, working in a United States Navy bomb-disposal squad, stepped on an improvised explosive device while trying to aid two victims of another blast. The explosion robbed him of his sight.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Marriage, Memory and Sex
text: Take the Quiz

headline: Yankees’ Pinstripes May Be Slimming, but a Nutritionist Helps
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The most famous player in Yankees history had the most infamous diet. Babe Ruth was said to subsist, at least in part, on hot dogs and beer, the fuel that added to his legendary persona as a charismatic, fun-loving superstar.

headline: Objects of Discretion
text: The exceedingly private philanthropist Maja Hoffmann shares fragments of her exquisite personal collection of art and design.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ Off to Hot Start at Broadway Box Office
text: “Hamilton,” the buzzy musical biography of an American founding father, is off to a strong start at the Broadway box office.

headline: SXSW Music 2015: Ancient Songs With a Rocking Beat
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — What may have been the oldest music at SXSW rocked as hard (if not as loudly) as anything newer. It had deep, unstoppable beats, instantly grasped melodies and vocals with a fervent bite. It was a Wednesday night set by Mai Dhai, a singer from rural Pakistan performing ancient songs she learned from her mother. She drummed as she sang, along with two more drummers and a harmonium player whose counter-melodies darted constantly around her voice. Ms. Dhai is a member of the Manganiyar tribe from the Tharparkar desert, with an Islamic culture that has a long tradition of female musicians performing at shrines and festivities.

headline: Elon Musk Says Self-Driving Tesla Cars Will Be in the U.S. by Summer
text: For many drivers who commute long distances, the prospect of owning a self-driving car — where a driver takes his hands off the wheel and feet off the gas — has been an elusive dream.

headline: The Judge’s Decision to Keep Garner Evidence Sealed
text: In a 12-page decision, Justice William E. Garnett of State Supreme Court decided against releasing evidence, testimony and instructions presented to the grand jury in the Eric Garner case.

headline: Ride in Mercedes’s F 015 Driverless Car
text: A sneak peek inside the Mercedes F 015 concept car, the company’s vision of a driverless future. The design turns the car into a shared social space where any passenger can interact with the vehicle.

headline: In Eric Garner Case, Judge Rules Against Releasing Grand Jury Evidence
text: A judge ruled on Thursday against releasing the evidence presented to the grand jury that decided not to indict a New York police officer in the chokehold death of Eric Garner.

headline: Video Feature: Inside the F 015, Mercedes’s Self-Driving Car
text: ALAMEDA, Calif. — AUTONOMOUS car technology is now so far along that some auto executives have said they expect a completely self-driving car — one that requires no human intervention — to appear in public use within five years.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Kumiko’

headline: Big in Japan, Tokyobike Gets a Permanent New York Home
text: He just wanted to buy a bike. That’s the short answer to the question of how Dean Di Simone, the founder of the New York digital agency Tender Creative, and his wife, the model-slash-marketer Juliana Rudell Di Simone, became the Stateside keepers of Tokyobike, which celebrates the opening of its first permanent shop at the corner of Bowery and Prince tomorrow. Di Simone first became acquainted with the brand on a trip to Tokyo in 2003. Six years later, he tried to buy one of the lightweight, custom-fit bikes at an outpost in London’s Shoreditch neighborhood, but was promptly turned away. “At the time, it was frustrating,” says Di Simone; company policy held that no customer should assemble his own two-wheeler. (Which, in turn, means no overseas shipments.)

headline: Monica Lewinsky Is Back, but This Time It’s on Her Terms
text: Monica Lewinsky was sitting in a Manhattan auditorium last month, watching teenage girls perform a play called “Slut.” Ms. Lewinsky was in blue jeans and a blazer, her hair pulled out of her face with a small clip. She was wiping away tears.

headline: Walker Reassures S. Carolinians That Raising Money Won’t Be a Problem
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. – Whenever he meets a new room of Republican voters, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin usually starts off by thanking them for their prayers. He did so on Thursday afternoon, during his first swing through South Carolina as a potential presidential candidate – but he also thanked them for their money, and bragged a bit in case anyone doubted his ability to raise funds nationally for a White House bid.
