headline: The Zellner Brothers Narrate a Scene From ‘Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter’
text: In this video, Nathan Zellner and David Zellner discuss a sequence from their drama “Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter,” starring Rinko Kikuchi as a Japanese woman who is obsessed with the movie “Fargo” and believes the money buried in the film actually exists. She sets out on a quest to the Midwest on a search for it. In this scene, before her departure, she says goodby to her beloved friend, a pet bunny Bunzo.

headline: Alfredo Jaar: ‘Shadows’
text: This is the second project in a trilogy by Alfredo Jaar exploring the power and politics of famous images. The first installation focused on a 1993 Pulitzer Prize-wining photograph of a starving child in Sudan; here Mr. Jaar has chosen the Dutch photographer Koen Wessing’s “Estelí, Nicaragua, September 1978” (1978), which shows two women at the moment they learn their father has been murdered.

headline: Betty Parsons: ‘A Life in Art’
text: This show has a big title for being fairly small: a total of 19 gouaches and painted-driftwood sculptures by Betty Parsons (1900-1982), the revered New York art dealer, advocate of Abstract Expressionism and an artist in her own right. Five of the pieces were seen in a larger show in 2010 at the recently closed Spanierman Gallery. But that show was the first sizable one in New York devoted to Ms. Parsons’s work since the 1980s, and who knows when another will come along.

headline: Arizona Shoots Past Texas Southern
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — The weight of national championship aspirations did not slow second-seeded Arizona on Thursday, as the Wildcats breezed to a 93-72 victory over No. 15 Texas Southern.

headline: Bank of New York Mellon Will Settle Currency Trade Case for $714 Million
text: The Bank of New York Mellon will pay $714 million to settle accusations that it cheated government pension funds and other investors for more than a decade, federal and state authorities announced on Thursday. It is part of a deal requiring the bank to dismiss some employees and make fuller public disclosures of its foreign exchange operation.

headline: Vera Iliatova: ‘For Now, at Once’
text: In her dreamy paintings of girls in verdant landscapes, Vera Iliatova toys with conventional associations of nature, femininity, childhood and innocence. The foregrounds of her pictures are occupied by lush, colorful floral bouquets; forests, meadows, hills and dales fill the backgrounds. Ms. Iliatova paints these with a deft, brushy touch that gives the surfaces of her canvases a sensuously tactile presence.

headline: Carolee Schneemann: ‘Part One’
text: Established in 2010 by Hunter College, the Artist’s Institute is a combination of exhibition gallery, historical laboratory and studio space dedicated to meditating on the work of one contemporary artist at a time for roughly one semester. Artists who’ve been in the spotlight — or under the microscope — have included Jo Baer, Jimmie Durham, Rosemarie Trockel and Haim Steinbach. Carolee Schneemann is the subject of attention this spring, and a richer one would be hard to find.

headline: Remains of 9/11 Victim at World Trade Center Are Identified
text: Matthew David Yarnell, a 26-year-old employee of Fiduciary Trust Company International, has been positively identified as a victim of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.

headline: Review: ‘Paint Your Wagon,’ Starring Keith Carradine, Opens at Encores!
text: Men in weathered woolens and suspenders roister vigorously around the stage, hungry for booze, gold and women — not necessarily in that order — in the jovial production of “Paint Your Wagon” being presented as part of the City Center Encores! series. There’s but a single gal in the gold-mining encampment where the show takes place, at least until the end of the first act, when a stagecoach brings a bevy of working (and dancing) girls to town and the boys throw out a lusty cheer.

headline: Suzan Frecon: ‘Oil Paintings and Sun’
text: Suzan Frecon came to Minimalism late, but she has persisted and her work has a deeper, quieter kind of originality: a sense of unassailable integrity and the fullness of form. Now in her early 70s, Ms. Frecon has for over three decades been homing in on one or two simple shapes seen against one color. Her newest paintings have two panels whose division forms a kind of horizon line, while the shapes themselves imply curved hillocks, small mountains, crystalline ponds, low-hanging clouds and rising or setting suns. Despite the use of ‘Sun” in this show’s title, her colors, which she grinds and mixes herself, tend toward dark. Rust, blues and greens prevail here with results that seem like nocturnes. They combine Rothko’s color at its most winey and most somber with the carefully modulated geometries of Ellsworth Kelly, but are always clearly handmade, painted with a meditative quality that evokes Morandi.

headline: Op-Talk: How Domestic Violence Costs Women Money
text: Campaigns to fight domestic violence typically focus on the physical and psychological effects of such violence. Now a new study highlights another area that both public officials and employers need to consider: the impact of domestic violence on survivors’ finances.

headline: Marsha Cottrell at Eleven Rivington
text: Born under another sign, Marsha Cottrell might have been a consumer tester for laser printers rather than an artist. Instead, she has created a body of work that harnesses the power of office equipment, treating it like a paintbrush or master printer’s tool.

headline: Peter Dundas Appointed as Creative Director of Roberto Cavalli
text: The Norwegian-born designer Peter Dundas will be the new creative director of Roberto Cavalli, the company announced today.

headline: Free Online Courses Keep Retirees in the Know
text: Mary Lou Russell has a passion for learning. Since retiring 10 years ago, the 79-year-old former grant maker has taken more than a dozen classes on subjects including classical music and appreciating Andy Warhol. She has attended most of her classes from her Manhattan living room.

headline: Not Digital Art, but Art Learned Digitally
text: Having worked as an art teacher for 50 years, Lois DeWitt decided to try offering drawing and painting classes online. So in 2008 she established a website — Free Online Art Classes — that now attracts about 15,000 visitors a month from places like Indonesia, Africa and Germany to courses that include instruction in watercolors, oil painting and “artful lighting.” (Ms. DeWitt also happens to work in the lighting department of a Home Depot store on Sundays.)

She had taught courses at New York University and at the Bread Loaf Writers’ Conference at Middlebury College but was finding it difficult to maintain a consistent class schedule while fulfilling her obligations as a staff writer for The New Yorker.

Near the busy intersection of Wilshire and Westwood Boulevards, nearly 200 locals have gathered to tune out the distractions of modern Los Angeles — and tune into themselves.

First, Mr. Gates shows Mr. Rose the Codex Leicester, a 500-year-old Leonardo da Vinci manuscript that Mr. Gates bought in 1994 for $30 million.

headline: Luring Working Executives to M.B.A. Programs

Through much of the winter, nearby St. Joseph’s University took advantage of the inevitable delays to place a billboard promoting its executive M.B.A. program along the curve.

headline: Review: ‘Jauja,’ a Desperate Odyssey in the Argentine Desert
text: The films of the Argentine director Lisandro Alonso often feel longer than they are. That isn’t a bad thing, necessarily. Too many movies hurtle forward on fast editing and breathless plotting, and too much of life goes by in a blur. The characters in four of Mr. Alonso’s features — “La Libertad,” “Los Muertos,” “Liverpool” and now “Jauja” — undertake difficult journeys, at least partly on foot, across hostile terrain. Following them through long takes and static shots accompanied by abundant silence and sparse dialogue and music, the viewer feels the weight of time. This can be uncomfortable, but the risk of tedium can deliver a special kind of intensity, a slowing of the metabolism and an awakening of the senses.

headline: Sphinx Organization’s Aaron P. Dworkin Will Go to University of Michigan
text: Since the violinist Aaron P. Dworkin founded the Sphinx Organization nearly two decades ago to encourage diversity in the stubbornly homogeneous field of classical music, he has held competitions and tours to showcase young black and Latino musicians, started educational programs and urged conservatories and orchestras to be more inclusive.

headline: Review: Jill Alexander Essbaum’s ‘Hausfrau,’ a Good Wife, With a Few Caveats
text: Have you heard the one about the only time a Swiss train runs late? Punch line: “When someone jumps in front of one.” That bit appears on the second page of Jill Alexander Essbaum’s “Hausfrau,” and I wish it were supposed to be funny only when considering what she really intends. Ms. Essbaum has named her married, dissatisfied heroine Anna, as in Karenina. So the train reference qualifies as an earnest literary allusion. And like all the rib-elbowing indications that this Anna has destructive traits, from promiscuity to pyromania, it qualifies as one of this graceless book’s ideas of foreshadowing. Big time.

headline: Review: ‘Bloodline,’ on Netflix, Depicts a Family With Nasty Secrets
text: At first glance, “Bloodline” looks ominously like a poignant family drama: Members of a close-knit Southern clan gather at a gracious seaside retreat to celebrate their formidable but aging patriarch. There are anniversary cookouts and multigenerational beach volleyball, and it looks awful.

headline: Review: In ‘The Gunman,’ Sean Penn Plays a Remorseful Sniper on the Run
text: It’s not a hard and fast rule, but in general when the main character, sometime in the third act, says, “I did some bad things ... ” and stares off into the middle distance, the implied end of the sentence is “including this movie.” I take no particular pleasure in reporting that this is the case in “The Gunman,” a globe-trotting action thriller and also, in passing, a melodrama of male sexual jealousy, an indictment of Western meddling in Africa and a concussion-awareness public service announcement.

headline: Review: ‘Richard Estes: Painting New York City’ Features Works in Abstract Realism
text: Painting used to be as much a craft as an art. That began to change in the late 19th and early 20th centuries as artists like van Gogh, Picasso and countless others shifted the focus from technical virtuosity to the expression of individual sensibility and intellect. Bravura skills with the brush, like those of Bouguereau and other academicians, became anathema for the early Modernists.

headline: Review: ‘Backcountry,’ a Wilderness Survival Thriller
text: For most of its 91 tense, uneven minutes, “Backcountry” plays on your nerves like a kid flicking you with a rubber band. You feel the sting (thwack, thwack), but it doesn’t bother you. Over time, though, the kid grows meaner, and the flicks grow harder, faster, too, and you realize that they’re keeping time with the thudding of your heart (thump, thump). The writer and director Adam MacDonald was born in 1977, two years after “Jaws” (chomp, chomp) forced everyone out of the water. He’s set out to have you now steer clear of the lovely, dark and deep woods, too.

headline: Review: ‘Insurgent’ Brandishes a Tougher Shailene Woodley
text: Tighter, tougher and every bit as witless as its predecessor, “The Divergent Series: Insurgent” — the second segment in the cycle — arrives with a yawn and ends with a bang. In between, bodies run, leap and fall amid nuzzling lips, blasting bullets and periodic story turns that make the movie a modest cultural artifact if one largely devoid of aesthetic interest. At this point, the heroine, Tris Prior (Shailene Woodley), can easily lock and load, having been trained by a thuggishly stylish faction, Dauntless, whose members wear the usual blah-blah black, tats and piercings and guard this dystopian world. “They’re our protectors, our soldiers, our police,” Tris says of them in the first movie, if also “crazy.”

This bogus character, introduced in a prologue set in 1971 as an intense, hungry young folk singer with a resemblance to the young Bob Dylan, is the latest in a lengthening Hollywood roster of rambunctious old goats.

headline: Bloodshed in Tunisia
text: With their massacre of at least 20 people from five countries at the National Bardo Museum in Tunis, the gunmen who carried out the rampage on Wednesday struck at Tunisia’s economic lifeblood, the tourism industry; its government; and the international community. The attack lays bare the extent to which extremists who are spreading through the region now threaten Tunisia, the only success story of the Arab Spring.

headline: Review: ‘Growing Up and Other Lies’ Stares Down the Advent of Adulthood
text: “Growing Up and Other Lies,” the story of four friends in their 30s who walk from the northern tip of Manhattan to the Battery (with detours), is nominally a buddy comedy. But the movie, written and directed by Danny Jacobs and Darren Grodsky, is so steeped in angst that you share its characters’ deep-seated dread of a future that looks anything but rosy. The prospect of parenthood is especially daunting.

headline: Sam Saunders, a Descendant of a King of Golf, Carves His Own Path
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — The starter on the 10th hole, Butch Cronon, took particular delight in announcing the first player in the final threesome of the morning wave Thursday at the Arnold Palmer Invitational. “From Fort Collins, Colo.,” Cronon intoned, “please welcome home, Sam Saunders.”

headline: Review: In Eugène Green’s ‘La Sapienza,’ a Search of Ideals of Civilization
text: The characters in “La Sapienza,” Eugène Green’s new film, tend to look directly into the camera when they speak, to speak clearly and grammatically, and to refrain from interrupting one another. The rhythm of the editing is similarly deliberate: The camera looks at one person, then another, and patiently surveys a landscape or the interior of an old and magnificent building. This graceful, unhurried style, with its blend of austerity and artifice and its roots in classical French theatrical traditions, is Mr. Green’s signature. American by birth and ardently European by residence and vocation, he elevates formal decorum to a moral principle. “La Sapienza,” quiet and conversational as it seems, is a passionate defense of — and perhaps also an elegy for — an old and dignified ideal of civilization.

headline: Amazon Wins Approval to Test Delivery Drones Outdoors
text: SEATTLE — Federal regulators have given Amazon a green light to begin testing drones, but it will most likely take years before the online retailer can start delivering packages from the air to peoples’ homes.

text: LOS ANGELES — Since the arrests of a dozen students here on suspicion of sex-related crimes, members of the Venice High School community have been doing some soul-searching about what they could have done to prevent the assaults — some of which the police said took place on campus — and what they can do to try to ensure that nothing similar happens again.

headline: Review: In ‘She’s Lost Control,’ Crossing Boundaries in Pursuit of Intimacy
text: “She’s Lost Control,” Anja Marquardt’s chilly portrait of a behavioral psychologist who works as a sexual surrogate, is so studiedly bleak it will pour ice water on anyone’s fantasies of earning a living as an erotic healer.

headline: T-Mobile Policy Violated Labor Law, Judge Rules
text: A National Labor Relations Board judge ruled on Wednesday that the employment policies of the wireless carrier T-Mobile violated United States labor law by restricting workers’ ability to organize and other rights, setting a potentially important precedent for unions.

headline: Crowds and Long Delays Fray Subway System and Riders’ Nerves
text: Fares are about to go up. Delays are driving riders to distraction. And on a recent evening, Ian Nolan’s train was out of service.

headline: Amazon Letter to the Federal Aviation Administration
text: This letter describes Amazon’s plans for a drone delivery system.

headline: Port Authority Agrees on the Need to Replace Its Bus Terminal, but Little Else
text: The commissioners of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey agreed on Thursday that the 65-year-old bus terminal in Manhattan that their agency operates is an overcrowded eyesore that cries out to be replaced. And there the consensus ended.

headline: McConnell Urges States to Help Thwart Obama’s ‘War on Coal’
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky has begun an aggressive campaign to block President Obama’s climate change agenda in statehouses and courtrooms across the country, arenas far beyond Mr. McConnell’s official reach and authority.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 19, 2015
text: March 19, 2015

headline: Black Man’s Body Found Hanging From Tree in Mississippi
text: NEW ORLEANS — Federal, state and local law enforcement agencies are investigating the death of a black man who was found hanging from a tree in a small Mississippi town on Thursday morning.

headline: Review: ‘Lost and Love’ (‘Shi Gu’) Stars Andy Lau as a Man Searching for His Lost Son
text: Peng Sanyuan’s “Lost and Love” could ably serve as a travelogue of China: glowingly verdant trees, winding roads, fishing shacks, ribbonlike bridges, cafes and grubby city intersections, all shot by Mark Lee Ping Bin, the cinematographer who has helped the great director Hou Hsiao-hsien sculpt time in images.

headline: More U.S. Troops Seen Staying in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is nearing a decision to keep more troops in Afghanistan next year than it had intended, effectively upending its drawdown plans in response to roiling violence in the country and another false start in the effort to open peace talks between the Taliban and the Afghan government.

headline: Director of the Clark Art Institute to Retire
text: Michael Conforti, director of the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute in the Berkshires since 1994, who spent almost 15 years reimagining the museum through a renovation and expansion, announced on Thursday that he would retire in August.

headline: In Video, Obama Appeals to Iranian Youth on Nuclear Deal
text: WASHINGTON — Two weeks after Senate Republicans issued a letter to the Iranian leadership warning that any nuclear agreement Iran signs with the administration may be temporary, President Obama has issued a missive of his own: A video directed at Iran’s young people, urging them to pressure their leaders to accept the deal on the table.

headline: Villanova Overwhelms Lafayette
text: PITTSBURGH — By halftime, seven Villanova players had each scored at least 5 points. The only starter who had not, Ryan Arcidiacono, was the Big East player of the year.

headline: Israel Election Result Complicates Life for Clinton
text: WASHINGTON — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s victory in this week’s Israeli elections has reverberated through American politics, reinforcing Republican faith in the political wisdom of a hawkish foreign policy, worsening his relationship with President Obama, and energizing liberal critics of Israel’s government. But mostly it has complicated the life of Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Clip: ‘White God’
text: A scene from the film.

headline: A Burst of Upsets, and Confidence, to Shake the N.C.A.A. Tournament Up
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — There was something about the way the University of Alabama at Birmingham’s men’s basketball team took the court here at midday Thursday that made me think that the Blazers fan holding a sign that said “U.A.B. Shock the World” might not be so crazy after all.

headline: Solar Eclipse and Supermoon Have Europe Energy Providers Watchful
text: BERLIN — Germany has enthusiastically embraced the sun as an important source of energy, but a strange celestial trifecta on Friday evoked a shiver of ancient fears — and the more practical concern that the lights might go out.

headline: Review: In ‘Metalhead,’ an Icelandic Girl Drowns Her Sorrows in Music
text: Ragnar Bragason’s “Metalhead” — about a disaffected teenage girl on an isolated farm who finds salvation in heavy-metal music — could have been set in a Great Plains town or in any American agricultural hamlet. But it takes place near Svarthamar, an empty, rural corner of Iceland, where much social activity revolves around the church.

headline: Review: ‘Please Be Normal,’ a Couple’s Dawning Desperation
text: It takes courage to ask your partner “Are we happy?”— especially if, like Mary (Elisabeth Waterston), you’re pregnant and your boyfriend, Victor (played by Ms. Waterston’s husband, Louis Cancelmi), seems increasingly detached from his imminent fatherhood. That detachment, its cause and consequence, forms the shrouded heart of “Please Be Normal,” a tiny, piercing study of dawning desperation that’s all the more remarkable for being virtually silent.

headline: Coverage of Arctic Sea Ice Shrinks to a Winter Low
text: There was less sea ice coverage in the Arctic this winter than in any year since satellite measurements began nearly four decades ago, researchers said Thursday. The National Snow and Ice Data Center, a government-sponsored research group, said that in late February ice cover in the Arctic Ocean reached its maximum extent, 5.61 million square miles, which is about 7 percent less than the average from 1981 to 2010 and about 1 percent less than the previous lowest year, 2011. The center said that changes in the jet stream created warmer than normal conditions on the Pacific side of the Arctic. While the extent of Arctic sea ice is naturally variable, it has been generally declining over the past several decades as the region warms more quickly than other parts of the planet.

headline: Review: ‘The Heidi Chronicles,’ With Elisabeth Moss, Opens on Broadway
text: Do the responsibilities that come with age inevitably erode the ideals of youth? Can women achieve the most in their careers while enjoying a fully satisfying family life? Is sadness a natural — as opposed to pathological — response to the realization that life will not bring us everything we had hoped it would?

headline: Augustus, to Julius Caesar
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Today marks another debut by a constructor from Canada named Roland Huget. He introduces himself in his notes, so I will limit myself to the puzzle.

headline: Review: In ‘Spring,’ Romance Gives Way to a Beastly Horror
text: Justin Benson and Aaron Moorhead don’t yet have many movies to their credit, but with “Spring,” which they directed, they show that they already possess something that many makers of horror films never develop: patience.

headline: Hostility From U.S. as China Lures Allies to New Bank
text: BEIJING — When Xi Jinping, then the newly minted Chinese leader, first broached the idea of a new Asian development bank in a public speech in 2013, few in Washington paid it much heed.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Defends Efforts to Help Struggling Schools
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio defended his administration’s efforts to fix New York City’s troubled schools on Thursday, describing those efforts as a cross between a war and a policing operation — “the educational equivalent of house-to-house combat.”

headline: Patz Trial Jury Is Told Suspect Was Prone to Confessing
text: Pedro Hernandez, the man who has confessed to strangling Etan Patz, was susceptible to giving a false confession while being questioned by detectives because of his low intelligence, a psychologist serving as a defense witness testified on Thursday.

headline: The Gesture That Turned a Fiscal Crisis Into Twitter Fodder — or Did It?
text: PARIS — Did he flip Germany the bird?

headline: M.L.B. Exhibition Possible in Cuba Next Year
text: Major League Baseball continues to highlight its intention to play at least one exhibition game in Cuba, bringing the game to the homeland of some of the league’s best players.

headline: U.S. Must Step Up Capacity for Cyberattacks, Chief Argues
text: WASHINGTON — The admiral who directs American cyberforces told a Senate committee on Thursday that the United States was “at a tipping point” where it needed to increase its ability to conduct cyberattacks, to create a deterrent against other countries that are attacking it.

headline: Greco-German ‘Fingergate’ Gets Curiouser and Curiouser
text: Amid tense negotiations between Greece and its European creditors, the eyes of the German media remained firmly focused Thursday on the Greek finance minister’s middle finger — specifically on the question of whether a two-year-old video clip of him extending that digit in Germany’s metaphorical direction was real or fake.

headline: Review: ‘Secret of Water’ Studies Liquid as an Archive of History
text: There’s a whole lot of hogwash in “Secret of Water,” a cheesy documentary stuffed full of pseudoscience masquerading as profound truth.

headline: Short-Handed Cincinnati Rallies Past Purdue
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Playing without its coach and suddenly its leading scorer, No. 8 seed Cincinnati rallied in regulation and defeated No. 9 seed Purdue, 66-65, in overtime in a Midwest Region game Thursday night.

headline: Review: In ‘Tracers,’ Taylor Lautner Joins a Shady Parkour Gang
text: Part urban crime film, part romantic fantasy, “Tracers” begins by zipping along with the street-level symbol of heedless New York motion, a bike messenger. When this particular speed demon, Cam (Taylor Lautner), has an accident, he slams into a young woman practicing another kind of perpetual motion, parkour, an equipment-free sport that treats urban spaces as obstacle courses. Corny twists and exchanges ensue in the wobbly story, but, delightfully, Daniel Benmayor’s film shows love not just for stunts but for the dynamic surfaces of the city.

headline: Utah Holds Off Stephen F. Austin’s Upset Bid
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Utah, one of the country’s best defensive teams, clamped down high-scoring Stephen F. Austin, staving off an upset bid and advancing to the round of 32.

headline: Head of Secret Service Denies Crash
text: Joseph P. Clancy, the director of the Secret Service, disputed reports that an incident at the White House involving his agents was a car crash.

headline: Virginia Just Can’t Win With Critics of Its Style
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — On the way to winning 29 games and a second consecutive Atlantic Coast Conference regular-season crown, Virginia has managed to help provoke one of the more fascinating academic discussions on the state of college basketball as we know it.

headline: Charles N. Shaffer Jr., Lawyer Who Bolstered Case Against Nixon, Dies at 82
text: Charles N. Shaffer Jr., a fastidious litigator whose painstaking defense of John W. Dean III, the White House counsel, helped cost Richard M. Nixon the presidency during the Watergate scandal, died on March 15 at his home in Woodbine, Md. He was 82.

headline: In a Battle of the Lowly, the Knicks End Up a Bit Lower
text: After nearly five months of futility, the Knicks and the Minnesota Timberwolves showed up at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night with matching records: 14-53, which qualified them as the two worst teams in the N.B.A.

headline: Review: In ‘Zombeavers,’ the Flesheaters Have Overbites
text: Great careers have begun with flesh-eating creatures. Take the writer-director John Sayles (“Lone Star”), who got his start in movies writing trash classics like “Piranha” and “Alligator.” Now the director Jordan Rubin, a former writer for Comedy Central’s “Crank Yankers,” and Evan Astrowsky, a producer of Eli Roth’s horror film “Cabin Fever,” pool their talents for “Zombeavers,” an intermittently diverting stew of low-budget effects and potty-mouth humor. Unsurprisingly, its writers and soundtrack composers, the brothers Jon and Al Kaplan, wrote the music for Syfy’s “Piranhaconda” and “Dinocroc vs. Supergator.” (More intriguingly, they also created “Silence!,” the stage parody of “The Silence of the Lambs.”)

headline: Review: ‘Can’t Stand Losing You,’ Andy Summers’s Version of the Police
text: The most exciting moment in Andy Grieve’s rather dull documentary, “Can’t Stand Losing You: Surviving the Police,” comes when we learn that Sting’s can of hair spray exploded in his face right before a 1978 television appearance. Had the actual detonation been recorded, it would have livened up a movie singularly lacking in rock-doc unpredictability and verve.

headline: Malcolm Fraser, a Leader Given Power During Crisis in Australia, Dies at 84
text: Malcolm Fraser, who was appointed prime minister of Australia by the British crown during a constitutional crisis and led his country for eight years, winning three elections, died on Friday. He was 84.

headline: Against North Carolina State, L.S.U. Lets One Slip Away
text: PITTSBURGH — The problem with being the team that came closest to beating mighty Kentucky, as Louisiana State has discovered, is the burden of expectations. The Tigers know how well they are capable of playing, but then there are the days when they lose to conference doormats like Auburn and Mississippi State, and how do they explain that?

headline: Elizabeth Alexander: Eat, Memory
text: The poet’s memoir recounts her romance with her late husband, but it also tells the story of their romance with food. In her Manhattan home, the tastes and scents of their shared life linger.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New Starring Zaha Hadid and Ricky Gervais
text: Ricky Gervais and Zaha Hadid curl up in a bird’s nest while considering a floor-scrubbing robot and a lamp made from a weed.

headline: Word of the Day | centigrade
text: centigrade • \ˈsen-tə-ˌgrad, ˈsän-\ • adjective

headline: Yankees’ Jacoby Ellsbury Expects to Play on Opening Day Despite Oblique Strain
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Yankees center fielder Jacoby Ellsbury said Thursday that the mild oblique strain that had sidelined him since Sunday would not prevent him from being in the lineup on opening day, which is less than three weeks away.

headline: Treating Exotic Pets
text: Correction appended below.

headline: A Hulking New Mexico State Front Line Prepares to Face Kansas
text: OMAHA — New Mexico State center Tshilidzi Nephawe stands 6 feet 10 inches with an intimidating natural scowl that belies an engaging manner. Nephawe, a South African, anchors a hulking front line for the No. 15-seeded Aggies (23-10), the Western Athletic Conference champions who often dominate teams inside.

headline: Northern Iowa and Wyoming Share a Familial Connection
text: SEATTLE — If you put a couple dozen people in a room together, there are good odds two of those people will share a birthday.

headline: ASAP Yams’s Cause of Death: Accidental Drug Intoxication
text: ASAP Yams, the hip-hop executive and co-owner of the ASAP Worldwide record label, died of an acute mixed drug intoxication (including opiates and benzodiazepine), a spokeswoman for New York City’s chief medical examiner said on Thursday in an email. The death was ruled an accident.

headline: St. John’s Will Be Short-Handed Against San Diego State
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Having made the N.C.A.A. tournament for only the second time in Coach Steve Lavin’s five-year tenure, and only the second time since 2002, No. 9-seeded St. John’s will be short-handed in its South Region game against San Diego State (26-8), the No. 8 seed, Friday in Charlotte, N.C.

headline: Arkansas Avoids the No. 5 Jinx by Edging Wofford
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Few teams cherish having a No. 5 seed, a position that seems cursed with upsets against opponents with nothing to lose. So Arkansas was in a tough spot Thursday night as it tried to fend off the 12th-seeded Wofford Terriers, who were looking for their first N.C.A.A. tournament victory in four appearances.

headline: Watch a Total Solar Eclipse Without Venturing to a Remote Island
text: By a lucky coincidence, the moon and the sun appear to be almost the same size, each subtending about half a degree of arc in diameter. As a result, the endless and repetitive wobbly dance of the worlds causes the moon to pass directly in front of the sun every year or two, sometimes hiding it completely in a total solar eclipse.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
text: 11 P.M. (Pop) THE DESCENDANTS (2011) Matt King (George Clooney, in an Oscar-nominated role), whose ancestors include the earliest white settlers in Hawaii, struggles to make the right decision about his family’s birthright, a pristine tract on Kauai — should it be sold to developers? — while his wife, Elizabeth (Patricia Hastie), lies in a coma after a boating accident. Not long after Matt learns he is about to become a widower and a single father to unruly daughters, Scottie (Amara Miller) and Alex (Shailene Woodley), he discovers that his wife had an affair. And Elizabeth’s father (Robert Forster) blames Matt for his daughter’s condition. The director Alexander Payne, “with a light touch and a keen sense of place — this Hawaii is as real and peculiar as the Nebraska of ‘About Schmidt’ or the California wine country of ‘Sideways’ — has made a movie that, for all its modesty, is as big as life,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Its heart is occupied by grief, pain and the haunting silence of Elizabeth, whose version of events is the only one we never hear. And yet it is also full of warmth, humor and the kind of grace that can result from our clumsy attempts to make things better.”

headline: Against Kentucky, Hampton Keeps It Close, for 12 Minutes
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — There was drama here for 12 minutes. No. 1 Kentucky led 16th-seeded Hampton, 18-14, with 8 minutes 27 seconds left in the first half, and John Calipari, the Kentucky coach, fumed at his players from the bench for misdeeds in execution.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Mar. 19
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of a public art sculpture in Queens, the St. Patrick’s Day parade and a comedian named Des Bishop.

headline: Midmajor Upsets Are Just Part of the Tournament
text: SEATTLE — On Thursday afternoon at KeyArena, several Northern Iowa players gathered around a smartphone in a locker room to watch the end of the Baylor-Georgia State game. The tension built as the time passed and Georgia State mounted an improbable rally.

headline: Mets’ Dillon Gee Looks Solid in Start; Daniel Murphy Tweaks Hamstring
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — On a day when the Mets looked to plug one hole, moving Dillon Gee from the bullpen to the rotation, another leak emerged, albeit not one as major as losing starting pitcher Zack Wheeler to season-ending Tommy John surgery.

headline: SXSW Music 2015: A Surprise Appearance From Miley Cyrus
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — The biggest buzz around town on Thursday, as the South by Southwest music mayhem hit its stride, was not about a breakout band from Brooklyn or Sweden, nor was it focused on the previous night’s exclusive Iggy Azalea set for Samsung. Instead, the increasingly loud whispers around Austin came straight from trending topics for 2013: Miley Cyrus was rumored to be making an appearance.

headline: Georgetown Finally Lives Up to Its Seeding and Outmuscles Eastern Washington
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Having built an unwanted reputation in recent years for losing to teams seeded far lower than itself, No. 4 Georgetown dominated No. 13 Eastern Washington, 84-74, on Thursday in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s round of 64.

headline: European Leaders Urge Greece to Accelerate Overhaul Efforts
text: BRUSSELS — With Greece rapidly running out of money and again teetering on the edge of default, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany stood firm early Friday against pleading by the Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, and prodded him to speed up efforts to overhaul his country’s gasping economy in return for cash.

headline: Rosetta Follows a Comet Through Perihelion
text: The Rosetta spacecraft is following Comet 67P/C-G as it makes its closest approach to the sun.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “I personally think we are just not smart enough — and won’t be for a very long time — to feel comfortable about the consequences of changing heredity, even in a single individual.”

headline: Corrections: March 20, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Anti-Semitism in Hungary
text: To the Editor:

headline: Helping the Victims in Syria and Iraq
text: To the Editor:

headline: Leniency for General Petraeus: His Lawyer’s Argument
text: To the Editor:

headline: Finding This Lost City in Honduras Was the Easy Part
text: RIGHT now, in the jungle some 50 miles inland from the Mosquito Coast of Honduras, sits an astounding cache of ancient artifacts, until this month most likely unseen by human eyes for somewhere between 600 and 1,000 years. I traveled there three weeks ago with a team of archaeologists, anthropologists, ethnobotanists, filmmakers and Honduran soldiers, who were following up on lidar images — a laser-based aerial surveillance technology — that suggested the presence of ruins.

headline: The Zero-Sum Moment
text: National elections take place within a specific global moment. In the 1990s, there was a presumption that we were living in an age of rapid progress. Democracy was spreading. Tyranny was receding. Asia was booming. The European Union was building. Conflict in the Middle East was lessening. The world was cumulatively heading toward greater pluralism, individualism, prosperity and freedom.

headline: Trillion Dollar Fraudsters
text: By now it’s a Republican Party tradition: Every year the party produces a budget that allegedly slashes deficits, but which turns out to contain a trillion-dollar “magic asterisk” — a line that promises huge spending cuts and/or revenue increases, but without explaining where the money is supposed to come from.

headline: The Case for Free-Range Parenting
text: BETHESDA, Md. — ON her first morning in America, last summer, my daughter went out to explore her new neighborhood — alone, without even telling my wife or me.

headline: Our Federal Policy on the Use of Ethanol
The Schneiderman Remedy for Sleaze
text: Calling for an end to “a golden age of graft” in Albany, Attorney General Eric Schneiderman of New York laid out a series of adventurous ethics proposals in a speech to Citizens Union on Monday. Though in some cases his ideas will need further exploration and debate, they represent a challenge to Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s promised reforms.

headline: U.S. Allies, Lured by China’s Bank
text: The Obama administration, to its embarrassment, has been spurned by Western allies flocking to a China-led Asian development bank, defying White House pleas to stand back. In a surprise announcement last week, Britain said it would become the first Western nation to join the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, a potential rival to the American-led World Bank.

headline: Test Yourself | Wake Up and Dance
text: Here are several paragraphs from a March 13 article, “The Rise of Early-Morning Dance Parties.”

headline: The Metro Areas With the Largest, and Smallest, Gay Populations
text: The Census Bureau asks Americans about subjects as varied as race, age, annual income and even their source of home heating. But there is one glaring demographic omission: The census does not ask people about their sexual orientation. As a result, there has long been a shroud of uncertainty around the geography of gay and lesbian Americans.

headline: Hackers Attack GreatFire.org, a Workaround for Websites Censored in China
text: For years, a group of anonymous activists known as GreatFire.org has monitored online censorship in China, provided access to blocked websites and collected messages deleted by censors.

headline: ‘The Salt of the Earth’ Presents a Photographer’s Life and Lens, in Focus
text: The German film director Wim Wenders was walking down La Brea Avenue in Los Angeles one day in the mid-1980s when out of the corner of his eye he caught sight of some startling photographs in the window of a gallery. Intrigued, he immediately entered, learned that the photographer was a Brazilian named Sebastião Salgado, and emerged an hour later the owner of a pair of prints — one from Mr. Salgado’s now-celebrated Serra Pelada series from a gold mine in the Amazon, the other from the Sahel in Africa — that continue to this day to hang over the director’s desk in his Berlin office.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The Next Frontier: The Great Indoors
text: In “The Next Frontier: The Great Indoors,” Carl Zimmer writes about scientific interest in the indoor biome.

headline: Adam Horovitz, a Beastie Boy in Middle Age
text: Longtime fans of the Beastie Boys could be forgiven for imagining that the rappers would be perennially young, forever New York’s impish hometown heroes, ollieing past authority on their way to after-hours fun.

headline: Amour by the Seine and the Nevada Desert
text: Abandoned yet nearly perfect, Jean Renoir’s “A Day in the Country” (1936) is a movie whose incomplete aspects only accentuate its freshness and spontaneity.

headline: Cement Giants Holcim and Lafarge Say Merger Is Back on Track
text: PARIS — Holcim and Lafarge, the two European cement giants, have broken a deadlock that threatened their merger plans, they said on Friday, expressing confidence that they would close the $46 billion deal this summer.

headline: At Least 32 Killed After Express Train Strikes Barrier in Northern India
text: NEW DELHI — An express train hit a safety barrier at a railway station in northern India on Friday morning, killing at least 32 people and injuring dozens more after two coach cars and the engine derailed, the authorities said.

headline: After the Kodak Moment
text: Kodak has prioritized its patent portfolio and the Eastman Business Park since it declared bankruptcy in 2012. Despite some success, the company might never live up to the legacy of its own past.

headline: Brazil’s Slumping Economy and Bribery Scandal Eat Away at Dilma Rousseff’s Popularity
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — President Dilma Rousseff ran for office declaring that she would harness an oil bonanza in Brazil to supercharge the economy while avoiding the corruption and mismanagement that have plagued other oil-rich countries in the developing world.

headline: Mitch McConnell Makes Changes, but Senate Gridlock Remains
text: WASHINGTON — When he became majority leader, propelled by sweeping Republican victories last year, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky vowed to run a more productive and traditional Senate than his Democratic predecessor, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada.

headline: Nigerian Army Noticeably Absent in Town Taken From Boko Haram
text: DAMASAK, Nigeria — Boko Haram’s black flag is everywhere in the town of Damasak, deep in Islamist-held territory in northern Nigeria: It is painted on former administrative buildings and schools, and on the side of abandoned gas stations.

headline: What Woman Would You Want to See on the $20 Bill?
text: The year 2020 is the 100th anniversary of women gaining the right to vote in the United States, and a campaign has started to put a woman’s face on paper money — to replace Andrew Jackson on the $20 bill.

headline: Refusing to Give Up on Kodak
text: What happens after a tech company is left for dead but the people left behind refuse to give up? At Kodak the answer is to dig into its legacy of innovation.

headline: At Kodak, Clinging to a Future Beyond Film
text: Of the roughly 200 buildings that once stood on the 1,300-acre campus of Eastman Kodak’s business park in Rochester, 80 have been demolished and 59 others sold off. Terry Taber, bespectacled, 60, and a loyal Kodak employee of 34 years, still works in one of the remaining Kodak structures, rubble from demolition not far from its doors.

headline: TSB to Recommend That Investors Accept Spanish Bank’s Takeover Offer
text: LONDON — TSB Banking Group, the lender spun out of the Lloyds Banking Group last year, said on Friday that its directors had agreed to recommend that investors accept a takeover offer from Banco Sabadell of Spain that values it at 1.7 billion pounds, or about $2.5 billion.

headline: Biogen Reports Its Alzheimer’s Drug Sharply Slowed Cognitive Decline
text: An experimental drug for Alzheimer’s disease sharply slowed the decline in mental function in a small clinical trial, researchers reported Friday, reviving hopes for an approach to therapy that until now has experienced repeated failures.

headline: Ask Well: Whiter Teeth
text: Question:

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: (Want to get the Morning Briefing in your inbox first thing? Sign up.)

headline: Q. and A.: Chang-rae Lee on His Tale of Migrants From an Environmentally Ruined China
text: Starting with his first novel, “Native Speaker,” the Korean-American author Chang-rae Lee has written of immigrant experiences in the United States. His latest novel, “On Such a Full Sea,” centers on a Chinese woman named Fan who is a laborer in a city called B-Mor, a future version of Baltimore. The novel is a dystopian tale, set in an era when nations around the world are suffering from overwhelming environmental degradation. Fan is one of tens of thousands of Chinese from smog-choked Shanxi Province who have taken jobs as food production workers in B-Mor to escape their toxic homeland.

headline: New York Today: Unbeloved Sculptures
text: Good morning on this final winter Friday.

headline: Gay America
text: A new analysis offers the most detailed estimates yet about where people who identify as gay, lesbian, bisexual or transgender live.

headline: Foreign Liberators Control the Streets of Damasak
text: Soldiers from Chad and Niger liberated Damasak from Boko Haram this week after a fierce firefight, and were surprised by the absence of the Nigerian Army.

headline: Europeans (Carefully) Gaze Upward for Glimpse of the Solar Eclipse
text: PARIS — Crowds across Europe gazed skyward on Friday to witness a solar eclipse, one where the moon came between the earth and the sun and its shadow blocked the sun in its entirety at some viewing points.

headline: Outgoing Credit Suisse C.E.O. Took Slight Pay Cut in 2014
text: LONDON — Brady W. Dougan, the outgoing chief executive of Credit Suisse, took a slight pay cut in 2014 as the Swiss bank faced what it described as a “challenging” macroeconomic environment and saw its annual results hurt by legacy legal issues.

headline: Traitors to Their Class
text: You probably know from his weepy reminiscences that the speaker of the House, John Boehner, once worked as a bartender and a janitor, and took seven years to get out of college. Maybe you’ve heard that Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin is a preacher’s son who churned out burgers and fries at McDonald’s. And you had to catch that bit from Senator Joni Ernst about putting bread bags over her shoes while growing up kind of poor in rural Iowa.

headline: 11 Books About Obsessive Searches
text: As the author of “Turn Right at Machu Picchu,” about a trek to find the lost city of the Incas along a relatively unknown route, and “Meet Me in Atlantis,” about amateur explorers’ passionate attempts to locate the sunken island metropolis, I’m intimately familiar with travel books that might be categorized as “obsessive quests.” My favorites are those written by authors who undertake adventures of their own. Here is a selection.

headline: Tranquil, Sandy Refuges From Bustling Santiago
text: The 35-story-tall sand dunes of Concón are grand formations that took shape over millions of years, growing into seemingly insurmountable mounds that draw thrill-seeking sand-boarders and lumbering climbers alike.

headline: My Quest for Atlantis
text: There’s nothing like a vigorous sea-to-summit hike up the Rock of Gibraltar to clear the jet-lagged mind, especially when you’re trying to solve a nearly 2,500-year-old mystery. Following the zigzagging lines on the colorful paper place mat I’d been handed at the Gibraltar welcome center when I’d asked for a map, I climbed a steep set of concrete and stone stairs high into the green solitude of the Upper Rock Nature Preserve. As the path cut through a thick tangle of scrub, the southern coast of Spain appeared to the west, far below. A little farther on, the view widened to take in the cinched waist of the Strait of Gibraltar. A few steps later, the northern shore of Africa emerged through the last of the morning’s light mist.

headline: Casino Dream
text: Two months ago, my brother asked me if I remembered playing with our father when we were children. I don’t. I remember that my father left the house early in the morning and came back in the evening, late. He always brought some chocolate for me and always put it in the same place, the kitchen cabinet. He was the kind part of the family, with a low voice. I saw him as the calm of the evening. But memories change the facts.

headline: ‘Binoculars’
text: A flicker is a type of woodpecker, but here the poet captures the word’s multiple meanings: the actual bird, wavering light and, most profoundly, how the past returns again and again, as a momentary confrontation with the things memory and self-reflection — that telescopic, magnifying lens — will not let us forget. Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

headline: Re: Is Most of Our DNA Garbage?
text: Is there garbage in our genome? Carl Zimmer’s March 8 article about the debate in the scientific community over junk DNA sparked a conversation that spread to the blogs of half a dozen scientists.

headline: Recycling Unused Medicines to Save Money and Lives
text: It always troubled Deane Kirchner to throw away good medicine. When residents of the Lincoln Glen long-term facility in San Jose, Calif., where she is the director of nursing, changed dosages, had adverse reactions, or died, she did what health professionals regularly do: sent their unused medicines to be destroyed.

headline: How to Negotiate a Prenup
text: Sometimes in the thick of a messy and awkward prenuptial agreement negotiation, Laura A. Wasser, a Los Angeles-based family lawyer, reminds her clients: “This is not someone you got into a fender bender with. This is someone you want to spend your life with.” So be nice, for starters. Wasser pushes clients to sign all the paperwork at least a month before the wedding, but she suggests broaching the subject much earlier. “Sit down to talk with a good bottle of wine, but don’t drink so much that you end up drunk and fighting,” she says. “Bring it up when things are good, not when you’re bickering.”

headline: Daily Report: F.A.A. Gives Amazon Limited Permission on Drones
text: Federal regulators have given Amazon a green light to begin testing drones, but it will most likely take years before the online retailer can start delivering packages from the air to peoples’ homes, writes Nick Wingfield.

headline: Morning Agenda: Bank of New York Mellon in Settlement
text: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON IN SETTLEMENT | Federal and state authorities announced on Thursday that the Bank of New York Mellon would pay $714 million to settle accusations that it cheated government pension funds and other investors for more than a decade, DealBook’s Ben Protess reports. The settlement is part of a broader deal requiring the bank to dismiss some employees and overhaul its foreign exchange operation.

headline: Today in Politics: With Talk of Building Ties, Clinton Draws Subtle Contrast With Obama
text: Good Friday morning from Washington, where the National Cherry Blossom Festival officially begins despite a forecast of flurries. Congress is busy finding creative new ways to approve spending without voting, and there’s a very good chance a potential presidential candidate is streaming live video right now on an app called Meerkat. If that sounds too “Back to the Future” for you, at least one person who might like to move back to the White House is yearning for the good old days of bipartisanship.

headline: No Child Left Behind Law Faces Its Own Reckoning
text: CLEVELAND — Ginn Academy, the first and only public high school in Ohio just for boys, was conceived to help at-risk students make it through school — experimenting with small classes, a tough discipline code and life coaches around the clock.

headline: When the 13-Year-Old Picks a $14 Million Condo
text: A year and a half ago, Skye van Merkensteijn was shooting hoops with a friend who lives at the Aldyn, a condominium-rental hybrid on Riverside Boulevard with its own indoor basketball court, climbing wall and bowling alley.

headline: An Online Sale Collects Rare Vintage Men’s Accoutrements from Hermes, Cartier and More
text: This weekend, an online sale put together by the vintage impresario Alan Bedwell for the auction site Paddle8 proves it’s the accessories that separate the man from the gentleman. Bedwell, the founder of the vintage accessories brand Foundwell, pulled together a range of vintage and antique items — equally practical and whimsical — to outfit the proper bar, desk and dressing room. For drinks, there’s an opulent sterling silver and crystal Champagne bottle from 1898, alongside a quirky 1960s Cartier flowerpot jigger. According to Bedwell, “a beautiful letter opener should be a part of anyone’s desk,” and the sale has several to offer, including an 1898 model bearing the brand “DuPont Explosives” and another created in 1970 by Hermès in a comically extended dachshund shape. An equally lively pair of French agate hamburger cufflinks from the ’70s are fun, but exquisitely crafted — each element was hand-cut, dyed and polished. The real standouts, though, act as conversation starters, like an ’80s Asprey rubber-band gun and a silver-plated peanut dish from the ’50s. “You do stumble across these amazing crazy pieces every now and then,” Bedwell says, “and you just think, ‘Wow, I can’t believe somebody actually sat down and made that.'”

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

text: NEW DELHI — Two heavily armed militants wearing Indian Army uniforms opened fire on a police station near the Pakistani border early Friday, killing three Indian security personnel and a civilian, officials said.

headline: A London Loft Designed With a Nod to New York
text: When Eric Perlberg, a photographer, decided to retire and renovate his London apartment, he thought about the best attributes of places where he had lived throughout his life: SoHo and Woodstock in New York, and Basel, Switzerland.

text: OVER the last eight years, Teresa Mears has cycled through enough change to last a lifetime: a partner’s death, helping to care for a mother with Alzheimer’s, leaving a steady job just before the recession hit, and the loss of her house.

headline: Graco to Pay $10 Million for Delay in Recall of Defective Child Seats
text: Graco Children’s Products has agreed to pay $10 million to settle claims that it failed to recall promptly about four million child car seats with a defective buckle that could make it difficult to free a child in an emergency, federal regulators said on Friday.

headline: Review: Joyce DiDonato Blends Bel Canto and Emotion at Carnegie Hall
text: Detractors of the bel canto style typically dislike it because, they argue, it is only that: beautiful singing. In the music of composers like Donizetti and Bellini the action stops and words take a back seat. All that matters, for the duration of an aria, is the glory of the human voice and its ability to dart up and down octaves while dashing off trills and other ornaments in a fizzy display of vocal pyrotechnics.

headline: Latest Iran Talks End Without a Deal
text: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — An intensive round of talks on limiting Iran’s nuclear program ended abruptly on Friday with the two sides still divided over some important issues.

headline: What Else Can We Add to a Smoothie?
text: Over the years I have given you a number of Recipes for Health devoted to smoothies – fruit smoothies with nuts and seeds; smoothies with vegetables; dairy free smoothies. I thought I had pretty much covered all the smoothie bases. Then I came across a recipe for a “Fresh Peach, Banana and Warm Millet Smoothie” in Bryant Terry’s impressive new cookbook “Afro-Vegan,” and a bell went off. Cooked millet in a smoothie? I had never seen such a thing; yet breakfast is a great meal for cooked grains, and also for smoothies. So why not? Adding cooked grains to smoothies would be a perfect way to thicken the drinks and bulk them up. It’s also a delicious way to incorporate more grains into your diet.

headline: After Backtracking on Trans-Atlantic Flights, Ryanair Learns Its Lessons
text: PARIS — In the little more than a year since Ryanair made a belated push into the digital age, the Irish budget airline has adopted an arsenal of tools aimed at improving communications with the flying public.

headline: Rick Perry Disavows Aide’s Comments on Women in the White House

H. Mumm Company, sold for $24,500,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Catfish Farmers, Seeking Regulation to Fight Foreign Competition, Face Higher Bills
text: WASHINGTON — In 2008, faced with increased competition from Vietnam and China, catfish producers in the United States did the unthinkable: They asked for more regulation of their industry.

headline: Winter Vegetables for Spring Holidays
text: It’s that time of year again, on the East Coast at least, when spring is in the air but not in your shopping basket.

headline: 1890: Hotel de Balzac Demolition
text: One of the landmarks of literary and historic Paris is now being removed. This is the hotel at the junction of the rue Berryer, rue de Balzac and rue du faubourg St. Honoré, formerly the residence of Balzac, from whom it took the name Hotel de Balzac. The hotel proper, which stood in a garden hid from the street, has already been demolished, while the more recently erected structure on the street is shortly to have the same fate. Of this mansion, which with its carved stonework, ogival windows and massive, iron knobbed door, and finally its desolate appearance, rendered the feature of the upper part of the faubourg, only a small portion, containing carved woodwork of great value, will be left standing. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 21, 1890

headline: ‘Thrift,’ by Andrew L. Yarrow
text: National Thrift Week, originally organized by the Y.M.C.A. in 1917, was the signature event of a nationwide moral crusade by elites to mold Americans’ behaviors. During seven days centered on Benjamin Franklin’s Jan. 17 birthday, thrift advocates taught people how to open savings accounts, buy insurance, purchase homes, pay bills promptly and share with others. By the early 1920s, Thrift Week was observed by more than a thousand cities in the United States, and still more around the globe. Thrift was put forward as the antidote to many of the nation’s perceived ills: working-class radicalism, urban poverty, squandering of natural resources and excessive consumerism.

text: Go home.

text: BREAK your financial life into chapters. Assign a high point, a low point and a turning point to each chapter. What’s the story and what stands out?

headline: Mortgage Amounts Rising More Quickly Than Home Prices

headline: Breast Milk Becomes a Commodity, With Mothers Caught Up in Debate
text: CITY OF INDUSTRY, Calif. — When Gretty Amaya took an unpaid maternity leave five months ago, she started what she calls a part-time job to help pay the bills. Ms. Amaya, who lives in Miami, has made more than $2,000 so far by pumping breast milk and selling what is left over after feeding her baby daughter.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘The Opposite of Spoiled’
text: This week, Ron Lieber discusses “The Opposite of Spoiled”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Harris Irfan talks about “Heaven’s Bankers”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Judi Dench Joins Cast of Live Election-Night Play in Britain
text: LONDON — In the very moments that Britons cast their vote for the next Parliament, a Dame will flicker across the nation’s TV screens.

headline: Afghan Leader Said to Be Centralizing Power as Unity Government Plan Stalls
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Through a tumultuous first six months as president of Afghanistan, Ashraf Ghani has been living up to his promises to transform the office. But rather than decentralizing the post’s powers, as he had vowed, he has instead been quietly creating an even more dominant presidency, according to a range of current and former Afghan officials.

headline: ‘Heaven’s Bankers,’ by Harris Irfan
text: Tell non-Muslims or people who work outside the financial industry that you write about Islamic finance, and you will almost certainly receive one of two reactions (not including blank stares). The first — in which people assume Islamic finance is synonymous with or inherently linked to the bankrolling of terrorism — is both the most depressing and the most easily dismissed, because it is untrue. People slightly more familiar with Islam might have some notion that Islamic finance entails interest-­free banking, but beyond that things get murky pretty quickly.

headline: ‘The Seventh Day,’ by Yu Hua
text: In Yu Hua’s surreal, mordant novel “The Seventh Day,” the victims of China’s ­explosively expanding market economy include the still conscious, still suffering, still impoverished dead. They can’t afford burial plots. They’ve been separated from their families and uprooted from their ­ancestral homes. Unable to be mourned in the proper Chinese way, they’re fated to roam a “hazy, indistinct city” where snow swirls around their legs and they have the opportunity to reflect upon their lives and the circumstances of their deaths. The limping shades may then encounter the dead former friends and loved ones who also inhabit this characteristically ­Chinese mega-necropolis.

headline: The Way We Read Now
text: This week, the Book Review looks at the ways we make, spend and obsess over money in its second annual Money Issue.

headline: Take the Money and Run
text: The career criminals in genre novels don’t have money problems. If they need some, they just go out and steal it. But such financial transactions can backfire, which is what happened back in 2004 when the Texas gang in Michael Robotham’s LIFE OR DEATH (Mulholland/Little, Brown, $26) robbed $7 million from an armored truck. That ill-fated enterprise ended with four people dead. One robber was shot and captured alive, but the surviving gang member was never seen again and the money was never recovered.

headline: ‘The Opposite of Spoiled,’ by Ron Lieber
text: I’m one of those people who are overcome with a strange combination of discomfort and ennui whenever they think about their children and money. Each time my husband brings up the topic of allowance, I wriggle out of the conversation, all but “la la la”-ing with my hands over my ears. Now I find I’m not alone. In his new book, “The Opposite of Spoiled,” Ron Lieber suggests that our unease about money prevents us from raising fiscally responsible kids. Open dialogue, he suggests, is the answer. Ask your children questions; listen to their answers. So I tried it. My husband and I waylaid our 16-year-old daughter, Lucy, as she headed out the door. “How much do you think we earn every year?” we asked. Lucy, who’s a pretty smart, sophisticated kid, replied after a moment’s thought: “Maybe around $10,000?” I don’t need to have an open dialogue with you, dear reader, but I will confess that’s not quite our income. I began to see how in the dark I have kept my children about our finances.

headline: ‘The Great Beanie Baby Bubble,’ by Zac Bissonnette
text: Beanie Babies, the small stuffed animals that retailed for $5, were introduced in 1993 and soon languished with mediocre sales. Then, a handful of neighbors in the Chicago suburbs discovered that each had a small collection and started trading with one another. They established some informal rules: Two Tabasco the Bull Beanies were equivalent to one of the rarer Kiwi the Toucan Beanies. Their trading spread and, eventually, went national. There were articles and TV segments about moms and dads who traded a $5 toy for thousands of dollars. Peggy Gallagher, an early trader, discovered that the Beanie craze hadn’t hit Germany yet and placed an order with a distributor in Nuremberg. She paid $2,000, including shipping, for a box of the toys that, back in the United States, had a value of $300,000, a return of nearly 15,000 percent. If she were a hedge fund trader with those numbers, she’d be the talk of Wall Street for generations. Instead, she was the talk of countless parents, who came to believe they, too, could fund their kids’ college education or an early retirement if they just got their hands on the right Beanies. The frenzy coincided with the start of eBay and the rise of home Internet use. Early on, Beanie Babies represented 10 percent of eBay’s sales.

headline: Filthy Lucre
text: SWEETLAND

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE LAST FLIGHT OF POXL WEST, by Daniel Torday. (St. Martin’s, $25.99.) A World War II memoir by Torday’s protagonist, a Jewish bomber pilot with the British Royal Air Force, is this utterly accomplished first novel’s book-within-a-book.

headline: ‘The Monopolists,’ by Mary Pilon
text: The national card game of the world’s first market democracy naturally turned out to be poker, in part because money is its language, raison d’être and means of keeping score. Our favorite board game, of course, is Monopoly, which has also gone global, and for similar reasons. Played by everyone from Jerry Hall and Mick ­Jagger to Carmela and Tony Soprano, it apparently scratches an itch to wheel and deal few of us can reach in real life. The game is sufficiently redolent of capitalism that in 1959 Fidel Castro ordered the ­destruction of every Monopoly set in Cuba, while these days Vladimir Putin seems to be its ultimate aficionado.

headline: Karen E. Bender’s ‘Refund’
text: Money is ostensibly the fuel that powers Karen E. Bender’s new collection, “Refund.” In the title story, a couple falsely advertises a TriBeCa sublet just before 9/11 to pay for a fancy nursery school. In “Reunion,” a woman impulsively buys an unseen plot of land on credit. Smaller risks prove to be, if not turning points, then those moments remembered in relief as emblematic of the Before — splurging on beef Wellington for supper, say, or setting up a kids’ lemonade stand — by those now living in the After. The theme works as an organizing tenet, but Bender’s subtler preoccupation is the eroding effect of emotional want.

headline: Paperback Row
text: MY PROMISED LAND: The Triumph and Tragedy of Israel, by Ari Shavit. (Spiegel & Grau, $17.) Drawing on historical documents, interviews and private diaries and letters — as well as his own family’s story — Shavit, a columnist for Haaretz, examines the entirety of the Israeli experience, expressing both solidarity with and criticism of his countrymen. “Shavit’s book is an extended test of his own capacity to maintain his principles in full view of the brutality that surrounds them,” Leon Wieseltier wrote here.

headline: ‘Wake Up Happy Every Day,’ by Stephen May
text: There’s a reason many readers will forgive the comic novel a clunky narrative structure or uneven pacing; a reason they’ll forgive a predisposition to tangents, tics or lack of emotional depth. The reason is simple — because funny is hard, both to execute and to resist.

headline: ‘The Looting Machine,’ by Tom Burgis
text: Back in the Mobutu era, I worked as a stringer in Kinshasa, the capital of what was then Zaire. “So, what do they want?” my driver Pierre would ask whenever I exited a Western embassy after a chat with a diplomat. “What’s the plan?” His question captured the sense of powerlessness that pervaded the country, a product of Big Man rule, Cold War interference and brutal colonial experience. If there was something of which Pierre felt certain, it was that he was not master of his fate.

headline: ‘Coined,’ by Kabir Sehgal
text: “Nothing had an effect on people like money,” recalled a Stanford neuroscientist who once experimented with scanning people’s brain activity while they played high-stakes financial games. “Not naked bodies, not corpses. It got people riled up. Like food provides motivation for dogs, money provides it for people.”

headline: ‘God’s Bankers,’ by Gerald Posner
text: Ask a devout, theologically literate ­Roman Catholic to describe the institution of the church, and you’re likely to be told that it was founded by Jesus Christ at the moment he gave his disciple ­Peter the “keys to the kingdom of heaven” and vowed that “whatever you bind on earth will be bound in heaven.” This made ­Peter the head of the universal church, ­empowered to administer the sacraments, spread the Gospel, save souls and forgive sins until Christ’s return, as well as to pronounce with infallible authority on ­matters of Christian faith and morals. Christ also promised Peter that “the gates of hell shall not prevail” against the church — meaning that no matter how corrupt the institution might appear at any given moment of history, it will never be so consumed by evil that it ceases to be capable of fulfilling its God-appointed tasks.

headline: Inside the List
text: Snow and Mo: Dennis Lehane’s new novel, “World Gone By,” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 8. Lehane remains closely identified with his native Boston, but this historical thriller — which continues a series about the fictional gangster Joe Coughlin — is set mostly in Florida and Cuba, while Lehane himself moved to Southern California a year and a half ago. He recently told The Hollywood Reporter that he was sorry to miss his hometown’s record snowfall this winter. “Bostonians, for better or worse, tend to like hard things,” he said. “You don’t really feel like something is fully worthwhile unless it’s hard-earned. It’s that sense of working-class pride, which, yeah, can be kind of annoying but can be really cool. So when I saw my friends emailing about getting the snow record, I thought, ‘What a bunch of sick bastards,’ but I really dig it. I’m jealous I’m not there, in a way.” Lehane added that his pleasure reading these days is confined to children’s books. “The go-to guy is Mo Willems,” he said. “Anyone outside of the children’s world has no idea who Mo Willems is. I didn’t. But anyone who has kids, he literally takes you from the very first book to all these great books I’m reading with my 5-year-old. He’s the Dr. Seuss of our time.”

headline: On ‘Empire': The Show, the Music and the Calamitous Finale
text: This week on Popcast: Reviewing the first season of “Empire,” which came to a calamitous end on Wednesday night with a two-hour episode that – spoiler alert – featured a murder, an attempted murder, an announced pregnancy and an arrest. The show has been renewed for a second season, and it will likely take the several months before it returns to process all that happened – “Empire” moves quickly, and does not stop for explanations.

headline: Akademgorodok
text: Inside the nuclear-physics laboratories in Akademgorodok, Siberia’s education capital.

headline: What I Love | Megan Fairchild and Andrew Veyette
text: The principal dancers with New York City Ballet live in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

headline: New Federal Rules Are Set for Fracking
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday unveiled the nation’s first major federal regulations on hydraulic fracturing, a technique for oil and gas drilling that has led to a significant increase in American energy production but has also raised concerns about health and safety risks.

headline: Why Is British Economic Discourse So Bad?
text: Still at SXSW, which accounts for lack of blog posts — I mean, seize the day and all that. Not much action this morning, except a discussion with Snoop Dogg, which I’m not going to; but whenever I think about Mr. Dogg, I think about Alan Simpson. Which brings me to the subject of this post.

headline: Tune In to The Times
text: The New York Times contributor Jessica Bennett appeared on NBC’s “Today” show to discuss her exclusive interview with Monica Lewinsky.

headline: Nick Cave Goes Straight to Fans With ‘The Sick Bag Song’
text: Nick Cave, the Australian-born poet, novelist, actor, composer and rock band frontman, has been known to cross-pollinate his various creative pursuits. His 2009 novel about a sex-addicted beauty product salesman, “The Death of Bunny Munro,” was available as an iPhone app that blended text with an audiobook narrated by Mr. Cave, set to music by one of his fellow band members. His book tour featured live music.

headline: My Childhood Pet
text: Ten artists recall the special creatures that found their way into their young lives.

headline: At Versailles, a Sumptuous Seven-Course Celebration of French Cuisine
text: The dinner celebrated Goût de France, an international initiative to advance French gastronomy.

headline: The Strange Beauty of Soviet-Era Nuclear Relics
text: Two years ago, the Russian government invited the Mexican photographer Pablo Ortiz Monasterio to come and photograph the country in advance of the Group of 20 summit meeting in Moscow. Ortiz Monasterio proposed a project on “brilliant minds,” documenting the people who work in the country’s space program or on nuclear submarines.

headline: Playful Parting Gifts Show Heads Aren’t Inflated at the Fed
text: The Federal Reserve delivered a clever parting gift to a pair of retiring reserve bank presidents who have repeatedly warned it is heading down a path that may lead to dangerous inflation.

headline: A New Documentary Shines a Light On the Artist Who Gave Shape to Eloise
text: “Fantasy is probably the most important drive in my life,” Hilary Knight says in “It’s Me, Hilary: The Man Who Drew Eloise,” an HBO documentary that offers a unique view into the one-of-a-kind mind of the illustrator behind the “Eloise” books. Produced by Lena Dunham, whose friendship with Knight began through her love of Eloise, the six-year-old resident of the Plaza Hotel whose antics were featured in a series of children’s books first published in 1955, the film creates a portrait of a man whose life and art are completely intertwined. Over 35 minutes, it traces Knight’s childhood as the son of two illustrators, the creation of Eloise, his creative tussles with the “Eloise” writer Kay Thompson and a post-Eloise career that’s included work for Vanity Fair, the publication of his own books and the illustration of posters for Broadway shows like “Gypsy.” Most compelling are the scenes of Hilary moving through his magically curated home, decorated with staged bird nests, an underwater-themed bathroom and countless pieces of his parents’ work, dressing up in a full gorilla suit or directing a short musical film in his backyard.

headline: Stuff We Liked
text: We spotted many wonderful things around the web this week.

headline: We’re Frighteningly in the Dark About Student Debt
text: Imagine that a big, complicated company holds a huge portfolio of loans, many of which are in default or delinquency. The company’s leadership and some vocal shareholders demand a detailed review but receive a thin and incomplete report from the loan division.

headline: Netanyahu's History on Palestinian Statehood
text: On the eve of the recent Israeli election, the prime minister said that no Palestinian state would be created on his watch. Two days later, he began to backtrack.

headline: Too Old to Commit Crime?
text: DZHOKHAR TSARNAEV is facing the death penalty or life in prison for the Boston Marathon bombing. But what if, instead, the maximum prison sentence were just 21 years?

headline: Netanyahu Tactics Anger Many U.S. Jews, Deepening a Divide
text: Long before the latest election in Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu was a polarizing figure among American Jews. But even many of his supporters said this week that they were appalled at his last-minute bid to mobilize Jewish voters by warning that Arabs were going to the polls in droves, and his renunciation of a two-state solution to the Palestinian crisis.

headline: Megan Fairchild, Ballet Dancer, at Home in Westchester
text: Just so there are no misunderstandings, Megan Fairchild, a principal dancer with New York City Ballet, is thrilled about making her Broadway debut in the acclaimed revival of the 1944 musical “On the Town.” She loves playing the would-be actress Ivy Smith, a.k.a. Miss Turnstiles; she loves her cast mates, loves adding a different sort of role to her extensive résumé.

headline: 5 Babies Found Dead in French Village
text: PARIS — The bodies of five babies, including four hidden in a freezer, were discovered in a house in southern France after a man told the police he had found the corpse of a baby in a cooler bag in his home, a senior police official said Friday.

headline: Azzedine Alaïa’s Collection
text: During four mini-shows that culminated just after Paris Fashion Week, Azzedine Alaïa presented pieces that demanded an intimate viewing.

headline: At Alaïa, Clothes That Are Ready for Their Close-Ups
text: Paris Fashion Week officially ended on March 11, but for fashion insiders it lasted until last Monday — the final day of Azzedine Alaïa’s series of four minishows. Though they took place off-schedule — Mr. Alaïa has his own time clock, and holds presentations when, and if, a collection is ready; never before — they were, for those who got to see them, entirely on point.

headline: French Court Orders Picasso’s Electrician to Return Nearly 300 Artworks
text: PARIS – A court in the town of Grasse in southern France on Friday found a retired electrician and his wife guilty of possessing 271 stolen works by Pablo Picasso, rejecting the couple’s claims that the trove of art was a gift from the artist’s wife.

headline: Letter From the Editor: Illuminating Gay America
text: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘The Opposite of Spoiled’
text: This week, Ron Lieber and Harris Irfan.

headline: 1915: Zeppelins Attack Paris
text: It was announced early this morning [March 21] that, despite the measures taken to guard against a Zeppelin raid over Paris, two of these German dirigibles succeeded in reaching the capital soon after midnight. Two incendiary bombs were dropped in the rue Dulong and the rue des Dames, in the Batignolles quarter, but they did not cause any fire. A fire broke out, however, in a house in the rue Chauveau, at Neuilly, just outside of Paris, and this is believed to be due to another incendiary bomb.

headline: Richard Fisher, Often Wrong but Seldom Boring, Leaves the Fed
text: DALLAS — In a decade as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, Richard W. Fisher was frequently mistaken in his economic predictions but seldom boring.

headline: Guardian Names Katharine Viner as Editor
