text: The Guardian appointed its first female editor on Friday, giving Katharine Viner, the current editor in chief of The Guardian’s United States operation, the job of leading the liberal British newspaper and media group as it seeks to expand its global ambitions.

headline: Gone Spearfishin’
text: The sturgeon spearfishing season at Lake Winnebago, the largest lake in Wisconsin, attracts ice fishermen to the lake and relatives and neighbors to the check-ins.

headline: Sturgeon and the Spear
text: It had been four years since Steve Krueger speared a sturgeon, but the outlook in his shanty was brighter this year. In the first four days of the 2015 Winnebago lake system spearing season in Wisconsin, his friends and family caught and registered three.

headline: A TV Version of the Noah’s Ark Story That Chooses Restraint Over Rain
text: The UP channel, expanding its efforts to grab some of the family-and-faith market, acquits itself pretty well Sunday night with “Noah’s Ark,” a film treatment of the religious story that relies on restraint and credible performances rather than literal and figurative thunder and lightning. Not a drop of precipitation falls until the final 10 minutes in this version of the oft-told tale; the focus is on a man’s personal ordeal rather than God’s rainy wrath.

headline: European Lawmaker Pushes Europe to Take Stronger Stance on Google
text: An outspoken European critic of Google said Friday that European Union antitrust regulators should bring formal charges against Google, after new documents showed that a report had recommended an American agency take a similar step three years ago.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Teaching Kids About Money
text: In this week’s special Money Issue of The New York Times Book Review, Claire Dederer reviews Ron Lieber’s “The Opposite of Spoiled.” Ms. Dederer writes:

headline: Miami Beach Celebrates Its Centennial
text: Incorporated in 1915, the city of Miami Beach will celebrate its 100th anniversary in fitting style, with a beach party.

headline: After a Sleepover With Mayor de Blasio, a Friendship Formed
text: The overnight guest had brought a pie. Apple, the host recalled. It went untouched.

headline: The Music, Revelry and Personalities of SXSW
text: The photographer Jackie Lee Young documents scenes from the South by Southwest festival.

headline: Elton John vs. Dolce & Gabbana, Gisele’s Extreme Non-Retirement and ‘Fashion Police’ Pulls Over
text: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Hillary Clinton Reaching Out to Catholics
text: In what could signal a coming pitch for the Catholic vote, Hillary Rodham Clinton met last week with Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the archbishop of New York, and on Monday she sat near the Rev. John I. Jenkins, president of the University of Notre Dame, at a St. Patrick’s Day-themed luncheon.

headline: Gene-Altered Apples and Potatoes Are Safe, F.D.A. Says
text: The Food and Drug Administration said on Friday that genetically engineered nonbrowning apples and bruise-resistant potatoes were as safe and nutritious as their conventional counterparts.

headline: Off-Duty Officer Among 2 Killed in a Wrong-Way Crash on Staten Island
text: A car carrying three off-duty New Jersey police officers who had been at a Staten Island strip club hurtled the wrong way down an expressway early on Friday before colliding head-on with a tractor-trailer, killing one officer and another person in the car, the authorities said.

headline: NBC’s ‘The Slap’ Finds Resonance in Park Slope, Brooklyn
text: One day last month, Louise Crawford, a 56-year-old with two grown children, was walking southward on Seventh Avenue in Brooklyn when a boy came hurtling toward her on a scooter at Nascar speed. This was already vividly contested space — Park Slope, where children on scooters have a long and menacing history and some people have practically called for legal interdiction. On this particular occasion, Ms. Crawford leapt out of the way, toward a Citibank, to avoid getting hit and in the moment, much to her surprise, found herself hurling a particularly non-PG expletive at her little would-be assailant. (The phrase she used began with, “Get the,” and ended with, “off the street.”)

headline: A Scary Movie: Filling Your 401(k) With Company Stock
text: We’ve seen the movie before, when employees of Enron and Lehman Brothers lost large sums of money in their 401(k) plans because of investments in company stock. And now, coming to a theater (and, inevitably, a courtroom) near you, is a sequel, surely not the last, this time featuring RadioShack.

headline: ‘Draft Joe Biden’ Group Urges Race Against Hillary Clinton
text: Amid Hillary Rodham Clinton’s email problems and Senator Elizabeth Warren’s reluctance to run for president, the “Draft Joe Biden” movement is getting real.

headline: Pirelli’s Largest Shareholder Is Said to Be in Talks With China National Chemical
text: LONDON — The holding company Camfin, the largest shareholder of the Italian tire maker Pirelli, is in talks to sell its stake in the company to China National Chemical Corporation in a deal that could pave the way for a full takeover of Pirelli, according to a person briefed on the discussions.

headline: SXSW Music 2015: And Now for a Hiatus, at Willie Nelson’s Ranch
text: LUCK, Tex. — I wanted a break from the music festival, so I went to a music festival. It was the Heartbreaker Banquet, held at Willie Nelson’s ranch, a place called Luck, Tex., located in the dry, rolling scrubland of Spicewood, Tex. It’s about 45 minutes northwest of Austin and a universe away from the frantic miscellany of SXSW. For me, it was a glimpse of the Austin I was introduced to in the early years of SXSW — one that’s still there, as evidenced in the annual Austin Music Awards held on Wednesday night, but a local flavor that gets inundated during SXSW with newer, flashier events.

headline: Turning Off the Android Texting Nanny
text: Some people would rather do without the word suggestions the software makes as they type a message.

headline: Merkel Warns That Greece Will Receive Aid Only if Reforms Are Met
text: PARIS — With Greece rapidly running out of money and again teetering on the edge of default, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said Friday that the Greeks would receive a desperately needed financial aid payment only after creditors approved a package of reform measures that the Greek government has promised to send them soon.

headline: The Movie ‘White God’ Unleashes a Cast of Hundreds
text: At the start of the drama “White God,” a girl in a hoodie is biking through the eerily deserted streets of Budapest. Then, in slow motion, as a sweeping score fills the soundtrack, a large group of dogs comes running after her. Not 10, not 25, but more than 200. The scene is devoid of digital imagery. These dogs are real. Large, small, furry or short-haired, and all very determined, racing toward the camera en masse. It’s an astonishing sequence revisited in greater detail later, and it sets up a moment when subjugated animals rise up against their oppressors, fighting back, taking over and leaving audiences in awe.

headline: Outsider Artist Gets Stamp of Approval
text: The United States Postal Service plans to issue five commemorative “forever” stamps on March 26 honoring the outsider artist Martín Ramírez, each with an image taken from one of his works.

headline: Kansas Rolls Past New Mexico State
text: OMAHA — New Mexico State’s tall front line and extended zone defense were supposed to pose matchup problems for Kansas, the No. 2 seed in the Midwest Region of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament. Instead, the Jayhawks found open shots everywhere, especially behind the arc, and repeatedly beat the slow-to-react Aggies down the floor to win easily, 75-56.

headline: Abiding Rifts Within Israel Threaten to Widen With Netanyahu Win
text: SDEROT, Israel — Stores in the rundown center of Sderot, a working-class Israeli border town plagued by years of rocket fire from Gaza, were still festooned with blue-and-white Likud banners at the end of this week.

headline: SXSW Music 2015: All Rise (Too) Early for Snoop Dogg
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — With parties and performances lasting well into the early morning hours all week, the music portion of the South by Southwest Conference was certainly asking something of its attendees by scheduling this year’s music keynote address, a Q. & A. with the incomparable Snoop Dogg, for 11 a.m. on Friday. This is not a place for morning people.

headline: White House Antagonism Toward Netanyahu Grows
text: WASHINGTON — The White House is stepping up its antagonism toward Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu despite his victory in this week’s elections, signaling that it is in no rush to repair a historic rift between the United States and Israel.

headline: Parades of Might
text: Lavish pageants of military hardware and marchers in formation.

headline: House Benghazi Committee Requests Hillary Clinton Email Server
text: The Congressional committee investigating the Benghazi attacks formally requested on Friday that Hillary Rodham Clinton turn over the email server that housed the personal account she exclusively used when she was secretary of state.

headline: Despite Top Lawyer’s Fears, Regulators Can Be Held in Check
text: The Wall Street lawyer H. Rodgin Cohen hit a sour regulatory note this week. Mr. Cohen, Sullivan & Cromwell’s top bank advocate, thinks watchdogs have gone overboard to prove they’re not captured by the industry.

headline: Can Washington’s Gift Economy in Marijuana Work?
text: It sounds like an idea a stoner might come up with.

headline: Musicians Discuss the Influence of Pierre Boulez
text: Pierre Boulez, the distinguished composer, conductor, pianist and theorist, turns 90 on Thursday. He’s peerlessly influential, yes — but how, exactly? Six musicians explored the different facets of that influence in interviews; their replies have been condensed and edited.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: This week’s properties include a loft in Madison Square, a studio in the Gramercy area and a two-bedroom in Brooklyn Heights.

headline: Michigan State Holds Off Georgia
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Reaching the N.C.A.A. tournament is enough of a rarity at Georgia that the Bulldogs celebrate each appearance on a banner that hangs in Stegeman Coliseum and lists every year they have made the field. The annual expectations at Michigan State, where the banners honor national championships and Final Four appearances, are just a tad higher.

headline: Review: Piotr Anderszewski Goes for Dim Lights and Intimacy at Carnegie Hall
text: In “Unquiet Traveler,” a revealing 2008 documentary that follows the great pianist Piotr Anderszewski on a tour through his native Poland, this powerfully individual artist speaks of the “extreme loneliness” of a recital, of the “heroism” but also of the “cruelty involved.”

headline: SXSW Music 2015: And Now, for a Horror — Make That Ho99o9 — Show
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Every festival needs one all-out barrage, and I got mine on Thursday night from Ho99o9 (pronounced “horror”). It’s a hip-hop group from Newark that blasts every way it can think of, which is plenty: “I’m an overload,” one song truthfully announced.

headline: An Illegal Boxing Club in the Bronx
text: Though unsanctioned, BX Fight Club aims to foster respect and redirect aggression among young men in the rougher sections of the Bronx.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
text: This week’s houses include a four-bedroom in Stamford, Conn., and a five-bedroom in Syosset, N.Y.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York Region:

headline: Clinton Backers Say Criticizing Netanyahu  Can Wait
text: Some supporters of Hillary Rodham Clinton, a longtime supporter of Israel, say she need not worry about excessive blowback from moderate Jewish supporters even if she were to join progressive Jews in criticizing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

headline: Lottery-Fueled Foundation Announces Second Theater Grant
text: The Roy Cockrum Foundation, established recently with part of the proceeds of a $153 million Powerball jackpot, has announced that its second grant will go to the Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago, to support a production of “Mary Page Marlowe,” a new play by the Pulitzer Prize-winner Tracy Letts (“August: Osage County”).

headline: A French Politician Who Has Helped Refine the National Front Party
text: ST.-MACAIRE-EN-MAGUES, France — Florian Philippot was about to take the stage in this small western village in the hope of lifting the fortunes of the local candidates of the far-right National Front party.

headline: At Versailles, a Sumptuous Seven-Course Celebration of French Cuisine
text: When the French have a serious point to make, the country’s pull-out-all-the-stops invitation is to dinner at the Château de Versailles, the vast royal palace 14 miles from Paris that remains as awe-inspiring in the age of Instagram as it was when the oil paintings of French royals that crowd its walls were created centuries ago. The French foreign minister Laurent Fabius and the chef Alain Ducasse convened Paris’s diplomatic community to a sumptuous seven-course dinner there last night to celebrate Goût de France (rather infelicitously translated in the bilingual program as “Good France”), an international initiative intended to reestablish the reputation of the French culinary arts around the world.

headline: Liberia Reports First Ebola Case in Weeks
text: A patient in Liberia has tested positive for the Ebola virus, health officials said Friday, more than two weeks after the last known case in the country had been discharged from the hospital.

headline: An Underground Boxer’s Struggle
text: Chris Cunningham stood wearing a white apron behind the checkout counter at Schaller & Weber, a butcher shop on the Upper East Side, ringing up a mink-draped customer. Under the rim of his crisp paper cap, Mr. Cunningham’s brow was visibly swollen, yet his smile was quick and generous — both products from the previous night’s championship bout at an illegal boxing club in an industrial section of the Bronx.

headline: How Tim Gunn of ‘Project Runway’ Spends His Sunday
text: Tim Gunn doesn’t balk at sharing his point of view, whether it’s favorable (“Your clothes have beautiful construction details. There is a real voice here.”), controversial (“The fashion industry has an inability to accept real women and their size and shape. I find it disdainful and disrespectful.”) or confessional (“I’m terribly shy. Every time I’m in front of a camera I’m nervous.”). In his new book, “Tim Gunn: The Natty Professor,” the “Project Runway” co-host and mentor shares such observations and musings. On Sundays, Mr. Gunn, 61, who lives on the Upper West Side, turns his focus inward in order to “heal and repair.”

headline: Review: ‘The Feast’ Plumbs the Depths of a Troubling Toilet
text: Ever had a leaky faucet? Or a clogged drain? Cory Finley’s “The Feast” at the Flea is the sort of play to make you grateful for such mundane plumbing problems. Matt’s wonky W.C. is a whole lot eerier.

headline: By Land and Sea, Curaçao Seeks to Sustain Its Coral Bounty
text: WILLEMSTAD, Curaçao — I apologize for the prolonged blog silence (I have withdrawal symptoms!), but this week has been devoted to filming, not writing. Since my move to Pace University five years ago, I’ve been working each spring with a colleague, Prof. Maria Luskay, to focus a long-running documentary production course on environmental stories.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Home Work
text: Stylish and practical ideas for furnishing a home office.

headline: Tesco and British Land Agree to Swap $1 Billion in Properties
text: LONDON — The real estate investor British Land and the British supermarket operator Tesco said on Friday that they had agreed to swap properties worth 733 million pounds, or about $1 billion.

headline: In Winter, Harbor Seals Become New York’s Beach Bums
text: As a naturalist in New York City, I have learned that a call about a sick dog on the beach is more often not about a dog. Increasingly, the beaches we abandon at the end of summer are resorts for seals in winter.

headline: Exploring the ‘Occupy’ Protest
text: The self-described radical tour guide Michael Pellagatti plans on telling stories of his Occupy Wall Street experiences on a new tour of Wall Street and surrounding areas.

headline: SXSW Music 2015: Sometimes a Band’s Equipment Can Make You Stick Around
text: They started late, but the equipment they were setting up looked promising, so I stuck around.

headline: Form Holds as Northern Iowa Ousts Wyoming
text: SEATTLE — About halfway through the first half, Seth Tuttle, Northern Iowa’s star senior forward, crashed toward the basket during an inbound play, received the ball midair and missed the easy basket. No matter. He got his own rebound and tossed the ball a few feet to the junior guard Paul Jesperson, who made the layup.

headline: TAG Heuer Smartwatch Is the Talk of Baselworld
text: BASEL, Switzerland — No one knows what it will look like. No one knows what it will cost. But the forthcoming — and thus far nameless — smartwatch announced by TAG Heuer, Google and Intel on Thursday became the watch to watch at the giant Baselworld watch fair.

headline: The Music, Revelry and Personalities of SXSW
text: The photographer Jackie Lee Young documents scenes from the South by Southwest festival.

headline: Henrik Lundqvist Loses Practice Time but Gains a Daughter
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Henrik Lundqvist, who was cleared to return to practice with the Rangers this week, was not at the team’s workout Friday because his wife, Therese, was close to giving birth to their second child.

headline: The Best Roast Lamb for Your Easter Feast
text: Apparently, I’m eating for 30.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
text: A visiting prince, stalled confirmation hearings and a Women’s History Month reception.

headline: Adult Children of AIDS Victims Take Their Memories Out of the Shadows
text: On a Thursday night in January, the atmosphere at the Housing Works Bookstore Cafe in SoHo was heavy with nostalgia. More than 100 people mingled, drank wine and swayed in place to hits of the ’70s and ’80s, featuring songs by Lou Reed, David Bowie, Elton John and the B-52’s.

headline: Online ‘Swatting’ Becomes a Hazard for Popular Video Gamers and Police Responders
text: Practical jokers have delighted for years at tormenting celebrities at home by calling in bogus reports of violence and provoking huge police responses.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
text: A visiting prince, stalled confirmation hearings and a Women’s History Month reception.

headline: Urging Treatment for Activist in Jail in China, 16 Are Briefly Detained Themselves
text: HONG KONG — Sixteen people who went to a Beijing detention center on Friday to push for medical treatment for one of five detained women’s rights activists were themselves taken into custody, according to one of the 16 detained and a website that documents rights violations. They were all released by 3 a.m. Saturday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
text: Russia and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: $200 Million to Help Food Stamp Recipients Find Jobs
text: Washington — The Obama administration announced on Friday that it would give $200 million to 10 states for pilot projects to help food stamp recipients find jobs, part of a larger effort to reduce the rolls of a program that provides assistance to nearly 50 million Americans.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Pierre Paulin: Beyond Pop
text: A revival of interest in the iconic 1960s and ’70s work of the French designer has revealed an artist whose career was more varied and extensive than most realize.

headline: A Love That Braved the Cold
text: Tina Zanetti and Tyler Forsyth were married on March 14 in the Ice Chapel at the Hôtel de Glace in Quebec.

headline: The Waiters Wear Tuxedos
text: The fine-dining experience at Le Périgord, a French restaurant at 52nd Street and First Avenue in Manhattan, has barely changed over 50 years.

headline: Cold Enough to Warm the Heart
text: It’s hard to avoid the irony: A woman who thwarted her boyfriend’s plan for a marriage proposal because of the cold is married in a chapel made of snow and ice in Quebec, with a blizzard as a bonus.

headline: Tituss Burgess on a Role Tailor-Made for Him on ‘Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt’
text: “ ‘Looking for a wannabe Broadway actor, broke, down on his luck, who lives in Harlem in a basement apartment,’ ” said Tituss Burgess, who was recently sitting in a cafe down the street from his former Harlem basement apartment. He was remembering the casting call for what would turn out to be the second lead on Netflix’s “Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt.” It was basically him. Sure, Titus, the character on the show, lacked the additional “s” in his name. But, otherwise, the similarities — gay, black, fabulous — were undeniable. “I thought, ‘Is this a joke or am I about to get a job?’ ” Mr. Burgess said with a laugh.

headline: At Le Périgord, Few Changes Since Burton and Taylor Dined There in ’64
text: On a recent chilly evening, when the weather called for a comforting meal and warm ambience, Le Périgord was as welcoming as ever. The restaurant’s 78-year-old owner, Georges Briguet, wearing a tuxedo, stood at the entry of his fancy French restaurant, greeting customers either with a handshake or a kiss on both cheeks, a ritual more than 50 years old.

headline: Bill Cunningham | The Gales of March
text: The new style of floppy wide-brimmed felt hats is a problem in the windy streets, especially on 23rd Street and Fifth Avenue, a corner that’s said to have been known in the 1920s as “23 Skidoo” because of the admonishment police would shout at men who waited there to see the wind lift the skirts of female passers-by.

headline: Bill Cunningham | The Gales of March
text: The new style of floppy wide-brimmed felt hats is a problem in the windy streets, especially on 23rd Street and Fifth Avenue, a corner that’s said to have been known in the 1920s as “23 Skidoo.”

headline: 49 Fouls Later, West Virginia Outlasts Buffalo
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — The windows of opportunity were left wide open, as if to beg 12th-seeded Buffalo to jump through them and escape its first N.C.A.A. tournament game with something to show for it.

headline: Narita, Japan: A Flight Crew Secret
text: Layovers at Narita International Airport mean time to visit this historic city.

headline: The Good Host, but Bad Bookseller, of Brazenhead Books
text: The tenement building on East 84th Street does not have a sign or a label on the downstairs buzzer for the apartment housing the secret bookstore.

headline: New York City Starts Car Loan Program to Curb Abusive Practices
text: When Hurricane Sandy destroyed her car, Rhoda Branche was desperate for another. But just a year later, she could not wait to get rid of the one that replaced it.

headline: March 20, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Russia, Mexico, Yemen and Turkey.

headline: How to Manage Media in Families
text: Parents have a love-hate relationship with firsts. Some they like: the first smile, the first steps, the first sleeping through the night. Others they dread: the first flu, the first tantrum, the first broken bone. As children get older, the firsts become more nuanced, generating both joy in our children’s independence and fear of their slipping away: the first summer away, the first date, the first driver’s license.

headline: A Visit to Vu Linh, Vietnam
text: The village includes a lodge that celebrates the culture of Dao, one of the country’s ethnic groups.

headline: Rules for Teen and Tween Cellphone Use: Unspoken, or Printed and Signed?
text: Last month, my 13-year-old bought his first mobile phone. In keeping with our family’s general electronic gadgetry policy, he saved up for it himself, and he’ll make the monthly payments himself, although he gets a good deal because he is on my brand-new “family plan.” If he referees two hockey games a month, he can cover it. (He has other income-making plans for spring and summer, and enough savings that I’m confident I won’t ever have to float him).

headline: Rand Paul Calls on Hillary Clinton to Return All Foreign Gifts
text: Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, appears to be trying to turn one of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s greatest strengths into a weakness, implicating her in a “war on women” because of gifts she has received from foreign countries.

headline: Evening Hours | Vibrant Celebrations
text: Celebrating activism, the arts and education.

headline: Death of a Muse: Manuela Pavesi, Miuccia Prada’s Close Collaborator
text: Manuela Pavesi was a passionate archivist of her own past, hanging on over time to cherished mementos of a life in style. Not long ago, she reminisced about the pinafore she wore as a schoolgirl in her native Mantua. “I still have it,” she said.

headline: The Age of Frozen Certainties
text: The Times has an interesting headline here: Richard Fisher, Often Wrong but Seldom Boring, Leaves the Fed. Because entertainment value is what we want from central bankers, right? I mean, Janet Yellen is such a drag — she just keeps being right about the economy, and that gets old really fast, you know?

headline: Lena Dunham and the ‘Man Who Drew Eloise’
text: A few years ago, Hilary Knight, the illustrator best known for “Eloise,” was talking with a builder he knows in East Hampton. The guy had just read a profile in New York Magazine of Lena Dunham, which mentioned she had an Eloise tattoo. “I was unaware of Lena Dunham,” Mr. Knight, 88, said recently.

headline: Young Mixed Pair Wins Lebhar Imp Title
text: NEW ORLEANS — The Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, the premier event at the Spring North American Championships here, will have new champions after Sunday’s final. Last year’s winners, Nick Nickell, Ralph Katz, Bobby Levin, Steve Weinstein, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell, lost in the Round of 32 to Gaylor Kasle and Larry Kozlove playing with four Europeans, Joris Lankveld and Berend Van Den Bos from the Netherlands and Bartosz Chmurski and Piotr Tuczynski from Poland by 94 international match points to 92.

headline: Review: New York Philharmonic Performs Esa-Pekka Salonen’s ‘Nyx’
text: Set the rumor machine to overdrive: Esa-Pekka Salonen appeared with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday.

headline: The Math of March Madness
text: THE N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament started Thursday, but for most Americans the real action began days before, as they pored over brackets, competing to make the most accurate predictions — for money, or just office glory. These days, when statistical algorithms can figure out what breakfast cereal you want based on your browser history, stats-minded hoops fans have thrown lots of complex analysis at the problem of picking winners.

headline: A History of the First Mass-Produced Baseball Card
text: Q. While waiting endlessly for Opening Day, I got to wondering: What was the first baseball card?

headline: The Problem With Egg Freezing
text: Nobody really knows how well egg freezing works. Despite that, the practice has received significant media attention, thanks in part to a startup that now hosts “egg-freezing parties.” And while it may turn out to be effective for some women, the current discussion underscores an enduring fact: When it comes to having and caring for children, women are all too often on their own.

headline: Hillary’s Eternal Quest for Relatability
text: This morning, I found myself in one of those overcaffeinated, overendorphined, “what could possibly go wrong?” states as I perused my Twitter feed. Dangerous! Soon I found myself talking back to certain tweets, usually in my head. But sometimes not. I hate Twitter.

headline: Mets’ Hopes May Be Dashed, but Not by the Loss of Zack Wheeler
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — When Zack Wheeler learned on Monday that his job had changed from pitcher to patient, he hung up the phone and returned to the Mets’ clubhouse in a daze.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Virginia Pulls Away Late Against Belmont
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Craig Bradshaw lofted a 3-point shot that banked off the glass and into the net with 4 minutes 37 seconds left as No. 15-seeded Belmont closed the Bruins to 2 points behind No. 2 Virginia in their first-round East Region game. Belmont was on a run, and Virginia was in trouble.

headline: An Imaginary Battle Comes to Life at the Hudson River Museum
text: Bonnie Prince Johnnie, flamboyant pharaoh of New York; Francesca, a.k.a. Tisiphone, Native American assassin; Maurits de Wolff, former slave and soldier extraordinaire; Akosua Van Der Zee, wrathful feminist and malicious schemer.

headline: Exploring ‘Married at First Sight,’ ‘Surviving Marriage’ and ‘Neighbors With Benefits’
text: Love is a feeling, to be sure, but love is also a choice — the choice to let someone in, and to get inside someone else.

headline: Wichita St. Withstands 3-Point Fest by Indiana
text: OMAHA — It took several anxious moments in the second half, and one jarred tooth, but basketball fans in Kansas will get exactly what they wanted: a cross-state matchup of Kansas and Wichita State in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s round of 32 on Sunday.

headline: Sebastião Salgado’s Journey From Brazil to the World
text: In a wide-ranging interview, Sebastião Salgado discusses a new documentary that tracks his path from childhood in Brazil to witnessing some of the greatest stories of his age.

headline: A Governor Faces Down the Gun Lobby
text: The power of the gun lobby over statehouse politicians has led to a raft of laws dear to gun rights adherents, from a measure allowing concealed firearms on college campuses to one legalizing the open carrying of holstered pistols for those who like to swagger into restaurants and coffee bars. The growing question of whether the lobby had nullified all serious political resistance was answered Friday when West Virginia Gov. Earl Ray Tomblin, usually a reliable supporter of the National Rifle Association, vetoed a bill to scrap the current law that citizens have to get a permit and take gun safety lessons in order to legally carry a concealed weapon in the state.

headline: Undoing the Ruins Once Wrought by Vesuvius
text: POMPEII, Italy — Despite its name, the Villa of the Mysteries, arguably the best-known monument at the archaeological site here buried by Vesuvian fury in A.D. 79, has something to reveal.

headline: Crime Scenes, as Seen by the Police
text: A trove of photographs taken by the New York Police Department will soon be made available to the public.

headline: Dusting Off a Police Trove of Photographs to Rival Weegee’s
text: The picture, of a coat and a hat, was one of seven taken that afternoon at the Latin Lounge. But why?

headline: Why Not Utopia?
text: SOME quake in terror as we approach the Terminator scenario, in which clever machines take over the world. After all, it isn’t sci-fi when Stephen Hawking says things like, “The development of full artificial intelligence could spell the end of the human race.”

headline: Review: The Joyce Unleashed Series, With a Middle Eastern Flavor
text: Is there anything more sentimental than a home video of a little kid dancing? What if you extracted only the motions and put them in a different body, on an empty stage? “Helga and the Three Sailors,” a richly detailed dance by Netta Yerushalmy, begins with an exercise in that vein. Alongside short, looping clips of herself as a child, Ms. Yerushalmy does again what she did back then, but with no emotional inflection. The physical facts of flailing in the living room or wobbling along a garden path, it turns out, make for compelling choreography.

headline: ‘Infinite Possibility’ From an Iranian Artist
text: The works of Monir Shahroudy Farmanfarmaian are on exhibition at the Guggenheim. At 91, she is having her first solo show at a major New York museum.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Insurgent’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The Divergent Series: Insurgent.”

headline: A Day After a Killing, Afghans React in Horror, but Some Show Approval
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The mentally ill woman, her face covered in blood, rose to her feet and looked out across the mob. She pleaded. But these men meant to kill her.

headline: Monir Farmanfarmaian, Iranian and Nonagenarian, Celebrates a New York Museum First
text: The artist Monir Farmanfarmaian used to visit the Guggenheim museum in the early 1950s, when it was still in a townhouse and still known by its ponderous first handle, the Museum of Non-Objective Painting. She was there the day in 1956 when ground was broken for Frank Lloyd Wright’s concrete spiral. And the other evening, at the age of 91, she stood in the rotunda of that spiral, using a reporter to help her fend off a crowd of admirers pressing in from all sides.

headline: Movie Review: ‘The Gunman’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “The Gunman.”

headline: Crimescenes, as Seen by the Police
text: A trove of photographs taken by the New York Police Department will soon be made available to the public.

headline: What They Did in the War: Two Japanese Actresses’ Propaganda Work
text: American moviegoers may know Setsuko Hara: symbol of the quiet strength of the Japanese woman in films from the 1940s and ’50s, especially Yasujiro Ozu’s “Late Spring,” “Early Summer” and “Tokyo Story.” And we know Shirley Yamaguchi: a spitfire whose career included starring roles in Samuel Fuller’s “House of Bamboo” and King Vidor’s “Japanese War Bride.”

headline: Scott Walker’s Path
text: Highlights of the political career of Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a candidate for the Republican presidential nomination in 2016.

headline: For 2016 Run, Scott Walker Washes ‘Wiscahnsin’ Out of His Mouth
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Out on the presidential campaign trail, Gov. Scott Walker has left “Wiscahnsin” back home in Wisconsin. He now wants to strengthen the economy, not the “ecahnahmy.” And while he once had the “ahnor” of meeting fellow Republicans, he told one group here this week that he simply enjoyed “talkin’ with y’all.”

headline: Do the Democrats and Israel Have a Future Together?
text: Last September, on the afternoon of Rosh Hashana, the beginning of the Jewish High Holy Days, Elliott Abrams sat cross-legged on a basement carpet in Virginia playing marbles with his grandson. The former George W. Bush administration official, who supervised U.S. policy in the Middle East, is the father-in-law of a young rabbi at a reform synagogue in Washington that had been torn between its love of Israel and its loathing of Benjamin Netanyahu’s right-wing government.

headline: Louisville’s Guards Outmaneuver U.C. Irvine’s Big Men in a Close Victory
text: SEATTLE — Through almost all of Louisville’s 57-55 win Friday, U.C. Irvine had the tallest player on the floor. In the first half, the Anteaters put in either the 7-foot-6 center Mamadou Ndiaye, a sophomore from Senegal, or the 7-2 center Ioannis Dimakopoulos, a sophomore from Greece.

headline: Bartolo Colon, Michael Cuddyer and Curtis Granderson Pace Mets
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Although their baseball odometer shows a lot of mileage, Bartolo Colon, Michael Cuddyer and Curtis Granderson showed for at least one day that there was still a lot of life left in their game.

headline: Tolstoy’s Home
text: The one-time estate of Leo Tolstoy is now a Russian state museum.

headline: In Putin’s Nationalist Russia, a Tolstoy as Cultural Diplomat
text: YASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — On a sunny winter afternoon here, Vladimir Tolstoy, a great-great-grandson of Leo Tolstoy and an adviser on cultural affairs to President Vladimir V. Putin, strode up the birch-lined path that leads to the bucolic family compound where his forebear wrote “War and Peace” and “Anna Karenina.” It is now a state museum. At each step, he was greeted by staff members heading home for the day.

headline: Scott Walker’s Accent Then and Now
text: As Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin gets ready for a presidential campaign, his regional accent seems to be softening.

headline: Woman Breaks Through Chains of Forced Marriage, and Helps Others Do the Same
text: NEWARK — One day in March 2011, Fraidy Reiss went to her lawyer’s office to close on a house. The prosaic routine of paperwork somehow diminished her sense of accomplishment. Not even the seller was present to hear what she yearned to say.

headline: Friday Night Music: SOAK
text: I saw a lot of great stuff at SWSX — San Fermin, Alvvays, Courtney Barnett, and more. Also ate and drank too much to make up despite some lovely long runs along the river.

headline: Robert Kastenmeier, Liberal Voice in House for 32 Years, Dies at 91
text: Robert W. Kastenmeier, a Wisconsin Democrat who in 32 years in the House was an early opponent of the Vietnam War and in 1976 earned the gratitude of authors when he managed the first general revision of copyright law since 1909, died on Friday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 91.

headline: Aging Bridge in California Needs All the Support It Can Get
text: ALBION, Calif. — Sometimes, a bridge is more than a way to get from here to there.

headline: A Car-Free Day on San Fernando Valley Roads
text: California’s San Fernando Valley is hosting the bike-centric event called CicLAvia for the first time on Sunday, March 22.

headline: Maryland Fends Off Valparaiso’s Upset Bid
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — In a skirmish of 3-pointers, Maryland slipped past Valparaiso, 65-62, and thwarted a furious bid to end its season Friday at Nationwide Arena.

headline: Cuba: Split in Dissident Group
text: The daughter of Laura Pollán, founder of the dissident group Ladies in White, has split from the organization, signaling divisions over the rapprochement between Cuba and the United States and, perhaps, the end of an era in which the white-clad women symbolized the fight for political freedom. Ms. Pollán’s daughter, Laura Maria Labrada, announced on Thursday that she would leave the group because of differences with its leader, Berta Soler. She said the Ladies in White could no longer use Ms. Pollán’s name or her house, which had been the group’s headquarters. Ms. Pollán died in 2011. Tensions within the group have sharpened since the Dec. 17 thaw between Cuba and the United States, which Ms. Soler opposes and Ms. Labrada supports. Members this month accused Ms. Soler of being autocratic and called for her to resign, leading to a vote on her leadership, which she won.

headline: In Tunisia, Taking Stock of the Dead, and the Survivors
text: TUNIS — Still shaken on Friday by a brazen attack that killed 23 people at the National Bardo Museum in the heart of the capital two days before, Tunisian officials spent their Independence Day — a public holiday here — evacuating dead and wounded foreign tourists and burying their own.

headline: Defending a Tax Analysis
text: To the Editor:

headline: Florida Justices Reject 70-Year Sentence for Juvenile, Likening It to Life Term
text: The Florida Supreme Court has ordered a new sentencing hearing for a man who received 70 years in prison without parole for an attempted murder at the age of 14. The court agreed with lawyers for the defendant, Shimeek D. Gridine, that his sentence violated the limits on juvenile penalties set by the United States Supreme Court.

headline: Poland: Priest’s Abuse Trial Opens
text: A Polish priest accused of sexually abusing minors in Poland and in the Dominican Republic, where he led a parish for almost a decade, offered to serve a seven-year jail sentence as his trial opened on Friday, according to a spokeswoman for a regional court in Warsaw. The priest, the Rev. Wojciech Gil, is charged with committing 10 crimes, most of which relate to the molestation of boys under the age of 15. If convicted, he could serve up to 15 years in prison. During the trial, Father Gil for the first time since his arrest did not deny the charges, the court spokeswoman said, but it is unclear whether he pleaded guilty. Under Polish law, a defendant can offer to serve a jail term for some crimes without admitting to any guilt. The trial resumes on Wednesday.

headline: Morgan Hoffmann, a Pilot, Handles Pressure as He Seeks His First PGA Win
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Morgan Hoffmann, pro golfer and amateur pilot, was performing touch-and-go maneuvers on a Stuart, Fla., runway when a vulture flew into his line of sight. Worried that the bird was on a collision course with the propeller, Hoffmann swiftly pulled up his aircraft, a six-seat Piper Lance turboprop.

headline: Cuomo Focuses on Ethics Reform, Not on Funding It
text: ALBANY — Though Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo made expanding oversight of public officials a centerpiece of his agenda this year, none of New York State’s commissions or agencies specifically charged with policing ethical lapses received an increase in funding in his proposed budget.

headline: Canada: Men Found Guilty of Terrorism
text: Two men who plotted to derail a passenger train traveling from New York to Toronto were convicted on Friday of various terrorism charges, including terrorism-related conspiracy to commit murder. Most of the evidence against the men, Chiheb Esseghaier, a Tunisian graduate student in Montreal, and Raed Jaser, a stateless Palestinian with previous criminal convictions, were recordings secretly made by an F.B.I. agent who posed as a wealthy American businessman who held radical political and religious views. The two men are to be sentenced next month.

headline: A Real-Time Peek at Traffic to U.S. Government Websites
text: The federal government is offering the public a window into its web traffic. On Thursday, it introduced a new site that gives real-time insight into how many people are navigating to many government websites.

headline: In a Good Sign, Alex Rodriguez Hits a Home Run
text: LAKELAND, Fla. — As Alex Rodriguez rounded first base on Friday, his eyes fixed on right field, he turned back toward the bag, uncertain where to go.

headline: Netanyahu, the Palestinians and the Election in Israel
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cincinnati Has a Bald, 5-Foot-8, Frenzied Coach. No, the Other One.
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — When he became ill, Mick Cronin, the head coach at Cincinnati, did not hand the reins of the basketball program to just any coach. He handed them to his twin, to his equivalent, to a man who shares Cronin’s doctrine of maniacal basketball. Cut them open, and Cronin and the interim coach Larry Davis are the same man.

headline: Is a Streetcar Still Something to Desire?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Walter Channing Jr., Vintner and Sculptor, Dies at 74
text: Walter Channing Jr., who combined careers as a venture capitalist, sculptor and well-regarded vintner on Long Island, died on March 12 in Southampton, N.Y. He was 74.

headline: McConnell and Coal
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tinder Appoints Chief Executive to Replace Sean Rad
text: Tinder, the mobile dating application, said on Friday it had appointed Christopher Payne chief executive, a step toward building the two-and-a-half-year-old company into a booming business.

headline: Skills in the New Economy
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Slaughterers of Srebrenica’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Robert Durst’s Papers Are Seized From a Hudson Valley Cellar
text: The authorities moved swiftly to search the home of Robert A. Durst in Houston as well as a hotel room in New Orleans after his arrest on first-degree murder charges there a week ago.

headline: Sherman’s Last Stand
text: By the final months of the Civil War, a combination of geography and human agency began to break down the long-standing distinction between the Eastern Theater, consisting of operations in and around Virginia, and the Western Theater, which encompassed everything between the Appalachian Mountains and the Mississippi River. In fact, in one of the war’s great ironies, the closing act of the Western Theater occurred in east central North Carolina.

headline: U.S. May Stay in Afghanistan After '16
text: WASHINGTON — A White House official on Friday appeared to leave open the possibility that American troops could remain in Afghanistan after President Obama leaves office, in what would be a marked shift from the administration’s insistence that only a small force based at the embassy in Kabul would remain after 2016.

headline: Officials Urge Patience as Hanging of Black Man Is Investigated in Mississippi
text: PORT GIBSON, Miss. — Approximately 30 federal, state and local law enforcement agents have descended upon this small Southern town to investigate the death of a black man whose body was found hanging from a tree. But two federal law enforcement officials said Friday that preliminary indications suggested that the man might have committed suicide, and the local sheriff said that there was no indication that racism had played a role.

headline: A Woman’s Place Is on the $20
text: You may have heard that there’s a movement afoot to kick Andrew Jackson off the $20 bill and replace him with a woman. Finally, we’ve got a current event that’s not depressing.

headline: Notre Dame Rides a Streak With Shoes Like Highlighters
text: PITTSBURGH — In the second week of February, a shipment from Under Armour arrived at Notre Dame. Mixed in with hats and jumpsuits and T-shirts were the boxes that Harold Swanagan, the coordinator of basketball operations, was expecting.

headline: Bill Raftery-Grant Hill Analyst Team Has a Bland Debut but a Better Sequel
text: Casting a three-announcer booth is rarely easy. You need a play-by-play announcer who can get the best out of two analysts, not the usual one. You need two analysts with different perspectives who can provide complementary commentary without each repeating what the other has just said. And you need those analysts to accommodate each other — and not fight for airtime between plays.

headline: Mexico: Elite Police Officers Slain
text: A new, elite federal police unit intended to be a premiere force against drug gangs suffered its biggest loss this week when five members were killed in an ambush, federal officials said Friday, raising questions among analysts about the unit’s training. The ambush, in Jalisco State on Thursday, left five other people dead, including two civilian bystanders and three of the presumed attackers, officials said. The officers belonged to the Gendarmerie, a 5,000-officer division of the federal police formed last year by President Enrique Peña Nieto to go after organized-crime groups hurting economic interests in various trouble spots in an effort to ease foreign investors’ concerns about safety. The officers were in a convoy patrolling an industrial corridor in Ocotlan when they came under gunfire from more than a dozen vehicles. It was unclear what prompted the attack.

headline: Philadelphia Commissioner Steps Into Fray Between Police and Public
text: PHILADELPHIA — When Police Commissioner Charles H. Ramsey and District Attorney R. Seth Williams appeared at a town hall meeting here on Thursday, they were prepared to explain why criminal charges had not been filed against an officer who in December fatally shot a young black man in the back of the head.

headline: Georgia State’s Sixth Man Has Four Wheels and Countless Fans
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — A celebrity deserves better. Fame, even for 15 minutes, should carry some cachet. Maybe an upgraded suite with plush carpeting, designer seat coverings, a comfy corner to rest weary wheels? How about a place behind a fancy desk, if just for one night?

headline: Duke Shows Robert Morris It Should Be Careful What It Wishes For
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Gleeful Robert Morris fans chanted “We want Duke” in the final seconds of their N.C.A.A. tournament play-in victory against North Florida on Wednesday in Dayton, Ohio. So the fans got what they wanted.

headline: How to Make Landslides Less Deadly
text: SEATTLE — IN the year since 43 people died in a landslide in Oso, Wash., we have often been asked, as researchers who investigated this tragedy, how many other potential landslide disasters exist around the country.

headline: The Greece Issue Breeds Brinkmanship in the Eurozone
text: Nobody expected that the discussions between Greece and the rest of the eurozone about a new loan agreement would go smoothly. But things seem to be going even worse than expected, with both sides sniping at each other and refusing to engage in meaningful negotiations.

headline: Overtime Pay for Overworked People
text: More than a year has passed since President Obama directed the Labor Department to revamp the nation’s outdated rules on overtime pay, which are basically stuck in the 1970s. A February deadline is long gone and there has been no proposal.

headline: Backsliding on Reform in Myanmar
text: This is an important year for Myanmar. Parliamentary elections are scheduled for November, and the military-dominated government of President Thein Sein promised they would be free, fair and inclusive. That promise is looking increasingly tenuous, as signs that Myanmar is retreating on democratic reform multiply.

headline: Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet Plans to Close
text: Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet seemed like the dance company that had it all: a wealthy benefactor, generous contracts and benefits for its dancers, and a snazzy Chelsea home.

headline: It Comes Before Iyar
text: SATURDAY POST — Today’s puzzle by Frederick J. Healy will be reviewed by editor Will Shortz today, because 1) he has a lot to say about it, and 2) he is a nice person and knows that I haven’t had a day off in a very long time.

headline: Evicted Tenant Started Queens Fire, Officials Say
text: A fire that raced through a block of homes in Woodhaven, Queens, on Wednesday night was started by an angry tenant just minutes after his landlord evicted him from his apartment, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: Chris Christie’s Fair Housing Problem
text: The Supreme Court of New Jersey has finally run out of patience with Gov. Chris Christie’s attempts to nullify its groundbreaking, three-decades-old decision in the Mount Laurel fair housing case, which prohibits wealthy towns from excluding affordable housing and requires them to write zoning laws that allow such housing to be built.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 20, 2015
text: March 20, 2015

headline: Oregon Shoots Down Oklahoma State
text: OMAHA — Dana Altman’s return to Nebraska, where he grew up and coached for 16 years at Creighton, has been extended by two more days.

headline: See No Junk Food, Buy No Junk Food
text: FROM urban ghettos to declining inner-ring suburbs to destitute rural areas, Americans with little money live in “food deserts” where it is hard to find fresh fruits and vegetables.

headline: Obama Calls Nominee ‘Hostage’ of Trafficking Dispute
text: President Obama on Friday said that Republicans were holding Loretta E. Lynch “hostage” to a legislative disagreement unrelated to her nomination as attorney general. “She is eminently qualified — nobody denies it,” Mr. Obama said in an interview with The Huffington Post. “Even the Republicans acknowledge she’s been a great prosecutor.” Republicans have said they will not hold the vote until a dispute with Democrats over a measure to create a fund for victims of sexual trafficking is resolved. “You don’t hold attorney general nominees hostage for other issues,” Mr. Obama said. He blamed “Senate dysfunction” and “stubbornness” by Republicans about approving any of his nominees.

headline: A Life Upended After an IV Glucose Treatment Popular Among Asian Immigrants
text: SEOUL, South Korea — On a Thursday in late February, Myung Hwa Jang swung her feet off her bed and gingerly placed her pink Nike sneakers on the floor. With effort, she balanced on her artificial limbs and stood. It had been two years since both of her legs were amputated below the knees, along with her right arm and most of her left hand, after an infection raced through her body following a glucose injection she received in a storefront clinic in Flushing, Queens.

headline: Taxi Jumps Curb, Killing Pedestrian in the Bronx
text: A taxi killed one pedestrian and critically injured two others in the Bronx on Friday when it jumped a curb and careered onto the sidewalk on a snowy night, the police said.

headline: Iowa’s Height Shuts Down Davidson’s 3-Point Game
text: SEATTLE — Time and again Friday night, one of Davidson’s guards — Jack Gibbs, perhaps, or Brian Sullivan, each 5 feet 11 inches — took the ball down the court and was met by a humid jungle of arms. Iowa’s lengthy, lithe forwards were outstretched, blocking passing lanes, ready to put a hand in the Davidson player’s face.

headline: Panic at New Orleans Airport as Police Shoot Man Who Attacked T.S.A. Officers
text: NEW ORLEANS — A 63-year-old man attacked Transportation Security Administration officers with wasp spray and a machete Friday night before he was shot by a law enforcement officer at a security gate to a busy concourse at Louis Armstrong International Airport outside New Orleans, the authorities said.

headline: Jason Kidd’s Past Meets, and Beats, His Present (and Future)
text: The juxtaposition of the Nets and the Milwaukee Bucks on Friday provided more evidence of the capriciousness of sports fates, the fallibility of best-laid plans and the peculiarity of the Eastern Conference.

headline: Oklahoma Sputters but Holds Off Feisty Albany
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Midway through the first half of Albany’s game against Oklahoma, Peter Hooley planted his feet, calibrated his hips and launched a 3-point attempt high into the air.

headline: Roosevelt Jones of Butler Is Cleared to Play
text: Butler’s second-leading scorer, Roosevelt Jones, will be available to play against Notre Dame on Saturday.

headline: Ron Hunter Says ‘Sorry’ After a Poke at the President
text: Occasionally at the tournament, coaches go on entertaining tangents during their off-day news conferences.

headline: Northern Iowa Player Aims to Follow Brother’s Path to Final Four
text: SEATTLE — In 2001, Gordy Bohannon drove his three older sons from their home in Iowa to the Final Four in Minneapolis. After watching Duke defeat Arizona for the national championship, they drove back, and the sons told themselves that their goal was to one day play in the Final Four.

headline: Readers Respond to Starbucks ‘Race Together’ Initiative
text: It’s early and a line of sleepy folk who just want to grab a soy latte and get to work snakes through Starbucks. But first, the barista behind the counter needs to broach a sensitive subject.

headline: Suddenly Hot-Shooting San Diego State Frustrates St. John’s
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — D’Angelo Harrison had just exhausted himself on the offensive end, trying to help St. John’s come back from a double-digit second-half deficit. Walking toward the raucous contingent of Red Storm fans, he shook his head back at them.

headline: Gonzaga Bears Down for Win After North Dakota State’s Strong Start
text: SEATTLE — Gonzaga began the game pressing North Dakota State, and the Bison, the heavy underdogs, passed right through it, getting ahead of Gonzaga’s defenders to sink two 3-pointers. Nearly three minutes into the game, they led by 9-4.

headline: Wisconsin Prevails as Coastal Carolina Fades After Strong First Half
text: OMAHA — Coastal Carolina, the No. 16 seed in the West Region of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, hit just enough shots to hang with top-seeded Wisconsin for the first 13 minutes of their game in the round of 64 on Friday.

headline: Serena Williams Withdraws From Indian Wells With Knee Injury
text: Serena Williams withdrew from the semifinals of the BNP Paribas Open, citing a knee injury. Her withdrawal gave Simona Halep a walkover into the final.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
text: 9 P.M. (IFC) INGLOURIOUS BASTERDS (2009) This revisionist history by Quentin Tarantino takes place during World War II as Lt. Aldo Raine (Brad Pitt) leads a special unit of Jewish American soldiers, dedicated to scalping Nazis, on to a plot to kill Hitler. Shosanna Dreyfus (Mélanie Laurent) escapes the murder of her family by Col. Hans Landa (Christoph Waltz) and his men and runs a movie theater in Paris. When the Nazis choose her theater for the premiere of a propaganda film, Shosanna begins scheming. For more Tarantino, “Kill Bill: Vol. 2” plays at 8 on Showtime. The film follows Beatrix Kiddo (Uma Thurman) as she takes revenge on the Deadly Viper Assassination Squad. Mr. Tarantino’s “movies are about loss and betrayal, and ‘Kill Bill Vol. 2’ is a double-burger helping of those motifs,” Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times. “It is rich, substantial and sustained, yet also greasy kids’ stuff.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “Well, I guess the question is, which one?”

headline: Editors’ Note: March 21, 2015
text: STYLES

headline: Dayton Upsets Providence in Front of Raucous Ohio Crowd
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — To earn a spot in the main portion of the N.C.A.A. tournament, Dayton slipped by Boise State this week in a play-in contest that was a virtual home game for the Flyers. When the team traveled an hour east to Columbus, it was as if the Flyers had moved from their living room to their kitchen.

headline: Chinese, Japanese and South Korean Ministers to Resume Three-Way Talks
text: SEOUL, South Korea — In their first trilateral meeting in three years, the foreign ministers of South Korea, Japan and China recognized on Saturday the urgent need to stop North Korea’s nuclear weapons program, South Korean officials said.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Backcountry’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Backcountry.”

headline: A Bustling Day on Board
text: As cruise ships grow larger, the employees’ attention to detail and planning have become more necessary.

headline: A Luxury Liner Docks, and the Countdown’s On
text: Once a week, after touring the Caribbean, the cruise ship Oasis of the Seas calls into its home port in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., for what is called “turnaround day.”

headline: Brooklyn Fire Kills 7 Children, City’s Worst Toll Since 2007
text: A hot plate warmed food in the darkened kitchen in Brooklyn, allowing an Orthodox Jewish mother to feed her family while observing the Sabbath prohibition on lighting a flame. Upstairs, she and eight children slept.

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photographers featured on @nytimes, our Instagram account, took viewers to Manhattan’s St. Patrick’s Day parade and offered a look from Air Force One.

headline: Hotel Gardens Go (and Grow) Local
text: ­Botanists and horticulturists are being hired by hotels to help their gardens grow, with an increasing focus on indigenous flora.

headline: Philadelphia Meeting Erupts Into Chaos
text: Protesters at a community meeting became disruptive and threw chairs after a district attorney announced that two police officers had been cleared in the shooting death of Brandon Tate-Brown.

headline: Kerry Pushes Iran Nuclear Deal Timetable Amid Differences With France
text: LONDON — Stressing that it was time to make tough decisions, Secretary of State John Kerry said Saturday that negotiators should stick to their goal of completing an initial accord limiting Iran‘s nuclear program by the end of March.

headline: Breaking Up Is Hard for Renters
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: From Minneapolis to ISIS: An American’s Path to Jihad
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Reading back over Abdi Nur’s Twitter feed, his chilling progression from the basketball courts of South Minneapolis to the battlefields of Syria is clear.

headline: A Tough Business
text: Here’s a writeup of the panel that brought me to SXSW. As you might expect, the Butler brothers from Arcade Fire are really well-spoken and interesting; basically, I’m pretty sure they could do my job, whereas there’s no way I could do theirs.

headline: Review: In the Comic ‘Baskerville’ at the McCarter Theater Center, Sherlock Holmes Investigates a Curse
text: The mystery inside the mystery of “Baskerville” is why this fairly amusing play isn’t funnier. Indeed, so many of the elements are first-rate — skilled actors and a clever staging at the McCarter Theater Center in Princeton among them — that it can feel downright puzzling when jokes miss their marks. Sure, there are laughs. But it often seems that they should be louder.

headline: Fatal Fire in Brooklyn
text: Seven children died in a two-alarm fire at a house in the Midwood neighborhood that was caused by a hot plate.

headline: Carter Burwell, Writing Music to Watch Corpses By
text: What kind of movie music best suits a psychopath?

headline: Variety: A Constrained Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — It is debatable whether the CORSET will ever regain the popularity it seems to have had during the VICTORIAN era, but there is still a contingent of women — and drag queens — who enjoy the shape it gives to their figures.

headline: In ‘The Pianist of Willesden Lane,’ Holding On to Her Mother’s Memories
text: After performances of her one-woman show, Mona Golabek said, people sometimes ask her, “Why wasn’t I warned to bring more handkerchiefs?”

headline: Izola Ware Curry, Who Stabbed King in 1958, Dies at 98
text: Izola Ware Curry, the mentally ill woman who in 1958 stabbed the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. at a Harlem book signing — an episode that a decade later would become a rhetorical touchstone in the last oration of his life — died on March 7 in Queens. She was 98.

headline: This Time, Serena Williams Is Cheered as She Leaves Indian Wells
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — In a stark change from 2001, Serena Williams was cheered upon her exit from the Indian Wells tournament on Friday night. Unlike 2001, when she was booed mercilessly, she did not win the tournament, but had to withdraw from the semifinals of the BNP Paribas Open with an injury to her right knee.

headline: At Kenta in Melville, the Menu Is Adventurous and Fun
text: Few Asian restaurants on Long Island have the firepower of Kenta, a newcomer offering food described as modern Asian with Japanese influences.

headline: Chuck Bednarik, Eagles’ Man of Concrete, Dies at 89
text: Chuck Bednarik, the Philadelphia Eagles’ Hall of Fame center and linebacker, one of the last N.F.L. players to commonly play on both offense and defense and a legendary football tough guy, died Saturday in Richland, Pa. He was 89.

headline: A Maven of Money Law
text: Obrea Poindexter is a lawyer at Morrison & Foerster in Washington.

headline: Bringing African Shoppers to the Global Mall
text: Last year, when Tunde Adebayo needed three inflatable bouncy castles for KidzPlay, his event-planning business in Lagos, Nigeria, he turned to an online shopping service called MallforAfrica.

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: A High School Where a Student Might Letter in Polo
text: When the billionaire William I. Koch spent $60 million to start the Oxbridge Academy in West Palm Beach, Fla., he vowed to teach children “how things get done in the real world.”

headline: Ways to Put the Boss’s Skin in the Game
text: Life is not fair, I know, but this is getting ridiculous.

headline: Writing My Way to a New Self
text: I stared at the head counselor with a mixture of defiance, annoyance and heartbreak. She had just informed me that she was demoting me. Gone was the prestige position of senior counselor for a group of 13-year-old girls, and in its place, a midlevel position as a co-counselor for a group of 11-year-olds.

headline: Under Health Care Act, Many Tax Filers Are Discovering Costly Complications
text: PITTSBURGH — When he signed up for health insurance through the Affordable Care Act last fall, J. C. Ciesielski estimated his income at $19,400, qualifying him for a federal subsidy that cut his premiums in half. But Mr. Ciesielski, an actor, earned an extra $2,340 from a voice-over job in December, and that welcome bit of income proved problematic when he did his taxes this month.

headline: Princeton Remains Unbeaten as Obama Watches
text: COLLEGE PARK, Md. — They were undefeated at 30-0 and perhaps under-respected, too, with a low seeding that left them feeling like the oddest underdogs in recent N.C.A.A. tournament memory.

headline: Scottish Party May Prove Crucial to Future of Britain’s Nuclear Fleet
text: FASLANE, Scotland — Britain’s aging nuclear-armed submarines, the force that keeps the nation in the first tier of global powers, have been the target of spirited if largely ineffectual protests by antiwar activists for more than three decades here in the fleet’s home port.

headline: The Curious (and Vital) Power of Print
text: WHO buys the print edition of the newspaper? Just a few Luddites who wouldn’t know a smartphone if their horse-drawn buggy crushed it on the cobblestones? Octogenarians and their older brothers?

headline: Second Person Dies After Taxi Jumps Curb in the Bronx
text: A 5-year-old girl who was among four people struck by a taxi that jumped a curb in the Bronx on Friday night has died, making her the second person killed in the crash, the police said on Saturday.

headline: Angry Protest Over New Bishop in Chile
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — Hundreds of demonstrators dressed in black barged into a cathedral in a city in southern Chile on Saturday and interrupted the installation ceremony for the city’s new Roman Catholic bishop, Juan Barros, whom they accuse of complicity in a notorious case of clerical sexual abuse, blocking his passage and shouting, “Barros, get out of the city!”

headline: Riled Herpetologists Press Obama Administration to Protect America’s Salamanders from a Fungal Threat
text: The herpetologists I’ve met over the decades tend to be a retiring lot. Explore the website of the Herpetologists’ League to get the idea. They hunker down and probe under rotting logs and leaf litter for salamanders or prowl deserts to study tortoises and lizards. Some study ancient specimens in dusty jars. That was the case with the first herpetologist I got to know, during a junior semester abroad in London in 1977. I approached Garth Underwood (yes), at London’s Natural History Museum about undertaking a line of independent study. Underwood set me to work dissecting water snakes, some more than a century old, to look for differences between the sexes. (He passed away in 2002.)

headline: Why Health Care Tech Is Still So Bad
text: LAST year, I saw an ad recruiting physicians to a Phoenix-area hospital. It promoted state-of-the-art operating rooms, dazzling radiology equipment and a lovely suburban location. But only one line was printed in bold: “No E.M.R.”

headline: For College Basketball Players, Skin Is No Longer In
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — In a game with so many tall people, you might expect a little more leg.

headline: ISIS Urges Sympathizers to Kill U.S. Service Members It Identifies on Website
text: WASHINGTON — In a new online threat to American military personnel, the Islamic State has called on its members and sympathizers in the United States to kill 100 service members whose names, photos and purported addresses it posted on a website.

headline: It’s a Whole New Paranoid World
text: THERE is probably nothing about me that is not in the hands of hackers.

headline: No Seasonal Fix for the Economy
text: Some economic forecasters have pinned their hopes for an improvement in the economy on this year’s early Easter to boost consumer spending after a brutal winter.

headline: Gregory Doran
text: Gregory Doran is the artistic director of the Royal Shakespeare Company in Stratford-upon-Avon, England.

headline: Brazil’s Dim Voice on the World Stage
text: When Dilma Rousseff was elected president of Brazil in 2010, industry was thriving and her goal of stamping out poverty in the world’s seventh-largest economy appeared within reach. Many Brazilians hoped that Ms. Rousseff, a former political prisoner, would establish a legacy as a transformational head of state at home and abroad.

headline: Two Women, Opposite Fortunes
text: LUANDA, Angola — THIS is the tale of two women, each an emblem, in her own way, of one of the world’s most corrupt and dysfunctional nations.

headline: A Football Player’s Safe Exit
text: It takes a special kind of professional football player to walk away from cheering crowds and multimillion-dollar paychecks. But that is what Chris Borland, a star rookie for the San Francisco 49ers, felt compelled to do in the face of mounting evidence that the game’s repetitive head trauma could leave him gravely and permanently damaged. “I just thought to myself, ‘What am I doing?’ ” the 24-year-old defensive player explained in an interview with ESPN. “ ‘Is this how I’m going to live my adult life, banging my head, especially with what I’ve learned and know about the dangers?’ ”

headline: Why Jeb Bush Might Lose
text: IF you’re keeping score during the endless 2016 preseason, this was a pretty good week for Jeb Bush.

headline: Our Immigration Policy
text: Readers discuss whether undocumented immigrants should be legitimized and integrated into the United States economy.

headline: In College and Hiding From Scary Ideas
text: KATHERINE BYRON, a senior at Brown University and a member of its Sexual Assault Task Force, considers it her duty to make Brown a safe place for rape victims, free from anything that might prompt memories of trauma.

headline: What’s New, Pussycat? Meerkat!
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — PITY the poor cat.

headline: Just How Nepotistic Are We?
text: THERE is a very real chance that the presidential election in 2016 will pit Jeb Bush against Hillary Clinton. According to oddsmakers, this is the likeliest outcome.

headline: What Begat What
text: IN a recent Daily Beast article, we learned that the two-way wrist radio worn by the cartoon character Dick Tracy helped pave the way for Apple’s new smartwatch, which can make and receive phone calls. “I have been wanting to do this since I was 5 years old,” said Apple’s chief executive, Timothy D. Cook, referring to 1965 when he became besotted with the fictional detective’s gizmo.

headline: Renewing Call to End Turkey Conflict, Kurdish Rebel Leader Hails ‘New Era’
text: ISTANBUL — The jailed Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan on Saturday renewed a call for his fighters to disarm and end a long conflict with Turkey, hailing a “new era” in relations between Turks and Kurds.

headline: A Changing Los Angeles
text: Gentrification comes to areas of the city.

headline: Viva Gentrification!
text: LOS ANGELES — FOR years, our family journeys have taken us from our hillside home, in the multiethnic Mount Washington district of northeast Los Angeles, into the flatlands of the Latino barrios that surround it.

headline: Review: Ariana Grande Leaves Nickelodeon in the Rearview Mirror
text: The first time Ariana Grande cried on Friday night at Madison Square Garden was a little before the halfway mark of her show.

headline: U.C.L.A. Romps Past U.A.B. With Unselfish Play and Domination in the Paint
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — This time, pluck was no match for pedigree, as U.C.L.A. turned to one extraordinary offensive player after another on Saturday to thwart another upset bid by the University of Alabama at Birmingham.

headline: A 50-Year Party, A Legend Revised
text: The ever-innovative Meredith Monk, a composer, dancer, singer, choreographer, director and filmmaker, is celebrating the 50th anniversary of her professional career. On Sunday at Carnegie Hall, she is joined by her acclaimed Vocal Ensemble — which champions her distinctive technique — and a host of musicians from the classical, jazz and D.J. worlds. Those colleagues will include the Bang on a Can All-Stars, Lukas Ligeti, John Zorn, Missy Mazzoli, Jessye Norman and DJ Spooky, performing an all-Monk program. (3 p.m., Zankel Hall, carnegiehall.org.)

headline: A Toxic Wasteland Called Home
text: Since he was a college student, the Houston artist Trenton Doyle Hancock has been drawing into existence a world that might be what Texas would look like if all of the state’s oil were to bubble up and turn it into a toxic zombie wasteland. Populated by creatures called Mounds, the work seems to be the residue of a postmodern fever dream, borrowing as much from museum walls (Peter Saul, Mike Kelley) as from comic-book pages (Basil Wolverton, Spain Rodriguez).

headline: On TV, That Thing With Feathers
text: Masterpiece isn’t a word to be thrown around lightly, but there’s no denying that Mark Morris’s “L’Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato” is thrillingly that. Choreographed in 1988, when Mr. Morris was the director of dance at the Théâtre Royal de la Monnaie in Brussels, this production, at long last, has been preserved on film by “Great Performances” and can be seen on PBS on Friday night. (Check local listings.) Set to Handel’s 1740 oratorio based on Milton’s pastoral poems, this performance by the Mark Morris Dance Group was recorded in 2014 at the Teatro Real in Madrid. Using dance, music, poetry and visual design — Adrianne Lobel’s series of color planes, inspired by watercolors of William Blake, moves right along with the dancers — the production, as the host, Mikhail Baryshnikov, summarizes, reveals “joy, abandon, restraint, dignity and pride for humankind.”

headline: The Lengths to Go for Love
text: You, there — you are worthy of love. How would you like to be loved this week? There are two options — two that count, at least.

headline: Eloise and Hilary, Together Again
text: Her hair was in perpetual disarray, her stomach hung over her skirt, and the things that came out of her mouth weren’t always very nice. But Eloise, that 6-year-old imp running amok at the Plaza Hotel, inspired the fantasies of many a precocious child and more than a few adults — not least Lena Dunham of “Girls” renown, who had Eloise’s likeness tattooed on her back at 17.

headline: A Mother’s Clutch Makes Its Mark
text: Perspectives from a local and international standpoint distinguish the fifth annual New Voices in Black Cinema, running Thursday through next Sunday at BAMCinématek. The festival begins with the world premiere of “Knucklehead,” the writer-director Ben Bowman’s drama about a mentally disabled youth (Gbenga Akinnagbe, from “The Wire”) who struggles to survive life in Brooklyn public housing after the shooting of his brother and the predations of his abusive mother (a terrifying Alfre Woodard). Mr. Bowman and Mr. Akinnagbe field questions after the screening.

headline: Democratic Booms
text: Everyone in the Republican Party knows that Reagan presided over an economy that has never been equalled, before or since. When I was on TV with Rand Paul, he confidently declared

headline: Yankees Squint and Flail Under the Dim Lights of Their Spring Training Stadium
text: TAMPA, Fla. — As the sun set behind George M. Steinbrenner Field on Thursday night, the lights atop the eight towers strained to illuminate the baseball game below.

headline: Threats by Yemen’s Warring Parties Escalate Crisis
text: AL MUKALLA, Yemen — From sparring seats of power across an increasingly divided country, Yemen’s president and the Houthi rebels who forced his government into exile traded ultimatums and threats on Saturday, escalating tensions after days of unrelenting violence.

headline: Myanmar’s Fight With Rebels Creates Refugees and Ill Will With China
text: BEIJING — When rumors spread around the sugar-cane farms in northern Myanmar that the army was advancing, Li Jiapeng and his family packed some clothes, grabbed some cash and joined a long line of people fleeing in cars and on foot. Everyone was heading for safety on the other side of the border in China, just six miles away.

headline: With History as Their Guide, Ducks Are on a Tempered Roll
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The Anaheim Ducks have a young roster, an enviable salary-cap situation, immense resilience to adversity and the N.H.L.’s best record, yet none of that seems to matter in their dressing room.

headline: Anthony Davis Is Unstoppable, Except on the Road to His First Playoffs
text: It may seem odd to suggest that the clock is ticking for Anthony Davis to make the playoffs in just his third season. But when a player as talented as Davis comes around, the wait for the postseason is generally rather short.

headline: ATP Tour Officials Seek Ways to Heighten the Profile of Doubles Players
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — The BNP Paribas Open has long been known for the strength of its doubles field, and this year was no exception, with nine of the top 10 singles players entered. But few ATP Tour events are as fortunate.

headline: Chocolates: Reviews of Holsten’s in Bloomfield, Chocodiem in Clinton and the Fudge Shoppe in Flemington
text: Poor Tony Soprano. When he visited Holsten’s in the final episode of “The Sopranos,” he ordered only the onion rings.

headline: White Sox Open Checkbook After Once Being Tight With Bullpen Budget
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — The strategy sounds wise, because each point behind it is sound. Relief pitchers are notoriously unpredictable. With shrewd scouting and coaching, teams can find effective, low-cost bullpen arms. Therefore, it is foolish to spend big on relievers.

headline: A Review: At Coals in Bronxville, Pizza’s on the Grill
text: Good pizza has been easy to find in Westchester for years. Beyond the traditional New York-style pizza available on virtually every streetcorner, there is the Neapolitan puffy-crusted version from places like Zero Otto Nove in Armonk, wonderful experiments with toppings like the white clam pie at Frank Pepe’s in Yonkers and numerous interpretations of flatbread pizza across the county.

headline: Curtain Rises on a Spanish Second Act
text: Making a great first impression in a community, never mind maintaining it for more than a decade, is a coup for any chef. But when a culinary ace has built a reputation with a particular restaurant, planning a second act presents its own challenges. How best to follow up, when your opening set has already been so well received?

headline: In ‘Just Kids From the Bronx,’ Famous Names Recall Their Roots
text: Real New Yorkers never tire of tales about Brooklyn, but for 20th-century nostalgia, the Bronx ranks a close second. Reinforcing that point, Arlene Alda has collected more than 60 evocative oral histories in “Just Kids From the Bronx: Telling It the Way It Was” (Henry Holt and Co.).

headline: Assailant Shot at New Orleans Airport Is Dead
text: NEW ORLEANS — The machete-wielding man who attacked officers at a security checkpoint at the New Orleans airport on Friday night and was shot by a sheriff’s deputy died on Saturday, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Documentaries Are the Go-To Players of Sports Television
