text: You have probably seen many of the films. There was “The Fab Five,” about the rise and fall of a fabled Michigan basketball recruiting class, and “The U,” which told the story of Miami football so well that its director made a sequel. More recently, “Of Miracles and Men” described the 1980 Olympic hockey tournament from the less familiar Soviet team’s point of view, and Duke-loathing basketball fans were treated to the analytic probing of “I Hate Christian Laettner.”

headline: Giants Sign Defensive End George Selvie
text: The Giants continued their understated accumulation of free agents Friday by signing the former Dallas Cowboys defensive end George Selvie to a one-year, $1.4 million contract. Selvie is the seventh free agent the team has acquired in the last 10 days, a list that includes signed the former Jets defensive tackle Kenrick Ellis.

headline: Unstated Factor in Iran Talks: Threat of Nuclear Tampering
text: WASHINGTON — In late 2012, just as President Obama and his aides began secretly sketching out a diplomatic opening to Iran, American intelligence agencies were busy with a parallel initiative: The latest spy-vs.-spy move in the decade-long effort to sabotage Tehran’s nuclear infrastructure.

headline: Deadly Fire in Brooklyn Renews Concerns Over a Weekly Ritual
text: In the hours after a malfunctioning hot plate started a fast-moving blaze that killed seven brothers and sisters in an Orthodox Jewish neighborhood of Brooklyn on Saturday, a Fire Department official went door to door at nearby homes handing out pamphlets titled “Fire Safety for Jewish Observances.”

headline: Upsides
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Hey, what’s UP? Everyone having a good spring so far? Here, in the Northeast, we are celebrating the arrival of spring not by dancing around a maypole or planning a picnic, but by shoveling snow. As my parents used to say, life is not always fair, but it is almost always interesting. The UPSIDE to a frosty spring weekend is that we can hole UP with a spicy hot chocolate and the Sunday puzzle.

headline: Arrests Made in Attack on Tunisian Museum
text: TUNIS — The Tunisian authorities have arrested more than 20 people in the investigation into Wednesday’s attack at the National Bardo Museum in Tunis, including 10 the authorities say were directly tied to the deadly assault, a spokesman for the Ministry of the Interior said Saturday.

headline: Kentucky Doesn’t Crack, Even as Cincinnati’s Defense Raises the Pressure
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Kentucky center Willie Cauley-Stein sat on a bench in the Wildcats’ locker room wearing a T-shirt featuring the menacing face of the Incredible Hulk and talked about Cincinnati’s menacing play.

headline: Yankees Cross a State to Play Against a Crosstown Rival
text: TAMPA, Fla. — C. C. Sabathia chuckled at the almost apologetic question: Would it mean anything to him to be starting Sunday against the Mets and their ace Matt Harvey when the Yankees travel across the state to play their crosstown rivals?

headline: Gonzaga Becomes a Melting Pot for Recruits From Across the Globe
text: SEATTLE — During Gonzaga’s 86-76 victory against North Dakota State on Friday night, forward Domantas Sabonis was fouled hard under the basket. He lay on his stomach for a moment until guard Byron Wesley ran over and stuck his hands beneath him as if lifting a piece of furniture.

headline: Study Suggests That Hitters’ Production Dips After They Return From Concussions
text: Concussions are not as common in Major League Baseball as they are in professional football, but they happen often enough, with players getting hit by pitches, running into walls or catching a knee in the head sliding into a base. Catchers are particularly at risk — a foul tip off the mask will snap the neck back and give the brain a solid rattle. Collisions at the plate take a toll, too.

headline: For a St. Francis Player, UConn, Long an Inspiration, Turns Rival
text: STORRS, Conn. — When Sarah Benedetti moved to Canton, Conn., as a fifth grader in 2004, she almost immediately started rooting for the University of Connecticut’s basketball teams. That year, UConn became the first Division I university to win the national titles in men’s and women’s basketball.

headline: Oklahoma’s Spotty Road Record Doesn’t Worry Buddy Hield
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — The Oklahoma star guard Buddy Hield sat in his team’s locker room on Saturday afternoon picking at a bag of Cheetos. His snack was interrupted by a gaggle of reporters who entered the team’s lair with questions about an upcoming game against Dayton, which will play in what is essentially its third home game in five days in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Chicago Mayor’s Race Is Cast as a Test of Liberalism
text: CHICAGO — Mayor Rahm Emanuel had just finished the quintessential municipal politics photo op, briefly inspecting a dusty street-paving project on a block of the South Side lined with tidy brick bungalows.

headline: An Illegal Boxing Club in the Bronx
text: Though unsanctioned, BX Fight Club aims to foster respect and redirect aggression among young men in the rougher sections of the Bronx.

headline: Duke and San Diego State Share a Long History
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The last time Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski and San Diego State’s Steve Fisher faced each other in an N.C.A.A. tournament game, it was the 1992 national championship game in Minneapolis, and Fisher was coaching the Fab Five of Michigan. Of course, Krzyzewski and Duke won that game for their second consecutive title.

headline: Andalusia Election a Measure of Spain’s Disillusionment
text: SEVILLE, Spain — Spain’s Socialists have run Andalusia, the country’s largest region, for 33 years, a bastion built on the party’s role in transforming the farming region by ushering Spain into the European Union in the 1980s.

headline: A San Diego State Forward Is Monitored by His Coach and an Implant
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — When San Diego State forward Dwayne Polee II collapsed in the middle of a game against U.C.-Riverside on Dec. 22, it could have meant the end of his basketball career. But an irregular heartbeat that requires a monitor implanted in his chest hasn’t stopped Polee or his team.

headline: Gone Spearfishin’
text: The sturgeon spearfishing season at Lake Winnebago, the largest lake in Wisconsin, attracts ice fishermen to the lake and relatives and neighbors to the check-ins.

headline: The Groups That May Decide the Chicago Mayoral Election
text: Who Rahm Emanuel needs to win over to keep his seat in the April 7 runoff.

headline: Arizona Goes Long to Defeat Ohio State
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — In a game featuring soon-to-be N.B.A. players and beefy big men, it was Arizona’s long-bombing guards who led the Wildcats to the round of 16 with a 73-58 victory over Ohio State.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Team Plots Vast Effort to Win Florida
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — The political apparatus surrounding former Gov. Jeb Bush, determined to avoid embarrassment in a state that has vexed his party and family in national elections, is plotting a vast operation aimed at turning Florida into a bulwark for his presidential campaign, according to dozens of interviews.

headline: Obama Says He Told Netanyahu That Talk Before Election Hurt the Peace Process
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama said he has told Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that the Israeli leader’s remarks in the closing days of his re-election campaign had upended the Israeli-Palestinian peace process and ran counter to the very nature of Israeli democracy, an unusually forceful and public condemnation of the top official of a vital United States ally.

headline: Double Eagle Bolsters Daniel Berger, a Rookie, at Bay Hill
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — After a 300-yard drive on Bay Hill’s par-5 sixth hole on Saturday, Daniel Berger had a downhill lie and a difficult decision. The 540-yard hole wraps around a lake like a backward “C,” and if Berger wanted to try for the green, his second shot would be flirting with the water.

headline: As Three Alfords Lead U.C.L.A., a Fourth Anchors the Family
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — At one point during U.C.L.A.’s victory on Saturday, the blonde behind the Bruins’ bench stood just feet behind Coach Steve Alford, and was almost his mirror image.

headline: Rematch in the Desert for Roger Federer and Novak Djokovic
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — One dominating with returns, the other with serves, Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer marched on toward another meeting in the desert.

headline: Before Judges, the Godfathers Become Sick Old Grandfathers
text: Not long ago, Thomas DiFiore cut an intimidating figure. For a time, he was the highest-ranking member of the Bonanno organized crime family not behind bars, despite a long record of arrests on charges of kidnapping, assault, promoting gambling and extortion. Even at 70, Mr. DiFiore did not seem to falter when challenging another aging Bonanno leader in 2013 for more than his share of a loan payment, according to prosecutors’ account of a government wiretap.

headline: Xavier, No Stranger to Upsets, Prevents One by Georgia State
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — The Xavier Musketeers were once N.C.A.A. tournament darlings, a plucky program and bottom-bracket seed looking to make a name. They understood the ride 14th-seeded Georgia State wanted to continue Saturday night and knew an upset lurked here at Jacksonville Veterans Memorial Arena.

headline: Kansas and Wichita State’s Unfulfilled Rivalry Receives a Little Help
text: OMAHA — They had one conversation about it. One. And it was not even formal.

headline: North Carolina State Adds to Its Lore by Shocking Top-Seeded Villanova
text: PITTSBURGH — Around North Carolina State’s program, its 1983 national title comes up from time to time. Coach Mark Gottfried makes sure it does. One of his top assistants, Dereck Whittenburg, played on that team, and he, too, reminds the current players of the Wolfpack’s brush with glory.

headline: Wisconsin Forward Plays Word Games
text: OMAHA — Wisconsin forward Nigel Hayes calls himself a lover of words, especially long, unusual ones. Saturday, at Wisconsin’s off-day news conference before the Badgers’ round of 32 game with Oregon, Hayes playfully tested the spelling skills of the stenographer transcribing his words for the news media.

headline: Mets Demote Steven Matz, a Top Prospect, After a Solid Outing
text: LAKELAND, Fla. — Everything about Steven Matz’s spring had an air of expectation.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 21, 2015
text: March 21, 2015

headline: With Jaroslav Halak Back in Goal, Islanders Top Devils to End Four-Game Skid
text: NEWARK — Struggling to score goals and fighting a four-game losing streak, the Islanders made their way to New Jersey hoping to rediscover their offense.

headline: Small Player Helps Utah Beat Georgetown by Thin Margin
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — A tight game between Utah and Georgetown, two teams rich in height and bulk, was decided in large part by the smallest player on the court.

headline: A Teenager Is Killed Near the Scene of a Brawl Caught on Video in Brooklyn
text: A teenager was killed and a baby girl was injured on Saturday in separate shootings in Flatbush, Brooklyn, the police said, one of which happened across the street from a McDonald’s that was the scene of a violent brawl widely seen on social media this month.

headline: North Carolina Stays Focused in Victory Over Arkansas
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — North Carolina’s focus has wandered in so many different directions that it was hard to figure out which team would show up Saturday night against Arkansas.

headline: Erin Mulhall, Eric DeBear
text: Erin Cathleen Mulhall and Eric Julien DeBear were married Saturday at the Memorial Chapel on the College Park campus of the University of Maryland. The Rev. Alexei A. Michalenko, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, with Rabbi Harold White taking part.

headline: Lindsay Kaplan,  Peter Kane
text: Lindsay Rachel Kaplan, the daughter of Gail Nussbaum Kaplan and James M. Kaplan of Englewood, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Peter Bijur Kane, a son of Priscilla B. Kane and Gerald Kane of Manhattan. Rabbi Angela Warnick Buchdahl, a senior rabbi at Central Synagogue, officiated at the Liberty Warehouse in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

headline: Staying Calm Among the Coyotes
text: Lisa Perri Sommer and Dr. Joshua David Balog were married Saturday evening at the Pleasantdale Chateau, an events space in West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Karen Perolman officiated.

headline: A Pairing With Punch
text: Minna Minhwa Kao and Paul Gerard Heck were married Saturday at the Queen of All Saints Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. Joseph A. Ceriello, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Alexandra Daum and Alexander Kleiner
text: Alexandra Devon Daum, a daughter of Julie H. Daum and Robert C. Daum of North Palm Beach, Fla., was married Saturday evening to Alexander Mark Kleiner, the son of Diana E. E. Kleiner and Fred S. Kleiner of Woodbridge, Conn. Jessica Krulis, a friend of the couple who became a minister of the American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated at Terra Gallery, an events space in San Francisco.

headline: Hannah DeLetto, Bryan Mochizuki
text: Hannah Naomi DeLetto, a daughter of Laura A. DeLetto and Vincent DeLetto of Massapequa, N.Y., was married Saturday to Bryan Paul Mochizuki, the son of Debbie C. Mochizuki and William J. Mochizuki of Clovis, Calif. Pastor John W. Quince, who was ordained through the Farmingdale Christian Church, performed the ceremony at Roslyn Presbyterian Church in Roslyn, N.Y.

headline: Valerie Brown and Garry Grant
text: Valerie Sharice Brown and Garry Fitzgerald Grant were married Saturday at the First African Baptist Church in Savannah, Ga. The Rev. Calvin O. Butts III, the Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Paige Elliott, Timothy McAdam
text: Paige Christian Elliott, a daughter of Patti Elliott and James R. Elliott III of Dallas, was married Saturday to Timothy Francis McAdam, a son of Maureen K. McAdam of Glen Cove, N.Y., and the late Dennis F. McAdam. The Rev. Paul Leggett, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Location 05, a photography studio and events space in Manhattan.

headline: Arielle Katz,  Brad Birenberg
text: Arielle Katz and Dr. Brad David Birenberg are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Martin S. Cohen at Oheka Castle in Huntington, N.Y.

Marinos of Old Bridge, N.J., was married Saturday to Alan Benjamin Freedman, a son of Nancy Redfern Freedman of Collingswood, N.J., and Dennis I. Freedman of Langhorne, Pa. Anthony N. headline: Bari Cohn, Jonathan Maniff

text: Dr. Meryl Suzanne Rosofsky and Stuart Hayden Coleman are to be married Sunday at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun in New York. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is to lead the ceremony.

headline: Notre Dame Tops Nearby Butler in Close Finish
text: PITTSBURGH — The best team in Indiana is Notre Dame. The third-seeded Fighting Irish proved as much Saturday night, escaping a tussle with sixth-seeded Butler to prevail, 67-64, in overtime, at Consol Energy Center to advance to the Midwest Regional semifinals in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Ted Cruz Hopes Early Campaign Entry Will Focus Voters’ Attention
text: The venue has little personal significance for him, but the timing of Senator Ted Cruz’s formal entry into the 2016 presidential field on Monday is full of meaning, as he seeks to catapult to the forefront of an increasingly competitive cluster of conservatives vying for the Republican nomination.

headline: Corrections: March 22, 2015
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
text: 12:30 P.M. (13) IL BARBIERE DI SIVIGLIA Lawrence Brownlee sings the role of the love-struck Count Almaviva; Isabel Leonard is Rosina, the feisty doctor’s ward who has captured his heart; and Christopher Maltman, making a spectacular entrance atop a traveling barber shop pulled by admirers, is Figaro in this Metropolitan Opera revival of Rossini’s comic classic. The production, staged by Bartlett Sher, conducted by Michele Mariotti and presented here by “Great Performances at the Met,” “delivers a heady fizz,” Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim wrote in The New York Times. “And it has stars,” she added — among them, Mr. Brownlee, who made “a dashing Almaviva, singing with a focused, ardent tenor”; Ms. Leonard, “a pitch-perfect Rosina, cute but sharp-clawed”; and Mr. Maltman (above right, with Mr. Brownlee and Ms. Leonard), who “oozed sex appeal during his opening aria, ‘Largo al factotum,’ wearing a magnificent red Phrygian cap like a royal insignia.”

headline: Melody Hwang and Craig Muhlrad
text: Melody Hwang, a daughter of May Hwang and Andrew B. Hwang of South Pasadena, Calif., was married Saturday to Craig Scott Muhlrad, the son of Patricia Samuels Muhlrad and Dr. Jeffrey S. Muhlrad of Old Field, N.Y. Rabbi Arthur Rosenberg officiated at Calamigos Equestrian Terrace, an event space at the Los Angeles Equestrian Center in Burbank, Calif.

headline: Brianna Serrano,  Jason Pierce
text: Brianna Kay Serrano and Jason Matthew Pierce were married Friday at Twin Oaks Garden Estate in San Marcos, Calif. Bethel Nathan, a pastor in the Church of Spiritual Humanism, officiated.

headline: Lauren Mancuso,  Alexander Jurecky
text: Lauren Aleesia Mancuso, the daughter of Victoria G. Mancuso and John J. Mancuso of Ossining, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Alexander Joseph Jurecky, the son of Blanka P. Jurecky and George T. Jurecky of Englewood, N.J. The Rev. Deborah S. Roth, an interfaith minister affiliated with the Sanctuary of the Beloved, officiated at the Harold Pratt House in New York.

headline: Still Hoping for Future Kodak Moments
text: There were almost 200 buildings that once housed Kodak’s daily production in Rochester. Over the last two decades, 80 of those buildings have been demolished and 59 others have been sold off — 61 buildings remain, awaiting an uncertain fate.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Catch up on the week’s top stories.

headline: Rebels Seize Key Parts of Yemen’s Third-Largest City, Taiz
text: Al MUKALLA, Yemen — Houthi rebel fighters have taken control of crucial installations in Taiz, Yemen’s third-largest city, including the international airport, security officials said on Sunday, in a provocative expansion of the seven-month rebel offensive that has moved the country closer to war.

headline: My Daughter Is Now Sister Mary Joseph, and No Longer Mine
text: My daughter is preparing to make final vows as a Catholic sister, and though I’m a devout Catholic, I am still grieving that reality. It’s one of the hardest things I’ve had to deal with in my three decades of motherhood. In many ways, I’ve come to realize, she is no longer mine.

headline: Indian Opposition Delays Modi’s Land-Acquisition Effort
text: NEW DELHI — When the government of Prime Minister Narendra Modi muscled through an executive order in December simplifying the government and private companies’ ability to obtain land for what it deems important development projects, it sent a message to voters — and Mr. Modi’s political adversaries — about his decisive style of leadership and his commitment to industry.

headline: 1940: Passenger Who Didn’t Pay Fares Because of Tobacco Is Sued
text: TRENTON, N.J. — Mrs. Amy P. Shirk, sixty-two years old, is being sued for $18.72 by the Reading Railroad, it was learned today, [Mar. 22] because her ‘‘allergy to tobacco smoke’’ led her to refuse to pay for 117 rides, at 16 cents each, on the Reading’s one-car local between Pennington and West Trenton. In the suit, filed yesterday in Trenton District Court, the railroad said that Mrs. Shirk made the trips between April and September, 1939, but refused to pay because the conductor would not heed her request that other passengers be restrained from smoking.

headline: For Obama, Ghani Offers Hope of a Less Fractious Relationship
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama meets this week with Ashraf Ghani, Afghanistan’s new president, he will finally be sitting across from an Afghan leader who is not brooding, agitated, suspicious or openly belligerent toward his American allies.

headline: Thousands Join Brooklyn Father Mourning 7 With ‘Faces of Angels’
text: The mourners pushed toward the funeral chapel, row after row of black hats and black coats bowed toward the Brooklyn asphalt.

headline: Health Care Systems Try to Cut Costs by Aiding the Poor and Troubled
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Jerome Pate, a homeless alcoholic, went to the emergency room when he was cold. He went when he needed a safe place to sleep. He went when he was hungry, or drunk, or suicidal.

headline: After an Uneasy Start, Finding Common Ground to Discuss Race Relations at Work
text: Carl Jones brought it up over lunch in the company break room: the news of the shooting death of an unarmed black man by a white police officer. “Did you read about it?” Mr. Jones, a software engineer who is black, remembers asking his colleagues. “How could this happen?”

text: Tris tripped on a glass slipper.

headline: Cuomo Is Called Controlling but a ‘Contender’ in an Unauthorized Biography
text: ALBANY — In the first few pages of “The Contender,” Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is portrayed as a “brilliant tactician” and a presidential hopeful, even if not in 2016. But the tone of the unauthorized biography quickly changes, positioning Mr. Cuomo as a control-obsessed politician who showed no tolerance for criticism or retail politics.

headline: Photographing Our Most Precious Resource
text: Associated Press photographers ahead of World Water Day on Sunday.

headline: 1965: Saigon Forces Use Tear Gas on Enemy
text: WASHINGTON — U.S.-equipped South Vietnamese troops are using nonlethal nauseating tear gas occasionally against South Vietnam’s Communist guerrillas, the United States said today [Mar. 22]. Although the State Department insisted that employment of the short-lived gas was not inhumane or internationally illegal, the use of the gas — with all its flesh crawling connotations of horror — may spark worldwide protests and give the United States a monumental propaganda black eye. The Soviet Union seized upon the gas issue immediately for a blast at the United States, with Moscow Radio charging the United States with ‘‘using increasingly barbarous methods — in particular waging chemical warfare.’’ It was unclear precisely what kind of gas was being used, but it apparently is the type, effective for about two hours, which causes tears, nausea, sneezing, coughing, nose, throat and chest discomfort or pains. The gas being used is not of the killing, stunning or nerve-affecting types. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 23, 1965

headline: Yiddish Production of ‘Death of a Salesman’ Coming to Off-Broadway
text: New Yiddish Rep will bring an updated Yiddish production of Arthur Miller’s “Death of a Salesman” to New York this October. The production play at the Castillo Theater for seven weeks and aims to uncover the play’s cultural foundations.

headline: In One-Woman Show, Arafat Protégée Offers Personal Take on Conflict
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In a measured voice, the middle-aged woman in the blue dress recalled how a colleague had come to her hotel room during a work trip years before and tried to rape her, retreating only after she had screamed to alert the neighbors.

headline: Sony Will Make ‘Beautiful: The Carole King Musical’ Into a Film
text: Sony Pictures Entertainment on Sunday said that it had closed a deal to bring “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical” to the big screen.

headline: Egyptian Official Says Protester, Shaimaa el-Sabbagh, Died in Shooting Because She Was Too Thin
text: CAIRO — A poet and activist hit with a blast of birdshot from a police shotgun during a march to lay flowers in Tahrir Square in Cairo died because she was too thin, a spokesman for Egypt’s medical examiner said late Saturday.

headline: A Bid to Save Sweet Briar College
text: The liberal arts institution in rural Virginia, one of a dwindling number of women’s schools, will close at the end of this term.

headline: Anger and Activism Greet Plan to Shut Sweet Briar College
text: SWEET BRIAR, Va. — Here at bucolic Sweet Briar College, equestrians awaken at dawn and trek to the stables to ride on 18 miles of trails through wooded countryside, fields and dells. Women study on the boathouse dock at sunset, as geese squawk over a lake. Pearls are still in fashion, and men must have escorts. Students call it “the pink bubble.”

headline: In Performance | Leung and Lim
text: Telly Leung and Jennifer Lim in a scene from Frances Ya-Chu Cowhig’s play “The World of Extreme Happiness,” at the City Center Stage I through March 29.

headline: Michigan State Again Sends Virginia Home Early
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Travis Trice, a senior guard at Michigan State, received a text message Sunday morning from a former Spartans teammate, Draymond Green of the Golden State Warriors: “Don’t let this be your last game.”

headline: Review: ‘Ernani,’ With Plácido Domingo, a Tussle to Hold on to a Love
text: In a 2009 interview, Plácido Domingo said that he could not imagine retiring from opera with a series of farewell performances and public celebrations. The time to stop will just come to him when it’s right, he explained.

headline: Seoul Philharmonic Orchestra Racked by Infighting
text: SEOUL, South Korea — When the respected Seoul Philharmonic Orchestra announced this month that it was canceling its United States tour set for April, it cited fiscal woes. Left unsaid were the lurid allegations of sexual harassment and financial improprieties that have rocked the orchestra recently, culminating in a police raid of its offices here.

headline: Review: In ‘Where You Go Is Not Who You’ll Be,’ Frank Bruni Examines College Admissions Mania
text: Getting into a top college, even for the most accomplished high school students, has become a mad scramble. But in his sensible and sensitive book, “Where You Go Is Not Who You’ll Be,” Frank Bruni, a columnist for The New York Times, wants to help young people understand the urgent truth of his title. “Where we go to college will have infinitely less bearing on our fulfillment in life than so much else: the wisdom with which we choose our romantic partners; our interactions with the communities that we inhabit; our generosity toward the families we inherit and the families that we make.” That’s something we all know in retrospect but that’s hard to know in prospect for anyone caught in what Mr. Bruni calls the “college admissions mania.”

headline: Lee Kuan Yew, Founding Father of Singapore, Dies at 91
text: Mr. Lee remained until late in his life the dominant personality and driving force in what he called a first-world oasis in a third-world region.

headline: Lee Kuan Yew, Founding Father and First Premier of Singapore, Dies at 91
text: SINGAPORE — Lee Kuan Yew, who transformed the tiny outpost of Singapore into one of Asia’s wealthiest and least corrupt countries as its founding father and first prime minister, died here on Monday. He was 91.

headline: Apple Opens Up to Praise New Book on Steve Jobs, and Criticize an Old One
text: Steve Jobs prized secrecy from his executives and employees during his tenure at Apple. Now his top lieutenants are speaking out — to help shape the legacy of Steve Jobs.

headline: Review: ‘Sin City Saints,’ a Yahoo Basketball Comedy
text: Yahoo’s attempt to make its video offerings more televisionlike — which is to say more like Netflix, Amazon and Hulu — began last week with the premiere of the sixth season of “Community,” a show that had been canceled by NBC. But a better test comes on Monday, when it will post all eight episodes of “Sin City Saints,” an original half-hour comedy, at Yahoo Screen.

headline: Americans’ Retirement Funds Increasingly Contain Tech Start-Up Stocks
text: The retirement accounts of millions of Americans have long contained shares of stalwart companies like General Electric, Ford and Coca-Cola. Today, they are likely to include riskier private stocks from Silicon Valley start-ups like Uber, Airbnb and Pinterest.

headline: Review: Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance Offers New and Old
text: Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance, a puzzling project on paper, is proving so in performance as well. As this new venture for the Paul Taylor Dance Company, one that expands to include works by other choreographers, continued into its second week at the David H. Koch Theater, the salient contrast remained that of previous years: Taylor versus Taylor.

headline: Review: David Robertson Leads the St. Louis Symphony at Carnegie Hall
text: Two potential New York Philharmonic music directors were in town last week. Esa-Pekka Salonen was with the Philharmonic itself, not conducting but taking a composer’s bow after the orchestra played his “Nyx” (2010) under Alan Gilbert. And David Robertson, a serious contender when Mr. Gilbert was chosen in 2007 and now once again a candidate, brought his St. Louis Symphony, sounding superb, to Carnegie Hall on Friday evening.

Snoop Dogg announced the project at his keynote speech at the South By Southwest Music Conference and Festival on Friday.

headline: At SXSW, Stepping Back to Allow Hopeful Artists to Step Up
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Mitski, a songwriter based in Brooklyn, clutched her hot-pink bass and surveyed the knots of people standing in the rain to hear her on Saturday afternoon. She was playing her fourth (and last) live set in 24 hours as part of the 29th annual South By Southwest Music Conference and Festival, the five-day blowout that brings an estimated 2,000 acts — bands, solo performers, rappers, D.J.s — to Austin each year.

headline: Starbucks Ends Conversation Starters on Race

Schultz, the chief executive of Starbucks, said in a letter to employees on Sunday that baristas would no longer be encouraged to write the phrase “Race Together” on customers’ coffee cups, drawing to a close a widely derided component of the company’s plan to promote a discussion on racial issues.

headline: For Clintons, a Hedge Fund in the Family

He has regularly appeared at charitable events, once introducing the former president at the Clinton Foundation’s celebrity poker tournament by dryly saying, “You may have heard of my father-in-law.” And at the recent N.B.A. All-Star Game, Mr. Mezvinsky took a seat next to Mr. Clinton and his partner in charitable endeavors, Dikembe Mutombo, the former basketball star.

headline: A Right to Die?
text: Jack Kevorkian’s unorthodox methods drew attention to assisted suicide. Decades later, Americans still struggle with whether doctors should be allowed to help suffering patients end their lives.

headline: Stigma Around Physician-Assisted Dying Lingers
text: “Death is nothing at all,” the English theologian Henry Scott Holland wrote a century ago in a reflection that is often quoted at funerals. Death is but life extended, Holland said: “I have only slipped away to the next room. Nothing has happened. Everything remains exactly as it was.”

headline: For the Defense-First St. Louis Blues, the Score Gets a Rewrite

headline: At the Box Office, It’s No Longer a Man’s World

headline: Two Maxims at Odds: Tell a Story, Tell the Truth
text: The last interview was over. The set, a room inside a New York hotel, had gone dark. The subject, Robert A. Durst, headed for the bathroom, apparently unaware his microphone was still on. “There it is. You’re caught,” he is heard saying. “What the hell did I do? Killed them all, of course.”

headline: Shy of Majority, Socialists Win in Spain’s Andalusia

headline: From First Inning, Yankees and Jose Pirela Are Rattled by the Mets
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — At the crack of the bat, Yankees center fielder Jose Pirela raced toward the center-field wall in pursuit of the ball. When left fielder Ramon Flores saw Pirela, a converted second baseman, still sprinting as he approached the warning track, he called out to him.

headline: After Bruising Winter Took Its Toll on Roads, Asphalt Is a Hot Commodity
text: MELVILLE, N.Y. — It is gummy. It is gooey. It has an aroma that is nothing like Chanel No. 5 — frankly, it stinks. But it is the hottest substance in local government right now.

headline: Netanyahu Aides Cite Iran as Source of U.S. Tensions

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of March 23
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Marlins Cement Their Core, and Their Plans for a Revival

headline: Howard H. Guttenplan, Who Nurtured Art Films in New York, Dies at 80
text: Howard H. Guttenplan, who took what began as an antipoverty program on the Lower East Side of Manhattan and transformed it into a leading workshop and showcase for experimental filmmakers, including Andy Warhol, died on Feb. 23 at his home in Manhattan. He was 80.

headline: Right-Wing Groups Find a Haven, for a Day, in Russia
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — A motley crew of representatives of fringe right-wing political organizations in Europe and the United States used a conference here on Sunday to denounce what they called the degradation of white, Christian traditions in the West. Their hosts used the conference to advance Russia’s effort to lure political allies of any stripe.

headline: Luis Suárez’s Validating Strike Lifts Barcelona Past Madrid
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Last October, Luis Suárez made his debut for F.C. Barcelona in a disappointing 3-1 loss to Real Madrid. He was substituted during that game after a long ban that had prompted questions over whether he could return to form and justify the record transfer fee that brought him here.

headline: Where Districts Are Rating Their Teachers Much Higher Than the State Is
text: Districts in the suburbs of New York City have a higher opinion of their teachers than state tests would appear to justify.

headline: Steve Nash Stands on His Own as an Ideal of Team Play

headline: Cuomo Fights Rating System in Which Few Teachers Are Bad
text: SOUTHOLD, N.Y. — The teachers and administrators in this rural Long Island district do not mince words when asked about Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s proposal to tie teacher evaluations more closely to test scores.

headline: Police Seek Third Gunman in Deadly Attack at Tunisian National Museum
text: TUNIS — Tunisian security forces are looking for a third man suspected in Wednesday’s attack at the National Bardo Museum, in which 20 foreign tourists, a Tunisian police officer and two gunmen were killed.

text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Novak Djokovic charitably kept Roger Federer in contention longer than he would have liked Sunday before again prevailing in the final of the BNP Paribas Open, 6-3, 6-7 (5), 6-2.

headline: Air of Invincibility Haunts Kentucky

headline: A Test of Free Speech and Bias, Served on a Plate From Texas
text: WASHINGTON — The next great First Amendment battleground is just six inches high. It is a license plate bearing the Confederate flag.

headline: Oklahoma Outmatches Feisty Dayton
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — It took Oklahoma 35 minutes to realize it was bigger and taller than Dayton. Once it finally did, the No. 3-seeded Sooners fended off the 11th-seeded Flyers, 72-66, on Sunday night at Nationwide Arena to advance to the round of 16 in the N.C.A.A. tournament. They will play Michigan State, the No. 7 seed, on Friday in Syracuse.

headline: In Greece, Syriza Struggles to Deliver Promises as Money Runs Out
text: ATHENS — Glowering with disdain, Evangelos Venizelos stepped into the well of the Greek Parliament and ridiculed members of the country’s new leftist government. They had vowed to roll back unpopular austerity measures that Mr. Venizelos and the prior government had pushed through. They had promised that Greece would stop kneeling to European creditors.

headline: No Corrections: March 23, 2015
text: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

headline: Even Losers at Arnold Palmer Invitational See Good Signs for Masters
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — The golf treadmill was turned up another notch at the Arnold Palmer Invitational, and Henrik Stenson was struggling to keep pace. Still, he managed to create enough momentum to carry him to a runner-up finish, and a third consecutive top-five showing, two days later.

headline: Concerns Over Geography Leave a Mark on Dayton’s Postseason Run
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Archie Miller’s quest to transform the Dayton Flyers into a college basketball power started in a dim and dilapidated gymnasium just southwest of the university’s main campus on the banks of the Great Miami River.

headline: Authentic Characters Seeking Sex and Romance, and a Future on HBO
text: As the college basketball scores poured in over the weekend, another contest — more sparsely but no less passionately followed — took place on HBO on Sunday night. It was Team Kevin versus Team Richie. Who would emerge happier from the season finale of “Looking”: fans of Kevin, the new, perhaps too perfect boyfriend of the show’s mercurial hero, Patrick, or fans of Richie, Patrick’s moody, soulful ex?

headline: Review: ‘I’m Looking for Helen Twelvetrees’ Explores the Life of an Early Talkies Movie Star
text: A disorderly life is viewed through an aptly fragmenting (if frustrating) lens in “I’m Looking for Helen Twelvetrees,” a new play written by and starring David Greenspan that opened on Sunday at Abrons Arts Center. Mr. Greenspan’s elliptical drama for three actors explores the life of the title character, a movie star of early talkies played by Brooke Bloom, as her career briefly peaks then heads south, and a tempestuous early marriage withers.

headline: Out of Yemen, U.S. Is Hobbled in Terror Fight

headline: Sabbath Routine a Risky Practice, Officials Warn
text: It is a practice common among Orthodox Jews observing the Sabbath: A hot plate or a stove burner is left on overnight so that food can be kept warm without violating a stricture against working.

headline: West Virginia Overpowers Maryland

headline: With Expansion of Medicaid, Some States Are Identifying More New Diabetes Cases
text: The number of new diabetes cases identified among poor Americans has surged in states that have embraced the Affordable Care Act, but not in those that have not, a new study has found, suggesting that the health care law may be helping thousands of people get earlier treatment for one of this country’s costliest medical conditions.

headline: Louisville’s Stingy Defense Shuts Down Northern Iowa’s Slow but Steady Offense

headline: Teary Mourners in Singapore Remember Lee Kuan Yew
text: SINGAPORE — The mourners who filed past the gates of the government building where the body of Lee Kuan Yew, who died on Monday, was being kept spoke about him with a zeal and adoration usually reserved for candidates for sainthood.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
text: 10:15 P.M. (IFC) THE BIG LEBOWSKI (1998) Jeffrey Lebowski, known as the Dude (Jeff Bridges, above, from left, with John Goodman and Steve Buscemi), is an unemployed bowling enthusiast who smokes a lot of weed. His tranquil daze is interrupted when he comes home to two goons demanding the money he owes them and urinating on his beloved rug. The goons turn out to have the Dude confused with the millionaire Jeffrey Lebowski (David Huddleston), who sends the Dude on a wild-goose chase. Ethan and Joel Coen wrote and directed this convoluted classic, which features bowling chatter, German nihilists, self-kidnapping and Creedence Clearwater Revival. Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times: “The film, which begins with a tumbleweed rolling from desert to Malibu, is narrated a bit needlessly by a mythic cowboy type (Sam Elliott) whose final assessment of the Dude’s tale goes like this: ‘It was a purty good story, don’t you think? Made me laugh to beat the band. Parts, anyway.’ Exactly right.”

headline: Sebastião Salgado’s Journey From Brazil to the World
text: Sebastião Salgado has won every major prize a photographer can receive, with his crisp, compassionate black-and-white images, many of them from war zones and other locations of human suffering, hanging on the walls of museums, galleries and private collections around the world. His books, including “Workers,” “Migrations,” “Sahel” and, most recently, the nature-oriented “Genesis,” have consistently met with commercial and critical success.

Slumlords, Hellholes and a System’s Failures

headline: The Myth of High-Protein Diets
text: MANY people have been making the case that Americans have grown fat because they eat too much starch and sugar, and not enough meat, fat and eggs. Recently, the Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee lifted recommendations that consumption of dietary cholesterol should be restricted, citing research that dietary cholesterol does not have a major effect on blood cholesterol levels. The predictable headlines followed: “Back to Eggs and Bacon?”

headline: In Clinton Emails on Benghazi, a Rare Glimpse at Her Concerns

headline: Why Ted Cruz Is Such a Long Shot
text: In nearly every presidential primary, a few candidates attract a lot of news media attention even though they have almost no chance to win the nomination. Sometimes they even lead national polls or win states, but invariably their appeal is too narrow to allow them to build the broad coalition necessary to unite a diverse party.

headline: At What Age Should Children Be Allowed to Go Places Without Adult Supervision?
text: Parents set rules about everything from their children’s curfew to where they can and cannot go — and with whom — and at what age kids can begin to attend school dances and games, participate in sleepovers and go to movies or concerts unaccompanied by adults.

headline: Botched 2008 Case Against Another Senator Looms Over Menendez Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — In 2008, the Justice Department took the unusual step of indicting a sitting United States senator. Prosecutors described the senator, Ted Stevens, an Alaska Republican, as a crafty politician who concealed the expensive gifts that had been lavished upon him by one of his friends, a millionaire oil contractor. The case ultimately collapsed, becoming an embarrassing cautionary tale about overzealous prosecuting.

text: The future is bright on the streets of New York. For Jolanta Benal and her neighbors in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, it is far too bright.

headline: Poll Finds Little Support for Cuomo’s Policy on Purging State Emails

headline: The Road to Cancer Treatment Through Clinical Trials
text: In 1947, children who developed acute lymphocytic leukemia died. Dr. Sidney Farber, a pathologist at Boston Children’s Hospital, was so distressed doing autopsies on these children that he moved into the clinic and, against the advice of more conservative colleagues, began treating children with aminopterin, a highly toxic drug that starved their cancerous white blood cells of critical nutrients.

Today, they are likely to include riskier private stocks from Silicon Valley start-ups like Uber, Airbnb and Pinterest, David Gelles and Conor Dougherty report.

headline: Protesters in Taiwan Mark Anniversary of Sunflower Movement

headline: Why God Is a Moral Issue
text: The New Atheists are not a comfortable group of people. They have scornful contempt for those with whom they differ — that includes religious believers, agnostics and other atheists who don’t share their vehement brand of nonbelief. They are self-confident to a degree that seems designed to irritate. And they have an ignorance of anything beyond their fields to an extent remarkable even in modern academia. They also have a moral passion unknown outside the pages of the Old Testament. For that, we can forgive much.

headline: Koch-Backed Group Bolsters Effort to Shut Down Export-Import Bank
text: A trade association linked to the conservative billionaires Charles G. and David H. Koch will begin a new lobbying effort pressuring lawmakers to shut down the Export-Import Bank, a top target of conservative activists and outside groups that will cease to exist after June 30 if it is not reauthorized by Congress.

headline: In Lee Kuan Yew, China Saw a Leader to Emulate
text: With the death of Singapore’s founding leader, Lee Kuan Yew, on Monday, China lost a figure who, in the eyes of Communist Party leaders, showed that economic prosperity could be achieved under crisply efficient one-party rule, immunized from the temptations of liberal democracy.

headline: Today in Politics: Making It Official, Cruz Kicks Off Race to Replace Obama
text: Good Monday morning from Washington. Congress will be tending to some budget business before a break, and Hillary Rodham Clinton’s private emails about attacks in Benghazi, Libya are unearthed. President Obama begins the week hosting a science fair at the White House, and the race to succeed him begins in earnest with a big speech from a certain Texas senator.

headline: Companies Adapt to Uber and Lyft Rides on the Expense Report
text: Erin Galey has grown so accustomed to using Uber on business trips that it is hard to imagine using a taxi. “I don’t know the taxis, but I know Uber, and I’m comfortable with it,” she said. “If I call a taxi, I’m not sure what I’m going to get.”

headline: New York Still Has More Gay Residents Than Anywhere Else in U.S.

headline: Islanders Invite Pat LaFontaine to Bid Farewell to Nassau Coliseum
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Pat LaFontaine has always been a popular Islander, though in recent years he has not been seen much at Nassau Coliseum.

headline: 1940: I.R.A. Riots in Dartmoor
text: LONDON — Twelve I.R.A. members imprisoned in Britain’s grim Dartmoor prison were held responsible this evening for an Easter mutiny that raged for more than three hours during the afternoon. The mutiny broke out when convicts in a cell block overpowered two guards, who were bound and gagged, then bundled into a cell. Using their keys, the guards’ attackers freed other convicts. With wild shouts, which were heard outside by many people living near the prison, the Irish Republicans collected piles of bedding and set them on fire. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 24, 1940

headline: Okinawa Governor Orders a Halt to Work on U.S. Military Airfield
text: TOKYO — The governor of Okinawa ordered the suspension of work on a new American military airfield on Monday, escalating a confrontation with the central government. Officials in Tokyo said they would ignore his order and continue preparations for the project.

headline: Deadlines Near as Greece and Germany Seek a Consensus on Debt
text: BERLIN — With time running ever shorter for an accord to ease Greece’s debt crisis and cash crunch, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany met on Monday and sought at least to take the sting out of venomous exchanges between Athens and Berlin in recent weeks.

headline: Tony May Is Selling SD26
text: Tony May, an esteemed veteran in the New York dining scene, is retiring. On March 30, he expects to turn his restaurant, SD26, over to John Doherty, a former executive chef at the Waldorf Astoria who has been a consultant for the last few years.

headline: Jerry Warren, Editor and Press Aide to Nixon and Ford, Dies at 84
text: WASHINGTON — Jerry Warren, a newspaper editor who became the deputy White House press secretary under Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford, but who returned to newspaper work after being disillusioned by the Watergate scandal, died on Friday in Arlington, Va. He was 84.

text: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Daniel Finkel of Math For Love, the Seattle-based team committed to sharing a love of math through  seminars, festivals and camps.

headline: From Sierra Nevada, a Taproom in North Carolina
text: Sierra Nevada Brewing Co. this month opened a much-anticipated taproom and restaurant at its brewery in Mills River, N.C., 15 miles south of Asheville.

headline: Justice Dept., Criticizing Philadelphia Police, Finds Shootings by Officers Are Common
text: WASHINGTON — Roughly once a week, 390 times over the past eight years, Philadelphia police officers opened fire at a suspect. The shootings involved 454 officers, most of them on patrol. Almost always, the suspects were black. Often, the officers were, too.

headline: Maira Kalman’s Most Treasured Cooking Tool
text: Maira Kalman’s most treasured cooking tool — a Sawa 2000 Deluxe Cookie Press, made about a half-century ago in Sweden — isn’t kept in the kitchen. It’s in a lingerie closet.

headline: With New Nonstick Coating, the Wait, and Waste, Is Over
text: CAMBRIDGE, MASS. — If a glue did not stick to the inside of the tube or bottle, you might think it must not be a very good glue.

headline: Police Find No Evidence of Rape at University of Virginia Fraternity
text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — The police here said Monday that they had found “no substantive basis” to support a Rolling Stone magazine article depicting a horrific gang rape at a University of Virginia fraternity house and that a four-month review had identified serious discrepancies in the account by a woman identified as Jackie, who refused to cooperate with their investigation.

headline: Sashimani Devi, Last of India’s Jagannath Temple Dancers, Dies at 92
text: NEW DELHI — Sashimani Devi, the last ritual dancer at the Jagannath Temple in eastern India, died on March 19 in the city of Puri, bringing an end to a centuries-old tradition that was condemned as exploitative by social reformers, Victorian missionaries and the leaders of independent India. She was 92.

headline: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s Likely Next Steps
text: What can Israelis, their Palestinian neighbors and the watching world expect next from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu? Jodi Rudoren, the Jerusalem bureau chief of The New York Times, answered readers’ questions about the peace process, U.S.-Israeli relations and other issues.

headline: A Frog That Can Change Skin Texture
text: A new species of frog discovered in Ecuador is the first vertebrate known to change its skin texture from smooth to spiny, researchers say.

text: Ahead of Senator Ted Cruz’s announcement that he would be running for president of the United States, the name of another country kept coming up: Canada.

headline: S.E.C. Faces Tough Challenge to Enhanced Broker Rule
text: In a Smith Barney commercial from the 1970s, the actor John Houseman intoned that the firm made money the old-fashioned way: “They earn it.” The question for clients is what standard their brokers should be judged by when making money off them, an issue that has proved to be divisive as the Securities and Exchange Commission considers imposing a higher standard for recommendations.

headline: Wisconsin Decides Not to Enforce Voter ID Law
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday turned away a challenge to a Wisconsin law that requires prospective voters to provide photo identification before casting their ballots.
