headline: Seeking the Facts on Medical Marijuana
text: Twenty-three states and the District of Columbia have legalized medical marijuana, but scientific research into its appropriate uses has lagged. Dr. Mark Ware would like to change that.

headline: How Ancient Cattle Herders Avoided Sleeping Sickness
text: It has long been a mystery how long ago cattle-raising people from Central Africa managed to reach southern Africa. It was assumed that the herders were stopped by sleeping sickness, which is carried by tsetse flies and kills cattle, goats, sheep and people.

headline: Go Ahead, Help Your Child Apply to College
text: Over the past month or two, my nightly routine has been the same: I climb into bed after 10 p.m. with the “Fiske Guide to Colleges,” pen and Post-it notes at the ready.

headline: Clever Pricing for Italian Tire Maker Pirelli
text: Pirelli’s would-be new owners have pitched their price cleverly. Marco Tronchetti Provera, the Italian tire maker’s chairman and a leading shareholder, has teamed up with the state-owned China National Chemical Corporation to buy and then delist the company’s shares. The deal highlights how Italian companies are up for sale to foreign owners, even at ungenerous prices.

headline: U.S. Private Equity Firms Find a Chilly Reception in Australia
text: SYDNEY, Australia — When the financing arm of General Electric agreed last week to sell its consumer lending business in Australia and New Zealand to a consortium of investors that included the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the firm’s managing partner for Asia trumpeted the news.

headline: How David Geffen’s $100 Million Lincoln Center Gift Came Together
text: Barbara Walters never expected a role in the renaming of Avery Fisher Hall. But it turns out that Ms. Walters, the ABC News broadcaster, was a crucial go-between who helped engineer a relationship between two of her friends that led to the unlikely, seemingly overnight emergence of the West Coast mogul David Geffen as one of New York’s most prominent philanthropists.

headline: Macaroons for Passover With a Difference
text: Traditional almond macaroons for Passover were never my thing: too sweet and not chewy enough. Then I met Eileen Dangoor Khalastchy, a Jew who traces her roots to ancient Babylonia, and tried her macaroon recipe from Iraq.

headline: Review: National Council Auditions Winners Named at Grand Finals Concert
text: “Grand Opera’s answer to ‘American Idol,’ ” said Peter Gelb, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, describing the organization’s annual National Council Auditions while the judges deliberated on Sunday afternoon. The important vocal event has helped propel the careers of many young singers, including the soprano Angela Meade, who presented the Grand Finals Concert at the Met.

headline: 1890: ‘Ascanio’ Composer a Mystery
text: Where is M. Saint-Saëns? For a couple of months past the question has been reiterated almost daily. Now that the production of ‘‘Ascanio’’ at the Opéra has brought its composer’s name before the public, the question has developed into as popular a problem as was that of the whereabouts of the huissier Gouffé last summer. Versions of the most varied and wildest nature are current. According to one account, M. Saint-Saëns is the inmate of a lunatic asylum; while another has it that he has died in a foreign land, and been buried in an unknown grave by alien hands. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 24, 1890

headline: Have a Seat Next to Don Draper: Jon Hamm Unveils a ‘Mad Men’ Bench
text: One of the defining images of “Mad Men,” which begins its final run of episodes on April 5, is from its opening credits sequence — a silhouette of lead character Don Draper (Jon Hamm) reclining in a seat, cigarette in hand. On Monday, that image was brought to life.

headline: First Draft Focus: Scouting Future Scientists
text: President Obama with a group of Girl Scouts from Oklahoma, part of the 2015 White House Science Fair.

headline: Ted Cruz as Conservative Torchbearer
text: Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, announced Monday he would run for president, making him the first major candidate to do so.

headline: N.F.L. to Hire B. Todd Jones, A.T.F. Director, as Disciplinary Officer
text: PHOENIX — Roger Goodell, the commissioner of the N.F.L., told the league’s 32 owners on Monday that he would soon appoint the departing director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives as the new chief disciplinary officer.

headline: Ukraine Turmoil Forces Cancellation of Kiev Art Biennale
text: MOSCOW — Security concerns and financial difficulties have forced the cancellation of Kiev’s second biennale of contemporary art, Art ARSENALE, which was supposed to be held later this year.

headline: Secularism With a Slightly Militant Edge
text: PARIS — It doesn’t take much these days to stir up a debate in France over “laïcité,” or secularism — a word that seems to be joining “liberté,” “égalité” and “fraternité” as a guiding principle of the French republic.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Readers respond to articles in The New York Times

headline: At Bat for a Century, Owner of Louisville Slugger Gives Way to a Player With More Tools
text: After more than a century, the owner of Louisville Slugger is finally handing over the company — whose bats have been used by the likes of Babe Ruth and Jackie Robinson — to a division of a Finnish sports gear maker.

headline: The Best-Selling Sports Books
text: The best-selling sports books in February 2015, according to the New York Times best-seller list.

headline: Amazon Forest Becoming Less of a Climate Change Safety Net
text: The ability of the Amazon forest to soak up excess carbon dioxide is weakening over time, researchers reported last week. That finding suggests that limiting climate change could be more difficult than expected.

headline: Netanyahu Apologizes; White House Is Unmoved
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel apologized on Monday for making what were widely condemned as racist comments last week in saying that Arab citizens were voting in “droves.”

headline: Tips From a Veteran on Making the Most of Coachella
text: Survival tips for the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, April 10 to 12 this year, are like advice for running a marathon. You’ll want to drink water regularly, for example, and be wary of the vicious desert sun. But with the right planning, you can avoid fatigue and make the most of a weekend with some of the biggest names in music.

headline: Brooklyn Siblings’ Funeral in Israel
text: The father of the seven children from the Sassoon family who were killed in a fire in Brooklyn remembered them at a funeral service in Israel, where they are to be buried.

headline: Robert Durst Is Denied Bail as Prosecutors Argue He Is a Flight Risk
text: NEW ORLEANS — On March 8, an HBO documentary revealed new evidence seeming to tie Robert A. Durst to the 2000 killing of his confidante Susan Berman. Not long after, Mr. Durst stopped using his cellphone.

headline: Review: Marissa Mulder Trusts Her Intuition at the Metropolitan Room
text: Life begins at 30 when you finally start to have some idea of who you really are. That’s the concept of Marissa Mulder’s new show, “Instincts,” which played at the Metropolitan Room on Friday evening. The singer, who recently turned 30, said she had decided not to hang on to the past and to begin trusting intuition to guide her.

headline: In Zurich, a Concept Shop That Promotes Graceful, Stylish Aging
text: The leading models in top ad campaigns for the past few seasons have shared an unusually attainable beauty ideal: age. Céline made quite a stir by casting Joan Didion in its spring campaign; she’s joined in the recent 60-plus modeling set by Joni Mitchell for Saint Laurent, Charlotte Rampling for Nars and Jessica Lange for Marc Jacobs Beauty. At age 93, Iris Apfel upstages her 22-year-old co-star, Karlie Kloss, in Kate Spade’s spring ads. Yet as Benjamin Moser of Zurich’s Senior Design Factory explains, he and his partner Debora Biffi were impelled to create their concept store, design studio and series of workshop projects because they saw a dearth of products specifically crafted for older people’s physical needs that also gave them “the confidence to not feel like they need to hide because they are old.”

headline: Jerusalem Mourns 7 Brief Lives Lost in Brooklyn Fire
text: JERUSALEM — Hundreds of mourners stood in shocked silence, some weeping quietly, some rocking in private prayer. Clouds gathered in the Jerusalem sky as a warm afternoon turned to dusk.

headline: Iran Judge Rejects Washington Post Reporter’s Petition for Prison Furlough
text: Jason Rezaian, the reporter for The Washington Post incarcerated in Iran for eight months, has been denied permission for a five-day Iranian New Year furlough from prison, his brother, Ali Rezaian, said Monday.

headline: Most Boston Residents Prefer Life Term Over Death Penalty in Marathon Case, Poll Shows
text: BOSTON — Despite this city’s immersion in a trial that is replaying the horrific details of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombing, the vast majority of Bostonians say in a new poll that if Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the admitted bomber, is found guilty, he should be sent to prison for life and not condemned to death.

headline: Hydrogen Bomb Physicist’s Book Runs Afoul of Energy Department
text: PHILADELPHIA — For all its horrific power, the atom bomb — leveler of Hiroshima and instant killer of some 80,000 people — is but a pale cousin compared to another product of American ingenuity: the hydrogen bomb.

headline: In France, Local Elections Maintain Rightward Trend
text: PARIS — The first round of local elections in France failed to remake French politics drastically, but did confirm political trends: that voters are seeking change, that the far-right National Front continues to gain ground and that the Socialist Party of President François Hollande continues to lose it.

headline: When Science Is Lost in a Legal Maze
text: In a saner world, where science and the law meshed more precisely, a case like Firstenberg v. Monribot would have been dead on arrival in court. But that is not what happened.

headline: Searching for a Magical Creature, Finding a Need for Wild Places
text: In May 1992, a team of field biologists set out to survey a remote patch of wilderness along the western border of Vietnam. After nine days on the trail, the group was running low on food, so two members were dispatched to a nearby village to stock up on provisions.

headline: White House Chief of Staff Says Netanyahu Declaration Could Not Be Ignored
text: WASHINGTON — Denis McDonough, President Obama’s chief of staff, said that the pre-election declaration by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel that there would be no Palestinian state while he was in office raised questions about his commitment to a two-state solution that the White House could not ignore.

headline: Review: In T. Coraghessan Boyle’s ‘The Harder They Come,’ Rugged Individualism Run Amok
text: The title of T. Coraghessan Boyle’s stunning new novel, “The Harder They Come,” refers less to the Jimmy Cliff movie than to a D. H. Lawrence observation quoted at the beginning of the book: “The essential American soul is hard, isolate, stoic, and a killer. It has never yet melted.”

headline: Longer Flights From La Guardia Might Be Mixed Blessing for Passengers
text: A PROPOSAL is under review that would make La Guardia Airport far more attractive to business travelers by adding domestic long-haul and coast-to-coast trips. So when I got off a short-haul flight at a teeming La Guardia last week, I wondered what this might portend.

headline: For ‘Mad Men,’ a Last Hurrah
text: Jon Hamm, Christina Hendricks, Elisabeth Moss and other stars of the AMC show at MoMA.

headline: Deep Freeze on Great Lakes Halts Cargo Shipments
text: THUNDER BAY, Ontario — The trip to pick up a load of iron ore powder in Conneaut, Ohio, was supposed to take four days by way of the Great Lakes.

headline: Stripe Makes a Bet on Marketplaces With New Product
text: In the lexicon of Silicon Valley, “marketplace” is an increasingly hot buzzword. That’s because it is the business model of companies like Uber, Airbnb and Lyft, where companies act as intermediaries for thousands of people who want to sell their services to the public.

headline: Review: Myra Melford’s ‘Snowy Egret’ Taps Into Dreams
text: Several years ago the pianist and composer Myra Melford formed the Snowy Egret quintet, its title inspired by a dream. The music for the group was a response to something more literary: “Memory of Fire,” the three-volume history of the Americas by Eduardo Galeano.

headline: Young Scientists Impress at the White House
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama marveled on Monday as a group of 6-year-old Girl Scouts at the White House Science Fair demonstrated the automatic page turner they had built out of Legos and explained that the invention was the result of a brainstorming session.

headline: Review: Emily Coates and Yve Laris Cohen, a Dialogue of Choreographers
text: Watching Emily Coates’s “Incarnations (Sketches for a Longer Work),” part of the third performance event in Danspace Project’s Platform 2015, you may wonder if your brain is turning to jelly. Ms. Coates’s embodiment of ideas about corporality and physics in relation to Isaac Newton’s Laws of Motion and the Higgs field challenges the nonscientific among us. At one point, Ms. Coates, a gorgeous redheaded, pregnant former dancer with the New York City Ballet performs Apollo’s solo from George Balanchine’s 1928 ballet of that name, while her co-performer, the Yale physicist Sarah Demers, rapidly describes Ms. Coates’s moves in terms of space, force, mass, acceleration, etc.

headline: Restoring the iCloud Drive Icon
text: Restoring the Icon

headline: Obama Reviews Science Education Program
text: President Obama visited the White House science fair and announced $240 million in contributions to encourage more students to pursue education in science, technology, engineering and math.

headline: 1956: Martin Luther King Makes a Stand
text: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: Ted Cruz, an Ambitious Conservative With Sharp Elbows
text: WASHINGTON — Back in late 2000, Ted Cruz found himself with one of the hottest tickets in town.

headline: Imagine President Ted Cruz
text: “Think just how different the world would be,” said Senator Ted Cruz on Monday, in a speech so packed with vision-spinning and the word “imagine” that it seemed as if John Lennon had returned, as a Hispanic Texan running a hard-right, anti-establishment, Christian-themed campaign for the White House. Weird. But weird is the essence of Mr. Cruz, who is now the first major Republican in the 2016 race. Let the fund-raising begin. Commence the swelling of the Cruz coffers, and of Mr. Cruz’s public profile beyond the gated confines of C-Span and Fox News.

headline: Review: ‘Actual Size Plus,’ Sally Silvers’s Hitchcock-Inspired Work
text: On Friday night at the 92nd Street Y, the choreographer Sally Silvers pulled back the curtain — “ ‘Wizard of Oz’ style,” as she put it — to show how Alfred Hitchcock helped her make a dance.

headline: N.F.L. Will Stream Game From London Next Season
text: PHOENIX — The N.F.L. will begin experimenting with streaming games worldwide next season as it searches for more broadcast revenue and ways to reach the growing number of consumers who do not pay for cable and satellite television.

headline: Review: David Kaplan Riffs on Schumann’s Spirit
text: Schumann emerged as a composer in the 1830s around the same time he started gaining attention for his critical writings. But, being Schumann, he brought an unabashed literary bent to his journalism. He fancied himself the leader of a half-real, half-imagined band of musicians called Davidsbündler (the League of David), artists who disdained the empty virtuosic display so popular in concert halls of the day and championed musical depth and substance along with genuine poetic fantasy and humor.

headline: What Would Lee Kuan Yew Do?
text: WASHINGTON — With China accelerating its military modernization, Russia continuing its slow-drip incursion into Ukraine, and an expanding section of the Middle East devolving into chaos, it has once again become fashionable to argue that the United States is in decline. Strangely, Americans are often far quicker to accept this diagnosis than their counterparts abroad.

headline: Intrepid in an Earthquake, but Rattled by Locking Luggage
text: MUCH of my career has been spent flying, mostly internationally. Now I’m an entrepreneur and a founder and chief executive of the technology company Dashbell, which offers a web-based booking solution for independent hotels. My travel schedule can get more than a little crazy since I may not be spending more than a few days in one place. I might be in Germany for a meeting and then have to fly to some other European country or South American spot for another meeting all in the same week.

headline: Heavenly Creatures
text: The artist Claudia Rankin harnesses the inner world of off-kilter animals in her quirky ceramics.

headline: Pictures of the Day: The United States and Elsewhere
text: The United States and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Justices Look for Reasoning Behind Texas Ban on Confederate License Plate
text: WASHINGTON — The question for the Supreme Court on Monday was whether Texas had violated the First Amendment by rejecting a specialty license plate bearing the Confederate battle flag. As the argument progressed, it became clear that many of the justices were not happy with either possible answer.

headline: Review: Gypsy Flamenco With Play and Passion, Not Flash
text: The art of flamenco has changed and changed again; and nothing has changed it more than the annual circuit of festivals, which usually present flamenco that’s over-choreographed, overproduced and often over-innovative. The “Generations of Gypsy Flamenco” concert at the Town Hall on Friday night, a world premiere that went on to San Francisco on Sunday, was a deliberate turn away from that.

headline: March 23, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from the United States, Yemen, Germany and India.

headline: Online Mischief Seeks to Dull Cruz’s Luster
text: Senator Ted Cruz raced to be first into the 2016 presidential campaign in part to grab some of the attention that potential rivals — Jeb Bush, Gov. Scott Walker and Senators Rand Paul and Marco Rubio, to name a few — have been garnering in recent weeks.

headline: Review: ‘Songs of the City,’ a Paean to New York at 92nd Street Y
text: “Oh, no, not again,” I groaned silently on Saturday evening while scanning the song list for the Lyrics and Lyricists program at the 92nd Street Y, “Songs of the City,” and came upon the inevitable “New York, New York.” But when the time arrived to introduce that Kander and Ebb war horse, the series’ artistic director and host, Deborah Grace Winer, said she had always thought that the song’s perspective was really that of an outsider anticipating living in the city and not the boastful declaration of a fat cat. Substituting ingenuous eagerness for egotism, the singer Darius de Haas turned it into a pop-jazz revelation.

headline: President Obama Could Unmask Big Political Donors
text: Long before Ted Cruz became the first presidential contender to officially declare his candidacy, the competition for big-money donors was well underway.

headline: 7 Friends Drown in Reservoir in India
text: NEW DELHI — Seven friends drowned in the western Indian state of Maharashtra after taking an abandoned boat to the middle of a natural reservoir, the police said Monday. A group of men ages 18 to 23 were celebrating a birthday on Sunday evening with a picnic in a remote village in the Nagpur district when eight of them decided to climb into the boat, using a stick to row to the middle of the 10-foot-deep reservoir, said the district police chief, Arti Singh. As they were taking selfies, the boat started leaking and eventually capsized. One of the men was saved by friends who remained on shore. The bodies of the seven others were dragged from the reservoir on Monday morning by the district police.

headline: Review: ‘Big Time in Hollywood, FL’ 30-Somethings Suddenly on Own
text: To say that Kathy Baker and Stephen Tobolowsky steal the new Comedy Central series “Big Time in Hollywood, FL” isn’t quite right, because it suggests an element of surprise — that there was anything else about this occasionally amusing trifle that might have stood in their way.

headline: Review: Yossi Berg and Oded Graf, Seeking Connection and Dissolving Into Humor
text: About halfway through “Heroes,” a duet by the Israeli choreographers Yossi Berg and Oded Graf, one of the dancers breaks into song. His emphatic rendition of “Happy Together” by the Turtles — “I think about you night and day!” he squawks — doesn’t appear to register with his partner. They seem more desperate and alone.

headline: Walkabout: For National Parks, an Older Crowd
text: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.

headline: Netanyahu Apologizes to Israeli Arabs
text: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized to Israel’s Arabs for his election-day rallying call to his supporters last week, which was called racist by opponents.

headline: Review: On Laura Marling’s ‘Short Movie,’ Songs of Restlessness and Solitude
text: “Love seems to be some kind of trickery,” Laura Marling sings about halfway through “Short Movie,” her intensely searching new album. “Some great thing to which I am a mystery.” She’s strumming an electric guitar against a rock beat, sounding steely and incredulous, unsure about a few things but not, in the end, about herself.

headline: Review: ‘The Ark Work’ Is Liturgy’s Third Album
text: About six years ago, Liturgy, a young band from Brooklyn, figured out a good counterintuitive response to black metal, a restricted, cultish kind of music that isn’t traditionally open to responses of any kind. It did so first through music alone. Liturgy used that subgenre’s basic musical identifying marks — its hyperactive, unsyncopated blast-beat drumming and its staccato guitar lines — but opened up the rhythms and harmonies to let in what black metal generally disallowed: tempo-warping improvisation, major keys, occasionally some nonscreamed singing. It was in the differences that you could smell the wood smoke of an original group sound.

headline: Trailer: New Directors/New Films
text: A look at films in the festival “New Directors/New Films,” presented by the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

headline: Review: Earl Sweatshirt’s Latest Album Goes to Dark Places
text: Another week, another highly touted Los Angeles rap dissenter.

headline: Police Say No Evidence of Rape at UVA
text: Timothy Longo, the Charlottesville police chief, said that the investigation into claims of gang rape at a University of Virginia fraternity had been suspended because of a lack of evidence.

headline: George Bush to Headline Dallas Fund-Raiser for Brother Jeb
text: George W. Bush is lending his younger brother a hand, in one of the few ways he can — for now.

headline: New Directors/New Films Festival Highlights Bold Narrative Experiments
text: Distinct cinematic visions and bold narrative experiments help distinguish the second week of New Directors/New Films, trumping the more familiar festival-ready drifting stories and generic youthful ennui. And, for a second week, the festival is again going (happily) to the dogs: Among last week’s highlights was the astonishing Hungarian pack in “White God”; among this week’s are the less numerous Argentine hounds of “Dog Lady.”

headline: Review: In Rebecca Serrell Cyr’s ‘Assemblage,’ an All-Inclusive Approach
text: What to keep, and what to throw away? That question can come up in any creative process, but in “Assemblage,” Rebecca Serrell Cyr essentially waves it aside. Why not keep everything? According to press notes about the work, which had its premiere at Jack in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, on Thursday, Ms. Cyr made “a radical decision not to edit anything out.”

headline: Review: Schubert and Schnittke, a Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center Concert
text: Schubert and Schnittke: Do they share anything more than alliteration? That was the question asked by the pianist Juho Pohjonen, the violinist Benjamin Beilman and the cellist Jan Vogler during a Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center concert at Alice Tully Hall on Friday.

headline: World’s Protected Areas Draw Estimated 8 Billion Visitors Annually
text: A growing number of people around the world are choosing to spend vacations and weekends in nature. But until recently no one had ever tried to quantify just how many visit protected areas each year.

headline: The Waves of the Future May Bend Around Metamaterials
text: BELLEVUE, Wash. — Plastics. Computers. Metamaterials?

headline: Judge Tells Korean-Restaurant Owner in Queens to Pay $2.7 Million in Back Wages
text: During the busiest banquet season at Kum Gang San, a venerable 24-hour Korean restaurant in Flushing, Queens, employees said they often worked more than 16 hours, with no overtime, and earned less than the minimum wage. When times were slow, workers had to shovel snow from the owner’s driveway and move the owner’s son to a new apartment.

headline: Intersection | Hong Kong
text: While on the streets of the Wan Chai neighborhood, Grace Lam, a contributing fashion editor for Vogue China, shares her fun and edgy style icons: Bruce Lee, David Bowie and her colorblind mother.

headline: Lionel Messi Is Back on His Game
text: It has been a pleasure to watch Lionel Messi playing with Barcelona during the past week, in a way that it hasn’t been in a long time. When I profiled the Argentine superstar for the magazine in June of last year, just before the World Cup, he was in a bit of a funk. As one Argentine writer told me at the time, “It’s like he’s tied up.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Conflict, Courage and Healing in Gaza
text: Heidi Levine’s coverage of the Gaza conflict earned her the Anja Niedringhaus Courage in Photojournalism Award, which honors the Associated Press photographer killed in Afghanistan.

headline: Festival Dressing at SXSW
text: Music lovers bring their unique style to Austin during the SXSW music festival.

headline: Wan Chai Style in Hong Kong
text: Grace Lam, a fashion stylist and contributing fashion editor for Vogue China, used to wear a lot of vintage clothing. But her style changed when she moved from London to Hong Kong. “In Hong Kong, there are not many vintage shops, so it’s difficult to find,” she said. “Now I’m a little more grown-up, and I can afford more designer clothes, which is great.” Recently, in the Wan Chai neighborhood, she was wearing an outfit by Johanna Ho, a local designer, with Balenciaga shoes and a Saint Laurent clutch. She credits the people in the area with taking fashion risks but still considers fashion in Hong Kong more conservative than in cities like Paris or London. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Expected Benefits of Renewed Brooklyn Sewage Station Include a Creek Less Foul
text: The jewel-like brick structure stands unmarked in a jumbled corner of Brooklyn, amid housing projects and plain rowhouses and elevated train tracks and the headquarters of the Aardvark Amusements carnival ride company.

headline: No Need to Run in Hawaii: The Lava Is Coming, but Very Slowly
text: PAHOA, Hawaii — If a disaster movie played out in slow motion, it might look a bit like the Puna District on the Big Island of Hawaii.

headline: Microsoft Partners With Android Makers in Its Latest Mobile Push
text: SEATTLE — Microsoft is serious about making its most lucrative business, Office, relevant to mobile users. What is less clear is how much money it will be able to make from them.

headline: Lee Kuan Yew’s Mixed Legacy in Singapore
text: Lee Kuan Yew, the founding leader of Singapore who died Monday morning, was a towering figure on the global stage who helped transform his small city-state into an economic powerhouse. President Obama went so far as to describe Mr. Lee as a “true giant of history.”

headline: Google Fiber Plans Experiment With Targeted Ads for Television
text: Cute animals. Addictive jingles. Local sports stars acting awkwardly. These are some of the charming hallmarks of local television ads, and Google would like you to see more of them.

headline: Jets Owner Woody Johnson Says He’s Not Concerned About Tampering Inquiry
text: Phoenix — Woody Johnson, owner of the Jets, said he was not concerned about an existing N.F.L. investigation into whether his team broke league rules on tampering before it signed the free-agent cornerback Darrelle Revis.

headline: Despite Regulatory Advances, Experts Say Risk Remains a Danger to Large Banks
text: With all the new laws and regulations since the financial crisis, it would be easy to believe that the banking industry is safer. Unfortunately, speakers at the Federal Reserve conference at George Washington University on Friday offered a range of reasons for why that’s not the case.

headline: Ted Cruz and the Basic Cable Primary
text: The message that Senator Ted Cruz of Texas hoped to convey by kicking off his presidential campaign with a speech Monday morning at Liberty University — a school founded by the Rev. Jerry Falwell — was unmistakable: Already an established star among Tea Party Republicans, Cruz wants to be the candidate of the party’s evangelical wing too.

headline: The N.C.A.A. Women’s Brackets May Be Crowded, but the Arenas Aren’t
text: DURHAM, N.C. — Behind both baskets in the upper levels of Cameron Indoor Stadium during the Duke women’s basketball team’s game Sunday were swaths of empty blue seats.

headline: As Oil Prices Fall, Airfares Still Stay High
text: Just over two years ago, one of the nation’s airline trade organizations called the industry “hypercompetitive” and declared “airfare remains a bargain.” At the time, the Justice Department was weighing the competitive implications of a merger between American Airlines and US Airways, around two years after the merger of United and Continental.

headline: Law Helps Those Who Escape Sex Trafficking Erase Their Criminal Record
text: She has applied for jobs cleaning airplane cabins between flights, tidying up offices overnight and ringing up orders at concession stands. But the 57-year-old woman from Queens has been rejected from these and dozens of other low-wage jobs because she has a long criminal record.

headline: Wynn Resorts Fight Over Board Seat Has Roots in Divorce Settlement
text: Without a trace of bitterness, the billionaire Stephen A. Wynn once described his divorce from Elaine P. Wynn as the most expensive in American history. They evenly split his stake in the casino-resort company they co-founded and seemed to remain compatible leaders of some of the most profitable hotel-casinos in the world.

headline: Charlatans, Cranks, and Cooling
text: Branko Milanovic notes Lee Kwan Yew’s explanation of the success of Singapore and other Asian economies; partly Confucian culture, partly air conditioning. If you’ve ever tried to walk around Singapore, you know whereof he speaks.

headline: A Bronx Man Is Charged With Manslaughter Over a Parking Dispute
text: A Bronx man was arrested and charged with manslaughter on Monday, several days after he punched a neighbor during a parking dispute, delivering a blow that knocked the man to the ground and killed him, the police said.

headline: Bill Takes Aim at S.E.C. Waivers for Firms That Broke Law
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission faces new pressure from Congress to make it harder for lawbreaking companies to hold on to important privileges that help them raise money in the markets.

headline: Hillary Clinton Pays President Obama a Visit
text: President Obama had a special visitor at the White House on Monday: Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: In Italy, Plans for an Easter Blessing Yield a Lawsuit for a Public School
text: BOLOGNA, Italy — The 16 board members of Giosuè Carducci Elementary School took their seats, chatting amicably, until the agenda turned to Easter. The board had already agreed to let a Roman Catholic priest offer a blessing at their public school. Now the questions involved setting the date and whether to hold the prayer in the gym.

headline: U.S. to Continue Afghan Security Funding
text: Defense Secretary Ashton Carter announced funding for Afghan security forces, while Secretary of State John Kerry and the Afghan president, Ashraf Ghani, discussed a “development partnership.”

headline: First Lawsuits Filed Against the F.C.C.’s ‘Net Neutrality’ Rules
text: The wait is over — and it wasn’t long.

headline: A. James Clark, ‘King of Concrete’ Who Built Arenas, Dies at 87
text: A. James Clark, the reclusive billionaire “King of Concrete” whose contracting company transformed the District of Columbia and built sports stadiums and convention centers across the country, died on March 20 at his home in Easton, Md. He was 87.

headline: A 135-Year Tradition
text: The Bok Kai festival in Marysville, Calif., dates to 1880.

headline: Bok Kai Festival in Marysville Brings Touch of 19th Century to 21st
text: MARYSVILLE, Calif. — The annual Chinese-American ritual known as Bomb Day begins peacefully enough, with a solemn procession in which a plaque adorned with the names of deities is carried through town. Before long, hundreds of exploding firecrackers turn the streets magenta with their residue.

headline: Israeli Officials Talk With French to Try to Influence Iran Nuclear Deal
text: PARIS — Fearing that the Obama administration may not take what they consider to be a tough enough stand in the next round of negotiations on a nuclear deal with Iran, senior Israeli officials held talks in Paris on Monday with senior members of the French government and will go to London on Tuesday in an attempt to influence the final terms of any agreement.

headline: Facebook May Host News Sites’ Content
text: Nothing attracts news organizations like Facebook. And nothing makes them more nervous.

headline: Giuliani and de Blasio Form Unlikely Alliance on New York City Schools
text: They are nobody’s idea of allies: Bill de Blasio and Rudolph W. Giuliani, New York City mayors of very different ilks, who have sniped at each other in veiled and less-than-veiled ways since Mr. de Blasio took office last year.

headline: Pete Rose’s Statistics: 4,256 Hits and a Big Error
text: CLEARWATER, Fla. — Mike Schmidt and Paul Molitor watched an exhibition game Monday from opposite dugouts here at the Philadelphia Phillies’ spring training camp. Historically, they belong to the same team, as Hall of Famers with plaques in Cooperstown, N.Y. But on an issue that divides so many in baseball, Schmidt and Molitor disagree.

headline: Review: Revisiting Saul Bellow’s Words, on Society, Chicago and Other Writers
text: There’s an asceticism, a kind of Zen purity, to “There Is Simply Too Much to Think About,” a new collection of Saul Bellow’s nonfiction, issued now on the centenary of his birth.

headline: Ashraf Ghani Thanks U.S. for Support in First Visit as Afghan Leader
text: CAMP DAVID, Md. — Ashraf Ghani, the new president of Afghanistan, opened his first official visit to the United States on Monday with a simple message: He is a man with whom the United States can work, and he is thankful for American support and sacrifices.

headline: West Virginia’s Upset Strategy Against Kentucky: Press, Press, Press
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — The following dynamics have been unable to unnerve Kentucky this season: luck, divine intervention and the bloating pressure of a 36-0 mark that grows greater the deeper the top-seeded Wildcats advance into the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Massachusetts: Divestment Suit Thrown Out
text: A state judge has thrown out a lawsuit brought by Harvard students seeking to force the school to remove investments in fossil fuel companies from its endowment. The suit asked courts to compel divestment on behalf of the students and “future generations.” Justice Paul D. Wilson of Superior Court wrote that the students had no standing to sue the school or the other defendant, the state attorney general. The students, he wrote, “have brought their advocacy, fervent and articulate and admirable as it is, to a forum that cannot grant the relief they seek.”

Poroshenko of Ukraine and the billionaire governor of one of the country’s regions over control of two state-owned energy companies widened Monday, confronting the new Ukrainian government with its most serious internal crisis since coming to power last year.

text: When Congress passed the Affordable Care Act in 2010, the law was expected to cover 21 million people in new insurance marketplaces by 2016. He said he saw them as an example of the federal government overstepping its bounds.

headline: Review: ‘Small Mouth Sounds,’ Silence at a Spiritual Spa
text: A half-dozen troubled souls find that enforced silence doesn’t necessarily bring inner peace in “Small Mouth Sounds,” an enchanting new play by Bess Wohl presented at Ars Nova. As funny as it is, uh, quietly moving, Ms. Wohl’s play is also a model of ingenuity. During its 100-minute running time and with one exception — the (unseen) guru running this spiritual retreat — the characters hardly ever speak. Both the humor and the pathos spring mostly from wordless interaction, which is testimony to Ms. Wohl’s intrepid writing, to the superb acting and to the precise work of the production’s director, Rachel Chavkin.

headline: Now It All Makes Sense

It gave me an estimated 87 percent risk of breast cancer and a 50 percent risk of ovarian cancer. I lost my mother, grandmother and aunt to cancer.

headline: An El Greco Seized by Nazis Returns to Owner’s Family

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
text: 12:30 P.M. (AMC) AMERICAN GANGSTER (2007) Ridley Scott directs this Oscar-nominated crime drama set in the 1970s. Frank Lucas (Denzel Washington) is a gangster in Harlem who finds that he can get the best heroin cheap from Southeast Asia, smuggled to the United States in the coffins of American soldiers sent from Vietnam. He calls the heroin Blue Magic and takes over the market. Richie Roberts (Russell Crowe) is an obnoxiously honest New Jersey detective. When his partner (John Ortiz) dies from an overdose of Blue Magic, Richie is asked to lead a drug trafficking task force. A corrupt New York detective named Trupo (Josh Brolin) bridges the gap between the two lead characters. “You can almost feel Mr. Scott trying to coax the material away from its generic trappings toward something rarefied, something like Francis Ford Coppola’s 1972 definitive American story, ‘The Godfather,’ ” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “He comes closest to that goal with the suggestion that the lethal pursuit of the American dream is not restricted to one or two families — the Corleones, say, or the Sopranos — but located in a network of warring tribes that help to obscure the larger war of all against all.”

headline: Many Will Need to Repay Health Subsidies
text: Half of the households that received subsidies to help pay health insurance premiums last year under the Affordable Care Act will probably have to repay some of that money to the federal government, according to a new analysis by the Kaiser Family Foundation. The foundation also predicted that 45 percent of households that received subsidies will probably get a refund, because their 2014 income was lower than what they estimated when they applied for coverage. Under the law, people can receive subsidies to help cover the cost of insurance purchased through online marketplaces if they earn between 100 and 400 percent of the federal poverty level. Taxpayers generally receive subsidies in advance, with the amount based on their projected household income for the year the insurance policy will be in effect. But they must then reconcile the estimate with their actual income when filing federal taxes. Kaiser estimated that subsidy recipients who underestimated their incomes will owe $794 on average, while those who overestimated will receive average refunds of $773.

headline: Debunking the Myth of the Job-Stealing Immigrant
text: When I was growing up in the 1980s, I watched my grandfather — my dad’s stepdad — struggle with his own prejudice. He was a blue-collar World War II veteran who loved his family above all things and was constantly afraid for them. He carried a gun and, like many men of his generation, saw threats in people he didn’t understand: African-Americans, independent women, gays. By the time he died, 10 years ago, he had softened. He stopped using racist and homophobic slurs; he even hugged my gay cousin. But there was one view he wasn’t going to change. He had no time for Hispanics, he told us, and he wasn’t backing down. After all, this wasn’t a matter of bigotry. It was plain economics. These immigrants were stealing jobs from “Americans.”

headline: Galaxies Inside His Head
text: Fifty students sat at bright white desks in concentric rows in the sterile new computer center at Woodland Hills High School, their eyes on the poet Terrance Hayes. At 6-foot-5, Hayes, who is 43, is easy to see from anywhere, and he seemed eminently approachable, neither teacher nor teen: bluejeans, a black sweater, a leather cellphone case clipped to his belt. He had come to the school, in a racially mixed district that serves several disadvantaged communities in Pittsburgh, to read poetry. The students — Goths, hip-hop fans in giant sweatshirts and jocks in sports jerseys — grew quiet, ready to listen.

headline: How ‘Flawless’ Became a Feminist Declaration
text: The word “flaw” is some 700 years old. It was born from fire and ice, first used to mean “ember” and “snowflake” — some fragment of a whole gone astray. It evolved to signify “defect,” initially in surfaces and soon after in character. But recently, it has become associated most closely with appearance, thanks to the popularity of its opposite, “flawless.” On social media, “flawless” has a celebratory sheen: Women apply it tenderly, reverently to one another — and triumphantly to themselves.

headline: A Persian in Therapy

headline: The LC2 Chair, in Living Color
text: Le Corbusier designed the LC2 chair in 1928, but its defining moment didn’t come until 51 years later, in a famous 1979 commercial by Maxell audio in which a slouching young man in aviator shades is nearly blown out of the seat by a gust of high fidelity. Little wonder he stayed put: The LC2 brings a distinctly modern profile to down-cushioned comfort. Now Cassina, which has licensed Le Corbusier’s furniture since 1964, has reached into the archives for five new frame colors, including arresting shades of blue and green, developed with the help of the two people who inspired the architect to start making his own furniture in the first place: his cousin and business partner, Pierre Jeanneret, and their collaborator, the incomparable Charlotte Perriand. Eighty-seven years after its creation, it’s still a chair you don’t want to get out of.

Meanwhile, President Obama’s program to give deportation relief to some unauthorized immigrants has been stymied, nationwide, by a hostile federal district judge in Texas.

The valuation could change because the talks are still occurring, according to this ​person, who requested anonymity because of continuing ties to the company.

headline: Ted Cruz Recruits Some Rand Paul Supporters in Iowa
text: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, whose path to the Republican nomination requires a breakout performance in Iowa, has quickly recruited more than a dozen party leaders for his statewide campaign, who are to be announced in coming days, according to people told of the choices.

headline: As Arizona Struggles to Fix Foster System, Children Suffer the Consequences
text: PHOENIX — She was just 5 months old the first time she and her siblings were taken from a mother struggling with addiction and placed in the care of the state. At times, she was separated from her brothers and sisters. She received neither the glasses she needed, nor the orthopedic shoes, leaving her with a limp. Now 10, she has spent more than half her life in foster care, having been returned to her mother only to be removed again, a routine that has been repeated multiple times.

headline: $20 Million Gift to Expand National World War II Museum

headline: Review: Daniel Beaty as Paul Robeson in ‘The Tallest Tree in the Forest’
text: The lives of actors often contain heady highs and dispiriting lows, so fragile is their hold on the public’s imagination and their access to the levers of power in the industry. But the story of Paul Robeson, the great African-American performer who achieved international fame in the 1920s and ’30s, only to be condemned for his political beliefs and branded a Communist during the witch hunts of the ’50s, is a particularly egregious example of a star falling at warp speed.

text: As a member of the Federal Reserve’s board, Jeremy C. Stein raised concerns about areas of frothiness in the financial markets.

headline: Commemoration of Death of Lincoln Features Report From a Doctor in the House
text: The National Archives in Washington is commemorating the 150th anniversary of the death of Abraham Lincoln with a series of book talks, a panel discussion and the exhibition of a key document relating to the assassination: a copy of the death report drafted a day after the shooting by Charles A. Leale, a doctor in the audience at Ford’s Theater.

headline: Memo by Democrats for Education Reform Looks Ahead to 2016
text: Joe Williams, the executive director of Democrats for Education Reform, wrote to board members about polling conducted for the group, presumably in an attempt to set the terms for a policy discussion with candidates.

headline: Hillary Clinton Caught Between Dueling Forces on Education: Teachers and Wealthy Donors
text: The last time she ran for president, Hillary Rodham Clinton did not have to take a position on the Common Core, Race to the Top or teacher evaluations in tenure decisions.

headline: Stubborn Pay Gap Is Found in Nursing
text: Male nurses make $5,100 more on average per year than female colleagues in similar positions, researchers reported on Tuesday.

headline: Ocwen to Sell Servicing Rights on $25 Billion in Mortgages to Nationstar
text: Ocwen Financial, the mortgage servicing firm under regulatory scrutiny, disclosed on Tuesday that it planned to sell loan servicing rights for $25 billion in loans to another firm, Nationstar Mortgage.

headline: Scene City: ‘Mad Men’ Toasts Its Final Season
text: On Sunday night, the stars of “Mad Men” celebrated the show’s final season with a party at the Museum of Modern Art. “For better or for worse, it’s not only the longest job I’ve ever had but certainly the career-defining one, to say the least,” Jon Hamm said. “Yeah, I will definitely miss it.”

headline: Cocktail Table Service Thinks Big
text: Whenever the bartender Pamela Wiznitzer goes home to Ohio at Thanksgiving, her family naturally enlists her to make drinks.

headline: 1915: Ankles Baffle Court Witness
text: The ankles of Mrs. Claudia Carlstedt Wheeler, once a New York stage favorite, were not recognized by a witness brought to testify against her in the Supreme Court yesterday [March 8]. Neither was her face or figure. Judson Rogers, night clerk of the San Remo Hotel, decided that she was not the woman with whom Walter W. Green had registered as man and wife. Mrs. Wheeler appeared before Justice Greenbaum and a jury to contest the action for divorce brought by Albert Gallatin Wheeler, Jr., son of the builder of the Chicago elevated railroad. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 25, 1915

headline: Trusted Aide Declines Formal Role in a Clinton Campaign
text: Cheryl D. Mills, an adviser to Hillary Rodham Clinton who has been closer to her than perhaps any other over the last six years, will not be playing a formal role in her soon-to-be-announced presidential bid, according to people in direct discussions with the campaign.

headline: Why Wall Streeters’ Defections to Silicon Valley Are Good News for the Economy
text: It’s easy to understand why Ruth Porat, the chief financial officer of the venerable investment bank Morgan Stanley and one of the most powerful women on Wall Street, would want to head west to become C.F.O. of Google.

headline: Festival Dressing at SXSW
text: The South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., marks the beginning of the music festival season, and the start of springtime weather and fashion. Outside of Red7, music fans show off their bleached and dyed locks and denim.

headline: After a Baby’s Arrival, Some Visit, and Others Stay Away
text: Since our daughter Evy got the go-ahead to be in the world, the parade of visitors hasn’t stopped. Yes, we had visitors before she was strong enough to be in public, but we kept things small, limiting visits to one or two people, and no children allowed, because of their germiness. It was tough to say that to people, but thanks to Skype and FaceTime, children on both sides of the family got a chance to see Evy for themselves, even if it was via webcam.

headline: Liberals, Conservatives, and Jobs
text: Just about everything I write evokes vituperative reactions from the usual suspects, but never so much as when I point out awkward facts. So there was a lot of mud-slinging when I pointed out last summer that California’s economy — which conservatives said was doomed by tax increases and generally liberal policies — was in fact experiencing an impressive recovery.

headline: A Simple Recipe for Pasta With Mussels
text: Pasta with mussels is one of those complex-tasting dishes that is simple to make. Steam mussels in white wine with chopped shallot and crushed garlic for a few minutes, just until they open. Set mussels aside, then strain and reserve some of the briny broth, which will enrich a light marinara sauce.

headline: Radio and TV Martí, U.S. Broadcasters to Cuba, Emerge From Cold War Past Facing Uneasy Future
text: MIAMI — The rat-a-tat Cuban-inflected Spanish of the two Radio Martí hosts ricocheted back and forth during “Revoltillo,” a show laced with humor that airs classified ads posted in Cuba on a Craigslist-style website called Revolico.

headline: 2015 James Beard Award Nominees
text: Nominees for the annual James Beard Awards, which honor chefs, restaurants, writers and other professionals in the world of American food, were announced Tuesday morning. The list of restaurant and chef nominees is below; the winners will be announced in Chicago on May 4. A full list of nominees in print, broadcast and other categories can be found on the James Beard Foundation website.

headline: Live Chat With Amy Klein: Tuesday, March 24, 9 P.M. Eastern Time
text: Amy Klein will be answering questions about her journey from infertility treatment to pregnancy here tonight (Tuesday, March 24, 2015) at 9 Eastern Time, and I’ll be moderating quickly so that conversation can flow fast and furious.

headline: ‘Hausfrau,’ by Jill Alexander Essbaum
text: Anna Benz, the heroine of Jill Alexander Essbaum’s frequently engrossing first novel, is a very bad girl indeed: ­indiscriminate in her philandering, highly specialized in secrets and lies and deeply invested in her own misery. Worst of all, she can’t even come clean to her shrink. “When will you trust me enough to tell me everything?” wonders her exasperated psychiatrist, Frau Doktor Messerli.

headline: Little Park
text: Andrew Carmellini’s latest restaurant in TriBeCa

headline: Restaurant Review: Little Park in TriBeCa
text: It is as colorful and otherworldly as a coral reef, this row of fried cauliflower knobs in purple, ivory and marigold yellow. Wrapping each floret is a pale-gold skin of batter. It’s almost invisible, but you feel it as you bite, its soft snap reinforced by the full-on crunch of chopped almonds. Poached before it is fried, the cauliflower is nicely salted all the way down to its tender core, but it is still cauliflower, so it needs a little support. This is supplied by a lush green tomatillo, pistachio and fresh herb sauce that gets in a quick, peppery jab before it signs off.

headline: Joseph Kanon’s ‘Leaving Berlin’
text: Heroes in espionage fiction tend to fall into two categories: the world-weary professional and the rank amateur. Milo Weaver, the killer-spook of Olen Steinhauer’s “The Tourist,” and John le Carré’s MI6 agent George Smiley are cynical veterans of the spying game, old hands at duplicity and betrayal. At the other end of the spectrum is the mild-mannered engineer of John Buchan’s “The Thirty-Nine Steps,” Richard Hannay, who stumbles across a German spy ring and finds himself framed for murder.

headline: Israel Denies Spying on Iran Nuclear Talks
text: JERUSALEM — Three top Israeli ministers on Tuesday denied a report that their intelligence services had spied on the closed-door negotiations over Iran’s nuclear program, as tensions continued to mount between Washington and Jerusalem.

headline: Jemima Kirke’s Workout Thwarts The Usual Fitness Trends
text: The “Girls” actor let T into a personal training session at Brooklyn Strength, where she engages in a mix of Pilates and kettlebell work to get strong — not skinny.

headline: ‘Night at the Fiestas,’ by Kirstin Valdez Quade
text: In 1985, a Yale professor named Jaroslav Pelikan published “Jesus Through the Centuries,” a book he described as “not a life of Jesus . . . but a series of images portraying his place in the history of culture.” These notions of Christ have been irreconcilably varied over 2,000 years, sometimes bolstering the powerful and sometimes consoling the powerless: the rabbi, the light of the gentiles, the king of kings, the cosmic Christ, the son of man, the monk who rules the world, the bridegroom of the soul, the universal man, the prince of peace, the teacher of common sense, the liberator, the man who belongs to the world.

headline: Review: James Corden Is Amiable, if Not Particularly Special, in ‘Late Late Show’ Debut on CBS
text: “Can’t act. Slightly bald. Also dances.”

headline: Senator Coats, Republican of Indiana, Won’t Seek Re-election
text: Senator Dan Coats of Indiana announced Tuesday that he would not seek re-election in 2016, ending a political career that has spanned more than three decades and setting up a potentially competitive race in what had been thought to be a safe Republican seat.

headline: Fringe Gone Wild
text: Not the wispy embellishment of days past, but a full-on takeover of a garment by its trim. At last, the ornamental becomes essential.

headline: ‘The X-Files’ to Return for Six-Episode Limited Series
text: Thirteen years after it went off the air, “The X-Files” is coming back to Fox.

headline: Cuomo Drops Dream Act and Education Tax Credit From Budget
text: After Republican and Democratic leaders could not agree on a proposal that linked immigration reform with an education tax credit in Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s proposed budget, the governor said on Tuesday that both would be dropped as negotiations continued.

headline: Gelso & Grand Comes to Little Italy
text: Headliner

headline: A New Look for a Laguna Beach Hotel
text: The Laguna Beach House, formerly known as Laguna Cliffs Inn, will reopen April 1 after a $1.5 million renovation to update all 36 guest rooms and public spaces, including an expanded lobby and pool deck.

headline: T. C. Boyle: By the Book
text: The author, most recently, of “The Harder They Come” is mad about nature writing: “I want to get inside the head of every creature in the world, even ants.”

headline: Cruz Campaign Begins With Round of TV Appearances
text: As the newly minted — and only — declared candidate for president in 2016, Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, has been a popular television guest in the last 24 hours.

headline: White House Names Biden Adviser as Message Strategist
text: WASHINGTON — Shailagh Murray, a former political reporter who has spent the last four years as a senior adviser to the vice president, will move to the West Wing as the top message strategist for President Obama, the White House announced on Tuesday.

headline: Readers’ Turn: The Marijuana Debate
text: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Details Offered in Germanwings Crash
text: The managing director of Germanwings, Thomas Winkelmann, said the Airbus A320 rapidly lost altitude for more than eight minutes before crashing in the French Alps on Tuesday.

headline: Rangers’ Henrik Lundqvist Expects to Play This Weekend
text: The Rangers have been on a roll with goalie Cam Talbot in net, winning 17 of 24 games since he became their starter in early February.

headline: 1940: Inventor of Radio Wave Dies
text: Dr. Edouard Branly, one of France’s greatest scientists and forerunner of Guglielmo Marconi in the development of wireless telegraphy, died at his home in Paris yesterday [March 24]. He was ninety-six years old. At the outbreak of the war he left Paris for Haute-Vienne and had returned to the city only recently. Although he was relatively unknown to the general public, scientific colleagues recognize that his experiments in the field of wave transmission by a park coil made possible the perfection of wireless by Marconi a few years later. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 25, 1940

headline: Perfectly Reasonable Question: Closed Captions on Times Videos
text: A reader, Sebastian Barrett St.Troy, likes The Times’s video offerings, but wonders about one feature that, so far, is missing.

headline: Ted Cruz on How 9/11 Changed His Taste in Music
text: Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas and a declared candidate for president, explained on CBS how the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, turned him from a lifelong classic rock fan into a country music fan.

headline: The Mother-Daughter Thing
text: You could never tell from the intriguingly opaque work of the poet Susan Howe and the artist R. H. Quaytman that the two women are related. Then you sit down with them.

headline: Ex-Gov. Rick Perry of Texas Won’t Discuss Cruz Candidacy
text: HOUSTON – Rick Perry, the former governor of Texas who is considering a second run for the White House after his politically disastrous 2012 campaign, sought to show off his domestic and foreign policy chops at a breakfast with reporters here on Tuesday. But he was silent when asked about Senator Ted Cruz, the conservative firebrand who announced his campaign for president on Monday.

headline: Aging Ex-Mafia Boss Fails in Bid for Leniency on Jail Time
text: High blood sugar, stress, swelling of kidneys, swelling of skin, lung problems, vision issues: These were some of the medical problems enumerated by lawyers for Thomas DiFiore, a 71-year-old Mafia member, at his sentencing on Tuesday in Brooklyn.

headline: Yale Researchers to Study Learning Game Apps
text: A three-year-old learning games company wants to raise the bar on how education technology start-ups measure and market the effectiveness of their products.

headline: Video of Most Recent Secret Service Incident Is Shown
text: Representative Jason Chaffetz, the chairman of the House Oversight Committee, publicly aired the surveillance footage at the center of the most recent Secret Service controversy.

headline: Google Should Feel Lucky in Its Finance Chief Hire
text: Google should feel lucky about its search for a new chief financial officer.

headline: Grading Teachers by the Test
text: In 2004, the Chinese government decided there were too many accidental deaths. China’s safety record, it decreed, should be brought in line with those of other middle-income countries. The State Council set a target: a decline in accidental deaths of 2.5 percent per year.

headline: What Happened on the Germanwings Flight
text: Maps and timeline of what is known about the crash.

headline: Arctic Ice Reaches a Low Winter Maximum
text: The winter ice covering the Arctic has reached its annual peak, but the extent this winter is smaller than it has been at the end of any since 1978.

headline: A Few Words From Bill Belichick After a Super Bowl Win. Very Few.
text: PHOENIX — The coaches’ round table is an annual ritual at the N.F.L. owners’ meeting. Reporters have an hour to meet new coaches, become reacquainted with veteran ones and try their best to draw something out of New England Patriots Coach Bill Belichick.

headline: Braised Brisket
text: Melissa Clark braises brisket and pairs it with a bright horseradish gremolata.

headline: ‘Rhapsody in Blue’ to Open 92nd Street Y Season
text: The 92nd Street Y will open its 2015-16 season in October with Gershwin’s “Rhapsody in Blue” in its original jazz band arrangement, pairing the pianist Kirill Gerstein with Vince Giordano & the Nighthawks, it announced Tuesday. Other pairings planned for the season will juxtapose Beethoven’s violin sonatas with contemporary works, and visual art with music.

headline: Video of Secret Service Barricade Mishap
text: A March 4 surveillance video released by the House Oversight Committee shows a car driven by Secret Service agents lightly knocking a barricade around a potential bomb in front of the White House.

headline: Gremolata Gives Passover Brisket a Brighter Side
text: Osso buco is one of Italy’s most celebrated dishes. But the soft, wine-braised veal shanks wouldn’t be nearly as sublime without those vivid flecks of piquant, herbal gremolata on top. The gremolata, a jumble of parsley, garlic and lemon zest, adds its own bright notes, and functions as a contrast to the dark sauce, relieving its heady intensity.

headline: No Bad Questions
text: Kids pose questions during a new sex-ed class that uses openness and humor to make “The Talk” less dreadful.

headline: In Reversal, Boston 2024 Wants Vote on Olympic Bid
text: BOSTON — Stung by recent polling that showed only a third of Boston residents want the city to host the 2024 Summer Olympics, the group organizing the bid has reversed itself and now supports a voter referendum on the proposal, an inauspicious development for an already shaky bid.

headline: Justices Rule Opinions May Sometimes Be Basis for Securities Fraud Suits
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday ruled that statements couched as opinions may sometimes be the basis for securities fraud suits.

headline: The Thorny Task of Advocating Good Corporate Behavior
text: In the war to control corporations, the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, the $300 billion pension fund, has decided that it is willing to actively press companies to emphasize the environment, diversity and good corporate governance, perhaps even at the expense of profitability. It may save the planet by changing the way companies are run, but will it lead to the returns Calpers desperately needs?

headline: Review: On Crackle, ‘Dead Rising: Watchtower’ Offers Second Helpings to Video Game Fans
text: The zombie movie “Dead Rising: Watchtower” might hold rewards for people who have spent hours immersed in the video game series on which it’s based. Judged as a free-standing film, though, it’s a time waster devoid of the wit and depth of other walking-dead fare currently available — see, for instance, the new CW series “iZombie.”

headline: Angelina Jolie: More ‘Common’ Than Any Celebrity Would Like to Be
text: I know I’m not the only person thinking about Angelina Jolie today.

headline: Review: In ‘Lonesome Traveler,’ a Folk Music Journey Unfolds
text: “Lonesome Traveler” is full of familiar songs prettily sung, a sort of jukebox folk musical. Too bad it didn’t aspire to be more; still, it sounds great.

headline: Femininity With a Point
text: Michelle Obama, who opted for clothes that recalled the ’50s during her Asia tour, may have been confronting stereotypes about femininity and power.

headline: Air Pollution Raises Stroke Risk
text: Air pollution — even for just one day — significantly increases the risk of stroke, a large review of studies has found.

headline: Second Day as a Candidate, Cruz Jabs at Bush Over Immigration
text: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas hasn’t wasted much time in seeking to distinguish himself from his potential rivals for the Republican presidential nomination, taking issue with Jeb Bush on Tuesday for his position on immigration and implicitly criticizing the former Florida governor for treating “voters as children.”

headline: Kimmy Schmidt’s Revolutionary Approach to Pain
text: “You can stand anything for 10 seconds,” says Kimmy Schmidt. “Then you just start on a new 10 seconds.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Spain and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Spain, Afghanistan, Singapore and Somalia.

headline: For Michelle Obama, Girlie Clothes That Lean In
text: I admit: I was startled last week when I saw the first photos of Michelle Obama debarking in Japan at the beginning of her five-day Asian tour to promote the “Let Girls Learn” education campaign.

headline: A Modern House With Views of Jungle and Ocean
text: In a gated community three miles from Manuel Antonio National Park, the four-bedroom home is on the market for $2.39 million.

headline: Wynn Resorts Board Raises Objections to a Co-Founder’s Re-election
text: The battle between the co-founders of the Wynn Resorts casino company escalated on Tuesday, when the company urged stockholders in a lengthy letter to reject a bid by Elaine P. Wynn to remain on the board on grounds she was “self-serving” and “ineffective,” and had ceased to act in the company’s best interest.

headline: Inquiry Finds Homeland Security Official Intervened in Visa Cases
text: After an investigation lasting more than two years, the inspector general of the Department of Homeland Security has found that Alejandro Mayorkas, the deputy secretary, intervened directly to gain fast-track consideration of visas for foreign investors connected to Democrats when he was the head of the visa agency.

headline: March 24, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Spain, Afghanistan, Singapore and Somalia.

headline: In the Kitchen With Jackson Pollock
text: Everyone knows we eat with our eyes, and that the world’s best chefs, despite their origins or cuisine, turn out dishes as visually arresting as any work of art. But what happens when an artist, say Jackson Pollock, wears the apron? Thanks to his iconic drip masterpieces, the late painter has become a household name. And today, with the release of a new book stemmed from the contents of his former kitchen, Pollock begins his second legacy: as a foodie with a penchant for baking.

headline: Obama to Slow Withdrawal in Afghanistan
text: President Obama, in an appearance with the Afghan president, Ashraf Ghani, said that delaying the withdrawal of the 9,800 American troops stationed in Afghanistan would be “well worth it.”

headline: Review: Richard Alston’s ‘Carmen’ in Fort Lauderdale
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — Richard Alston’s one-act “Carmen,” recently performed by Miami City Ballet at the Broward Center here, is the best “Carmen” ballet I’ve seen. That is less a compliment than it sounds: Most “Carmen” ballets are clunkily melodramatic and choreographically dismal.

headline: A Clean Getaway at St. Lucia Resort
text: Sugar Beach, a Viceroy property on the Caribbean island of St. Lucia, will ease at least one re-entry chore for some departing guests: the laundry.

headline: Jeb Bush Returns to the Washington Fund-Raising Well
text: WASHINGTON — “I’m not an expert on the ways of Washington,” Jeb Bush told conservatives last month when he was asked about a funding dispute in Congress.

headline: March Madness, the Politics Edition
text: To the delight of those who see politics as sport, Senator Ted Cruz and his aides have taken to describing the Republican primary constituencies in terms of March Madness brackets, with Final Four spots for the Establishment, Libertarians, Evangelicals and the Tea Party.

headline: Manhattan Area Codes Multiply, but the Original, 212, Is Still Coveted
text: For Kelli Parker and her husband, Andy Lippitt, finding a place to live in Manhattan was secondary to obtaining what they thought would instantly identify them as New Yorkers: his-and-hers cellphone numbers with 212 area codes.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: What You Get for … $2,200,000
text: This week’s properties include homes in Colorado, New Hampshire and Chicago.

headline: Will Homebuyers Come Through This Spring?
text: In real estate, the spring selling season is something of a misnomer. It gets underway around now and lasts until back-to-school season in September.

headline: YouTube’s ‘Sunshine Girl’ Comes to Print
text: Nearly five years ago, a chirpy, animated 16-year-old named Paige McKenzie uploaded a 68-second video to YouTube. “Hey everybody, so, I know this is a little strange,” she says, then confides that her house is haunted and she aims to capture the ghost on camera.

headline: Netflix, Amazon and Hulu No Longer Find Themselves Upstarts in Online Streaming
text: Netflix, Amazon and Hulu have suddenly found themselves playing a new role: the establishment.

headline: Review: ‘The Kidnapping of Michel Houellebecq’ Blurs Fiction and Reality
text: The crumpled, ashen-faced man on screen stands on a corner in Paris alone and seemingly ignored. The world is not paying attention to Michel Houellebecq, save for the off-screen movie crew and us, of course. This probably doesn’t happen often to Mr. Houellebecq (pronounced WELL-beck), the French novelist whose putatively scandalous work touches on subjects — despair, sex tourism, cloning, Islamic political power, despair again — that seem calculated to provoke, especially, the humorless. A typically vulgar caricature of him was on the cover of the magazine Charlie Hebdo on Jan. 7, the day that two jihadists entered its Paris offices and set about slaughtering 12 people.

headline: From Cho Junglae, a Film on Japanese Wartime Brothels
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The painting showed Japanese soldiers taking young women who had been forced to work in Japan’s military brothels to a burning pit. When he saw it, the Korean filmmaker Cho Junglae said, he was shocked — and inspired to make a feature film about the so-called comfort women of World War II, many of whom never made it home.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Leon Bridges’s Retro Festival Style
text: Leon Bridges, a soul singer from Forth Worth, Texas, who made a splash at last weekend’s South By Southwest festival in Austin, talks about his high-waisted pants and the Dapper Rebels.

headline: Walker’s Troubles With Vetting Staff Members
text: Gov. Scott Walker faced criticism last week after a newly hired aide to his fledgling presidential campaign resigned under pressure for derogatory remarks she had made about Iowa and its first-in-the-nation nominating contest. But the incident wasn’t the first time Mr. Walker had run into a problem over an apparent lack of vetting of a staff member.

headline: A Tour of Le District
text: An Eataly-type market for French food is set to open in the financial district.

headline: Afghan Protesters Demand Justice for Woman Killed by Mob
text: Hundreds of Afghan protesters marched to the nation’s Supreme Court on Tuesday, demanding justice for a woman who was beaten to death by a mob last week after being falsely accused of burning pages from the Quran.

headline: First Draft Focus: Emotional Day for a Golf Legend
text: Jack Nicklaus became the third golfer to be awarded a Congressional Gold Medal.

headline: Ukraine Tells Bondholders to Expect Some Losses
text: Moscow — Holders of Ukrainian bonds, already beleaguered by the last year of war and upheaval in that country, should expect to lose some of their principal in negotiations with the government, Ukraine’s finance minister said Tuesday.

headline: Living in Mott Haven, the Bronx
text: The waterfront enclave, a mix of industrial and residential properties, is undergoing a gradual reinvention.

headline: Hearing and Feeling What Photographers Are Saying
text: Chuck Kelton says most printers can get 90 percent of an image right. But that final 10 percent is where a printer’s darkroom skills draw out a photo’s magnificence.

headline: Notes on the Hip-Hop Messiah
text: The hip-hop messiah is both real and not real. He — and with the possible exception of Lauryn Hill, it has always been a “he” — is real in the sense that every five years or so, whenever hip-hop feels too boring, or, worse, too corporate, an artist will be appointed as the spiritual future of the form.

headline: In German Town, a School-Year Highlight That Ended in Disaster
text: HALTERN AM SEE, Germany — It had to have been one of the happiest experiences of their lives, people said.

headline: Cruz, Critic of Health Care Law, Now Seeks to Sign Up
text: Senator Ted Cruz helped lead an effort to shut down the government in 2013 in an attempt to defund President Obama’s health care law. Now the Texas senator, a newly announced Republican presidential candidate, is signing up for coverage under it.
