headline: Brooklyn Stepfather of 2-Year-Old Is Charged With Murder
text: A man accused of violently shaking his 2-year-old stepdaughter, leading to her death in November and a fight over her organs, was arraigned on a murder charge on Thursday after the girl’s death was ruled a homicide.

headline: Review: In ‘While We’re Young,’ a Coupling of Gen X and Y
text: If you’ve seen Noah Baumbach’s “Greenberg” you may remember a scene in which the title character, played by Ben Stiller, unleashes a tirade against a roomful of 20-year-olds whom he believes have been ruined by sensitive parenting, among other things. (If you haven’t seen “Greenberg,” we need to talk). “While We’re Young,” Mr. Baumbach’s buoyant, vinegar-laced new film, is not a sequel — Mr. Stiller plays Josh, a reasonably pleasant and well-adjusted guy for a Ben Stiller character in a Noah Baumbach picture — but it does pick up where the earlier movie left off in its exploration of the fraught relations between ascendant millennials and the rapidly aging members of Generation X.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, March 29 to April 4, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: New Google C.F.O. Gets $70 Million Pay Package (and $7,500 to Move)
text: Ruth Porat, Google’s new chief financial officer, is joining a company that has more than 50,000 employees and is one of the most valuable corporations in the world. Thus, given Google is long past its early days, it’s not the kind of place that will make her a start-up billionaire.

headline: A Slice of Times Square, Always in Motion
text: The miracle of photography is that it takes moving objects and makes them still. Yet in real life, motion is part of who we are, the pulse of the city around us. Adam Magyar invented a way to insert that motion into still images. What you see on this page are not block-wide streetscapes, but minutes in the life of a one-pixel-wide sliver of New York life, captured in all its chaos and motion.

headline: Fire and a Building Collapse in East Village
text: A powerful explosion on Second Avenue near Seventh Street caused two buildings to collapse and damaged two others on Thursday afternoon.

headline: Review: In ‘White God,’ Man Bites Dog, Dog Bites Back
text: The hand that feeds — and also brutalizes — is righteously bitten in “White God,” a Hungarian revenge fantasy that’s like nothing you’ve seen on screen before. The story is as simple as a parable, a campfire story, a children’s book: A faithful animal, separated from its loving owner, endures, suffers, struggles and resists while trying to transcend its brutal fate. The director, Kornel Mundruczo, has said that he was partly inspired by J. M. Coetzee’s devastating novel “Disgrace,” but the movie also invokes haunting animal classics like “Black Beauty” and “The Call of the Wild.”

headline: Review: ‘Get Hard,’ With Will Ferrell and Kevin Hart
text: The comic premise of “Get Hard” could hardly be simpler. Will Ferrell is white. Kevin Hart, in contrast, is black. But you don’t have to consult a Starbucks barista to know that race is a very complicated matter. It’s been a source of humor for a very long time, but which jokes are acceptable to whom is never an easy matter to determine. Somebody is likely to be offended. The trick in a movie like this one is to appear daring while playing it safe, to act provocative while not actually provoking anyone.

headline: Suicide by Plane Crash Is Rare but Not Without Precedent
text: What goes through the mind of a pilot as he turns the nose of an airliner toward the ground and prepares for death, taking 149 other people with him?

headline: Review: Trio 3 Shows Off Its Jazz Avant-Garde Pedigree
text: One misperception about the jazz avant-garde is that it’s essentially reactive, a single-minded pushback against conventions of form. Whatever lump of truth or slander you might find in that idea, Trio 3, which plays at the Village Vanguard this week, provides scant supporting evidence for it.

headline: Movie Review: ‘White God’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “White God.”

headline: Review: Ibeyi, Twin Sisters and a Duo, Uses Songs to Show Roots
text: Ancient rituals reply to modern concerns in the music of Ibeyi, the duo of Naomi and Lisa-Kaindé Díaz, who performed on Wednesday night at the Music Hall of Williamsburg. They are twins born in France and steeped in the Cuban heritage of their father, Angá Díaz, who was a leading percussionist in Cuba.

headline: Jason Heyward’s Ability Seems Boundless. Soon, So May His Contract.
text: JUPITER, Fla. — The most captivating thing about Jason Heyward may also be the most confounding. He could be any type of player you imagine, and it is almost time to put a price on his future.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Get Hard’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Get Hard.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘While We’re Young’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “While We’re Young.”

headline: This Week’s Movies | March 27, 2015
text: The New York Times film critics review “Get Hard,” “While We’re Young” and “White God.”

headline: Inside a Pilot’s Mind
text: I WORKED as a pilot for about 10 years before going back to school to become an architect. There are a few oddballs I can remember flying with, but mostly we’re just talking quirks and eccentricities. Never did I fear a colleague intended to kill himself, or everyone onboard.

headline: Orthodox Jews in Brooklyn Rush to Buy Smoke Detectors Before Sabbath
text: The Buzz, an electronics store in Borough Park, Brooklyn, had by Wednesday sold out of its supply of smoke detectors three times and then started a charity giveaway to distribute hundreds more.

headline: A Fight to Save Pieces of the Past as a Phoenix Enclave Is Reshaped
text: PHOENIX — Inside a worn-down building on the edge of downtown, a rambling mural that covered nearly the length of one wall looked like something a traveling artist might have painted for the sole purpose of settling a bar tab — as many here suspect was the case.

headline: William King, Sculptor, Dies at 90; His Pointed Wit Was a Tool
text: William King, a sculptor in a variety of materials whose human figures traced social attitudes through the last half of the 20th century, often poking sly and poignant fun at human follies and foibles, died on March 4 at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 90.

headline: Contact Lens Makers and Discounters Tussle Over Price Setting
text: Anthony D. Morrow had been wearing the same brand of contact lenses for years, so when he saw the bill for his latest order last November, he did a double take.

headline: Review: ‘Man From Reno,’ a Mystery of Missing Persons and Priceless Turtles
text: The two main characters in Dave Boyle’s labyrinthine neo-noir, “Man From Reno,” make an oddball pair of sleuths. Aki Akahori (Ayako Fujitani) is a renowned Japanese mystery writer, nicknamed “the J. D. Salinger of Japan,” hiding out from the paparazzi in San Francisco. Paul Del Moral (Pepe Serna) is the sheriff of the fictional San Marco County, south of the city. The depressed, enigmatic Aki and the grizzled, avuncular Paul don’t meet until an hour into the movie, when he knocks on her hotel door while investigating a murder.

headline: In Bergdahl Case, the Rare Charge of Misbehavior
text: In the military’s case against Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, the charge of desertion, with a maximum penalty of imprisonment for five years, is the lesser count and the easier one to prove, legal experts say.

headline: Review: In ‘The Riot Club,’ an Elite British Dining Club Excels in Debauchery
text: “The Riot Club,” a poisonous satire of Britain’s upper class, adapted from Laura Wade’s play “Posh,” may puncture any lingering fantasies that good breeding is synonymous with noblesse oblige. The small group of rich young men on whom it focuses belong to an Oxford University dining club that has a fabled history of drunken mischief making. As they exercise their privilege at the club’s annual bacchanal, an alternate title for the movie comes to mind: “Boozing and Vomiting.”

headline: Murky Inquiry Targets Critic of N.Y.U. Role in Abu Dhabi, and a Reporter
text: New York University’s fraught tenure as an intellectual prize of the Middle East has taken a new and mysterious turn: A private investigator has been making inquiries about an N.Y.U. professor who criticized the exploitation of migrant workers building the university’s campus in Abu Dhabi.

headline: Yemenis Share Reports, Rumors and Wry Commentary Online as Bombs Drop
text: As soon as the first airstrikes hit Yemen’s capital, Sana, in the early hours of Thursday morning, Yemenis deployed across social networks to share a stream of firsthand reports, images, analysis and wry commentary on the Saudi-led assault.

headline: Review: Bradley Cooper and Jennifer Lawrence Felling Trees in ‘Serena’
text: Bradley Cooper and Jennifer Lawrence will probably get a lot of grief and negative reviews for “Serena,” but this isn’t the kind of fiasco you can entirely pin on its stars. Miscast and misdirected from first ridiculous scene to last, they play George and Serena Pemberton, 1929 glamour-pusses who, soon after the story opens, marry and move to his timber camp. There, he plans to build an empire or dominate nature or something — it’s telling that it is never wholly clear what he has in mind beyond felling trees — while Serena, well, she intends to dominate poor George.

headline: A Dangerous Escalation in Iraq
text: By ordering the bombing of the Iraqi city of Tikrit, President Obama has escalated America’s involvement in the fight against the Islamic State without providing a shred of evidence showing how it could advance American interests, or what happens once the bombs stop falling.

headline: Review: In ‘A Wolf at the Door,’ a Fiery Affair Turns Rancid
text: In the frantic opening scene of the Brazilian filmmaker Fernando Coimbra’s “A Wolf at the Door,” Sylvia (Fabiula Nascimento), a distraught mother whose 6-year-old daughter, Clara, is missing, visits the little girl’s school in a suburb of Rio de Janeiro. A harried official insists that Clara was picked up by a woman the girl appeared to adore.

headline: No Need to Prosecute Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl
text: It won’t be hard for military lawyers to argue that Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl violated military regulations when he slipped out of a remote outpost in Afghanistan in 2009 and became a Taliban prisoner for five years.

headline: After East Village Blast, a Familiar Sight: New Yorkers to the Rescue
text: First there was the smell of gas, then an explosion and a burst of flying glass. Smoke and a hail of hot ash spattered onto the pavement of Second Avenue in the East Village as a red-brick building folded into itself on Thursday afternoon. Flames licked out of some windows, and the bottom floors blew out.

headline: Review: Larry Clark’s ‘Marfa Girl’ Looks at Dysfunction and Desire
text: “Marfa Girl” is the latest exploration — and exploitation — of teenage sexuality from Larry Clark, the photographer and filmmaker who has been splitting the difference between fearless honesty and leering prurience for more than four decades. “Tulsa,” the 1971 book of portraits that made his reputation, still has the power to shock and unsettle with its blunt portrayal of drug use and promiscuity among the provincial American young. But the scandal of Mr. Clark’s more recent movies, including “Wassup Rockers” and “Ken Park” and this new one, resides more in its tedium and lack of insight than its strenuously provocative content.

headline: Man Killed by Bus at Port Authority Terminal
text: A man was struck and killed by a bus at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan on Thursday, officials said, causing extensive delays and evening-rush havoc at the busy station.

headline: Michigan State Acquires a Size Advantage in a Spreadsheet
text: SYRACUSE — As Oklahoma practiced Thursday afternoon, Kevin Pauga pulled out his laptop while he sat courtside.

headline: Post-Sept. 11, Cockpits Are Built to Protect From Outside Threats
text: Although airplane cockpits are supposed to be the last line of defense from outside aggressors, airlines have fewer options if the threat comes from within.

headline: Ferguson Chief Takes Steps Urged in Report
text: FERGUSON, Mo. — Addressing one of the Justice Department’s primary recommendations for the Police Department here, the new acting police chief said on Thursday that he was working to better integrate his officers with the community by putting them on more bike patrols and encouraging them to walk the beat and speak with residents. The efforts pushed by Chief Alan Eickhoff, who took his post a week ago, come even as he conceded that many of his officers were still worried about their safety as anger continues after a white Ferguson police officer fatally shot an unarmed black teenager last August.

headline: Review: In ‘Cupcakes,’ an Impromptu Cellphone Video Is Noticed
text: The gaudy excesses of the annual Eurovision contest have inspired filmmakers before (Farah Khan’s 2014 Bollywood extravaganza, “Happy New Year,” comes to mind), but rarely have they been employed as sure-footedly as in Eytan Fox’s dramedy “Cupcakes.” This candy-coated confection is so irresistible that you’re captivated by its sentiment even as you acknowledge its manipulations.

headline: Review: In ‘Nightlight,’ Fun and Games in a Forest Turn Deadly
text: Into the pantheon of found-footage horror cinema comes “Nightlight,” a spare trifle carried largely by its leading actress. The film begins with a videotaped message from the teenage Ethan (an affecting Kyle Fain) to his parents, talking about his struggles with suicide and his hopes to see Robin (Shelby Young) at a dance. Cut to weeks later, and Robin is joining Nia (Chloe Bridges), Ben (Mitch Hewer), Amelia (Taylor Murphy) and Chris (Carter Jenkins) for a night of fun and games in a forest enclosed by barbed wire.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 26, 2015
text: March 26, 2015

headline: Notre Dame, Again Relying on Its Mental Toughness, Edges Wichita State
text: CLEVELAND — After Thursday night’s game, an 81-70 victory over Wichita State, several of Notre Dame’s tired but satisfied players sat in their locker room watching the tense ending of the Wisconsin-North Carolina matchup.

headline: Q. and A.: Karl E. Meyer and Shareen Blair Brysac on ‘The China Collectors’
text: Karl E. Meyer and Shareen Blair Brysac have written a rollicking account of the acquisition of Chinese art and antiquities by Americans who came to China in the 19th and 20th centuries and took back vast collections from caves, palaces and the back rooms of dealers in Beijing. In “The China Collectors: America’s Century-Long Hunt for Asian Art Treasures,” the authors describe how lovers of Chinese art roamed the country hunting for sculptures, wall panels, furniture, porcelain and paintings that are now housed in important museums in the United States. Some of the artworks they tried to send back were ruined in the process.

headline: Review: Attacca Quartet Serves Up John Adams, With Dance as a Side Dish
text: The Attacca Quartet, the string ensemble in residence at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, played a robust, gripping concert of music by John Adams on Tuesday. The program paired Mr. Adams’s 2008 “String Quartet” with selections from “John’s Book of Alleged Dances” from 1994. Mr. Adams was present, as were 17 dancers. But the choreography they performed, by Francesca Harper, was so flimsy and poorly constructed that the fanciful title of Mr. Adams’s music remained descriptive. Whether the pieces should even count as dances stayed in doubt.

headline: Off to Space for a Year, an American’s Longest Journey
text: The New York Times provided live updates about the launch.

headline: Review: ‘Killing Jesus,’ Biblical Tale Retold, Softer on Its Politics
text: If you’re a devotee of a particular religion, you probably don’t want the story on which its whole belief system rests told by someone facing challenges to his credibility. But that’s not even the main problem with “Killing Jesus,” which has its premiere Sunday on the National Geographic Channel and is based on a book by Martin Dugard and the embattled Bill O’Reilly. The main problem is that this three-hour affair is unrelentingly drab. The program dramatizes the life of Jesus, culminating, of course, in his crucifixion. Mr. O’Reilly and Mr. Dugard turned the tale into a best seller in 2013 with “Killing Jesus: A History,” part of a franchise that has also seen them kill Presidents Abraham Lincoln and John F. Kennedy and Gen. George S. Patton.

headline: A Policy Puzzle of U.S. Goals and Alliances in the Middle East
text: WASHINGTON — Already struggling to navigate the chaos engulfing much of the Middle East, the United States is now dipping its toe into another conflict.

headline: Having Some Strings Attached
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — At first, I thought this was a puzzle about punctuation. That, of course, turned out to be wrong.

headline: Review: ‘New York Spring Spectacular’ Barrels Into Radio City
text: Well, at least the Rockettes get to take the final bow.

headline: Jailhouse Informant Points to Alternate Suspect at Patz Trial
text: A jailhouse informant provided dramatic testimony on Thursday about an alternate suspect in the 1979 disappearance of 6-year-old Etan Patz.

headline: Francis C. Rooney Jr. Dies at 93; Turned Melville Into a Retail Giant
text: Francis C. Rooney Jr., who as chief executive of the Melville Corporation transformed it from a shoe company into a retail behemoth embracing CVS, Thom McAn and Marshall’s, died on Tuesday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 93.

headline: A Giant, Upset, Lifts No. 1 Wisconsin Over North Carolina
text: LOS ANGELES — With a little over 11 minutes left in the first West Regional semifinal Thursday, the North Carolina sophomore forward Isaiah Hicks inadvertently woke the slumping giant. Battling for a rebound under the Tar Heels’ basket, Hicks tangled with Frank Kaminsky, Wisconsin’s standout 7-foot forward.

headline: Rev. Lyle E. Schaller Dies at 91; Helped Protestant Churches Survive and Grow
text: The Rev. Lyle E. Schaller, whose half-century of practical advice on how Protestant congregations could grow — from installing air-conditioning to encouraging pastors to critique their videotaped sermons — made him the nation’s dean of church consultants, died on March 18 in Oklahoma City. He was 91.

headline: Chase Headley Is Playing Plenty, but He’s Begging for More Work
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Third base is a position known as the hot corner, where it helps to be as quick as a lizard’s tongue and blessed with a razor-sharp attention span since you never know when a line drive will come screaming at you.

headline: Cuomo and Lawmakers Appear Near to Ethics Reform Deal
text: ALBANY — As Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and lawmakers race to finish the state budget by the April 1 deadline, they appear close to an agreement on ethics policies that would increase what legislators have to disclose about the money they make on top of their government salaries.

headline: A Team Effort for Health
text: At Iora Health, doctors, nurses and health coaches share the responsibilities of looking after patients.

headline: Taking to Twitter, Iran’s President Argues for Rapid End to Sanctions
text: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — While American negotiators maintained tight secrecy at the nuclear talks here, President Hassan Rouhani of Iran took to Twitter late Thursday to describe a letter he sent to President Obama and other world leaders justifying Iran’s positions.

headline: Long Line of Suitors for New York State’s $5.4 Billion Windfall
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has called the money “a gift from above”: more than $5 billion in settlement payments from financial institutions that is padding the state’s coffers.

headline: John F. Burns, Pulitzer Prize-Winning Journalist, Ends Acclaimed Run
text: With an article about the reburial of Richard III, John F. Burns concludes a distinguished career spanning 40 years with The New York Times, 39 of them with the international desk. Beginning with South Africa in 1976, Mr. Burns reported from 10 foreign bureaus and was chief of the Baghdad bureau during the American invasion and occupation of Iraq. Along the way, he wrote more than 3,300 articles and collected two Pulitzer Prizes for International Reporting, one in Afghanistan and the other in Bosnia. His portrait of a cellist playing on Sarajevo’s main pedestrian concourse while artillery shells exploded nearby is considered a classic of modern journalism. He will continue to contribute to the international and sports desks, among others.

headline: Sudan Joins Coalition Against Yemen Rebels
text: UNITED NATIONS — It is an awkward moment.

headline: Louisville’s Rick Pitino Defends Syracuse’s Jim Boeheim
text: SYRACUSE, N.Y. — Louisville Coach Rick Pitino, a former assistant to Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim, defended the embattled Boeheim on Thursday before Pitino’s fourth-seeded Cardinals practiced for their East Regional game Friday against No. 8-seeded North Carolina State in Syracuse.

headline: Coach K Will Win and Lose
text: HOUSTON — Coach K wants Duke to beat Utah. Coach K also wants Utah to beat Duke. No matter what happens, Coach K will be pleased.

headline: Deputies Said to Taunt Prisoners
text: San Francisco’s public defender called on Thursday for an independent investigation into the Sheriff’s Department after accusations that four deputies forced prisoners to engage in “gladiator-style fights” for their own amusement.

headline: President of Argentina Won’t Face Charges
text: BUENOS AIRES — An Argentine appellate court dismissed a criminal case Thursday against President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner and her political supporters that accused them of conspiring to hide Iranian officials’ involvement in a bombing here in 1994.

headline: U.S. and Syria Discuss Missing Journalist
text: The United States and Syrian governments are engaged in direct talks concerning the whereabouts of Austin Tice, an American freelance journalist and photographer who disappeared in Syria more than two and a half years ago in the midst of the country’s widening civil war, a State Department official and Mr. Tice’s father said Thursday.

headline: The Sequence Of Destruction Of Three East Village Buildings
text: The fire started at 121 2nd Ave., set off by by a possible gas explosion in a restaurant where plumbing and gas work was being done.

headline: U.N. Middle East Peace Envoy Urges Security Council to Revive Talks
text: UNITED NATIONS — The departing United Nations envoy for the Middle East peace process said Thursday that Israel’s policy of building settlements in the Palestinian territories “may kill” any chance of peace, as he nudged the Security Council to step in and revive talks that were halted last year.

headline: An American With Ebola Is Improving
text: An American aid worker being treated for Ebola at the National Institutes of Health clinical center in Maryland is doing better and has been upgraded from critical to serious condition, the N.I.H. announced Thursday. The patient, who worked with the American charity Partners in Health in Sierra Leone, was transferred to the United States on March 13. A Sierra Leonean colleague who also contracted Ebola in March has recovered and was discharged from a treatment unit, said Dr. Adikali Kamara, a district medical officer in Sierra Leone. People who came into contact with the two men, including more than a dozen Americans who were evacuated in several groups to the United States, are still being monitored for symptoms.

headline: Shooting Oysters in Northeast London
text: The term “happy hour” takes on a maritime meaning at the Richmond, the latest in a line of modern neighborhood restaurants turning the indistinct northeast London district of Haggerston into an unlikely but legitimate food destination. Come 5 p.m. every weekday, and 3 p.m. on weekends, fresh oysters here — the East End’s first raw bar — are an attainable £1 a pop. It’s the latest venture from the stylist Mags Crow and the Australian chef Brett Redman, who has been awarded a triumvirate of Michelin Bib Gourmands (rewarding exceptional food at modest prices) for the well-loved Elliot’s Cafe in Borough Market.

headline: Mark Haddawy’s True West
text: As he did with fashion — making us see vintage clothing as valuable — so he does with architecture. The purist would no sooner tweak a Halston gown than alter a great ’70s house. Even one he lives in.

headline: What the First Mixologist Honored by the James Beard Foundation Is Drinking Now
text: This May, the James Beard Foundation will induct Dale DeGroff, 66, into its Who’s Who of Food & Beverage in America. Often credited as the grandfather of the modern cocktail revival, his trailblazing cocktail menu for the 1987 reopening of New York’s Rainbow Room brought back to life the works of pre-Prohibition bartenders like “Professor” Jerry Thomas.

headline: Gerald and Betty Ford’s Restoration Politics
text: The Continental chic of Camelot in the ’60s, the gilded splendor of the Reagan-era ’80s — but what about a new take on the unique charms of Gerald and Betty Ford’s ’70s Southern California dreaming? Here’s looking at the most truly American of styles.

headline: Word of the Day | bevy
text: bevy • \ˈbe-ve\ • noun

headline: North Korea Claims to Have Arrested Two Spies From South
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Friday that it had arrested two South Korean men on espionage charges for collecting military and other secrets on the isolated country, including data regarding its top leadership, and infiltrating it with political propaganda and subversive religious materials.

headline: After a Bold Forecast, West Virginia Is Blown Away by Kentucky
text: CLEVELAND — On Wednesday afternoon, the day before his team was to play West Virginia, John Calipari walked into the Kentucky locker room after practice and delivered an important message with a tone of levity. He had heard about the comments made by West Virginia’s freshman guard Daxter Miles Jr., who predicted that the Mountaineers would end Kentucky’s unbeaten streak.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
text: 12 A.M. (Comedy Central) PINEAPPLE EXPRESS (2008) Seth Rogen and Evan Goldberg (“Superbad”) wrote this comic stoner caper directed by David Gordon Green. Mr. Rogen stars as Dale Denton, a process server who loves to smoke weed to escape the tedium of his life. He witnesses a murder while smoking a joint of rare marijuana and throws it out the window of his car in a rush to flee the scene. He goes to see his dealer, Saul (James Franco), and they become paranoid that the killer (Gary Cole) will be able to identify him as the witness because of the distinct pot he had been carrying. Off they run, without confirming that they are being pursued. Danny McBride plays an eccentric, backstabbing, midlevel drug dealer, and Rosie Perez portrays a crooked cop conspiring with the murderer. And a strain of pot is named “Spanish trampoline.” Writing about the film in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said, “In the tradition of Cheech and Chong, Abbott and Costello, Hope and Crosby, Ricky and Lucy, Martin and Lewis, Rowan and Martin, Smothers and Smothers, Sanford and son, Spicoli and Hand, Bert and Ernie, Riggs and Murtaugh, cops and robbers, dumb and dumber, right brain and left, peanut butter and jelly, bong hit, roach clip and Snoop Doggy Dogg comes ‘Pineapple Express,’ a stoner comedy that partakes of a gentle indie vibe before hitting the hard stuff for a major Shane Black-style blowup and meltdown.”

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: March 27
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of a carillon player, the No. 7 train in Queens, and the library in Gloversville, N.Y.

headline: Arizona Beats Xavier, Setting Up Rematch With Wisconsin in Regional Final
text: LOS ANGELES — In a tournament in which one loss means elimination, Arizona’s situation is as close as a team can get to a do-over.

headline: Family Searches for Missing Son After Blast in the East Village
text: Nicholas Figueroa went on a lunchtime date to a restaurant where an explosion severely damaged several buildings along an East Village block on Thursday. He has not been heard from since, said his family, which was frantically searching for him early Friday.

headline: Corrections: March 27, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “The interpretation we can give at this time is that the co-pilot, through a deliberate act, refused to open the door of the cockpit to the commander, and activated the button that commands the loss of altitude.”

headline: Documenting the Blues in the Mississippi Delta
text: The urgent need to preserve a cornerstone of American culture led folklorists like John Lomax to travel the country documenting early blues recordings and writers like Amiri Baraka to publish “Blues People: Negro Music in White America.” Although Margo Cooper did not know it when she began more than 20 years ago, she has followed that tradition and produced a documentary project that archives the oral and visual histories of blues musicians, their families and communities in northern Mississippi and the Delta.

headline: Cause of Financial Crisis
text: To the Editor:

headline: New York, a ‘Famously Secular City,’ Is Also Religious
text: To the Editor:

headline: Anti-Semitism: Its Roots, and How to Respond
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Field Is Flat
text: Like a lot of people who pay attention to such things, I had assumed that Democrats had a huge advantage going into next year’s presidential race. Democrats do really well among the growing demographic groups, like Hispanics, single people and the young. Republicans, meanwhile, do doing sensationally well with just about every shrinking group. If 67-year-old rural white men were the future of the electorate, the G.O.P. would be rolling.

headline: Mornings in Blue America
text: Two impossible things happened to the U.S. economy over the course of the past year — or at least they were supposed to be impossible, according to the ideology that dominates half our political spectrum. First, remember how Obamacare was supposed to be a gigantic job killer? Well, in the first year of the Affordable Care Act’s full implementation, the U.S. economy as a whole added 3.3 million jobs — the biggest gain since the 1990s. Second, half a million of those jobs were added in California, which has taken the lead in job creation away from Texas.

headline: Critiquing How Cuomo Rates Teachers
Give Breast Milk
text: I PRODUCED more than 2,500 ounces of surplus breast milk with my first son. I am almost six months postpartum with my second child, and already my freezers are stuffed with five-ounce bags of milk. Some women are computer programmers or impressive cooks. I’m good at producing breast milk. My friends and family marvel at this talent, sort of. They like to joke that I could make real money if I sold it.

headline: Test Yourself | A YouTube Star Leaps From the Screen to the Page
text: Here are several paragraphs from a March 25 article, “YouTube’s ‘Sunshine Girl’ Comes to Print.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Germanwings Co-Pilot, Andreas Lubitz, Deliberately Crashed Plane, Prosecutor Says
text: In “Germanwings Co-Pilot, Andreas Lubitz, Deliberately Crashed Plane, Prosecutor Says,” Nicola Clark, Dan Bilefsky and Aurelien Breeden report on the crash of Germanwings flight 9525.

headline: As Reid Exits, Schumer Sees Door Opening
text: WASHINGTON — Around 8 p.m. Thursday, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the minority leader, called Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York into his office with news that would stun Washington the next morning: Mr. Reid planned to retire at the end of his term.

headline: Is There Anything UConn Can’t Do? Tweet, for One
text: STORRS, Conn. — On Oct. 14, the day before their first practice of the season, several Connecticut women’s basketball players sent similar messages to their Twitter followers. The words differed, but the meaning was the same.

headline: Chad Strongman Says Nigeria Is Absent in Fight Against Boko Haram
text: NDJAMENA, Chad — Chad’s president, Idriss Déby, speaks in a soft mumble, wears spectacles and an immaculate white robe, and is to be found in the quiet inner recesses of a gilt-edged, marble presidential palace — under crystal chandeliers and vaulted arches that seem part Renaissance, part Vegas — at the dusty center of his country’s capital.

headline: As ‘Mad Men’ Comes to an End, Jon Hamm Reflects on Don Draper
text: It’s not only the 1960s that will come to an end when “Mad Men” reaches its conclusion on May 17, but also a chapter of television history. Since its debut in 2007, this influential period drama has shaped our present while turning its lens on the past: The series, which returns for its final seven episodes on April 5, has helped to revive the fashion and pop culture of a tumultuous decade, while also reminding viewers of the racism, sexism and selfishness that was endemic to one of the most picked-over eras in American history.

headline: Bronx Science Teacher in Child Pornography Case Told Students ‘You’re a Big Deal’
text: A trophy case framed in brass, set inside a wall near the entrance to the Bronx High School of Science, testified to the triumph of the school’s debate team. So did classroom 203, the de facto debate headquarters, where the sunlight danced off a collection of plaques and trophies.

headline: In Silicon Valley, Auto Racing Becomes a Favorite Hobby for Tech Elites
text: When you get past the noise and the smell, the unbearable heat, the G-force, the surprising physical exertion and, always, the constant threat of injury or death — auto racing, like much else, comes down to math. There is an optimal path around a racetrack, a geometric arc of least resistance. It is the driver’s job to find this sweet spot of physics and stick to it, lap after lap, as consistently as a microprocessor crunching through an algorithm.

headline: Kamala Harris, California’s Attorney General, Leaps to Forefront of Senate Race
text: CASTAIC, Calif. — When Kamala D. Harris, a Democrat, was the newly elected district attorney of San Francisco in 2004, she walked into a firestorm after deciding not to pursue the death penalty for a man accused in the killing of a police officer — drawing attacks from law enforcement leaders and even Senator Dianne Feinstein, one of the most respected Democrats in the state.

headline: Does Your School Do a Good Job of Teaching Sex Ed?
text: The way schools teach sex education varies widely across the country and the world. Some programs exclusively teach abstinence until marriage. Others emphasize the dangers of sexual activity, such as venereal diseases. Some classes foster more open conversations about sexual decision-making and sexuality.

headline: R.B.S. Agrees to Sell International Arm of Coutts Private Banking Unit
text: LONDON — The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Friday that it had agreed to sell the international operations of its Coutts & Company private banking business to the Swiss private bank Union Bancaire Privée.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Upbeat Emotions, Male Nurses and Whiter Teeth
text: Take the Quiz

headline: House Tour | The Ford House
text: The new homeowners discuss renovating Gerald and Betty Ford’s former home in Rancho Mirage, California.

headline: Co-Pilot in Germanwings Crash Hid Mental Illness From Employer, Authorities Say
text: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — Andreas Lubitz, the pilot at the controls of the Germanwings jetliner that crashed into the French Alps on Tuesday, had a mental illness but kept the diagnosis hidden from his employer, the authorities said Friday.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Ask Well: Does Kinesiology Tape Really Work?
text: Question:

headline: New York Today: After the Fire
text: Good morning on this drizzly Friday.At least two people are unaccounted for this morning, including a 23-year-old man, after Thursday’s explosion, fire and building collapse in the East Village, the police said.

headline: Losing the Plot
text: “I have a plot problem,” Heidi Julavits said in a recent email interview. “I’ve been joking for years that I have to check into the Betty Ford Clinic for plot addicts. I can’t seem to access an imaginative world without instantly building into it a complicated mechanism of psychological and dramatic causality. And I wanted to learn a new way to move through a book.”

headline: ‘The Folded Clock,’ by Heidi Julavits
text: The self, a friend once informed me, is an illusion. We were 19 at the time, and he was reading Foucault, but that was 18 years ago, and now he doesn’t think he understood Foucault back then. “It’s real,” my friend says of the self, “but it’s made.”

headline: ‘The Boatmaker,’ by John Benditt
text: Spare and solemn as a parable, John Benditt’s powerful first novel begins simply, with a man and a woman and a child in a little wooden house on remote, windswept Small Island. The man is feverish, dreaming of himself as a boy, walking toward a towering oak tree, its leaves rustling in the breeze. “Everything else is quiet; no insects or birds are singing. It’s high summer, the time of afternoon when the sun stands still and everything hushes. Even the sea.” If “The Boat­maker” were a film, Sven Nykvist would be its only possible cinematographer.

headline: Daily Report: Live-Streaming Apps Aspire to Be Next Big Thing in Social Media
text: Periscope, a live-streaming video app that Twitter introduced on Thursday, is one among a surge of such apps with names like Meerkat and Camio that are taking the social media world by storm, Mike Issac and Vindu Goel report.

headline: Financial Conduct Authority Made a ‘Serious Error’ on Insurance Review, Panel Says
text: LONDON — The Financial Conduct Authority of Britain made a “serious error” in providing an exclusive briefing to a newspaper reporter last year on its plans to review the life insurance industry, and in not responding quickly after the report inadvertently sent British insurance stocks down sharply, a parliamentary committee said on Friday.

headline: Republicans Have Little to Fear From a Divisive Primary
text: Will the fight for the G.O.P. presidential nomination be Hillary Clinton’s secret weapon in the 2016 election? Not according to the best political science research.

headline: In the Hills of Sri Lanka’s Tea Country
text: The man in the khaki vest slurped noisily from his cup, descended briefly into scowling meditation, spat the contents into a sink and then unleashed a torrent of approving descriptors, lavishly rolling his r’s along the way: “No foreign taste, very refreshing, robust, strong tannins, a tingly sensation at the end of the tongue — good show!”

headline: Re: The Reach
text: Is the death-defying free-solo rock climber Alex Honnold, who appeared on the cover of our March 15 issue, really the insane daredevil that so many people made him out to be? “Life is defined by risk,” wrote Ernieh1, in Queens, on The New York Times’s site. “Every time you enter a crosswalk at a busy time of day, you take a risk.”

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Gel Manicures
text: I wore less makeup when I was a makeup artist than at any other time in my life. In beauty school, they asked us to arrive wearing none at all, so that we could practice the day’s lessons on one another’s faces. Nail polish was frowned upon, too, because it flaked and chipped; the odds that clients would inhale runaway polish were high. Later, when I found work, the hassle of making early-morning call times in the strangest locations (4 a.m. on a small Ontario farm, 6 a.m. at an abandoned church in the heart of downtown Toronto) made my own appearance seem inconsequential. The years I spent helping other people look their best were years I looked my worst: purple bags under my eyes and sallow complexion. But more than anything else, I hated the look of my bare nails as I smoothed creams onto a client’s face.

headline: How to Find a Message in a Bottle
text: Sean Smyth has found six messages in bottles, or M.I.B.s, in the argot of serious beachcombers. Five were typical, tossed-from-a-cruise-ship messages along the lines of “Hi, my name is Dave. If you find this note, email me and tell me where it turned up.” But one green wine bottle contained a rambling love poem written by a man who apparently drank the bottle’s contents first. “That’s the only one I kept,” says Smyth, a helicopter pilot who shuttles miners and oil workers to remote locations between Vancouver, British Columbia, and Nome, Alaska.

headline: ‘Mercy’
text: “Mercy” is full of echoes: the subtle repetition of sounds, alliteration and rhyme, and the repetition of image and action — what is taught, learned, passed down. The hinge in the middle of the poem’s one long sentence opens a space in which to contemplate what such legacies mean. Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

headline: Bruce Bochy Won’t Let Success Go to His Head
text: Five years ago, you had been a manager for 15 years and had never won a World Series. Now you’ve won three, you have the most wins of any active manager and you’re probably going to the Hall of Fame. How is life different? Not much. My wife still tells me to take the trash out. I guess she finds a way to make sure I stay humble.

headline: Taxi Driver
text: The minute we got into the taxi, I had a bad feeling. It wasn’t because the driver asked me impatiently to buckle the kid’s safety belt after I already had, or because he muttered something that sounded like a curse when I said we wanted to go to Ramat Gan. I take a lot of taxis, so I’m used to the tempers, the impatience, the armpit stains. But there was something about the way that driver spoke, half-violent and half on the verge of tears, that made me uncomfortable.

headline: Out of Debtors’ Prison, With Law as the Key
text: When Jack Dawley returned in 2007 to his hometown, Norwalk, Ohio, after eight years in prison and on parole in Wisconsin, he knew getting by would be difficult. He had a felony conviction and a history of past drug and alcohol abuse, although he’d been sober since 1999. He was unprepared for another obstacle, however: A few years later, he would keep landing in debtors’ prison.

headline: The End of the Slave Trade
text: Even in the final months of the Civil War, Southern whites were buying and selling human beings.

headline: ‘My Documents,’ by Alejandro Zambra
text: “My Documents” is the Chilean ­writer Alejandro Zambra’s first collection of short stories and at the same time his longest book to date — at 240-odd ­pages, it’s a veritable tome next to “Bonsai” (2008, 86 pages), “The Private Lives of Trees” (2010, 98 pages) and “Ways of Going Home” (2013, 160 pages). These slight, ­intimate novels created a stir when they appeared in English, attracting readers who appreciated their meshing of ­Barthesian inquiry with the muffled malaise of daily life in post-Pinochet Chile. Their chronicles of diffident romances or precarious domestic arrangements set the stage for intensely affecting examinations of the mechanics of fiction.

headline: Student Crossword | Women’s Suffrage
text: Test your knowledge of the history of the women’s suffrage movement by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Stampede at Hindu Bathing Ritual in Bangladesh Kills at Least 10
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — At least 10 Hindu pilgrims were killed and dozens more were injured 12 miles southeast of the Bangladeshi capital, Dhaka, on Friday when an annual bathing ritual turned into a stampede, the police said.

headline: Morning Agenda: The Fine Print in the Heinz-Kraft Deal
text: THE FINE PRINT IN THE HEINZ-KRAFT DEAL | H.J. Heinz’s takeover of Kraft Foods in a stock and cash dividend deal is “odd,”  contends Steven Davidoff Solomon in the Deal Professor column. In part, that’s because Heinz is a private company so knowing how to value its stock is a tricky exercise. Heinz’s owners — Warren E. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway and the Brazilian investment firm 3G Capital – have, he writes, “the best knowledge, and in some cases, the only knowledge, on Heinz’s value.”

headline: ‘Washington’s Revolution,’ by Robert Middlekauff
text: Robert Middlekauff, the distinguished historian of colonial and early America, has already written about the American Revolution in his 1982 book “The Glorious Cause,” the first volume of the ­Oxford History of the United States. Now he turns to the war’s most famous figure. George Washington was commander in chief of the American Army for almost the whole of the war (1775-83). He served at a time when there was no executive branch of government, only a one-house ­Congress to guide him. He had ­direct ­command of the war’s central theater, from coastal New ­England to Philadelphia, and he was in at the death at Yorktown. The title of Middlekauff’s new book thus has two meanings: “Washington’s Revolution” is a story of the war from one man’s point of view, as well as an account of a conflict that was that man’s to win or lose.

headline: Kent Russell’s ‘I Am Sorry to Think I Have Raised a Timid Son’
text: A book of essays can be a constellation. Individual pieces shine like stars, but to see the whole project as a unified thing requires a mythology. You need faith to make out a shape around all those dots of light, to believe in the bear or the swan.

headline: Harry Reid to Retire From Senate in 2016
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Harry Reid, the tough tactician who has led Senate Democrats since 2005, will not seek re-election next year, bringing an end to a three-decade congressional career that culminated in his push of President Obama’s ambitious agenda against fierce Republican resistance.

headline: ‘The Upstairs Wife,’ by Rafia Zakaria
text: In the mid-1950s, when the Pakistani prime minister Mohammad Ali Bogra falls in love with his secretary, it occurs to him that according to the Islamic principles on which his country is governed, he would be legally within his rights should he take a second (or even a third and fourth) wife. What he doesn’t calculate, however, are the social consequences of bigamy. His decision to remarry so infuriates his first wife, Hamida Bogra, that she initiates a women’s rights campaign calling for reforms in marriage law.

headline: Star-Struck
text: A TOUCH OF STARDUST

headline: What’s at Stake in the Iran Negotiations
text: Can the West trust Iran? Can Iran trust the West? A look at the bet each side is making in the nuclear talks, along with the challenges and risks that they face.

headline: A Small Protest Movement Again Picks Up Steam
text: As the six-month anniversary of the start of the Occupy Central protests nears, the encampment around government offices has slowly expanded.

headline: Today in Politics: Marathon Vote a Challenge for Senators Thinking About 2016
text: Good Friday morning from Washington. Jeb Bush’s aides are mulling a new data strategy, while Hillary Rodham Clinton is building up her communications team. Ending a week that included the first presidential announcement, we reminisce about Ted Cruz’s old debate days. Meanwhile, members of Congress will most likely start the weekend groggy from a marathon “vote-orama.” Finally, Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, says he will not seek re-election in 2016.

text: São Paulo, Brazil

headline: Company Thinks It Has Answer for Lower Health Costs: Customer Service
text: Virginnia Schock seemed headed for a health crisis. She was 64 years old, had poorly controlled diabetes, a wound on her foot and a cast on her broken wrist. She didn’t drive, so getting to the people who could tend to her ailments was complicated and expensive. She had stopped taking her diabetes pills months before and was reluctant to use insulin; she was afraid of needles and was worried that a friend’s son, a drug addict, might use her syringes to inject them.

headline: Fancy Nancy Lands a TV Deal With Disney
text: LOS ANGELES – With her big-screen debut stalled, Fancy Nancy will instead try her luck on a small one.

headline: Milton Glaser on Starting New York Magazine, the Serendipity of ‘I Heart NY’ and Selling His First Nudes
text: The sign above the door to Milton Glaser’s Manhattan studio reads “Art is Work,” and for good reason. For the past 60-plus years, 50 of which he’s spent in the same office in Murray Hill, the influential graphic designer has made it his business to give visual identity to the very ideas that have shaped our culture — his sprawling body of work includes both the ever-present “I ♥ NY” logo and a psychedelia-inspired Bob Dylan poster that’s been a dorm-room staple since 1966. Now 85, Glaser invited T into his studio to discuss the early days of New York magazine, the origins of “I ♥ NY” and his lasting impact as a champion of ethical design.

headline: Six Months Later, Small Protest Camp Grows Again in Hong Kong
text: After workers under police watch dismantled the main camp of Hong Kong pro-democracy protesters in the Admiralty district in December, a small number of holdouts vowed to fight on.

headline: Video: The Iran Nuclear Talks, and a Matter of Trust
text: Before dawn on a freezing February morning, Amar Bakshi watched as a crane lifted a gold-colored shipping container off a flatbed truck outside the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven, Conn. As diplomats consider a deal over Iran’s nuclear program, the shipping container is Mr. Bakshi’s attempt at restoring a relationship with that country.

headline: ‘The Great Leader and the Fighter Pilot,’ by Blaine Harden
text: Gordon G. Chang is the author of ­“Nuclear Showdown: North Korea Takes On the World,” among other books.

text: Dow Chemical on Friday took another step to streamline itself in the face of pressure from the activist investor Daniel S. Loeb, agreeing to separate its chlorine business and merge it with the Olin Corporation, another chemical company.

headline: Thomas McGuane’s ‘Crow Fair’
text: Imagine your hands are trapped in a viscous tarlike substance. How do you get free? Every effort to push and pull embeds you deeper. Eventually, exhausted, you get sucked in all the way and die like an animal in quicksand — unless you’re Thomas McGuane, author of the new story collection “Crow Fair.”

headline: Hey, Man, Dig the Crazy Hippie Flicks ‘The Wild Angels’ and ‘Psych-Out’
text: American International Pictures, the studio that pioneered the low-budget drive-in fare of the 1950s, specialized in two genres: horror films and youth pictures. Often, the two modes were conflated. In 1957, AIP unleashed “I Was a Teenage Werewolf”; in 1966, the studio brought forth “The Wild Angels.”

headline: Economy Grew 2.2% in 4th Quarter, Final Estimate Shows
text: The United States economy grew at a rate of slightly more than 2 percent as 2014 drew to a close, but economists fear some of that momentum flagged in the first quarter of this year.

headline: An Interesting Theory About the Shoe Bubble, Courtesy of Jimmy Choo
text: I defy anyone these days not to go to one of the megaliths that masquerade as the shoe floor of a department store (Harrods’ 42,000 square feet of shoe space, say, or Macy’s 63,000, or the Level Shoe District in Dubai’s 96,000) and scratch her head in amazement at the sheer number of shoes in the world, followed shortly thereafter by the corollary question: Can there really be that many shoe consumers?

headline: Inside the List
text: The Naughty Bits: “Anna was a good wife, mostly.” That’s the irresistible first sentence of Jill Alexander Essbaum’s debut novel, “Hausfrau,” which recounts the tawdry affairs of a bored housewife in Switzerland (you thought I was going to say Russia, didn’t you?); it enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 16. Essbaum was a poet before she was a novelist, and she’s no stranger to the naughty bits. Her poem “On Reading Poorly Transcribed Erotica” — collected in David Lehman’s 2008 anthology “The Best American Erotic Poems: From 1800 to the Present” — begins like this: “She stood before him wearing only pantries / and he groped for her Volvo under the gauze.” In the contributors’ notes to that volume, asked to name her favorite steamy reading material, Essbaum recalls a childhood appreciation for Harold Robbins and Nancy Friday before finally settling on the Bible. “A voluptuous buffet of bawd!” she declares, singling out passages from the Song of Solomon (of course) and Jeremiah (“Thou hast played the harlot with many lovers,” Jeremiah 3:1). “But for my favorite perverse verse,” she concludes, “I’m keen to point to one that — were I equally inclined and indecorous — I might assign to particularize my own prickly proclivities: ‘There she lusted after her lovers, whose genitals were like those of donkeys and whose emission was like that of horses’ (Ezekiel 23:20). Preach it, sister!” In other words: The Bible is a Good Book, mostly.

headline: Should We Keep a Low Profile in Space?
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — For more than a half-century, a small group of astronomers has sought intelligent company among the stars. They’ve done so by turning large radio antennas skyward, hoping to eavesdrop on signals from an advanced society. It’s a program known as SETI, the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence.

headline: Review: ‘On the Nature of Things,’ Karole Armitage’s New Dance Work
text: Some dances aim to entertain, some to tell a story or make a point or transport a viewer with beauty. The goal of “On the Nature of Things,” the latest work by the choreographer Karole Armitage, is to fundamentally alter human behavior and save the world.

headline: 1890: Strange Case of Lunacy
text: The pont de la Concorde was on Wednesday [March 26] the scene of a ‘‘bataille de dames’’ which had for its outcome the removal of one of the combattants to the Dépôt infirmary. The lady is the sister-in-law of a well known French general. On Wednesday evening, Mme. L. went for a drive, wearing over her dress a broad tricolored sash. As the carriage was passing across the pont de la Concorde, Mme. L. jumped out, and, going up to a lady pedestrian, snatched the latter’s umbrella from her hand and broke it over her head. The lady attacked defended herself to the best of her power, but she had been rather severely handled ere the police came up and dragged Mme. L. off. At the Dépôt, Mme. L. declared that she was Joan of Arc, and had been sent back into the world in the flesh to liberate her country a second time. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 28, 1890

headline: Toshio Shibata’s Mesmerizing Photographs of Water

For the later half of his almost-40-year career in photography, he has explored this relationship in novel ways, hiding horizon lines and taking the perspective of the water itself with his camera, visually evoking its rushing sound.

headline: Milton Glaser’s Legacy
text: Milton Glaser, one of the world’s most celebrated graphic designers, may also be its most iconic. The illustrator, 85, established a cult following in the ’60s and ’70s with his now-ubiquitous “I ♥ NY” logo and as the co-founder of both New York magazine and the influential design firm Push Pin Studios, though his reach extends far beyond the Empire State. A classically trained artist who studied under the painter Giorgio Morandi, Glaser creates instantly recognizable images — like the psychedelic silhouette he made of Bob Dylan in 1966 — that blur the line between fine art and graphic design. He has conceived book jackets for Philip Roth, album covers for Nina Simone and branding for the Winter Olympics, and in 2009, he became the first graphic designer to receive the National Medal of the Arts. Here, a look at the indelible mark of Manhattan’s most colorful campaigner.

headline: As Job Rate Rises, Older Workers Are Often Left Behind
text: THOMAS R. COLLINS, 66, a former sheriff’s deputy, takes little comfort in the lower national unemployment rate because, like many older workers, he has had a long spell of joblessness since he retired in 2010.

headline: Tips for the Future Care of Disabled Family Members
text: Christine Salerno is like many other single working mothers with small children, but her days are often packed with even more emotional highs and lows: Her 4-year-old daughter, Lily, with soft brown eyes and a wide smile, was found to have Rett syndrome, a rare neurological disorder, last year.

headline: Add Uncertainty to Your Financial Plans
text: Human beings don’t like uncertainty, especially when we’re contemplating our financial futures. It’s not enough for us to think that we’ll have enough money to send our kids to college, or to retire. We want to know exactly how much money we’ll need to achieve those goals — and precisely how we’re going to get it.

headline: German Court Upholds Bequest of Gurlitt Collection to the Kunstmuseum Bern
text: A Munich court has struck down a legal challenge by a cousin of Cornelius Gurlitt who claimed that she should inherit works from his vast art collection. Mr. Gurlitt had bequeathed the works to the Kunstmuseum Bern in Switzerland, and the court ruled that they rightfully belong there.

headline: 1940: Crew Not Guilty of Mutiny
text: BORDEAUX – Thirty-nine members of the crew of the French freighter Winnipeg were absolved of charges of mutiny today [March 27] by a maritime court which deliberated forty-five minutes before giving its decision. ‘‘Much ado about nothing,’’ one of the defense lawyers characterized the two-day trial, and apparently the judges agreed with him. The crew members, who had been held in prison three months, were accused of mutiny after they refused to sail for France from a South American port on the first day of the war. ‘‘The case was born of an excited imagination,’’ said M. de Moro-Giafferi. ‘‘The crew has been imprisoned and slandered when all that the men wanted was an equitable judgment. The sailors maintained that they had not mutinied, but had refused to leave port under their captain, whom they considered irresponsible. Several testified they had heard the captain threaten to ‘‘run his ship aground and demolish it.’’ Politics or war conditions had nothing to do with the refusal, according to the crew. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 28, 1940

headline: A New View for NYTimes Photos
text: The New York Times loves photos. We publish around 700 images every single day. These run the gamut from delectable dessert close-ups to evidence of the ravaging effects of climate change. Photos are an important part of our journalism and the stories we tell.

headline: A Radish and Herb Salad That’s on the Cutting Edge

text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has just released all 20 episodes of the first season of “The Artist Project,” a web series in which 100 contemporary artists respond to the museum’s vast collection, using video voice-overs of about three minutes each.

headline: Campaign Money Tests Wisconsin Justices’ Impartiality
text: MADISON, Wis. — In an off year for major elections in Wisconsin, one race in 2011 unexpectedly turned into a full-blown battle: David Prosser, a Supreme Court justice seen as part of the court’s conservative majority, was fighting for his seat against a more liberal opponent, JoAnne Kloppenburg, a little-known assistant attorney general.

headline: In Song: Tales of Personal Finance
text: I first heard of (and heard) Amy Speace in college, though she had no idea who I was. A lowly freshman boy with enough singing skills to land in the glee club but not enough to make the a cappella groups, I could only listen in wonder when she, a glamorous senior, sang solos in her own group.

headline: Second Thoughts
text: One of the great pleasures of an interest in design is being converted to ideas you hadn’t fully grasped or admired the first time around. The style I’ve always cringed at most — that of the international, postmodern Memphis group, which existed from 1981 to 1987 — now seems kind of appealing: cheerfully earnest and playfully rigorous. The current influence of Memphis, which is popping up everywhere all of a sudden, is to be found throughout these pages. So is the renewed taste for furniture and décor from the 1970s. We didn’t intend to focus in this issue on previously disdained periods of design, but we did just that, and we feel really good about it.

headline: Be Your Guest? How About I Just Pay and Leave?
text: The long line moves slowly. Clutching baskets of detergent, dental floss and such, the errand-running patrons of Walgreens assume their places with resignation, seeking only to pay and get out the door.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘The Folded Clock’
text: This week, Heidi Julavits discusses “The Folded Clock”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Jeffrey Lieberman talks about “Shrinks”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: France Seeks U.N. Security Council Resolution on Mideast Talks
text: UNITED NATIONS — France signaled on Friday that it would press the Security Council to adopt a resolution soon to spur talks between Israel and the Palestinians, a step that the United States resisted last year.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘The Folded Clock’
text: This week, Heidi Julavits and Jeffrey Lieberman.

headline: A Colorful Passover Seder
text: The Passover meal is one of the most meaningful gatherings in Judaism, symbolizing the Jews’ flight from slavery in Egypt. As the cookbook author Joan Nathan writes, the annual event gives her “chills, knowing that I’m following what was written in the Bible more than 2,500 years ago.”

headline: Vows | Muay Thai Bride
text: Early in their relationship, Paul Heck, 47, patiently fit himself into Minna Kao’s intensive competition training. Ms. Kao, 40, realized soon after that she had a cheerleader and a partner for life.

headline: Australia Warns of Terror Threat in Kenyan Capital
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Australian diplomatic office in Kenya on Friday warned of a possible terrorist attack here in the capital, reiterating its recommendation that protests and political rallies be avoided. The warning came two days after the United States issued a similar advisory for neighboring Uganda.

headline: Google and Johnson & Johnson Team for Robotic Surgery Projects
text: Google wants to be everywhere, even inside your body.

headline: Draft on Boards' Engagement With Shareholders
text: A pension fund in Britain and a Dutch pension fund manager have drafted a policy on boards’ engagement with shareholders that they hope companies will make their own.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘The Folded Clock’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Eula Biss reviews Heidi Julavits’s “The Folded Clock.” Ms. Biss writes:

headline: Tech Executives Pressure Indiana After Passage of Controversial Law
text: The tech industry is applying its economic muscle well outside of Silicon Valley.

headline: Audra McDonald Takes to Twitter to Criticize Indiana Law
text: The winningest actress in Broadway history has sharply criticized the passage of a law in Indiana that opponents say would allow businesses to deny service to gays and lesbians.

headline: What I Love | Stewart Lane and Bonnie Comley
text: The Broadway producers live in a 4,000-square-foot duplex penthouse on the Upper East Side.

headline: Citadel Securities Said to Close Apogee Dark Pool
text: Citadel Securities is preparing to close its Apogee dark pool as it focuses on another so-called off-exchange trading platform.

headline: Firefighter’s Account of East Village Blast: ‘Oh Man, It’s a Big One’
text: Firefighter Mike Shepherd, 47, of Squad 41 in the Bronx, is a third-generation New York City firefighter, following in the path of his grandfather and great-grandfather. When there was an explosion at a building in the East Village on Thursday, he raced to the scene.

headline: Kendrick Lamar, Dissenting From the Mainstream as He Influences It
text: Discussing the rapper’s new album, “To Pimp A Butterfly.”

headline: Which Companies Are Buying the Election?
text: Midway into a three-and-a-half-hour congressional hearing this week featuring Mary Jo White, the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, none of the legislators had bothered to ask if or when her agency would require that corporations disclose their political spending.

headline: Obama Praises Harry Reid in Call to Radio Station
text: Fresh on the heels of Senator Harry Reid’s retirement announcement, President Obama took a few minutes on Friday to call into Nevada’s National Public Radio station during an interview with Mr. Reid.

headline: What the Jury in the Ellen Pao-Kleiner Perkins Case Needed to Decide
text: Members of the jury had to sift through seven pages of verdict questions in a trial that pitted the venture firm against a former junior partner who claimed that she was discriminated against and was ultimately let go after complaining.

headline: Israeli Center-Left Leader Seeks Path Forward
text: TEL AVIV — Isaac Herzog is not acting like a sore loser. He is not seeking scapegoats to blame for his center-left Zionist Union’s failure to capture enough votes in Israel’s election last week to unseat Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. He is not shouting “I told you so” as the Obama administration and Europe threaten to isolate Israel as never before.

headline: What John Bolton Gets Wrong About Iran
text: John Bolton’s best quality may be that he says what he thinks. Diplomats are trained to set aside personal beliefs as they fulfill their professional duties but even when Mr. Bolton was a senior official in the administration of President George W. Bush, and supposed to be exercising discretion, he was brash and outspoken.

headline: Popcast: Kendrick Lamar, Dissenting From the Mainstream as He Influences It
text: Last week, Kendrick Lamar released his second album “To Pimp a Butterfly” (TDE/Aftermath/Interscope), one of this year’s most anticipated releases in any genre, and also one of the least likely. (It was surprise-released online, a week before its advertised release.)

headline: Paul Walker’s Films, Beyond ‘The Fast and the Furious’
text: When “Furious 7” opens on April 3, Paul Walker will appear one last time as Brian O’Conner, the role that introduced him to many moviegoers. Like several of Mr. Walker’s characters, O’Conner follows his heart. He begins his journey on one side of the law, but doesn’t stay there. Mr. Walker was the cool, laid-back California dude who often seemed to be having a ball on screen. In most of his films, he ran with a diverse crew and was ready with a bro handshake and a quick laugh.

headline: Slack Gets Hacked as Start-Up Technologies Become Targets
text: Security breaches at start-up technologies are starting to become the new normal.

headline: Beyoncé Designs a Shoe, McDonald’s Ready-to-Wear and the American Apparel Saga Continues
text: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: With Keen Eye for Derby Talent, Todd Pletcher Begins Chase
text: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla. — The horse trainer Todd Pletcher appears to be in an enviable position before the Kentucky Derby on May 2, given the caliber and depth of talent he is sending into key prep races during the next two weekends. But Pletcher’s 1-for-40 Derby history, and the stars he has developed who never got there, underscore how perilous the days ahead may be.

headline: Broadway Producers and Their Upper East Side Penthouse
text: Unlike most New Yorkers, the Broadway producers Stewart F. Lane and Bonnie Comley haven’t minded the harsh winter.

headline: A Townhouse on a Prime Block for $14,990,000
text: A stately limestone and white brick townhouse on a prime block on the Upper East Side, with a filigree wrought-iron fence guarding two sunken gardens in the front and with a paved garden in the back, sold for $14,990,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Dow Chemical Tempts Fate With $5 Billion Deal
text: Dow Chemical is tempting fate with its $5 billion chlorine sale. The $54 billion company is offloading the bulk of its low-margin bleach and vinyl-related operations to a smaller rival, the Olin Corporation, using an esoteric structure known as a reverse Morris Trust. The valuation looks solid, especially considering the tax savings. Yet investors should remain wary given the history of such complex deals.

headline: Shiite Militias in Iraq Back Off Boycott Over U.S. Strikes on ISIS
text: BAGHDAD — A day after several Shiite militias quit the offensive against the Islamic State in protest of American airstrikes, senior Iraqi leaders made assurances on Friday that the militiamen would adhere to government command and cooperate with the American role.

headline: Steve Lavin and St. John’s Part Ways
text: A week after leading St. John’s back to the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament for the first time in four years, Coach Steve Lavin has agreed to part ways with the Red Storm, the university announced Friday.

headline: Monica Lewinsky: Cultural Rorschach Test?
text: I told a group of friends at dinner recently that I was working on a story about Monica Lewinsky.

headline: Japanese Fabric, Illustrated
text: From a series for T in which the artist Leanne Shapton makes new artworks from pictures in old books.

headline: Brothers Sentenced to Three Years for Selling Guns Overseas
text: Two brothers, one a former New York City police officer and the other a federal customs officer, were sentenced on Friday to three years in prison for illegally exporting military-grade weapons to the Philippines for more than four years.

headline: Firefighter Searches for Blast Victims
text: Video shows the moments immediately after an explosion at a building in the East Village on Thursday, with a firefighter, Mike Shepherd, climbing a drop ladder to search for anyone trapped inside.

headline: Learning to Say No to Dialysis
text: Gerald J. Hladik was 74 when the day long anticipated by his doctors arrived: His kidneys, damaged years earlier by a viral infection, had lost 85 percent of their function.

headline: British Museum to Open Gallery Dedicated to Islamic Art
text: LONDON — The British Museum will open a new gallery in 2018 dedicated to a broad swath of Islamic art, the museum announced.

headline: Yellen Says Fed Will Increase Rates Slowly
text: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said on Friday that the Fed planned to raise interest rates more slowly than in past recoveries because of the unusually fragile condition of the American economy.

headline: In ‘iZombie,’ Rose McIver Devours Her Brainiest Role Yet
text: Rose McIver looks awfully alive for someone playing undead. In “iZombie,” her new CW series, she’s a vision of iron deficiency — ghostly pallor, under-eye circles the color of eggplant, brittle platinum bob — as Olivia Moore, a Type A medical student turned zombified coroner’s assistant with a taste for human brains. The twist? Those brains, fresh from the morgue’s cadavers, allow her to channel the memories of the deceased and feed crime information to the Seattle homicide division.

headline: There’s Just One Problem With Photos on Food Stamp Cards
text: Putting photos on the cards people use to redeem food stamps seems like a simple anti-fraud idea. But in Massachusetts, which started putting photos on Electronic Benefit Transfer cards in 2013, it hasn’t worked out for reasons that should have been obvious from the outset, according to a report from the Urban Institute, a left-of-center think tank.

headline: ‘RainForest,’ Cunningham’s Primeval Rarity, Returns to the Joyce
text: “RainForest,” a dance made by Merce Cunningham in 1968, has décor like no other theater piece: helium-filled silver pillows by Andy Warhol that he called “Silver Clouds.” Encountering a flock of them that year at a Warhol exhibition, Cunningham at once spotted their theatrical potential. Four to six of them are moored to the stage, where they sway or bounce like forest undergrowth. Most, however, are loose; some get sent flying by performers. It’s not uncommon during the action for a cloud to float out into the auditorium.

headline: Jordi Savall’s Never-Ending Repertory
text: For the Catalan early-music master Jordi Savall, who has spent decades rediscovering works that had vanished for centuries, the most difficult aspect of the 2011 death of his wife and performing partner, the singer Montserrat Figueras, may have been the music that’s once again disappeared.

headline: Alabama Police Officer Indicted in Confrontation With Unarmed Indian Man
text: ATLANTA — An Alabama police officer has been indicted by a federal grand jury, accused of using unreasonable force against an unarmed Indian man during an episode in which the officer slammed the man to the ground while he was on an early-morning stroll through his family’s suburban neighborhood.

headline: Oklahoma Inquiry Traces Racist Song to National Gathering of Fraternity
text: NORMAN, Okla. — A racist song that caused a national uproar when it was caught on video was a fixture within a fraternity chapter at the University of Oklahoma and not an anomaly, the university reported Friday, and members first learned it at a gathering of the national fraternity four years ago.

headline: Oklahoma President on Racist Chant
text: David L. Boren, president of the University of Oklahoma, said that disciplinary measures had been taken against fraternity members involved in a racist chant.

headline: Weed Killer, Long Cleared, Is Doubted
text: Thirty years ago, an Environmental Protection Agency committee determined that the popular weed killer Roundup might cause cancer. Six years later, in 1991, the agency reversed itself after re-evaluating the mouse study that had been the basis for the original conclusion.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: Exposing Hedge Fund Politics in New York
text: Two weeks ago, several busloads of New Yorkers made a pilgrimage to Greenwich, Conn., to visit the waterfront estate of the hedge fund titan Paul Tudor Jones II, where, suffice it to say, they were not invited in to see the china. It was a rainy Saturday afternoon and the protesters, many of them ordinary working people who have felt cheated by the inequities of a tax system that favors the rarefied few, were there to call attention to Mr. Jones’s educational agenda, built on the premise that the extravagantly rich know better how to teach reading, and to his support of Republican candidates and causes in the New York State Legislature that disadvantage the poor and working class.

headline: Homes for Sale in New Jersey and Connecticut
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York region:

headline: De Blasio’s Blast Investigation Update
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio said there was a possibility that a gas line was “inappropriately accessed” before a building explosion in the East Village.

headline: Starting a Life Together With Pi
text: When Robert Burton Jr. proposed to Jaclyn Sawler, he had a wedding date in mind: March 14. He had a time in mind, too: 9:26 a.m. He had his reasons.

headline: ‘Dylan, Cash and the Nashville Cats’
text: A new exhibition at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum in Nashville, explores noted collaborations between rock and country acts and the session musicians who played on the recordings.

headline: Schumer Shores Up Support for Replacing Reid as Party Leader
text: The official vote to replace Senator Harry Reid as Democratic leader is still nearly two years away, but that hasn’t stopped Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York, now the chamber’s No. 3 Democrat, from making his move.

headline: ‘Dylan, Cash and the Nashville Cats,’ an Unlikely Alliance of Rock and Country
text: NASHVILLE — In recent years, lots of attention has been paid to Nashville’s expansion beyond the country music community, as rockers like Jack White, the Black Keys and Kings of Leon have relocated here to take advantage of the history, atmosphere and infrastructure of Music City, U.S.A. But this, of course, isn’t the first time that artists outside the country tradition have been attracted to Nashville. In the late 1960s and early 1970s, dozens of rock and folk acts traveled to Tennessee and, in a series of unlikely alliances, emerged with an astonishing number of big hits and classic recordings.

headline: Sports Entities Begin to Digest Implications of Indiana Law
text: CLEVELAND — Dakari Johnson, one of the towering big men on Kentucky’s undefeated team, played with Derrick Gordon at St. Patrick High School in Elizabeth, N.J. Gordon, who started for Massachusetts this season, announced that we was gay last year.

headline: New Music From Amy Speace, Diagrams and Elle King
text: Amy Speace

headline: In Mexico, Firing of Carmen Aristegui Highlights Rising Pressures on News Media
text: MEXICO CITY — When Carmen Aristegui, Mexico’s most famous radio personality, was abruptly fired this month, nobody expected her to go quietly. But anger over her dismissal has been rising steadily, and it has turned up the heat in this country’s charged political atmosphere.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Nigeria and Elsewhere
text: Nigeria and Elsewhere – Pictures of the Day

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: How to Avoid a Post-Wedding Letdown
text: The risk of self-delusion is ever-present in the days leading up to a wedding.

headline: March 27, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Nigeria, Myanmar, Somalia and the United States.

headline: What Explains Brazil’s Surfing Boom?
text: BRAZIL has gone surf crazy.

headline: How Patricia Field, Costume Designer for Fashionable Characters, Spends Her Sunday
text: Patricia Field, a New York fashion fixture since opening her first boutique in 1966, has also become a successful costume designer, dressing Meryl Streep in “The Devil Wears Prada,” Vanessa Williams in “Ugly Betty” and Sarah Jessica Parker in “Sex and the City.” Her next project, “Younger,” will debut on TV Land on March 31. When she’s not at her namesake store on the Bowery, the fiery-headed 73-year-old lives in the Seward Park Cooperative on the Lower East Side with her poodles, Sultana and Putana, also known as Pooty.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: New Excursions for Grandparents and Their Grandchildren
text: Road Scholar, a travel company that specializes in 55-and-older learning excursions, is introducing a series of intergenerational “summer sessions” for grandparents and their college-age grandchildren. The new programs include cultural exchanges in Cuba, Costa Rica and Ireland, with itineraries designed to educate and bond families.

headline: Ellen Pao Loses Silicon Valley Bias Case Against Kleiner Perkins
