text: SAN FRANCISCO — One of Silicon Valley’s most famous venture capital firms prevailed on Friday over a former partner in a closely watched suit claiming gender discrimination, but hardly got away unscathed.

headline: Hidden Healthcare Horrors
text: One of the odder subplots of the health reform saga has been the almost pathetic efforts of Republicans to come up with Obamacare horror stories. You might think that given the complexity of the law and the almost unlimited resources of the propaganda machine, they’d be able to come up with someone to serve as the poster child of the law’s terrible effects on innocent Americans. As far as I know, however, we have yet to see a single credible example — all the characters featured in Koch brothers ads or GOP speeches have turned out to be potential beneficiaries of the Affordable Care Act, if only they were willing to look at their actual options.

headline: Intel Said to Be in Talks to Acquire Chip Maker
text: Intel is in discussions to buy Altera, a designer of specialized computer chips, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday. It would be one of the company’s biggest deals ever.

headline: New Talent, New Work
text: The next generation of American designers is experimenting with form — inspired by everything from organic shapes in nature to the funky geometries of postmodernism.

headline: The ‘Street-Level’ Artist
text: At roughly 2 a.m. last Monday morning, B. D. White, 31, drove through Chinatown, working the gas and break with his left hand. He stopped on Division Street and eyed a graffiti-strewn section of brick wall.

headline: How to Make Investing Safer
text: As the comptroller of New York City, Scott Stringer oversees five municipal public pension funds with $160 billion in assets.

headline: Indiana Law Denounced as Invitation to Discriminate Against Gays
text: An Indiana law that could make it easier for religious conservatives to refuse service to gay couples touched off storms of protest on Friday from the worlds of arts, business and college athletics and opened an emotional new debate in the emerging campaign for president.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ Puts Politics Onstage and Politicians in Attendance
text: The hip-hop musical “Hamilton,” featuring a mainly black and Latino cast playing America’s founding fathers, has drawn a steady stream of boldface names since it began its sold-out run at the Public Theater in January.

headline: Cedar Lake Ballet’s Closing Reveals the Perils of Relying on a Single Donor
text: Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet was the envy of many in New York’s dance world: It had a wealthy patron who loved dance, provided good pay and benefits to its dancers, built the troupe a chic Chelsea home and almost single-handedly bore the brunt of the company’s costs.

headline: Review: Argento Chamber Ensemble Brings Out Mahler’s Inventive Side
text: “America for the moment has no idea of what to make of me,” Mahler wrote to a Swiss correspondent in 1908 as he was rehearsing his Symphony No. 2 with the New York Symphony Orchestra. A century later, Mahler’s music is a familiar and well-loved fixture on American concert stages. But this season the inspired Argento Chamber Ensemble is making the case for a fresh listen with a four-concert series titled Mahler as New York Contemporary. By performing the composer’s seminal works in chamber arrangements alongside contemporary pieces that reflect his influence, the group draws attention to aspects of Mahler’s music that remain bracingly original and even weird.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Spring Unfurls
text: As the weather fluctuated between harsh and mild, New Yorkers were on the lookout for signs of spring.

headline: Collecting Human Voices With a StoryCorps App
text: David Isay is a Guggenheim fellow, a longtime audio documentarian and a voice familiar to anyone who has listened to public radio in the last 15 years. He is also the founder of StoryCorps, a Brooklyn organization that collects the stories of ordinary Americans. In its brief existence, StoryCorps has amassed a significant trove of American oral history. In remarks at the annual TED conference in Vancouver a couple of weeks ago, Mr. Isay said StoryCorps held “the largest single collection of human voices ever gathered.”

headline: Talking Photography With Elliott Erwitt
text: Elliott Erwitt has been prolific with his photo books, but he warned Todd Heisler that he was a lousy interview. He was wrong. And funny.

headline: Review: Martha Graham and Merce Cunningham Works at Juilliard Dance
text: The Juilliard Dance performances of late March have long been one of the finest fixtures on the New York dance calendar. The programs consist of two or more works, often classics; the student dancers spend months preparing with leading authorities. The level of execution is often professionally excellent; it’s easy to believe the students will remember lessons from the choreography for the rest of their lives.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Spring Unfurls
text: As the weather fluctuated between harsh and mild, New Yorkers were on the lookout for signs of spring, such as the blossoming of magnolia trees on the lawn of the Frick Collection. A stunning visual in Bryant Park was the transformation of the skating rink into a turf-covered lawn. On the fashion front, legs emerged, and New Yorkers added a surprising color to their signature black-white-and-gray looks: chrome silver.

headline: Notable Deaths of 2015
text: Remembering Oliver Sacks, B.B. King, Leonard Nimoy, Happy Rockefeller, E.L. Doctorow, Maya Plisetskaya, Omar Sharif and many others who died this year.

headline: Review: Melissa Manchester, Liberated, at 54 Below
text: Melissa Manchester has a history of laboring in other people’s shadows. At the start of her career, her mentors included Barry Manilow and Bette Midler, with whom she sang backup in Ms. Midler’s saucy group the Harlettes. At the height of her popularity in the 1970s, she was guided in her choice of material for both good and ill by the redoubtable record company honcho Clive Davis. Only recently has Ms. Manchester, who lives in Southern California and teaches music at the University of Southern California, emerged fully into the light.

headline: In Hamilton Heights, a Link to Ecuador
text: The identity of Hamilton Heights has been in flux, but the Ecuadorean community’s impact on the neighborhood is alive at Ecuatoriana Restaurant.

headline: Review: Trio 3 Shows Off Its Jazz Avant-Garde Pedigree
text: One misperception about the jazz avant-garde is that it’s essentially reactive, a single-minded pushback against conventions of form. Whatever lump of truth or slander you might find in that idea, Trio 3, which is playing at the Village Vanguard, provides scant supporting evidence for it.

headline: Review: John Adams Unveils ‘Scheherazade.2,’ an Answer to Male Brutality
text: Two years ago, the composer John Adams took in an exhibition at the Arab World Institute in Paris about the history of the “Arabian Nights” collection of folk stories. He already knew, or so he thought, the tale of Scheherazade, the young woman forced into marriage with a Persian king who takes a succession of virgins as wives and has each one executed the morning after lest she have a chance to dishonor him. Scheherazade delays her own death by telling the king a riveting tale night after night.

headline: Review: Tobias Jesso Jr., Puppyish and Playful, Plays the Mercury Lounge
text: “I’m going to switch to guitar — that cool?” Tobias Jesso Jr. was a few songs into his first official New York concert Thursday night, and he was ready for a change. He got up from behind the piano, an instrument he began playing only a couple of years ago at age 27, and shuffled over to the other side of the stage, where a guitar was waiting for him.

headline: A Co-Pilot Bent on Destruction
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ecuatoriana Restaurant Is a Link to Ecuador in Harlem
text: On a high ridge in West Harlem, a steady wind from the bluffs of the Jersey Palisades reflects the swirling dynamics of the Sugar Hill area of Hamilton Heights, whose identity has been in steady flux since the days when Harlem was in vogue and Duke Ellington dispensed subway directions. One of the more recent cultures to pass through this historic area was that of the Ecuadoreans. And while most have moved east to Queens or north to the Bronx, and beyond into Westchester, the impression they left on the neighborhood remains alive and vital at Ecuatoriana Restaurant, on Amsterdam Avenue between West 143rd and 144th Streets.

headline: Baselworld, Where the Watch Is Still the Greatest Gadget
text: BASEL, Switzerland — “Are you wearing a Fifty Fathoms?”

headline: What Silicon Valley Learned From the Kleiner Perkins Case
text: Kleiner Perkins’s victory Friday in the gender discrimination suit brought by Ellen Pao could be seen as an affirmation of the Silicon Valley old boys club. But venture capitalists have said that the trial has already put the tech industry on notice: It can no longer operate as a band of outsiders, often oblivious to rules that govern the modern workplace — even if that has been a key to its success.

headline: A Deal From the Machlin Women’s Swiss Teams
text: On Sunday, the last day of the Spring Nationals in New Orleans, the Machlin Women’s Swiss Teams was won by Lynn Baker of Austin, Tex.; Karen McCallum of Exeter, N.H.; Pamela Granovetter of Cincinnati; JoAnna Stansby of Dublin, Calif.; Irina Levitina of Hackensack, N.J.; and Kerri Sanborn of Delray Beach, Fla.

headline: A Broadway Composer Takes a Night Off for Drag Queens
text: Jeanine Tesori is the award-winning composer behind “Caroline, or Change” and “Thoroughly Modern Millie,” but Broadway shows aren’t truly her favorite thing.

headline: Review: In ‘Flexn,’ Street Dance Gets a Grand Stage
text: Get-low, gliding, bone-breaking, connecting, pauzin, waving: Even the language of flexing, a street-dance style born in Jamaica and raised in the Brooklyn neighborhood of East New York, pops with energy. Flip through the enormous program book for “Flexn,” a show of grand proportions that opened on Wednesday at the Park Avenue Armory, and you’ll find a “Flexapedia” defining these terms. It’s a glossary of action words. Flexing is doing.

headline: Review: Shaina Taub, Prolific Earth Mother, and Friends
text: The singer and songwriter Shaina Taub belongs to a breed of performers who, apart from being artists, are gravitational forces around whom others cluster like filings to a magnet. For her concert on Wednesday at the Kaplan Penthouse as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series, Ms. Taub commanded a musical army that included a sizable chorus and a horn section in a program of 19 original songs. A prolific songwriter, Ms. Taub won a 2014 Jonathan Larson Grant, awarded to rising musical-theater talents.

headline: Amanda Knox Acquitted of 2007 Murder by Italy’s Highest Court
text: ROME — Italy’s highest court overturned the murder convictions of Amanda Knox and her Italian former boyfriend on Friday, throwing out all charges and ending a long-running courtroom drama over the killing of a British student in 2007.

headline: Sustenance From the Scrap Heap
text: If America is a country of agricultural abundance, it is also one of great waste. Surplus at every level of the food chain, from farming to fishing to distributing and processing, goes in the trash heap. In comes Dan Barber, the renowned chef at Blue Hill restaurant, with the idea of creating high cuisine out of what is usually discarded and to highlight the dishes at a monthlong pop-up at his restaurant in the West Village, called WastED. “I was studying the history of cuisines, and I started seeing something kind of obvious, that cuisines by their nature evolved by utilizing waste,” Mr. Barber said. “Maybe some of this stuff on the menu will end up coming around to everyday food culture. Chefs and restaurants have that power.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Inside T’s Design Issue
text: T’s latest issue examines the current state of design by looking backward — namely, to the hedonistic ’70s and oddly alluring po-mo ’80s. The onetime California home of Gerald and Betty Ford is a perfect example of this revival; its new owners have kept many of the house’s original charms (including a giant portrait of the former First Lady), while adding their own contemporary touches, to create a space that’s anything but conservative. Likewise, the purist Mark Haddawy — the co-founder of the retailer Resurrection Vintage and restorer of Modernist houses — has doubled down on his version of ’70s California cool by doing very little to his own home in Big Sur. And the fashion reporter and insider Mary Russell, who for many years was as likely to cavort among (and occasionally hop in bed with) her stylish subjects as she was to photograph them, reminisces about Europe in the freewheeling ’60s and ’70s. Elsewhere, Nicola Del Roscio, the longtime close companion of Cy Twombly, remembers the late painter while creating his own Eden in the hills of Gaeta, Italy; Sarah Lucas, the former rude girl of British art, discusses how she grew up without losing her nerve; Ricky Gervais and Zaha Hadid say yes to sriracha-flavored ketchup and a floor-cleaning robot while lounging in a giant bird’s nest; the New York magazine co-founder and “I Heart NY” creator Milton Glaser gets the By the Numbers treatment; and a handful of authors with new books out this year pay tribute to the spaces where they write. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Review: ‘The Originalist,’ About Scalia, Opens in Washington
text: WASHINGTON — Few people seeing “The Originalist,” a new play by John Strand having its premiere at Arena Stage here, are likely to have a fuzzy opinion about the character at its center, the Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia. He’s arguably among the most polarizing jurists of his stature in American history, and inarguably the most combative justice currently on the court. For that matter, it’s unlikely that anyone will emerge from Mr. Strand’s play, which is essentially a series of debates dressed up in the robes of drama, with a radically changed view of Justice Scalia’s ideas about American jurisprudence as expressed through the often heated rhetoric in his writings and speeches.

headline: A Window Into the Real Lauren Bacall
text: She loved animals. And piecework quilts. And Louis Vuitton suitcases.

headline: Joe Assadourian, of ‘The Bullpen,’ Visits His Former Cellmates
text: OTISVILLE, N.Y. — It’s a familiar enough homecoming scene: A successful performer returns to his old stomping ground and puts on a show in the gymnasium because he wants to give a little something back. Joe Assadourian, who has been starring in a one-man show in Manhattan since last June, made his pilgrimage Thursday, but the gymnasium he performed in wasn’t in a high school. It was at the state prison here, and many inmates in the audience were also his buddies, because not that long ago he was one of them.

headline: The Week In Political Pictures
text: A major retirement, a major announcement, and a major honor for a legend of golf.

headline: She Sounds Smart, but Look at Her Hair!
text: A few months ago, I moderated a televised book-fair panel, an event I approached with a certain amount of trepidation, but that providentially went well. An overflowing audience laughed and clapped in the right places. The panelists thanked me after. I felt great.

headline: Unplugging Without FOMO
text: At the Breslin Bar & Dining Room last month, Amy Chan and three friends were eating oysters when one of them mentioned “the dress.” BuzzFeed had fueled a media frenzy that day by asking readers to vote on whether a dress posted on Tumblr was white with gold trim or blue and black. Ms. Chan’s friends had argued that it was blue. Others online had declared it white.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
Contested Legacy of Dr. Ben, a Father of African Studies
text: The faded plaque to the right of the door said “Jochannan, Yosef B.,” but visitors to this nursing home on the northern edge of the Bronx knew the frail 96-year-old inside by another name: Dr. Ben.

headline: wastED
text: The chef Dan Barber’s pop-up serving food that is normally thrown out, scavenged from around the city.

headline: At the Chef Dan Barber’s Pop-Up, WastED, Bruised and Misshapen Bits Are Dinner
text: On Monday, I chopped a week’s worth of food scraps. It took most of an hour in my kitchen to reduce carrot leaves, cauliflower stems, onion butts and scallion greens to small bits that I hoped would make an appetizing lunch for the molds, mini-bugs and earthworms in the backyard compost bin.

headline: Obama Seeks to Double Funding to Fight Antibiotic Resistance
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday urged Congress to double the funding to confront the danger of antibiotic-resistant bacteria, calling it a major public health issue that, if left unchecked, would “cause tens of thousands of deaths, millions of illnesses.”

headline: Robert Moses, French Comic Book Hero
text: Robert Moses, the bureaucrat-visionary who shaped the modern face of New York City, has been the subject of countless symposia, museum exhibitions, a TV documentary and a Pulitzer-winning biography.

headline: A Bergdahl Court-Martial Serves Military Justice
text: To the Editor:

headline: Review: São Paulo State Youth Orchestra Saves Razzle-Dazzle for the End
text: You had to wait till the third encore for things to bust loose, but most of the audience did so, clearly expectant.

headline: Tammy Duckworth Expected to Challenge Senator Mark Kirk in Illinois
text: Representative Tammy L. Duckworth, Democrat of Illinois, is expected to announce next week that she will challenge Senator Mark S. Kirk, a first-term Republican, potentially pitting two candidates with personal stories of overcoming physical handicaps against each other in 2016 in a race for President Obama’s old seat.

headline: End the Loss of Driver’s Licenses for Drug Crimes
text: To the Editor:

headline: Review: Bach Passions in New York
text: You can generally count on a New York spring to produce three or four prominent performances of Bach Passions. This year the activity is minimal.

headline: Madison Square Garden Confirms Plan to Split in Two
text: The Madison Square Garden Company confirmed on Friday that it will break itself up, dividing the New York Knicks and Rangers professional sports teams from the company’s regional sports networks.

headline: For Consumers, Forced Arbitration Equals Injustice
text: To the Editor:

headline: No Copies of Clinton Emails on Server, Lawyer Says
text: WASHINGTON — An examination of the server that housed the personal email account that Hillary Rodham Clinton used exclusively when she was secretary of state showed that there are no copies of any emails she sent during her time in office, her lawyer told a congressional committee on Friday.

headline: Review: ‘Camp Kappawanna,’ Complete With Insecurities and Bug Spray
text: No one, you’ll be relieved to learn, sings “Kumbaya.” Arts and crafts haven’t made the list of activities. And neither, oddly, has theater.

headline: Next for the Big City Book Club: Russell Shorto’s ‘The Island at the Center of the World’
text: Recently we asked readers to suggest new titles for the next meeting of the Big City Book Club. We were flooded with ideas and from your suggestions drafted a short list of three titles. The final contestants were Edith Wharton’s “The Age of Innocence,” Teju Cole’s “Open City,” and Russell Shorto’s “The Island at the Center of the World: The Epic Story of Dutch Manhattan and the Forgotten Colony That Shaped America.” More than 300 votes were cast and the race was tight. But the winner is ... “The Island at the Center of the World.”

headline: Celebrating John F. Burns, War Reporter and Witness to Era-Defining Events
text: For many Americans, the indelible image of John Burns is that unruly shock of gray curls, seemingly at odds with the stream of perfectly formed sentences illuminating the war in Iraq. His television appearances guaranteed he would be recognized by ordinary New Yorkers when he made his infrequent forays to headquarters — a place he spent most of his 40 years at The New York Times managing to avoid.

headline: Poland Charges Russian Air Traffic Controllers in Crash
text: WARSAW — Polish military prosecutors charged two Russian air traffic controllers on Friday in a 2010 plane crash in western Russia that killed President Lech Kaczynski and 95 top-ranking officials traveling with him. The charges are likely to strain already tense relations between Poland and Russia.

headline: Can Data Stop Car Wrecks?
text: IN 2008 the owner of a 2001 Honda Civic posted a note on an Internet forum for Honda enthusiasts, saying that the car’s airbag had exploded in an accident, shooting shrapnel in multiple directions. “There were even strips of metal torn from the airbag backing plate that shot forward and smashed out the instrument panel,” the owner wrote.

headline: Hurdles Loom in Iran Nuclear Talks, U.S. Official Says
text: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — A senior State Department official said Friday night that the negotiations over Iran’s nuclear program had turned difficult and that an initial accord would not be possible unless the Iranian leadership made “tough decisions” over the coming days.

headline: Catholics on Left and Right Find Common Ground Opposing Death Penalty
text: As the editor of The National Catholic Reporter, a national biweekly, Dennis Coday reads his competitor, The National Catholic Register. But he does not have to agree with it.

headline: Ellen Pao Disrupts How Silicon Valley Does Business
text: Silicon Valley is enamored of “disrupters,” those shrewd, brave men — it is almost always men — who are hailed for enduring years of ridicule and risking everything to shake up the conventional order.

headline: Owners of Restaurants Destroyed in East Village Explosion Mourn Their Losses
text: Three in a row the food shops sat, a tiny stretch of New York no more than a few hundred feet long that somehow contained the city itself. The patch of Second Avenue in the East Village was home to a Japanese restaurant, owned and run by a Korean family; a shop selling Belgian-style French fries founded by a woman from the Bronx; and a bodega called Sam’s Deli, the hub of generations of one Indian family that owned it for nearly two decades.

headline: Militants Take Hostages in Deadly Attack on Mogadishu Hotel
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Armed assailants attacked a Mogadishu hotel on Friday, leaving at least seven people dead, including a Somali ambassador, and seizing an unknown number of hostages, officials and witnesses said. The Shabab militant Islamist group, which routinely targets government and business sites in the Somali capital, claimed responsibility.

headline: G.O.P. Hawks Upset With Bush After Baker Speech on Israel
text: The warnings trickled in soon after an announcement began circulating last month that James A. Baker III, the former diplomat who is now a foreign policy adviser to Jeb Bush, would be a featured speaker at a conference hosted by J Street, the liberal pro-Israel advocacy organization.

headline: This Coach Doesn’t Tolerate Losing. Now, Neither Does Minnesota State.
text: MANKATO, Minn. — Everything about Mike Hastings, the coach of the Minnesota State Mankato men’s hockey team, the surprising No. 1 overall seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament, involves a story — like how his family acquired its dog, a 3-year-old golden retriever named Gracie.

headline: Mike Brey Hopes for a Nearly Impossible Win After a Personal Loss
text: CLEVELAND — Shortly after Notre Dame beat Wichita State on Thursday night, Irish Coach Mike Brey stood in a corridor just off the court and answered questions about Saturday’s opponent, which he knew would be West Virginia or Kentucky. As he spoke, the repeated roars of a partisan crowd made it clear that that opponent would be Kentucky.

headline: Housing Homeless Youth Poses Challenge for Mayor de Blasio
text: Lijuan Hartfield often caught up on sleep on the subway, at friends’ apartments, sometimes at a 24-hour McDonald’s.

headline: Long Night in Senate, but Real Budget Work Awaits
text: WASHINGTON — Emerging from an all-night session that was more exhausting than dramatic, Senate Republicans on Friday squeaked through a budget blueprint that would repeal the Affordable Care Act, fundamentally remake federal health care for the poor and elderly, and push the federal deficit toward zero over the next decade.

headline: Steve Vasturia Is Modest, Like His Mother, and Tough, Like His Team
text: CLEVELAND — Kathy Vasturia knew how hard her son Steve was working. She could see him fighting through screens, chasing Ron Baker of Wichita State all over the floor, running nonstop and bouncing off shoulders, elbows and well-placed hips.

headline: Tomas Transtromer, Swedish Poet Who Won Nobel, Dies at 83
text: Tomas Transtromer, a Swedish poet who won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2011 for a body of work known for shrewd metaphors couched in deceptively spare language, crystalline descriptions of natural beauty and explorations of the mysteries of identity and creativity, died on Thursday in Stockholm. He was 83.

headline: Healing Fire in Londonderry: The Temple Was Built to Burn
text: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland — The Rev. David Latimer thought it was a terrible idea. The streets of this Northern Irish city had burned in the Troubles. His Protestant church was firebombed by Catholics. Every summer, rival bonfires the size of small mountains still burn, and with them the flags and effigies of the other side.

headline: Makers of Generic Drugs Challenge F.D.A. Plan for Updated Warnings
text: BETHESDA, Md. — The pharmaceutical industry mounted a new challenge on Friday to a federal plan that would require generic drug companies to take the initiative to update their labels to warn consumers whenever health risks were discovered, a shift that would expose the companies to legal liability.

headline: T.J. McConnell Is a Mirror Image of Arizona Coach Sean Miller, Minus the Suit and Tie
text: LOS ANGELES — The men’s basketball team from Pittsburgh’s Duquesne University opened the 2011-12 season with a game at highly ranked Arizona. The Duquesne coach at the time, Ron Everhart, said beforehand that his sophomore point guard, T. J. McConnell, reminded him of a young Sean Miller — a Pittsburgh-area star in high school, a four-year collegiate starter at Pittsburgh and now Arizona’s coach.

headline: Extent of Losses Begins to Come Into Focus a Day After an East Village Explosion
text: On a wall of his rented room in Queens, Moises Ismael Locón Yac has paid tribute to the city where he has lived for seven of his 27 years: a poster of the Empire State Building and a framed cover from The New Yorker — a drawing of a cat looking out an apartment window at the cityscape.

headline: Turning a Wrongful Imprisonment Into Advocacy
text: ACCUSED of murder, railroaded through the Nicaraguan courts and wrongly convicted, Eric Volz can be forgiven for not having immediately recognized that his ordeal would become the foundation for his life’s work.

headline: A West Village Bar Crawl Leaves Behind a Trail of Counterfeit Green
text: The gray jumpsuits that inmates wear into the visiting room at the Manhattan Detention Complex can be scratchy and uncomfortable, and Eddie Ashley, 21, tugged at his collar as he thought about that night. Hard to believe it all happened just a few subway stops from his current surroundings, traditionally known as the Tombs. It was three weeks ago.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 27, 2015
text: March 27, 2015

headline: George Spitz, Civic Gadfly Who Helped Transform Marathon, Dies at 92
text: George N. Spitz, a relentless gadfly who is credited with recasting the New York City Marathon from a four-lap run around Central Park with 339 finishers to a celebratory five-borough race that has become the largest of its kind in the world, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 92.

headline: Matt Harvey Continues His Sterling Spring by Taming the Cardinals
text: JUPITER, Fla. — Matt Harvey turned 26 on Friday, and to an outsider, it might have seemed like an unremarkable moment. The Mets had a birthday cake in the clubhouse in the morning — no big deal — and Harvey pitched well against the St. Louis Cardinals in the afternoon, which, in the past, would have been no big deal, either.

headline: Guantánamo’s Charade of Justice
text: LAST week, we learned that, only months into the job, the official in charge of the military courts system at Guantánamo Bay was stepping down, after judges ruled he had interfered in proceedings. The appointment of an interim replacement was the sixth change of leadership for the tribunals since 2003.

headline: Cops With Hearing Aids?
text: SHOULD police officers be allowed to wear hearing aids?

headline: Need Anything Else?
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Confession: I’m sick. I have my annual “Great Timing, Deb, Just in Time For The American Crossword Puzzle Tournament!” cold, and it’s at the point where I can barely see my computer screen. So I’m going to turn things over to David Steinberg, today’s constructor, and let him tell you about his puzzle.

headline: Feds Gone Wild
text: It certainly holds promise as a plot for a B-list thriller: Drug Enforcement Administration agents stationed in Colombia regularly cavort with prostitutes at parties paid for by local drug cartels. In a few instances, cash and expensive gifts appear to change hands. A local officer is kind enough to keep an eye on the agents’ guns and property while the agents are busy with the girls.

headline: Ex-Agent in Patz Case Says Sex Offender Was Suspect
text: An F.B.I. agent who worked on the Etan Patz case for nearly a decade testified on Friday that a previous suspect in the boy’s 1979 disappearance admitted to having sexually abused a young boy on the same day that Etan disappeared, though he called the boy “Jimmy.”

headline: Rick Pitino’s Alchemy Turns Louisville’s Bricks to Gold
text: SYRACUSE — Louisville’s reserve guard Anton Gill had not played more than 12 minutes in a game since mid-February. This month, he had missed every shot he tried, five field goals and two free throws. Once a top recruit, Gill came to Louisville as a shooter, having scored 50 points or more twice in one week while in high school.

headline: China’s Fear of Women With Pamphlets
text: China’s growing crackdown on political dissent is stirring global protests and demands for the release of five women’s rights advocates arrested this month as they sought to hand out leaflets as part of a campaign against sexual harassment on China’s public transportation.

headline: Gonzaga Recovers to Beat U.C.L.A. in Sloppy Game
text: HOUSTON — These were not the deadeye Gonzaga Bulldogs who could shoot opponents into submission without getting dirty underneath the basket. These Bulldogs were clanging balls off the rim at such an alarming rate Friday night that Coach Mark Few’s patience finally wore as thin as the lead U.C.L.A. had just cut to 1 point early in the second half.

headline: Arizona Fallout From Ferguson
text: The nation’s grave problems of police procedures and racial insensitivity laid bare by the simmering events in Ferguson, Mo., can only be worsened by concealment. Yet that is what a bill approved by Arizona’s Legislature would do by keeping identities of police officers secret for 60 days after officers are involved in deadly or serious shootings.

headline: So Who Needs Matt Harvey?
text: The Mets’ decision to give this year’s opening day start to Bartolo Colon instead of Matt Harvey has created something of a stir. Then again, the Mets have done really well on opening days, whether an ace like Tom Seaver or Dwight Gooden was starting or a less-heralded pitcher was on the mound.

headline: Ted Cruz Pop Quiz
text: We officially have a 2016 presidential candidate! How well do you know him?

headline: Governor Cuomo’s Former Aide Moves to the Private Sector
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s former top aide and longtime confidant, Lawrence S. Schwartz, has found a job in the private sector.

headline: John Renbourn, Eclectic Guitarist Who Founded the Pentangle, Dies at 70
text: John Renbourn, an English guitarist known for his light-fingered fusion of classical, folk, blues and jazz and for his work with the group the Pentangle, was found dead on Thursday at his home in Hawick, Scotland, near the English border. He was 70.

headline: Nets, Playing for a Playoff Spot, Grab a Win
text: The volume in professional sports locker rooms late at night tends to fluctuate depending on the result of a game. Losses demand silence. Wins inspire a joyous rumpus.

headline: With Little Notice, Citi Bike Is Suspended for the Weekend
text: New York City’s bike share program abruptly announced on Friday evening that it would shut down for the weekend to improve the service.

headline: Kevin Durant to Have Bone Graft and Miss Rest of Season
text: Kevin Durant, the N.B.A.’s reigning most valuable player, has played his final game of an injury-marred season. Durant is scheduled to undergo a bone graft next week on his ailing right foot, the team announced Friday, and is not expected to resume basketball-related activities for four to six months.

headline: Rod Hundley, an Outsize Personality on and Off the Court, Dies at 80
text: Rod Hundley, basketball’s irrepressible Hot Rod, who parlayed showmanship on the court with flair at the microphone to become a fan favorite for more than half a century, died on Friday at his home near Phoenix. He was 80.

headline: Duke’s Core of 8 Reaches the Round of 8
text: HOUSTON — For the last two months, Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski has issued his team a daily reminder. Eight is enough, he tells the Blue Devils.

headline: Michigan State Edges Oklahoma With Second-Half Surge
text: SYRACUSE — It has become almost trite and half-expected: Tom Izzo coaching Michigan State deep into the N.C.A.A. tournament, pushing all the right buttons at all the right times in March.

headline: Corrections: March 28, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “This case sends a powerful signal to Silicon Valley in general and the venture capital industry in particular.”

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
text: 6:45 P.M. (Sundance) SHAUN OF THE DEAD (2004) Shaun (Simon Pegg) and his girlfriend, Liz (Kate Ashfield), are having problems because of Shaun’s insistence on always doing the same thing. He likes to hang out at the pub with his friend Ed (Nick Frost) and has yet to meet Liz’s mother. After Liz dumps Shaun, he continues in his habits. Shaun and Ed are so complacent that it takes them an astonishingly long time to realize that the odd events increasing in frequency around them are the result of a zombie outbreak. Shaun and Ed find themselves in a comedic fight for survival in which zombies are fought with bad records and clumsy luck in this film directed by Edgar Wright (“Hot Fuzz,” “Scott Pilgrim vs. the World”). “There is something intrinsically ridiculous about zombie movies,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “The British horror comedy ‘Shaun of the Dead’ skillfully plays off that ridiculousness by implying that Britain may already be populated with the living dead, metaphorically speaking.”

headline: Turning Around for a Farewell Glance
text: I leave The New York Times after having had an amazing 31-year career here, first spending 16 years as a staff photographer, followed by 15 more as a picture editor. During my time as a photographer, I had the honor of being based in Washington, covering the White House during the Reagan, Bush (41) and Clinton administrations.

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: In Brazil, Some Inmates Get Therapy With Hallucinogenic Tea
text: JI-PARANÁ, Brazil — As the night sky enveloped this outpost in Brazil’s Amazon basin, the ceremony at the open-air temple began simply enough.

headline: Ex-Yemeni Leader Urges Truce and Successor’s Ouster
text: CAIRO — Under pressure from a Saudi Arabian-led campaign of airstrikes, the former leader of Yemen who is backing the group that has seized the country’s largest cities said on Saturday that he was pleading for a truce, urging negotiations, but standing by demands for the ouster of his Saudi-backed successor.

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photographers featured this week on @nytimes took viewers from an explosion in the East Village to a small village in Egypt.

headline: Nigeria Votes in Sharply Contested Presidential Election
text: KANO, Nigeria — Eager voters waited to cast ballots all day as the most contested election in Nigeria’s post-independence history wound down to a tense conclusion on Saturday amid fears that the polarized electorate would clash regardless of the outcome in a country sharply split on ethnic and sectarian lines.

headline: Strong Dollar Yields Savings From Tour Operators
text: With the dollar strengthening against many foreign currencies, travel abroad may be cheaper than in the past, inspiring tour operators to offer booking rebates and increase departures.

headline: Stress and Hope In Tehran
text: As Iran and world powers including the United States try to reach a deal on nuclear controls in exchange for the lifting of sanctions, Iranians from all walks of life are watching and hoping for a new start.

headline: Masquerading As a Two-Family Home
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2015: Welcome to the Show
text: SPECIAL POST — Stop me if you’ve heard this one. It’s not so much a joke as a moment of recognition; a moment in a crowded elevator when you realize that, amongst a group of strangers, you’re home.

headline: Germanwings Pilot Andreas Lubitz Sought Treatment for Vision Problems Before Crash, Authorities Say
text: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — Andreas Lubitz, who was flying the Germanwings jetliner that slammed into a mountain in the French Alps on Tuesday, sought treatment for vision problems that may have jeopardized his ability to continue working as a pilot, two officials with knowledge of the investigation said Saturday.

headline: After Germanwings Crash, a Week of Mourning and Questions
text: Memorial services were held for the victims as investigators looked into Andreas Lubitz, the co-pilot who plowed the plane into a mountain.

headline: Two Men Remain Missing as Remnants of Explosion Are Scoured in Manhattan
text: With hopes fading in the search for two men who have been missing since an explosion jolted a stretch of the East Village, emergency workers on Saturday continued to scour the debris of the three buildings that were destroyed on Thursday in the blast and ensuing fire.

headline: Somali Troops End Siege at Hotel as Death Toll Rises to 15
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Somali troops ended a 16-hour siege at a hotel in Somalia’s capital on Saturday, during which gunmen killed 15 people, officials said.

headline: Spring Pasta Night!
text: Spring cooking means fresh vegetables and simple dishes. This week Martha Rose Shulman offers a new simple pasta dish with mussels. It’s a meal that tastes like you went to a lot of work, but only you will know how simple it was to put it on the table.

headline: Linda Zecher of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt: The Danger of ‘One Size Fits All’
text: This interview with Linda K. Zecher the chief executive of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, a publishing house that also provides educational content, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Variety: Marching Bands
text: Administrivial Get More Puzzles Alert! Do you love the Marching Bands variety puzzles as much as I do? The devious constructor and man-about-town Brendan Emmett Quigley is beginning a Kickstarter campaign that will result in a whole slew of these wonderful puzzles landing squarely in your email inbox every other week. Click here for more information.

headline: At U.S. Companies, Time to Coax the Directors Into Talking
text: It’s shareholder meeting season again, corporate America’s version of Groundhog Day.

headline: Helping Veterans Get Hired
text: Nick Swaggert, 33, is the veterans program director for Genesis10, a technology staffing and services firm. He is based in its St. Paul office.

headline: Wainwright House, a Haven for the Spirit on Long Island Sound
text: Before the second installment of Linda Richichi’s three-part Soul Vision workshop started at Wainwright House in Rye on a recent sunny Sunday, Joanne Mendola was feeling hopeful about dissolving what remained of her spiritual blockages.

headline: Mild Winters and Crank Economics
text: Neil Irwin writes about migration patterns within the United States, and points out that they overwhelmingly reflect just two factors. Most important, people are moving to places with mild winters:

headline: Make Way for Generation Z
text: I recall the exact moment the temperature changed in the workplace. It was 2005, and I was speaking to an audience of 100 young professionals. I was relating my experiences building a career as a Gen Xer (born 1964-79) in a world of traditionalists (born before 1945) and baby boomers (born 1946-63).

headline: No. 2 Negotiators in Iran Talks Argue Physics Behind Politics
text: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — At the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the mid-1970s, Ernest J. Moniz was an up-and-coming nuclear scientist in search of tenure, and Ali Akbar Salehi, a brilliant Iranian graduate student, was finishing a dissertation on fast-neutron reactors.

headline: The Mystery of the Missing Mask
text: Our episode about one man’s maddening efforts to get reimbursed by Optum, a health services provider, elicited some “me too” email from other frustrated and unhappy consumers. There was also an interesting email from a therapist, who asked that she not be identified, mostly because she could see no upside in speaking out against the company.

headline: Iraqi Forces in No Hurry to Expel ISIS From Tikrit
text: TIKRIT, Iraq — Here at the headquarters of Iraqi ground forces, after three days of American airstrikes that at times witnesses here described as “carpet bombing,” Iraq’s military seemed in no great hurry on Saturday to press its advantage.

headline: Unreal Keynesians
text: Brad DeLong points me to Lars Syll declaring that I am not a “real Keynesian”, because I use equilibrium models and don’t emphasize the instability of expectations.

headline: A Wi-Fi Barbie Doll With the Soul of Siri
text: Ever since Siri appeared as a regular feature on the iPhone, certain young children — and, let’s face it, some of their parents — have spent hours chatting up the virtual assistant, curious about the details of her humanoid back story.

headline: In Bid to Inspire Faith in Senate, Kennedy Institute Has the Floor
text: BOSTON — When creators of the Edward M. Kennedy Institute for the United States Senate set out to rebuild the crumbling image of the world’s greatest deliberative body, they started from the ground up.

headline: All Grown Up and In Charge of the Seder
text: EVERY person I know remembers a specific moment, a signpost marking the day, or the year, that childhood was left behind.

headline: In the N.C.A.A. Tournament, Games Are Big, but Life Is Bigger
text: LOS ANGELES — The victories against Coastal Carolina and Oregon cleared Wisconsin’s path to the West Regional semifinal, but long after the details of the N.C.A.A. tournament games in Nebraska are lost to memory’s slow leak, the Badger players will recall their go-karting excursion in Omaha.

headline: A Review of Encore Bistro, in Rye
text: There must be a company called Parisian Bistro Decorators that specializes in giving American restaurants the look and feel of something approaching French charm. Diners can take it all in at Encore Bistro in Rye, with its white ceramic tile walls, black and white hexagonal tile floor, posters in saturated colors and a horizontal mirror over a long banquette. Additional niceties please as well, like the appealing bottles of tap water that arrive after orders have been taken and the dish towels that make sturdy napkins.

headline: Sri Lankan President’s Brother Dies From Ax Wounds
text: A brother of Sri Lanka’s president, Maithripala Sirisena, died on Saturday from severe head wounds he suffered in an ax attack two days earlier, according to a statement by the Sri Lankan government.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2015: The Standings Emerge?
text: SPECIAL POST — With three puzzles in the bag, the standings are starting to be posted for Puzzle 1.

headline: Athletes Finding Their Voice in Derek Jeter’s Digital Venture
text: David Ortiz’s blustery rant about being unfairly branded a cheater for testing positive for a banned substance in 2003 made news Thursday, not only for its strident tone, but for where it appeared.

headline: The Chinese-Americans
text: A photographer explores his place in the country’s social landscape.

headline: Embracing My Chinese-American Identity
text: WHEN I was in eighth grade, in Queens, in the early 2000s, I was often picked on by other children for my almond-shaped eyes, beige complexion and jet-black hair — essentially, my Chinese face. They’d ask me if I ate vermin and felines and constantly mocked my native language. These adolescent experiences planted within me seeds of self-hatred, and for years I tried to rid myself of my cultural heritage.

headline: Altered Visions and Changing Vistas
text: Ansel Adams, the master photographer of the American West, made small, soft-edged prints early in his career and high-contrast, large-scale prints later on. Michael Mattis, who with his wife, Judith Hochberg, owns the 41 early Adams prints (1920s to 1950s) now at the Long Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages, compares the early prints to chamber music and the later ones to brass bands. (The analogies are apt, since Adams, who died at 82 in 1984, started out as a concert pianist.)

headline: Campus ‘Safe Spaces’
text: Readers discuss whether colleges should be protecting students from distressing ideas.

headline: Stand Up for Your Cats
text: TAYLOR SWIFT, I salute you.

headline: Ready for 45?
text: MIAMI — JAMES BAKER can take credit for two presidencies and one vice presidency in the Bush family.

headline: What Starbucks Is Ditching Along With CDs
text: I CURRENTLY possess around six large moving boxes of compact discs tossed beneath a tarp in the dank cellar of my apartment building. Since 1999, I have been receiving promotional copies of CDs, an occupational hazard of my job as a professional music critic.

headline: The Method to Obama’s Middle East Mess
text: LET’S recap the state of America’s commitments in the Middle East. Our military is fighting in a tacit alliance with Iranian proxies in Iraq, even as it assists in a campaign against Iranian-backed forces in Yemen. We are formally committed to regime change in Syria, but we’re intervening against the regime’s Islamist enemies. Our strongest allies, officially, are still Israel and Saudi Arabia, but we’re busy alienating them by pushing for détente with Iran. And please don’t mention Libya or Al Qaeda — you’ll confuse everyone even more.

headline: Pregnant, Obese ... and in Danger
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — ONE recent night on my delivery shift, eight out of 10 of my laboring patients were too heavy, with two weighing over 300 pounds.

headline: Progress on Payday Lending
text: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took the most important step in its brief four-year history this week when it issued a preliminary proposal aimed at protecting the working poor from the payday lending industry, which bills itself as a source of “easy” short-term loans but earns its profits by luring borrowers into debt traps. If finalized, rules based on this proposal would protect millions of people from deceptive, predatory loans that can wreck their already fragile finances. The bureau could better protect consumers by closing one loophole that would allow some lenders of relatively small amounts to keep making high-cost loans.

headline: Preparing for Tomorrow’s Storms
text: Californians are understandably focused on the state’s severe drought, now in its fourth year. But drought is not the only environmental risk the state’s residents face.

headline: Afghanistan’s Next Chapter
text: Now that President Obama has decided to slow the withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan, he and the new Afghan president, Ashraf Ghani, have an obligation to prove that the additional American investment will be worth it. It will not be easy, and it may not be possible. For more than a decade, the Afghan government has stubbornly resisted taking most of the political, economic and military steps needed to put the country on a firm footing.

headline: Why Reconstruction Matters
text: THE surrender of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee at Appomattox Court House, 150 years ago next month, effectively ended the Civil War. Preoccupied with the challenges of our own time, Americans will probably devote little attention to the sesquicentennial of Reconstruction, the turbulent era that followed the conflict. This is unfortunate, for if any historical period deserves the label “relevant,” it is Reconstruction.

headline: Katherine Meyer
text: Katherine Meyer is a Washington, D.C.-based lawyer who specializes in animal welfare, advocating on behalf of circus elephants, sea turtles and wild horses.

headline: A Little Respect for Dr. Foster
text: ONE sign of a landmark shift in public attitudes: A poll last year found that Americans approved more of gays and lesbians (53 percent) than of evangelical Christians (42 percent).

headline: Trying to Fool Cancer
text: CLEVELAND — WHEN it airs on Monday, the Ken Burns-produced documentary “Cancer: The Emperor of All Maladies” will emphasize how much more we now know about the genetic basis for cancer. This year, according to President Obama, cancer research and funding will focus on so-called precision, personalized or targeted medicine — using cancer’s molecular underpinnings to develop drugs that attack the genes or gene products that make up cancer’s factory while sparing normal cells. What a beautiful concept.

headline: Tweeting Mom’s Goodbye
text: My mother finally closed her eyes amid the grim bleats of the intensive care unit for a little sleep. I slipped my hand from hers and sat back. I picked up my phone to call my wife but saw it was 3 in the morning. I looked at emails, but didn’t really read them. Then I remembered something my mother had said a couple of hours before, as we knew our time together was winding down. It had made me smile; and now I sent out a tweet:

headline: To Longtime Geno Auriemma Assistant, There’s No Better Place Than UConn
text: ALBANY — It is the little things that have kept Chris Dailey by Geno Auriemma’s side for 29 years, and counting.

headline: Coffeehouses Where the Brew Is as Crucial as the Bean
text: On a recent Saturday afternoon, Jenna Martiello, 20, sipped a cup of coffee and admired the nearly six-foot tall roaster occupying center stage at Gentle Brew Coffee, a little coffeehouse in Long Beach. The stainless steel roaster with blue enamel accents was as shiny as a new car parked in a living room, surrounded by cafe tables, chairs and several armchairs.

headline: Plucking Notes, and Strings, of Long Ago
text: In 1640, Andreas Ruckers of Antwerp was producing harpsichords of such clarity and consistency that they were the envy of Northern Europe. Most of those harpsichords, like others of their vintage, have disappeared or been radically altered, sometimes with disastrous results.

headline: Man Killed by Bus at Port Authority Terminal Is Identified
text: A man struck and killed by a bus at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan this week was identified by the authorities on Saturday as Samuel Rodriguez, 67, of Garrison, N.Y.

headline: After Kleiner Trial, Expect Less Shooting From the Hip in Silicon Valley
text: SAN FRANCISCO — John Doerr really needed a win, and late Friday the esteemed venture capitalist got one of the biggest of his career: a jury’s complete dismissal of gender discrimination claims against his firm, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers.

headline: A Review of Falls Village Inn Restaurant in Connecticut
text: One of the most stately buildings in Falls Village in the town of Canaan is the Falls Village Inn, built in the Italianate style in 1834. Nine years ago, the former stagecoach stop closed, was sold, and then reopened in 2010.

headline: Playing Shortstop for the Mets, Wilmer Flores. Really? Yeah, Really.
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — A few weeks before spring training, Sandy Alderson, the Mets’ general manager, was summoned to jury duty at a Manhattan courthouse. At one point in the selection process, he was asked, “What do you do in your spare time?”

headline: Review: At Le Malt, Food Makes an Appearance but Cocktails Rule
text: Daylight saving time had just begun as I drove Route 1 to Le Malt early one evening, and the sun slanted over the strip malls. Heaps of exhaust-stained ice were melting, and one could have leapt for joy. But instead I walked into a windowless, beige bunker that, from the outside, looks like nothing so much as a strip club. I blinked hard, waited for my pupils to triple in diameter. Goodbye daylight, goodbye saving.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2015: Everyone Hates Puzzle 5
text: SPECIAL POST — It’s a well-known fact that many people competing in the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament consider Puzzle 5 to be their personal Rubicon. Anyone can fill in as many squares as possible in Puzzles 1-4. If you make it through the devilishly hard Puzzle 5, you’ve crossed the line into hardcore solving.

headline: No Winner or Loser When a No. 1 Pick Goes Under the Knife
text: In the movie “The Program,” Alvin Mack, a college linebacker played by the actor Duane Davis, appears destined for the N.F.L. That is, until a knee injury instantly rewrites his future. In a span of minutes, Mack goes from a potential first-round pick to a former player considering a future in coaching.

headline: Privatization Memories
text: Dave Weigel has one of the more interesting Harry Reid retrospectives, focusing on his role in fighting back Bush’s attempt to privatize Social Security — and in particular on the way he forged an alliance with liberal bloggers.

headline: Air Conditioning and the Rise of the South
text: Just a short further note on this subject. (If you’re wondering why I’m doing posting so much on a Saturday, I’m housebound with a cold, so why not?)

headline: Elite Chess Teams Reach Final Four, Which Should Be a Quiet Affair
text: Elite college basketball programs are battling in the N.C.A.A. tournament this weekend to reach the Final Four. For fans of chess, the top four teams are squaring off now.

headline: Henrik Lundqvist’s Return to Rangers Is Ruined by Bruins
text: BOSTON — Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist had waited almost two months for this day. Sidelined by a serious neck injury, he had gone through a couple of practices this week and was cleared to start Saturday against the Bruins.

headline: Moving Onward With Cool Passion
text: Glaciers can be cool and awesome as they move inexorably onward. That may also describe Liz Gerring’s “glacier,” as presented by her Liz Gerring Dance Company. Neither a choreographic travelogue nor a geological survey, Ms. Gerring’s abstract dance demands cool passion of its eight dancers, requiring them to move with unbroken stamina but often at a far from glacial pace. Although it has nothing to do with ice and snow, “glacier” may nonetheless convey a sense of an awesome territory. Ms. Gerring has said that one of her inspirations was a memory of a visit to the vast North Dakota prairie where her mother grew up. Michael J. Schumacher’s taped score combines instruments like guitar, harp, cello, clarinet, recorder and piano with natural sounds recorded during a residency at Glacier Lake in Colorado. (Tuesday and Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Thursday at 8 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue at 19th Street, Chelsea; 212-242-0800, joyce.org.)

headline: Neglected No More, A Rich Latin Legacy
text: Preparing for the Museum of Modern Art’s “Latin America in Construction: Architecture 1955-1980,” which opens on Sunday, was a process of excavation. Barry Bergdoll, who organized the show with Carlos Eduardo Comas, Patricio del Real and Jorge Francisco Liernur, made multiple visits to the region, scouring architects’ offices, tracking down architects’ descendants and borrowing material from state archives.

headline: A Last Call For ‘Cougar Town’
text: In the world of television, being flashy and new gets you attention. So does being dumb and tasteless. But what keeps TV percolating are the shows that fit neither profile; they’re just reliably good week after week, season after season. One of those, “Cougar Town,” has its final episode at 10:30 on Tuesday night on TBS.

headline: Hollywood Hero Of the Second Rank
text: He wasn’t ever as front-tier as Cary Grant or Jimmy Stewart, but Joel McCrea shared the same camera-ready ease and light touch that defined Hollywood’s biggest stars as the studio system hit its stride in the 1930s and ’40s. While directors from Alfred Hitchcock (“Foreign Correspondent”) to Preston Sturges — “Sullivan’s Travels” is, arguably, both men’s greatest film — sought him out, McCrea, a natural-born horseman, focused on westerns for the later years of his career.

headline: An Immersive History Lesson
text: The New Orleans-born pianist and singer Henry Butler, now in his mid-60s and a Brooklyn resident, delivers gigs as if they were full-immersion lessons: in old New Orleans repertory, gospel music, American theater songs, 1960s jazz, Southern rhythm and blues and soul. He’s a virtuosic pianist and a startling baritone singer; he’s inevitably the focus of whatever bands he plays in, and exactly the right performer to hear playing unaccompanied, tracing a casually authoritative history of American music. At Minton’s, the Harlem jazz club that has been tightening up its bookings in exciting ways, he’ll play on April 16, with sets at 7 p.m. and 11 p.m. (206 West 118th Street, 212-243-2222; mintonsharlem.com.)

headline: A Worshiper At Bach’s Altar
text: “People are religious or not, but Bach makes you believe in something, and for sure,” Lisa Batiashvili, the Georgian star violinist, said in a recent interview. A frequent guest soloist with the New York Philharmonic, she is the orchestra’s artist in residence this season. The run of concerts, conducted by Alan Gilbert, that begins on April 8 has a special significance for her. It features the music of Bach, which she only recently recorded after a long period of awe-struck distance, and brings her together, in Bach’s gorgeous Concerto for Violin and Oboe, with her husband, the marvelous oboist François Leleux.

headline: 7 Wounded in Spring Break Shooting in Florida
text: Spring break turned bloody when seven people in their early 20s were shot with a .40-caliber handgun early Saturday at a house in Panama City Beach, Fla. The shootings were described on an official Facebook page for Frank McKeithen, the Bay County sheriff.

headline: Portraying Bill Bradley, a Star Who Had a Sense of Where He Was
text: As Harvard and Yale played for the Ivy League men’s basketball title earlier this month at the Palestra in Philadelphia, the writer John McPhee, 84, was a block away at Franklin Field. As a faculty fellow of Princeton’s men’s lacrosse team — “which means,” he said, “I stand around looking interested” — he watched the Tigers beat the Penn Quakers, 17-11.

headline: Speed on Display at Retooled IndyCar
text: The IndyCar season finally arrives this weekend with a street race in St. Petersburg, Fla., featuring a familiar-looking cast of drivers but an array of perhaps less familiar Chevrolet- and Honda-powered machines.

headline: For Golden State Warriors, Winning Isn’t the Only Thing
text: MEMPHIS — What is most remarkable about the Golden State Warriors’ season has nothing to do with their N.B.A.-best record or their league-leading shooting percentages or the ease with which they regularly dismantle opposing teams of highly paid professionals.

headline: A Franchise-Changing Player
text: Connor McDavid is only 18, but he is already being compared to some of the sport‘s best players.

headline: Hockey’s Next Great One Draws a Crowd
text: ERIE, Pa. — For Connor McDavid, an 18-year-old center for the Erie Otters of the Ontario Hockey League and the most anticipated N.H.L. prospect in decades, compliments accrue as steadily as goals and assists.

headline: Insurgents Seize Much of Key Syrian City
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A coalition of Islamist insurgents, including a branch of Al Qaeda, seized most of the northern Syrian city of Idlib on Saturday after four days of heavy fighting. It was an unusually dramatic front-line shift in a four-year war that has long appeared to be at a stalemate even as it grows more bloody and complex.

headline: Big Decision (and Plenty of Advice) for Hockey Prospect
text: BOSTON — The image is a lasting one for David Quinn. He recalls a somewhat disheveled and unusually conversant Phil Kessel making a surprising confession during the 2007 world hockey championships.

headline: California, Here I Come
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle is a letter-insertion theme by Alan Arbesfeld, wherein the state abbreviation for California, CA, is inserted at various points in phrases (for you kids out there, “REALLY BIG SHEW” at 82 Across is how 1950s – ’60s television host Ed Sullivan used to introduce his weekly variety show, SHEW being a mispronunciation of “show.”)

headline: Tailoring His Message, Ted Cruz Makes His First Swing Through New Hampshire
text: GREENLAND, N.H. — When Senator Ted Cruz declared his candidacy for president, he said a broad coalition of “courageous conservatives” would carry him to the White House. On his first campaign swing through New Hampshire, a two-day trip that ended Saturday, he showed how he hoped to build that coalition.

headline: Liberia Recommends Ebola Survivors Practice Safe Sex Indefinitely
text: The Liberian government recommended on Saturday that survivors of Ebola practice safe sex indefinitely, until more information can be collected on the length of time the virus might remain present in body fluids including semen. Previously, male survivors were advised to abstain from sexual intercourse or to use condoms for three months, reflecting that the active virus had been detected for up to 82 days in semen.

headline: Wanted at the White House: A Fence That Says Halt! (With Curb Appeal)
text: WASHINGTON — Just after a Secret Service official shouted “Go!” and started a stopwatch, an agent hurtled toward a 10-foot-high fence with curving rods at the top.

headline: Tribes See Name on Oregon Maps as Being Out of Bounds
text: Grant County, a mountainous patch of eastern Oregon, has few Native Americans, but maps point to a different past, marking a spring, a rock, three meadows and several creeks with “squaw” in their names.

headline: Fragile Cease-Fire in Ukraine Inspires Little Confidence in West
text: BRUSSELS — No one really expects Ukraine to get better before it gets worse, or for the promises contained in last month’s cease-fire agreement to be kept.

headline: A Divided Nigeria Chooses Its President
text: Voters cast ballots in the most contested election in Nigeria’s post-independence history.

headline: A Franchise-Changing Player
text: Connor McDavid is only 18, but he is already being compared to some of the sport‘s best players.

headline: Before I Die
text: When doctors diagnosed Karly Koch with a rare genetic disorder, they also made a grim prognosis.

headline: To Avert Repeat of 2008, Clinton Team Hopes to Keep Bill at His Best
text: Bill Clinton’s hearing has faded. With his head of white hair and frail frame, he looks older than his 68 years — “truly grandfatherly,” as one friend said. He often jokes about what would happen if he were to “drop dead.”

headline: Iran’s Top Negotiator Says Accord Can Be Drafted
text: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — Iran’s chief diplomat said on Saturday that he had had productive discussions with his European counterparts and that Iranian negotiators were ready to begin drafting an initial agreement on a nuclear accord.

headline: In a Win Over Arizona, a Resounding Repeat for Wisconsin
text: LOS ANGELES — It felt familiar, on both ends of the court and across the spectrum of emotions.

headline: Months Before East Village Blast, Utility Found Gas Line Was Tapped in Dangerous Way
text: More than seven months before an explosion and fire destroyed three buildings in the East Village on Thursday, utility workers discovered that the gas line to a restaurant in one of them had been tapped in a dangerous way, Consolidated Edison and the restaurant’s owner said on Saturday.

headline: Germanwings Crash Raises Questions About Shifting Ideas of Pilot Fitness
text: Aviation agencies in Europe and the United States once banned all pilots from flying if they disclosed a mental illness to their employers.

headline: Teenagers Face Early Death, on Their Terms
text: Tumors had disfigured AshLeigh McHale’s features and spread to her organs. A year ago, AshLeigh, 17, flew from her home in Catoosa, Okla., to the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., with a thread-thin hope of slowing her melanoma.

headline: Residents in Eastern Ukraine City Rally Against Separatism
text: DNEPROPETROVSK, Ukraine — Residents of this city held what they called a “unity rally” on Saturday meant to help mend a rift between President Petro O. Poroshenko and the regional governor he fired and ease worries that Ukraine, on top of everything else, is also now at risk of unraveling into privately ruled fiefs.

headline: Louisville Coach Rick Pitino Keeps Recalling How to Dream
text: SYRACUSE — Rick Pitino is 62 years old and has been a basketball coach since 1974. That is old enough to have had a handful of former players grow into established, veteran coaches. That is old enough to have a son as a coaching rival. It is old enough to have first sparred with the N.C.A.A. over allegations of recruiting violations 38 years ago — when the N.C.A.A.’s first president was in office.

headline: Haji Wright, a Rising 17-Year-Old American, Is Said to Join the Cosmos
text: As the goals piled up for Haji Wright, a rising star for the United States’ under-17 national team, the biggest question was whether he would continue his development in M.L.S. or leave for Europe.

headline: Duke Turns Up the Heat With a Slap of the Floor
text: HOUSTON — Its precise origin is ambiguous. Even the man who introduced the tradition at Duke does not remember when it began or who did it first.

headline: Australia to Join Regional Development Bank Led by China
text: BEIJING — Australia plans to join an Asian infrastructure bank led by China, the government announced on Sunday, reversing an earlier decision taken at the urging of the United States not to become a member. The move made Australia the latest of a list of major American allies to sign up.

headline: Vin Scelsa, Host of Radio’s ‘Idiot’s Delight,’ to Retire
text: Vin Scelsa, a master of free-form radio who has been a standby on New York radio stations for nearly 50 years, will retire on May 2 with the last installment of his long-running show, “Idiot’s Delight,” on WFUV, he announced on the air Saturday night.

headline: Despite Inexperience, Materiality Wins Florida Derby With Stretch Run
text: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla. — No horse that went unraced as a 2-year-old has won the Kentucky Derby since Apollo in 1882. Todd Pletcher, winner of a record seven Eclipse Awards as the leading trainer in North America, may have a horse capable of overcoming that daunting history.

headline: Almost 37-1, Kentucky Isn’t Done, Holding Off a Fearless Notre Dame
text: CLEVELAND — When the final buzzer sounded and the desperation heave by Jerian Grant had gone safely long, the Kentucky players swarmed off the bench to jump and hug their victorious teammates on the floor, a signal of how close they had come to heartbreak.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 28, 2015
text: March 28, 2015

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 29, 2015
text: “When I saw him as an adult compared to a youth, I thought, ‘He really amounted to something.’ He was confident, helpful. I thought, ‘Man, he’s someone who made it.’”

headline: New Path to the Same Spot for Arizona: Just Shy of the Final Four
text: LOS ANGELES — They played a game within the game Saturday at Staples Center. During breaks in the West Regional final between Wisconsin and Arizona, the giant video screens at midcourt showed two nearly identical pictures and asked, “What’s the difference?”

headline: Without Much Ado
text: Timepieces so perfectly minimal they leave you wanting for nothing.

headline: A Wedding Album to Savor
text: This month we asked our couples to dish about what they served at their receptions.

headline: Ashley Etienne and Nigel Stephens
text: Ashley Danielle Etienne and Nigel Audley Stephens were married Friday in Rock Creek Park in Washington by the Rev. Maxine Reed-Vance, a minister affiliated with Grace Baptist Church in Baltimore.

headline: Somjen Frazer and Andrea Bowen
text: Melanie Somjen Frazer and Andrea Majanik Bowen were married Saturday at St. Stephen and the Incarnation Episcopal Church in Washington. The Rev. Frank Dunn, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Kristen Tracey and John Davies
text: Kristen Hamelin Tracey, a daughter of Marcia J. Hamelin and Dennis H. Tracey III of Weston, Conn., was married Saturday to John Oliver Davies, the son of Rebecca B. Davies and David O. Davies of Irving, Tex. The Rev. Dr. Shane Scott-Hamblen performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Mary-in-the-Highlands, where he is the rector, in Cold Spring, N.Y.

headline: Deena Tauster, Peter Feldman
text: Deena Megan Tauster, the daughter of Michelle H. Tauster and Paul G. Tauster of Lido Beach, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Peter Garrett Feldman, a son of Lynn E. Feldman and Samuel F. Feldman of Allentown, Pa. Cantor Kevin Wartell officiated at the Park Hyatt in Washington.

headline: Geri Hirsch,  Darin Friedman
text: Geri Hirsch and Darin Michael Friedman were married Saturday evening at Kayne Griffin Corcoran, a contemporary art gallery in Los Angeles. Rabbi Ken Chasen officiated at the ceremony, which was led by Haley Gilbert Fisher, a friend of the bride’s family and a cantorial soloist.

headline: Nathan Cardin, Benjamin Procter
text: Nathan Benjamin Cardin and Benjamin Butin Procter were married Saturday evening at the Annenberg Community Beach House in Santa Monica, Calif. William Scott Calvert, a friend of the couple who was appointed a deputy marriage commissioner by the state, officiated.

headline: Sherry Shore, Auren Kule
text: Sherry Melissa Shore and Auren Justin Kule were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Gary M. Bretton-Granatoor at the St. Regis in New York.

headline: Laura Goldin, Kenneth Ames
text: Laura Rachael Goldin and Kenneth Scott Ames are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Shmuel Herzfeld at the Sixth & I Historic Synagogue in Washington.

headline: Amy Farkas, Samuel Levy
text: Amy Rachel Farkas and Samuel Paul Levy are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Mayer Perelmuter at Liberty House in Jersey City.

headline: Haley Moss, Asher Schranz
text: Dr. Haley Arden Moss and Dr. Asher Jacob Schranz are to be married Sunday by Rabbi William Berman at the Foundry, an event space in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: Emily Abate, Joshua Guttman
text: Emily Anne Abate and Joshua Lee Guttman are to be married Sunday at Pioneer Works, Center for Art and Innovation, in Red Hook, Brooklyn. Rabbi Amichai Lau-Lavie is to officiate.

headline: Lily Lorenzo, Bryan Boisi
text: Lily Elizabeth Lorenzo and Bryan Patrick Boisi were married Saturday at the Church of St. Thomas More in New York. The Rev. Edwin B. Diaz, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Emily Hom and John Le Gall
text: Emily Katherine Hom and Dr. John Brian Le Gall were married Saturday at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County in California. The officiant was Karen Chin, a cousin of the groom, who was temporarily appointed a deputy commissioner of civil marriages by Santa Clara County.

headline: Margaret Lam, Stanley Wong
text: Margaret Chiu-Leung Lam, the daughter of Christine C. Lam and Kin C. Lam of Boston, was married there Saturday evening to Stanley York Wong, the son of Elaine H. Wong and Norman S. Wong of Edison, N.J. The Rev. Enoch Y. Liao, a minister of the Boston Chinese Evangelical Church, officiated at the Lenox Hotel.

headline: Brittany Freda,  A.J. Somers
text: Brittany Michelle Freda and Alexander Justin Somers were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Yaron Kapitulnik at the Breakers in Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Joanna Lack and Brendan Lowe
text: Joanna Alexander Lack, the daughter of Pamela L. Goldman of Manhattan and Andrew R. Lack of Bronxville, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Brendan Robert Lowe, the son of Bettina C. Lowe and Dr. Michael R. Lowe of Cherry Hill, N.J. Rabbi Will Berkovitz officiated at Pioneer Works, Center for Art and Innovation, in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

headline: Lauren Loeb, Keith Doll
text: Lauren Joy Loeb and Keith Andrew Doll were married Saturday at the Reeds at Shelter Haven, a hotel resort and private events space in Stone Harbor, N.J. Carlos Cuartas, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Ariella Morrow and Ryan Tolkin
text: Ariella Sarette Morrow, a daughter of Livia F. Morrow and Joel I. Morrow of Merrick, N.Y., was married in Aspen, Colo., Saturday evening to Ryan Andrew Tolkin, a son of Maggie L. Tolkin and Bradley J. Tolkin of Brookville, N.Y. Rabbi Itzhak Vardy officiated at the St. Regis Aspen Resort.

headline: Friends, First and Always
text: Leah Frances Greenberg, a daughter of Sara B. Anderson and Mark H. Greenberg of Chevy Chase, Md., was married Saturday evening to Ezra Philip Levin, the son of Ronda Jones Levin of Buda, Tex., and Daniel D. Levin of Austin, Tex. The ceremony, at the Mexican Cultural Institute in Washington, was led by Tom Perriello, a former Virginia congressman who received authorization from the District of Columbia as a temporary officiant.

headline: Kezia McKeague, Eric Gettig
text: Kezia Frances McKeague and Eric Thomas Gettig were married Saturday at Dahlgren Chapel of the Sacred Heart on the campus of Georgetown University in Washington. The Rev. Salvador R. Jordan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Without David Villa, New York City F.C. Falls to Sporting K.C.
text: The atmosphere was different on Saturday at Yankee Stadium for New York City F.C.’s second home game. The buzz outside the stadium before the club’s March 15 home opener was missing this time, and with the upper deck closed and the stadium in its reduced soccer configuration, the match against Sporting Kansas City hardly felt like a special event.

headline: Neville Wakefield’s Many Muses
text: From the toy sailboats he made as a boy to the large-scale installations he’s overseen in his career, the art world curator credits his rural childhood and his own children for sharpening his keen aesthetic.

headline: Latin Glamour
text: Modern architects, artists and designers find inspiration in the colorful, sensuous landscapes and indigenous flora of the region south of the border.

headline: Loving the Unlovable Decade
text: Long derided as tacky and vulgar, the design of the ’70s is now a source of great inspiration.

headline: Air Canada Plane Lands Short of Runway in Nova Scotia
text: OTTAWA — An Air Canada Airbus A320 landed in an antenna array 1,100 feet short of a runway in Halifax, Nova Scotia, early Sunday morning, shearing off its landing gear, accident investigators said.

headline: Notre Dame Is Just the Latest to Almost Defeat Kentucky
text: CLEVELAND — The most consistent lament of Kentucky’s opponents this season has been, “Almost.”

headline: Corrections: March 29, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) GOING CLEAR: SCIENTOLOGY AND THE PRISON OF BELIEF (2015) The Oscar-winning documentarian Alex Gibney directs this film about the Church of Scientology, based on Lawrence Wright’s book “Going Clear.” Details about the church (above, its building in Los Angeles), which was founded by the science-fiction writer L. Ron Hubbard, are revealed through profiles and interviews with former members including the Oscar-winning screenwriter Paul Haggis. “Drawing from a trove of archival material, including filmed interviews with Mr. Hubbard, Mr. Gibney paints a profile of a church that grew by leaps and bounds through profound faith and drag-out fights,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Mr. Gibney spends a lot of time on Scientology’s celebrities, but those sections of the film pale next to the harrowing allegations of the church’s serious physical and psychological abuse, including exploited labor.”

headline: Beef Ban in India Reaches Into Cages of Lions and Tigers
text: MUMBAI, India — Palash, the largest tiger at the Sanjay Gandhi National Park in Mumbai, still paces his cage for the hour leading up to dinner and still pounces on his meal when his handlers lift the gate to his feeding room. But lately what the 440-pound feline finds is not his usual 15 pounds of raw beef, fresh from the slaughter.

headline: For Hardware Makers, Sharing Their Secrets Is Now Part of the Business Plan
text: Facebook showed plans last week for drone aircraft that beam lasers conveying high-speed data to remote parts of the world.

headline: Singapore’s Lee Kuan Yew, in His Own Words
text: The founder and first prime minister of Singapore, Lee Kuan Yew, was known for his blunt and pithy honesty, died in March 23 at the age of 91. Below are some of his memorable quotes.

headline: Singaporeans and World Leaders Gather for Final Farewell to Lee Kuan Yew
text: SINGAPORE — Thousands of Singaporeans braved a torrential downpour on Sunday for a final farewell to the country’s founding prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew, whose funeral drew a long list of leaders and dignitaries from across the globe.

headline: 1940: Russell Refutes Nudism Charge
text: NEW YORK — Bertrand Russell, British philosopher and peer, whose appointment as professor on the faculty of the New York City College was confirmed by the Board of Higher Education March 19 after a state-wide controversy, today [March 29] emphatically denied that he had ever conducted a nudist colony in England or gone in for salacious poetry, in answering charges made against him by Mrs. Jean Kay, wife of a Brooklyn dentist. After the board upheld the appointment by an 11-to-3 vote, Mrs. Kay, who said she was acting for irate taxpayers, gave the board eight days in which to show the action was not ‘‘contrary to the public interest,’’ before she resorted to legal action.

headline: The Truck That Sparked Our Marriage Back to Life
