text: When my husband was transferred back to the United States for work after we had been living in Germany for four years, we bought a house and moved in with our children and our dog. My parents donated their used minivan to our family cause, and we parked it in our new driveway, exhaling with relief. Life would be so much easier now, I thought.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2015: Headed to the Big Boards
text: SPECIAL POST — Good morning! As the bleary-eyed competitors file into the ballroom at the Stamford Marriott, the large, final round boards are being built in a staging room behind the scenes.

headline: Question in Boston Bombing Trial: For Tsarnaev to Testify or Not
text: BOSTON — He swaggers into the courtroom. Freed of handcuffs and leg manacles, he occasionally taps the witness box on his way to the defense table, where he takes his place between two lawyers. During most of the proceedings, he slouches in his chair like a bored student, picking at his goatee, his mind somewhere else.

headline: An ‘Ask Me Anything’ Chat on Climate Science and Coverage
text: The event described below has taken place and the video is now posted here:

headline: Citi Bike Resumes Service After Weekend Maintenance
text: New York City’s bike-sharing program was up and running on Sunday after abruptly shutting down for part of the weekend.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2015: The Tension Mounts
text: SPECIAL POST — It’s currently unconfirmed, but the buzz amongst the judges is that there might be an upset in the top ranks.

headline: Rising From Wreckage, Australia Sweeps to World Cup Title
text: Australia completed its climb from the depths to the heights of world cricket on Sunday when it won its fifth World Cup, defeating New Zealand by seven wickets in the final at the Melbourne Cricket Ground.

headline: Arab Nations to Form Military Force to Counter Iran and Islamist Extremists
text: CAIRO — The Arab states said on Sunday that they had agreed to form a combined military force to counter both Iranian influence and Islamist extremism, a gesture many analysts attributed in large part to their drive for more independence from Washington.

headline: Flea Theater Names Niegel Smith as Next Artistic Director
text: The Flea Theater, an Off Off Broadway company that proudly embraces being named for an irksome insect, has chosen a new artistic director who promises to continue producing risky theater while also seeking to reach out to families when the organization moves into a new TriBeCa home.

headline: Talking Econoheads
text: A couple of events I was involved in are now online:

headline: 1965: Pope Seeks Urgent Review of Birth Control Ban
text: VATICAN CITY — Pope Paul VI has called for utmost urgency in reviewing the Catholic ban on birth control because ‘‘the church cannot ignore’’ the population explosion, the Vatican reported  today [March 29]. The pontiff, in a speech to his secret birth-control commission, said the church must give ‘‘absolutely clear indications’’ on the controversial issue. The Pope stressed that the church owes an answer to the world and to men and women whose married life is too often impeded by uncertainties from developing ‘‘according to the design of God.’’ Pope Paul told over 50 members of the international commission on Saturday to ‘‘let mature what must mature, but you must understand the anguish of many souls. Work diligently without attention to criticism and  difficulty.’’ He added that the church at all times took care to give an adequate reply to the great problems facing men. The Vatican communiqué, released today, revealed that there were three married couples as well as other laymen on the commission,  which includes doctors, psychologists, sociologists, population  and family planning experts and theologians. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 30, 1965.

headline: Pratt Institute to Offer Master’s With a Focus on Public Space
text: Pratt Institute’s Architecture School this fall plans to start a master’s program in “Urban Placemaking and Management,” led by David Burney, the city’s former commissioner in the department of design and construction.

headline: After Outcry Over Pink Sculpture, Queens Councilman Wants Public Hearing on City Art Plans
text: After an outcry over a plan to install a boldly colored, government-financed sculpture in Queens, a councilman intends to submit a bill to the City Council this week that would allow for more public comment on public art commissions.

headline: Gene Saks, Tony-Winning Director of Neil Simon Hits, Dies at 93
text: Gene Saks, an actor who switched to stage and film directing in midcareer, winning three Tony Awards and becoming the leading interpreter of the plays of Neil Simon, died on Saturday at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 93.

headline: O’Malley Speaks Out Against Possible Dynastic Rematch for White House
text: Former Gov. Martin O’Malley of Maryland, who has been promoting himself to Democrats as a potential alternative to Hillary Rodham Clinton in the 2016 race for the White House, on Sunday spoke out against the possibility of a dynastic rematch between Mrs. Clinton and Jeb Bush.

headline: Family-Friendly ‘Home’ Takes Top Box Office Spot
text: The crude “Get Hard,” a Warner Bros. effort described by some critics as homophobic and borderline racist, was cowed at the weekend box office by “Home,” a family-friendly adventure from DreamWorks Animation.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2015: And the Winner Is …
text: SPECIAL POST — Congratulations to Dan Feyer, the winner of the 38th American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, as well as to all who came to Stamford, Connecticut to be part of the fun. Dan took the championship away from Tyler Hinman yet again, with just a half second lead. That’s about as exciting as it gets without a total upset.

headline: Cyclone Roller Coaster at Coney Island Gets Stuck at Top of Track
text: The Cyclone roller coaster at Coney Island got stuck near the top of its track on Sunday, marring its season debut and forcing passengers to walk down the tracks to safety, an amusement park official said.

headline: Sullivan Fortner Wins 2015 Cole Porter Fellowship in Jazz
text: Sullivan Fortner has won the 2015 Cole Porter Fellowship in Jazz, presented by the American Pianists Association. The honor was awarded on Saturday night at the Hilbert Circle Theater in Indianapolis, after a final round of performances by the five finalists in competition. As the winner, Mr. Fortner will receive $50,000, the opportunity to record for Mack Avenue Records, and two years of professional career services and development.

headline: Before Starbucks, a Bronx Cafe Blended Coffee and Racial Dialogue
text: Vernicia Colon did not know whether to be angry, amused or flattered when Starbucks announced its campaign to prompt barista-led conversations on race. She knew the complexities of being an overlooked “other” in the usual black-white discussions, and not just because she is the child of a Puerto Rican mother and a black father.

headline: Boehner Reflects on Bipartisan Support for Medicare Bill
text: Lately, in the House of Representatives, all it takes to claim a major success is a bill passed with support from both Republicans and Democrats.

headline: Operation Dragoon Ride
text: The commander of United States Army forces in Europe conceived of the convoy as people in Poland and elsewhere grew increasingly anxious about Russia’s intentions amid the long conflict in Ukraine.

headline: An American Military Convoy in Europe Aims to Reassure Allies
text: DRAWSKO POMORSKIE, Poland — The line of 4-year-olds clutched hands tightly in their matching, reflective yellow vests and stared open-mouthed at the hovering Chinook helicopters kicking up grit last week in the school parking lot. Shy teenage girls took pictures beside grinning American soldiers while Polish families clambered over a line of Stryker armored vehicles.

headline: Two Bodies Recovered at East Village Explosion Site
text: As firefighters worked on Sunday afternoon to pull two bodies from the scene of an explosion that demolished three buildings in the East Village, a brother of one of the men reported missing in the blast urged his friends and relatives not to give up hope.

headline: Germanwings Crash Investigators Sorting Through Physical and Psychological Clues
text: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — As aviation experts in the French Alps piece together the shattered fragments of the Germanwings jetliner that crashed there on Tuesday, investigators here are engaged in a task that is at least as challenging: trying to understand what drove Andreas Lubitz, who was at the controls, to the apparent decision to fly the plane into a mountainside.

headline: Review: ‘So You’ve Been Publicly Shamed’ Delves Into Infamy in the Age of Social Media
text: One of the people Jon Ronson interviewed for his latest book asked him a tough question. “Given that my previous books were about such frivolous topics as military psychics (‘The Men Who Stare at Goats’) and conspiracy theorists (‘Them: Adventures With Extremists’), why did I suppose my readers would be interested in the important question of public shaming?” Mr. Ronson was asked. Since his writerly persona is that of a stellar entertainer-explorer-clown, humiliation does seem weightier and less breezy than what he usually likes to handle.

headline: Jacoby Swiss Teams Winners at the Spring Nationals
text: On March 22, the final day of the Spring Nationals in New Orleans, the Jacoby Swiss Teams was captured by Richie Schwartz of Aventura, Fla.; Allan Graves of St. Johnsbury, Vt.; Boye Brogeland and Espen Lindqvist from Norway; and Lotan Fisher and Ron Schwartz from Israel.

headline: Michigan State Outlasts Louisville to Advance to the Final Four
text: SYRACUSE — The moment was worth savoring, so Michigan State stayed on the court long after the final buzzer sounded, the nets came down and Travis Trice’s back began tightening up enough to almost double him over. Matt Costello skipped around, and Lourawls Nairn Jr. wept. They stayed until there was no one left to hug. Then they went into the locker room and hugged some more.

headline: Laura Marling Bids Goodbye to All That
text: The British singer-songwriter has always been precocious, down to her (very productive) midlife crisis at 23.

headline: Review: A Present-Day ‘Parsifal’ With a Nod to the Past
text: BERLIN — Dmitri Tcherniakov’s suggestive yet stolid production of Wagner’s “Parsifal,” which opened on Saturday at the Staatsoper here, doesn’t begin in a forest, as the libretto indicates. But it otherwise conforms to the description provided in the text: a scene “shady and solemn, but not gloomy.” The audience enters with the curtain already up on a great hall lined with columns joined by high arches, the smoky air cut by a thick shaft of afternoon light.

headline: Review: Title Fight Trades Urgency for Depth at Webster Hall
text: Toward the end of Title Fight’s Friday night set at Webster Hall, Ned Russin, one of the band’s two singers, introduced “Rose of Sharon,” a song from the band’s new album, with a bit of hushed reverence.

headline: Review: ‘The Tempest Songbook’ Closes Gotham Chamber Opera’s Season
text: When the New York City Opera closed in 2013, talk soon started within opera circles about which smaller companies might be able to fill the void. There was special focus on the enterprising Gotham Chamber Opera. But its directors said that they had to be careful not to build beyond the company’s means.

headline: Globally Minded Books Win Bancroft Prize
text: Books on the international cotton trade and on the shipboard slave revolt that inspired Herman Melville’s short story “Benito Cereno” have won this year’s Bancroft Prize, considered one of the most prestigious honors in writing about history. Sven Beckert’s “Empire of Cotton: A Global History,” published by Alfred A. Knopf, was cited as “a masterful achievement in the burgeoning field of the study of capitalism.” It was researched in archives on four continents, to provide a deeper understanding of the commodity that shaped the story of slavery, the Civil War and Reconstruction. Greg Grandin’s “Empire of Necessity: Slavery, Freedom, and Deception in the New World,” published by Metropolitan Books/Henry Holt, was similarly cited for its effort to “decenter the history of African slavery in the Americas,” while also telling a gripping story of the complex processes that brought a crew of New England seal hunters “into fateful contact with a Spanish ship under the invisible control of the enslaved men and women it was supposed to be transporting.” The prize, which comes with a $10,000 award, was established in 1948 by the Columbia University trustees with a bequest from the historian Frederic Bancroft.

headline: At Yale, a New Home for Lincoln Portraits
text: The rare book and manuscript library at Yale has bought a vast private collection of photographs devoted primarily to Lincoln and the Civil War.

headline: Yale’s Beinecke Library Buys Vast Collection of Lincoln Photos
text: Abraham Lincoln last visited New Haven in March 1860, when, as a likely presidential candidate, he gave a speech on slavery. He is now set for a triumphal return.

headline: ‘Hot Bench,’ a Court Show From Judge Judy, Is a Surprise Hit
text: LOS ANGELES — A plaintiff shuffled onto a courtroom set at Sunset Bronson Studios here with a simple complaint. She had lent money to a shady guy who — shocker — turned out to be a total deadbeat.

headline: Review: Miami City Ballet in ‘Heatscape,’ a Fleeting Chase of Romance
text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — No ballet by the 27-year-old choreographer Justin Peck is much like another; with each assignment he sets himself new choreographic hurdles. But Mr. Peck has quickly become the most eminent choreographer of ballet in the United States — and two particular characteristics have propelled him to the top: the exciting formal architecture of his dances and the kinesthetic thrill of his movement.

headline: Review: In ‘Weird Loners,’ Four Single New Yorkers Dodge Commitment
text: Among television’s current epidemics — zombies, serial killers, reality-show families with gigantic numbers of children — one is easy to overlook: rootless single characters reluctant to commit to love or anything else. “Undateable.” “About a Boy.” The recently departed “Mulaney.” And so on.

headline: Review: ‘The Dovekeepers,’ a CBS Mini-Series Starring Cote de Pablo
text: Whatever happened to Ziva? Those still wondering can rest easy. She has been located on a mountaintop in the first century A.D.

headline: 2016 Hopefuls and Wealthy Are Aligned on Inequality
text: Appearing at a candidate forum in late January, three likely Republican presidential contenders — Senators Ted Cruz, Marco Rubio and Rand Paul — all made a striking confession: They considered “the increasing gap between rich and poor” to be a problem.

headline: No Net Ensnares Me
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — Bruce Haight seems to be vying with Elizabeth Gorski for the title of grid artist, albeit in 15×15 grids. Today, Mr. Haight takes flight with a puzzle that is all about our avian friends. Either that, or he’s launched a whole lot of boomerangs. I’m going to go with the bird theory.

headline: News Companies See Movies as Opportunity for Growth
text: LOS ANGELES — When the digital wizards at a forward-leaning media company last year introduced their newest idea, an entertainment unit, they couldn’t resist an antique touch: “BuzzFeed Motion Pictures” arrived with a video logo modeled on images from a primitive movie projector called a zoopraxiscope, invented by one Eadweard Muybridge, circa 1879.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of March 30
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: A Deadline for Greece, and U.S. Jobs Data
text: Here are some of the top business stories to pay attention to in the coming week.

headline: Share the Pork, Be President for Life
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Republic of Congo’s ruling party just joined the long list of regimes in Africa that are pushing to change constitutions to alter term limits and permit sitting leaders to extend their stays in office. The country’s 2002 Constitution limits the number of presidential terms to two. Now the Congolese Labor Party has had second thoughts, and is seeking to amend the law so that, the opposition says, President Denis Sassou Nguesso will be able to run for a third term.

headline: In Delaying Vote on Loretta Lynch as Attorney General, G.O.P. Is in a Quandary
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans bolted for a two-week spring recess with the confirmation of Loretta E. Lynch as attorney general in jeopardy, and themselves in a quandary: Accept a qualified nominee they oppose because she backs President Obama’s policies or reject her and live with an attorney general they despise, Eric H. Holder Jr.

headline: Uzbeks Vote on Expected 4th Term for Authoritarian Leader
text: TASHKENT, Uzbekistan — Uzbeks went to the polls in droves on Sunday for an election in which the result was a foregone conclusion: maintaining President Islam Karimov in power in the authoritarian Central Asian state, which he has led since 1989.

headline: Austerity, Big and Small
text: At this point it’s fairly common to look at the effects of austerity via cross-country scatterplots: one axis shows some measure of fiscal consolidation, while the other shows the change in GDP. Who started this practice? I think I did, here, although I’m happy to cede credit to someone else if I missed it.

headline: Duke Defeats Gonzaga to Advance to Its 16th Final Four
text: HOUSTON — Every day for the last two years, Quinn Cook has thought about one game, and it is not a game that he enjoys reliving. He remembers the confetti falling and Louisville celebrating and his Duke teammates consoling one another. Their faces, the sadness, he will never forget.

headline: On Obama Delaying the Afghanistan Pullout
text: President Obama has decided to slow the withdrawal of troops from the country.

headline: Official Says Commander of Group That Massacred 21 in Tunisia Is Dead
text: TUNIS — Tunisian security forces have killed the commander of the group responsible for the recent massacre of 21 foreign tourists at the National Bardo Museum, Tunisia’s prime minister, Habib Essid, announced on Sunday.

headline: Grown-Ups Get Out Their Crayons
text: It may surprise fans of Johanna Basford’s intricately hand-drawn coloring books that the artist is, by her own admission, “pretty bad” at coloring.

headline: Secrecy on the Set: Hollywood Embraces Digital Security
text: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, Lulu Zezza has played one of the toughest roles in Hollywood.

headline: Which States Make Life Easier or Harder for Illegal Immigrants
text: How different laws affect unauthorized immigrants in each state.

headline: States Are Divided by the Lines They Draw on Immigration
text: Washington has long allowed immigrants without legal status to get driver’s licenses. So Ofelia Rosas Ramos, a Mexican living illegally in Seattle, has had her license since 2008.

headline: So Far, So Good: Alex Rodriguez Has Been on His Best Behavior
text: KISSIMMEE, Fla. — When Baltimore Orioles Manager Buck Showalter was asked his assessment of Alex Rodriguez, who had homered against his team Saturday, he paused to think. He asked some questions of his own. He offered a quip.

headline: New York State’s Medical Marijuana Rules Shaping Up as Unusually Restrictive
text: ALBANY — When New York State’s lawmakers were mulling legalizing the medical use of marijuana last summer, some proponents feared that the proposed law was so restrictive that it would prevent many patients from receiving the drug.

headline: Diversity in the Toss-Up States
text: Should Jeb Bush or Scott Walker become the Republican presidential nominee, their paths to victory would look very different.

headline: Conservative Alliance Gains in French Voting
text: PARIS — The clear winner in the second round of France’s local elections on Sunday was an alliance of conservative parties that took control of at least two-thirds of the country’s departments, trouncing the Socialists.

headline: Foreclosure to Home Free, as 5-Year Clock Expires
text: MIAMI — In September, Susan Rodolfi celebrated an unusual anniversary: five years of missed mortgage payments.

headline: Jeb Bush and Scott Walker Point G.O.P. to Contrary Paths
text: HUDSON, N.H. — As Jeb Bush mingled with Hispanic workers on a company tour a few weeks ago on his first trip here as an all-but-declared candidate for president, he was able to guess the region in Colombia where one woman was born just from hearing her accent.

headline: A Carriage Horse Driver’s Viewpoint
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Shooters Can’t See? Fans, Cover Your Eyes
text: HOUSTON — A huge black curtain looms at each end of the raised court, creating an illusion that players are launching jump shots deep into another galaxy. Lights appear to give off an unusually strong glare, as if signaling a tavern’s last call or the intermission of a play.

headline: Germanwings Crash Settlements Are Likely to Vary by Passenger Nationality
text: The extraordinary circumstances that led to last week’s crash of the Germanwings jet, where a pilot seemingly brought down an airplane, killing everyone aboard, means that the airline’s insurers could end up paying hundreds of millions of dollars to the victims’ families, according to legal experts.

headline: Popular Demand
text: Worldwide revenue in February for digital console games, which covers downloadable content played on machines like Playstation or Xbox connected to TV monitors, was $233 million, down 3.7 percent from February 2014.

headline: Bumpy Road for Bill to Ban Credit Checks for Job Applicants
text: For nearly a year now, advocates for struggling New Yorkers have argued that the stars were aligned for passage of a powerful pro-worker statute: A law that would prohibit employers from denying jobs to applicants with poor credit histories.

headline: Rangers Fall Flat at the End of a Lost Weekend
text: After a game to forget Saturday in Boston and a lackluster third period Sunday, the Rangers find themselves suddenly mired in a rare losing streak.

headline: Jet Crash Tests Germany’s Faith in Its Precision
text: BERLIN — Even in the nightmarish immediate aftermath of the plane crash in the French Alps on Tuesday, Carsten Spohr, the former pilot who runs Germany’s Lufthansa airline, was sure of one thing: the co-pilot, Andreas Lubitz, 27, was “100 percent” fit to fly.

headline: Iran Backs Away From Key Detail in Nuclear Deal
text: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — With a negotiating deadline just two days away, Iranian officials on Sunday backed away from a critical element of a proposed nuclear agreement, saying they are no longer willing to ship their atomic fuel out of the country.

headline: With Late Surge, South Carolina Earns Its First Final Four Berth
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — There are only a handful of elite programs in women’s college basketball, and every year, it seems, those same teams run through the N.C.A.A. tournament on the way to the round of 8 and the Final Four.

headline: Win Is a Win, as the Nets Continue a Playoff Push
text: The Nets met the Los Angeles Lakers, one of the worst teams in the N.B.A., at Barclays Center on Sunday and had somewhat more trouble than they would have liked on their way to a 107-99 victory. But as they approach their final 10 games, tussling for one of the last playoff spots in the Eastern Conference, they will take every victory they can get, pretty or not.

headline: Missouri Candidate Picks Up Where She Left Off After Rival’s Suicide
text: SPRINGFIELD, Mo. — Ever since Tom Schweich, Missouri’s auditor and a candidate for the Republican nomination for governor, took his own life in late February, his leading primary opponent, Catherine Hanaway, has quietly avoided the campaign trail.

headline: Woman Killed in Kabul Transformed From Pariah to Martyr
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In indignant tones, the Islamic law student told her family about the superstitious practices she had witnessed earlier that day at a historic shrine in Kabul.

headline: In Westchester, a Skinny House With Big Aims Vies for a Spot in History
text: MAMARONECK, N.Y. — The red-shingled house on Grand Street shares several attributes with its neighbors. It has three stories, a full basement, hardwood floors and a neat yard.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 30, 2015
text: “The court will proceed to gargle in an effort to remove the lingering bad taste.”

headline: Indiana Governor Says Legislators May Clarify Religious Beliefs Law
text: Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana, moving to address a growing political firestorm over a religious freedom law enacted last week, said over the weekend that he would seek legislation to clarify the intent of the law, and rejected assertions that it sanctioned discrimination against gays and lesbians.

headline: Turkey Moves to Close All Gates at Border With Syria
text: ISTANBUL — After maintaining an open-door policy throughout the four-year conflict in neighboring Syria, Turkey has moved this month to close the two remaining border gates between the countries, shutting out displaced Syrian refugees amid fears of a potential terrorist attack.

headline: Wisconsin’s Frank Kaminsky Hopes for a Hollywood Ending
text: LOS ANGELES — An ascendant star heads west, with his best friends in tow, to Tinseltown, where boom times and madcap adventures await. As that star, Frank Kaminsky, winds down his Wisconsin basketball career, his life has begun to resemble one of his favorite television series, “Entourage,” right down to the guest appearance by a celebrity playing himself.

headline: Review: ‘Twelfth Night,’ in Two Plays, Blurs Identity
text: Every so often, evidence arises that acting might just be the most satisfying profession on the planet. Take the company called Bedlam, which is putting on not one but two inspired productions of Shakespeare’s “Twelfth Night” in a small and airless room in the garment district that seats about 50, and making you feel like its members are the luckiest people alive.

headline: Russian Theater Director Fired for Offending Christians
text: MOSCOW — In the latest skirmish between the Russian Orthodox Church and the cultural elite, the culture minister on Sunday fired the director of a Siberian theater who included a controversial interpretation of the life of Jesus in the Richard Wagner opera “Tannhauser.”

headline: ‘The Good Wife’ Recap: Absence of Yes
text: Season 6, Episode 17: Undisclosed Recipients

headline: Bronx Son of Yankees Fans Rekindles Father’s Dream With the Mets
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — It’s been a long road from the Bronx to Queens, measured not in miles, but in lifetimes.

headline: Deal Is Reached on New York State Budget; Ethics Measures Are Included
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders on Sunday night reached an agreement on the next state budget, capping weeks of deliberations over issues like deterring public corruption and improving public schools.

headline: Slater and Gordon, Australian Law Firm, to Acquire Arm of Quindell of Britain
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Slater and Gordon, the Australian law firm that was the first in the world to list on a stock exchange, said on Monday that it planned to buy the professional services unit of Quindell for 637 million pounds, or about $947 million, to become Britain’s leading personal injury law firm.

headline: Off the Dribble and Into a Firestorm in Indiana
text: In an interview with The Indianapolis Star on Sunday, Mike Pence, the Republican governor of Indiana, tried to extricate himself from a cage of intolerance and divisiveness into which he had put himself and his state. After coming under ferocious criticism from around the country, he said that he would now support legislation to “clarify” that the state’s new Religious Freedom Restoration Act, which he signed into law last week, would not discriminate against gays and lesbians.

headline: The Kentucky Derby Dartboard
text: Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert weigh in on some of the contenders for the 141st Kentucky Derby, which is set to be run May 2.

headline: Notre Dame’s Heartbreaking Defeat Should Hearten Wisconsin
text: CLEVELAND — In Notre Dame’s locker room after Saturday night’s loss to Kentucky, the whiteboard still bore the coaches’ talking points in black Sharpie. On offense: “Great Movement=Great Shots.” On defense, the only instruction underlined in blue was “Level 5 Team Rebounding.”

headline: Clinton Wants to Improve Ties With Israel
text: Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton told a representative of a group of prominent Jewish leaders on Sunday that she wanted to put the relationship between the United States and Israel back on “constructive footing,” the representative said.

headline: Roger L. Mayer, Pioneer of Film Preservation, Dies at 88
text: Roger L. Mayer, a film executive who was instrumental in preserving and restoring countless classic movies and who also courted controversy by coloring some black-and-white ones, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 88.

headline: De Blasio to Name Former ‘Right-Hand Man’ of Boston Mayor as His Chief of Staff
text: Earning a place in Mayor Bill de Blasio’s close-knit inner circle is not easy. In choosing top aides, the mayor often seeks municipal know-how, liberal bona fides and the approval of those he trusts.

headline: GNC to Strengthen Supplement Quality Controls
text: GNC, the country’s largest specialty retailer of dietary supplements, has agreed to institute sweeping new testing procedures on its herbal products that far exceed quality controls mandated under federal law.

headline: Word of the Day | douse
text: douse • \ˈdau̇s also ˈdau̇z\ • verb

headline: What’s On TV Monday
text: 8:30 P.M. (ABC Family) THE GOONIES (1985) Richard Donner directed, Chris Columbus wrote the screenplay and Steven Spielberg wrote the story for this classic buddy adventure. Friends in Astoria, Ore., face the glum prospect of having their group broken apart as a country club tries to build a golf course on their properties. They a map they believe will lead them to buried treasure with which they can buy off the country club and keep their homes. They set off in search of the treasure. “The Goonies themselves are an appealing bunch: There is a smart-alecky one (Corey Feldman), a mature one (Josh Brolin), a precociously responsible one (Sean Astin), a weirdly inventive one (Ke Huy Quan) and an effervescent fat one (Jeff Cohen) who steals half the film,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. The film “has crooks, bats, cobwebs, skeletons, a lovable monster, an underground grotto and a treasure hidden by some of the most considerate, clue-loving pirates who ever lived.” (The Goonies, above.)

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Clippers at Trail Blazers
text: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Lincoln Continental Is Reborn, Inspired by Its American Roots and Chinese Tastes
text: DETROIT — It took the interest of Chinese consumers to persuade Ford Motor to revive a quintessentially American car, the Lincoln Continental.

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Season 5 Finale Recap: Rick, Do It
text: Season 5, Episode 16, “Conquer”

headline: Corrections: March 30, 2015
text: NEW YORK

headline: Talking Photography With Elliott Erwitt
text: I learned long ago that it’s best to approach your heroes with trepidation, because they rarely live up to expectations. So when I met Elliott Erwitt in Perpignan, France, years ago, when we both had shows for Visa Pour l’Image, I was reluctant to talk to him. Imagine my surprise when he asked to trade prints. I upped the ante and asked whether if I bought his book, “Personal Best,” he would sign it for me.

headline: A Truce in the War Over Family
text: THE war over the family has been a disheartening part of American politics for decades. Conservatives saw growing numbers of children born outside of marriage and thought the family as they knew it was in trouble, the result of a cultural decline — a decrease in personal responsibility, and a growing dependence on government social welfare programs. Liberals saw families struggling and thought the problems reflected poverty and the dearth of good jobs.

headline: Immigration Reform: The Drawbacks of E-Verify
After 50 Years, It’s Time for a Better ‘Sound of Music’
text: “The Sound of Music,” the movie, turns 50 this year, as popular as ever, a bedrock memory of untold millions of childhoods. Mine, for sure. Some far-off day, when neural engineers do a digital download of my dying brain, they will find, way back with the oldest grudges and PIN numbers, the “Sound of Music” soundtrack, every line and rhyme. She climbs a tree and scrapes her knee. When the dog bites. Yodel-ay-hee-hoo.

headline: Stronger Dollar in a Weak Global Economy
text: In the last several months, the dollar has strengthened tremendously against other currencies like the euro, the pound and the yen. This largely reflects the realization among investors that the American economy will do much better than other major economies in the coming months.

headline: Imaginary Health Care Horrors
text: There’s a lot of fuzzy math in American politics, but Representative Pete Sessions of Texas, the chairman of the House Rules Committee, recently set a new standard when he declared the cost of Obamacare “unconscionable.” If you do “simple multiplication,” he insisted, you find that the coverage expansion is costing $5 million per recipient. But his calculation was a bit off — namely, by a factor of more than a thousand. The actual cost per newly insured American is about $4,000.

headline: For the Police, Quality Over Quantity
text: Is the thin blue line too thin? Should the New York Police Department staff up, adding more cops even though crime is at historic lows and a sense of civic calm — a “peacetime dividend,” as Commissioner William Bratton calls it — is evident across most of the city?

headline: Ovarian Cancer: Learning the Risks
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Beating of Floyd Dent
text: “He was beating me upside the head,” Floyd Dent, a 57-year-old longtime autoworker told a gaggle of reporters last week, according to The Detroit Free Press. “I was trying to protect my face with my right arm. I heard one of them say, ‘Tase the M...F.’ ”

headline: Test Yourself | Street Dance in Performance
text: Here are several paragraphs from a March 27 article, “In ‘Flexn,’ Street Dance Gets a Grand Stage.”

headline: Ehud Olmert, Israeli Ex-Premier, Is Convicted of Fraud
text: JERUSALEM — Ehud Olmert, the former Israeli prime minister who was forced from office under a cloud of corruption, was convicted on Monday of fraud and breach of trust in a retrial of a case involving an American businessman, whose sensational testimony in a Jerusalem court in 2008 was instrumental in Mr. Olmert’s downfall.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | A Fire to Unite People Long Divided in Northern Ireland
text: In “Healing Fire in Londonderry: The Temple Was Built to Burn,” Katrin Bennhold writes about

headline: Suspect’s Request to Testify Adds Wrinkle to Litvinenko Inquiry
text: LONDON — An inquiry into the poisoning death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer, whistle-blower and bitter foe of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, ran into a last-minute delay on Monday after one of the two suspects in the killing demanded a chance to clear his name and exonerate the Kremlin.

headline: Pay for Performance Extends to Health Care in New York State Experiment
text: For a generation, doctors in New York City’s economically depressed neighborhoods have been the ugly ducklings of the medical hierarchy. Many are foreign born and foreign trained, serve mostly minority and immigrant patients, and often run high-volume practices to compensate for Medicaid’s low rate of payment.

headline: Amid Inquiry, Menendez Finds Well of Support Among Jewish Leaders
text: FRANKLIN LAKES, N.J. — Senator Robert Menendez spoke in a level, matter-of-fact tone, but his words were grave. Anti-Semitism is on the march around the world, he said. Negotiations with Iran, he warned, have reached “the witching hour,” with the security of both the United States and Israel at stake.

headline: Pioneering Combat Pilot Persists in Rise From Arizona
text: WASHINGTON — In 2012, Martha McSally, a political novice, came so close to defeating her Democratic opponent, Representative Ron Barber, in Arizona that she flew to Washington for orientation and even appeared in the freshman class picture. She ultimately lost by fewer than 2,500 votes.

headline: The High Cost of Calling the Imprisoned
text: Since the police in Pennsylvania arrested Anthony Kofalt last March for walking out of a Walmart with 21 boxes of Crest Whitestrips he had not paid for, his wife, Heather, has spent $3,000 — about $60 a week — on phone calls to the prisons and jails where he has been held.

headline: Queens Clock Tower, Once the Tallest, Helps a 77-Story Skyscraper Rise Next Door
text: The hands have not moved in decades, and the lights behind them went dark a year ago. But the gargoyles still glower atop the Long Island City clock tower, alongside its castellated turret, copper windows and granite shields.

headline: Chinese Outlets Say Security Official in Graft Case Had 6 Mistresses
text: BEIJING — Chinese corruption investigators looking into a top security and intelligence official have found that he had six mistresses and two sons by them, according to a report published by a respected newsmagazine that was carried Monday on the websites of state-run news organizations.

headline: What Are Your Thoughts on Cats?
text: People say there are “cat people” and “dog people,” but is that really true? What if you happen to like both equally?

headline: ABN Amro Managers Give Up Pay Increases After I.P.O. Delay
text: LONDON — A group of ABN Amro’s top managers has said that it would give up a pay increase after the Dutch government delayed a decision last week on an initial public offering of the state-owned lender and after an uproar by lawmakers over the executive salary increases.

headline: Andreas Lubitz’s Home City Is Left to Clear Away Emotional Wreckage
text: MONTABAUR, Germany — When employees at a Burger King in this city between Frankfurt and Cologne heard that one of their former co-workers had been aboard the Germanwings flight that crashed in the French Alps last week, they prepared a condolence card for the family.

headline: South Korea Picks Contractor to Develop New Jet Fighter
text: SEOUL — The South Korean military preliminarily selected Korea Aerospace Industries on Monday as a partner in its $7.7 billion project to develop its own advanced jet fighter with technological help from the American military contractor Lockheed Martin.

headline: The Path Toward Tomorrow’s Internet
text: High school students in Tennessee can see and manipulate ocean plankton under a superhigh-resolution microscope in Southern California, with a biologist in California serving as their tour guide.

headline: Nuts Are a Nutritional Powerhouse
text: Sadly, for more than half my life, I had avoided some of nature’s most perfect and healthful foods: nuts and peanuts. I had been mistakenly told as a teenager that nuts were fattening and constipating, effects I certainly wanted to avoid.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Bank of England Outlines Parameters of 2015 Stress Test
text: LONDON — The Bank of England said on Monday that it would test major British banks on their potential performance against financial shocks including a global slowdown, a sharp drop in inflation and a reduction in worldwide appetite for risk.

headline: Dufry to Undertake Bid for All of Its Rival, World Duty Free
text: LONDON — Dufry, the Swiss operator of duty-free and other airport retail locations, said on Monday that it would undertake a bid to acquire all of the outstanding shares of the rival World Duty Free after it struck a deal during the weekend to obtain a controlling stake.

headline: UnitedHealth Group to Buy Catamaran in $12.8 Billion Pharmacy Benefits Deal
text: Two pharmacy benefits managers are combining forces in an effort to negotiate better deals with pharmaceutical makers, a move that could in theory lead to lower drug prices for consumers.

headline: New York Today: Not Trickling Down
text: Good chilly Monday morning to you.

headline: The Deer in the Garden
text: Eight deer of various sizes are grazing the winter azaleas and fringe of monkey grass just outside the front window. Several young ruminants are right up next to the house, tugging at a tattered rhododendron, occasionally bumping the window screen. Although the dog is flipping out in the hallway below, barking sharply, indignantly, the herd is unfazed.

headline: Daily Report: Hollywood Increases Its Digital Security Efforts
text: Lulu Zezza has played one of the toughest roles in Hollywood, Nicole Perlroth reports.

headline: Income Inequality: It’s Also Bad for Your Health
text: We know that living in a poor community makes you less likely to live a long life. New evidence suggests that living in a community with high income inequality also seems to be bad for your health.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 30, 2015
text: Updated: March 31, 2015

headline: Iran Matters Most
text: Do the Iran deal. Defeat the barbaric marauders of Islamic State. In the fragmenting mayhem of the Middle East, these must be the American and Western priorities.

headline: Being There: Heidegger on Why Our Presence Matters
text: A cognitive scientist and a German philosopher walk into the woods and come upon a tree in bloom: What does each one see? And why does it matter?

headline: Judging Forensic Science
text: How can forensic science be made more dependable and professional?

headline: Today in Politics: Obama’s Countdown for His Ascent Predated Politics, Book Says
text: A new biography of Michelle Obama has Washington buzzing, and the 2016 Senate race gets an early start.

headline: Rhodes Scholarships Expanding to Include Chinese Students
text: BEIJING — The organization that administers Rhodes scholarships, the prestigious grant program that sends promising students to the University of Oxford, is preparing to expand to the developing world and other countries and will soon begin naming scholars from China.

headline: Morning Agenda: Lessons  From the Kleiner Perkins Trial
text: LESSONS FROM THE KLEINER PERKINS TRIAL | Though Ellen Pao  lost her gender discrimination suit against her former employer, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the trial has succeeded in putting Silicon Valley on notice that it cannot continue with its freewheeling ways. “In Ellen Pao, the Valley has found its newest disrupter,” contends Farhad Manjoo in the State of the Art column.

headline: Horizon Pharma Offers to Acquire Hyperion Therapeutics for $1.1 Billion
text: The Irish pharmaceutical company Horizon Pharma said on Monday that it had offered to buy Hyperion Therapeutics of California for $1.1 billion in cash.

headline: ‘The Daily Show’ Names a New Host
text: Trevor Noah, a 31-year-old comedian from South Africa, will replace Jon Stewart as the host of “The Daily Show.”

headline: Trevor Noah to Succeed Jon Stewart on ‘The Daily Show’
text: In December, Trevor Noah, a 31-year-old comedian, made his debut as an on-air contributor on “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart,” offering his outsider’s perspective, as a biracial South African, on the United States.

headline: Trevor Noah, New ‘Daily Show’ Host, Has an Earnest and Comedic Profile on Twitter and YouTube
text: When Jon Stewart started as the host of “The Daily Show,” in 1999, Internet video was hard to come by, and social networks like Twitter didn’t exist. During his years as a professional comedian, Trevor Noah, like many of his peers, has established a strong footprint on Twitter, YouTube and Instagram. His tweets and clips from his standup performances may offer clues about what kind of host he’ll be on Comedy Central’s crown jewel nightly program.

headline: Ben Bernanke Blog Blogging
text: Ben Bernanke’s Brookings blog begins! And the subject of the first post is a defense of the Fed against the charge that it has been keeping interest rates “artificially low” and hurting savers.

headline: ‘Tricky Issues’ Remain as Deadline Nears in Nuclear Talks With Iran
text: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — Negotiators from the United States, Iran and five other nations pushed into the night on Monday to try to reach a preliminary political agreement on limiting Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Singapore Arrests Teenager Over Video Critical of Lee Kuan Yew
text: HONG KONG — A 16-year-old who appeared in a video that criticized Lee Kuan Yew, the founding father of modern Singapore who died on March 23, was arrested because of his comments that disparaged Christianity, according to the Singaporean police and local news reports.

headline: Teva to Buy Auspex, an American Drug Developer, for $3.2 Billion
text: Teva Pharmaceutical said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire Auspex Pharmaceuticals, a developer of drugs that treat people with movement disorders, for about $3.2 billion in cash.

headline: Men’s Wear Continues Its Global Surge
text: Prada announced its 2014 results on Monday, and for anyone looking to see how the high-fashion wind is blowing, the results confirm two major market trends: First, things may be looking up for sales in Japan and the United States, but China is still a challenge; and second, men’s wear and footwear are still growing strong.

headline: Q. and A.: Adam Fisk on Evading Internet Censorship in China
text: In recent months, China’s Internet regulators have further restricted the already limited access that the nation’s 648 million Internet users have to the web. Several Google services, including Gmail and Gchat, have become inaccessible. Virtual private networks, or V.P.N.s, that once let users skirt online censorship have also been blocked.

headline: Red Meat Is Not the Enemy
text: There are people in this country eating too much red meat. They should cut back. There are people eating too many carbs. They should cut back on those. There are also people eating too much fat, and the same advice applies to them, too.

headline: Yoox Group in Talks With Luxury Online Seller Net-a-Porter
text: The Yoox Group, the Italian online fashion retailer, said on Monday that it was in discussions with Compagnie Financière Richemont of Switzerland about a “potential business combination” with Net-a-Porter, the luxury e-commerce pioneer.

headline: R.B.S. Says Head of Its Corporate and Institutional Bank Will Leave
text: The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Monday that Rory Cullinan, the recently appointed head of its corporate and institutional bank, was leaving the company at the end of April.

headline: Bangladesh Killings Send Chilling Message to Secular Bloggers
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — When the steamy, clamorous evening had settled over this city, and Oyasiqur Rhaman had finished his day’s work at a travel agency, he would turn to one of his favorite pastimes: Poking fun at fundamentalist Islam.

headline: In Atlanta, a Quest to Keep Its Airport the World’s Busiest
text: ATLANTA — The typical flier might wonder why an airport would promote its designation as the world’s busiest. Images of long lines, crowded concourses and auxiliary parking lots in the next area code could be evoked.

headline: Palestinian Discontent With Abbas Is Growing
text: AL AMARI REFUGEE CAMP, West Bank — Residents of this cinder-block ghetto, a few miles from the headquarters of President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority, recently removed his portrait from the camp’s entrance.

headline: 1940: War Intrudes on Historians
text: LONDON — Great Britain’s official military historians are hard at work trying to finish the story of the last war and wondering when they will be able to start writing about his one. In another volume of the long series on the conflict of 1914- 1918, to be published tomorrow [March 31], the scribes have chronicled such events of 1917 as the Battles of Arras and the German retreat to the Hindenberg Line. Half the staff of writers and research workers is busy amassing and pigeon-holing data on the present war. A weary official said today: ‘‘I don’t know when we shall start writing it up. It depends on how long it lasts. It is far too early yet to get the right perspective.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 31, 1940

headline: Germanwings Co-Pilot Was Treated for ‘Suicidal Tendencies,’ Authorities Say
text: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — Before he received his pilot’s license or achieved his dream of flying passenger jets, the co-pilot of the crashed Germanwings jetliner was so troubled that he underwent treatment for “suicidal tendencies,” a prosecutor said Monday, raising questions about what the airline should have known about his condition.

headline: Headgear Rule for Girls’ Lacrosse Ignites Outcry
text: Worried about the risk of serious head injuries in a sport where the players wield reinforced sticks and rifle shots with a hard, unyielding ball, Florida last month became the first state to require high school girls’ lacrosse teams to wear protective headgear.

headline: N.C.A.A. Final Four Preview: Kentucky Heads a Familiar Four
text: Call it the Familiar Four.

headline: The Price of Damming Tibet’s Rivers
text: NEW DELHI — CHINA has more than 26,000 large dams, more than the rest of the world combined. They feed its insatiable demand for energy and supply water for mining, manufacturing and agriculture.

headline: President Obama to Visit Kenya
text: President Obama will visit Kenya this summer for an international business conference in his first trip to his father’s homeland since taking office, the White House announced on Monday.

headline: Arrests After Bangladesh Blogger’s Death
text: Biplob Kumar Sarker, a police official in Dhaka, spoke after a blogger was killed in a machete attack by three men in Bangladesh’s capital on Monday.

headline: Water Colors
text: Toshio Shibata’s meditative photographs of infrastructure in Japan take the perspective of the ceaseless flow of water.

headline: Israeli Ex-Premier Convicted Again
text: A state prosecutor and a lawyer representing Ehud Olmert spoke after the former Israeli prime minister was found guilty on Monday of accepting illegal payments from an American businessman.

headline: As Jobs Become Scarce, Teenagers Drive Farther to Find Work
text: Many parents hold teenage work experience in the same high regard as good grades and extracurricular activities. But what happens when the corner drugstore closes, the family-owned supermarket shuts its doors, and the only jobs available for high schoolers are more than 30 minutes away?

headline: Ask Your Easter and Passover Cooking Questions
text: Melissa Clark, Kim Severson, Julia Moskin and I will answer your questions about the Passover and Easter feasts all week long on the Food department Facebook page.

headline: In Boston Olympic Bid Vote, More Is at Stake Than Games
text: BOSTON — In the glassy offices of Boston’s headquarters for bidding on the 2024 Olympics, signs remind officials: “Keep Calm and Bid On.”

headline: China Is Urged to Confront Its Own History
text: The tour guide outside the bloodstained classrooms of the Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum, the high school in the Cambodian capital of Phnom Penh transformed into a prison and torture center by the Khmer Rouge, paused to ask whether any tourists in the group were from China. Visibly relieved when no hands were raised, he went on to describe the enabling role that Beijing played in the Khmer Rouge’s murderous rampage that claimed the lives of an estimated 1.7 million Cambodians beginning in 1975.

headline: A Singapore Story
text: SINGAPORE — An hour or so after the end of the funeral ceremony at the National University of Singapore, the crowds were only just beginning to thin out. Earlier, despite torrential downpours, they had stood six-deep in some stretches of the 10-mile route of the procession accompanying Lee Kuan Yew’s coffin. It was a last homage in a week of homages and an intense outpouring of national grief.

headline: Poetry Everywhere, and They Mean Everywhere, in Miami Festival
text: On April 1 the organizers of the O, Miami Poetry Festival begin their annual monthlong campaign to put a poem in front of all 2.6 million residents of Miami-Dade County. “Miamians should watch out for poems on buildings, on fences, in the mail, even in the bathroom,” Scott Cunningham, the festival director, said.

headline: Alex Garland’s Sci-Fi Faves
text: The British novelist makes his directorial debut with “Ex Machina,” a sci-fi parable that he also wrote about the dangers of artificial intelligence. Here, the screenwriter of “28 Days Later,” “Never Let Me Go” and “Dredd” on his five favorite genre offerings.

headline: 1965: Bomb Kills 13 at U.S. Embassy
text: A video by British Pathé of the bomb attack on the United States Embassy in Saigon, Vietnam, in 1965. britishpathe.com

headline: Walker Art Center to Begin $75 Million Renovation
text: MINNEAPOLIS – To celebrate its 75th anniversary as a public institution, the Walker Art Center will embark on a $75 million renovation of its rolling campus, the final stage of an expansion that began more than a decade ago with the addition of a new building by the architects Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron. The new project will restructure the museum’s grounds and add a highly visible entrance pavilion, and it will also tie the Walker more closely to the Minneapolis Sculpture Garden across the street, home to “Spoonbridge and Cherry,” the sculpture by Claes Oldenburg and Coosje van Bruggen that has become a Minneapolis landmark.

headline: Driver Killed as Stolen Car Enters N.S.A. Campus
text: WASHINGTON — The two young men who spent the night at a nearby motel with an older man and stole his car on Monday morning may not have known exactly where they were going. But they sped into a special highway exit reserved for employees of the National Security Agency.

headline: ‘Root to Leaf,’ a Field Guide to Vegetables
text: “Where my friend saw nothing, I saw possibility.”

headline: Supreme Court Leaves Intact New York’s Ban on Religious Services in Schools
text: The Supreme Court declined on Monday to review a case involving New York City’s ban on religious groups’ holding worship services in public school buildings, leaving in place a decision by a lower court that found the longstanding policy constitutional.

headline: Indiana Races to Fight H.I.V. Surge Tied to Drug Abuse
text: AUSTIN, Ind. — Jeanni McCarty, a nurse and native of this threadbare city of 4,200, hurried up and down Main Street in Saturday’s bright sun, handing out stacks of fliers to any business that would take them. They were announcing a hastily planned specialty clinic — FREE, they emphasized in red — that would provide H.I.V. treatment to anyone who needed it.

headline: Hanya Yanagihara’s ‘A Little Life’
text: The lock on the toolshed is smashed, the motel door is kicked in and a child ­emerges — blinky, freed from years of sexual service, the violence finally at an end. The newspapers celebrate another triumph of the human spirit, and move on. But does the victim do the same? How does someone go from years of suffering and shame to live out the rest of a life? This is the question Hanya Yanagihara, author of “People in the Trees,” takes on in her second novel.

headline: Islamic State’s Grip on City Appears Firmer Than Iraqis Acknowledge
text: TIKRIT, Iraq — Iraqi officials insisted for weeks that Islamic State fighters had been all but exterminated in Tikrit, confined to a few pockets in the city center. Yet on Sunday, military officials in the city were reluctant to allow journalists to head back to Baghdad by road — even though the highway skirts Tikrit well to the west.

headline: Fluoridated Water Helps Older Adults Keep Teeth, Study Says
text: Fluoridation of water supplies, long ago proved to protect children from cavities, also helps older adults keep their teeth, a new study from Ireland has shown.

headline: ‘All the Old Knives,’ by Olen Steinhauer
text: A middle-aged man, dazed, drunk and unsteady, clambers up a staircase to reach the fresh air of a rooftop. Pigeons scatter. He slumps, closes his eyes, loses sight of the London skyline, loses consciousness. He has done something wrong in the restaurant downstairs — though as the scene plays out, this transgression is revealed to be little more than drunkenness. He’s been acting distant and withdrawn at a lunch date with an old flame. He may leave the Soho restaurant feeling longing and regret, wounded by her criticism of his collection of poems, but there are thankfully no bullet holes. In this filmed version of Christopher Reid’s narrative poem “The Song of Lunch,” the slumping man is played by Alan Rickman. Emma Thompson is the woman who’s been looking across the table at him with disdain. She’s gone by the time he descends.

headline: Inquiry of Silk Road Website Spurred Agents’ Own Illegal Acts, Officials Say
text: On the so-called dark web, drug dealing and other illicit sales have thrived in recent years, the authorities have said, through hidden websites like Silk Road and hard-to-trace digital currencies like Bitcoins.

headline: More Details on Co-Pilot’s Mental State
text: Christoph Kumpa, deputy spokesman for the prosecutors’ office, said before the Germanwings co-pilot received his license, Andreas Lubitz was seeking help from a psychotherapist.

headline: Math Madness
text: Celebrate March Madness with these two basketball-related math challenges.

headline: New York Times Co. Appoints Kinsey Wilson to Expanded Digital Role
text: The New York Times Company has appointed Kinsey Wilson, a former NPR executive who joined the newspaper last month as an editor for strategy and innovation, to lead its companywide digital product and technology operations.

headline: Rahm Emanuel, Chicago’s Rough-Edged Mayor, Tries the Sandpaper
text: CHICAGO — Alderman Scott Waguespack was in a conference room at City Hall in the spring of 2011 for a formal sit-down with this city’s newly elected mayor, Rahm Emanuel. Mr. Waguespack attempted some small talk, he said, but Mr. Emanuel was not much interested.

headline: Dozens Are Reported Killed as Saudi-Led Strike Hits Camp for Displaced Yemeni Civilians
text: AL MUKALLA, Yemen — Dozens of civilians were killed when, according to aid workers and officials, what appeared to be an airstrike hit a camp for displaced families in northern Yemen on Monday. It was thought to be the deadliest single episode involving civilians since Saudi Arabia began a military campaign to drive back the Houthi movement five days earlier.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Financier Lynn Tilton of Defrauding Investors
text: Federal regulators have accused Lynn Tilton, who calls herself the “turnaround queen,” and her firm, Patriarch Partners, of defrauding investors by hiding the poor performance of assets she managed for them.

headline: Islamic State Destruction Renews Debate Over Repatriation of Antiquities
text: Assyrian relics that have stood for 3,000 years smashed and desecrated. Ruins from Babylonian times bombed and bulldozed. Scrolls and shrines ravaged from Somalia to Timbuktu.

headline: Spokesman for Missouri Official Who Committed Suicide Is Found Dead
text: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. — Slightly more than a month after Tom Schweich, Missouri’s auditor and a candidate for governor, took his own life, Spence Jackson, a longtime Republican spokesman who worked for Mr. Schweich, appears to have done the same.

headline: A Paris Picnic, Delivered
text: Paris Picnic is a made-to-order delivery service that offers an assist for the most quintessential of Parisian activities: laying down a blanket, breaking out some Brie and a baguette and basking in the City of Light.

headline: Velvet Worms, Squirting Slime
text: Velvet worms undulate through leaf litter on many stubby legs until they find an insect or other small prey. Then the creatures, which are not worms at all, strike. They squirt slime in a wavy, oscillating stream, trapping the prey in a sticky net.

headline: Secrets of Velvet Worm Slime
text: A new study sheds light on how exactly the velvet worm controls the jet of slime it sprays to deter would-be predators.

headline: Stephen Posen (Yes, Zac’s Dad) Finds Poetry in Paired Photos
text: The artist’s new book, “Ellipsis,” features 174 images juxtaposed in surprising, thought-provoking ways.

headline: Russian History Receives a Makeover That Starts With Ivan the Terrible
text: MOSCOW — Ivan the Terrible, the Russian czar, should really be considered Ivan the Not So Bad, according to a wildly popular historical exhibition held recently near the Kremlin.

headline: Scott Walker: From Eagle Scout to Commander in Chief?
text: It is a quadrennial political ritual: Although very few candidates for president in recent history have actually had any experience that “qualified” them to be the commander in chief of the armed forces, the contenders often feel compelled to act as though they have that experience.

headline: Florida Highway Official on Van Crash
text: Lt. Gregory S. Bueno of the Florida Highway Patrol gave an update on the injured passengers after a church van crashed into a canal in Glades County, Fla., killing eight people.

headline: Profiling the Distracted Driver: Young, Female and Solo
text: People younger than 25 are more than four times as likely as older people to use a cellphone while driving, a new study reports, and a driver talking on a phone is about 63 percent more likely to be a woman than a man.

headline: Ready Thyself for an All-Night Philosophy Jam
text: It might be the most intense all-nighter ever staged in New York. For 12 hours, starting at 7 p.m. on April 24, the French Embassy on Fifth Avenue and its next-door-neighbor, the Ukrainian Institute of America, will be joint hosts of “A Night of Philosophy,” an event that combines elements of a teach-in, a triathlon and a sweat-lodge ceremony. Only the mentally strong will survive.

headline: Stephen Posen (Yes, Zac’s Dad) Finds Poetry in Paired Photos
text: The artist’s new book, “Ellipsis,” features 174 images juxtaposed in surprising, thought-provoking ways.

headline: Verbatim: To Be More Like Ted
text: President Obama, speaking at the opening of the Edward M. Kennedy Institute in Boston.

headline: The White House and Paid Leave: Let Flowers Bloom
text: Is it “time for America to Lead on Leave” — as in, finally join the rest of the industrialized world by requiring employers to offer employees some version of paid family and sick leave? The numbers suggest the “leading” ship sailed long ago: We are one of only four countries in the world not to guarantee paid family leave to at least some portion of our work force, and the only one of 22 countries ranked highly by the Center for Economic and Policy Research in terms of economic and human development that does not guarantee that workers receive paid sick days or paid sick leave. We have not led on leave. We lag on leave.

headline: Charges Against Ex-Federal Agents in Silk Road Investigation
text: The two former agents, Carl Mark Force IV and Shaun Bridges, were accused of laundering Bitcoins, the digital currency used on the once-thriving website for drug dealing.

headline: The Golden Age of Annual Reports
text: David W. Dunlap takes a look back at some of The Times’s annual report covers that were influenced by Louis Silverstein, one of the paper’s design directors.

headline: The Condition Cancer Research Is In
text: In a letter to colleagues announcing his departure as the director of the National Cancer Institute, Dr. Harold Varmus, 75, quoted Mae West. “I’ve been rich and I’ve been poor,” he wrote, “and rich is better.”

headline: Lawmakers Focus on How S.E.C. Does Its Job
text: Congress has taken intensified interest in how the Securities and Exchange Commission should enforce the law, introducing several legislative proposals. Although quick passage of the bills is unlikely, they signal how much interest there is, at least among Democrats, about the agency’s work.

headline: Mannequins at the Museum
text: Though passers-by often fail to so much as notice them, mannequins can reveal as much about the culture of their time as the clothing they display does. And, with his family business and the help of creative collaborators, Ralph Pucci is single-handedly responsible for many of the major developments in the modern-day mannequin industry. Pucci joined his parents’ New York mannequin-repair company in 1976 and began manufacturing the forms, teaming up with such design talents as Ruben Toledo, Andrée Putman and Maira Kalman to redefine the genre through diverse and dynamic new shapes, colors and body gestures. Now, in anticipation of Pucci’s 40th anniversary in the business, 30 of the company’s greatest hits are featured in a new exhibition, “Ralph Pucci: The Art of the Mannequin,” opening tomorrow at the Museum of Arts and Design in Manhattan.

headline: Video Shows Scene of N.S.A. Shootings
text: Aerial video shows damaged vehicles and debris at the gate to Fort Meade, Md., where the National Security Agency has its headquarters.

headline: With Travis Trice in Control, Michigan State Keeps Calm and Moves On
text: SYRACUSE — Ten seconds remained in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s tense East Regional final Sunday when the basketball unexpectedly ricocheted into the hands of the Michigan State senior guard Travis Trice.

headline: Now That Ben Bernanke Is Blogging, Here’s What He Should Write About
text: Welcome to the wonderful world of economics blogging, Ben Bernanke! The former Federal Reserve chairman rolled out a blog and a Twitter account Monday morning, promising to engage more publicly on a range of economic issues, and occasionally on baseball.

headline: A Burrito Filled to the Brim Downtown
text: To Stuff: A Burrito Filled to the Brim

headline: China Appears to Attack GitHub by Diverting Web Traffic
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese government has long used a sophisticated set of Internet filters known as the Great Firewall as a barrier to prevent its citizens from obtaining access to foreign websites with information it deems threatening.

headline: A Struggle to Save the Scaly Pangolin
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — With its scaly exterior, peculiar body shape and propensity for rolling into an armored ball when threatened, the pangolin has invited comparison to the artichoke and the pine cone.

headline: Endometriosis Is Often Ignored in Teenage Girls
text: Senie Byrne began menstruating at 15, and she quickly became an expert in pain management. Every month, it felt as if 1,000 darts had plunged into her abdomen; she sometimes passed out from the cramps. She was often nauseated, constipated and exhausted. At times, she had diarrhea. She said she saw 22 doctors over the years, but none took her seriously.

headline: Facts & Figures: Millennials More Accepting of Homosexuality Than of Abortion
text: In a survey conducted by the Public Religion Research Institute, 42 percent of millennial respondents said sex between two adults of the same gender was morally acceptable, while 37 percent said the same of casual sex. Twenty-four percent said sex between minors was acceptable, and 21 percent said so of abortion.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
text: This week’s schedule includes a few friendlies, one not-so-friendly and a rare low-stakes version of Der Klassiker in Germany.

headline: A World Shared With H.I.V.
text: The grayest heads among us still think of AIDS as a terrible new disease. But younger adults have never known a world without it, and many of the youngest think of it only as an annoying condition you take a pill for. They know nothing of the anguish and heroism that once surrounded the word “AIDS.”

headline: BSI Becomes First Swiss Bank to Settle Under D.O.J. Disclosure Program
text: LONDON — BSI, one of Switzerland’s largest private banks, on Monday became the first Swiss lender to reach a settlement with the Justice Department under a disclosure program intended to encourage Swiss banks to cooperate in an inquiry into wealthy Americans who used secret Swiss accounts to avoid taxes.

headline: In Vietnam, Rampant Wildlife Smuggling Prompts Little Concern
text: U MINH, Vietnam — Luc Van Ho slips through a tangled thicket of jungle, graceful as a dancer. A blanket of dried bamboo and melaleuca leaves on the forest floor barely crackles beneath his bare feet. Only the smell of cigarette smoke betrays his presence.

headline: Indiana Legislators Say They’ll Clarify Beliefs Law
text: Indiana’s legislative leaders on Monday joined Gov. Mike Pence in saying that they planned to amend a new religious freedom law to make clear that it did not allow discrimination against gays and lesbians, while still insisting that the law did not do so in its current form.

headline: UnitedHealth’s $12.8 Billion Deal Could Reduce Further Consolidation
text: A $12.8 billion prescription should address the chronic merger game among pharmacy benefit managers. The UnitedHealth Group is paying a 27 percent premium for the Catamaran Corporation and should generate more than enough savings to cover it.

headline: Clinton’s Effort on Israel Viewed Dimly by American Jewish Leader
text: The prominent American Jewish leader who on Sunday talked with Hillary Rodham Clinton about the need to put the relationship between Israel and the United States back on “constructive footing” did not think her role as the administration’s “designated yeller” at Israel as secretary of state was all that constructive.

headline: Ask Well: Jet Crash Raises Questions on Mental Illness Risks
text: The crash of the Germanwings jetliner has raised questions about mental illness and its consequences. Authorities have said that Andreas Lubitz, the co-pilot believed to have intentionally crashed the plane into the Alps, had a mental illness that he hid from the airline, that he was treated for “suicidal tendencies” before he got his pilot’s license, and that antidepressants were found in his apartment.

headline: A Cure for the Cacophony
text: Life in the big city can get overwhelming, which is why Beijing’s five-star Rosewood hotel, situated among the bustling bars and hustling bankers of the Chaoyang District, is opening Sense this month, for guests who want to sleep where they spa. In addition to 11 treatment rooms, there are five suites overlooking the skyline — all decorated with limestone, dark wood and a serene palette of muted beige and gray — so that guests can opt to enjoy the extensive menu of treatments in the privacy of their own palatial accommodations.

headline: Major British Parties Struggle to Fend Off Challenges as Campaigns Begin
text: LONDON — And they’re off! Parliament was dissolved at midnight, making Monday the official start of what is already a bitter and bad-tempered effort to win the minds, if not the hearts, of Britain’s undecided voters, who by most accounts make up close to 40 percent of the electorate. This election promises to be one of the most unpredictable British elections in recent times.

headline: Justices Hear Arguments on Intellectual Disability in Death Penalty Case
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday heard arguments in a death penalty case and issued decisions on the monitoring of sex offenders and on the significance of a lawyer’s brief absence from a criminal trial.

headline: 1957: Frisbees Fly at Princeton
text: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: Greece Looks to Russia as Deal With Europe Stumbles
text: ATHENS — With the prospect of a default looming in Greece, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is preparing to meet next week with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia as a European deal to give more aid to Athens falters.

headline: How Not to Catch a Cold on a Plane
text: Q. What can you do to reduce the possibility of becoming sick when you are trapped on a plane with a sneezing, coughing fellow passenger?

headline: Ignacio Mattos’s Most Treasured Cooking Tool
text: The Microplane was never meant to be a grater. It was never designed to turn walnuts to dust, or lemon peel into sunny snow, or to make confetti of mojama — salt-cured, wind-hardened tuna loin from southern Spain — the way it does in the hands of Ignacio Mattos, the chef of the Manhattan restaurant Estela.

headline: Parsing Ronald Reagan’s Words for Early Signs of Alzheimer’s
text: WASHINGTON — Even before Ronald Reagan became the oldest elected president, his mental state was a political issue. His adversaries often suggested his penchant for contradictory statements, forgetting names and seeming absent-mindedness could be linked to dementia.

headline: Chirlane McCray, on the Germanwings Co-Pilot’s Mental Health
text: To the Editor:

headline: N.F.L. Punishes Falcons and Browns for Rules Violations
text: The N.F.L. penalized the Atlanta Falcons and the Cleveland Browns on Monday, suspending two team executives for off-the-field infractions last season.

headline: Phytoplankton on Decline in Southern Ocean
text: A type of phytoplankton important for carbon storage in marine environments is declining in the Southern Ocean, possibly because of climate change, researchers reported in Geophysical Research Letters. Emiliania huxleyi secretes a calcite shell, helping transport carbon dioxide from the surface into the deeper reaches. From 1998 to 2014, there was about a 4 percent reduction in the calcification rate during the summer months in the Southern Ocean.

headline: A Wing That Can Recover From Midair Collisions
text: A new robotic wing, inspired by those of birds and bats, recovers from midair collisions with a simple mechanism: a pin joint that allows it to bend.

headline: Review: Soho Rep’s ‘Washeteria,’ Staged in a Brooklyn Storefront
text: In recent years, Soho Rep has offered dramas like “Blasted,” “Born Bad,” “An Octoroon” and “We Are Proud to Present a Presentation” — tough, turbulent, troubling. But in the new show, “Washeteria,” the company is running on a much, much gentler cycle, with lots of fabric softener, too.

headline: Britain Acts to Block Removal of Egyptian Statue
text: Britain’s Culture Ministry has temporarily barred the unidentified buyer of a $27 million Egyptian statue, purchased last year from a museum in the town of Northampton, from taking the 4,400-year-old antiquity overseas, according to the BBC.

headline: Stephen Posen (Yes, Zac’s Dad) Finds Poetry in Paired Photos
text: It’s common knowledge that the designer and “Project Runway” judge Zac Posen has always had a quirky and creative eye — long before he began creating ethereal and dramatic gowns for the likes of Reese Witherspoon and Naomi Campbell, he was repurposing yarmulkes for Barbie doll dresses. Perhaps less known is how much of the designer’s appreciation for visual shape-shifting can be credited to his father, the artist Stephen Posen, whose new photography book, “Ellipsis: Dual Visions” ($75, Glitterati), is out this week.

headline: Review: Paquito D’Rivera in Concert at Jazz at Lincoln Center
text: Paquito D’Rivera practiced an impish historical revisionism at the Rose Theater on Friday, in his first of two nights at Jazz at Lincoln Center. At one point his darting lines on soprano saxophone came girded by the triplet thump of a Peruvian landó rhythm — not the usual musical setting for Beethoven’s “Pathétique” piano sonata. But Mr. D’Rivera had explained himself in an introduction to the piece: “Beethoven was really from Machu Picchu,” he said, agreeably. “His name was not Ludwig but Luisito.”

headline: ‘Mad Men’: Megan Sings ‘Zou Bisou Bisou’
text: Jessica Paré, as Megan Draper, performs the song in Season 5.

headline: Questions For Indiana’s Critics
text: I know that I should say something about the backlash and debate over Indiana’s version of the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, but it’s been hard to come up with something that I didn’t already say in my column when it was Arizona’s variation on the same law, vetoed under pressure, that was in the news. That column made the case that the only remaining question in the same-sex marriage “debate” was what kind of space, if any, an ascendant cultural liberalism would leave to Americans with traditional views on what constitutes a marriage; that the correlation of forces (corporate now as well as cultural and legal) was such that the choice of exactly how far to push and how much pluralism to permit would be almost entirely in the hands of liberals and supporters of same-sex marriage. That’s still basically how it looks to me today: Elements of the Indiana debate have been particularly … striking, but none of it has been particularly surprising given how this played out in Arizona.

headline: Harvey Weinstein, Producer, Questioned by New York Police After Groping Accusation
text: The film producer Harvey Weinstein was questioned by the police on Saturday after a 22-year-old woman accused him of touching her inappropriately during a meeting in Manhattan, according to two law enforcement officials.

headline: Small Planes and Frequent Delays Don’t Cool Ardor for Flying
text: I’VE been with real estate trade associations for about 40 years. But it’s really only the last four years, after joining the National Association of Realtors, that my business travel has really expanded. The association is based in Washington, but I live in Madison, Wis. What I do is help run a political education program called the Realtor Party, and I work directly with more than 1,400 local and state Realtor Association chapters in every state.

headline: Foreigners Are Attacking ... American TV!
text: American late-night television shows have probably never had so many anchors with foreign accents as they will have soon. Trevor Noah, a South African comedian, will become at least the third non-American native to host a popular TV comedy show later this year when he takes over “The Daily Show” from Jon Stewart. He will join two Britons, John Oliver of HBO’s “Last Week Tonight” and James Corden, who recently started hosting “The Late Late Show” on CBS.

headline: Conservative Gains in Local Elections Leave Left-Leaning Parties Adrift in France
text: PARIS — In the aftermath of balloting on Sunday, conservatives in France were well positioned to build momentum before the presidential election in 2017, political analysts said Monday.

headline: Review: ‘The Brothers’ and the Boston Marathon Bombing
text: The lead attorney for the accused Boston Marathon bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev began his defense this month with a blunt and dramatic statement: “It was him.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
text: Iraq and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day

headline: Obama at Kennedy Institute Opening
