text: President Obama attended the opening of the Edward M. Kennedy Institute in Boston and delivered remarks praising the longtime Massachusetts senator.

headline: Obama Praises Edward Kennedy, and Mourns the Loss of Collegiality
text: BOSTON — President Obama on Monday condemned the demise of bipartisan compromise in American politics that he said had prompted voters to turn away in bitterness and “disgust,” using the dedication of the Edward M. Kennedy Institute to call for a new era of consensus-building.

headline: March 30, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Iraq, India, Colombia and Nigeria.

headline: Jay Z Reveals Plans for Tidal, a Streaming Music Service
text: As Jay Z sees it, there is a clear solution to the problems facing musicians in the streaming age. They should band together — behind him, of course.

headline: The Fifth Season of ‘The Walking Dead’ Turned Into a Post-Apocalyptic Debate Club
text: The sword came off the wall, but it was too late to make a difference.

headline: Fish Oil Claims Not Supported by Research
text: Fish oil is now the third most widely used dietary supplement in the United States, after vitamins and minerals, according to a recent report from the National Institutes of Health. At least 10 percent of Americans take fish oil regularly, most believing that the omega-3 fatty acids in the supplements will protect their cardiovascular health.

headline: A Farmer Ant’s Unique Fungal Crop
text: Much like human farmers, fungus-farming ants meticulously maintain their subterranean gardens. They regularly fertilize, weed and tend to their crops.

headline: Photos That Echo Russia and Ukraine
text: To commemorate Russia’s annexation of Crimea, five photographers are collaborating on image mash-ups that add layers of new meaning.

headline: Walkabout: More Travel Warnings in Kenya; Luring Tourists to Appalachia
text: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.

headline: Review: ‘Living Here’ Sends Gideon Irving to Wander City Apartments
text: There were only two dozen people in the audience when the folksy balladeer Gideon Irving performed “Living Here: A Map of Songs,” produced by the Foundry Theater, on Wednesday.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Readers respond to Times articles about science and health.

headline: Modern Explorers Seek a Place in a GPS World
text: Eric Larsen seemed ill at ease in his tuxedo. He is more inclined to trudge across an ice shelf than mingle at a fancy party in Manhattan. Yet here he was, in black tie, nibbling on canapés at the American Museum of Natural History.

headline: Review: In TV Land’s ‘Younger,’ a Woman Cheats the Clock to Land a Job
text: When it comes to stories about time travel, male characters often focus on what they would do. Mark Twain’s hero uses 19th-century technology to outsmart medieval sorcerers in “A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur’s Court.” The time traveler in “Back to the Future” can perform “Johnny B. Goode” years before that song’s release.

headline: Rubio Confirms Date of ‘Big Announcement’
text: The slow walk of candidates declaring they are running for president took another step forward on Monday with Senator Marco Rubio saying he plans to make a “big announcement” in a couple of weeks.

headline: In Performance | Lena Hall
text: Ms. Hall, with Watt White on guitar, sings “Falling Slowly,” a ballad from the movie and Broadway musical “Once.”

headline: Big Ears in Knoxville, Tenn.
text: The three-day festival of experimental music took place last weekend in Knoxville, Tenn.

headline: Big Ears Festival Stars the Avant-Garde
text: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — The avant-garde is a notion shaped by discomfort, as well as defiance. No music gets that designation unless it makes people feel uneasy or threatened. Tanya Tagaq, a singer from Nunavut, the northernmost territory in Canada, gave an exemplary lesson in assuaging worry here on Saturday afternoon at Big Ears, an ambitious three-day festival of experimental music in a place without much of a history of nurturing it.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: ‘The Wiz’ Will Be NBC’s Next Live Musical and Then Return to Broadway
text: Earlier this year, Robert Greenblatt, the chairman of NBC’s entertainment division, announced that after “The Sound of Music Live” in 2013 and “Peter Pan Live” in 2014, his network’s next live musical production would be either “The Wiz” or “The Music Man.”

headline: Excerpt: ‘Bye Bye Birdie’
text: Ann-Margret performs the opening credits for the 1963 film.

headline: Review: Dawn Upshaw Gets Down to Earth at Town Hall
text: Certain musicians are often referred to as “communicative performers,” a particularly apt description in the case of the soprano Dawn Upshaw, who sang at the Town Hall on Sunday afternoon as part of the Peoples’ Symphony Concerts series.

headline: Review: The Cellist Leonard Elschenbroich Played at the Frick
text: The German cellist Leonard Elschenbroich is a rising star on the European concert scene. On Sunday afternoon, together with the pianist Alexei Grynyuk, he presented his New York recital debut at the Frick Collection. In a program of just three works — one Classical, one contemporary and one Romantic — Mr. Elschenbroich not only revealed himself as a musician of great technical prowess, intellectual curiosity and expressive depth but also displayed an easygoing way of communicating with an audience.

headline: Review: 20 Years Later, Jodeci Is Back, in ‘The Past, the Present, the Future’
text: A few months ago the soul savant D’Angelo released a new album, “Black Messiah,” some 14 years after his previous one, “Voodoo.” On its own, it was an accomplishment, but it was also a reminder of many things that today’s R&B mainstream lacks: political engagement, the warmth and tension of a live band, a voice with fascinating crevices.

headline: ‘Cabaret’ Says Auf Wiedersehen With Big Week at Broadway Box Office
text: The Kit Kat Klub closed up shop with a bang last week, as Sienna Miller led “Cabaret” to a strong finish in its run at Studio 54.

headline: The Story Behind ‘Woman in Gold’: Nazi Art Thieves and One Painting’s Return
text: There are many reasons that among the hundreds of thousands of cases involving artwork looted by the Nazis the story of Gustav Klimt’s “Adele Bloch-Bauer I” would particularly appeal to filmmakers. For one, there is the mesmerizing gold-flecked painting itself, which set a record price of $135 million when it was sold in 2006. Then there is the David-and-Goliath tale featuring a feisty octogenarian heroine — Ms. Bloch-Bauer’s niece Maria Altmann — taking on a recalcitrant Austrian government. And finally there is the satisfying conclusion. Ms. Altmann gets the portrait back. Justice prevails.

headline: Review: Missy Mazzoli’s Unsettling ‘Vespers for a New Dark Age’
text: The composer and keyboardist  Missy Mazzoli has a thing for unlikely connections and startling gestures, and one of her gifts is the ability to tease out the hidden logic behind her choices. Her ravishing, unsettling album “Vespers for a New Dark Age” unfolds as a meditation on technology and spirituality, alienation and self-interest. Its ominous but propulsive score ranges from the chamber-operatic to the electronic and semiabstract.

headline: Boy Locked in Manhattan Restroom With Mother Later Dies
text: A 1-year-old boy whose mother locked herself in a restroom with him at a restaurant in Midtown Manhattan on Monday was declared dead at Bellevue Hospital Center, where he was taken after workers who unlocked the door found him unconscious and foaming at the mouth, the police said.

headline: Review: Sufjan Stevens’s Quietly Moving ‘Carrie & Lowell’
text: A hushed, intent Sufjan Stevens contemplates death, grief, family and memory on his quietly moving new album, “Carrie & Lowell,” in songs that entwine autobiography and archetype. The music is restrained and meticulous, all graceful melodies, plucked strings and shimmery keyboard tones. But ungovernable circumstances and emotions course through the lyrics.

headline: Obama’s Passport Data Leaked in Australian Email Blunder
text: WASHINGTON — The government of Australia accidentally disclosed personal information about President Obama and 30 other world leaders who traveled there last fall for a summit meeting, according to a report on Monday in The Guardian.

headline: Enterovirus 68 May Be Linked to Paralysis in Children, Study Says
text: A new strain of a common respiratory virus may be responsible for partly paralyzing scores of children nationwide, researchers reported on Monday.

headline: Labor’s $15 Wage Strategy
text: Ebony Hughes works two jobs and still struggles to make ends meet. She is an example of the kind of worker that organizers are trying to galvanize under the banner of civil rights to raise wages.

headline: Movement to Increase McDonald’s Minimum Wage Broadens Its Tactics
text: ATLANTA — On a recent Friday, Kwanza Brooks, a $7.25-an-hour McDonald’s worker, climbed into a 14-person van to take a four-hour ride from Charlotte, N.C., to Atlanta.

headline: Teenager Faces Charges After Mocking Singapore’s Founding Father on YouTube
text: The Singaporean police confirmed on Monday that a teenage video blogger was arrested a day earlier for an obscenity-laced tirade posted on YouTube that celebrated the death of Lee Kuan Yew, the country’s founding father, and disparaged Christians.

headline: Thoughts at the End of the Road, and a Word of Advice
text: ALL roads end, and now we come to the end of this one.

headline: Heated Words as Iran Deadline Nears
Prosecutors Scrutinize Minority Borrowers’ Auto Loans
text: Minority borrowers were once starved for credit through redlining — banks’ refusal to provide mortgages in their communities.

headline: Detroit Group Calls for Overhaul of Schools
text: A coalition of Detroit’s leaders called on Monday for sweeping changes to the city’s educational system, including an end to emergency management of the troubled public schools, the transfer of the system’s financial debt to the state, and creation of a commission to oversee the opening and closing of schools in the city.

headline: Climate Change Threatens to Kill Off More Aspen Forests by 2050s, Scientists Say
text: The beloved aspen forests that shimmer across mountainsides of the American West could be doomed if emissions of greenhouse gases continue at a high level, scientists warned on Monday. That finding adds to a growing body of work suggesting forests worldwide may be imperiled by climate change.

headline: Jeb Bush Defends Indiana’s Religious Beliefs Law
text: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida weighed in Monday on the debate that has engulfed Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana over a new religious freedom law in the state that critics are calling legalized discrimination.

headline: N.C.A.A. Steps Up Pressure Over New Indiana Law
text: While Indiana’s legislature and governor said Monday that they would clarify a new law that critics say could condone discrimination against gay people, the Indianapolis-based N.C.A.A., days before the Final Four was set to begin in Indianapolis, left the door open to moving future events and its own headquarters.

headline: Lauren Smithson,  Manfred Philogene
text: Lauren Elizabeth Smithson and Manfred Joseph Philogene were married Friday at Carlyle on the Green, an events space in Farmingdale, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Jerome D. Taylor, a Lutheran minister, officiated.

headline: Miriam Bienstock, Co-Founder of Atlantic Records, Dies at 92
text: Miriam Bienstock, a co-founder of Atlantic Records who ran the business side of the company in its formative years, helping to lay the groundwork for what became a colossus of the recording industry, died on March 21 at her home in Manhattan. She was 92.

headline: Religious Protection Laws, Once Called Shields, Are Now Seen as Cudgels
text: When the federal government adopted a religious protection act in 1993, same-sex marriage was not on the horizon.

headline: Robert Hite, 95, Survivor of Doolittle Raid and Japanese Imprisonment, Dies
text: Lt. Col. Robert L. Hite, the last survivor among eight crewmen who were captured by the Japanese when American bombers brought World War II home to Japan in Jimmy Doolittle’s daring air raid in 1942, died on Sunday in Nashville. He was 95.

headline: As U.S. and Iran Seek Nuclear Deal, Saudi Arabia Makes Its Own Moves
text: CAIRO — As America talks to Iran, Saudi Arabia is lashing out against it.

headline: House Provision Offers Doctors More Protection Against Malpractice Suits
text: WASHINGTON — A little-noticed provision of a bill passed by the House of Representatives with overwhelming bipartisan support would provide doctors new protections against medical malpractice lawsuits.

headline: Witnesses, Who Say Police Killed Activist, Are to Be Charged in Egypt
text: CAIRO — Egyptian prosecutors are bringing criminal charges against witnesses who said they saw the police kill an unarmed poet and activist during a demonstration, a lawyer who has seen the charges said on Monday.

headline: Prosecution in Boston Marathon Trial Closes With Raw Details of Killings
text: BOSTON — The government’s case against Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the admitted Boston Marathon bomber, ended Monday where it began, with a raw, wrenching account of the carnage wrought nearly two years ago by Mr. Tsarnaev on Boylston Street.

headline: Defense Witness Places Different Suspect in Etan Patz’s Apartment
text: After weeks of trying to link a convicted child molester to the 1979 disappearance of Etan Patz, defense lawyers for Pedro Hernandez called a witness on Monday who placed the molester inside the Patzes’ SoHo apartment.

headline: Arizona Governor Vetoes Bill to Shield Police Names
text: PHOENIX — With just hours left before a midnight deadline, Gov. Doug Ducey of Arizona vetoed legislation on Monday that would have prevented law enforcement agencies from releasing the names of officers involved in serious or fatal shootings for 60 days.

headline: Virginia: Suit Seeks to Prevent College From Closing
text: State authorities filed suit Monday to block the closing of Sweet Briar College, giving a boost to alumnae and faculty who are fighting to save the 114-year-old women’s liberal arts institution near rural Amherst. The Amherst County attorney, Ellen Bowyer, argued in court filings that she has jurisdiction to sue on behalf of the state, and said shutting down Sweet Briar would violate the will of its founder, Indiana Fletcher Williams, who in 1901 bequeathed her former plantation for the purpose of educating young women to be “useful members of society.” A college spokeswoman had no immediate comment.

headline: UConn Women Trail at Halftime but Surge to Another Final Four
text: ALBANY — Connecticut’s steamroller of a women’s basketball team met a head-on challenge for one half on Monday night but ultimately went merrily on its way to another Final Four, undented and undaunted.

headline: Shopping for Yacht? New York Budget Offers a Tax Break
text: Of the thousands of items packed into Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s $150 billion budget for New York State, one in particular seemed to float to the top: a tax credit for buyers of luxury boats.

headline: Obama, Last Election Behind Him, Plans First Visit as President to Kenya
text: WASHINGTON — For years, Kenya has been a political headache for President Obama and a geopolitical headache for the United States. But now in his seventh year in office, with his last election behind him, Mr. Obama has decided to embrace his heritage by visiting the land of his father for the first time as president.

headline: Dietitians Group Negotiating to End Labeling Deal With Kraft Singles
text: The Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics said it was working with the Kraft Foods Group to end part of a deal that allowed the food company to use one of the academy’s logos on packages of Kraft Singles.

headline: 3 Injured in East Village Explosion Are Released From Hospital
text: Three of four people who were hospitalized in critical condition after an explosion and fire in the East Village last week have been released, Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Monday.

headline: Father Stays on Sideline as Georgia State’s R.J. Hunter Enters the N.B.A. Draft
text: ATLANTA — For its N.C.A.A. tournament coda, “One Shining Moment,” CBS could justify devoting an entire segment to the Hunters of Georgia State. During the first weekend alone, Ron, the coach-father, and R. J., the player-son, provided the types of images that endear the tournament to its rapt followers.

headline: Role of Illness in Germanwings Crash Raises Worry About Stigma
text: An intense focus on the role of the co-pilot’s mental illness in the Germanwings jetliner crash has raised concerns that it risks unfairly stigmatizing millions of people with mental disorders and making it less likely they will seek treatment. That, in turn, could make it even harder to identify people working in high-risk professions who pose a threat to public safety.

headline: Intersection | Seoul, South Korea
text: In the Hongdae neighborhood of Seoul, Mina Kwon, an illustrator, says her style is influenced by hip-hop and androgyny.

headline: Fancy, Evasive Language
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — An easy theme today, perhaps to help us ease our way back into solving after the exciting weekend in Stamford, Conn., at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. If you want to watch a video clip that will have you on the edge of your seat, check out the last moments of the A Division finals below, provided by Ben Zimmer.

headline: Cuomo Gets Timely New York Budget but Pays Price
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo started his second term with a zeal to address broad societal problems like income inequality, faltering public schools and waning trust in the criminal justice system.

headline: An Anxious Wait in Syrian City Held by Insurgents
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Residents of the northern Syrian provincial capital of Idlib are waiting anxiously to learn who will govern them, and how, after Islamist insurgent groups hoisted their flags over the city last weekend.

headline: Nigeria’s Presidential Race Stretches to Another Day
text: KANO, Nigeria — The most competitive presidential race ever in Africa’s largest democracy continued to play out late into Monday night, with the incumbent president facing a tough challenge as voting results poured in from distant states in this crowded and chaotic land.

headline: Lawyer Asks Judge to Vacate Conviction in 2003 Killing of Fairfield Student
text: A lawyer for John Giuca, convicted of the 2003 killing of a Fairfield University student athlete, filed a motion on Monday asking a judge to vacate Mr. Giuca’s murder conviction.

headline: Chris Mullin Is Set to Lead St. John’s Again, but This Time as a Rookie Coach
text: His floppy hair, puckered mouth and timeless shooting stroke captivated New York City and the Big East Conference in the early 1980s. Now, 30 years later, Chris Mullin will return to St. John’s as the coach of the men’s basketball team, according to a person with knowledge of the agreement.

headline: A Trial Partnership for 2 Jewish Cultural Institutions in New York
text: Two Jewish cultural organizations in New York City — one in need of a permanent home and the other in a quest for more visitors — have agreed to join forces.

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Recap: A Chimp With a Machine Gun
text: Season 1, Episode 9: “Pimento”

headline: Old, New and Unusual Alliances in the Middle East

headline: Mets Owner Fred Wilpon Is Making Good on His Promise to Be More Engaged With the Team

headline: Replace a Legend? These Yankees Did
text: The Yankees are in transition again — the tricky transition of replacing a revered player. Bob Sheppard’s recorded voice will not intone, “Num-bah 2, Der-ek Jee-tah, Num-bah 2” this season. Didi Gregorius, obtained in an off-season trade, is the new shortstop. But because the Yankees have had so many revered players in winning a record 27 World Series, they have had to manage this transition every so often.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
text: 11 P.M. (Spike) CON AIR (1997) Cameron Poe (Nicolas Cage) kills a man with his fists while defending his pregnant wife (Monica Potter). In court, a judge says that because he is a United States Army Ranger veteran he is a deadly weapon, and sentences him to 7 to 10 years in prison. When it comes time for him to return home, he finds himself the only good man on a flight full of villainous convicts, played by Ving Rhames, Danny Trejo, Steve Buscemi and others. Led by Cyrus the Virus (John Malkovich), the convicts plan to hijack the plane. Cameron must prevent the hijacking so he can get home to his wife and daughter on her seventh birthday. “As directed by Simon West and written wryly by Scott Rosenberg (“Beautiful Girls”), ‘Con Air’ is a simple setup followed by endless stunts,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times.

headline: What Family Traditions Do You Want to Carry On When You Get Older?
text: When we’re children, family traditions often just happen to us. We eat, we sing, we get dressed up, often without much choice in the matter. But when we get older and make our own families, we can get the opportunity to decide what traditions we want to carry on as adults, whether holiday meals on Thanksgiving or Christmas, family summer camping trips or coming-of-age celebrations such as quinceañeras.

headline: ‘The Contender,’ a Biography of Andrew Cuomo
text: Andrew Cuomo is not running for president. Not in 2016 — since the governor of New York is not about to throw himself in front of the freight train that is Hillary Clinton — and possibly not ever. Indeed, bypassing a White House bid would most likely be less a political than a personal calculation for Cuomo. “He is the uncommon elected official with a streak of misanthropy,” Jeffrey Toobin of The New Yorker recently wrote about him. Or as a former Cuomo aide told Toobin: “Andrew will not run for president. He’d have to talk to too many people.”

headline: How ‘You Do You’ Perfectly Captures Our Narcissistic Culture
text: You will recall the fable of the Scorpion and the Frog. The Scorpion needs a ride across the river. The waters are rising on account of climate change, or perhaps he has been priced out of his burrow, who knows? The exact reason is lost in the fog of pre-­modernity. The Frog is afraid that the Scorpion will sting him, but his would-­be passenger reassures him that they would both die if that happened. That would be crazy. Sure enough, halfway across, the Scorpion stings the Frog. Just before they drown, the Scorpion says, “Aren’t you going to ask why I did that?” And the Frog croaks, “You do you.”

headline: Rory McIlroy Has the Best Swing in Golf
text: Even before Rory McIlroy could walk, he was envisioning the shots of his dreams. The story has been related to him countless times: how back in the early 1990s, his father, Gerry, then a bar manager at the local golf club in Holywood, County Down, Northern Ireland, would put his 18-month-old son — in his father’s daily care while his mother, Rosie, a night-shift worker at a nearby 3M plant, slept — in a pram and wheel him a half-mile or so from the McIlroys’ small, red-brick house on Belfast Road to the club, its 18-hole course on the outskirts of Belfast nestled into a tiered wooded hillside. When his day shift ended, Gerry, an avid golfer, would bring his son out to the range, set his pram just behind the practice tee and swat out buckets of balls before his transfixed toddler.

headline: In Treatment, but in Which Language?
text: I have a psychotherapy practice in Madrid, but I often receive email requests for counseling from people in other parts of the world, since I also practice psychotherapy online, via Skype, in several languages: English, French, Italian and Russian. Alex’s email looked like spam, and I nearly deleted it. He wrote in an abrupt English, with neither a greeting nor a sign-off. When I read more closely, I saw that he was seeking therapy, though he didn’t say much else. In his brevity I sensed hesitation, a shade of doubt.

headline: Morning Agenda: Auto Loans to Minorities Under Scrutiny
text: AUTO LOANS TO MINORITIES UNDER SCRUTINY | The Justice Department’s civil rights division is examining whether auto dealerships are steering minority borrowers to the most expensive loans, a practice known as reverse redlining, Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. In particular, the federal authorities are looking at whether “dealer markups,” in which dealers add additional interest onto a borrower’s loan, are being used to charge minority customers higher rates than white borrowers with similar credit profiles.

headline: Meatpacking District’s Next Act Includes an Influx of Office Space and More

headline: Fleeting Stability for a Woman Charged With Killing Her Son

No more sitting on her stoop on the Lower East Side of Manhattan at 2 a.m., sipping from a bottle. No more marijuana and cocaine. No more of the violence that sent her to Rikers Island and no more of the turmoil that landed her in the files of New York City’s child welfare agency.

headline: 1890: Misery in Rome
text: ROME — A group of pale men surrounded two rude graves in  today [March 28], and tenderly laid clumsy laurel wreaths upon them. Thirteen months ago there were riots in Rome. Hundreds of workingmen demanded the means of life. The King’s troops poured around them, a bristling sea of steel. Over two hundred prisoners were taken. Next day, all were released but thirty-four. These men have been in the prison ever since, and were only tried this week. Twenty-nine were declared innocent after more than a year’s suffering. In the meantime two of the poor fellows died and the men who crowned their dust today were the released prisoners. — The New York Herald, European Edition, April 1, 1890

headline: Not an Adoption Diary. Yet.

Evy’s a difficult burper, to say the least; no matter how much we rub and pat her back or put her down and pick her up, she rarely lets out a burp, no matter how much she wants to. So as I walked her around the house, rubbing her back, I said a sentence I never thought I’d say in my life:

And in my pantry, there’s a bag of very pale green dried flageolet beans; this early spring stew is a perfect home for them.

headline: Belarus Free Theater Returns to New York With ‘Trash Cuisine’
text: The Belarus Free Theater troupe, banned from its homeland for its politically charged works, will be returning to New York this spring with the American premiere of the original play “Trash Cuisine.” The work addresses capital punishment and opens on April 29 at La MaMa’s Ellen Stewart Theater. It runs through May 17.

headline: 2004: Hillary Clinton’s D.N.C. Speech
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton introduced her husband, former president Bill Clinton, at the Democratic National Convention held in Boston in July 2004.

headline: U.S. Dance Troupes to Tour Overseas
text: In 1954, the Limón Dance Company was one of the first American dance troupes to be sent on a government-sponsored tour, to South America, under a new cultural diplomacy directive from President Dwight D. Eisenhower. Now the company will once again assume the role of cultural ambassador. On Tuesday, the Limón company was announced as one of three companies selected for the fifth iteration of DanceMotion USA, an initiative of the State Department, produced in partnership with the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Joining the Limón company are Dance Heginbotham and Bodytraffic, a Los Angeles troupe.

headline: Verizon Wireless Customers Can Now Opt Out of ‘Supercookies’
text: Verizon Wireless customers now have the ability to completely opt out of the phone carrier’s controversial ad-targeting program that tagged users with undeletable tracking codes, which critics called “supercookies.”

headline: Charter’s Deal May Not Be the Last Word on Bright House
text: The United States cable puzzle is starting to take shape. None of the pieces is a snug fit just yet, though.

headline: Exercise Beats Vitamin D for Injury Prevention
text: Exercise and vitamin D supplements may help prevent injurious falls in older adults, a randomized trial found.

headline: Angel Investors Lend Expertise as Well as Cash
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Like many tech entrepreneurs, Joshua Reeves says he thinks his company can change the world. It may do it, too — with the way it was financed, as much as by the product itself.

headline: New York Times Develops an Apple Watch App
text: The New York Times said on Tuesday that it had developed an app to provide brief news reports for the Apple watch when it is released next month.

headline: Small Plates Grow Up
text: We live in a messy revolutionary period for restaurants. The old rules for going out to eat, under which Mom and Dad ambled down a predictable path from appetizer to main course to dessert, with Mom pausing halfway through dinner to ask about Dad’s veal chop, were repealed some time ago. In place of rules, we got small plates, and anarchy. The last decade has been the era of messy tables, of gonzo pacing, of menus that came with a spoken introduction, of senseless plating, of endless instructions to share dishes that collapsed into rubble when you tried.

headline: Clinton Team Nabs McAuliffe Adviser to Focus on Iowa
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton appears determined to put to rest questions about whether she will aggressively compete in the Iowa caucuses.

headline: What’s the First Thing You Should Do When You Get into College?
text: Defer.

headline: A New Exhibition Memorializes the Madness of Jean Paul Gaultier
text: The Grand Palais in Paris will celebrate Jean Paul Gaultier this spring with an extensive show featuring 175 haute couture designs, select ready-to-wear pieces and, of course, Madonna’s iconic cone bra — all presented on mannequins topped with dramatic wigs by the hairstylist Odile Gilbert. Along with sketches, film costumes, famous red-carpet looks and videos (including clips from “Eurotrash,” the talk show Gaultier co-hosted in the ’90s), there will be a section showcasing the former Hermès creative director’s rich corsetry, and a hi-tech installation that projects his ensembles onto visitors so that, says the curator Thierry-Maxime Loriot, “everyone can be a Gaultier model.”

headline: Saudi Arabia’s Ominous Reach Into Yemen
text: The Saudi-led military intervention in Yemen threatens to turn what has been a civil war between competing branches of Islam into a wider regional struggle involving Iran. It could also destroy any hope of stability in Yemen. Even before the Saudis and their Arab allies started the bombing, Yemen was in severe distress; on Tuesday, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights warned that it is now on the brink of collapse.

headline: AshLeigh2
text: tk

headline: Iraqi Claims That ‘Tikrit Has Fallen’ Is Disputed
text: BAGHDAD — The prime minister of Iraq claimed that his country’s security forces had reached the center of Tikrit on Tuesday. A subtitle crawling across TV screens tuned to the official Iraqiya television network went further: “Tikrit has fallen to us,” it said. On YouTube, an Iraqi flag was shown flying atop a downtown government building.

headline: Blithe Spirit
text: A true aesthete with a taste for imperfection, Victoria Press creates her decorating masterpiece — frayed carpets and all — in a storied London townhouse.

headline: Recipes for Health: Passover
text: Recipes for Passover.

headline: Campaign Finance Complaints Filed Against 4 Presidential Hopefuls
text: WASHINGTON — For months, White House hopefuls from both parties have been raising millions in unlimited contributions at upscale fund-raisers from Manhattan to Palm Springs, Calif. — all without officially declaring themselves candidates and becoming subject to federal caps on contributions.

headline: Obama Rejects Republican Bid to Overturn New Union Rules
text: WASHINGTON — In his latest confrontation with Congress, President Obama on Tuesday blocked Republican efforts to overturn new union-friendly federal regulations issued by his administration.

headline: Obama Removes Weapons Freeze Against Egypt
text: WASHINGTON — Seeking to repair relations with a longtime ally at a time of spreading war in the Middle East, President Obama on Tuesday lifted an arms freeze against Egypt that he had first imposed after the military overthrow of the country’s democratically elected government nearly two years ago.

headline: Old Hat
text: The baseball cap is ubiquitous but not anonymous; with a tilt of the bill or a curve of the brim, it communicates a definite point of view.

headline: Marcus Samuelsson’s Latest Venture: Streetbird
text: Headliner

headline: AshLeigh2
text: tk

headline: Soho House Lets the Public In With Turkish Baths
text: Soho House, the members-only social club that began in London and has since built additional outposts around England and the United States (plus one in Berlin), opens the doors of its newest location, in Istanbul, next month. The venue was constructed in a 19th-century mansion, Palazzo Corpi, which housed the U.S. Embassy for 100 years (until 2003) and was originally built as a home for a wealthy shipbuilder, Ignazio Corpi. The property’s original Italian frescoes and marble floors remain intact.

headline: AshLeigh McHale’s Wishes
text: Ms. McHale’s document.

headline: Investing Early On for Insights, Not Profits
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The small office on the edge of the financial district here serves as a kind of listening post for a giant Spanish bank.

headline: Jets to Stay in Florham Park for Training Camp
text: Following a leaguewide trend, the Jets announced Tuesday that they would hold training camp at their headquarters in Florham Park, N.J.

headline: Karly Koch’s “Voicing My Choices”
text: Karly Koch’s document.

headline: How Lauren Weller Sidorowicz Wanted to Be Remembered
text: Lauren Weller Sidorowicz’s wishes.

headline: 1993: A Healthcare Reform P.S.A.
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton, in a public service announcement released while she was first lady, outlined proposed reforms to the healthcare system.

headline: South Carolina, Once a Doormat, Is Now a Step From a Final
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Aleighsa Welch wore a basketball net around her neck like treasured family jewelry as she stood in the locker room Sunday afternoon at the Greensboro Coliseum. South Carolina had just defeated Florida State, 80-74, to advance to the Final Four of the women’s N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time in program history. Welch was savoring the moment — until a giddy teammate ran over and asked her for the net they had just cut down in celebration.

headline: Republican Abolishment Threats? Just ‘Politics,’ I.R.S. Chief Says
text: The demolition of the Internal Revenue Service — a perennial punching bag for many conservatives – has become a rallying cry for Republicans who are thinking about running for president in 2016.

headline: Making Mac and Cheese Without a Recipe
text: Amanda Hesser and Merrill Stubbs of Food52 show you how to make macaroni and cheese without a recipe.

headline: Blue Note Jazz Festival to Mark Fifth Anniversary With a Wide-Ranging Lineup
text: The Blue Note Jazz Festival will celebrate its fifth anniversary in June, with headliners including the pop-R&B singer Natalie Cole, the blues legend Buddy Guy and the venerable South African jazz pianist Abdullah Ibrahim. The festival runs all month long with shows at a handful of venues in Manhattan; details are at bluenotejazzfestival.com.

headline: Small Plates Grow Up
text: The shrunken-portions revolution has won, as top chefs enter the fray and start shaping the new rules of dining.

headline: Nasdaq Builds Nursery for Start-Ups
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The Nasdaq OMX Group has long courted technology companies as they seek to go public.

headline: Food For Thought
text: I once had a conversation with some Times people about reader interests, which are something the paper knows much more about than it did in the pre-digital age. And what they said, ruefully, was that what readers really seem to care about is food — sure, they may email a hard-hitting column or a revelatory piece of investigative reporting, but the sure-fire stuff is about eating (and health, and using animal training techniques on your husband).

headline: Religious Freedom and Political Lies in Indiana
text: One of the most popular rejoinders to the charge that so-called “religious freedom” laws, such as the one enacted last week in Indiana, are little more than vehicles for anti-gay discrimination is that no one ever uses them to discriminate.

headline: Japanese Fabric, Illustrated
text: From a series for T in which the artist Leanne Shapton makes new artworks from pictures in old books.

headline: Review: ‘The Lizzie Borden Chronicles,’ a Lifetime Series Starring Christina Ricci
text: What, you ask, became of Lizzie? Turns out she stayed very busy. Call the cops, alert the warden. No one’s safe around this Borden.

headline: What You Get For ... $1,695,000
text: This week’s offerings include a log house in California, Southwestern style in Arizona and an 1844 house in Georgia.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Quantity Time Begets Quality Time, and Parents Spend Enough of Both
text: The “quality, not quantity” trope about the time parents spend with children has been around for decades. It’s a good one, when it helps parents (particularly mothers) to release their guilt about not spending “Little House on the Prairie” amounts of time with their children. New research, well described by Brigid Schulte in The Washington Post, supports the idea that such maternal omnipresence isn’t necessary for children. “In fact, it appears the sheer amount of time parents spend with their kids between the ages of 3 and 11 has virtually no relationship to how children turn out, and a minimal effect on adolescents, according to the first large-scale longitudinal study of parent time to be published in April in the Journal of Marriage and Family,” she writes. “The finding includes children’s academic achievement, behavior and emotional well-being.”

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Pennsylvania Roots
text: While the future Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton grew up in Illinois, her family ties are in many ways stronger in Scranton, Pa.

headline: After Horror in Libya, Christians’ Grief in an Egyptian Village
text: When Islamic State militants in Libya killed 21 Egyptian Christians, Jonathan Rashad went to the village many called home to understand the impact.

headline: Review: ‘Don Carlo’ Gets a Gripping Revival at the Met Opera
text: A solid cast with no weak links and a probing conductor. That’s what it takes, even more than superlative individual performances, for the profundity of Verdi’s “Don Carlo” to come through. That’s what the Metropolitan Opera’s revival offered on Monday when the director Nicholas Hytner’s 2010 production, which combines traditional and contemporary imagery and was last seen here in 2013, returned to the house.

headline: OAS, Brazilian Engineering Company, Seeks Bankruptcy Protection
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The corruption scandal  surrounding the petroleum giant Petrobras of Brazil has claimed another victim: The country’s third-largest engineering and construction company, OAS, requested a bankruptcy court’s protection on Tuesday.

headline: Review: Alt-J at Madison Square Garden
text: Cryptic with a crisp beat: That’s how Alt-J keeps its songs, letting listeners choose how much to decipher and how much to enjoy more simply. It’s a strategy the band probably learned from Radiohead; Alt-J also shares Radiohead’s broad but particular eclecticism and now its arena-sized audiences. On Monday night, Alt-J sold out Madison Square Garden. (On Apple keyboards, Alt-J produces the symbol for delta, used in equations to represent change.)

headline: Law Schools and Industry Show Signs of Life, Despite Forecasts of Doom
text: Law school enrollment has plummeted to the lowest level in decades. If a bottom has been reached, is now a good time to go to law school?

headline: Review: ‘American Odyssey,’ a New NBC Series, Stars Anna Friel
text: Casting directors are the quartermasters of the TV and movie industries — there’s not a lot of glory or recognition for their work, but it’s vital nonetheless.

headline: Court in Turkey Acquits Military Officers of Trying to Overthrow Government
text: ISTANBUL — An Istanbul court on Tuesday acquitted 236 military officers who had been convicted of trying to overthrow the government after the prosecutor said that evidence in the case had been forged.

headline: Review: Paul Lewis and Lisa Batiashvili, Recital Partners at Alice Tully Hall
text: Paul Lewis, the Liverpudlian pianist renowned for his solo Beethoven and Schubert, is fastidious in his choice of recital partners. His work with the tenor Mark Padmore has been a recent touchstone in Schubert’s lieder cycles. In piano duets, his steady temperament has beautifully complemented artists like Imogen Cooper and Steven Osborne.

headline: Strikes in Argentina Bring Transportation to Standstill
text: BUENOS AIRES — The taut political climate in Argentina came under new strain on Tuesday as strikes by transportation workers and others brought the country to a halt.

headline: The False Hope of a Limited Government, Built on Tax Breaks
text: In the early years of the Reagan Revolution, Senator Robert Packwood, then the powerful Republican chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, offered a robust — if unusual — defense of the tax exclusion for employer-provided health insurance: It prevented the government from getting bigger.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Nigeria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Nigeria, the United States, the Netherlands and Germany.

headline: U.S. Delays Deportation of Salvadoran Ex-Official Accused in ’80s Killings
text: After a 16-year legal battle, the Obama administration has received court approval to deport a former defense minister of El Salvador accused of participating in human rights abuses by his troops when he was a top military commander in the 1980s.

headline: Where Wall Street and Silicon Valley Intersect
text: Entrepreneurs and venture capitalists try to resist Wall Street’s entreaties, but a new relationship has lead to new fund-raising methods.

headline: Obama Commutes Long Sentences of 22 Drug Offenders
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama commuted the prison sentences of 22 people on Tuesday, part of an effort to correct a disparity among inmates who received lengthy sentences under laws passed during the crack epidemic of the 1980s and ’90s.

headline: March 31, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Nigeria, India, the United States and the Netherlands.

headline: Review: ‘Woman in Gold’ Stars Helen Mirren in Tug of War Over Artwork
text: “Woman in Gold” rests heavily on the squared shoulders of Helen Mirren, whose character, Maria Altmann, is a proud, elderly Austrian Jewish woman who fled the Nazi scourge to settle in California. Reawakened to the past by the death of her sister, at whose 1998 funeral she is first observed, Maria wages a protracted legal battle to regain possession of a priceless canvas stolen from her family by the Nazis 60 years earlier.

headline: Orbital Publishing Accused of Fraud in Selling Subscriptions
text: Top prosecutors in several states accused an Oregon company on Tuesday of overcharging consumers for subscriptions to newspapers, magazines and other periodicals.

headline: Review: In Hal Hartley’s ‘Ned Rifle,’ Closure for a Son and a Series
text: Hal Hartley is no longer as dominant a figure in independent cinema as he was in the 1990s, when his deadpan humor was a mainstay in art-house theaters. His magnum opus remains “Henry Fool” (1998), whose title character (Thomas Jay Ryan), a rogue with a criminal past, inspires Simon Grim (James Urbaniak), a garbage man in Woodside, Queens, to write poetry. As a poet, Simon finds worldwide success.

headline: Plan to Keep 1,700 RadioShack Stores Open Is Approved
text: A bankruptcy judge gave his blessing on Tuesday to a plan that would keep about 1,700 RadioShack stores open, saying he would approve the plan over a higher cash bid that would probably have liquidated the retailer but raised more money for its creditors.

headline: Supreme Court Weighs Overruling a 1964 Patent Decision
text: WASHINGTON — The dispute before the Supreme Court on Tuesday concerned a toy made up of a glove with a valve and a canister of pressurized foam. It was designed, Marvel Enterprises told the court in its brief, “to evoke Spider-Man, Marvel’s iconic superhero renowned for his spider superpowers and web-slinging.”

headline: John Krasinski vs. Anna Kendrick
text: In this exclusive clip from the new Spike TV show, “Lip Sync Battle,” John Krasinski and Anna Kendrick compete for the top spot.

headline: Living in Peekskill, N.Y.
text: The city in northwest Westchester County is being discovered by those looking for housing bargains and a reasonable commute.

headline: Player Ratings: Switzerland (1) vs. United States (1)
text: Another game, another late goal for the United States national team, which tied Switzerland, 1-1, on Tuesday in Zurich.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Planet of the Apes’
text: A scene from “Planet of the Apes,” with Charlton Heston.

headline: Etan Patz’s Mother Testifies at Murder Trial
text: Julie Patz, the mother of Etan Patz, the 6-year-old boy who disappeared while walking to his school bus stop in 1979, testified on Tuesday that she did not recall the man whom defense lawyers for Pedro Hernandez cast as an alternate suspect in the boy’s death as having ever been in her apartment.

headline: On Spike TV, Celebrities Clash Where Everyone Can Watch Their Lips Move
text: John Krasinski was driving on Route 101 to Los Angeles with some friends about two years ago when the global beats of Lionel Richie’s “All Night Long (All Night)” took over the car. The actor and comedian, known for playing Jim Halpert on “The Office,” grabbed an air microphone and started lip syncing.

headline: Just Don’t Call Them Bling
text: Gold watches are catching on with a street-smart crowd.

headline: This Will Get ‘The Lonely Goatherd’ Out of Your Head
text: An Editorial Observer piece I wrote on Monday suggested that the 1965 movie “The Sound of Music” could be improved upon, as recent theatrical revivals of Rodgers and Hammerstein musicals have been. My point was that by removing some of the Hollywood artificial sweetener, and perhaps darkening and deepening the themes already in the text, a more satisfying, more human, less mockable musical might result.

headline: Syracuse to Drop Fossil Fuel Stocks From Endowment
text: Syracuse University is dropping all fossil fuel stocks from its endowment, the university announced on Tuesday.

headline: A Conversation With Veronica Mainetti of the Sorgente Group of America
text: Ms. Mainetti, 36, is president of the Sorgente Group of America, one of three holding companies of the Sorgente Group of Rome, which is run by her father, Valter Mainetti, the majority shareholder and chief executive.

headline: A President’s Best Friend
text: A brief history of presidential pets, from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Barack Obama.

headline: Scott Walker, Allergic to Dogs, May Run Against Political History
text: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin and his wife, Tonette, had planned to spend a recent Friday night at the Nashua home of Jennifer Horn, the New Hampshire Republican chairwoman.

headline: Activist Links More Than 26,000 Twitter Accounts to ISIS
text: A cybersecurity activist who recently helped publicize 9,200 Twitter accounts that were said to be linked to the Islamic State released a roster of 26,382 accounts on Tuesday, the biggest such list yet.

headline: A President’s Best Friend
text: A brief history of presidential pets, from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Barack Obama.

headline: Recent Commercial Transactions
text: RECENT SALE

headline: Buhari Supporters Celebrate in Nigeria
text: Supporters of the former military ruler, Muhammadu Buhari, celebrated his victory over the incumbent, Goodluck Jonathan, in the presidential election on Tuesday.

headline: Gary Dahl, Inventor of the Pet Rock, Dies at 78
text: It was a craze to rival the Hula-Hoop, and even less explicable. For a mere three dollars and 95 cents, a consumer could buy ... a rock — a plain, ordinary, egg-shaped rock of the kind one could dig up in almost any backyard.

headline: Etsy Sets Price Range for Its I.P.O.
text: Etsy, the online marketplace beloved by makers of handmade jewelry and yoga bags, is hoping that Wall Street investors will be equally ardent fans.

headline: In Canada, Unabashed Wooing of Commercial Drones
text: OTTAWA — It didn’t take long for Canada’s transport minister to exploit the promotional possibilities of Amazon testing its drone delivery service in the country — testing that the company confirmed on Monday.

headline: GoDaddy Said to Price I.P.O. Above Expected Range
text: San Francisco — Nearly four years ago, GoDaddy was an Internet registration company with a history of risqué advertising.

headline: Group Linked to Islamic State Claims Responsibility for Tunisia Attack
text: TUNIS — A day after the Tunisian government said it had killed the orchestrator of the massacre at the National Bardo Museum and rounded up most of those involved, another group of militants declaring themselves to be members of the Islamic State operating inside Tunisia claimed responsibility for the attack and threatened more in the future.

headline: Carlos Falchi, 70, Dies; Turned Exotic Animal Skins Into Coveted Handbags
text: Carlos Falchi, a Brazilian-born accessories designer famous for his amiably rumpled, highly coveted handbags made of the skins of exotic animals, died on Friday in Durham, N.C. He was 70.

headline: Hollywood Reporter Signs Content Deal With Tencent, Chinese Online Giant
text: LOS ANGELES – Pushing to broaden its international readership – even if that means the occasional censored article — The Hollywood Reporter said on Tuesday that it had signed an expansive content deal with the Chinese online giant Tencent Holdings.

headline: Defense Rests in Boston Marathon Bombing Trial After Just 4 Witnesses
text: BOSTON — After questioning just four witnesses over five hours, the defense for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev in the Boston Marathon bombing trial rested its case on Tuesday.

headline: Silicon Valley Leaders, New to Social Issues, Come Together Over Indiana Law
text: The technology industry’s leaders have found their collective voice on a social issue in the last week, rallying with great intensity against a new Indiana law that will allow businesses, they predict, to discriminate against gay couples. The heads of Apple, Salesforce.com, Yelp and Square have all publicly criticized the law, as have some leaders from other industries.

headline: Gas Utilities Reduce Leaks of Methane, Study Finds
text: Utilities are making progress in reducing leaks from their natural gas distribution networks, a new study has found, but the industry and regulators can do more.

headline: Amazon Dash Aims to Be a Push-Button Substitute for the Supply Run
text: Amazon has built a booming business of making it easy to buy things online. It has a patented one-click ordering mechanism. It offers subscription-style services. And on Tuesday, Amazon unveiled a pilot program that allows customers to order items with the push of a single physical button.

headline: In Advertising Technology Deal, Rubicon Buys Chango
text: The advertising company Rubicon Project said on Tuesday that it had agreed to buy the Canadian start-up Chango for about $122 million, in the latest sign that the advertising technology industry is consolidating.

headline: Man in Fatal Encounter With N.S.A. Is Identified
text: The F.B.I. on Tuesday identified a man who was fatally shot by the police at the National Security Agency as Ricky Hall, 27, of Baltimore, who had a criminal record that included convictions for prostitution, theft and assault. A passenger in the vehicle that Mr. Hall was driving, Kevin Fleming, 20, also of Baltimore, remained hospitalized for gunshot wounds. Law enforcement officials said the men were picked up by a 60-year-old Baltimore man early Monday and driven to a motel in Elkridge, Md. They stole his Ford Escape and sped down a highway exit, apparently unintentionally, that is reserved for the N.S.A. Agency police shot the men as Mr. Hall drove toward a parked police car, the N.S.A. said.

headline: Tired of War, Yemeni Bloggers Say, ‘Enough’
text: As the death toll mounts in Yemen, and airstrikes make life in the capital, Sana, a nerve-racking ordeal, Yemeni bloggers continue to post firsthand dispatches on social networks, frequently tagged with the Arabic word kefaya, meaning “enough.”
